A fortiori
A fool always accuses other people; a partially wise man, himself; a wholly wise man, neither himself nor others.
A fool always finds a greater fool to admire
him.
A fool and his money are soon parted.
A fool flatters himself, a wise man flatters the fool.
A fool is often as dangerous to deal with as a knave, and always more incorrigible.

A fool knows more in his own house than a
wise man in another's.
A fool may give a wise man counsel.
A fool may make money, but it takes a wise man to spend it.
A fool may sometimes have talent, but he never has judgment.
A fool may speer

lays it to heart.
A fool's bolt is soon shot.
A fool's bolt may sometimes hit the mark.
A fool when he is silent is counted wise.

A little body often harbours a great soul.

A little is better than none.

A little more than kin, and less than kind.

All advantages are attended with disadvantages.
All are but parts of one stupendous whole / Whose body Nature is, and God the soul.
All argument will vanish before one touch of Nature.
All are not hunters that blow the horn.
All are not saints that go to church.
All are not soldiers that go to the wars.
All are not thieves that dogs bark at.
All art is great, and good, and true, only so far as it is distinctively the work of manhood in its entire and highest sense.
All balloons give up their gas in the pressure of things, and collapse in a sufficiently wretched manner erelong.
All battle is misunderstanding.
All beginnings are easy; it is the ulterior
steps that are of most difficult ascent and most rarely taken.
All cats are grey in the dark.
All censure of a man's self is oblique praise; it is in order to show how much he can spare.
All cruelty springs from weakness.
All death in nature is birth.
All deep joy has something of awful in it.
All delights are vain; but that most vain / Which, with pain purchas'd, doth inherit pain.
All destruction, by violent revolution or howsoever it be, is but new creation on a wider scale.
All disputation makes the mind deaf, and when people are deaf I am dumb.
All evil is as a nightmare; the instant you
begin to
All evils, when extreme, are the same.
All faults are properly shortcomings.
All faiths are to their own believers just / For none believe because they will, but must.
All feet tread not in one shoe.
All flesh consorteth according to its kind, and
a man will cleave to his like.
All forms of government are good, so far as the wise and kind in them govern the unwise and unkind.
All good colour is in some degree pensive, and the purest and most thoughtful minds are those which love colour the most.
All good government must begin at home.
All good has an end but the goodness of God.
All good things / Are ours, nor soul helps
flesh more now / Than flesh helps soul.
All good things go in threes.
All governments are to some extent a treaty with the Devil.
All great art is the expression of man's delight in God's work, not in his own.
All great discoveries are made by men whose feelings run ahead of their thinkings.
All great peoples are conservative.
All great song has been sincere song.
All healthy things are sweet-tempered.
All his geese are swans.
All history is an inarticulate Bible.
All immortal writers speak out of their hearts.
All imposture weakens confidence and chills benevolence.
All inmost things are melodious, naturally utter themselves in song.
All is but toys.
All is good that God sends us.
All is influence except ourselves.
All is not gold that glitters.
All is not lost that's in peril.
All live by seeming.
All living objects do by necessity form to themselves a skin.
Allmächtig ist doch das Gold; auch Mohren
kann's bleichen
All mankind love a lover.
All man's miseries go to prove his greatness.
All martyrdoms looked mean when they were suffered.
All measures of reformation are effective in proportion to their timeliness.
All men are bores except when we want them.
All men are born sincere and die deceivers.
All men are fools, and with every effort they differ only in the degree.
All men commend patience, though few be willing to practise it.
All men have their price.
All men honour love, because it looks up, and
not down.
All men, if they work not as in the great taskmaster's eye, will work wrong.
All men live by truth, and stand in need of expression.
All men may dare what has by man been done.
All men that are ruined are ruined on the side of their natural propensities.
All men think all men mortal but themselves.
All men would be masters of others, and no man is lord of himself.
All men who know not where to look for truth, save in the narrow well of self, will find their own image at the bottom and mistake it for what they are seeking.
All minds quote. Old and new make up the warp and woof of every moment.
All mischief comes from our inability to be alone.
All money is but a divisible title-deed.
All my possessions for a moment of time!
All nature is but art unknown to thee. / All chance, direction which thou canst not see. / All discord, harmony not understood; / All partial evil, universal good.
All nobility in its beginnings was somebody's natural superiority.
All objects are as windows through which the philosophic eye looks into infinitude.
All orators are dumb when beauty pleadeth.
All our evils are imaginary, except pain of body and remorse of conscience.
All our most honest striving prospers only in unconscious moments.
All passions exaggerate; and they are passions
only because they do exaggerate.
All pleasure must be bought at the price of pain.
All power appears only in transition.
All power, even the most despotic, rests ultimately on opinion.
All power of fancy over reason is a degree of insanity.
All promise outruns performance.
All public disorder proceeds from want of work.
All speech, even the commonest, has something of song in it.
All strength lies within, not without.
All strong men love life.
All strong souls are related.
All's well that ends well.
All talent, all intellect, is in the first place moral.
All that a man has he will give for right relations with his mates.
All that glisters is not gold; / Gilded tombs do worms infold.
All that is best in the great poets of all countries
is not what is national in them, but what is universal.
All that is human must retrograde, if it do not advance.
All that is noble is in itself of a quiet nature, and appears to sleep until it is aroused and summoned forth by contrast.
All that lives must die, / Passing through nature to eternity.
All that man does and brings to pass is the vesture of a thought.
All that mankind has done, thought, gained,
or been, it is all lying in magic preservation in the pages of books.
All that tread the globe are but a handful to the tribes that slumber in its bosom.
All the armed prophets have conquered, all the unarmed have perished.
All the arts affecting culture
have a certain common bond, and are connected by a certain blood relationship with each other.
All the difference between the wise man and the fool is, that the wise man keeps his counsel, and the fool reveals it.
All the diseases of mind, leading to fatalest
ruin, are due to the concentration of man upon himself, whether his heavenly interests or his worldly interests, matters not.
All the faults of the man I can pardon in the player; no fault of the player can I pardon in the man.
All the good of which humanity is capable is comprised in obedience.
All the great ages have been ages of belief.
All the keys don't hang at one man's girdle.
All the makers of dictionaries, all the compilers
of opinions already printed, we may term plagiarists, but honest plagiarists, who arrogate not the merit of invention.
All the perfumes of Arabia will not sweeten this little hand.
All the pursuits of men are the pursuits of women also, and in all of them a woman is only a weaker man.
All the thinking in the world does not bring us to thought; we must be right by nature, so that good thoughts may come.
All the wit in the world is not in one head.
All the wit in the world is thrown away upon
the man who has none.
All the world's a stage / And all the men and women merely players.
All things are double, one against another. Good is set against evil, and life against death.
All things are for the sake of the good, and it is the cause of everything beautiful.
All things are in perpetual flux and fleeting.
All things are symbolical, and what we call
results are beginnings.
All things happen by necessity; in Nature there is neither good nor bad.
All things that are / Are with more spirit chased than enjoyed.
All things that love the sun are out of doors.
All this (in the daily press) does not concern one in the least; one is neither the wiser nor the better for knowing what the day brings forth.
All true men are soldiers in the same army,
to do battle against the same enemy--the empire of darkness and wrong.
All truth is not to be told at all times.
All virtue is most rewarded, and all wickedness most punished, in itself.
All went as merry as a marriage-bell.
All, were it only a withered leaf, works together with all.
All will be as God wills.
All wise men are of the same religion, and
keep it to themselves.
All women are good
All work and no play makes Jack a dull boy.
Allzugrosse Zartheit der Gefühle ist ein wahres Unglück
Allzustraff gespannt, zerspringt der Bogen
Allzuviel ist nicht genug

Al molino, ed alla sposa / Sempre manca qualche cosa
Almost all our sorrows spring out of our relations with other people.
Almsgiving never made any man poor.
A loan should come laughing home.
A l'œuvre on connaît l'artisan

Alomban és szerelemben nincs lehetetlenséej
Along the cool sequester'd vale of life / They kept the noiseless tenor of their way.

Alterum tantum
Although men are accused of not knowing their weakness, yet perhaps as few know their strength.
Although the last, not least.
Altissima quæque flumina minimo sono labuntur
Alt ist das Wort, doch bleibet hoch und wahr der Sinn
Altro diletto che' mparar, non provo
Always filling, never full.
Always have two strings to your bow.
Always strive for the whole; and if thou canst not become a whole thyself, connect thyself with a whole as a ministering member.
Always there is a black spot in our sunshine, the shadow of ourselves.
Always to distrust is an error, as well as always
to trust.
Always win fools first; they talk much, and what they have once uttered they will stick to.
Amabilis insania
A machine is not a man or a work of art; it is destructive of humanity and art.

A mad world, my masters.
A main armée
Ama l'amico tuo con il diffetto suo
A man at sixteen will prove a child at sixty.
A man belongs to his age and race, even when he acts against them.
A man, be the heavens praised, is sufficient
for himself; yet were ten men, united in love, capable of being and doing what ten thousand singly would fail in.
A man can be so changed by love as to be unrecognisable as the same person.
A man
A man can keep another's secret better than his own; a woman, her own better than another's.
A man canna wive and thrive the same year.
A man can never be too much on his guard
when he writes to the public, and never too easy towards those with whom he converses.
A man can receive nothing except it be given him from heaven.
A man cannot be in the seventeenth century and the nineteenth at one and the same moment.
A man cannot spin and reel at the same time.
A man cannot whistle and drink at the same time.
A man dishonoured is worse than dead.
A man does not represent a fraction, but a whole number; he is complete in himself.
A man hears only what he understands.
A man he was to all the country dear, / And passing rich with forty pounds a year.
A man in a farm and his thoughts away, is better out of it than in it.
A man in debt is so far a slave.
A man in the right, with God on his side, is in the majority, though he be alone.
A man is a fool or his own physician at forty.
A man is a golden impossibility.
A man is always nearest to his good when at home, and farthest from it when away.
A man is king in his own house.
A man is never happy till his vague striving has itself marked out its proper limitation.
A man is not born the second time, any more than the first, without travail.
A man is not as God, / But then most godlike being most a man.
A man is not strong who takes convulsion fits, though six men cannot hold him; only he that can walk under the heaviest weight without staggering.
A man is only a relative and a representative
nature.
A man is the façade of a temple wherein all wisdom and all good abide.
A man is the prisoner of his power.
A man lives by believing something; not by debating and arguing about many things.
A man may be proud of his house, and not ride on the rigging (ridge) of it.
A man may do what he likes with his own.
A man may smile, and smile, and be a villain.
A man may spit in his nieve and do little.
A man may survive distress, but not disgrace.
A man / More sinn'd against than sinning.
A man must ask his wife's leave to thrive.
A man must become wise at his own expense.
A man must be healthy before he can be holy.
A man must be well off who is irritated by trifles, for in misfortune trifles are not felt.
A man must carry knowledge with him if he would bring home knowledge.
A man must seek his happiness and inward
peace from objects which cannot be taken away from him.
A man must take himself for better, for worse, as his portion.
A man must thank his defects, and stand in some terror of his talents.

A man must wait for the right moment.
A man never feels the want of what it never
occurs to him to ask for.
A man never rises so high as when he knows not whither he is going.
A man of intellect without energy added to it is a failure.
A man of maxims only is like a Cyclops with one eye, and that eye in the back of his head.
A man of pleasure is a man of pains.
A man often pays dear for a small frugality.
A man of the world must seem to be what he wishes to be.
A man of wit would often be much embarrassed without the company of fools.
A man only understands what is akin to some things already in his mind.
A man places himself on a level with him whom he praises.
A man protesting against error is on the way
towards uniting himself with all men that believe in truth.
A man so various, that he seem'd to be, / Not one, but all mankind's epitome.
A man that is young in years may be old in hours, if he have lost no time.
A man used to vicissitudes is not easily dejected.
A man who cannot gird himself into harness will take no weight along these highways.
A man who claps his Pegasus into a harness,
and urges on his muse with the whip, will have to pay to Nature the penalty of this trespass.
A man who does not know rigour cannot pity either.
A man who feels that his religion is a slavery has not began to comprehend the real nature of it.
A man who has nothing to do is the devil's playfellow.
A man who is ignorant of foreign languages is ignorant of his own.
A man who reads much becomes arrogant and
pedantic; one who sees much becomes wise, sociable, and helpful.
A man will love or hate solitude--that is, his own society--according as he is himself worthy or worthless.
A man will not be observed in doing that which he can do best.
A man with half a volition goes backwards and forwards, and makes no way on the smoothest road.
A man with knowledge but without energy, is a house furnished but not inhabited; a man with energy but no knowledge, a house dwelt in but unfurnished.
A man's a man for a' that.
A man's aye crousest in his ain cause.
A man's best fortune or his worst is his wife.
A man's best things are nearest him, / Lie close about his feet.
A man's fate is his own temper.
A man's friends belong no more to him than
he to them.
A man's gift makes room for him.
A man's happiness consists infinitely more in admiration of the faculties of others than in confidence in his own.
A man's house is his castle.
A man's power is hooped in by a necessity, which, by many experiments, he touches on every side until he learns its arc.
A man's task is always light if his heart is
light.
A man's virtue is to be measured not by his extraordinary efforts, but his everyday conduct.
A man's walking is a succession of falls.
A man's wife is his blessing or his bane.

of reason and traversing its work.

Analysis is not the business of the poet. His office is to portray, not to dissect.
Analysis kills spontaneity, just as grain, once it is ground into flour, no longer springs and germinates.

An ambitious man is slave to everybody.

for the sake of a great name, broke in pieces almost half a world.

An archer is known by his aim, not by his arrows.

An army, like a serpent, goes on its belly.

should keep out of it.
An ass may bray a good while before he shakes the stars down.

on the bounties of an hour?

And e'en his failings lean'd to virtue's side.
And found no end, in wand'ring mazes lost.

And Mammon wins his way where seraphs might despair.

And then, from hour to hour, we rot and rot, / And thereby hangs a tale.

Argumentum baculinum
Argus at home, a mole abroad.
Argus-eyes
A righteous man regardeth the life of his beast, but the tender mercies of the wicked are cruel.
Aristocracy has three successive ages--of superiorities, of privileges, and of vanities; having passed out of the first, it degenerates in the second, and dies away in the third.
Arma amens capio; nec sat rationis in armis
Arma cerealia
Arm am Beutel, krank am Herzen
Arma pacis fulcra
Arma tenenti omnia dat, qui justa negat
Arma, viri, ferte arma; vocat lux ultima victos, /
Nunquam omnes hodie moriemur inulti
Armé de foi hardi
Armes blanches
Arm in Arm mit dir, / So fordr' ich mein Jahrhundert in die Schranken
Arms and the man I sing.
Armuth des Geistes Gott erfreut, / Armuth,
und nicht Armseligkeit
Armuth ist der sechste Sinn
Armuth ist die grösste Plage, / Reichtum ist das höchste Gut
Armuth ist listig, sie fängt auch einen Fuchs
Armuth und Hunger haben viel gelehrte Jünger
A rogue is a roundabout fool.
A rolling stone gathers no moss.
A Rome comment à Rome
A royal heart is often hid under a tattered coat.
Arrectis auribus adsto
Arrière pensée
Arrogance is the obstruction of wisdom.
Ars artium omnium conservatrix
Ars est celare artem
Ars est sine arte, cujus principium est mentiri, medium laborare, et finis mendicare
Ars longa, vita brevis
Ars varia vulpis, ast una echino maxima
Art does not represent things falsely, but truly as they appear to mankind.
Arte magistra
Art is a jealous mistress.
Art is long and time is fleeting, / And our
hearts, though stout and brave, / Still, like muffled drums, are beating / Funeral marches to the grave.
Art is noble, but the sanctuary of the human soul is nobler still.
Art is not the bread indeed, but it is the wine of life.
Art is simply a bringing into relief of the obscure thought of Nature.
Art is the mediatrix of the unspeakable.
Art is the path of the creator to his work.
Art is the work of man under the guidance and inspiration of a mightier power.
Artists are of three classes: those who perceive and pursue the good, and leave the evil; those who perceive and pursue the good and evil together, the whole thing as it verily is; and those who perceive and pursue the evil, and leave the good.
Artium magister
Art may err, but Nature cannot miss.
Art may make a suit of clothes, but Nature
must produce a man.
Art must anchor in nature, or it is the sport of every breath of folly.
Art must not be a superficial talent, but must begin further back in man.
Art, not less eloquently than literature, teaches her children to venerate the single eye.
Art not thou a man?
Art rests on a kind of religious sense, on a
deep, steadfast earnestness; and on this account it unites so readily with religion.
Art thou afraid of death, and dost thou wish to live for ever? Live in the whole that remains when thou hast long been gone
A rude âne rude ânier
A rusty nail, placed near the faithful compass, / Will sway it from the truth, and wreck the argosy.
A sage is the instructor of a hundred ages.
A saint abroad, a devil at home.
A saint in crape is twice a saint in lawn.
As all men have some access to primary truth, so all have some art or power of communication in the head, but only in the artist does it descend into the hand.
As a man makes his bed, so must he lie.
As a priest, or interpreter of the holy, is the noblest and highest of all men; so is a sham priest the falsest and basest.
A satirical poet is the check of the layman on
bad priests.
As a tree falls, so shall it lie.
A scalded cat dreads cauld water.
As dear to me as are the ruddy drops / That visit my sad heart.
A second Daniel.
A secret is in my custody if I keep it; but if
I blab it, it is I that am prisoner.
A self-denial no less austere than the saint's is demanded of the scholar.
As ever in my great taskmaster's eye.
As every great evil, so every excessive power wears itself out at last.
As falls the dew on quenchless sands, / Blood only serves to wash ambition's hands.
As for discontentments, they are in the politic
body like humours in the natural, which are apt to gather a preternatural heat and inflame.
As formerly we suffered from wickedness, so now we suffer from the laws.
As for murmurs, mother, we grumble a little now and then, to be sure. But there's no love lost between us.
As for talkers and futile persons, they are commonly vain and credulous withal.
As from the wing no scar the sky retains, / The parted wave no furrow from the keel; So dies in human hearts the thought of death.
As good be out of the world as out of the
fashion.
As good almost kill a man as kill a good book; who kills a man kills a reasonable creature, God's image; but he who destroys a good book kills reason itself.
As guid fish i' the sea as e'er came oot o't.
As guid may haud (hold) the stirrup as he that loups on.
A's guid that God sends.
As he alone is a good father who at table serves
his children first, so is he alone a good citizen who, before all other outlays, discharges what he owes to the state.
As he who has health is young, so he who owes nothing is rich.
A short cut is often a wrong cut.
A sicht (sight) o' you is guid for sair een.
A sick man's sacrifice is but a lame oblation.
As idle as a painted ship / Upon a painted
ocean.
A sight to dream of, not to tell.
A silent man's words are not brought into court.
A sillerless (moneyless) man gangs fast through the market.
A silver key can open an iron lock.
A simple child, / That lightly draws its breath, /
And feels its life in every limb, / What should it know of death?
A simple maiden in her flower, / Is worth a hundred coats of arms.
A simple, manly character need never make an apology.
As in a theatre, the eyes of men, / After a well-graced actor leaves the stage, / Are idly bent on him that enters next, / Thinking his prattle to be tedious.
A single grateful thought turned heavenwards is the most perfect prayer.
A single moment may transform everything.
A single word is often a concentrated poem, a little grain of pure gold, capable of being beaten out into a broad extent of gold-leaf.

Asinus asino, et sus sui pulcher

Asinus inter simias

As is the garden, such is the gardener.
As is the man, so is his God.
A sip is the most that mortals are permitted
from any goblet of delight.
Ask, and it shall be given you; seek, and ye shall find; knock, and it shall be opened to you.
Ask for the old paths, where is the good way, and walk therein.
Ask me no questions, and I'll tell you no fibs.
Ask why God made the gem so small, / And why so huge the granite? / Because God meant mankind should set / The higher value on it.
As long as any man exists, there is some need
of him.
As long lives a merry heart as a sad.
As love without esteem is capricious and volatile, esteem without love is languid and cold.
A slow fire makes sweet malt.
A small man, if he stands too near a great, may see single portions well, and, if he will survey the whole, must stand too far off, where his eyes do not reach the details.
A small sorrow distracts us, a great one makes
us collected.
A small unkindness is a great offence.
As man, perhaps, the moment of his breath, / Receives the lurking principle of death; / The young disease, that must subdue at length, / Grows with his growth, and strengthens with his strength.
As many suffer from too much as too little.
A smart coat is a good letter of introduction.
As merry as the day is long.
A smile abroad is oft a scowl at home.
A smile re-cures the wounding of a frown.
As much love, so much mind, or heart.
As much virtue as there is, so much appears; as much goodness as there is, so much reverence it commands.
A snapper up of unconsidered trifles.
A society of people will cursorily represent a certain culture, though there is not a gentleman or a lady in the group.
A soldier, / Seeking the bubble reputation / Even in the cannon's mouth.
A solis ortu usque ad occasum
A song will outlive all sermons in the memory.
A sorrow's crown of sorrow is remembering happier things.
A sorrow shared is but half a trouble, / But a joy that's shared is a joy made double.
A' sottili cascano le brache
A soul without reflection, like a pile / Without inhabitant, to ruin runs.
A spark neglected makes a mighty fire.
A species is a succession of individuals which perpetuates itself.
Asperæ facetiæ ubi multum ex vero traxere, acrem sui memoriam relinquunt
Asperius nihil est humili, cum surgit in altum
Aspettare e non venire, / Stare in letto e non dormire, / Ben servire e non gradire, / Son tre cose da morire
A spirit may be known from only a single
thought.
As poor as Job.
A spot is most seen on the finest cloth.
As proud go behind as before.
A spur in the head is worth two in the heels.
As reason is a rebel unto faith, so is passion
unto reason.
Assai acqua passa per il molino, che il molinaio non se n'accorge
Assai basta, e troppo guasta
Assai ben balla, à chi fortuna suona
Assai è ricco à chi non manca
Assai guadagna chi vano sperar perde
Assai sa, chi non sa, se tacer sa

Assez dort qui rien ne fait
Assez gagne qui malheur perd
Assez sait qui sait vivre et se taire

Associate with the good, and you will be esteemed one of them.
As some tall cliff, that lifts its awful form, / Swells from the vale, and midway leaves the storm, / Though round its breast the rolling clouds are spread, / Eternal sunshine settles on its head.
As soon as a man is born he begins to die.
As soon as beauty is sought, not from religion and love, but for pleasure, it degrades the seeker.
As soon as the soul sees any object, it stops before that object.
Assume a virtue, if you have it not.
Assumpsit
Assurance is two-thirds of success.
A state is never greater than when all its superfluous hands are employed in the service of the public.
A state of violence cannot be perpetual, or disaster and ruin would be universal.
A statesman requires rather a large converse with men, and much intercourse in life, than deep study of books.
A stern discipline pervades all Nature, which is a little cruel that it may be very kind.
As the births of living creatures at first are
ill-shapen, so are all innovations, which are the births of time.
As the first order of wisdom is to know thyself, so the first order of charity is to be sufficient for thyself.
As the fool thinks, the bell clinks.
As the good man saith, so say we: / As the good woman saith, so it must be.
As the husband is, the wife is: / Thou art mated with a clown, / And the grossness of his nature / Will have weight to drag thee down.
As the man is, so is his strength.
As the old cock crows, the young one learns.
As there is no worldly gain without some loss, so there is no worldly loss without some gain.
As the sun breaks through the darkest clouds, / So honour peereth in the meanest habit.
As the youth lives in the future, so the man lives with the past; no one knows rightly how to live in the present.
As thy days, so shall thy strength be.
A still, small voice.
A stitch in time saves nine.
As to the value of conversions, God alone can judge.

Astræa redux
A straight line is the shortest in morals as well as in geometry.
A strange fish.
Astra regunt homines, sed regit astra Deus
A strenuous soul hates cheap success.
A strong memory is generally joined to a weak judgment.
A strong soil that has produced weeds may be made to produce wheat with far less difficulty than it would cost to make it produce nothing.
Astronomy has revealed the great truth that
the whole universe is bound together by one all-pervading influence.
A' Stuarts are no sib (related) to the king
Astutior coccyge
A subject's faults a subject may proclaim, / A monarch's errors are forbidden game.
A substitute shines brightly as a king, until a king be by.
A sudden thought strikes me, / Let us swear
an eternal friendship.
A sunbeam passes through pollution unpolluted.
A surfeit of sweetest things.
As water spilt upon the ground, which cannot be gathered up again.
As we advance in life, we learn the limits of our abilities.
As we are born to work, so others are born to
watch over us while working.
As weel be oot o' the world as oot o' the fashion.
As wholesome meat corrupteth to little worms, so good forms and orders corrupt into a number of petty observances.
As yet a child, not yet a fool to fame, / I lisp'd in numbers, for the numbers came.
As you do to others, expect others to do to you.
As you make your bed you must lie on it.
As you sow you shall reap.
A tale never loses in the telling.
A talisman that shall turn base metal into precious, Nature acknowledges not; but a talisman to turn base souls into noble, Nature has given us; and that is a "philosopher's stone," but it is a stone which the builders refuse.
A tâtons
A tattler is worse than a thief.
A (man of) teachable mind will hang about a wise man's neck.
At every trifle scorn to take offence; / That always shows great pride or little sense.
At first one omits writing for a little while; and then one stays a little while to consider of excuses; and at last it grows desperate, and one does not write at all.
At the gates of the forest the surprised man
of the world is forced to leave his city estimates of great and small, wise and foolish.
Atheism is rather in the life than in the heart of man.
Atheism leaves a man to sense, to philosophy, to natural piety, to laws, to reputation, all which may be guides to an outward moral virtue, though religion were not; but superstition dismounts all these, and erecteth an absolute monarchy in the minds of men.
A thief knows a thief, as a wolf knows a wolf.
A thing is the bigger of being shared.
A thing is what it is, only in and by means of
its limit.
A thing is worth what it
A thing of beauty is a joy for ever; / Its loveliness increases; it will never / Pass into nothingness.
A thing you don't want is dear at any price.
A thinking man is the worst enemy the Prince of Darkness can have.
A third interprets motion, looks, and eyes, /
At every word a reputation dies.
A thorn is a changed bud.
A thorough-paced antiquary not only remembers what others have thought proper to forget, but he also forgets what others think proper to remember.
A thousand years scarce serve to form a state; / An hour may lay it in the dust.
A thread will tie an honest man better than a rope will do a rogue.
A threatened blow is seldom given.
A threefold cord is not quickly broken.
A thrill passes through all men at the reception of a new truth, or at the performance of a great action, which comes out of the heart of nature.... By the necessity of our constitution, a certain enthusiasm attends the individual's consciousness of that Divine presence.

A true man hates no one.
A truly great genius will be the first to prescribe limits for its own exertions.
A truth / Looks freshest in the fashion of the day.
A truth to an age that has rejected and trampled on it, is not a word of peace, but a sword.
At spes non fracta
Attempts at reform, when they fail, strengthen
despotism; as he that struggles tightens those cords he does not succeed in breaking.

At the sight of a
At thirty, man suspects himself a fool, / Knows
it at forty, and reforms his plan. / At fifty, chides his infamous delay. / Pushes his prudent purpose to resolve. / Resolves--and re-resolves; then dies the same.
At twenty years of age, the will reigns; at thirty, the wit; and at forty, the judgment.

Aut Cæsar aut nihil
Authority, not majority.
Authors alone, with more than savage rage, / Unnatural war with brother authors wage.
Authors are martyrs, witnesses to the truth,
or else nothing.
Authors may be divided into falling stars, planets, and fixed stars: the first have a momentary effect; the second, a much longer duration; and the third are unchangeable, possess their own light, and shine for all time.

A votre santé
A wee bush is better than nae bield (shelter).
A weel-bred dog gaes oot when he sees them preparing to kick him oot.
A well-bred man is always sociable and complaisant.
A well-cultivated mind is, so to say, made up of all the minds of the centuries preceding.
A well-governed appetite is a great part of liberty.
A well-written life is almost as rare as a well-spent
one.
A wicked fellow is the most pious when he takes to it. He'll beat you all in piety.
A wilful man must have his way.
A willing mind makes a light foot.
A wise man gets learning frae them that hae nane.
A wise man is never less alone than when
alone.
A wise man is strong; yea, a man of knowledge increaseth strength.
A wise man neither suffers himself to be governed, nor attempts to govern others.
A wise man should have money in his head, but not in his heart.
A wise man will make more opportunities than he finds.
A wise physician, skill'd our wounds to heal, / Is more than armies to the public weal.
A wise scepticism is the first attribute of a good critic.
A wise writer does not reveal himself here and there, but everywhere.
A witless heed (head) mak's weary feet.
A wit with dunces, and a dunce with wits.
A wolf in sheep's clothing.
A woman conceals what she does not know.
A woman has two smiles that an angel might envy: the smile that accepts the lover before the words are uttered, and the smile that lights on the first-born baby, and assures it of a mother's love.
A woman in love is a very poor judge of character.
A woman moved is like a fountain troubled, /
Muddy, ill-seeming, thick, bereft of beauty.
A woman's friendship borders more closely on love than a man's.
A woman's head is always influenced by her heart; but a man's heart is always influenced by his head.
A woman sometimes scorns what best contents her.
A woman's whole life is a history of the affections.
A word and a stone let go cannot be recalled.
A word from a friend is doubly enjoyable in dark days.
A word once vulgarised can never be rehabilitated.
A word sooner wounds than heals.
A word spoken in season, at the right moment, is the mother of ages.
A word spoken in due season, how good is it?
A work of real merit finds favour at last.
A world all sincere, a believing world; the like has been; the like will again be--cannot help being.
A world in the hand is worth two in the bush.
A world this in which much is to be done, and little to be known.
A worn-out sinner is sometimes found to make
the best declaimer against sin.
A worthless man will always remain worthless, and a little mind will not, by daily intercourse with great minds, become an inch greater.
A wounded spirit who can bear?
A wound never heals so well that the scar cannot be seen.
A wreck on shore is a beacon at sea.
A wretched soul, bruised with adversity, / We
bid be quiet when we hear it cry; / But were we burdened with like weight of pain, / As much, or more, we should ourselves complain.
Ay, but to die, and go we know not where; / To lie in cold obstruction and to rot.
Aye free, aff-han' your story tell, when wi' a bosom crony; / But still keep something to yoursel' / Ye scarcely tell to ony.
Aye in a hurry, and aye ahint.
Ay, every inch a king.
Ay me! for aught that ever I could read, /
Could ever hear by tale or history, / The course of true love never did run smooth.
Aymez loyauté
A young man idle, an old man needy.
Ay, sir, to be honest as this world goes, is to be one man picked out of two thousand.
Bachelor, a peacock; betrothed, a lion; wedded, an ass.
"Bad company," muttered the thief, as he
stepped to the gallows between the hangman and a monk.
Bad is by its very nature negative, and can do nothing; whatsoever enables us to do anything, is by its very nature good.
Bad laws are the worst sort of tyranny.
Bad men excuse their faults; good men will leave them.
Bal abonné
Bal champêtre
Ballon d'essai
Banish the canker of ambitious thoughts.
Bankrupt of life, yet prodigal of ease.
Barba bagnata è mezza rasa
Barbæ tenus sapientes
Barbarism is no longer at our frontiers; it lives side by side with us.
Barbarism is the non-appreciation of what is excellent.
Barbarus hic ego sum, quia non intelligor ulli
Barbouillage
Barking dogs seldom bite.
Bas bleu
Base envy withers at another's joy, / And hates that excellence it cannot reach.
Base in kind, and born to be a slave.
Base men, being in love, have then a nobility in their natures more than is native to them.
Base souls have no faith in great men.
Bashfulness is an ornament to youth, but a reproach to old age.
Bashfulness is but the passage from one season of life to another.
Basis virtutum constantia
Battering the gates of heaven with storms of prayer.
Battle's magnificently stern array.
Be a philosopher; but, amidst all your philosophy, be still a man.
Beard was never the true standard of brains.
Bear one another's burdens.
Bear wealth, poverty will bear itself.
Be a sinner and sin manfully (fortiter), but believe and rejoice in Christ more manfully still.
Be as you would seem to be.
Beatæ memoriæ
Beati monoculi in regione cæcorum
Beatus ille qui procul negotiis, / Ut prisca
gens mortalium, / Paterna rura bobus exercet suis, / Solutus omni fœnore
Beaucoup de mémoire et peu de jugement
Beau idéal
Beau monde
Beauté et folie sont souvent en compagnie
Beauties in vain their pretty eyes may roll; /
Charms strike the sight, but merit wins the soul.
Beautiful it is to understand and know that a thought did never yet die; that as thou, the originator thereof, hast gathered it and created it from the whole past, so thou wilt transmit to the whole future.
Beauty blemished once, for ever's lost.
Beauty can afford to laugh at distinctions; it is itself the greatest distinction.
Beauty carries its dower in its face.
Beauty depends more on the movement of the
face than the form of the features.
Beauty doth varnish age, as if new-born, / And gives the crutch the cradle's infancy. / O, 'tis the sun that maketh all things shine.
Beauty draws us with a single hair.
Beauty is a good letter of introduction.
Beauty is a hovering, shining, shadowy form, the outline of which no definition holds.
Beauty is an all-pervading presence.
Beauty is a patent of nobility.
Beauty is as summer fruits, which are easy to corrupt and cannot last.
Beauty is a witch, / Against whose charms faith melteth into blood.
Beauty is bought by judgment of the eye, / Not utter'd by base sale of chapmen's tongues.
Beauty is but a vain and doubtful good.
Beauty is everywhere a right welcome guest.
Beauty is never a delusion.
Beauty is the flowering of virtue.
Beauty is the highest principle and the highest aim of art.
Beauty is the pilot of the young soul.
Beauty is the purgation of superfluities.
Beauty is truth, truth beauty--that is all / Ye know on earth, and all ye need to know.
Beauty is worse than wine; it intoxicates both holder and the beholder.
Beauty, like wit, to judges should be shown; / Both most are valued where they best are known.
Beauty lives with kindness.
Beauty provoketh thieves sooner than gold.
Beauty should be the dowry of every man and woman.
Beauty stands / In the admiration only of weak minds, / Led captive.
Beauty's tears are lovelier than her smile.
Beauty too rich for use; for earth too dear.
Beauty, when unadorned, adorned the most.
Beauty without expression tires.
Beauty without grace is a violet without smell.
Beaux esprits
Be bold, be bold, and everywhere be bold.
Be checked for silence, / But never tax'd for speech.
Be commonplace and cringing, and everything is within your reach.
Bedenkt, der Teufel der ist alt, / So werdet alt ihn zu verstehen
Be discreet in all things, and so render it unnecessary to be mysterious about any.
Be England what she will, / With all her faults
she is my country still.
Bees will not work except in darkness; thought will not work except in silence; neither will virtue work except in secrecy.
Before a leaf-bud has burst, its whole life acts; in the full-blown flower there is no more; in the leafless root there is no less.
Before every one stands an image (Bild) of what he ought to be; so long as he is not that, his peace is not complete.
Before honour is humility.
Before man made us citizens, great Nature
made us men.
Before the curing of a strong disease, / Even in the instant of repair and health, / The fit is strongest; evils that take leave, / On their departure most of all show evil.
Before the immense possibilities of man, all mere experience, all past biography, however spotless and sainted, shrinks away.
Before the revelations of the soul, Time, Space, and Nature shrink away.
Before you trust a man, eat a peck of salt with him.
Beggars, mounted, run their horse to death.
Beggars must not be choosers.
Beggar that I am, I am even poor in thanks.
Begnügt euch doch ein Mensch zu sein
Begun is half done.
Behaupten ist nicht beweisen
Behaviour is a mirror in which each one shows his image.
Behind a frowning providence / God hides a shining face.
Behind us, as we go, all things assume pleasing forms, as clouds do afar off.
Behind every individual closes organisation;
before him opens liberty.
Behind every mountain lies a vale.
Behold how great a matter a little fire kindleth.
Beholding heaven and feeling hell.
Behold now is the accepted time.
Behold the child, by Nature's kindly law, /
Pleased with a rattle, tickled with a straw.

Bei Geldsachen hört die Gemütlichkeit auf
Beinahe bringt keine Mücke um
Being alone when one's belief is firm, is not to be alone.
Being done, / There is no pause.
Being without well-being is a curse; and the greater being, the greater curse.
Be in possession, and thou hast the right, and sacred will the many guard it for thee.
Be it never so humble, there's no place like home.
Bei wahrer Liebe ist Vertrauen

aim'st at be thy country's, / Thy God's, and truth's.

Beleidigst du einen Mönch, so knappen alle Kuttenzipfel bis nach Rom

Belief and love,--a believing love, will relieve us of a vast load of care.
Belief consists in accepting the affirmations of
the soul; unbelief, in denying them.
Believe not each accusing tongue, / As most weak persons do; / But still believe that story wrong / Which ought not to be true.
Believe not every spirit.

Beneath the rule of men entirely great, the pen is mightier than the sword.

Be no one like another, yet every one like the Highest; to this end let each one be perfect in himself.
Be not angry that you cannot make others what you wish them to be, since you cannot make yourself what you wish to be.
Be not overcome of evil, but overcome evil with good.
Be not righteous overmuch.
Be not the first by whom the new is tried, / Nor yet the last to lay the old aside.

Besser ein Flick als ein Loch

Be still and have thy will.
Be stirring as the time; be fire with fire; /
Threaten the threatner, and outface the brow / Of bragging horror; so shall inferior eyes, / That borrow their behaviours from the great, / Grow great by your example, and put on / The dauntless spirit of resolution.
Best men are moulded out of faults.
Be strong, and quit yourselves like men.
Best time is present time.
Be substantially great in thyself, and more than thou appearest unto others.
Be sure you can obey good laws before you
seek to alter bad ones.
Be sure your sin will find you out.
Be swift to hear, slow to speak.

Beter eens in den hemel dan tienmaal aan de deur
Be thankful for your ennui; it is your last
mark of manhood.
Be thou as chaste as ice, as pure as snow, thou shalt not escape calumny.
Be thou assured, if words be made of breath, / And breath of life, I have no life to breathe / What thou hast said to me.

Better a blush in the face than a blot in the
heart.
Better a child should be ignorant of a thousand truths than have consecrated in its heart a single lie.
Better a diamond with a flaw than a pebble without one.
Better a fortune in a wife than with a wife.
Better a fremit freend than a freend fremit
Better a living dog than a dead lion.
Better an egg to-day than a hen to-morrow.
Better an end with terror than a terror without
end.
Better a toom (empty) house than an ill tenant.
Better a witty fool than a foolish wit.
Better bairns greet (weep) than bearded men.
Better be at the end o' a feast than the beginning o' a fray.
Better be a nettle in the side of your friend
than his echo.
Better be a poor fisherman than have to do with the governing of men.
Better be disagreeable in a sort than altogether insipid.
Better be idle than ill employed.
Better bend than break.
Better be persecuted than shunned.
Better be poor than wicked.
Better be unborn than untaught.
Better buy than borrow.
Better deny at once than promise long.
Better far off, than--near, be ne'er the near'.
Better far to die in the old harness than to try to put on another.
Better fifty years of Europe than a cycle of Cathay.
Better go back than go wrong.
Better go to bed supperless than rise in debt.
Better haud (hold on) wi' the hound than rin
wi' the hare.
Better is an ass that carries us than a horse that throws us.
Better it is to be envied than pitied.
Better keep the deil oot than hae to turn him oot.
Better keep weel than mak' weel.
Better knot straws than do nothing.
Better lose a jest than a friend.
Better mad with all the world than wise all alone.
Better my freen's think me fremit as fasheous
Better never begin than never make an end.
Better not be at all / Than not be noble.
Better not read books in which you make the acquaintance of the devil.
Better one-eyed than stone-blind.
Better one living word than a hundred dead ones.
Better rue sit than rue flit
Better say nothing than nothing to the purpose.
Better sit still than rise and fa'.
Better sma' fish than nane.
Better suffer for truth than prosper by falsehood.
Better ten guilty escape than one innocent man suffer.
Better that people should laugh at one while
they instruct, than that they should praise without benefiting.
Better the ill ken'd than the ill unken'd
Better the world know you as a sinner than God as a hypocrite.
Better to ask than go astray.
Better to get wisdom than gold.
Better to hunt in fields for health unbought, /
Than fee the doctor for a nauseous draught. / The wise for cure on exercise depend; / God never made his work for man to mend.
Better to reign in hell than serve in heaven.
Better to say "Here it is" than "Here it was."
Better understand the world than condemn it.
Better untaught than ill taught.
Better wear out than rust out.
Better wear shoon (shoes) than sheets.
Better wrong with the many than right with the few.
Between a woman's "Yes" and "No" you may insert the point of a needle.
Between saying and doing there's a long road.
Between the acting of a dreadful thing / And
the first motion, all the interim is / Like a phantasma or a hideous dream.
Between the deil and the deep sea.
Between us and hell or heaven there is nothing but life, which of all things is the frailest.
Beware, my lord, of jealousy; / It is the green-eyed monster that doth mock / The meat it feeds on.
Beware of a silent dog and still water.
Beware of a silent man and a dog that does
not bark.
Beware of a talent which you cannot hope to cultivate to perfection.
Beware / Of entrance to a quarrel; but, being in, / Bear 't that the opposed may beware of thee.
Beware of false prophets.
Beware of "Had I wist."
Beware of one who has nothing to lose.
Beware of too much good staying in your hand.
Beware the fury of a patient man.
Beware when the great God lets loose a thinker on this planet.
Be warned by thy good angel and not ensnared by thy bad one.
Be wisely worldly; be not worldly wise.
Be wise to-day; 'tis madness to defer.
Be wise with speed; / A fool at forty is a fool indeed.
Bewunderung verdient ein Wunder wohl, / Doch scheint ein Weib kein echtes Weib zu sein, / So bald es nur Bewunderung verdient
Be ye therefore wise as serpents, and harmless as doves.
Bezwingt des Herzens Bitterkeit. Es bringt /
Nicht gute Frucht, wenn Hass dem Hass begegnet

Bless, and curse not.
Blessed are they that have not seen, and yet
have believed.
Blessed are they that hear the Word of God, and keep it.
Blessed be he who first invented sleep; it covers a man all over like a cloak.
Blessed be nothing.
Blessed is he that considereth the poor.
Blessed is he that continueth where he is; here
let us rest and lay out seed-fields; here let us learn to dwell.
Blessed is he who expects nothing, for he shall never be disappointed.
Blessed is he who is made happy by the sound of a rat-tat.
Blessed is the man that endureth temptation.
Blessed is the voice that, amid dispiritment, stupidity, and contradiction, proclaims to us, Euge!

damnation.
Blessings are upon the head of the just.

Books are divisible into two classes, the books
of the hour and the books of all time.
Books are embalmed minds.
Books are made from books.
Books cannot always please, however good; / Minds are not ever craving for their food.
Books generally do little else than give our errors names.
Books, like friends, should be few and well chosen.
Books still accomplish miracles; they persuade men.
Books, we know, / Are a substantial world, pure and good.
Boomen die men veel verplant gedijen zelden
Borgen thut nur einmal wohl

Borrowing is not much better than begging; just as lending on interest is not much better than stealing.

Brag is a good dog, but Holdfast is better.
Brain is always to be bought, but passion never comes to market.

Breathes there the man with soul so dead, /
Who never to himself hath said, / "This is my own, my native land?"

Brief as the lightning in the collied night, /
That, in a spleen, unfolds both heaven and earth, / And ere a man hath power to say, "Behold!" / The jaws of darkness do devour it up.

leather.

Brute force holds communities together as an iron nail, if a little rusted with age, binds pieces of wood; but intelligence binds like a screw, which must be gently turned, not driven.
Brutum fulmen

Brutus will start a spirit as soon as Cæsar.

Buen siglo haya quien dijó bolta

Bullies are generally cowards.
Buon cavallo non ha bisogno di sproni
Burlaos con el loco en casa, burlará con vos en la plaza
Burnt bairns dread the fire.
Business dispatched is business well done, but business hurried is business ill done.
Busy readers are seldom good readers.
But a bold peasantry, their country's pride, / When once destroyed, can never be supplied.
But all was false and hollow; though his tongue / Dropp'd manna, and could make the worse appear / The better reason, to perplex and dash / Maturest counsels.
But by bad courses may be understood, / That their events can never fall out good.
But Cristes lore, and his apostles twelve, / He taught, but first he folwed it himselve.
But earthlier happy is the rose distilled, / Than
that which, withering on the virgin thorn, / Grows, lives, and dies in single blessedness.
But evil is wrought by want of thought / As well as want of heart.
But facts are chiels that winna ding, / An' douna be disputed.
But far more numerous was the herd of such / Who think too little and who talk too much.
But for women, our life would be without help at the outset, without pleasure in its course, and without consolation at the end.
But from the heart of Nature rolled / The burdens
of the Bible old.
But human bodies are sic fools, / For a' their colleges and schools, / That, when nae real ills perplex them, / They make enow themsels to vex them.
But hushed be every thought that springs / From out the bitterness of things.
But I am constant as the northern star, / Of whose true-fixed and resting quality, / There is no fellow in the firmament.
But I will wear my heart upon my sleeve / For daws to peck at.
But man, proud man, / Drest in a little brief
authority, / Most ignorant of what he's most assured, / His glassy essence,--like an angry ape, / Plays such fantastic tricks before high Heaven / As make the angels weep.
But men may construe things after their fashion, clean from the purpose of the things themselves.
But men must work, and women must weep, / Though storms be sudden and waters deep, / And the harbour bar be moaning.
But mercy is above this sceptred sway; / It is enthroned in the hearts of kings, / It is an attribute to God Himself, / And earthly power doth then show likest God's / When mercy seasons justice.
But now our fates from unmomentous things / May rise like rivers out of little springs.
But O for the touch of a vanish'd hand, / And
the sound of a voice that is still.
But O what damned minutes tells he o'er, / Who dotes, yet doubts; suspects, yet strongly loves?
But pleasures are like poppies spread, / You seize the flower, its bloom is shed; / Or, like the snowfall on the river, / A moment white--then melts for ever.
But Shakespeare's magic could not copied be; / Within that circle none durst walk but he.
But shapes that come not at an earthly call, / Will not depart when mortal voices bid.
But souls that of His own good life partake, /
He loves as His own self; dear as His eye / They are to Him; He'll never them forsake; / When they shall die, then God Himself shall die: / They live, they live in blest eternity.
But spite of all the criticising elves, / Those that would make us feel, must feel themselves.
But there are wanderers o'er eternity, / Whose bark drives on and on, and anchor'd ne'er shall be.
But there's nothing half so sweet in life / As love's young dream.
But thought's the slave of life, and life time's fool; / And time, that takes survey of all the world, / Must have a stop.
But to see her was to love her--love but her,
and love for ever.
But truths on which depend our main concern, / That 'tis our shame and misery not to learn, / Shine by the side of every path we tread, / With such a lustre, he that runs may read.
But war's a game which, were their subjects wise, / Kings would not play at.
But were I Brutus, / And Brutus Antony, there were an Antony / Would ruffle up your spirits, and put a tongue / In every wound of Cæsar, that should move / The stones of Rome to rise and mutiny.
But what fate does, let fate answer for.
But whether on the scaffold high, / Or in the
battle's van, / The fittest place where man can die / Is where he dies for man.
But who would force the soul, tilts with a straw / Against a champion cased in adamant.
But winter lingering chills the lap of May.
But words are things, and a small drop of ink, / Falling, like dew, upon a thought, produces / That which makes thousands, perhaps millions, think.
But wouldst thou know what's heaven? I'll tell thee what: / Think what thou canst not think, and heaven is that.
But yesterday the word of Cæsar might /
Have stood against the world; now lies he there, / And none so poor to do him reverence.
Buying is cheaper than asking.
Buy the truth, and sell it not.
Buy what ye dinna want, an' ye'll sell what ye canna spare.
By-and-by is easily said.
By any ballot-box, Jesus Christ goes just as
far as Judas Iscariot.
By blood a king, in heart a clown.
By bravely enduring it, an evil which cannot be avoided is overcome.
By desiring little, a poor man makes himself rich.
By dint of dining out, I run the risk of dying by starvation at home.
By doing nothing we learn to do ill.
By education most have been misled.
By experience we find out a short way by a
long wandering.
By nature man hates change; seldom will he quit his old home till it has actually fallen about his ears.
By night an atheist half believes a God.
By nothing do men more show what they are than by their appreciation of what is and what is not ridiculous.
By others' faults wise men correct their own.
By persisting in your path, though you forfeit
the little, you gain the great.
By pious heroic climbing of our own, not by arguing with our poor neighbours, wandering to right and left, do we at length reach the sanctuary--the victorious summit, and see with our own eyes.
By pride cometh contention.
By robbing Peter he paid Paul ... and hoped to catch larks if ever the heavens should fall.
By seeking and blundering we learn.
By shallow rivers to whose falls / Melodious
birds sing madrigals.
By sports like these are all their cares beguil'd, / The sports of children satisfy the child.
By strength of heart the sailor fights with roaring seas.
By the long practice of caricature I have lost the enjoyment of beauty: I never see a face but distorted.
By three methods we may learn wisdom: first, by reflection, which is the noblest; second, by imitation, which is the easiest; and third, by experience, which is the bitterest.
By time and counsel do the best we can: /
Th' event is never in the power of man.
Ca' (drive) a cow to the ha' (hall), and she'll rin to the byre.
Cabin'd, cribb'd, confin'd.

Cacoëthes scribendi

Calamitosus est animus futuri anxius
Calamity is man's true touchstone
Calf love, half love; old love, cold love.
Call a spade a spade.
Call him wise whose actions, words, and steps
are all a clear Because to a clear Why.
Callida junctura
Call me what instrument you will, though you fret me, you cannot play on me.
Call not that man wretched who, whatever ills he suffers, has a child he loves.
Call not the devil; he will come fast enough without.
Call your opinions your creed, and you will
change it every week. Make your creed simply and broadly out of the revelation of God, and you may keep it to the end.
Calmness of will is a sign of grandeur. The vulgar, far from hiding their will, blab their wishes. A single spark of occasion discharges the child of passions into a thousand crackers of desire.
Calumnies are sparks which, if you do not blow them, will go out of themselves.
Calumny is like the wasp which worries you; which it were best not to try to get rid of, unless you are sure of slaying it, for otherwise it will return to the charge more furious than ever.
Calumny will sear / Virtue itself: these shrugs, these hums and ha's.
Camelus desiderans cornua etiam aures perdidit
Campos ubi Troja fuit

Canaille
Canam mihi et Musis
"Can" and "shall," well understood, mean the same thing under this sun of ours.
Can anybody remember when the times were not hard and money not scarce? or when sensible men, and the right sort of men, and the right sort of women, were plentiful?
Can ch' abbaia non morde
Can che morde non abbaia in vano
Can despots compass aught that hails their
sway? / Or call with truth one span of earth their own, / Save that wherein at last they crumble bone by bone?

Debet et a radiis sideris esse niger

Candor dat viribus alas
Candour is the brightest gem of criticism.
Canes timidi vehementius latrant quam mordent

Can I choose my king? I can choose my King Popinjay, and play what farce or tragedy I may with him; but he who is to be my ruler, whose will is higher than my will, was chosen for me in heaven.
Canina facundia
Canis a non canendo
Canis in præsepi
Cannon and firearms are cruel and damnable
machines. I believe them to have been the direct suggestion of the devil.
Can storied urn or animated bust / Back to its mansion call the fleeting breath? / Can honour's voice provoke the silent dust, / Or flattery soothe the dull cold ear of death?
Canst thou not minister to a mind diseas'd, / Pluck from the memory a rooted sorrow, / Raze out the written troubles of the brain? / And with some sweet oblivious antidote, / Cleanse the stuff'd bosom of that perilous stuff / Which weighs upon the heart?
Can such things be, / And overcome us like a summer's cloud, / Without our special wonder?
Cantabit vacuus coram latrone viator
Can that which is the greatest virtue in philosophy,
doubt, be in religion, what we priests term it, the greatest of sins?
Can the Ethiopian change his skin, or the leopard his spots?
Can there any good thing come out of Nazareth?
Cantilenam eandem canis
Cant is properly a double-distilled lie, the second power of a lie.
Cant is the voluntary overcharging or prolonging
of a real sentiment.
Can wealth give happiness? look around and see, / What gay distress! what splendid misery! / Whatever fortunes lavishly can pour, / The mind annihilates and calls for more.
Can we wonder that men perish and are forgotten, when their noblest and most enduring works decay?
"Can you tell a plain man the plain road to heaven?"--"Surely. Turn at once to the right, then go straight forward."
Caõ que muito ladra, nunca bom para a caça
Capable of all kinds of devotion, and of all
kinds of treason, raised to the second power, woman is at once the delight and the terror of man.
Capacity without education is deplorable, and education without capacity is thrown away.

Cara al mio cuor tu sei, / Ciò ch'è il sole agli occhi miei
Care, and not fine stables, makes a good horse.
Care is no cure, but rather a corrosive, / For things that are not to be remedied.
Care is taken that trees do not grow into the sky.
Care keeps his watch in every old man's eye, / And where care lodges, sleep will never lie.
Care killed the cat.
Carelessness is worse than theft.
Careless their merits or their faults to scan, / His pity gave ere charity began.
Care's an enemy to life.
Cares are often more difficult to throw off than sorrows; the latter die with time, the former grow with it.
Care that has enter'd once into the breast, /
Will have the whole possession ere it rest.

Care will kill a cat, but ye canna live without
it.

Cast all your cares on God; that anchor holds.
Cast forth thy act, thy word, into the ever-living, ever-working universe. It is a seed-grain that cannot die; unnoticed to-day, it will be found flourishing as a banyan-grove, perhaps, alas! as a hemlock forest, after a thousand years.
Cast him (a lucky fellow) into the Nile, and he
will come up with a fish in his mouth.

Catch as catch can.
Catching a Tartar
Catch not at the shadow and lose the substance.
Catch, then, O catch the transient hour; / Improve each moment as it flies; / Life's a short summer--man a flower--/ He dies--alas! how soon he dies!
Catholicism commonly softens, while Protestantism strengthens, the character; but the softness of the one often degenerates into weakness, and the strength of the other into hardness.

Causa latet, vis est notissima
Causa sine qua non
Cause and effect are two sides of one fact.
Cause and effect, means and end, seed and fruit, cannot be severed; for the effect already blooms in the cause, the end preexists in the means, the fruit in the seed.

Cease, every joy, to glimmer in my mind, / But leave,--oh! leave the light of hope behind! / What though my winged hours of bliss have been, / Like angel-visits, few and far between?
Cease to lament for that thou canst not help, / And study help for that which thou lament'st.

punishment of talent.

Ceremonies are different in every country; but true politeness is everywhere the same.
Ceremony is necessary as the outwork and
defence of manners.
Ceremony is the invention of wise men to keep fools at a distance.
Ceremony keeps up all things; 'tis like a penny glass to a rich spirit or some excellent water; without it the water were spilt, the spirit lost.
Ceremony leads her bigots forth, / Prepared to fight for shadows of no worth; / While truths, on which eternal things depend, / Find not, or hardly find, a single friend.
Ceremony was but devised at first / To set a gloss on faint deeds ... / But where there is true friendship, there needs none.
Cereus in vitium flecti, monitoribus asper
Cernit omnia Deus vindex
Certa amittimus dum incerta petimus
Certain defects are necessary to the existence of the individual. It would be painful to us if our old friends laid aside certain peculiarities.
Certain it is that there is no kind of affection so purely angelic as that of a father to a daughter. In love to our wives there is desire; to our sons, ambition; but to our daughters there is something which there are no words to express.

Chance corrects us of many faults that reason would not know how to correct.
Chance generally favours the prudent.
Chance is but the pseudonym of God for those
particular cases which He does not choose to subscribe openly with His own sign-manual.
Chance is the providence of adventurers.
Chance will not do the work: / Chance sends the breeze, / But if the pilot slumber at the helm, / The very wind that wafts us towards the port / May dash us on the shelves.
Chances, as they are now called, I regard as guidances, and even, if rightly understood, commands, which, as far as I have read history, the best and sincerest men think providential.
Change is inevitable in a progressive country--is constant.
Change of fashions is the tax which industry
imposes on the vanity of the rich.
Changes are lightsome, an' fules are fond o' them.
Change yourself, and your fortune will change too.

Chapeau bas
Chapelle ardente
Chapter of accidents.
Chaque âge a ses plaisirs, son esprit, et ses mœurs
Chaque branche de nos connaissances passe successivement par trois états théoretiques différents: l'état théologique, ou fictif; l'état métaphysique, ou abstrait; l'état scientifique, ou positif
Chaque demain apporte son pain
Chaque instant de la vie est un pas vers la mort

Chaque potier vante sa pot
Char-à-bancs
Character gives splendour to youth, and awe to wrinkled skin and grey hairs.
Character is a fact, and that is much in a world of pretence and concession.
Character is a perfectly educated will.
Character is a reserved force which acts directly by presence and without means.
Character is a thing that will take care of
itself.
Character is centrality, the impossibility of being displaced or overset.
Character is higher than intellect. Thinking is the function; living is the functionary.
Character is impulse reined down into steady continuance.
Character is the result of a system of stereotyped principles.
Character is the spiritual body of the person,
and represents the individualisation of vital experience, the conversion of unconscious things into self-conscious men.
Character is victory organised.
Character is what Nature has engraven on us; can we then efface it?
Characters are developed, and never change.
Character teaches over our head, above our wills.
Character wants room; must not be crowded
on by persons, nor be judged of from glimpses got in the press of affairs or a few occasions.
Charbonnier est maître chez soi
Charge, Chester, charge! On, Stanley, on! / Were the last words of Marmion.
Chargé d'affaires
Charity begins at hame, but shouldna end there.
Charity begins at home.
Charity draws down a blessing on the charitable.
Charity gives itself rich; covetousness hoards itself poor.
Charity is the scope of all God's commands.
Charity is the temple of which justice is the foundation, but you can't have the top without the bottom.
Charity shall cover the multitude of sins.
Charm'd with the foolish whistling of a name.
Charms strike the sight, but merit wins the soul.
Charms which, like flowers, lie on the surface and always glitter, easily produce vanity; whereas other excellences, which lie deep like gold and are discovered with difficulty, leave their possessors modest and proud.
Charta non erubescit
Chasse cousin
Chassez le naturel, il revient au galop
Chaste as the icicle / That's curded by the frost from purest snow, / And hangs on Dian's temple.
Chastise the good, and he will grow better; chastise the bad, and he will grow worse.
Chastity is like an icicle; if it once melts, that's the last of it.
Chastity is the band that holds together the
sheaf of all holy affections and duties.
Chastity, lost once, cannot be recalled; it goes only once.

Chat échaudé craint l'eau froide
Cheapest is the dearest.
Che dorme coi cani, si leva colle pulci
Cheerfulness is health; the opposite, melancholy, is disease.
Cheerfulness is just as natural to the heart of a man in strong health as colour to his cheek.
Cheerfulness is the best promoter of health, and is as friendly to the mind as to the body.
Cheerfulness is the daughter of employment.
Cheerfulness is the heaven under which everything
but poison thrives.
Cheerfulness is the very flower of health.
Cheerfulness opens, like spring, all the blossoms of the inward man.
Cheese is gold in the morning, silver at mid-day, and lead at night.

Che ne può la gatta se la massaia è matta

Chercher à connaître, c'est chercher à douter
Che sarà, sarà

Chewing the food of sweet and bitter fancy.
Chew the cud of politics.
Chi altri giudica, sè condanna
Chi ama, crede
Chi ama, qual chi muore / Non ha da gire al ciel dal mondo altr' ale
Chi ama, teme
Chi asino è, e cervo esser si crede, al saltar del fosso se n'avvede
Chi compra ciò pagar non può, vende ciò che non vuole
Chi compra ha bisogno di cent occhi
Chi compra terra, compra guerra
Chi con l'occhio vede, di cuor crede

Chi dinanzi mi pinge, di dietro mi tinge
