Chi é causa del suo mal, pianga se stesso
Chi edifica, sua borsa purifica
Chien sur son fumier est hardi
Chi erra nelle decine, erra nelle migliaja
Chiesa libera in libero stato
Chi fa il conto senza l'oste, gli convien farlo due volte
Chi fa quel ch' e' può, non fa mal bene
Chi ha capo di cera non vada al sole
Chi ha danari da buttar via, metta gli operaj, e non vi stia
Chi ha denti, non ha pane; e chi ha pane, non
ha denti
Chi ha, è
Chi ha l'amor nel petto, ha lo sprone a' fianchi
Chi ha lingua in bocca, può andar per tutto
Chi ha paura del diavolo, non fa roba
Chi ha sanità è ricco, e non lo sa
Chi ha sospetto, di rado è in difetto
Chi ha tempo, non aspetti tempo
Childhood and youth see all the world in persons.
Childhood has no forebodings; but then it is soothed by no memories of outlived sorrow.
Childhood is the sleep of reason.
Childhood itself is scarcely more lovely than a cheerful, kindly, sunshiny old age.
Childhood often holds a truth in its feeble fingers which the grasp of manhood cannot retain, and which it is the pride of utmost age to recover.
Childhood shows the man, as morning shows the day.
Childhood, who like an April morn appears, / Sunshine and rain, hopes clouded o'er with fears.
Children always turn toward the light.
Children and chickens are always a-picking.
Children and drunk people speak the truth.
Children and fools speak the truth.
Children are certain sorrows, but uncertain joys.
Children are the poor man's wealth.
Children are very nice observers, and they will often perceive your slightest defects.
Children blessings seem, but torments are, / When young, our folly, and when old, our fear.
Children generally hate to be idle; all the care is then that their busy humour should be constantly employed in something of use to them.
Children have more need of models than of critics.
Children have scarcely any other fear than
that produced by strangeness.
Children, like dogs, have so sharp and fine a scent, that they detect and hunt out everything--the bad before all the rest.
Children of night, of indigestion bred.
Children of wealth or want, to each is given / One spot of green, and all the blue of heaven.
Children see in their parents the past, they again in their children the future; and if we find more love in parents for their children than in children for their parents, this is sad indeed, but natural. Who does not fondle his hopes more than his recollections?
Children should have their times of being off
duty, like soldiers.
Children should laugh, but not mock; and when they laugh, it should not be at the weaknesses and the faults of others.
Children suck the mother when they are young, and the father when they are old.
Children sweeten labours, but they make misfortunes more bitter.
Children tell in the highway what they hear by the fireside.
Children think not of what is past, nor what is to come, but enjoy the present time, which few of us do.
Chi lingua ha, a Roma va
Chi nasce bella, nasce maritata
Chi niente sa, di niente dubita
Chi non dà fine al pensare, non dà principio al fare
Chi non ha cuore, abbia gambe
Chi non ha, non è
Chi non ha piaghe, se ne fa
Chi non ha testa, abbia gambe
Chi non istima vien stimato
Chi non puo fare come voglia, faccia come puo
Chi non sa fingere, non sa vivere
Chi non vede il fondo, non passi l'acqua
Chi non vuol servir ad un sol signor, a molto ha da servir
Chi offende, non perdona mai
Chi offende scrive nella rena, chi è offeso nel marmo
Chi parla semina, chi tace raccoglie
Chi piglia leone in assenza suol temer del topi in presenza
Chi più sa, meno crede
Chi più sa, meno parla
Chi sa la strada, puo andar di trotto
Chi sa poco presto lo dice
Chi serve al commune serve nessuno
Chi si affoga, s'attaccherebbe a' rasoj
Chi si fa fango, il porco lo calpestra
Chi si trova senz' amici, è come un corpo senz' anima
Chi sta bene, non si muova
Chi tace confessa
Chi t'ha offeso non ti perdonera mai
Chi troppo abbraccia nulla stringe
Chi tutto vuole, tutto perde
Chivalry was founded invariably by knights
who were content all their lives with their horse and armour and daily bread.
Chi va piano, va sano, chi va sano va lontano
Chi va, vuole; chi manda, non se ha cura
Chi vuol dell' acqua chiara, vada alla fonte
Chi vuol esser mal servito tenga assai famiglia
Chi vuol il lavoro mal fatto, paghi innanzi
tratto
Chi vuol presto e ben, faccia da se
Choose a good mother's daughter, though her father were the devil.
Choose always the way that seems the best, however rough it may be. Custom will render it easy and agreeable.
Choose an author as you choose a friend.
Choose thy speech.
Choose your wife as you wish your children to be.
Chords that vibrate sweetest pleasure / Thrill the deepest notes of woe.
Chose perdue, chose connue
Christen haben keine Nachbarn
Christianity has not yet penetrated into the whole heart of Jesus.
Christianity appeals to the noblest feelings of the human heart, and these are emotion and imagination.
Christianity has a might of its own; it is raised above all philosophy, and needs no support therefrom.
Christianity has made martyrdom sublime and sorrow triumphant.
Christianity is a religion that can make men
good, only if they are good already.
Christianity is salvation by the conversion of the will; humanism by the enlightenment of the mind.
Christianity is the apotheosis of grief, the marvellous transmutation of suffering into triumph, the death of death and the defeat of sin.
Christianity is the practical demonstration that holiness and pity, justice and mercy, may meet together and become one in man and in God.
Christianity is the root of all democracy, the highest fact in the rights of men.
Christianity is the worship of sorrow.
Christianity's husk and shell / Threaten its heart like a blight.
Christianity teaches us to love our neighbour.
Modern society acknowledges no neighbour.
Christianity, which is always true to the heart, knows no abstract virtues, but virtues resulting from our wants, and useful to all.
Christianity without the cross is nothing.
Christians have burnt each other, quite persuaded / That all the apostles would have done as they did.
Christ is not valued at all, unless He is valued above all.
Christ left us not a system of logic, but a few
simple truths.
Christmas comes but once a year.
Christ never wrote a tract, but He went about doing good.
Christ's truth itself may yet be taught / With something of the devil's spirit.
Churches are not built on Christ's principles, but on His tropes.
Ci-devant
Cieco è l'occhio, se l'animo è distratto
Ciencia es locura si buen senso no la cura
Ci-git
Cineri gloria sera venit
Ciò che Dio vuole, io voglio
Ciò che si usa, non ha bisogno di scusa
Circles are prais'd, not that abound / In largeness, but th' exactly round; / So life we praise, that does excel, / Not in much time, but acting well.
Circles in water as they wider flow, / The less conspicuous in their progress grow, / And when at last they trench upon the shore, / Distinction ceases, and they're view'd no more.
Circles to square, and cubes to double, / Would give a man excessive trouble.
Circuitus verborum
Circulus in probando
Circumstances are beyond the control of man, but his conduct is in his own power.
Circumstances are things round about; we are in them, not under them.
Circumstances form the character, but, like petrifying matters, they harden while they form.
Circumstances? I make circumstances.
Cita mors ruit
Citharœdus / Ridetur chorda qui semper obberrat eadem
Cities force growth, and make men talkative and entertaining, but they make them artificial.
Cities give not the human senses room enough.
Cities have always been the fire-places
of civilisation, whence light and heat radiated out into the dark, cold world.
Citius venit periculum cum contemnitur
Civil dissension is a viperous worm / That gnaws the bowels of the commonwealth.
Civilisation degrades the many to exalt the few.
Civilisation depends on morality.
Civilisation is the result of highly complex
organisation.
Civilisation means the recession of passional and material life, and the development of social and moral life.
Civilisation tends to corrupt men, as large towns vitiate the air.
Civility costs nothing, and buys everything.
Clamorous labour knocks with its hundred hands at the golden gate of the morning.
Claqueur
Clarior e tenebris
Clarum et venerabile nomen
Classical quotation is the parole of literary men all over the world.
Classisch ist das Gesunde, romantisch das Kranke
Claude os, aperi oculos
Claudite jam rivos, pueri; sat prata biberunt
Clausum fregit
Clay and clay differs in dignity, / Whose dust is both alike.
Cleanliness is near of kin to godliness.
Clear and bright it should be ever, / Flowing
like a crystal river; / Bright as light, and clear as wind.
Clear conception leads naturally to clear and correct expression.
Clear writers, like clear fountains, do not seem so deep as they are; the turbid look the most profound.
Clear your mind of cant.
Clemency alone makes us equal with the gods.
Clemency is one of the brightest diamonds in
the crown of majesty.
Cleverness is serviceable for everything, sufficient for nothing.
Clever people will recognise and tolerate nothing but cleverness.
Climbing is performed in the same posture as creeping.
Clocks will go as they are set; but man, irregular man, is never constant, never certain.
Close sits my shirt, but closer sits my skin.
Clothes are for necessity; warm clothes, for health; cleanly, for decency; lasting, for thrift; and rich, for magnificence.
Clothes have made men of us; they are threatening to make clothes-screens of us.
Clothes make the man.
Clouds are the veil behind which the face of day coquettishly hides itself, to enhance its beauty.
Coal is a portable climate.
Cobblers go to mass and pray that the cows may die
Cobra buena fama, y échate á dormir
Cobre gana cobre que no huesos de hombre
Cœlitus mihi vires
Cœlo tegitur qui non habet urnam
Cœlum ipsum petimus stultitia
Cœlum non animum mutant qui trans mare currunt
Coerced innocence is like an imprisoned lark; open the door, and it is off for ever.
Cogenda mens est ut incipiat
Cogi qui potest nescit mori
Cogitatio nostra cœli munimenta perrumpit, nec contenta est, id, quod ostenditur, scire
Cogito, ergo sum
Cognovit actionem
Coigne of vantage.
Coin heaven's image / In stamps that are forbid.
Cold hand, warm heart.
Cold pudding settles one's love.
Collision is as necessary to produce virtue in men, as it is to elicit fire in inanimate matter; and chivalry is the essence of virtue.
Colonies don't cease to be colonies because they are independent.
Colour answers to feeling in man; shape, to
thought; motion, to will.
Colour blindness, which may mistake drab for scarlet, is better than total blindness, which sees no distinction of colour at all.
Colour is the type of love. Hence it is especially connected with the blossoming of the earth, and with its fruits; also with the spring and fall of the leaf, and with the morning and evening of the day, in order to show the waiting of love about the birth and death of man.
Colours are the smiles of Nature ... her laughs, as in the flowers.
Colubram in sinu fovere
Columbus discovered no isle or key so lonely
as himself.
Combien de héros, glorieux, magnanimes, ont vécu trop d'un jour
Combinations of wickedness would overwhelm the world, did not those who have long practised perfidy grow faithless to each other.
Come, and trip it as you go, / On the light fantastic toe.
Come, civil night, / Thou sober-suited matron, all in black.
Come, cordial, not poison.
Comedians are not actors; they are only imitators of actors.
Come è duro calle
Come, fair Repentance, daughter of the skies! / Soft harbinger of soon returning virtue; / The weeping messenger of grace from heaven.
Come forth into the light of things, / Let Nature be your teacher.
Come he slow or come he fast, / It is but
Death who comes at last.
Come like shadows, so depart.
Come, my best friends, my books, and lead me on.
Come one, come all! this rock shall fly / From its firm base as soon as I.
Comes jucundus in via pro vehiculo est
Come the three corners of the world in arms, /
And we shall shock them. Nought shall make us rue, / If England to itself do rest but true.
Come, we burn daylight.
Come what come may, / Time and the hour runs through the roughest day.
Come what sorrow can, / It cannot countervail th' exchange of joy / That one short minute gives me in her sight.
Comfort is the god of this world, but comfort it will never obtain by making it an object.
Comfort's in heaven; and we are on the earth, /
Where nothing lives but crosses, care, and grief.
Coming events cast their shadows before.
Comitas inter gentes
Command large fields, but cultivate small ones.
Comme il faut
Comme je fus
Comme je trouve
Commend a fool for his wit or a knave for his honesty, and he will receive you into his bosom.
Commend me rather to him who goes wrong in a way that is his own, than to him who walks correctly in a way that is not.
Commerce changes the fate and genius of nations.
Commerce flourishes by circumstances, precarious, contingent, transitory, almost as liable to change as the winds and waves that waft it to our shores.
Commerce has set the mark of selfishness, the
signet of all-enslaving power, upon a shining ore and called it gold.
Commerce is a game of skill, which every one cannot play, which few men can play well.
Commerce is one of the daughters of Fortune, inconstant and deceitful as her mother. She chooses her residence where she is least expected, and shifts her abode when her continuance is, in appearance, most firmly settled.
Commit a crime, and the earth is made of glass.
Committunt multi eadem diverso crimina fato, / Ille crucem sceleris pretium tulerit, hic diadema
Common as light is love, / And its familiar
voice wearies not ever.
Common chances common men can bear.
Common distress is a great promoter both of friendship and speculation.
Common fame is seldom to blame.
Commonly they use their feet for defence whose tongue is their weapon.
Common men are apologies for men; they
bow the head, excuse themselves with prolix reasons, and accumulate appearances, because the substance is not.
Common-place people see no difference between one man and another.
Common-sense is calculation applied to life.
Common-sense is the average sensibility and intelligence of men undisturbed by individual peculiarities.
Common-sense is the genius of humanity.
Common-sense is the measure of the possible;
it is calculation applied to life.
Common souls pay with what they do; nobler souls, with what they are.
Communautés commencent par bâtir leur cuisine

Commune naufragium omnibus est consolatio
Commune periculum concordiam parit
Communia esse amicorum inter se omnia

Communi consensu
Communion is the law of growth, and homes only thrive when they sustain relations with each other.
Communism is the exploitation of the strong
by the weak. In communism, inequality springs from placing mediocrity on a level with excellence.
Como canta el abad, así responde el monacillo
Compagnon de voyage
Company, villanous company, has been the spoil of me.
Comparaison n'est pas raison
Compare her face with some that I shall
show, / And I will make thee think thy swan a crow.
Comparisons are odious.
Comparisons are odorous.
Compassion to the offender who has grossly violated the laws is, in effect, a cruelty to the peaceable subject who has observed them.
Compassion will cure more sins than condemnation.
Compendia dispendia
Compendiaria res improbitas, virtusque tarda
Compesce mentem
Complaining never so loud, and with never so much reason, is of no use.
Complaining profits little; stating of the truth may profit.
Complaint is the largest tribute heaven receives,
and the sincerest part of our devotion.
Compliments are only lies in court clothes.
Componitur orbis / Regis ad exemplum; nec sic inflectere sensus / Humanos edicta valent, quam vita regentis
Compose thy mind, and prepare thy soul calmly to obey; such offering will be more acceptable to God than every other sacrifice.
Compositum miraculi causa
Compos mentis
Compound for sins they are inclined to / By damning those they have no mind to.
Comprendre c'est pardonner

Con agua pasada no muele molino
Con amore
Con arte e con inganno si vive mezzo l'anno; con inganno si vive l'altra parte
Conceal not the meanness of thy family, nor think it disgraceful to be descended from peasants; for when it is seen thou art not thyself ashamed, no one will endeavour to make thee so.
Conceit in weakest bodies strongest works.
Conceit may puff a man up, but never prop him up.
Concentration is the secret of strength in politics, in war, in trade, in short, in all the management of human affairs.
Concio ad clerum
Concordia discors
Concordia res parvæ crescunt, discordia maximæ dilabuntur
Concours
Condemnable idolatry is insincere idolatry--a human soul clinging spasmodically to an Ark of the Covenant, which it half feels is now a phantasm.
Condemn the fault, and not the actor of it! /
Why, every fault's condemned ere it be done.
Condense some daily experience into a glowing symbol, and an audience is electrified.
Con dineros no te conocerás, sin dineros no te conocerán
Condition, circumstance, is not the thing, / Bliss is the same in subject or in king.
Conditions are pleasant or grievous to us according to our sensibilities.
Con el Rey y con la Inquisicion, chitos
Confessed faults are half mended.
Confess yourself to Heaven; / Repent what's past; avoid what is to come; / And do not spread the compost on the weeds, / To make them ranker.
Confess you were wrong yesterday; it will show you are wise to-day.
Confidence imparts a wondrous inspiration to its possessor. It bears him on in security, either to meet no danger or to find matter of glorious trial.
Confidence in another man's virtue is no slight
evidence of a man's own.
Confidence in one's self is the chief nurse of magnanimity.
Confidence is a plant of slow growth in an aged bosom.
Confidence is a thing not to be produced by compulsion. Men cannot be forced into trust.
Confido, conquiesco
Confine your tongue, lest it confine you.
Confrère
Confusion now hath made his masterpiece. / Most sacrilegious murder hath broke ope / The Lord's anointed temple, and stole thence / The life o' the building.
Confusion worse confounded.
Congé d'élire
Con poco cervello si governa il mondo
Conquer we shall, but we must first contend; / 'Tis not the fight that crowns us, but the end.
Conscia mens recti famæ mendacia risit
Conscience does make cowards of us all; / And thus the native hue of resolution / Is sicklied o'er with the pale cast of thought; / And enterprises of great pith and moment, / With this regard, their currents turn awry, / And lose the name of action.
Conscience is but a word that cowards use, / Devised at first to keep the strong in awe; / Our strong arms be our conscience, swords our law.
Conscience is our magnetic needle; / reason,
our chart.
Conscience is the chamber of justice.
Conscience is the compass of the unknown.
Conscience is the sentinel of virtue.
Conscience is the voice of the soul; the passions, of the body.
Conscience is wiser than science.
Conscientia mille testes
Con scienza
Consecrated is the spot which a good man has trodden.
Consecration is going out into the world where God Almighty is, and using every power for His glory.
Conseil d'état
Consensus facit legem
Consequitur quodcunque petit
Conservatism is the pause on the last movement.
Consideration, like an angel, came, / And whipp'd th' offending Adam out of him, / Leaving his body as a paradise, / To envelop and contain celestial spirits.
Consider the lilies of the field, how they grow;
they toil not, neither do they spin; and yet I say unto you, that even Solomon in all his glory was not arrayed like one of these.
Consilio et animis
Conspicuous by its absence.
Constans et fidelitate
Constant attention wears the active mind, / Blots out her powers, and leaves a blank behind.
Constantia et virtute
Constantly choose rather to want less than to have more.
Constant occupation prevents temptation.
Constant thought will overflow in words unconsciously.
Consuetudinis magna vis est
Consuetudo est altera lex
Consuetudo est secunda natura
Consuetudo pro lege servatur
Consult duty, not events.
Contaminate our fingers with base bribes?... I'd rather be a dog and bay the moon than such a Roman.
Contas na maõ, e o demonio no coraçaõ
Contemni est gravius stultitiæ quam percuti
Contemporaries appreciate the man rather than his merit; posterity will regard the merit rather than the man.
Contempt is a dangerous element to sport in; a deadly one, if we habitually live in it.
Contempt is a kind of gangrene, which, if it seizes one part of a character, corrupts all the rest by degrees.
Contempt is the only way to triumph over
calumny.
Contented wi' little, an' cantie (cheerily happy) wi' mair.
Content if hence th' unlearn'd their wants may view, / The learn'd reflect on what before they knew.
Contention is a hydra's head; the more they strive, the more they may.
Contention, like a horse / Full of high feeding, madly hath broken loose, / And bears all down before him.
Contentions fierce, / Ardent, and dire, spring
from no petty cause.
Contentions for trifles can get but a trifling victory.
Content is better than riches.
Content is the true philosopher's stone.
Contentment, as it is a short road and pleasant, has great delight and little trouble.
Contentment consisteth not in adding more
fuel, but in taking away some fire.
Contentment is natural wealth.
Contentment will make a cottage look as fair as a palace.
Contentment without money is the philosopher's stone.
Content's a kingdom, and I wear that crown.
Content thyself to be obscurely good; / When
vice prevails, and impious men bear sway, / The post of honour is a private station.
Content with poverty, my soul I arm; / And virtue, though in rags, will keep me warm.
Contesa vecchia tosto si fa nuova
Conticuere omnes, intentique ora tenebant
Continued eloquence wearies.
Contra bonos mores
Contra malum mortis, non est medicamen in hortis
Contraria contrariis curantur
Contrast increases the splendour of beauty, but it disturbs its influence; it adds to its attractiveness, but diminishes its power.
Contrat social
Contra verbosos noli contendere verbis; /
Sermo datur cunctis, animi sapientia paucis
Contredire, c'est quelquefois frapper à une porte, pour savoir s'il y a quelqu'un dans la maison
Contre fortune bon cœur
Contre les rebelles, c'est cruauté que d'estre humain et humanité d'estre cruel
Contre-temps
Contrivances of the time / For sowing broadcast
the seeds of crime.
Contumeliam si dicis, audies
Conversation enriches the understanding; but solitude is the school of genius.
Conversation in society is found to be on a platform so low as to exclude science, the saint, and the poet.
Conversation is an abandonment to ideas, a surrender to persons.
Conversation is an art in which a man has all
mankind for competitors.
Conversation is a traffic; and if you enter into it without some stock of knowledge to balance the account perpetually, the trade drops at once.
Conversation will not corrupt us if we come to the assembly in our own garb and speech, and with the energy of health to select what is ours and reject what is not.
Converse with a mind that is grandly simple, and literature looks like word-catching.
Conversion--a grand epoch for a man; properly the one epoch; the turning-point which guides upwards, or guides downwards, him and his activities for evermore.
Conversion is the awakening of a soul to see
into the awful
Time and its shows all rest on Eternity, and this poor earth of ours is the threshold either of heaven or hell.
Convey a libel in a frown, / And wink a reputation down.
Convey thy love to thy friend as an arrow to the mark; not as a ball against the wall, to rebound back again.
Conviction, never so excellent, is worthless till it convert itself into conduct.

Coraçaõ determinado, naõ soffre conselho

Corbies (crows) and clergy are kittle shot (hard to hit).

Corporations cannot commit treason, nor be
outlawed nor excommunicated, for they have no souls.
Corporations have neither bodies to be punished nor souls to be damned.

Correction does much, but encouragement does
more.

Corrupted freemen are the worst of slaves.
Corruption is like a ball of snow, when once
set a rolling it must increase.
Corruptions can only be expiated by the blood of the just ascending to heaven by the steps of the scaffold.

Cos ingeniorum
Costly thy habit as thy purse can buy, / But not expressed in fancy; rich, not gaudy; / For the apparel oft proclaims the man.
Costumbre hace ley
Could everything be done twice, it would be done better.
Could great men thunder / As Jove himself does, Jove would ne'er be quiet; / For every pelting, petty officer / Would use his heaven for thunder; nothing but thunder.
Could we forbear dispute and practise love, /
We should agree as angels do above.
Could you see every man's career in life, you would find a woman clogging him ... or cheering him and goading him.
Couleur de rose
Count art by gold, and it fetters the feet it once winged.
Count the world not an inn but an hospital; and a place not to live in, but to die in.
Countries are well cultivated, not as they
are fertile, but as they are free.

Coup d'œil
Courage against misfortune, and reason against passion.
Courage and modesty are the most unequivocal
of virtues, for they are of a kind that hypocrisy cannot imitate.
Courage consists in equality to the problem before us.
Courage consists not in blindly overlooking danger, but in meeting it with the eyes open.
Courage consists not in hazarding without fear, but being resolutely minded in a just cause.
Courage! even sorrows, when once they are vanished, quicken the soul, as rain the valley.
Courage is generosity of the highest order,
for the brave are prodigal of the most precious things.
Courage is on all hands considered an essential of high character.
Courage is the wisdom of manhood; foolhardiness, the folly of youth.
Courage mounteth with occasion.
Courage never to submit or yield.
Courage of soul is necessary for the triumphs
of genius.
Courage of the soldier awakes the courage of woman.
Courage, or the degree of life, is as the degree of circulation of the blood in the arteries.
Courage sans peur
Courage, sir, / That makes man or woman look their goodliest.
Courage, so far as it is a sign of race, is peculiarly the mark of a gentleman or a lady; but it becomes vulgar if rude or insensitive.
Courtesy costs nothing.
Courtesy is cumbersome to him that kens it not.
Courtesy is often sooner found in lowly sheds with smoky rafters, than in tapestry halls and courts of princes, where it first was named.
Courtesy itself must convert to disdain, if you come in her presence.
Courtesy never broke one's crown.
Courtesy of temper, when it is used to veil
churlishness of deed, is but a knight's girdle around the breast of a base clown.
Courtship consists in a number of quiet attentions, not so pointed as to alarm, nor so vague as not to be understood.
Coûte qu'il coûte
Cover yourself with honey and the flies will fasten on you.
Covetous men need money least, yet most affect it; and prodigals, who need it most, do least regard it.
Covetousness bursts the bag.
Covetousness is a sort of mental gluttony, not confined to money, but greedy of honour and feeding on selfishness.
Covetousness is ever attended with solicitude and anxiety.
Covetousness is rich, while modesty goes barefoot.
Covetousness, like jealousy, when it has once taken root, never leaves a man but with his life.
Covetousness often starves other vices.
Covetousness swells the principal to no purpose, and lessens the use to all purposes.
Covetousness, which is idolatry.
Coward dogs / Most spend their mouths when what they seem to threaten / Runs far before them.
Cowardice is the dread of what will happen.
Cowards are cruel, but the brave / Love mercy,
and delight to save.
Cowards die many times before their deaths; / The valiant never taste of death but once. / Of all the wonders that I yet have heard, It seems to me most strange that men should fear; / Seeing that death, a necessary end, / Will come when it will come.
Cowards falter, but danger is often overcome by those who nobly dare.
Cowards father cowards, and base things sire base; / Nature hath meal and bran, contempt and grace.
Cowards tell lies, and those that fear the rod.
Crabbed age and youth / Cannot live together.
Craftiness is a quality in the mind and a vice in the character.
Craft maun hae claes (clothes), but truth gaes naked.
Crafty men contemn studies; simple men admire them; and wise men use them; for they teach not their own use; but that is wisdom without them, and above them won by observation.
Craignez honte
Craignez tout d'un auteur en courroux
Crambe repetita
Cras credemus, hodie nihil
Crea el cuervo, y sacarte ha los ojos
Creaking waggons are long in passing.
Created half to rise and half to fall, / Great
lord of all things, yet a prey to all; / Sole judge of truth, in endless error hurl'd; / The glory, jest, and riddle of the world.
Creation is great, and cannot be understood.
Creation lies before us like a glorious rainbow; but the sun that made it lies behind us, hidden from us.
Creation's heir, the world, the world is mine.
Creation sleeps! 'Tis as the general pulse / Of life stood still, and Nature made a pause, / An awful pause, prophetic of her end.
Credat Judæus Apella
Crede quod est quod vis
Crede quod habes, et habes
Credit keeps the crown o' the causey
Creditors have better memories than debtors.
Credo, quia absurdum
Credula res amor est
Credula vitam / Spes fovet, et fore cras semper ait melius
Credulity is perhaps a weakness almost inseparable from eminently truthful characters.
Credulity is the common failing of inexperienced virtue.
Creep before you gang (walk).
Crescentem sequitur cura pecuniam, / Majorumque fames
Crescit amor nummi quantum ipsa pecunia crescit
Crescit occulto velut arbor ævo
Crescit sub pondere virtus
Cressa ne careat pulchra dies nota
Creta an carbone notandi?
Crime and punishment grow out of one stem.
Punishment is a fruit that, unsuspected, ripens within the flower of the pleasure that concealed it.
Crime cannot be hindered by punishment, but only by letting no man grow up a criminal.
Crime, like virtue, has its degrees.
Crimen læsæ majestatis
Crimen quos inquinat, æquat
Crimes generally punish themselves.
Crimes sometimes shock us too much; vices almost always too little.
Crimina qui cernunt aliorum, non sua cernunt, / Hi sapiunt aliis, desipiuntque sibi
Crimine ab uno / Disce omnes
Cripples are aye better schemers than walkers.
Criticism is a disinterested endeavour to learn
and propagate the best that is known and thought in the world.
Criticism is as often a trade as a science, requiring, as it does, more health than wit, more labour than capacity, more practice than genius.
Criticism is like champagne, nothing more execrable if bad, nothing more excellent if good.
Criticism is not construction; it is observation.
Criticism must never be sharpened into anatomy. The life of the imagination, as of the body, disappears when we pursue it.
Criticism often takes from the tree caterpillars
and blossoms together.
Criticism should be written for the public, not the artist.
Critics all are ready made.
Critics are men who have failed in literature and art.
Critics are sentinels in the grand army of letters, stationed at the corners of newspapers and reviews to challenge every new author.
Critics must excuse me if I compare them to
certain animals called asses, who, by gnawing vines, originally taught the great advantage of pruning them.
Crosses are ladders that lead to heaven.
Crows do not pick out crows' eyes.
Cruci dum spiro fido
Crudelem medicum intemperans æger facit
Crudelis ubique / Luctus, ubique pavor, et
plurima mortis imago
Cruel as death, and hungry as the grave.
Cruel men are the greatest lovers of mercy; avaricious, of generosity; proud, of humility,--in others.
Cruelty in war buyeth conquest at the dearest price.
Cruelty is no more the cure of crimes than it is the cure of sufferings.
Crux criticorum
Crux est si metuas quod vincere nequeas
Crux medicorum
Cry "Havock," and let slip the dogs of war.
Cucullus non facit monachum
Cudgel thy brains no more about it, for your
dull ass will not mend his pace with beating.
Cui bono?
Cuidar muitas cousas, fazer huma
Cuidar naõ he saber
Cui lecta potenter erit res / Nec facundia deseret hunc nec lucidus ordo
Cuilibet in arte sua perito credendum est
Cui licitus est finis, etiam licent media
Cui malo?
Cui mens divinior atque os / Magna sonaturum des nominis hujus honorem
Cui non conveniat sua res, ut calceus olim, / Si pede major erit, subvertet, si minor, uret
Cui placet alterius, sua nimirum est odio sors
Cui placet, obliviscitur; cui dolet, meminit
Cui prodest scelus, is fecit
Cuique suum
Cui serpe mozzica, lucenta teme
Cujus est solum, ejus est usque ad cœlum
Cujus rei libet simulator atque dissimulator
Cujusvis hominis est errare: nullius nisi insipientis in errore perseverare
Cujus vita fulgor, ejus verba tonitrua
Cujus vulturis hoc erit cadaver?
Cul de sac
Culpam pœna premit comes
Cultivated labour drives out brute labour.
Cultivate not only the cornfields of your mind, but the pleasure-grounds also.
Cultivation is as necessary to the mind as food to the body.
Culture, aiming at the perfection of the man as the end, degrades everything else, as health and bodily life, into means.
Culture enables us to express ourselves.
Culture implies all which gives the mind possession of its own powers.
Culture inverts the vulgar views of nature, and brings the mind to call that apparent which it uses to call real, and that real which it uses to call visionary.
Culture is a study of perfection.
Culture is the passion for sweetness and light, and (what is more) the passion for making them prevail.
Culture (is the process by which a man) becomes
all that he was created capable of being, resisting all impediments, casting off all foreign, especially all noxious, adhesions, and showing himself at length in his own shape and stature, be these what they may.
Culture merely for culture's sake can never be anything but a sapless root, capable of producing at best a shrivelled branch.
Culture must not omit the arming of the man.
Culture of the thinking, the dispositions
and the morals is the only education that deserves the name, not mere instruction.
Cum grano salis
Cum privilegio
Cunctando restituit rem
Cuncti adsint, meritæque expectent præmia palmæ
Cunctis servatorem liberatoremque acclamantibus
Cunning is the art of concealing our own defects, and discovering other people's weaknesses.
Cunning is the dwarf of wisdom.
Cunning is the intensest rendering of vulgarity, absolute and utter.
Cunning is to wisdom as an ape to a man.
Cunning leads to knavery; 'tis but a step, and that a very slippery, from the one to the other. Lying only makes the difference; add that to cunning, and it is knavery.
Cunning signifies especially a habit or gift of over-reaching, accompanied with enjoyment and a sense of superiority.
Cunning surpasses strength.
Cupias non placuisse nimis
Cupid is a knavish lad, / Thus to make poor females mad.
Cupid makes it his sport to pull the warrior's plumes.
Cupido dominandi cunctis affectibus flagrantior est
Cupid's butt-shaft is too hard for Hercules'
club.
Curæ leves loquuntur, ingentes stupent
Cura facit canos
Cura pii dis sunt, et qui coluere, coluntur
Cura ut valeas
Curiosa felicitas
Curiosis fabricavit inferos
Curiosity is a desire to know why and how; such as is in no living creature but man.
Curiosity is lying in wait for every secret.
Curiosity is one of the forms of feminine bravery.
Curiosity is the direct incontinency of the spirit.
Knock, therefore, at the door before you enter on your neighbour's privacy; and remember that there is no difference between entering into his house and looking into it.
Curiosity is the kernel of the forbidden fruit.
Curiosus nemo est, quin idem sit malevolus
Curious to think how, for every man, any the truest fact is modelled by the nature of the man.
Currente calamo
Cursed be the social ties that warp us from
the living truth.
Curse on all laws but those which love has made.
Curses always recoil on the head of him who imprecates them. If you put a chain around the neck of a slave, the other end fastens itself around your own.
Curses are like chickens; they always return home.
Curses, not loud, but deep, mouth-honour, breath, / Which the poor heart would fain deny, but dare not.
Curst be the man, the poorest wretch in life, / The crouching vassal to the tyrant wife, / Who has no will but by her high permission; / Who has not sixpence but in her possession; / Who must to her his dear friend's secret tell; / Who dreads a curtain lecture worse than hell. / Were such the wife had fallen to my part, / I'd break her spirit or I'd break her heart.
Curst be the verse, how well soe'er it flow, / That tends to make one worthy man my foe, / Give virtue scandal, innocence a fear, / Or from the soft-ey'd virgin steal a tear.
Curs'd merchandise, where life is sold, / And avarice consents to starve for gold.
Custom does often reason overrule, / And only serves for reason to the fool.
Custom doth make dotards of us all.
Custom forms us all; / Our thoughts, our morals, our most fixed belief, / Are consequences of our place of birth.
Custom is the law of one set of fools, and fashion of another; but the two often clash, for precedent is the legislator of the one and novelty of the other.
Custom is the plague of wise men and the idol of fools.
Custom may lead a man into many errors, but it justifies none.
Custom reconciles to everything.
Custos morum
Custos regni
Custos rotulorum
Cutis vulpina consuenda est cum cute leonis
Cut men's throats with whisperings.
Cut off even in the blossoms of my sin, / Unhousel'd, disappointed, unanel'd; / No reckoning made, but sent to my account / With all my imperfections on my head.
Cut out the love of self, like an autumn lotus, with thy hand.
Cutting honest throats by whispers.
Cut your coat according to your cloth.
Daar niets goeds in is, gaat niets goeds nit
Daar 't een mensch wee doet, daar heeft hij de hand
Daar twee kijven hebben ze beiden schuld
Daar zijn meer dieven als er opgehangen worden
Dabit Deus his quoque finem

D'accord
Da chi mi fido, / Guardi mi Dio. / Da chi non mi fido, / Mi guarderò io
Dachtet ihr, der Löwe schliefe, weil er nicht brüllte?

Dádivas quebrantan peñas

Dafür bin ich ein Mann, dass sich aushalte in dem was ich begonnen, dass ich einstehe mit Leib und Leben für das Trachten meines Geistes
Daily life is more instructive than the most effective book.
Dal detto al fatto v'è un gran tratto
Da locum melioribus
Dame donde me asiente, que yo me haré donde me acueste

Dämmerung ist Menschenlos in jeder Beziehung
Damna minus consueta movent
Damnant quod non intelligunt
Damn'd neuters, in their middle way of steering, / Are neither fish, nor flesh, nor good red-herring.
Damnosa hæreditas
Damnosa quid non imminuit dies?
Damnum absque injuria
Damnum appellandum est cum mala fama lucrum
Damn with faint praise, assent with civil leer, / And without sneering, teach the rest to sneer. / Willing to wound, and yet afraid to strike; / Just hint a fault, and hesitate dislike.
Danari fanno danari
Dance attendance on their lordships' pleasure.
Dan Chaucer, well of English undefiled, / On Fame's eternal bead-roll worthy to be filed.
Dandies, when first-rate, are generally very agreeable men.
Danger for danger's sake is senseless.
Danger is the very basis of superstition. It produces a searching after help supernaturally when human means are no longer supposed to be available.
Danger levels man and brute, / And all are fellows in their need.
Danger past, God forgotten.
Dannosa è il dono che toglie la libertà
Dans l'adversité de nos meilleurs amis, nous trouvons toujours quelque chose qui ne nous déplait pas
Dans la morale, comme l'art, dire n'est rien, faire est tout
Dans l'art d'intéresser consiste l'art d'écrire
Dans le nombre de quarante ne fait-il pas un
zéro?
Dans les conseils d'un état, il ne faut pas tant regarder ce qu'on doit faire, que ce qu'on peut faire
Dante was very bad company, and was never invited to dinner.
Dante, who loved well because he hated, / Hated wickedness that hinders loving.
Dantur opes nulli nunc nisi divitibus
Dapes inemptæ
Dapibus supremi / Grata testudo Jovis
Dare pondus idonea fumo
Dare to be true, nothing can need a lie; / A fault which needs it most, grows two thereby.
Daring nonsense seldom fails to hit, / Like scattered shot, and pass with some for wit.
Darkness visible.
Darkness which may be felt.
Dark night, that from the eye his function takes, / The ear more quick of apprehension makes.
Dark with excessive bright.
Das Alte stürzt, es ändert sich die Zeit, / Und neues Leben blüht aus den Ruinen
Das Alter der göttlichen Phantasie / Es
ist verschwunden, es kehret nie
Das Alter wägt, die Jugend wagt
Das arme Herz, hienieden / Von manchem Sturm bewegt, / Erlangt den wahren Frieden, / Nur, wo es nicht mehr schlägt
Das Auge des Herrn schafft mehr als seine beiden Hände
Das begreife ein andrer als ich!
Das Beste, was wir von der Geschichte haben,
ist der Enthusiasmus, den sie erregt
Das Edle zu erkennen ist Gewinnst / Der nimmer uns entrissen werden kann
Das einfach Schöne soll der Kenner schätzen; / Verziertes aber spricht der Menge zu
Das Erste und Letzte, was vom Genie gefordert wird, ist Wahrheitsliebe
Das Geeinte zu entzweien, das Entzweite zu einigen, ist das Leben der Natur
Das Geheimniss ist für die Glücklichen
Das Genie erfindet, der Witz findet bloss
Das Gesetz ist der Freund des Schwachen
Das Gesetz nur kann uns Freiheit geben
Das Gewebe dieser Welt ist aus Nothwendigkeit und Zufall gebildet; die Vernunft des Menschen stellt sich zwischen beide, und weiss sie zu beherrschen
Das glaub' ich
Das Glück deiner Tage / Wäge nicht mit der Goldwage. / Wirst du die Krämerwage nehmen, / So wirst du dich schämen und dich bequemen
Das Glück giebt Vielen zu viel, aber Keinem genug
Das glücklichste Wort es wird verhöhnt, / Wenn der Hörer ein Schiefohr ist
Das grosse unzerstörbare Wunder ist der Menschenglaube an Wunder
Das Grösste, was dem Menschen begegnen
kann, ist es wohl, in der eigenen Sache die allgemeine zu vertheitigen
Das hat die Freude mit dem Schmerz gemein, / Dass sie die Menschen der Vernunft beraubt
Das Heiligste, die Pflicht, ist leider das, was wir am öftersten in uns bekämpfen und meistens wider Willen thun
Das Herz gleicht dem Mühlsteine der Mehl gibt, wenn man Korn aufshüttet, aber sich selbst zerreibt, wenn man es unterlasst
Das Herz und nicht die Meinung ehrt den Mann
Das höchste Glück ist das, welches unsere
Mängel verbessert und unsere Fehler ausgleicht
Das Hohngelächter der Hölle
Das Ideal in der Kunst, Grösse in Ruhe darzustellen, sei das Ideal auf dem Throne
Das ist die wahre Liebe, die immer und immer sich gleich bleibt, / Wenn man ihr alles gewährt, wenn man ihr alles versagt
Das Jahrhundert / Ist meinem Ideal nicht reif. Ich lebe / Ein Bürge derer, welche kommen werden
Das Kind mit dem Bade verschütten
Das Kleine in einen grossen Sinne behandeln, ist Hoheit des Geistes; das Kleine für gross und wichtig halten, ist Pedantismus
Das Leben dünkt ein ew'ger Frühling mir
Das Leben eines Staates ist, wie ein Strom, in fortgehender Bewegung; wenn der Strom steht, so wird er Eis oder Sumpf
Das Leben gehört den Lebendigen an, und wer lebt, muss auf Wechsel gefasst sein
Das Leben heisst Streben
Das Leben ist die Liebe / Und des Lebens Leben Geist
Das Leben ist nur ein Moment, der Tod ist auch nur einer
Das Leben lehrt uns, weniger mit uns / Und andern strenge sein
Das Nächste das Liebste
Das Nächste steht oft unergreifbar fern
Da spatium tenuemque moram; male cuncta, ministrat / Impetus
Das Publikum, das ist ein Mann / Der alles weiss und gar nichts kann
Das Recht hat eine wächserne Nase
Das Reich der Dichtung ist das Reich der Wahrheit / Schliesst auf das Heiligthum, es werde Licht
Das Schicksal ist ein vornehmer aber theurer
Hofmeister
Das schönste Glück des denkenden Menschen ist, das Erforschliche erforscht zu haben, und das Unerforschliche ruhig zu verehren
Das schwere Herz wird nicht durch Worte leicht
Das Schwerste in allen Werken der Kunst ist dass dasjenige, was sehr ausgearbeitet worden, nicht ausgearbeitet scheine
Das Siegel der Wahrheit ist Einfachheit
Das sind die Weisen, / Die durch Irrtum zur
Wahrheit reisen; / Die bei dem Irrtum verharren, / Das sind die Narren
Das Sprichwort sagt: Ein eigner Herd, / Ein braves Weib sind Gold und Perlen wert
Das Talent arbeitet, das Genie schafft
Das Unglück kann die Weisheit nicht, Doch Weisheit kann das Unglück tragen
Das Universum ist ein Gedanke Gottes
Das Unvermeidliche mit Würde trage
Das Vaterland der Gedanken ist das Herz: an dieser Quelle muss schöpfen, wer frisch trinken will
Das Verhängte muss geschehen, / Das Gefürchte muss nahn
Das Volk ist frei; seht an, wie wohl's ihm geht!
Das Volk schätzt Stärke vor allem
Das Vortreffliche ist unergründlich, man mag damit anfangen was man will
Das Wahre ist gottähnlich; es erscheint nicht unmittelbar, wir müssen es ans seinen Manifestationen errathen
Das Warum wird offenbar, / Wann die Toten aufersteh'n
Das was mir wichtig scheint, hältst du für
Kleinigkeiten; / Das was mich ärgert hat bei dir nichts zu bedeuten
Das Weib sieht tief, der Mann sieht weit. Dem Manne ist die Welt das Herz, dem Weibe ist das Herz die Welt

Das Wort ist frei, die That ist stumm, der Gehorsam blind

Davus sum, non Œdipus
Dawted dochters mak' dawly wives
Day follows the murkiest night; and when the time comes, the latest fruits also ripen.
Day is driven on by day, and the new moons
hasten to their wane.
Daylight will come, though the cock does not crow.
Days should speak, and multitude of years should teach wisdom.
De adel der ziel is meer waardig dan de adel des geslachts
Dead men open living men's eyes.
Dead scandals form good subjects for dissection.
De alieno largitor, et sui restrictor
Deal mildly with his youth; / For young hot colts, being raged, do rage the more.
Deal so plainly with man and woman as to constrain the utmost sincerity and destroy all hope of trifling with you.
Dear is cheap, and cheap is dear.
Dear son of memory, great heir of fame.
Death and life are in the power of the tongue.
Death-bed repentance is sowing seed at Martinmas.
Death borders upon our birth, and our cradle stands in the grave.
Death but supplies the oil for the inextinguishable lamp of life.
Death comes equally to us all, and makes us
all equal when it comes.
Death finds us 'mid our playthings--snatches us, / As a cross nurse might do a wayward child. / From all our toys and baubles.
Death gives us sleep, eternal youth, and immortality.
Death is a black camel that kneels at every man's door.
Death is a commingling of eternity with time; in the death of a good man eternity is seen looking through time.
Death is a fearful thing.
Death is a friend of ours, and he who is not ready to entertain him is not at home.
Death is but another phasis of life, which also is awful, fearful, and wonderful, reaching to heaven and hell.
Death is but a word to us. Our own experience alone can teach us the real meaning of the word.
Death is but what the haughty brave, / The weak must bear, the wretch must crave.
Death is sure / To those that stay and those
that roam.
Death is the only physician, the shadow of his valley the only journeying that will cure us of age and the gathering fatigue of years.
Death is the quiet haven of us all.
Death is the tyrant of the imagination.
Death is the wish of some, the relief of many, and the end of all.
Death joins us to the great majority; / 'Tis to be borne to Platos and to Cæsars; / 'Tis to be great for ever; / 'Tis pleasure, 'tis ambition, then, to die.
Death lays his icy hand on kings.
Death levels all distinctions.
Death lies on her, like an untimely frost, / Upon the sweetest flower of all the field.
Death may expiate faults, but it does not
repair them.
Death opens the gate of fame, and shuts the gate of envy after it.
Death pays all debts.
Death puts an end to all rivalship and competition. The dead can boast no advantage over us, nor can we triumph over them.
Death rides in every passing breeze, / He lurks in every flower.
Death's but a path that must be trod, / If
man would ever pass to God.
Death shuns the wretch who fain the blow would meet.
Death, so called, is a thing which makes men weep, / And yet a third of life is passed in sleep.
Death stands behind the young man's back, before the old man's face.
Death treads in pleasure's footsteps round the world.
Death will have his day.
De auditu
Debate is masculine, conversation is feminine; the former angular, the latter circular and radiant of the underlying unity.
De beste zaak heeft nog een goed' advocaat noodig
Debetis velle quæ velimus
De bonne grâce
De bonne lutte
De bon vouloir servir le roy
Debt is the worst kind of poverty.
Debt is to a man what the serpent is to the bird; its eye fascinates, its breath poisons, its coil crushes both sinew and bone; its jaw is the pitiless grave.
Debts make the cheeks black.
De calceo sollicitus, at pedem nihil curans
Deceit and falsehood, whatever conveniences they may for a time promise or produce, are, in the sum of life, obstacles to happiness.
Deceit is a game played only by small minds.
Decency is the least of all laws, yet it is the one which is the most strictly observed.
Deceptio visus
Decet affectus animi neque se nimium erigere nec subjicere serviliter
Decet imperatorem stantem mori
Decet patriam nobis cariorem esse quam nosmetipsos
Decet verecundum esse adolescentem
Decies repetita placebit
Decipimur specie recti
Decipit / Frons prima multos
Decision and perseverance are the noblest qualities of man.
Declaring the end from the beginning, and from the ancient times the things that are not yet done.

Decorum ab honesto non potest separari
De court plaisir, long repentir

De die in diem
Dedimus potestatem
Dediscit animus sero quod didicit diu
Deeds survive the doers.
Deep calleth unto deep.
Deep insight will always, like Nature, ultimate its thought in a thing.
Deep in the frozen regions of the north, / A goddess violated brought thee forth, / Immortal liberty.
Deep on his front engraven / Deliberation sat, and public care.
Deep subtle wits, / In truth, are master spirits in the world.
Deep vengeance is the daughter of deep                               55 silence.
Deep vers'd in books, and shallow in himself.
De ezels dragen de haver, en de paarden eten die
De facto
Defeat is a school in which truth always grows strong.
Defeat is nothing but education, nothing but                         60 the first step to something better.
Defect in manners is usually the defect of fine perception.
Defectio virium adolescentiæ vitiis efficitur sæpius quam senectutis
Defendit numerus junctæque umbone phalanges
Defend me, common sense, say I, / From reveries so airy, from the toil / Of dropping buckets into empty wells, / And growing old with drawing nothing up.
Defend me from my friends; I can defend myself from my enemies.
Deference is the most complicate, the most indirect, and the most elegant of all compliments.
Defer no time; / Delays have dangerous ends.
Defer not the least virtue; life's poor span /
Make not an ell, by trifling in thy woe. / If thou do ill, the joy fades, not the pains; / If well, the pain doth fade, the joy remains.
Defer not till to-morrow to be wise, / To-morrow's sun to thee may never rise.
Deficiunt vires
Defienda me Dios de my
Definition of words has been commonly called a mere exercise of grammarians; but when we come to consider the innumerable evils men have inflicted on each other from mistaking the meaning of words, the exercise of definition certainly begins to assume rather a more dignified aspect.
Deformed, unfinished, sent before my time /
Into this breathing world, scarce half made up, / And that so lamely and unfashionable, / That dogs bark at me as I halt by them.
Deformity is daring; it is its essence to overtake mankind by heart and soul, and make itself the equal, ay, the superior of the rest.

De gaieté de cœur
Degeneres animos timor arguit
Degli uomini si può dire questo generalmente che sieno ingrate, volubili simulatori, fuggitori pericoli, cupidi di guadagno
Degrees infinite of lustre there must always be, but the weakest among us has a gift, however seemingly trivial, which is peculiar to him, and which, worthily used, will be a gift also to his race for ever.
De gustibus non disputandum
De hambre a nadie vi morir, de mucho comer a cien mil

De hoc multi multa, omnes aliquid, nemo satis

Dei jussu non unquam credita Teneris
Deil stick pride, for my dog deed o'd.

a' their weel-swall'd kytes belyve / Are bent like drums, / And auld guid man maist like to rive / "Bethankit" hums.

De kleine dieven hangt men, de groote laat men loopen

De lana caprina
Delay has always been injurious to those who are ready.
Delay in vengeance gives a heavier blow.
Delay of justice is injustice.
Delectando pariterque monendo
Delenda est Carthago
Del giudizio, ognun ne vende
Deliberando sæpe perit occasio
Deliberandum est diu quod statuendum est semel
Deliberate treachery entails punishment upon the traitor.
Deliberate with caution, but act with decision;
and yield with graciousness or oppose with firmness.
Deliberat Roma, perit Saguntum
Delicacy is to the affections what grace is to the beauty.
Delicacy of taste has the same effect as delicacy of passion; it enlarges the sphere both of our happiness and misery, and makes us sensible to pain as well as pleasures, which escape the rest of mankind.
Deliciæ illepidæ atque inelegantes
Deligas tantum quem diligas
Delightful task! to rear the tender thought, / To teach the young idea how to shoot.
Deliramenta doctrinæ
Delirant reges, plectuntur Achivi
Deliriums are dreams not rounded with a sleep.
Deliverer, God hath appointed thee to free the oppressed and crush the oppressor.
Dell' albero non si giudica dalla scorza
De loin c'est quelque chose, et de près ce n'est rien
Delphinum sylvis appingit, fluctibus aprum
De lunatico inquirendo
Delusion and weakness produce not one mischief the less because they are universal.
Delusion may triumph, but the triumphs of delusion are but for a day.
Delusions are as necessary to our happiness as realities.
Delusive ideas are the motives of the greatest
part of mankind, and a heated imagination the power by which their actions are incited. The world in the eye of a philosopher may be said to be a large madhouse.
Del vero s'adira l'uomo
De mal en pis
De male quæsitis vix gaudet tertius hæres
Demean thyself more warily in thy study than in the street. If thy public actions have a hundred witnesses, thy private have a thousand.
De medietate linguæ
Dem Esel träumet von Disteln
Dem Glücklichen schlägt keine Stunde
Dem harten Muss bequemt sich Will' und Grille
Dem Herlichsten, was auch der Geist empfangen, drängt Stoff sich an
Dem Hunde, wenn er gut gezogen / Wird
selbst ein weiser Mann gewogen
De minimis non curat lex
Dem Menschen ist / Ein Mensch noch immer lieber als ein Engel
Democracies are prone to war, and war consumes them.
Democracy has done a wrong to everything that is not first-rate.
Democracy is always the work of kings.
Ashes, which in themselves are sterile, fertilise the land they are cast upon.
Democracy is, by the nature of it, a self-cancelling business, and gives in the long-run a net result of zero.
Democracy is the healthful life-blood which circulates through the veins and arteries, which supports the system, but which ought never to appear externally, and as the mere blood itself.
Democracy is the most powerful solvent of military organisation. The latter is founded on discipline; the former on the negation of discipline.
De monte alto
De mortuis nil nisi bonum
De motu proprio
Dem thätigen Menschen kommt es darauf an, dass er das Rechte thue; ob das Rechte geschehe, soll ihn nicht kümmern
Den Bösen sind sie los; die Bösen sind geblieben
De nihilo nihil, in nihilum nil posse reverti
Denique non omnes eadem mirantur amantque
Den Irrthum zu bekennen, schändet nicht
Denken und Thun, Thun und Denken, das ist die Summe aller Weisheit von jeher anerkannt, von jeher geübt, nicht eingesehen von einem jeden
Denke nur niemand, dass man auf ihn als den Heiland gewartet habe
Den leeren Schlauch bläst der Wind auf, / Den leeren Kopf der Dünkel
Den Mantel nach dem Winde kehren
Den Menschen Liebe, den Göttern Ehrfurcht
Denn geschwätzig sind die Zeiten, / Und sie sind auch wieder stumm
De non apparentibus, et non existentibus, eadem est ratio
De novo
Den Profit som kom seent, er bedre end aldeles
ingen
Den rechten Weg wirst nie vermissen, / Handle nur nach Gefühl und Gewissen
Den schlecten Mann muss man verachten / Der nie bedacht was er vollbringt
Dens theonina
Deo adjuvante non timendum
Deoch an doris
Deo dante nil nocet invidia, et non dante, nil
proficit labor
Deo date
Deo duce, ferro comitante
Deo duce, fortuna comitante

Deo favente
Deo fidelis et regi

Deo juvante
De omnibus rebus, et quibusdam aliis
De omni re scibile et quibusdam aliis
Deo, non fortuna
Deo, optimo maximo
Deo, patriæ, amicis
Deo, regi, patriæ
Deo, regi, vicino
Deo, republicæ, amicis
Deorum cibus est
De oui et non vient toute question
Deo volente
Depart from the highway and transplant thyself in some enclosed ground; for it is hard for a tree that stands by the wayside to keep her fruit till it be ripe.
De paupertate tacentes / Plus poscente ferent
De' peccati de' signori fanno penitenza i poveri
Dependence goes somewhat against the grain
of a generous mind; and it is no wonder, considering the unreasonable advantage which is often taken of the inequality of fortune.
Dependence is a perpetual call upon humanity, and a greater incitement to tenderness and pity than any other motive whatsoever.
Depend upon it, if a man talks of his misfortunes, there is something in them that is not disagreeable to him.
De pilo
De pis en pis
De plano
De præscientia Dei
Deprendi miserum est
Depressus extollor
De profundis
De propaganda fide
De publico est elatus
Der Ausgang giebt den Thaten ihre Titel
Der beste Prediger ist die Zeit
Der Böse hat nicht nur die Guten, sondern auch die Bösen gegen sich
Der brave Mann denkt an sich selbst zuletzt
Der civilisierte Wilde ist der schlimmste aller Wilden
Der den Augenblick ergreift / Das ist der rechte Mann
Der Dichter steht auf einer höhern Warte / Als auf den Zinnen der Partei
Der echte Geist schwingt sich empor / Und rafft die Zeit sich nach
Derelictio communis utilitatis contra naturam
Der Erde Paradies und Hölle / Liegt in dem Worte "Weib"
Der Fluss bleibt trüb, der nicht durch einen See gegangen, / Das Herz unsauber, das nicht durch ein Weh gegangen
Der Frauen Zungen ja nimmer ruhn
Der Friede ist immer die letzte Absicht des Krieges
Der Fuchs ändert den Pelz und behält den
Schalk
Der Fürst ist nichts, als der erste Diener des Staates
Der Geist, aus dem wir handeln, ist das Höchste
Der Geist der Medicin ist leicht zu fassen; / Ihr durchstudiert die gross' und kleine Welt, / Um es am Ende gehn zu lassen, / Wie's Gott gefällt
Der Geist, der stets verneint
Der Geist ist immer autochthone
Der geringste Mensch kann complet sein, wenn er sich innerhalb der Gränzen seiner Fähigkeiten und Fertigkeiten bewegt
Der Glaube ist der rechte, der, dass er der rechte bleibt, nicht gezwungen ist einen andern irrgläubig zu finden
Der Gott, der mir im Busen wohnt, / Kann
tief mein Innerstes erregen; der über allen meinen Kräften thront, er kann nach aussen nichts bewegen
Der grösste Mensch bleibt stets ein Menschenkind
Der grösste Schritt ist der aus der Thür
Der gute Mann braucht überall viel Boden
Der gute Wille ist in der Moral alles; aber in der Kunst ist er nichts: da gilt, wie schon das Wort andeutet, allein Können
Der Hahn schliesst die Augen, wann er krähet,
weil er es auswendig kann
Der Handelnde ist immer gewissenlos, es hat niemand Gewissen, als der Betrachtende
Der hat die Macht, an den die Menge glaubt
Der hat nie das Glück gekostet, der's in Ruh geniessen will
Der Hauptfehler des Menschen bleibt, dass er so viele kleine hat
Der Himmel giebt die Gunst des Augenblicks; /
Wer schnell sie fasst, wird Meister des Geschicks
Der Himmel kann ersetzen / Was er entzogen hat
Der Historiker ist ein rückwärts gekehrter Prophet
Der höchste Stolz und der höchste Kleinmuth ist die höchste Unkenntniss seiner selbst
Der höchste Vorwurf der Kunst für denkende Menschen ist der Mensch
Deridet, sed non derideor
Der Irrthum ist recht gut, so lange wir jung sind; man muss ihn nur nicht mit ins Alter schleppen
Der ist edel, / Welcher edel fühlt und handelt
Der Jugend Führer sei das Alter; beiden sei / Nur wenn sie als Verbundne wandeln, Glück versichert
Der Jüngling kämpft, damit der Greis geniesse
Der kann nicht klagen über harten Spruch,
den man zum Meister seines Schicksals macht
Der kleine Gott der Welt bleibt stets von gleichem Schlag / Und ist so wunderlich, als wie am ersten Tag
Der Krieg ist die stärkende Eisenkur der Menschheit
Der Künstler muss mit Feuer entwerfen und mit Phlegma ausführen
Der Lebende hat Recht
Der Mann, der das Wenn und das Aber
erdacht / Hat sicher aus Häckerling Gold schon gemacht
Der Mann muss hinaus ins feindliche Leben
Der Mensch begreift niemals wie anthropomorphisch er ist
Der Mensch denkt, Gott lenkt
Der Menschenkenner steht überall an seinem Platze
Der Mensch erfährt, er sei auch wer er mag, /
Ein letztes Glück und einen letzten Tag
Der Mensch hat nur allzusehr Ursache, sich vor dem Menschen zu schützen
Der Mensch ist ein nachahmendes Geschöpf und wer der vorderste ist, führt die Herde
Der Mensch ist entwickelt, nicht erschaffen
Der Mensch ist frei geschaffen, ist frei, / Und würd' er in Ketten geboren!
Der Mensch ist frei wie der Vogel im Käfig; er kann sich innerhalb gewisser Grenzen bewegen
Der Mensch ist im Grunde ein wildes, entsetzliches Thier
Der Mensch ist nicht bloss ein denkendes, er ist zugleich ein empfindendes Wesen. Er ist ein Ganzes, eine Einheit vielfacher, innig verbundner Kräfte, und zu diesem Ganzen muss das Kunstwerk reden
Der Mensch ist nicht geboren frei zu sein /
Und für den Edeln ist kein schöner Glück / Als einem Fürst, den er ehrt, zu dienen
Der Mensch ist selbst sein Gott, sein Beruf ist: Handeln
Der Mensch ist, was er isst
Der Mensch liebt nur einmal
Der Mensch muss bei dem Glauben verharren, dass das Unbegreifliche begreiflich sei; er würde sonst nicht forschen
Der Mensch muss ein Höheres, ein Göttliches
anerkennen--ob in sich oder über sich, gleichviel
Der Mensch versuche die Götter nicht
Der Mensch war immer Mensch, voll Unvollkommenheit
Der Mensch, wo ist er her? / Zu schlecht für einen Gott, zu gut für's Ungefähr
Der Muth der Wahrheit ist die erste Bedingung des philosophischen Studiums
Dernier ressort
Der Pfaff liebt seine Herde, doch die Lämmlein mehr als die Widder
Der preise glücklich sein, der von / Den Göttern dieser Welt entfernt lebt
Der Rathgeber eines Höheren handelt klüglich, wenn er sein geistiges Uebergewicht verbirgt, wie das Weib seine Schönheit verhüllt um des Sieges desto gewisser zu sein
Derrière la croix souvent se tient le diable
Der Ring macht Ehen, / Und Ringe sind's, die
eine Kette machen
Der Rose süsser Duft genügt, / Man braucht sie nicht zu brechen / Und wer sich mit dem Duft begnügt / Den wird ihr Dorn nicht stechen
Der Schein regiert die Welt, und die Gerechtigkeit ist nur auf der Bühne
Der Schein, was ist er, dem das Wesen fehlt? / Das Wesen wär' es, wenn es nicht erschiene?
Der Schmerz ist die Geburt der höheren Naturen
Der Sinn erweitert, aber lähmt; die That
belebt, aber beschränkt
Der Stärkste hat Recht
Der Stein im Sumpf / Macht keine Ringe
Der Tod entbindet von erzwungnen Pflichten
Der Umgang mit Frauen ist das Element guter Sitten
Der Verständige findet fast alles lächerlich,
der Vernünftige fast nichts
Der Vortrag macht des Redners Glück
Der Wahn ist kurz, die Reu' ist lang
Der Weg der Ordnung, ging er auch durch Krümmen, / Er ist kein Umweg
Der Weise hat die Ohren lang, die Zunge kurz
Der Weise kann des Mächtigen Gunst entbehren,
/ Doch nicht der Mächtige des Weisen Lehren
Der Wille ist des Werkes Seele
Der wird stets das Beste missen / Wer nicht borgt, was andre wissen
Der Witz ist die Freiheit des Sklaven
Der Zug des Herzens ist des Schicksals Stimme
Descend a step in choosing thy wife; ascend a step in choosing thy friend.
Description is always a bore, both to the describer
and the describee.
Deserted, at his utmost need, / By those his former bounty fed, / On the bare earth exposed be lies, / With not a friend to close his eyes.
Desiderantem quod satis est, neque / Tumultuosum sollicitat mare, / Non verberatæ grandine vineæ / Fundusque mendax
Desideratum
Desine fata Deum flecti sperare precando
Desinit in piscem mulier formosa superne
Désir de Dieu et désir de l'homme sont deux
Desires are the pulse of the soul.
Des Lebens Mühe / Lehrt uns allein des Lebens Güter schätzen
Des Mannes Mutter ist der Frau Teufel
Des Menschen Engel ist die Zeit
Des Menschens Leben ist / Ein kurzes Blühen und ein langes Welken
Despair defies even despotism; there is that in my heart would make its way through hosts with levelled spears.
Despair is like froward children, who, when you take away one of their playthings, throw the rest into the fire for madness.
Despair is the only genuine atheism.
Despair takes heart when there's no hope to
speed; / The coward then takes arms and does the deed.
Despair--the last dignity of the wretched.
Despatch is the soul of business.
Desperate diseases need desperate remedies.
Despise anxiety and wishing, the past and the future.
Despise not any man, and do not spurn anything;
for there is no man that has not his hour, nor is there anything that has not its place.
Despise not the discoveries of the wise, but acquaint thyself with their proverbs, for of them thou shalt learn instruction.
Despise your enemy and you will soon be beaten.
Despite his titles, power, and pelf, / The wretch concentred all in self, / Living, shall forfeit fair renown, / And, doubly dying, shall go down / To the vile dust, from whence he sprung, / Unwept, unhonoured, and unsung.
Despondency comes readily enough to the most sanguine.
Desponding fear, of feeble fancies full, / Weak
and unmanly, loosens every power.
Despotism is a legitimate mode of government in dealing with barbarians, provided the end be their improvement, and the means justified by actually effecting that end.
Despotism is essential in most enterprises; I am told they do not tolerate "freedom of debate" on board a seventy-four.
Despotism is often the effort of Nature to cure herself from a worse disease.
Despotism sits nowhere so secure as under the effigy and ensigns of freedom.
Despotismus ist der schwarze Punkt in aller
Menschen Herzen
Desque nací lloré, y cada dia nace porqué
Des Rats bedarf die Seele nicht, die Rechtes will
Destiny is our will, and will is nature.
Destitutus ventis remos adhibe

creature's at his dirty work again.
Des Uebels Quelle findest du nicht aus, und aufgefunden fliesst sie ewig fort

De tout s'avise à qui pain faut

and every evening will find something done.
