Did charity prevail, the press would prove / A
vehicle of virtue, truth, and love.
Did I know that my heart was bound to temporal possessions, I would throw the flaming brand among them with my own hand.
"Did I not tell you that after thunder rain would be sure to come on?"
Didst thou but know the inly touch of love, / Thou wouldst as soon go kindle fire with snow, / As seek to quench the fire of love with words.
Did you ever hear of Captain Wattle? / He was all for love and a little for the bottle.
Die Aemter sind Gottes; die Amtleute Teufels
Die alleinige Quelle des Rechts ist das gemeinsame Bewusstsein des ganzen Volks; der allgemeine Geist
Die Alten sind die einzigen Alten, die nie alt werden
Die Anmut macht unwiderstehlich
Die ärgsten Studenten werden die frömmsten Prediger
Die Armen müssen tanzen wie die Reichen
pfeifen
Die Augen glauben sich selbst, die Ohren andern Leuten
Die Augen sind weiter als der Bauch
Die besten Freunde stehen im Beutel
Die Bewunderung preist, die Liebe ist stumm
Die Blumen zu pflegen, / Das Unkraut zu
tilgen, / Ist Sache des Gärtners
Die Botschaft hör' ich wohl, allein mir fehlt der Glaube
Die Damen geben sich und ihren Putz zum besten / Und spielen ohne Gage mit
Die Dämmerung ist das freundliche Licht der Liebenden
Die de wereld wel beziet, men zag nooit schoonder niet
Die Dornen, die Disteln, sie stechen gar sehr,
doch stechen die Altjungfernzungen noch mehr
Die een ander jaagt zit zelfs niet stil
Die Ehe ist Himmel und Hölle
Die eigentliche Religion bleibt ein Inneres, ja Individuelles, denn sie hat ganz allein mit dem Gewissen zu thun; dieses soll erregt, soll beschwichtigt werden
Die Einsamkeit ist noth; doch sei nur nicht gemein, / So kannst du überall in einer Wüste sein
Die Eintracht nur macht stark und gross, /
Die Zwietracht stürzet alles nieder
Die Erde wird durch Liebe frei; / Durch Thaten wird sie gross
Die Erinnerung ist das einzige / Paradies, aus dem wir nicht vertrieben werden kann
Die Fabel ist der Liebe Heimatwelt, / Gern wohnt sie unter Feen, Talismanen, / Glaubt gern an Götter, weil sie göttlich ist
Die Frauen sind das einzige Gefäss, was uns Neuern noch geblieben ist, um unsere Idealität hineinzugiessen
Die Frauen tragen ihre Beweise im Herzen,
die Männer im Kopfe
Die Freiheit der Vernunft ist unser wahres Leben
Die Freiheit kann nicht untergehn, / So lange Schmiede Eisen hämmern
Die Freude kennst du nicht, wenn du nur Freuden kennest; / Dir fehlt das ganze Licht, wenn du's in Strahlen trennest
Die Freudigkeit ist die Mutter aller Tugenden
Die Gegenwart ist eine mächtige Göttin; Lern'
ihren Einfluss kennen
Die Geheimnisse der Lebenspfade darf und kann man nicht offenbaren; es gibt Steine des Anstosses, über die ein jeder Wanderer stolpern muss. Der Poet aber deutet auf die Stelle hin
Die Geisterwelt ist nicht verschlossen; / Dein Sinn ist zu, dein Herz ist todt
Die Geschichte der Wissenschaften ist eine grosse Fuge, in der die Stimmen der Völker nach und nach zum Vorschein kommen
Die Geschichte des Menschen ist sein Charakter
Die Gesetze der Moral sind auch die der
Kunst
Die Glocken sind die Artillerie der Geistlichkeit
Die goldne Zeit, wohin ist sie geflohen? / Nach der sich jedes Herz vergebens sehnt
Die Götter brauchen manchen guten Mann / Zu ihrem Dienst auf dieser weiten Erde. / Sie haben noch auf dich gezählt
Die Götter sprechen nur durch unser Herz zu uns
Die grosse Moral--das Interesse, sagte Mirabeau,
tötet in der Regel die kleine--das Gewissen
Die grössten Menschen hängen immer mit ihrem Jahrhundert durch eine Schwachheit zusammen
Die grössten Schwierigkeiten liegen da, wo wir sie nicht suchen
Die het in het vuur verloren heeft, moet het in de asch zoeken
Die Hindus der Wüste geloben keine Fische zu essen
Die höchste Naturschönheit ist das gottgleiche Wesen: der Mensch
Die höchste Weisheit ist, nicht weise stets zu sein
Die Hölle selbst hat ihre Rechte?
Die Ideale sind zerronnen, / Die einst das trunkne Herz geschwellt
Die Idee ist ewig und einzig.... Alles was
wir gewahr werden und wovon wir reden können, sind nur Manifestationen der Idee
Die Irrthümer des Menschen machen ihn eigentlich liebenswürdig
Diejenige Regierung ist die beste, die sich überflüssig macht
Die Kinder sind mein liebster Zeitvertreib
Die Kirche hat einen guten Magen, hat ganze Länder aufgefressen, und doch noch nie sich übergessen
Die Kirche ist's, die heilige, die hohe, / Die zu
dem Himmel uns die Leiter baut
Die Kleinen reden gar so gern von dem was die Grossen thun
Die Klugheit sich zur Führerin zu wählen / Das ist es, was den Weisen macht
Die Kraft ist schwach, allein die Lust ist gross
Die kranke Seele muss sich selber helfen
Die Krankheit des Gemütes löset sich / In
Klagen und Vertrauen am leichtesten auf
Die Kunst darf nie ein Kunststück werden
Die Kunst geht nach Brod
Die Kunst ist eine Vermittlerin des Unaussprechlichen
Die Leidenschaften sind Mängel oder Tugenden, nur gesteigerte
Die Leidenschaft flieht, / Die Liebe muss bleiben;
/ Die Blume verblüht, / Die Frucht muss treiben
Die letzte Wahl steht auch dem Schwächsten offen; / Ein Sprung von dieser Brücke macht mich frei
Die Liebe hat kein Mass der Zeit; sie keimt / Und blüht und reift in einer schönen Stunde
Die Liebe ist der Liebe Preis
Die Liebe macht zum Goldpalast die Hütte
Die Lieb' umfasst des Weibes volles Leben, /
Sie ist ihr Kerker und ihr Himmelreich
Die Lust ist mächtiger als alle Furcht der Strafe
Die Lust zu reden kommt zu rechter Stunde, / Und wahrhaft fliesst das Wort aus Herz und Munde
Die Manifestationen der Idee als des Schönen, ist eben so flüchtig, als die Manifestationen des Erhabenen, des Geistreichen, des Lustigen, des Lächerlichen. Dies ist die Ursache, warum so schwer darüber zu reden ist
Die Meisterhaft gilt oft für Egoismus
Die Menge macht den Künstler irr' und scheu
Die Menschen fürchtet nur, wer sie nicht kennt, / Und wer sie meidet, wird sie bald verkennen
Die Menschen kennen einander nicht leicht, selbst mit dem besten Willen und Vorsatz; nun tritt noch der böse Wille hinzu, der Alles entstellt
Die Menschen sind im ganzen Leben blind
Die Menschheit geben uns Vater und Mutter, die Menschlichkeit aber gibt uns nur die Erziehung
Die Milde ziemt dem Weibe, / Dem Manne
ziemt die Rache!
Die Mode ist weiblichen Geschlechts, hat folglich ihre Launen
Die monarchische Regierungsform ist die dem Menschen natürliche
Die Moral steckt in kurzen Sprüchen besser, als in langen Reden und Predigten
Diem perdidi!
Die Mütter geben uns von Geiste Wärme, und die Väter Licht
Die Natur ist ein unendlich geteilter Gott
Die Natur weiss allein, was sie will
Die of a rose in aromatic pain.
Die Phantasie ward auserkoren / Zu öffnen
uns die reiche Wunderwelt
Die Rachegötter schaffen im Stillen
Dies adimit ægritudinem
Die Schönheit ist das höchste Princip und der höchste Zweck der Kunst
Die Schönheit ist vergänglich, die ihr doch / Allein zu ehren scheint. Was übrig bleibt, / Das reizt nicht mehr, und was nicht reizt, ist tot
Die Schönheit ruhrt, doch nur die Anmuth
sieget, / Und Unschuld nur behält den Preis
Die Schulden sind der nächste Erbe
Die Schwierigkeiten wachsen, je näher man dem Ziele kommt
Dies datus
Dies faustus
Dies infaustus
Die Sinne trügen nicht, aber das Urteil trügt
Dies iræ, dies illa, / Sæclum solvet in favilla / Teste David cum Sibylla
Dies non
Die Sorgen zu bannen, / (Das Unkraut des Geistes), den Kummer zu scheuchen, / Die Schmerzen zu lindern, / Ist Sache des Sängers
Die Sorg' um Künft'ges niemals frommt; Man
fühlt kein Uebel, bis es kommt. / Und wenn man's fühlt, so hilft kein Rat; / Weisheit ist immer zu früh und zu spat
Dies religiosi
Die süssesten Trauben hängen am höchsten
Diet cures more than doctors.
Die te veel onderneemt slaagt zelden
Die That allein beweist der Liebe Kraft
Die Thätigkeit ist was den Menschen glücklich macht; / Die, erst das Gute schaffend, bald ein Uebel selbst / Durch göttlich wirkende Gewalt in Gutes kehrt
Die Todten reiten schnell!
Die treue Brust des braven Manns allein ist ein sturmfester Dach in diesen Zeiten
Die Tugend des Menschen, der nach dem Geboten der Vernunft lebt, zeigt sich gleich gross in Vermeidung, wie in Ueberwindung der Gefahren
Die Tugend grosser Seelen ist Gerechtigkeit
Die Tugend ist das höchste Gut, / Das Laster Weh dem Menschen thut
Die Tugend ist nicht ein Wissen, sondern ein Wollen
Die Tugend ohne Lohn ist doppelt schön
Dieu aide à trois sortes de personnes, aux fous, aux enfants, et aux ivrognes
Dieu avec nous
Dieu ayde
Dieu défend le droit
Dieu donne le froid selon le drap
Dieu et mon droit
Dieu fit du repentir la vertu des mortels
Dieu garde la lune des loups
Dieu mésure le froid à la brebis tondue
Die unbegreiflich hohen Werke / Sind herrlich wie am ersten Tag
Dieu nous garde d'un homme qui n'a qu'une affaire
Die Unschuld hat im Himmel einen Freund
Die Unsterblichkeit ist nicht jedermann's Sache
Dieu pour la tranchée, qui contre?
Dieu seul devine les sots
Die veel dienstboden heeft, die heeft veel dieven
Die vernünftige Welt ist als ein grosses unsterbliches Individuum zu betrachten, das unaufhaltsam das Nothwendige bewirkt und dadurch sich sogar über das Zufällige zum Herrn macht
Die Vernunft ist auf das Werdende, der Verstand auf das Gewordene angewiesen; jene bekümmert sich nicht: wozu? dieser fragt nicht: woher?
Die Wacht am Rhein
Die Wahrheit richtet sich nicht nach uns, sondern wir müssen uns nach ihr richten
Die Wahrheit schwindet von der Erde / Auch
mit der Treu' ist es vorbei, / Die Hunde wedeln noch und stinken / Wie sonst, doch sind sie nicht mehr treu
Die Wahrheit zu sagen ist nützlich dem, der höret, schädlich dem der spricht
Die wankelmüt'ge Menge, / Die jeder Wind herumtreibt! Wehe dem, / Der auf dies Rohr sich lehnet
Die Weiber lieben die Stärke ohne sie nachzuahmen; die Männer die Zartheit, ohne sie zu erwiedern
Die Weiber meiden nichts so sehr als das Wörtchen Ja; wenigstens sagen sie es erst nach dem Nein
Die Weisen wägen ihre Worte mit der Goldwage
Die Weiseste merken höchstens nur wie das Schicksal sie leitet, und sind es zufrieden
Die Welt der Freiheit trägt der Mensch in seinem Innern. / Und Tugend ist der Freiheit Götterkind
Die Weltgeschichte ist das Weltgericht
Die Welt ist dumm die Welt ist blind, / Wird täglich abgeschmackter
Die Welt ist ein Gefängniss
Die Welt ist voller Widerspruch
Die Welt ist vollkommen überall, / Wo der Mensch nicht hinkommt mit seiner Qual
Die Worte sind gut, sie sind aber nicht das Beste. Das Beste wird nicht deutlich durch Worte
Die Zeiten der Vergangenheit / Sind uns ein Buch mit sieben Siegeln; / Was Ihr den Geist der Zeiten heisst / Das ist im Grund' der Herrn eigner Geist, / In dem die Zeiten sich bespiegeln
Die Zeit ist schlecht, doch giebt's noch grosse
Seelen!
Die Zukunft decket Schmerzen und Glücke
Different good, by art or nature given, / To different nations, makes their blessings even.
Different minds / Incline to different objects; one pursues / The vast alone, the wonderful, the wild; / Another sighs for harmony and grace, / And gentlest beauty.
Different times different manners.
Difficile est crimen non prodere vultu
Difficile est longum subito deponere amorem
Difficile est plurimum virtutem revereri, qui semper secunda fortuna sit usus
Difficile est proprie communia dicere
Difficile est satiram non scribere
Difficile est tristi fingere mente jocum
Difficilem oportet aurem habere ad crimina
Difficilia quæ pulchra
Difficilis, facilis, jucundus, acerbus es idem; / Nec tecum possum vivere, nec sine te
Difficilis in otio quies
Difficilius est sarcire concordiam quam rumpere
Difficult to sweep the intricate foul chimneys of law.
Difficulties are meant to rouse, not discourage.
Difficulties are things that show what men are.
Difficulties may surround our path, but if the difficulties be not in ourselves, they may generally be overcome.
Difficulties strengthen the mind, as labour does the body.
Difficulty, abnegation, martyrdom, death, are the allurements that act on the heart of man. Kindle the inner genial life of him, you have a flame that burns up all lower considerations.
Diffugiunt, cadis / Cum fæce siccatis, amici, / Ferre jugum pariter dolosi
Diffused knowledge immortalises itself.
Dignity and love do not blend well, nor do they continue long together.
Dignity consists not in possessing honours, but in deserving them.
Dignity is often a veil between us and the real truth of things.
Dignity of position adds to dignity of character, as well as dignity of carriage.
Dignum laude virum Musa vetat mori
Digressions in a book are like foreign troops in a state, which argue the nation to want a heart and hands of its own; and often either subdue the natives, or drive them into the most unfruitful corners.
Digressions incontestably are the sunshine; they are the life, the soul of reading.

Dilexi justiciam et odi iniquitatem, propterea morior in exilio
Diligence increases the fruits of labour.
Diligence is the mother of good fortune.

Diligent, that includes all virtues in it a student can have.
Diligent working makes an expert workman.
Diligitur nemo, nisi cui fortuna secunda est

Dinna lift me before I fa'.

Diogenes has well said that the only way to preserve one's liberty was being always ready to die without pain.

Dir war das Unglück eine strenge Schule
Disappointment is often the salt of life.
Disasters, do the best we can, / Will reach both great and small; / And he is oft the wisest man / Who is not wise at all.
Disce aut discede
Disce pati
Disce, puer, virtutem ex me, verumque laborem,
/ Fortunam ex aliis
Disciplined inaction.
Discipulus est prioris posterior dies
Discite justitiam moniti, et non temnere divos
Discit enim citius, meminitque libentius illud / Quod quis deridet quam quod probat et veneratur
Discontent is like ink poured into water, which
fills the whole fountain full of blackness. It casts a cloud over the mind, and renders it more occupied about the evil which disquiets it than about the means of removing it.
Discontent is the want of self-reliance; it is infirmity of will.
Discontent makes us to lose what we have; contentment gets us what we want. Fretting never removed a cross nor procured a comfort; quiet submission doth both.
Discontents are sometimes the better part of our life.
Discord oft in music makes the sweeter lay.
Discreet women have neither eyes nor ears.
Discrepant facta cum dictis
Discretion / And hard valour are the twins of honour, / And, nursed together, make a conqueror; / Divided, but a talker.
Discretion is the perfection of reason, and a guide to us in all the duties of life.
Discretion is the salt, and fancy the sugar, of life; the one preserves, the other sweetens it.
Discretion of speech is more than eloquence,
and to speak agreeably to him with whom we deal is more than to speak in good words or in good order.
Discretion, the best part of valour.
Disdain and scorn ride sparkling in her eye, / Misprising what they look on.
Diseased nature oftentimes breaks forth / In strange eruptions, and the teeming earth / Is with a kind of cholic pinch'd and vex'd / By the imprisoning of unruly wind / Within her womb, which, for enlargement striving, / Shakes the old bedlam earth, and topples down / Steeples and moss-grown towers.
Diseases, desperate grown, / By desperate appliance are relieved, / Or not at all.
Diseur de bons mots
Diseuse de bonne aventure
Disgrace consists infinitely more in the crime than in the punishment.
Disguise our bondage as we will, / 'Tis woman, woman rules us still.
Disguise thyself as thou wilt, still, Slavery, thou art a bitter draught.
Dishonesty is the forsaking of permanent for
temporary advantages.
Dishonest men conceal their faults from themselves as well as others; honest men know and confess them.
Dishonesty will stare honesty out of countenance any day in the week, if there is anything to be got by it.
Dishonour waits on perfidy. The villain / Should blush to think a falsehood; 'tis the crime / Of cowards.
Disillusion is the chief characteristic of old age.
Disjecta membra
Disjecti membra poetæ
Disjice compositam pacem, sere crimina belli
Dismiss your vows, your feigned tears, your flattery; / For where a heart is hard, they make no battery.
Disobedience is the beginning of evil and the broad way to ruin.
Disorder in a drawing-room is vulgar; in an
antiquary's study, not; the black stain on a soldier's face is not vulgar, but the dirty face of a housemaid is.
Disorder is dissolution, death.
Disorder makes nothing at all, but unmakes everything.
Disponendo me, non mutando me
Disputandi pruritus ecclesiarum scabies
Dissensions, like small streams at first begun, /
Unseen they rise, but gather as they run.
Dissimulation in youth is the forerunner of perfidy in old age.
Dissimulation is but faint policy, for it asketh a strong wit and a strong heart to know when to tell the truth and to do it.
Distance produces in idea the same effect as in real perspective.
Distance sometimes endears friendship, and absence sweeteneth it.
Distinction is an eminence that is attained but
too frequently at the expense of a fireside.
Distinction is the consequence, never the object, of a great mind.
Distinction, with a broad and powerful fan / Puffing at all, winnows the light away.
Distingué
Distinguished talents are not necessarily connected with discretion.
Distortion is the agony of weakness. It is the
dislocated mind whose movements are spasmodic.
Distrahit animum librorum multitudo
Distrait
Distressed valour challenges great respect, even from enemies.
Distringas
Distrust and darkness of a future state /
Make poor mankind so fearful of their fate, / Death in itself is nothing; but we fear / To be we know not what, we know not where.
Dites-moi ce que tu manges, je te dirai ce que tu es

Di tutte le arti maestro è amore

Divina natura dedit agros, ars humana ædificavit
urbes
Divination seems heightened to its highest power in woman.
Divine love is a sacred flower, which in its early bud is happiness, and in its full bloom is heaven.
Divine moment, when over the tempest-tossed soul, as over the wild-weltering chaos, it was spoken: Let there be light. Even to the greatest that has felt such a moment, is it not miraculous and God-announcing; even as, under simpler figures, to the humblest and least?
Divine Philosophy, by whose pure light / We first distinguish, then pursue the right; / Thy power the breast from every error frees, / And weeds out all its vices by degrees.
Divine
to mean divine
Divines but peep on undiscovered worlds, / And draw the distant landscape as they please.
Divinity should be empress, and philosophy and other arts merely her servants.
Divitiæ grandes homini sunt, vivere parce / Æquo animo
Divitiæ virum faciunt

virtus clara æternaque habetur

Divorce from this world is marriage with the next.
Dla przyjaciela nowego / Nie opuszczaj starego!
Do as others do, and few will laugh at you.
Do as the bee does with the rose, take the
honey and leave the thorn.

Doctor utriusque legis

cultus pectora roborant
Doctrine is nothing but the skin of truth set up and stuffed.
Does Homer interest us now, because he wrote of what passed beyond his native Greece, and two centuries before he was born; or because he wrote what passed in God's world, which is the same after thirty centuries?
Do faita dicha, por demas es diligencia
Dogmatic jargon, learn'd by heart, / Trite sentences, hard terms of art, / To vulgar ears seem so profound, / They fancy learning in the sound.
Do good and throw it into the sea; if the fish
know it not, the Lord will.
Do good by stealth, and blush to find it fame.
Do good to thy friend to keep him, to thy enemy to gain him.
Dogs should not be taught to eat leather (so indispensable for leashes and muzzles).
Dogs that bark at a distance ne'er bite at hand.
Doing good is the only certainly happy action
of a man's life.
Doing is activity; and he will still be doing.
Doing is the great thing; for if people resolutely do what is right, they come in time to like doing it.
Doing leads more surely to saying than saying to doing.
Doing nothing is doing ill.

Dolendi modus, timendi non autem

Domestic happiness! thou only bliss / Of happiness
that has survived the Fall.

Donec eris felix multos numerabis amicos; /

Donna è mobile come piume in vento

Dono dedit
Do not allow your daughters to be taught letters by a man, though he be a St. Paul or a St Francis of Assisi. The saints are in heaven.
Do not ask if a man has been through college. Ask if a college has been through him.
Do not, as some ungracious pastors do, / Show
me the steep and thorny way to heaven, / Whilst, like a puffed and reckless libertine, / Himself the primrose path of dalliance treads, / And recks not his own rede.
Do not flatter your benefactors.
Do not, for one repulse, forego the purpose / That you resolv'd to effect.
Do not give dalliance / Too much the rein; the strongest oaths are straw / To the fire i' the blood. Be more abstemious, / Or else good night your vow.
Do not halloo till you are out of the wood.
Do not lose the present in vain perplexities
about the future. If fortune lours to-day, she may smile to-morrow.
Do not refuse the employment which the hour brings you for one more ambitious.
Do not talk Arabic in the house of a Moor.
Do not tell a friend anything that you would conceal from an enemy.
Do not think of one falsity as harmless, and one as slight, and another as unintended. Cast them all aside; it is better our hearts should be swept clean of them.
Do not train boys to learning by force or harshness;
but direct them to it by what amuses their minds, so that you may be the better able to discover with accuracy the peculiar bent of the genius of each.
Do not trouble yourself too much about the light on your statue; the light of the public square will test its value.
Don't be a cynic and disconsolate preacher. Don't bewail and moan. Omit the negative propositions. Nerve us with incessant affirmatives. Don't waste yourself in rejection, nor bark against the bad, but chant the beauty of the good.
Don't be "consistent," but be simply true.
Don't budge, if you are at ease where you are.
Don't despise a slight wound or a poor relative.
Don't dissipate your powers; strive constantly to concentrate them. Genius thinks it can do whatever it sees others doing, but it is sure to repent of every ill-judged outlay.
Don terrible de la familiarité
Don't fly till your wings are fledged.
Don't hate; only pity and avoid those that follow lies.
Don't put too fine a point to your wit, for fear
it should get blunted.
Don't quit the highway for a short cut.
Don't reckon your chickens before they are hatched.
Don't throw away the old shoes till you've got new ones.
Donum exitiale Minervæ
Do on the hill as ye do in the ha'.
Do right; though pain and anguish be thy lot, / Thy heart will cheer thee when the pain's forgot; / Do wrong for pleasure's sake, then count thy gains, / The pleasure soon departs, the sin remains.
Dormit aliquando jus, moritur nunquam
Dormiunt aliquando leges, nunquam moriuntur

Dos est magna parentum / Virtus
Dos est uxoria lites
Dos linajes solo hay en el mundo, el "tener" y el "no tener"
Dost thou love life? Then do not squander
time, for that is the stuff life is made of.
Dost thou love me? I know thou wilt say aye; / And I will take thy word. Yet if thou swear'st, / Thou may'st prove false; at lovers' perjuries / They say Jove laughs.
Dost thou love pictures? We will fetch thee straight / Adonis painted by a running brook; / And Cytherea all in sedges hid; / Which seem to move and wanton with her breath; / Even as the waving sedges play with wind.
Dost thou think, because thou art virtuous, there are to be no more cakes and ale?
Do that which is assigned you, and you cannot hope too much or dare too much.
Do the duty that lies nearest to you. Every
duty which is bidden to wait returns with seven fresh duties at its back.
Do the duty which lies nearest to thee. Thy second duty will already have become clearer.
Do thine own task, and be therewith content.
Doth not the appetite alter? A man loves the meat in his youth that he cannot endure in his age.
Doth the eagle know what is in the pit, / Or wilt thou go ask the mole?
Do thy little well, and for thy comfort know, /
Great men can do their greatest work no better than just so.
Double, double, toil and trouble, / Fire burn, and caldron bubble.
Double, double toil and trouble; that is the life of all governors that really govern; not the spoil of victory, only the glorious toil of battle can be theirs.
Double entendre
Double entente
Doubting the reality of love leads to doubting
everything.
Doubting things go ill often hurts more / Than to be sure they do.
Doubt is an incentive to truth, and patient inquiry leadeth the way.
Doubt is the abettor of tyranny.
Doubt is the vestibule which all must pass before they can enter into the temple of wisdom.
Doubtless the pleasure is as great / Of being
cheated as to cheat.
Doubt of any sort cannot be removed except by action.
Doubt thou the stars are fire; / Doubt that the sun doth move; / Doubt truth to be a liar; / But never doubt I love.

Do weel and doubt nae man; do ill and doubt a' men.
Do we not all submit to death? The highest sentence of the law, sentence of death, is passed on all of us by the fact of birth; yet we live patiently under it, patiently undergo it when the hour comes.
Dower'd with the hate of hate, the scorn of scorn, / The love of love.
Do what he will, he cannot realise / Half he
conceives--the glorious vision flies; / Go where he may, he cannot hope to find / The truth, the beauty pictured in the mind.
Do what we can, summer will have its flies; if we go a-fishing, we must expect a wet coat.
Down, thou climbing sorrow; / Thy element's below.
Downward to climb and backward to advance.
Downy sleep, death's counterfeit.
Do you think the porter and the cook have no
anecdotes, no experiences, no wonders for you?
Do you wish to find out the really sublime? Repeat the Lord's Prayer.
Dramatis personæ
Draw thyself from thyself.
Dream after dream ensues, / And still they dream that they shall still succeed / And still are disappointed.
Dream delivers us to dream, and there is no
end to illusion.
Dreams are but interludes which fancy makes. / When monarch reason sleeps, this mimic wakes; / Compounds a medley of disjointed things, / A mob of cobblers and a court of kings; / Light fumes are merry, grosser fumes are sad; / Both are the reasonable soul run mad.
Dreams are excursions into the limbo of things, a semi-deliverance from the human prison.
Dreams are the bright creatures of poem and legend, who sport on the earth in the night season, and melt away with the first beams of the sun.
Dreams are the children of an idle brain, / Begot of nothing but vain phantasy; / Which are as thin of substance as the air, / And more inconstant than the wind.
Dreams, books, are each a world; and books, we know, / Are a substantial world, both pure and good; / Round these, with tendrils strong as flesh and blood, / Our pastime and our happiness will grow.
Dreams, indeed, are ambition; for the substance of the ambitious is merely the shadow of a dream.
Dreams, in general, take their rise from those incidents that have occurred during the day.
Dreams in their development have breath /
And tears and torture and the touch of joy; / They leave a weight upon our waking thoughts; / They take a weight from off our waking toils; / They do divide our being; they become a portion of ourselves as of our time, / And look like heralds of eternity.
Dreigers vechten niet
Dress has a moral effect upon the conduct of mankind.
Drinking water neither makes a man sick nor in debt, nor his wife a widow.
Drink nothing without seeing it, sign nothing without reading it.
Drink not the third glass, which thou canst
not tame / When once it is within thee; but before, / May'st rule it as thou list; and pour the shame, / Which it would pour on thee, upon the floor.
Drink to me only with thine eyes, / And I will pledge with mine; / Or leave a kiss but in the cup, / And I'll not look for wine.
Drink waters out of thine own cistern, and running waters out of thine own well.
Drive a coach and six through an act of parliament.
Drive a cow to the ha', and she'll run to the byre.
Drive thy business, let not thy business drive
thee.

Drones hive not with me.
Drowsiness shall clothe a man with rags.
Drudgery and knowledge are of kin, / And both descended from one parent sin.
Drunkenness is the vice of a good constitution or of a bad memory;--of a constitution so treacherously good than it never bends till it breaks; or of a memory that recollects the pleasures of getting intoxicated, but forgets the pains of getting sober.
Drunkenness is voluntary madness.

Dry shoes won't catch fish.

Duties are but coldly performed which are but philosophically fulfilled.
Duties are ours; events are God's.
Duty by habit is to pleasure turn'd; / He is content who to obey has learn'd.
Duty demands the parent's voice / Should sanctify
the daughter's choice, / In that is due obedience shown; / To choose belongs to her alone.
Duty, especially out of the domain of love, is the veriest slavery in the world.
Duty has the virtue of making us feel the reality of a positive world, while at the same time it detaches us from it.
Duty is a power which rises with us in the morning, and goes to bed with us in the evening.
Duty is the demand of the passing hour.
Duty scorns prudence, and criticism has few
terrors for a man with a great purpose.
Duty--the command of Heaven, the eldest voice of God.
Dux fœmina facti
Each animal out of its habitat would starve.
Each change of many-colour'd life he drew, / Exhausted worlds, and then imagined new.
Each creature is only a modification of the other; the likeness in them is more than the difference, and their radical law is one and the same.
Each creature seeks its perfection in another.
Each day still better other's happiness, / Until
the heavens, envying earth's good hap, / Add an immortal title to your crown.
Each departed friend is a magnet that attracts us to the next world, and the old man lives among graves.
Each good thought or action moves / The dark world nearer to the sun.
Each heart is a world. You find all within yourself that you find without. The world that surrounds you is the magic glass of the world within you.
Each human heart can properly exhibit but one love, if even one; the "first love, which is infinite," can be followed by no second like unto it.
Each in his narrow cell for ever laid,/ The rude
forefathers of the hamlet sleep.
Each man begins the world afresh, and the last man repeats the blunders of the first.
Each man can learn something from his neighbour; at least he can learn to have patience with him--to live and let live.
Each man has his fortune in his own hands, as the artist has a piece of rude matter, which he is to fashion into a certain shape.
Each man has his own vocation; his talent is his call. There is one direction in which all space is open to him.
Each man sees over his own experience a
certain stain of error, whilst that of other men looks fair and ideal.
Each man's chimney is his golden milestone, is the central point from which he measures every distance through the gateways of the world around him.
Each mind has its own method. A true man never acquires after college rules.
Each must stand on his glass tripod, if he would keep his electricity.
Each one of us here, let the world go how it will, and be victorious or not victorious, has he not a life of his own to lead?
Each particle of matter is an immensity, each
leaf a world, each insect an inexplicable compendium.
Each plant has its parasite, and each created thing its lover and poet.
Each present joy or sorrow seems the chief.
Each sin at heart is Deicide.
Each substance of a grief hath twenty shadows, / Which show like grief itself, but are not so; / For sorrow's eye, glazed with blinding tears, / Divides one thing entire to many objects.
Each thing is a half, and suggests another thing
to make it whole; as spirit, matter; man, woman; odd, even; subjective, objective; in, out; motion, rest; yea, nay.
Each thing lives according to its kind; the heart by love, the intellect by truth, the higher nature of man by intimate communion with God.
Each year one vicious habit rooted out, in time might make the worst man good.
Ea fama vagatur
Eagles fly alone; they are but sheep that always herd together.
Eamus quo ducit gula
Early and provident fear is the mother of safety.
Early birds catch the worms.
Early, bright, transient, chaste, as morning dew, / She sparkled, was exhaled, and went to heaven.
Early master soon knave (servant).
Early start makes easy stages.
Early to bed and early to rise, makes a man healthy, wealthy, and wise.
Earn well the thrifty months, nor wed / Raw Haste, half-sister to Delay.
Earnest and sport go well together.
Earnestness alone makes life eternity.
Earnestness in life, even when carried to an
extreme, is something very noble and great.
Earnestness is a quality as old as the heart of man.
Earnestness is enthusiasm tempered by reason.
Earnestness is the cause of patience; it gives endurance, overcomes pain, strengthens weakness, braves dangers, sustains hope, makes light of difficulties, and lessens the sense of weariness in overcoming them.
Earnestness is the devotion of all the faculties.
Earth changes, but thy soul and God stand
sure.
Earth felt the wound; and Nature from her seat, / Sighing through all her work, gave sign of woe / That all was lost.
Earth has scarcely an acre that does not remind us of actions that have long preceded our own, and its clustering tombstones loom up like reefs of the eternal shore, to show us where so many human barks have struck and gone down.
Earth hath no sorrow that heaven cannot heal.
Earth hath nothing more tender than a woman's heart when it is the abode of piety.
Earth is here (in Australia) so kind, just tickle
her with a hoe and she laughs with a harvest.
Earthly pride is like a passing flower, that springs to fall and blossoms but to die.
Earth, sea, man, are all in each.
Earth, that's Nature's mother, is her tomb.
Earth to earth, ashes to ashes, dust to dust, in sure and certain hope of the Resurrection.
Earth, turning from the sun, brings night to man.
Earth with her thousand voices praises God.
Earth's crammed with heaven, / And every common bush afire with God.
Earth's noblest thing, a woman perfected.
Ease and honour are seldom bed-fellows.
Ea sola voluptas / Solamenque mali
East and west, home (hame) is best
Ea sub oculis posita negligimus; proximorum incuriosi, longinqua sectamur
Easy-crying widows take new husbands soonest; there's nothing like wet weather for transplanting.
Easy writing's curst hard reading.
Eat at your own table as you would eat at the table of the king.
Eat at your pleasure, drink in measure.
Eating little and speaking little can never do harm.
Eating the bitter bread of banishment.
Eat in measure and defy the doctor.
Eat to please thyself, but dress to please others.
Eat-weel's drink-weel's brither.
Eat what you like, but pocket nothing.

Eau sucrée
Ebbe il migliore / De' miei giorni la patria
E bello predicare il digiuno a corpo pieno

Ecce homo
Ecce iterum Crispinus!
Eccentricity has always abounded when and where strength of character has abounded; and the amount of eccentricity in a society has been proportional to the amount of genius, mental vigour, and moral courage it contained. That so few now dare to be eccentric, marks the chief danger of the time.
Eccentricity is sometimes found connected with genius, but it does not coalesce with true wisdom.
Ecce signum
Eccovi l'uom ch' è stato all'Inferno
Echoes we: listen! / We cannot stay, / As dewdrops glisten, / Then fade away.
Echo is the voice of a reflection in a mirror.
Eclaircissement
Eclat de rire
E cœlo descendit
Economy does not consist in the reckless reduction of estimates; on the contrary, such a course almost necessarily tends to increased expenditure. There can be no economy where there is no efficiency.
Economy is an excellent lure to betray people into expense.
Economy is half the battle of life; it is not so
hard to earn money as to spend it.
Economy is the parent of integrity, of liberty, and of ease, and the beauteous sister of temperance, of cheerfulness, and health.
Economy no more means saving money than it means spending money. It means the administration of a house, its stewardship; spending or saving, that is, whether money or time, or anything else, to the best possible advantage.
E contra
E contrario
Ecorcher l'anguille par la queue
Ecrasons l'infâme
Edel ist, der edel thut
Edel macht das Gemüth, nicht das Geblüt
Edel sei der Mensch / Hülfreich und gut / Denn das allein / Unterscheidet ihn / Von allen Wesen / Die wir kennen
Edition de luxe
Editiones expurgatæ
Editio princeps
Edo, ergo ego sum
Educated persons should share their thoughts with the uneducated, and take also a certain part in their labours.
Educate men without religion, and you make them but clever devils.
Education alone can conduct us to that enjoyment
which is at once best in quality and infinite in quantity.
Education begins its work with the first breath of the child.
Education begins the gentleman, but reading, good company, and reflection must finish him.
Education commences at the mother's knee, and every word spoken within the hearing of little children tends towards the formation of character.
Education does not mean teaching people to know what they do not know; it means teaching them to behave as they do not behave.
Education gives fecundity of thought, copiousness
of illustration, quickness, vigour, fancy, words, images, and illustrations; it decorates every common thing, and gives the power of trifling without being undignified and absurd.
Education, however indispensable in a cultivated age, produces nothing on the side of genius. Where education ends, genius often begins.
Education is a better safeguard of liberty than a standing army.
Education is generally the worse in proportion to the wealth and grandeur of the parents.
Education is only like good culture; it changes the size, but not the sort.
Education is only second to nature.
Education is our only political safety. Outside of this ark all is deluge.
Education is the apprenticeship of life.
Education is the constraining and directing of youth towards that right reason which the law affirms, and which the experience of the best of our elders has sanctioned as truly great.
Education is the only interest worthy the deep, controlling anxiety of the thoughtful man.
Education is the leading human souls to what
is best, and making what is best of them. The training which makes men happiest in themselves also makes them most serviceable to others.
Education may work wonders as well in warping the genius of individuals as in seconding it.
Education of youth is not a bow for every man to shoot in that counts himself a teacher, but will require sinews almost equal to those which Homer gave Ulysses.
Education ought, as a first principle, to stimulate the will to activity.
Education should be as broad as man.

Een dief maakt gelegenheid

Een once geduld is meer dan een pond verstand
E'en though vanquished he could argue still.

Elocution is the adjustment of apt words and

Eloignement
Eloquence, at its highest pitch, leaves little room for reason or reflection, but addresses itself entirely to the fancy or the affections, captivates the willing hearers, and subdues their understanding.
Eloquence is a pictorial representation of thought.
Eloquence is in the assembly, not in the speaker.
Eloquence is like flame: it requires matter to
feed on, motion to excite it, and it brightens as it burns.
Eloquence is the appropriate organ of the highest personal energy.
Eloquence is the child of knowledge. When the mind is full, like a wholesome river, it is also clear.
Eloquence is the language of nature, and cannot be learned in the schools.
Eloquence is the painting of thought; and thus those who, after having painted it, still add to it, make a picture instead of a portrait.
Eloquence is the poetry of prose.
Eloquence is the power to translate a truth into language perfectly intelligible to the person to whom you speak.
Eloquence is to the sublime as a whole to its part.
Eloquence must be grounded on the plainest narrative.
Eloquence shows the power and possibility of man.
Eloquence the soul, song charms the sense.
Eloquence, to produce her full effect, should start from the head of the orator, as Pallas from the brain of Jove, completely armed and equipped.

Emeritus
Emerson tells us to hitch our waggon to a star; and the star is without doubt a good steed, when once fairly caught and harnessed, but it takes an astronomer to catch it.
Emerson wants Emersonian epigrams from Carlyle, and Carlyle wants Carlylean thunder from Emerson. The thing which a man's nature calls him to do, what else is so well worth his doing?
Eminent positions are like the summits of rocks; only eagles and reptiles can get there.
Eminent stations make great men greater and little men less.
Emori nolo, sed me esse mortuum nihil curo
Emotion is always new.
Emotion is the atmosphere in which thought is steeped, that which lends to thought its tone or temperature, that to which thought is often indebted for half its power.
Emotion, not thought, is the sphere of music; and emotion quite as often precedes as follows thought.
Emotion turning back on itself, and not leading on to thought or action, is the element of madness.
Empfindliche Ohren sind, bei Mädchen so gut als bei Pferden, gute Gesundheitszeichen
Empires and nations flourish and decay, / By turns command, and in their turns obey.
Empires are only sandhills in the hour-glass of Time; they crumble spontaneously by the process of their own growth.
Empires flourish till they become commercial, and then they are scattered abroad to the four winds.
Empirical sciences prosecuted simply for their
own sake, and without a philosophic tendency, resemble a face without eyes.
Employment and hardships prevent melancholy.
Employment gives health, sobriety, and morals.
Employment is enjoyment.
Employment is Nature's physician, and is essential to human happiness.
Employ thy time well if thou meanest to gain
leisure, and, since you are not sure of a minute, throw not away an hour.

Empta dolore docet experientia
Empty vessels make the most noise.
Emulation admires and strives to imitate great
actions; envy is only moved to malice.
Emulation, even in the brutes, is sensitively nervous; see the tremor of the thorough-bred racer before he starts.

En émoi
Energy may be turned to bad uses; but more
good may always be made of an energetic nature than of an indolent and impassive one.
Energy will do anything that can be done in this world; no talents, no circumstances, no opportunities will make a two-legged animal a man without it.

En foule
England expects this day that every man shall do his duty.
England is a domestic country: here home is revered and the hearth sacred.
England is a paradise for women and a hell
for horses; Italy a paradise for horses and a hell for women.
England is safe if true within itself.

En habiles gens
Enjoying things which are pleasant, that is not the evil; it is the reducing of our moral self to slavery by them that is.
Enjoyment soon wearies both itself and us; effort, never.
Enjoyment stops when indolence begins.
Enjoy the blessings of this day, if God sends them, and the evils bear patiently and sweetly. For this day only is ours; we are dead to yesterday and we are not born to to-morrow.
Enjoy what God has given thee, and willingly
dispense with what thou hast not. Every condition has its own joys and sorrows.
Enjoy what thou hast inherited from thy sires if thou wouldst possess it; what we employ not is an oppressive burden; what the moment brings forth, that only can it profit by.
Enjoy when you can, and endure when you must.
Enjoy your little while the fool is seeking for more.
Enjoy your own life without comparing it with that of another.
En la cour du roi chacun y est pour soi
Enlarge not thy destiny; endeavour not to do more than is given thee in charge.
En la rose je fleuris
En mariage, comme ailleurs, contentement passe richesse

Ennemi ne s'endort
Ennui has perhaps made more gamblers than avarice, more drunkards than thirst, and perhaps as many suicides as despair.
Ennui is a growth of English root, though nameless in our language.
Ennui is a word which the French invented, though of all nations in Europe they know the least of it.
Ennui is our greatest enemy.
Ennui is the desire of activity without the fit means of gratifying the desire.
Ennui shortens life and bereaves the day of its
light.
Ennui, the parent of expensive and ruinous vices.
Enough is as good as a feast.
Enough is better than too much.
Enough is great riches.
Enough is the wild-goose-chase of most men's
lives.
Enough--no foreign foe could quell / Thy soul, till from itself it fell; / Yes, self-abasement paved the way / To villain bonds and despot sway.
Enough requires too much; too much craves more.

En suivant la vérité
Entente cordiale
Enthusiasm begets enthusiasm.
Enthusiasm flourishes in adversity, kindles in
the hour of danger, and awakens to deeds of renown.
Enthusiasm gives life to what is invisible, and interest to what has no immediate action on our comfort in this world.
Enthusiasm imparts itself magnetically, and fuses all into one happy and harmonious unity of feeling and sentiment.
Enthusiasm is grave, inward, self-controlled; mere excitement, outward, fantastical, hysterical, and passing in a moment from tears to laughter.
Enthusiasm is the genius of sincerity, and truth accomplishes no victories without it.
Enthusiasm is the height of man; it is the
passing from the human to the divine.
Enthusiasm is the leaping lightning, not to be measured by the horse-power of the understanding.
Entienda primero, y habla postrero
Entire affection hateth nicer hands.
Entire love is a worship and cannot be angry.
Entourage
En toute chose il faut considérer la fin
Entre chien et loup
Entre deux vins
Entre esprit et talent il y a la proportion du
tout à sa partie
Entre le bon sens et le bon goût il y a la différence de la cause à son effet
Entre nos ennemis les plus à craindre sont souvent les plus petits
Entre nous
Entzwei und gebiete
Entzwei und gebiete! Tüchtig Wort: Verein'
und leite, Bessrer Hort
En vérité
En vérité l'amour ne saurait être profond, s'il n'est pas pur
En vieillissant on devient plus fou et plus sage
En villig Hielper töver ei til man beder
Envy, among other ingredients, has a mixture
of the love of justice in it. We are more angry at undeserved than at deserved good fortune.
Envy does not enter an empty house.
Envy feels not its own happiness but by comparison with the misery of others.
Envy, if surrounded on all sides by the brightness of another's prosperity, like the scorpion confined with a circle of fire, will sting itself to death.
Envy is a passion so full of cowardice and shame, that nobody ever had the confidence to own it.
Envy is ignorance.
Envy is littleness of soul.
Envy is more irreconcilable than hatred.
Envy is the antagonist of the fortunate.
Envy is the deformed and distorted offspring of egotism.
Envy is the most acid fruit that grows on the stock of sin, a fluid so subtle that nothing but the fire of divine love can purge it from the soul.
Envy, like the worm, never runs but to the fairest fruit; like a cunning bloodhound, it singles out the fattest deer in the flock.
Envy ne'er does a gude turn but when it means an ill ane.
Envy will merit as its shade pursue, / But, like a shadow, proves the substance true.

Eo instanti
Eo magis præfulgebat quod non videbatur
Epicuri de grege porcus
E pluribus unum
"Eppur si muove"
Equality
Equality
Eques ipso melior Bellerophonte
Equi et poetæ alendi, non saginandi
Equity is a roguish thing; for law we have a measure ... (but) equity is according to the conscience of him who is chancellor, and, as that is larger or narrower, so is equity.
Equity judges with lenity, laws with severity.
Equivocation is half way to lying, and lying is the whole way to hell.
Equo frænato est auris in ore
Equo ne credite, Teucri
Erant in officio, sed tamen qui mallent imperantium mandata interpretari, quam exsequi

and Luther hatched it.

das Rechte / Sei, von seinen hundert Namen, / Dieser hochgelobet!--Amen!
Ere sin could blight or sorrow fade, / Death came with friendly care, / The opening bud to heaven conveyed, / And bade it blossom there.
Ere we censure a man for seeming what he is not, we should be sure that we know what he is.
Er geht herum, wie die Katze um den heissen Brei

Eris mihi magnus Apollo
Erlaubt ist was gefällt; erlaubt ist was sich ziemt
Ernste Thätigkeit söhnt suletzt immer mit dem Leben aus
Ernst ist der Anblick der Nothwendigkeit. /
Nicht ohne Schauder greift des Menschen Hand / In des Geschicks geheimnissvolle Urne
Ernst ist das Leben; heiter ist die Kunst
Erquickung hast du nicht gewonnen, / Wenn sie dir nicht aus eigner Seele quillt
Errantem in viam reducito
Errare humanum est
Errare malo cum Platone, quam cum istis vera
sentire
Errata
Erringen will der Mensch, er will nicht sicher sein
Erring is not cheating.
Error cannot be defended but by error.
Error is always more busy than ignorance.
Ignorance is a blank sheet on which we may write, but error is a scribbled one from which we must first erase.
Error is always talkative.
Error is but opinion in the making.
Error is but the shadow of truth.
Error is created; truth is eternal.
Error is on the surface; truth is hid in great depths.
Error is sometimes so nearly allied to truth that it blends with it as imperceptibly as the colours of the rainbow fade into each other.
Error is worse than ignorance.
Error never leaves us, yet a higher need
always draws the striving spirit gently on to truth.
Error of opinion may be tolerated where reason is left free to combat it.
Errors like straws upon the surface flow; / He who would search for pearls must dive below.
Error, sterile in itself, produces only by means of the portion of truth which it contains.
Errors, to be dangerous, must have a great deal of truth mingled with them; ... from pure extravagance, and genuine, unmingled falsehood, the world never has sustained, and never can sustain, any mischief.
Error, when she retraces her steps, has farther
to go before she can arrive at truth than ignorance.
Erröten macht die Hässlichen so schön: / Und sollte Schöne nicht noch schöner machen?
Ersparte Wahl ist auch ersparte Mühe
Er steckt seine Nase in Alles
Erst seit ich liebe ist das Leben schön, / Erst seit ich liebe, weiss ich, dass ich lebe
Erst wägen, dann wagen
Ertragen muss man was der Himmel sendet. / Unbilliges erträgt kein edles Herz
Erudition is not like a lark, which flies high and delights in nothing but singing; 'tis rather like a hawk, which soars aloft indeed, but can stoop when she finds it convenient, and seize her prey.
Er wünscht sich einen grossen Kreis / Um ihn gewisser zu erschüttern
Es bedarf nur einer Kleinigkeit, um zwei Liebende zu unterhalten
Es bildet ein Talent sich in der Stille, / Sich ein
Character in dem Strom der Welt
Es bildet / Nur das Leben den Mann, und wenig bedeuten die Worte
Eschew fine words as you would rouge; love simple ones as you would native roses on your cheek.
Escuchas al agujero; oirás de tû mal y del ageno
E se finxit velut araneus
Esel singen schlecht, weil sie zu hoch anstimmen
Es erben sich Gesetz' und Rechte / Wie eine ewige Krankheit fort
Es findet jeder seinen Meister
Es geht an
Es giebt eine Höflichkeit des Herzens; sie ist der Liebe verwandt.
Es giebt eine Schwelgerei des Geistes wie
es eine Schwelgerei der Sinne giebt
Es giebt gewisse Dinge, wo ein Frauenzimmer immer schärfer sieht, als hundert Augen der Mannspersonen
Es giebt keine andre Offenbarung, als die Gedanken der Weisen
Es giebt kein Gesetz was hat nicht ein Loch, wer's finden kann
Es giebt Männer welche die Beredsamkeit weiblicher Zungen übertreffen, aber kein Mann besitzt die Beredsamkeit weiblicher Augen
Es giebt mehr Diebe als Galgen
Es giebt Menschen, die auf die Mängel ihrer Freunde sinnen; dabei kommt nichts heraus. Ich habe immer auf die Verdienste meiner Widersacher Acht gehabt und davon Vortheil gezogen
Es giebt Naturen, die gut sind durch das was sie erreichen, andere durch das was sie verschmähen
Es giebt nur eine Religion, aber es kann vielerlei Arten der Glaubens geben
Es hört doch Jeder nur was er versteht
Es irrt der Mensch, so lang er strebt
Es ist besser, das geringste Ding von der Welt zu thun, als eine halbe Stunde für gering halten
Es ist bestimmt in Gottes Rath / Dass man vom Liebsten, was man hat, / Muss scheiden
Es ist das Wohl des Ganzen, wovon jedes patriotische, wovon selbst jedes eigennützige Gemüth das seinige hofft
Es ist der Geist, der sich den Körper baut
Es ist freundlicher das menschliche Leben anzulachen, als es anzugrinzen
Es ist klug und kühn den unvermeidlichen. Uebel entgegenzugehen
Es ist nicht gut, wenn derjenige der die
Fackel trägt, zugleich auch den Weg sucht
Es ist nicht nötig, dass ich lebe, wohl aber, dass ich meine Pflicht thue und für mein Vaterland kämpfe
Es ist öde, nichts ehren können, als sich selbst
Es ist schwer gegen den Augenblick gerecht sein; der gleichgültige macht uns Langeweile, am Guten hat man zu tragen und am Bösen zu schleppen
Es ist so schwer, den falschen Weg zu meiden
Es ist unköniglich zu weinen--ach, / Und
hier nicht weinen ist unväterlich
Es kämpft der Held am liebsten mit dem Held
Es kann der beste Herz in dunkeln Stunden fehlen
Es kann ja nicht immer so bleiben / Hier unter dem wechselnden Mond
Es kann nichts helfen ein grosses Schicksal zu haben, wenn man nicht weiss, dass man eines hat
Es kommen Fälle vor im Menschenleben, /
Wo's Weisheit ist, nicht allzu weise sein
Es leben Götter, die den Hochmut rächen
Es liebt die Welt das Strahlende zu schwärtzen, / Und das Erhabne in den Staub zu ziehn
Es liesse sich Alles trefflich schlichten, Könnte man die Sachen zweimal verrichten
Es muss auch solche Käuze geben

Es sind so gute Katzen die Mäuse verjagen, als die sie fangen
Es steckt nicht in Spiegel was man im Spiegel sieht
Es steht ihm an der Stirn' geschrieben, / Das er nicht mag eine Seele lieben
Establish thou the work of our hands upon us; yea, the work of our hands establish thou it.
Est aliquid fatale malum per verba levare
Est animus tibi / Rerumque prudens, et secundis / Temporibus dubiisque rectus
Est animus tibi, sunt mores et lingua, fidesque
Est assez riche qui ne doit rien
Est aviditas dives, et pauper pudor
Est bonus, ut melior vir / Non alius quisquam
Est brevitate opus, ut currat sententia
Est demum vera felicitas, felicitate dignum videri
Est deus in nobis, agitante calescimus illo
Est deus in nobis, et sunt commercia cœli
Esteem a man of many words and many lies
much alike.
Esteem is the harvest of a whole life spent in usefulness; but reputation is often bestowed upon a chance action, and depends most on success.
Est enim lex nihil aliud nisi recta et a numine deorum tracta ratio, imperans honesta, prohibens contraria
Est egentissimus in sua re
Est etiam miseris pietas, et in hoste probatur
Est etiam, ubi profecto damnnum præstet facere,
quam lucrum
Est genus hominum qui esse primos se omnium rerum volunt, / Nec sunt
Est hic, / Est ubivis, animus si te non deficit æquus
Est miserorum, ut malevolentes sint atque invideant bonis
Est modus in rebus; sunt certi denique fines, / Quos ultra citraque nequit consistere rectum
Est multi fabula plena joci
Est natura hominum novitatis avida
Estne Dei sedes nisi terra, et pontus, et aër, / Et cœlum, et virtus? Superos quid quærimus ultra? / Jupiter est, quodcunque vides, quodcunque moveris
Est nobis voluisse satis
Esto perpetua

esse: / Quod non es, nolis; quod potes esse, velis
Esto quod esse videris
Esto, ut nunc multi, dives tibi, pauper amicis
Est pater ille quem nuptiæ demonstrant
Est profecto Deus, qui quæ nos gerimus auditque et videt
Est proprium stultitiæ aliorum cernere vitia,
oblivisci suorum
Est quadam prodire tenus, si non datur ultra
Est quædam flere voluptas, / Expletur lachrymis egeriturque dolor
Est quoque cunctarum novitas carissima rerum
Es trägt Verstand und rechter Sinn / Mit wenig Kunst sich selber vor; und wenn's euch Ernst ist was zu sagen / Ist's nötig Worten nachzujagen?
Es trinken tausend sich den Tod, ehe einer
stirbt vor Durstes Noth

Es will einer was er soll, aber er kann's nicht machen; es kann einer was er soll, aber er will's nicht; es will und kann einer, aber er weiss nicht, was er soll
Es wird wohl auch drüben nicht anders seyn als hier

E tenui casa sæpe vir magnus exit
Eternal love made me.
Eternal smiles his emptiness betray, / As shallow streams run dimpling all the way.
Eternity, depending on an hour.
Eternity looks grander and kinder if Time grow meaner and more hostile.
Eternity of being and well-being simply for
being and well-being's sake, is an ideal belonging to appetite alone, and which only the struggle of mere animalism
longing to be infinite gives rise to.
Et facere et pati fortiter Romanum est
Et genus et formam regina pecunia donat
Et genus et proavos, et quæ non fecimus ipsi, / Vix ea nostra voco
Et genus et virtus, nisi cum re, vilior alga est
Ethics makes man's soul mannerly and wise,
but logic is the armoury of reason, furnished with all offensive and defensive weapons.
Et hoc genus omne
Etiam celeritas in desiderio, mora est
Etiam fera animalia, si clausa teneas, virtutis obliviscuntur
Etiam fortes viros subitis terreri
Etiam innocentes cogit mentiri dolor
Etiam oblivisci quod scis, interdum expedit
Etiam sanato vulnere cicatrix manet
Etiam sapientibus cupido gloriæ novissima exuitur
Et jam summa procul villarum culmina fumant, / Majoresque cadunt altis de montibus umbræ
Et je sais, sur ce fait, / Bon nombre d'hommes
qui sont femmes
Et l'avare Achéron ne lâche pas sa proie
Et le combat cessa faute de combattants
Et l'on revient toujours / A ses premiers amours
Et mala sunt vicina bonis
Et male tornatos incudi reddere versus
Et mea cymba semel vasta percussa procella, / Illum, quo læsa est, horret adire locum
Et mihi res, non me rebus, subjungere conor
Et minimæ vires frangere quassa valent
Et monere, et moneri, proprium est veræ amicitiæ
Et nati natorum, et qui nascentur ab illis
Et nova fictaque nuper habebunt verba fidem, si / Græco fonte cadunt parce detorta
Et pudet, et metuo, semperque eademque precari, / Ne subeant animo tædia justa tuo
Et quæ sibi quisque timebat, / Unius in miseri exitium conversa tulere
Et quiescenti agendum est, et agenti quiescendum est
Et qui nolunt occidere quenquam / Posse
volunt
Et quorum pars magna fui
Etre capable de se laisser servir n'est pas une des moindres qualités que puisse avoir un grand roi
Etre pauvre sans être libre, c'est le pire état où l'homme puisse tomber
Etre sur le qui vive
Etre sur un grand pied dans le monde
Et rose elle a vécu ce que vivent les roses / L'espace d'un matin
Et sanguis et spiritus pecunia mortalibus
Et semel emissum volat irrevocabile verbum

Et vaincre sans péril serait vaincre sans gloire
