Et voilà justement comme on écrit l'histoire
Etwas ist besser als gar nichts
Euch zu gefallen war mein höchster Wunsch; / Euch zu ergötzen war mein letzter Zweck
Euge, poeta!
Eum ausculta, cui quatuor sunt aures
Europe's eye is fixed on mighty things, / The fall of empires and the fate of kings.
E' va più d'un asino al mercato
Evasion is unworthy of us, and is always the intimate of equivocation.
Evasions are the common subterfuge of the hard-hearted, the false, and impotent, when called upon to assist.
Even a fly has its spleen.
Even a fool, when he holdeth his peace, is counted wise.
Even a frog would bite if it had teeth.
Even a haggis could charge down-hill.
Even a hair casts a shadow.
Even a horse, though he has four feet, will
stumble.
Even among the apostles there was a Judas.
Even beauty cannot palliate eccentricity.
Even by means of our sorrows we belong to the eternal plan.
Even foxes are outwitted and caught.
Even in a righteous cause force is a fearful
thing; God only helps when men can help no more.
Evening is the delight of virtuous age; it seems an emblem of the tranquil close of busy life.
Even in social life, it is persistency which attracts confidence, more than talents and accomplishments.
Even perfect examples lead astray by tempting us to overleap the necessary steps in their development, whereby we are for the most part led past the goal into boundless error.
Even so my sun one early morn did shine, / With all triumphant splendour on my brow; / But out, alack! it was but one hour mine.
Even success needs its consolations.
Even that fish may be caught which resists most stoutly against it.
Even the just man has need of help.
Even the lowest book of chronicles partakes of the spirit of the age in which it was written.
Even then a wish (I mind its power), / A wish that to my latest hour / Shall strongly heave my breast, / That I, for puir auld Scotland's sake, / Some usefu' plan or beuk could make, / Or sing a sang at least.
Even though the cloud veils it, the sun is ever
in the canopy of heaven
holy will rules there; the world does not serve blind chance.
Even though vanquished, he could argue still.
Even thou who mourn'st the daisy's fate, / That fate is thine--no distant date; / Stern Ruin's ploughshare drives elate / Full on thy bloom, / Till crush'd beneath the farrow's weight / Shall be thy doom.
Events are only the shells of ideas; and often it is the fluent thought of ages that is crystallised in a moment by the stroke of a pen or the point of a bayonet.
Events of all sorts creep or fly exactly as God pleases.
Eventus stultorum magister est
Even weak men when united are powerful.
Evêque d'or, crosse de bois; crosse d'or, évêque de bois
Ever, as of old, the thing a man will do is the thing he feels commanded to do.
Ever charming, ever new, / When will the landscape tire the view?
Ever learning, and never able to come to the
knowledge of the truth.
Evermore thanks, the exchequer of the poor.
Ever must pain urge us to labour, and only in free effort can any blessedness be imagined for us.

Ever since Adam's time fools have been in the majority.
Ever take it for granted that man collectively
wishes that which is right; but take care never to think so of one!
Every absurdity has a champion to defend it; for error is talkative.
Every action is measured by the depth of the sentiment from which it proceeds.
Every advantage has its tax, but there is none on the good of virtue; that is the incoming of God himself, or absolute existence.
Every age regards the dawning of new light as the destroying fire of morality; while that very age itself, with heart uninjured, finds itself raised one degree of light above the preceding.
Every attempt to crush an insurrection with means inadequate to the end foments instead of suppressing it.
Every author, in some degree, portrays himself in his works, be it even against his will.
Every base occupation makes one sharp in its practice and dull in every other.
Every bean has its black.
Every beginning is cheerful; the threshold is
the place of expectation.
Every beloved object is the centre of a paradise.
Every being is a moving temple of the Infinite.
Everybody is wise after the event.
Everybody knows that fanaticism is religion caricatured; yet with many, contempt of fanaticism is received as a sure sign of hostility to religion.
Everybody knows that government never began
anything. It is the whole world that thinks and governs.
Everybody likes and respects self-made men. It is a great deal better to be made in that way than not to be made at all.
Everybody says it, and what everybody says must be true.
Everybody's business in the social system is to be agreeable.
Everybody's business is nobody's.
Everybody's friend is nobody's.
Every book is good to read which sets the reader in a working mood.
Every book is written with a constant secret reference to the few intelligent persons whom the writer believes to exist in the million.
Every brave life out of the past does not appear to us so brave as it really was, for the forms of terror with which it wrestled are now overthrown.
Every brave man is a man of his word.
Every brave youth is in training to ride and
rule his dragon.
Every bullet has its billet.
Every Calvary has its Olivet.
Every capability, however slight, is born with us; there is no vague general capability in man.
Every child is to a certain extent a genius, and every genius is to a certain extent a child.
Every cloud engenders not a storm.
Every cloud that spreads above / And veileth love, itself is love.
Every cock is proud on his own dunghill.
Every conceivable society may well be figured as properly and wholly a Church, in one or other of these three predicaments: an audibly preaching and prophesying Church, which is the best; a Church that struggles to preach and prophesy, but cannot as yet till its Pentecost come; a Church gone dumb with old age, or which only mumbles delirium prior to dissolution.
Every cottage should have its porch, its oven, and its tank.
Every couple is not a pair.
Every craw thinks her ain bird whitest.
Every creature can bear well-being except man.
Every crime has in the moment of its perpetration its own avenging angel.
Every day hath its night, every weal its woe.
Every day in thy life is a leaf in thy history.
Every day is the best day in the year. No man has learned anything rightly until he knows that every day is Doomsday.
Every day should be spent by us as if it were to be our last.
Every department of knowledge passes successively through three stages: the theological, or fictitious; the metaphysical, or abstract; and the scientific, or positive.
Every desire bears its death in its very gratification.
Every desire is a viper in the bosom, who,
when he was chill, was harmless, but when warmth gave him strength, exerted it in poison.
Every dog must have his day.
Every door may be shut but death's door.
Every established religion was once a heresy.
Every event that a man would master must be mounted on the run, and no man ever caught the reins of a thought except as it galloped past him.
Every evil to which we do not succumb is a
benefactor; we gain the strength of the temptation we resist.
Every excess causes a defect; every deficit, an excess. Every sweet has its sour; every evil, its good. Every faculty which is a receiver of pleasure has an equal penalty put on its abuse.
Every experiment, by multitudes or by individuals, that has a sensual and selfish aim, will fail.
Every faculty is conserved and increased by its appropriate exercise.
Every fancy that we would substitute for a reality is, if we saw it aright and saw the whole, not only false, but every way less beautiful and excellent than that which we sacrifice to it.
Every flood has its ebb.
Every fool thinks himself clever enough.
Every fool will be meddling.
Every foot will tread on him who is in the mud.
Every form of freedom is hurtful, except that which delivers us over to perfect command of ourselves.
Every form of human life is romantic.
Every fresh acquirement is another remedy
against affliction and time.
Every friend is to the other a sun and a sunflower also: he attracts and follows.
Every generation laughs at the old fashions, but follows religiously the herd.
Every generous action loves the public view, yet no theatre for virtue is equal to a consciousness of it.
Every genius has most power in his own language, and every heart in its own religion.
Every genius is defended from approach by quantities of unavailableness.
Every genuine work of art has as much reason
for being as the earth and the sun.
Every gift which is given, even though it be small, is in reality great if it be given with affection.
Every good act is charity. A man's true wealth hereafter is the good that he does in this world to his fellows.
Every good gift and every perfect gift is from above.
Every good gift comes from God.
Every good picture is the best of sermons
and lectures: the sense informs the soul.
Every good writer has much idiom; it is the life and spirit of language.
Every great and commanding movement in the annals of the world is the triumph of enthusiasm.
Every great and original writer, in proportion as he is great or original, must himself create the taste by which he is to be relished.
Every great book is an action, and every great action is a book.
Every great genius has a special vocation,
and when he has fulfilled it, he is no longer needed.
Every great man is unique.
Every great mind seeks to labour for eternity. All men are captivated by immediate advantages; great minds alone are excited by the prospect of distant good.
Every great poem is in itself limited by necessity, but in its suggestions unlimited and infinite.
Every great reform which has been effected has consisted, not in doing something new, but in undoing something old.
Every great writer is a writer of history, let
him treat on almost what subject he may. He carries with him for thousands of years a portion of his times; and, indeed, if only his own effigy were there, it would be greatly more than a fragment of his century.
Every healthy effort is directed from the inward to the outward world.
Every heart knows its own bitterness.
Every hero becomes a bore at last.
Every heroic act measures itself by its contempt of some external good; but it finds its own success at last, and then the prudent also extol.
Every honest miller has a golden thumb.
Every hour has its end.
Every house is builded by some man; but he that built all things is God.
Every human being is intended to have a character of his own, to be what no other is, to do what no other can.
Every human feeling is greater and larger than the exciting cause--a proof, I think, that man is designed for a higher state of existence.
Every idea must have a visible unfolding.
Every idle word that men shall speak, they shall give account thereof in the day of judgment.
Every inch a king.
Every inch of joy has an ell of annoy.
Every individual colour makes on men an impression of its own, and thereby reveals its nature to the eye as well as the mind.
Every individual nature has its own beauty.
Every inordinate cup is unbless'd, and the ingredient is a devil.
Every joy that comes to us is only to strengthen us for some greater labour that is to succeed.
Every knave is a thorough knave, and a thorough knave is a knave throughout.
Every light has its shadow.
Every little fish expects to become a whale.
Every little helps.
Every little helps, as the sow said when she snapt at a gnat.
Every loving woman is a priestess of the past.
Every man alone is sincere; at the entrance of a second person, hypocrisy begins.
Every man as an individual is secondary to
what he is as a worker for the progress of his kind and the glory of the gift allotted to him.
Every man can build a chapel in his breast, himself the priest, his heart the sacrifice, and the earth he treads on the altar.
Every man can guide an ill wife but him that has her.
Every man carries an enemy in his own bosom.
Every man carries within him a potential madman.
Every man deems that he has precisely the
trials and temptations which are the hardest to bear; but they are so because they are the very ones he needs.
Every man desires to live long, but no man would be old.
Every man feels instinctively that all the beautiful sentiments in the world weigh less than a single lovely action.
Every man has a bag hanging before him in which he puts his neighbour's faults, and another behind him in which he stows his own.
Every man has a goose that lays golden eggs, if he only knew it.
Every man has at times in his mind the ideal
of what he should be, but is not. In all men that really seek to improve, it is better than the actual character.
Every man hath business and desire, / Such as it is.
Every man has his fault, and honesty is his.
Every man has his lot, and the wide world before him.
Every man has his own style, just as he has his own nose.
Every man has his weak side.
Every man has in himself a continent of undiscovered character. Happy is he who acts the Columbus to his own soul.
Every man has just as much vanity as he wants understanding.
Every man hath a good and a bad angel attending on him in particular all his life long.
Every man, however good he may be, has a still better man dwelling in him which is properly himself, but to whom nevertheless he is often unfaithful. It is to this interior and less unstable being that we should attach ourselves, not to the changeable every-day man.
Every man in his lifetime needs to thank his
faults.
Every man is an impossibility until he is born; everything impossible till we see it a success.
Every man is a quotation from all his ancestors.
Every man is a rascal as soon as he is sick.
Every man is exceptional.
Every man is his own greatest dupe.
Every man is not so much a workman in the world as he is a suggestion of that he should be. Men walk as prophecies of the next age.
Every man is the architect of his own fortune.
Every man must carry his own sack to the mill.
Every man must in a measure be alone in the world. No heart was ever cast in the same mould as that which we bear within us.
Every man of sound brain whom you meet
knows something worth knowing better than yourself.
Every man ought to have his opportunity to conquer the world for himself.
Every man rejoices twice when he has a partner of his joy.
Every man seeks the truth, but God only knows who has found it.
Every man shall bear his own burden.
Every man shall kiss his lips that giveth a
right answer.
Every man should study conciseness in speaking; it is a sign of ignorance not to know that long speeches, though they may please the speaker, are the torture of the hearer.
Every man stamps his value on himself. The price we challenge for ourselves is given us.
Every man takes care that his neighbour shall not cheat him.
Every man acts truly so long as he acts his nature, or some way makes good the faculties in himself.
Every man turns his dreams into realities as
far as he can. Man is cold as ice to the truth, but as fire to falsehood.
Every man who observes vigilantly and resolves steadfastly grows unconsciously into a genius.
Every man who strikes blows for power, for influence, for institutions, for the right, must be just as good an anvil as he is a hammer.
Every man who would do anything well must come to us from a higher ground.
Every man willingly gives value to the praise which he receives, and considers the sentence passed in his favour as the sentence of discernment.
Every man, within that inconsiderable figure
of his, contains a whole spirit-kingdom and reflex of the All; and, though to the eye but some six standard feet in size, reaches downwards and upwards, unsurveyable, fading into the regions of immensity and eternity.
Every man without passions has within him no principle of action nor motive to act.
Every man's blind in his ain cause.
Every man's destiny is in his own hands.
Every man's follies are the caricature resemblances of his wisdom.
Every man's life lies within the present.
 (a Douglas
Every man's own reason is his best Œdipus.
Every man's powers have relation to some kind of work, and wherever he finds that kind of work which he can do best, he finds that by which he can best build up or make his manhood.
Every man's reason is every man's oracle.
Every moment, as it passes, is of infinite
value, for it is the representative of a whole eternity.
Every moment instructs, and every object, for wisdom is infused into every form. It has been poured into us as blood; it convulsed us as pain; it slid into us as pleasure.
Every morsel to a satisfied hunger is only a new labour to a tired digestion.
Every mortal longs for his parade-place; would still wish, at banquets, to be master of some seat or other wherein to overtop this or that plucked goose of the neighbourhood.
Every movement in the skies or upon the earth proclaims to us that the universe is under government.
Every natural action is graceful.
Every natural fact is a symbol of some spiritual fact.
Every newly discovered truth judges the world, separates the good from the evil, and calls on faithful souls to make sure their election.
Every new opinion, at its starting, is precisely in a minority of one.
Every noble crown is, and on earth will ever be, a crown of thorns.
Every noble life leaves the fibre of it interwoven for ever in the work of the world.
Every noble work is at first impossible.
Every novel is a debtor to Homer.
Every offence is not a hate at first.
Every one believes in his youth that the world really began with him, and that all merely exists for his sake.
Every one bows to the bush that bields

Every one can master a grief but he that has it.
Every one complains of his memory, no one of
his judgment.
Every one draws the water to his own mill.
Every one excels in something in which another fails.
Every one fault seeming monstrous till his fellow-fault came to match it.
Every one finds sin sweet and repentance bitter.
Every one for himself and God for us all.
Every one has a trial of his own: my wife is mine. Happy is he who has no other.
Every one is a preacher under the gallows.
Every one is as God made him, and often a great deal worse.
Every one is his own worst enemy.
Every one is judge of what a man seems, no
one of what a man is.
Every one is poorer in proportion as he has more wants, and counts not what he has, but wishes only what he has not.
Every one is well or ill at ease according as he finds himself.
Every one knows best where his shoe pinches him.
Every one knows better than he practises, and recognises a better law than he obeys.
Every one knows good counsel except him who
needs it.
Every one of us believes in his heart, or would like to have others believe, that he is something which he is not.
Every one of us shall give account of himself to God.
Every one rakes the fire under his own pot.
Every one regards his duty as a troublesome master from whom he would like to be free.
Every one should sweep before his own door.
Every one sings as he has the gift, and marries as he has the luck.
Every one that asketh receiveth; and he that seeketh findeth; and to him that knocketh it shall be opened.
Every one that doeth evil hateth the light.
Every one that is of the truth heareth my voice.
Every one thinks his own burden the heaviest.
Every one who is able to administer what he has, has enough.
Every one would be wise; no one will become so.
Every one would rather believe than exercise his own judgment.
Every opinion reacts on him who utters it.
Every other master is known by what he
utters; the master of style commends himself to me by what he wisely passes over in silence.
Every painter ought to paint what he himself loves.
Every passion gives a particular cast to the countenance, and is apt to discover itself in some feature or other.
Every people has its prophet.
Every period of life has its peculiar prejudices. Whoever saw old age that did not applaud the past and condemn the present?
Every period of life has its peculiar temptations
and dangers.
Every period of life is obliged to borrow its happiness from the time to come.
Every person who manages another is a hypocrite.
Every petition to God is a precept to man.
Every place is safe to him who lives with justice.
Every pleasure pre-supposes some sort of
activity.
Every poet, be his outward lot what it may, finds himself born in the midst of prose; he has to struggle from the littleness and obstruction of an actual world into the freedom and infinitude of an ideal.
Every power of both heaven and earth is friendly to a noble and courageous activity.
Every production of genius must be the production of enthusiasm.
Every race has its own habitat.
Every reader reads himself out of the book
that he reads.
Every real master of speaking or writing uses his personality as he would any other serviceable material.
Every real need is appeased and every vice stimulated by satisfaction.
Every rightly constituted mind ought to rejoice, not so much in knowing anything clearly, as in feeling that there is infinitely more which it cannot know.
Every rose has its thorn.
Every scripture is to be interpreted by the
same spirit which gave it forth.
Every sect, as far as reason will help it, gladly uses it; when it fails them, they cry out it is matter of faith, and above reason.
Every shadow points to the sun.
Every ship is a romantic object except that we sail in.
Every shoe fits not every foot.
Every shot does not bring down a bird.
Every soo (sow) to its ain trough.
Every species of activity is met by a negation.
Every spirit builds itself a house, and beyond its house a world, and beyond its world a heaven.
Every spirit makes its house, but afterwards the house confines the spirit.
Every step of life shows how much caution is required.
Every step of progress which the world has made has been from scaffold to scaffold and from stake to stake.
Every Stoic was a Stoic, but in Christendom
where is the Christian?
Every style formed elaborately on any model must be affected and strait-laced.
Every subject's duty is the king's, but every subject's soul is his own.
Every tear of sorrow sown by the righteous springs up a pearl.
Everything a man parts with is the cost of something. Everything he receives is the compensation of something.
Everything calls for interest, only it must be
an interest divested of self-interest and sincere.
Everything comes if a man will only wait.
Everything, even piety, is dangerous in a man without judgment.
Everything good in a man thrives best when properly recognised.
Everything good in man leans on what is higher.
Everything good is on the highway.
Everything great is not always good, but all good things are great.
Everything holy is before what is unholy; guilt presupposes innocence, not the reverse; angels, but not fallen ones, were created.
Everything in life, to be of value, must have a sequence.
Everything in nature contains all the powers of nature. Everything is made of one hidden stuff.
Everything in nature goes by law, and not by
luck.
Everything in nature has a positive and a negative pole.
Everything in nature is a puzzle until it finds its solution in man, who solves it in some way with God, and so completes the circle of creation.
Everything in the world can be borne except a long succession of beautiful days.
Everything in this world depends upon will.
Everything in this world is a tangled yarn;
we taste nothing in its purity; we do not remain two moments in the same state.
Everything is as you take it.
Everything is beautiful, seen from the point of the intellect; but all is sour if seen as experience.
Everything is good as it comes from the hands of the Creator; everything degenerates in the hands of man.
Everything is mere opinion.
Everything is sold to skill and labour.
Everything is sweetened by risk.
Everything is what it is, and not another thing.
Everything is worth the money that can be got for it.
Everything looks easy that is practised to perfection.
Everything rises but to fall, and increases but
to decay.
Everything runs to excess; every good quality is noxious if unmixed; and to carry the danger to the edge of ruin, Nature causes each man's peculiarity to superabound.
Everything springs into being and passes away according to law, yet how fluctuating is the lot that presides over the life which is to us so priceless.
Everything that exceeds the bounds of moderation has an unstable foundation.
Everything that happens, happens of necessity.
Everything that happens in this world is part
of a great plan of God running through all time.
Everything that happens to us leaves some trace behind it, and everything insensibly contributes to make us what we are.
Everything that is exquisite hides itself.
Everything that is popular deserves the attention of the philosopher; although it may not be of any worth in itself, yet it characterises the people.
Everything that looks to the future elevates human nature; for never is life so low as when occupied with the present.
Everything that tends to emancipate us from
external restraint without adding to our own power of self-government is mischievous.
Everything unnatural is imperfect.
Everything useful to the life of man arises from the ground, but few things arise in that condition which is requisite to render them useful.
Every thought that arises in the mind, in its rising aims to pass out of the mind into act; just as every plant, in the moment of generation, struggles up to the light.
Every thought was once a poem.
Every thought which genius and piety throw
into the world alters the world.
Every time a man smiles, much more when he laughs, it adds something to his fragment of life.
Every time you forgive a man you weaken him and strengthen yourself.
Every transition is a crisis, and a crisis presupposes sickness.
Every traveller has a home of his own, and he learns to appreciate it the more from his wandering.
Every tree that bringeth not forth good fruit is hewn down and cast into the fire.
Every true man's apparel fits your thief.
Every tub must stand on its own bottom.
Every unpleasant feeling is a sign that I have
become untrue to my resolutions.
Every unpunished murder takes away something from the security of every man's life.
Every vicious habit and chronic disease communicates itself by descent, and by purity of birth the entire system of the human body and soul may be gradually elevated, or by recklessness of birth degraded, until there shall be as much difference between the well-bred and ill-bred human creature (whatever pains be taken with their education) as between a wolf-hound and the vilest mongrel cur.
Every violation of truth is a stab at the health of society.
Every wanton and causeless restraint of the will of the subject, whether practised by a monarch, a nobility, or a popular assembly, is a degree of tyranny.
Everywhere I am hindered of meeting God in
my brother, because he has shut his own temple doors, and recites fables merely of his brother's or his brother's brother's God.
Everywhere in life the true question is, not what we gain, but what we do; so also in intellectual matters it is not what we receive, but what we are made to give, that chiefly contents and profits us.
Everywhere the formed world is the only habitable one.
Everywhere the human soul stands between a hemisphere of light and another of darkness; on the confines of two everlasting, hostile empires, Necessity and Free Will.
Everywhere the individual seeks to show himself off to advantage, and nowhere honestly endeavours to make himself subservient to the whole.
Every white will have its black, / And every
sweet its sour.
Every why hath a wherefore.
Every wise woman buildeth her house, but the foolish plucketh it down with her hands.
Every word was once a poem.
Every worm beneath the moon / Draws different threads, and late and soon / Spins, toiling out his own cocoon.
Every youth, from the king's son downwards,
should learn to do something finely and thoroughly with his hand.
E vestigio
Evil and good are everywhere, like shadow and substance; (for men) inseparable, yet not hostile, only opposed.
Evil, be thou my good.
Evil comes to us by ells and goes away by inches.
Evil communications corrupt good manners.
Evil events from evil causes spring.
Evil is a far more cunning and persevering propagandist than good, for it has no inward strength, and is driven to seek countenance and sympathy.
Evil is generally committed under the hope of some advantage the pursuit of virtue seldom obtains.
Evil is merely privative, not absolute; it is like cold, which is the privation of heat. All evil is so much death or nonentity.
Evil is wrought by want of thought / As well
as want of heart.
Evil, like a rolling stone upon a mountain-top, / A child may first impel, a giant cannot stop.
Evil men understand not judgment, but they that seek the Lord understand all things.
Evil news rides post, while good news bates.
Evil often triumphs, but never conquers.
Evil, what we call evil, must ever exist while
man exists; evil, in the widest sense we can give it, is precisely the dark, disordered material out of which man's freewill has to create an edifice of order and good. Ever must pain urge us to labour; and only in free effort can any blessedness be imagined for us.
Evils can never pass away; for there must always remain something which is antagonistic to good.
Evils that take leave, / On their departure most of all show evil.
Evolare rus ex urbe tanquam ex vinculis
Ewig jung zu bleiben / Ist, wie Dichter schreiben / Hochstes Lebensgut; / Willst du es erwerben / Musst du frühe sterben
Ewig zu sein in jedem Momente
Ex abrupto
Ex abundante cautela
Ex abusu non arguitur ad usum
Ex abusu non argumentum ad desuetudinem
Exact justice is commonly more merciful in
the long run than pity, for it tends to foster in men those stronger qualities which make them good citizens.
Ex æquo
Ex æquo et bono
Exaggeration is a blood relation to falsehood.
Exaggeration is to paint a snake and add legs.
Examine the religious principles which have, in fact, prevailed in the world. You will scarcely be persuaded that they are anything but sick men's dreams.
Examine your soul and its emotions, and thoughts will be to you so many glorious revelations of the Godhead.
Example acquires tenfold authority when it speaks from the grave.
Example has more followers than reason.
Example is a hazardous lure: where the wasp
gets through, the gnat sticks.
Example is more efficacious than precept.
Example is more forcible than precept. People look at me six days in the week, to see what I mean on the seventh.
Example is the school of mankind, and they will learn at no other.
Examples of rare intelligence, yet more rarely cultivated, are not lights kindled for a moment; they live on here in their good deeds, and in their venerated memories.
Examples would indeed be excellent things,
were not people so modest that none will set them, and so vain that none will follow them.
Ex animo
Ex aperto
Ex auribus cognoscitur asinus
Ex cathedra
Excellence is never granted to man but as the
reward of labour.
Excellent wretch! Perdition catch my soul, / But I do love thee! and when I love thee not, / Chaos is come again.
Excelsior
Except a corn of wheat fall into the ground and die, it abideth alone; but if it die, it bringeth forth much fruit.
Except by mastership and servantship, there is no conceivable deliverance from tyranny and slavery.
Except I be by Silvia in the night, / There is
no music in the nightingale.
Except in knowing what it has to do and how to do it, the soul cannot resolve the riddle of its destiny.
Except in obedience to the heaven-chosen is freedom not so much as conceivable.
Except pain of body and remorse of conscience, all our evils are imaginary.
Except the Lord build the house, they labour in vain that build it; except the Lord keep the city, the watchman waketh in vain.
Except ye be converted and become as little
children, ye shall not enter into the kingdom of heaven.
Exceptio probat regulam
Exceptis excipiendis
Excepto quod non simul esses, cætera lætus
Excerpta
Excess generally causes reaction, and produces
a change in the opposite direction, whether it be in the seasons, or in individuals, or in governments.
Excess in apparel is costly folly. The very trimming of the vain world would clothe all the naked ones.
Excess of wealth is cause of covetousness.
Excessit ex ephebis
Excessive distrust is not less hurtful than its opposite. Most men become useless to him who is unwilling to risk being deceived.
Excitari, non hebescere
Exclusa opes omnes
Ex commodo
Ex concesso
Ex confesso
Ex curia
Excusing of a fault / Doth make the fault worse by the excuse.
Ex debito justitiæ
Ex delicto
Ex desuetudine amittuntur privilegia
Ex diuturnitate temporis omnia præsumuntur
esse solemniter acta
Exeat
Exegi monumentum ære perennius
Exempli gratia
Exemplo plus quam ratione vivimus
Exemplumque Dei quisque est in imagine
parva
Exercise the muscles well, but spare the nerves always.
Exercitatio optimus est magister
Exercitatio potest omnia
Exeunt omnes
Ex facie
Ex factis non ex dictis amici pensandi
Ex facto jus oritur
Ex fide fortis
Ex fumo dare lucem
Ex humili magna ad fastigia rerum / Extollit, quoties voluit fortuna jocari
Ex hypothesi
Exigite ut mores teneros ceu pollice ducat, / Ut si quis cera vultum facit
Exigui numero, sed bello vivida virtus
Exiguum est ad legem bonum esse
Exile is terrible to those who have, as it were, a circumscribed habitation; but not to those who look upon the whole globe as one city.
Exilioque domos et dulcia limina mutant /
Atque alio patriam quærunt sub sole jacentem
Ex improviso
Ex industria
Ex inimico cogita posse fieri amicum
Ex integro
Ex intervallo
Existence is not to be measured by mere duration.
Exitio est avidium mare nautis
Ex malis eligere minima
Ex malis moribus bonæ leges natæ sunt
Ex mero motu
Ex nihilo nihil fit
Ex officio
Ex opere operato
Exoriare aliquis nostris ex ossibus ultor
Ex otio plus negotii quam ex negotio habemus
Ex parte
Ex pede Herculem
Expect injuries; for men are weak, and thou thyself doest such too often.
Expediency is the science of exigencies.
Expense of time is the most costly of all expenses.
Experience, a jewel that I have purchased at an infinite rate.
Experience converts us to ourselves when books fail us.
Experience is a text to which reflection and knowledge supply the commentary.
Experience is by industry achieved, / And perfected by swift course of time.
"Experience is the best teacher," only the
school-fees are heavy.
Experience is the grand spiritual doctor.
Experience is the mistress of fools.
Experience is the only genuine knowledge.
Experience keeps a dear school, but fools will learn in no other, and scarce in that; for it is true we may give advice, but we cannot give conduct.
Experience makes even fools wise.
Experience makes us see a wonderful difference between devotion and goodness.
Experience takes dreadfully high school-wages, but teaches as no other.
Experience teaches us again and again that there is nothing men have less command over than their tongues.
Experience teacheth that resolution is a sole help in need.
Experience that is bought is good, if not too
dear.
Experience to most men is like the stern-lights of a ship, which illumine only the track it has passed.
Experientia docet
Experimentum crucis
Expert men can execute, but learned men are more fit to judge and censure.
Experto credite
Expertus metuit
Expetuntur divitiæ ad perficiendas voluptates
Explorant adversa viros; perque aspera duro / Nititur ad laudem virtus interrita clivo
Ex post facto
Expression alone can invest beauty with
supreme and lasting command over the eye.
Expressio unius est exclusio alterius
Ex professo
Ex quovis ligno non fit Mercurius
Ex scintilla incendium
Ex tempore
Extended empire, like expanded gold, exchanges solid strength for feeble splendour.
External manners of lament / Are merely shadows to the unseen grief / That swells with silence in the tortured soul.
Extinctus amabilis idem
Extinguished theologians lie about the cradle of every science, as the strangled snakes beside that of Hercules.
Extra ecclesiam nulla salus
Extra lutum pedes habes
Extra muros
Extra telorum jactum
Extrema gaudii luctus occupat
Extrema manus nondum operibus ejus imposita est
Extreme justice is often extreme injustice.
Extremes beget extremes.
Extreme in all things! hadst thou been betwixt,
/ Thy throne had still been thine, or never been.
Extremes in nature equal ends produce; / In man they join to some mysterious use.
Extremes meet.
Extremes, though contrary, have the like effects; extreme heat mortifies, like extreme cold; extreme love breeds satiety as well as extreme hatred; and too violent rigour tempts chastity as much as too much license.
Extremis malis extrema remedia
Extremity is the trier of spirits.
Exuerint sylvestrem animum, cultuque frequenti, / In quascunque voces artes, haud tarda sequentur
Ex umbra in solem
Ex ungue leonem
Ex uno disce omnes
Ex vita discedo, tanquam ex hospitio, non
tanquam ex domo
Ex vitio alterius sapiens emendat suum
Ex vitulo bos fit
Ex vultibus hominum mores colligere
Eye hath not seen, nor ear heard, neither have entered into the heart of man, the things which God hath prepared for them that love him.
Eye Nature's walks, shoot folly as it flies, /
And catch the manners living as they rise.
Eyes are better, on the whole, than telescopes or microscopes.
Eyes bright, with many tears behind them.
Eyes not down-dropp'd nor over-bright, but fed with the clear-pointed flame of chastity.
Eyes / Of microscopic power, that could discern / The population of a dewdrop.
Eyes raised towards heaven are always beautiful,
whatever they be.
Eyes speak all languages; wait for no letter of introduction; they ask no leave of age or rank; they respect neither poverty nor riches, neither learning, nor power, nor virtue, nor sex, but intrude and come again, and go through and through you in a moment of time.
Eyes will not see when the heart wishes them to be blind; desire conceals truth as darkness does the earth.
Ez for war, I call it murder; / There you hev it plain and flat; / I don't want to go no furder / Than my Testyment for that.
Fa bene, e non guardare a chi
Faber suæ fortunæ
Fabricando fabri fimus
Fabula, nec sentis, tota jactaris in urbe
Faces are as legible as books, only they are read in much less time, and are much less likely to deceive us.
Faces are as paper money, for which, on demand, there frequently proves to be no gold in the coffer.
Faces are but a gallery of portraits.
Faces which have charmed us the most escape us the soonest.
Fac et excusa
Facetiarum apud præpotentes in longum memoria est
Fach
Facienda
Facies non omnibus una, / Nec diversa tamen; qualem decet esse sororum
Facies tua computat annos
Facile est imperium in bonis
Facile est inventis addere
Facile largiri de alieno
Facile omnes cum valemus recta consilia / Ægrotis damus
Facile princeps
Facilis descensus Averno est, / Noctes atque dies patet atri janua Ditis; / Sed revocare gradum superasque evadere ad auras, / Hoc opus, hic labor est
Facilius crescit quam inchoatur dignitas
Facilius sit Nili caput invenire
Facinus audax incipit, / Qui cum opulento pauper homine cœpit rem habere aut negotium
Facinus majoris abollæ
Facinus quos inquinat æquat
Facit indignatio versum
Facito aliquid operis, ut semper te diabolus
inveniat occupatum
Faciunt næ intelligendo, ut nihil intelligant
Façon de parler
Facsimile
Facta canam; sed erunt qui me finxisse loquantur
Facta ejus cum dictis discrepant
Facta, non verba
Fact is better than fiction, if only we could get it pure.
Facts are apt to alarm us more than the most dangerous principles.
Facts are chiels that winna ding, / And downa be disputed.
Facts are stubborn things.
Facts are to the mind the same thing as food to the body.
Facts--historical facts, still more biographical--are sacred hierograms, for which the fewest have the key.
Factis ignoscite nostris / Si scelus ingenio scitis abesse meo
Factotum
Factum abiit; monumenta manent
Factum est
Factum est illud; fieri infectum non potest
Fader og Moder ere gode, end er Gud bedre
Fæx populi
Fagerhed uden Tugt, Rose uden Hugt
Fähigkeiten werden vorausgesetzt; sie sollen zu Fertigkeiten werden
Failures are with heroic minds the stepping-stones to success.
Fain would I, but I dare not; I dare, and yet I may not; / I may, although I care not, for pleasure when I play not.
"Fain would I climb, but that I fear a fall."
Fainéant
Faint heart never won fair lady.
Faint not; the miles to heaven are but few and short.
Fair and softly goes far in a day.
Fair enough, if good enough.
Fair fa' guid drink, for it gars
speak as they think.
Fair fa' your honest, sonsie face, / Great chieftain o' the puddin' race! / Abune them a' ye tak' your place, / Paunch, tripe, or thairm; / Weel are ye wordy o' a grace / As lang's my airm.
Fair flowers don't remain lying by the highway.
Fair folk are aye fusionless
Fair is not fair, but that which pleaseth.
Fair maidens wear nae purses
Fair play's a jewel.
Fair tresses man's imperial race ensnare, / And beauty draws us with a single hair.
Fair words butter no parsnips.
Faire bonne mine à mauvaise jeu
Faire le chien couchant
Faire le diable à quatre
Faire le pendant
Faire mon devoir
Faire patte de velours
Faire prose sans le savoir
Faire sans dire
Faire un trou pour en boucher un autre
Fairest of stars, last in the train of night, / If better thou belong not to the dawn.
Fais ce que dois, advienne que pourra
Fait accompli
Faith affirms many things respecting which the senses are silent; but nothing that they deny.
Faith always implies the disbelief of a lesser fact in favour of a greater. A little mind often sees the unbelief, without seeing the belief, of large ones.
Faith and joy are the ascensive forces of song.
Faith builds a bridge across the gulf of death, / To break the shock blind Nature cannot shun, / And lands thought smoothly on the farther shore.
Faith builds a bridge from the old world to the
next.
Faith doth not lie dead in the breast, but is lovely and fruitful in bringing forth good works.
Faith, fanatic faith, once wedded fast, / To save dear falsehood, hugs it to the last.
Faith has given man an inward willingness, a world of strength wherewith to front a world of difficulty.
Faith in a better than that which appears is no less required by art than religion.
Faith is generally strongest in those whose character may be called weakest.
Faith is letting down our nets into the untransparent deeps at the Divine command, not knowing what we shall take.
Faith is like love; it does not admit of being forced.
Faith is love taking the form of aspiration.
Faith is loyalty to some inspired teacher, some spiritual hero.
Faith is necessary to victory.
Faith is nothing but spiritualised imagination.
Faith is nothing more than obedience.
Faith is not reason's labour, but repose.
Faith is not the beginning, but the end of all knowledge.
Faith is our largest manufacturer of good works, and wherever her furnaces are blown out, morality suffers.
Faith is required at thy hands, and a sincere life, not loftiness of intellect or inquiry into the deep mysteries of God.
Faith is taking God at His word.
Faith is that courage in the heart which trusts
for all good to God.
Faith is the creator of the Godhead; not that it creates anything in the Divine Eternal Being, but that it creates that Being in us.
Faith is the heroism of intellect.
Faith is the soul of religion, and works the body.
Faith loves to lean on Time's destroying arm.
Faith makes us, and not we it; and faith makes
its own forms.
Faith, mighty faith, the promise sees, / And looks to that alone; / Laughs at impossibilities, / And cries--"It shall be done."
Faith opens a way for the understanding; unbelief closes it.
Faith without works is like a bird without wings.
Faith's abode / Is mystery for evermore, / Its life, to worship and adore, / And meekly bow beneath the rod, / When the day is dark and the burden sore.
Faiths that are different in their roots, /
Where the will is right and the heart is sound, / Are much the same in their fruits.
Faithful are the wounds of a friend.
Faithful found / Among the faithless; faithful only he.
Faithfulness and sincerity are the highest things.
Falla pouco, e bem, ter-te-haô por alguem
Fallacia / Alia aliam trudit
Fallacies we are apt to put upon ourselves by taking words for things.
Fallentis semita vitæ
Fallit enim vitium, specie virtutis et umbra, / Cum sit triste habitu, vultuque et veste severum
Fallitur, egregio quisquis sub principe credit / Servitium. Nunquam libertas gratior extat / Quam sub rege pio
Falls have their risings, wanings have their
primes, / And desperate sorrows wait for better times.
Falsch ist das Geschlecht der Menschen
False as dicers' oaths.
False by degrees and exquisitely wrong.
False face must hide what the false heart doth know.
False folk should hae mony witnesses.
False freends are waur than bitter enemies.
False friends are like our shadow, close to us while we walk in the sunshine, but leaving us the instant we cross into the shade.
False glory is the rock of vanity.
False modesty is the masterpiece of vanity.
False modesty is the most decent of all falsehood.
False shame is the parent of many crimes.
Falsehood and death are synonymous.
Falsehood borders so closely upon truth, that a wise man should not trust himself too near the precipice.
Falsehood is cowardice; truth is courage.
Falsehood is easy, truth is difficult.
Falsehood is folly.
Falsehood is never so successful as when she baits her hook with truth.
Falsehood is our one enemy in this world.
Falsehood is so much the more commendable, by how much more it resembles truth, and is the more pleasing the more it is doubtful and possible.
Falsehood is the devil's daughter, and speaks
her father's tongue.
Falsehood is the essence of all sin.
Falsehood, like poison, will generally be rejected when administered alone; but when blended with wholesome ingredients may be swallowed unperceived.
Falsehood, like the dry rot, flourishes the more in proportion as air and light are excluded.
Falso damnati crimine mortis
Falsum in uno, falsum in omni
Falsus honor juvat, et mendax infamia terret / Quem nisi mendosum et medicandum
Fama clamosa
Fama crescit eundo
Fama nihil est celerius
Famæ damna majora sunt, quam quæ æstimari possint
Famæ laboranti non facile succurritur
Famam extendere factis.
Fame and censure with a tether / By fate are
always linked together.
Fame at its best is but a poor compensation for all the ills of existence.
Fame comes only when deserved, and then it is as inevitable as destiny, for it is destiny.
Fame is a fancied life in others' breath.
Fame is an undertaker that pays but little attention to the living, but bedizens the dead, furnishes out their funerals, and follows them to the grave.
Fame is a revenue payable only to our ghosts.
Fame is a shuttlecock. If it be struck only at one end of a room, it will soon fall to the floor. To keep it up, it must be struck at both ends.
Fame is but the breath of the people, and that often unwholesome.
Fame is no plant that grows on mortal soil.
Fame is not won on downy plumes nor under canopies.
Fame is the advantage of being known by
people of whom you yourself know nothing, and for whom you care as little.
Fame is the breath of popular applause.
Fame is the perfume of noble deeds.
Fame is the spur that the clear spirit doth raise, / (That last infirmity of noble minds,) / To scorn delights and live laborious days.
Fame may be compared to a scold; the best way to silence her is to let her alone, and she will at last be out of breath in blowing her own trumpet.
Fame only reflects the estimate in which a
man is held in comparison with others.
Fame sometimes hath created something of nothing.
Fame usually comes to those who are thinking about something else; very rarely to those who say to themselves, "Go to now, let us be a celebrated individual."
Fame, we may understand, is no sure test of merit, but only a probability of such: it is an accident, not a property, of a man; like light, it can give little or nothing, but at most may show what is given; often it is but a false glare, dazzling the eyes of the vulgar, lending, by casual extrinsic splendour, the brightness and manifold glance of the diamond to pebbles of no value.
Fame with men, / Being but ampler means to serve mankind, / Should have small rest or pleasure in herself, / But work as vassal to the larger love, / That dwarfs the petty love of one to one.
Fames et mora bilem in nasum conciunt
Fames, pestis, et bellum, populi sunt pernicies
Familiare est hominibus omnia sibi ignoscere
Familiarity breeds contempt.
Familiarity is a suspension of almost all the laws of civility which libertinism has introduced into society under the notion of ease.
Family likeness has often a deep sadness in it.
Famine hath a sharp and meagre face.
Fammi indovino, e ti farò ricco
Fanaticism is a fire which heats the mind indeed, but heats without purifying.
Fanaticism is such an overwhelming impression of the ideas relating to the future world as disqualifies for the duties of this.
Fanaticism is to superstition what delirium is
to fever and rage to anger.
Fanaticism obliterates the feelings of humanity.
Fanaticism, soberly defined, / Is the false fire of an o'erheated mind.
Fancy is capricious; wit must not be searched for, and pleasantry will not come in at a call.
Fancy is imagination in her youth and adolescence.
Fancy kills and fancy cures.
Fancy requires much, necessity but little.
Fancy restrained may be compared to a fountain, which plays highest by diminishing the aperture.
Fancy rules over two-thirds of the universe, the past and the future, while reality is confined to the present.
Fancy runs most furiously when a guilty conscience drives it.
Fancy surpasses beauty.
Fancy, when once brought into religion, knows not where to stop.
Fanfaronnade
Fanned fires and forced love ne'er did weel.
Fantastic tyrant of the amorous heart, / How hard thy yoke! how cruel is thy dart! / Those 'scape thy anger who refuse thy sway, / And those are punished most who most obey.
Fantasy is of royal blood; the senses, of noble descent; and reason, of civic
origin.
Fantasy is the true heaven-gate and hell-gate of man.
Far ahint maun follow the faster.
Far-awa fowls hae aye fair feathers.
Far better it is to know everything of a little than a little of everything.
Far frae court, far frae care.
Far from all resort of mirth / Save the cricket on the hearth.
Far from home is near to harm.
Far from the madding crowd's ignoble strife, /
Their sober wishes never learned to stray; / Along the cool sequester'd vale of life / They kept the noiseless tenor of their way.
Far greater numbers have been lost by hopes / Than all the magazines of daggers, ropes, / And other ammunitions of despair, / Were ever able to despatch by fear.
Far niente
Far-off cows have long horns.
Far-off fowls hae feathers fair, / And aye until ye try them; / Though they seem fair, still have a care, / They may prove waur than I am.
Far or forgot to me is near; / Shadow and
sunlight are the same; / The vanished gods to me appear; / And one to me are shame and fear.
Fare, fac
Fare thee well! and if for ever, / Still for ever fare thee well! / E'en though unforgiving, never / 'Gainst thee shall my heart rebel.
Fare you weel, auld Nickie-ben! / O wad ye tak' a thocht and men'! / Ye aiblins micht--I dinna ken--/ Still hae a stake: / I'm wae to think upo' yon den, / E'en for your sake.
Farewell, a long farewell to all my greatness! / This is the state of man: to-day he puts forth / The tender leaves of hope, to-morrow blossoms, / And bears his blushing honours thick upon him: / The third day comes a frost, a killing frost: / And when he thinks, good easy man, full surely / His greatness is a-ripening, nips his root / And then he falls, as I do.
Farewell! God knows when we shall meet
again. / I have a faint cold fear thrills through my veins, / That almost freezes up the heat of life.
Farewell, happy fields, / Where joy for ever dwells; hail, horror, hail!
Farewell the tranquil mind! farewell content! / Farewell the plumed troop and the big wars / That make ambition virtue! oh, farewell! / Farewell the neighing steed and the shrill trump, / The spirit-stirring drum, the ear-piercing fife, / The royal banner, and all quality, / Pride, pomp, and circumstance of glorious war!
Farewell to Lochaber, farewell to my Jean, / Where heartsome wi' thee I hae mony days been; / For Lochaber no more, Lochaber no more, / We'll maybe return to Lochaber no more.
Fari quæ sentiat
Farmers are the founders of civilisation.
Farrago libelli
Fas est et ab hoste doceri
Fashionability is a kind of elevated vulgarity.
Fashion, a word which fools use, / Their knavery and folly to excuse.
Fashion begins and ends in two things it
abhors most--singularity and vulgarity.
Fashion is a potency in art, making it hard to judge between the temporary and the lasting.
Fashion is aristocratic-autocratic.
Fashion is, for the most part, nothing but the ostentation of riches.
Fashion is gentility running away from vulgarity, and afraid to be overtaken by it. It is a sign that the two things are not far asunder.
Fashion is the great governor of the world.
Fashion is the science of appearances, and it inspires one with the desire to seem rather than to be.
Fashion seldom interferes with Nature without diminishing her grace and efficiency.
Fashion wears out more apparel than the man.
Fast and loose.
Fast bind, fast find.
Faster than his tongue / Did make offence, his eye did heal it up.
Fastidientis est stomachi multa degustare
Fasti et nefasti dies
Fat hens are aye ill layers.
Fat paunches make lean pates, and dainty
bits / Make rich the ribs, but bankrupt quite the wits.
Fata obstant
Fata volentem ducunt, nolentem trahunt
Fate follows and limits power; power attends and antagonises fate; we must respect fate as natural history, but there is more than natural history.
Fate hath no voice but the heart's impulses.
Fate is a distinguished but an expensive tutor.
Fate is character.
Fate is ever better than design.
Fate is known to us as limitations.
Fate is nothing but the deeds committed in a former state of existence.
Fate is the friend of the good, the guide of the wise, the tyrant of the foolish, the enemy of the bad.
Fate is unpenetrated causes.
Fate leads the willing, but drives the stubborn.
Fate made me what I am, may make me nothing; / But either that or nothing must I be; / I will not live degraded.
Fate steals along with silent tread, / Found
oftenest in what least we dread; / Frowns in the storm with angry brow, / But in the sunshine strikes the blow.
Fatetur facinus is qui judicium fugit
Father of all! in every age, / In every clime adored, / By saint, by savage, and by sage, / Jehovah, Jove, or Lord.
Fathers alone a father's heart can know, / What secret tides of sweet enjoyment flow / When brothers love! But if their hate succeeds, / They wage the war, but 'tis the father bleeds.
Fathers first enter bonds to Nature's ends; / And are her sureties ere they are a friend's.
Fathers that wear rags / Do make their children
blind; / But fathers that wear bags / Do make their children kind.
Fathers their children and themselves abuse / That wealth a husband for their daughters choose.
Fatigatis humus cubile est
Fatta la legge, trovata la malizia
Faulheit ist der Schlüssel zur Armuth
Faulheit ist Dummheit des Körpers, und
Dummheit Faulheit des Geistes
Faultily faultless, icily regular, splendidly null.
Faults are beauties in lover's eyes.
Faults are thick when love is thin.
Faute de grives le diable mange des merles
Faux pas
Favete linguis
Favourable chance is the god of all men who follow their own devices instead of obeying a law they believe in.
Favour and gifts disturb justice.
Favour is deceitful, and beauty is vain: but a woman that feareth the Lord, she shall be praised.
Favours, and especially pecuniary ones, are
generally fatal to friendship.
Favours unused are favours abused.
Fax mentis honestæ gloria
Fax mentis incendium gloriæ
Fay ce que voudras
Fear always springs from ignorance.
Fear and sorrow are the true characters and inseparable companions of most melancholy.
Fear can keep a man out of danger, but courage only can support him in it.
Fear God and keep his commandments; for this is the whole duty of man.
Fear God; honour the king.
Fear guards the vineyard.
Fear guides more to their duty than gratitude.
Fear has many eyes.
Fear hath torment.
Fear is an instructor of great sagacity, and the herald of all revolutions. It has boded, and mowed, and gibbered for ages over government and property.
Fear is described by Spenser to ride in armour,
at the clashing whereof he looks afeared of himself.
Fear is far more painful to cowardice than death to true courage.
Fear is the underminer of all determinations; and necessity, the victorious rebel of all laws.
Fear is the virtue of slaves; but the heart that loveth is willing.
Fear is worse than fighting.
Fear not that tyrants shall rule for ever, / Or
the priests of the bloody faith; / They stand on the brink of that mighty river / Whose waves they have tainted with death.
Fear not the confusion

of thee, but that within thee; strive after unity, but seek it not in uniformity; strive after repose, but through the equipoise, thy activity.
Fear not the future; weep not for the past.
Fear not, then, thou child infirm; / There's no god dare wrong a worm.
Fear not where Heaven bids come; / Heaven's never deaf but when man's heart is dumb.
Fear of change / Perplexes monarchs.
Fear oftentimes restraineth words, but makes not thought to cease.
Fear sometimes adds wings to the heels, and sometimes nails them to the ground and fetters them from moving.
Fear to do base, unworthy things is valour; / If they be done to us, to suffer them / Is valour too.
Fear's a fine spur.
Fear's a large promiser; who subject live /
To that base passion, know not what they give.
Fears of the brave and follies of the wise.
Fearfully and wonderfully made.
Fearless minds climb soonest into crowns.
Feasting makes no friendship.
Feast-won, fast-lost.
Feather by feather the goose is plucked.
Fecisti enim nos ad te, et cor inquietum donec requiescat in te
Fecit
Fecundi calices quem non fecere disertum?
Fede ed innocenzia son reperte / Solo ne' pargoletti
Feeble souls always set to work at the wrong time.
Feebleness is sometimes the best security.
Feed a cold and starve a fever.
Feed no man in his sins; for adulation / Doth make thee parcel-devil in damnation.
Feeling comes before reflection.
Feeling should be stirred only when it can be sent to labour for worthy ends.
Feelings are always purest and most glowing
in the hour of meeting and farewell; like the glaciers, which are transparent and rose-hued only at sunrise and sunset, but throughout the day grey and cold.
Feelings are like chemicals; the more you analyse them, the worse they smell.
Feelings come and go like light troops following the victory of the present; but principles, like troops of the line, are undisturbed, and stand fast.
Feelings, like flowers and butterflies, last longer the later they are delayed.
Fehlst du, lass dich's nicht betrüben; Denn der Mangel führt zum Lieben; / Kannst dich nicht vom Fehl befrein, / Wirst du Andern gern verzeihn
Feindlich ist die Welt / Und falsch gesinnt;
Es liebt ein jeder nur / Sich selbst
Felices errore suo
Felices ter et amplius / Quos irrupta tenet copula, nec, malis / Divulsus quærimoniis, / Suprema citius solvet amor die
Felicitas nutrix est iracundiæ
Feliciter is sapit, qui periculo alieno sapit
Felicity lies much in fancy.
Felicity, not fluency, of language is a merit.
Felix, heu nimium felix
Felix qui nihil debet
Felix qui potuit rerum cognoscere causas
Felix, qui quod amat, defendere fortiter andet
Fell luxury! more perilous to youth than storms or quicksands, poverty or chains.
Fell sorrow's tooth doth never rankle more / Than when it bites but lanceth not the sore.
Fellowship in treason is a bad ground of confidence.
Felo de se
Female friendships are of rapid growth.
Feme covert

Femme, argent et vin ont leur bien et leur venin
Femme de chambre

Femme rit quand elle peut, et pleure quand elle veut

Fere libenter homines id quod volunt credunt
