Ferme fugiendo in media fata ruitur
Ferme modèle
Fern von Menschen wachsen Grundsätze; unter ihnen Handlungen
Ferreus assiduo consumitur annulus usu
Ferro, non gladio
Fervet olla, vivit amicitia
Fervet opus
Festina lente
Festinare nocet, nocet et cunctatio sæpe; / Tempore quæque suo qui facit, ille sapit
Festinatione nil tutius in discordiis civilibus
Festinatio tarda est
Fetch a spray from the wood and place it on your mantel-shelf, and your household ornaments will seem plebeian beside its nobler fashion and bearing. It will wave superior there, as if used to a more refined and polished circle. It has a salute and response to all your enthusiasm and heroism.
Fête champêtre
Fêtes des mœurs
Fette Küche, magere Erbschaft
Feu de joie
Few are fit to be entrusted with themselves.
Few are open to conviction, but the majority of men to persuasion.
Few, few shall part where many meet; The snow shall be their winding-sheet, / And every turf beneath their feet / Shall be a soldier's sepulchre.
Few have all they need, none all they wish.
Few have borne unconsciously the spell of loveliness.
Few have the gift of discerning when to have done.
Few have wealth, but all must have a home.
Few love to hear the sins they love to act.
Few may play with the devil and win.
Few men are much worth loving in whom there is not something well worth laughing at.
Few men have been admired by their domestics.
Few men dare show their thoughts of worst or
best.
Few men have any next; they live from hand to mouth without plan, and are ever at the end of their line.
Few men have imagination enough for the truth of reality.
Few men have virtue to withstand the highest bidder.
Few minds wear out; more rust out.
Few mortals are so insensible that their affections
cannot be gained by mildness, their confidence by sincerity, their hatred by scorn or neglect.
Few of the many wise apothegms which have been uttered, from the time of the seven sages of Greece to that of Poor Richard, have prevented a single foolish action.
Few people know how to be old.
Few persons have courage to appear as good as they really are.
Few spirits are made better by the pain and languor of sickness; as few great pilgrims become eminent saints.
Few take wives for God's sake, or for fair
looks.
Few things are impossible to diligence and skill.
Few things are impracticable in themselves; and it is from want of application rather than want of means that men fail of success.
Few things are more unpleasant than the transaction of business with men who are above knowing or caring what they have to do.
Fiandeira, fiai manso, que me estorvais, que estou rezando
Fiar de Dios sobre buena prenda
Fiat experimentum in corpore vili
Fiat justitiam, pereat mundus
Fiat justitia, ruat cœlum
Fiat lux
Fickleness has its rise in the experience of the
deceptiveness of present pleasures, and in ignorance of the vanity of absent ones.
Ficta voluptatis causa sit proxima veris
Fiction is a potent agent for good in the hands of the good.
Fiction lags after truth, invention is unfruitful, and imagination cold and barren.
Fiction, while the feigner of it knows that he is feigning, partakes, more than we suspect, of the nature of lying; and has ever an, in some degree, unsatisfactory character.
Fictis meminerit nos jocari fabulis
Fidarsi è bene, ma non fidarsi è meglio
Fidati era un buon uomo, Nontifidare era meglio
Fide abrogata, omnis humana societas tollitur
Fide et amore
Fide et fiducia
Fide et fortitudine
Fide et literis
Fide, non armis
Fidei coticula crux
Fidei defensor
Fideli certa merces
Fidelis ad urnam
Fidelis et audax
Fidélité est de Dieu
Fideliter et constanter
Fidelity, diligence, decency, are good and indispensable; yet, without faculty, without light, they will not do the work.
Fidelity is the sister of justice.
Fidelity purchased with money, money can destroy.
Fidelius rident tiguria
Fidem qui perdit perdere ultra nil potest
Fidem qui perdit, quo se servet relicuo?
Fides facit fidem
Fides probata coronat
Fides Punica
Fides servanda est
Fides sit penes auctorem
Fides ut anima, unde abiit, eo nunquam redit
Fidus Achates
Fidus et audax
Fie! fie! how wayward is this foolish love, / That like a testy babe will scratch the nurse, / And presently, all humbled, kiss the rod.
Fiel pero desdichado
Fierce fiery warriors fought upon the clouds, / In ranks and squadrons, and right form of war, / Which drizzled blood upon the Capitol.
Fieri facias
Fight on, thou brave true heart, and falter not, through dark fortune and through bright, the cause thou fightest for, so far as it is true, is very sure of victory.
Fight the good fight.
Filii non plus possessionum quam morborum
hæredes sumus
Filius nullius
Filius terræ
Fille de chambre
Fille de joie
Fin contre fin
Fin de siècle
Find earth where grows no weed, and you may find a heart where no error grows.
Find employment for the body, and the mind will find enjoyment for itself.
Find fault, when you must find fault, in private, if possible, and some time after the offence, rather than at the time.
Find mankind where thou wilt, thou findest it
in living movement, in progress faster or slower; the phœnix soars aloft, hovers with outstretched wings, filling earth with her music; or, as now, she sinks, and with spheral swan-song immolates herself in flame, that she may soar the higher and sing the clearer.
Find out men's wants and will, / And meet them there. All worldly joys go less / To the one joy of doing kindnesses.
Finding your able man, and getting him invested with the symbols of ability, is the business, well or ill accomplished, of all social procedure whatsoever in this world.
Fine art is that in which the hand, the head, and the heart of man go together; the head inferior to the heart, and the hand inferior to both heart and head.
Fine by defect and delicately weak.
Fine by degrees and beautifully less.
Fine feathers make fine birds.
Fine feelings, without vigour of reason, are in the situation of the extreme feathers of a peacock's tail--dragging in the mud.
Fine manners are the mantle of fair minds. None are truly great without this ornament.
Fine manners need the support of fine manners in others.
Fine sense and exalted sense are not half so
useful as common sense.
Fine speeches are the instruments of knaves / Or fools, that use them when they want good sense; / Honesty needs no disguise or ornament.
Fine words without deeds go not far.
Finem respice
Finge datos currus, quid agas?
Fingers were made before forks, and hands
before knives.
Fingunt se medicos quivis idiota, sacerdos, Judæus, monachus, histrio, rasor, anus
Finis coronat opus
Fire and sword are but slow engines of destruction in comparison with the tongue of the babbler.
Fire and water are good servants but bad masters.
Fire in the heart sends smoke into the head.
Fire is the best of servants; but what a master!
Fire maks an auld wife nimble.
Fire that's closest kept burns most of all.
Fire trieth iron, and temptation a just man.
Firmior quo paratior
Firmness, both in sufferance and exertion, is a character I would wish to possess. I have always despised the whining yelp of complaint and the cowardly feeble resolve.
First assay / To stuff thy mind with solid bravery; / Then march on gallant: get substantial worth: / Boldness gilds finely, and will set it forth.
First cast the beam out of thine own eye, and then thou shalt see clearly to cast out the mote out of thy brother's eye.
First catch your hare.
First come, first served.
First deserve and then desire.
First flower of the earth and first gem of the sea.
First keep thyself in peace, and then thou shalt be able to keep peace among others.
First must the dead letter of religion own itself dead, and drop piecemeal into dust, if the living spirit of religion, freed from its charnel-house, is to arise in us, new-born of heaven, and with new healing under its wings.
First resolutions are not always the wisest, but they are usually the most honest.
First worship God; he that forgets to pray / Bids not himself good-morrow nor good day.
Fishes live in the sea, ... as men do on land--the great ones eat up the little ones.
Fit cito per multas præda petita manus
Fit erranti medicina confessio
Fit fabricando faber
Fit in dominatu servitus, in servitute dominatus
Fit scelus indulgens per nubila sæcula virtus
Fit the foot to the shoe, not the shoe to the foot.
Fit words are fine, but often fine words are
not fit.
Five great intellectual professions have hitherto existed in every civilised nation: the soldier's, to defend it; the pastor's, to teach it; the physician's, to keep it in health; the lawyer's, to enforce justice in it; and the merchant's, to provide for it; and the duty of all these men is, on due occasion, to die for it.
Five minutes of to-day are worth as much to me as five minutes in the next millennium.
Fix'd to no spot is happiness sincere; / 'Tis nowhere to be found, or everywhere.
Fixed like a plant on his peculiar spot, / To draw nutrition, propagate, and rot.
Flagrante bello
Flagrante delicto
Flames rise and sink by fits; at last they soar / In one bright flame, and then return no more.
Flamma fumo est proxima
Flatter not the rich; neither do thou appear willingly before the great.
Flatterers are cats that lick before, and scratch
behind.
Flatterers are the bosom enemies of princes.
Flatterers are the worst kind of traitors.
Flattery brings friends, but the truth begets enmity.
Flattery corrupts both the receiver and the giver, and adulation is not of more service to the people than to kings.
Flattery is a base coin, to which only our
vanity gives currency.
Flattery is the bellows blows up sin; / The thing the which is flattered, but a spark, / To which that blast gives heat and stronger glowing; / Whereas reproof, obedient and in order, / Fits kings, as they are men, for they may err.
Flattery is the destruction of all good fellowship.
Flattery is the food of pride, and may be well assimilated to those cordials which hurt the constitution while they exhilarate the spirits.
Flattery labours under the odious charge of servility.
Flattery sits in the parlour when plain dealing
is kicked out of doors.
Flattery's the turnpike road to Fortune's door.
Flebile ludibrium
Flebit, et insignis tota cantabitur urbe
Flectere si nequeo superos, Acheronta movebo
Flecti, non frangi
Flee sloth, for the indolence of the soul is the decay of the body.
Flee you ne'er so fast, your fortune will be at your tail.
Flesh will warm in a man to his kin against his will.
Flet victus, victor interiit
Fleur d'eau
Fleur de terre
Fleurs-de-lis
Fleying
Flies are easier caught with honey than vinegar.
Fling away ambition; / By that sin fell the
angels; how can man, then, / The image of his Maker, hope to win by it?
Flints may be melted, but an ungrateful heart cannot; no, not by the strongest and noblest flame.
Floriferis ut apes in saltibus omnia libant
Flour cannot be sown and seed-corn ought not to be ground.
Flowers and fruits are always fit presents--flowers, because they are a proud assertion that a ray of beauty outvalues all the utilities of man.
Flowers are the beautiful hieroglyphics of
Nature, by which she indicates how much she loves us.
Flowers are the pledges of fruit.
Flowers are the sweetest things God ever made and forgot to put a soul into.
Flowers never emit so sweet and strong a fragrance as before a storm.
Flowers of rhetoric in sermons and serious discourses are like the blue and red flowers in corn, pleasing to those who come only for amusement, but prejudicial to him who would reap profit from it.
Fluctus in simpulo exitare
Fluvius cum mari certas
Fly idleness, which yet thou canst not fly / By dressing, mistressing, and compliment. / If these take up thy day, the sun will cry / Against thee; for his light was only lent.
Fœdum inceptu, fœdum exitu
Fœnum habet in cornu, longe fuge, dummodo risum / Excutiat sibi, non hic cuiquam parcit amico
Foliis tantum ne carmina manda; / Ne turbata volent rapidis ludibria ventis
Folk canna help a' their kin
Folk wi' lang noses aye tak' till themsels.
Folks as have no mind to be o' use have always the luck to be out o' the road when there's anything to be done.
Folks must put up with their own kin as they put up with their own noses.
Folle est la brébis qui au loup se confesse
Follow love and it will flee, flee love and it
will follow thee.
Follow the copy though it fly out of the window.
Follow the customs or fly the country.
Follow the devil faithfully, you are sure to go to the devil.
Follow the river, and you will get to the sea.
Follow the road, and you will come to an inn.
Follow the wise few rather than the vulgar many.
Folly, as it grows in years, / The more extravagant appears.
Folly ends where genuine hope begins.
Folly is its own burden.
Folly is the most incurable of maladies.
Folly, letting down buckets into empty wells, and growing old with drawing nothing up.
Folly loves the martyrdom of fame.
Fond fools / Promise themselves a name from building churches.
Fond gaillard
Fons et origo mali
Fons malorum
Fons omnium viventium
Fontes ipsi sitiunt
Food can only be got out of the ground, or the air, or the sea.
Food fills the wame and keeps us livin'; /
Though life's a gift no worth receivin', / When heavy dragg'd wi' pine and grievin'; / But oil'd by thee, the wheels o' life gae doonhill scrievin' / Wi' rattlin' glee.
Food for powder.
Fool before all is he who does not instantly seize the right moment; who has what he loves before his eyes, and yet swerves

Fool not; for all may have, / If they dare try, a glorious life or grave.
Fool, not to know that love endures no tie, / And Jove but laughs at lovers' perjury.
Fool of fortune.
Fooled thou must be, though wisest of the wise; / Then be the fool of virtue, not of vice.
Foolish legislation is a rope of sand, which perishes in the twisting.
Foolish people are a hundred times more averse to meet with wise people than wise people are to meet with foolish.
Fools and bairns shouldna see things half done.
Fools and obstinate men make lawyers rich.
Fools are apt to imitate only the defects of their betters.
Fools are aye fond o' flittin', and wise men o' sittin'.
Fools are aye seeing ferlies
Fools are known by looking wise.
Fools are my theme; let satire be my song.
Fools ask what's o'clock, but wise men know their time.
Fools build houses, and wise men buy them.
Fools can indeed find fault, but cannot act more wisely.
Fools for arguments use wagers.
Fools grant whate'er ambition craves, / And
men, once ignorant, are slaves.
Fools grow of themselves without sowing or planting.
Fools grow without watering.
Fools invent fashions and wise men follow them.
Fools learn nothing from wise men, but wise men much from fools.
Fools make a mock at sin.
Fools mak' feasts, and wise men eat them. / Wise men mak' jests, and fools repeat them.
Fools may our scorn, not envy raise, / For envy is a kind of praise.
Fools measure actions after they are done by the event; wise men beforehand, by the rules of reason and right.
Fools need no passport.
Fools ravel and wise men redd
Fools, to talking ever prone, / Are sure to make their follies known.
Fools with bookish knowledge are children with edged weapons; they hurt themselves and put others in pain.
Footpaths give a private, human touch to the landscape that roads do not. They are sacred to the human foot. They have the sentiment of domesticity, and suggest the way to cottage doors and to simple, primitive times.
Foppery is never cured; once a coxcomb, always a coxcomb.
For age, long age! / Nought else divides us from the fresh young days / Which men call ancient.
For a genuine man it is no evil to be poor.
For a just man falleth seven times, and riseth up again.
For a large conscience is all one, / And signifies
the same with none.
For all a rhetorician's rules / Teach nothing but to name his tools.
For all he did he had a reason, / For all he said, a word in season; / And ready ever was to quote / Authorities for what he wrote.
For all men live and judge amiss / Whose talents do not jump with his.
For all right judgment of any man or thing it is useful, nay, essential, to see his good qualities before pronouncing on his bad.
For all their luxury was doing good.
For an honest man half his wits are enough; for a knave, the whole are too little.
For an orator delivery is everything.
For a republic you must have men.
For as a fly that goes to bed / Rests with his tail above his head, / So, in this mongrel state of ours, / The rabble are the supreme powers.
For as a ship without a helm is tossed to and
fro by the waves, so the man who is careless and forsaketh his purpose is many ways tempted.
For a' that, and a' that, / Our toils obscure, and a' that; / The rank is but the guinea's stamp, / The man's the gowd for a' that.
For a tint
For aught I see, they are as sick that surfeit with too much as they that starve with nothing.
For aught that ever I could read, / Could ever hear by tale or history, / The course of true love never did run smooth.
For a web begun God sends thread.
For behaviour, men learn it, as they take diseases, one of another.
For blessings ever wait on virtuous deeds, / And though a late, a sure reward succeeds.
For Brutus is an honourable man, / So are they all, all honourable men.
For captivity, perhaps your poor watchdog is as sorrowful a type as you will easily find.
For contemplation he and valour form'd, / For
softness she and sweet attractive grace; / He for God only, she for God in him, / His fair large front and eye sublime declared.
For cowards the road of desertion should be left open; they will carry over to the enemy nothing but their fears.
For dear to gods and men is sacred song.
For ebbing resolution ne'er returns, / But falls still further from its former shore.
For emulation hath a thousand sons, / That one by one pursue; if you give way, / Or hedge aside from the direct forthright, / Like to an enter'd tide, they all rush by, And leave you hindmost.
For ever and a day.
For ever is not a category that can establish itself in this world of time.
For every dawn that breaks brings a new world, / And every budding bosom a new life.
For every grain of wit there is a grain of folly.
For every ten jokes thou hast got an hundred enemies.
For everything you have missed, you have
gained something else; and for everything you gain, you lose something.
For fate has wove the thread of life with pain, / And twins e'en from the birth are misery and man.
For faith, and peace, and mighty love / That from the Godhead flow, / Show'd them the life of heaven above / Springs from the earth below.
For fault o' wise men fools sit on binks
For fools rush in where angels fear to tread.
For forms of government let fools contest; /
Whate'er is best administered is best.
For Freedom's battle, once begun, / Bequeath'd by bleeding sire to son, / Though baffled oft, is ever won.
For glances beget ogles, ogles sighs, / Sighs wishes, wishes words, and words a letter; / And then God knows what mischief may arise / When love links two young people in one fetter.
For gold the merchant ploughs the main, / The farmer ploughs the manor; / But glory is the soldier's prize, / The soldier's wealth is honour.
For good and evil must in our actions meet; / Wicked is not much worse than indiscreet.
For greatest scandal waits on greatest state.
For grief indeed is love, and grief beside.
For he being dead, with him is beauty slain, / And, beauty dead, black chaos comes again.
For he, by geometric scale, / Could take the size of pots of ale.
For he is but a bastard to the time / That doth not smack of observation.
For he lives twice who can at once employ /
The present well and e'en the past enjoy.
For he that fights and runs away / May live to fight another day; / But he who is in battle slain, / Can never rise and fight again.
For he that worketh high and wise, / Nor pauses in his plan, / Will take the sun out of the skies / Ere freedom out of man.
For his bounty, / There was no winter in't; an autumn 'twas, / That grew the more by reaping.
For his chaste Muse employed her heaven-taught lyre / None but the noblest passions to inspire, / Not one immoral, one corrupted thought, / One line which, dying, he could wish to blot.
For hope is but the dream of those that wake.
For I am nothing if not critical.
For I am full of spirit, and resolved / To meet all perils very constantly.
For I say this is death, and the sole death, / When a man's loss comes to him from his gain, / Darkness from light, from knowledge ignorance, / And lack of love from love made manifest.
For it so falls out, / That what we have we prize not to the worth / While we enjoy it, but being lack'd and lost, / Why, then we rack the value.
For it stirs the blood in an old man's heart, / And makes his pulses fly, / To catch the thrill of a happy voice / And the light of a pleasant eye.
For just experience tells, in every soil, / That
those that think must govern those that toil.
For knowledge is a barren tree and bare, / Bereft of God, and duty but a word, / And strength but tyranny, and love, desire, / And purity a folly.
For knowledge is a steep which few may climb, / While duty is a path which all may tread.
For let our finger ache, and it endues / Our other healthful members ev'n to that sense / Of pain.
For loan oft loses both itself and friend.
For love of grace, / Lay not the flattering
unction to your soul / That not your trespass but my madness speaks.
For lovers' eyes more sharply sighted be / Than other men's, and in dear love's delight / See more than any other eyes can see.
For man's well-being faith is properly the one thing needful; with it, martyrs, otherwise weak, can cheerfully endure the shame and the cross; and without it, worldlings puke up their sick existence by suicide in the midst of luxury.
For man there is but one misfortune, when some idea lays hold of him which exerts no influence upon his active life, or still more, which withdraws him from it.
For men are brought to worse diseases / By taking physic than diseases, / And therefore commonly recover / As soon as doctors give them over.
For men at most differ as heaven and earth, /
But women, worst and best, as heaven and hell.
For men cherish love, for gods reverence.
For men may come and men may go, / But I go on for ever.
For modes of faith let graceless zealots fight; / His can't be wrong whose life is in the right.
For murder, though it hath no tongue, will speak / With most miraculous organ.
For my means, I'll husband them so well, /
They shall go far with little.
For my name and memory I leave to men's charitable speeches, to foreign nations, and to the next ages.
For nought so vile that on the earth doth live, / But to the earth some special good doth give; / Nor aught so good, but strain'd from that fair use, / Revolts from true birth, stumbling on abuse.
For now we see through a glass darkly, but then face to face.
For oaths are straws, men's faith are wafer cakes, / And holdfast is the only dog, my duck.
For of all sad words of tongue or pen, / The
saddest were these: "It might have been."
For of fortunes sharpe adversite, / The worst kind of infortune is this, / A man that hath been in prosperite, / And it remember when it passéd is.
For of the soul the body form doth take, / For soul is form, and doth the body make.
For one man who can stand prosperity, there are a hundred that will stand adversity.
For one person who can think, there are at least a hundred who can observe. An accurate observer is, no doubt, rare; but an accurate thinker is far rarer.
For one rich man that is content there are a
hundred who are not.
For one word a man is often deemed wise, and for one word he is often deemed foolish.
For our pleasure, the lackeyed train, the slow parading pageant, with all the gravity of grandeur, moves in review; a single coat, or a single footman, answers all the purposes of the most indolent refinement as well; and those who have twenty, may be said to keep one for their own pleasure, and the other nineteen merely for ours.
For pity is the virtue of the law, / And none but tyrants use it cruelly.
For pleasures past I do not grieve, / Nor perils gathering near; / My greatest grief is that I leave / Nothing that claims a tear.
For poems to have beauty of style is not
enough; they must have pathos also, and lead at will the hearer's soul.
For present grief there is always a remedy. However much thou sufferest, hope. The greatest happiness of man is hope.
For rarely do we meet in one combined / A beauteous body and a virtuous mind.
For rhetoric, he could not ope / His mouth, but out there flew a trope.
For rhyme the rudder is of verses, / With which, like ships, they steer their courses.
For right is right, since God is God, / And right the day must win; / To doubt would be disloyalty, / To falter would be sin.
For sacred even to gods is misery.
For Satan finds some mischief still / For idle
hands to do.
For slander lives upon successión, / For ever housed where it gets possessión.
For solitude sometimes is best society, / And short retirement urges sweet return.
For sufferance is the badge of all our tribe.
For suffering and enduring there is no remedy but striving and doing.
For that fine madness still he did retain /
Which rightly should possess a poet's brain.
For the apotheosis of Reason we have substituted that of Instinct; and we call everything instinct which we find in ourselves, and for which we cannot trace any rational foundation.
For the bow cannot possibly stand always bent, nor can human nature or human frailty subsist without some lawful recreation.
For the buyer a hundred eyes are too few, for the seller one is enough.
For thee the family of man has no use; it rejects thee; thou art wholly as a dissevered limb: so be it; perhaps it is better so.
For the fashion of this world passeth away.
For the gay beams of lightsome day / Gild but to flout the ruins grey.
For the greatest crime of man is that he was born.
For the narrow mind, whatever he attempts, is still a trade; for the higher, an art; and the highest, in doing one thing does all; or, to speak less paradoxically, in the one thing which he does rightly, he sees the likeness of all that is done rightly.
For the rain it raineth every day.
For there's nae luck aboot the hoose, / There's
nae luck ava', / There's little pleesure in the hoose / When oor guidman's awa'.
For there was never yet philosopher / That could endure the toothache patiently.
For the sake of one good action a hundred evil actions should be condoned.
For the son of man there is no noble crown, well-worn or even ill-worn, but is a crown of thorns.
For the true the price is paid before you enjoy it; for the false, after you enjoy it.
For the world was built in order, / And the
atoms march in tune; / Rhyme the pipe, and the Time the warder, / The sun obeys them and the moon.
For they can conquer who believe they can.
For 'tis a truth well known to most, / That whatsoever thing is lost, / We seek it, ere it comes to light, / In every cranny but the right.
For 'tis the mind that makes the body rich: / And as the sun breaks through the darkest clouds, / So honour peereth in the meanest habit.
For to him that is joined to all the living there is hope: for a living dog is better than a dead lion.
For to see and eek for to be seye.
For truth has such a face and such a mien, / As to be loved needs only to be seen.
For truth is precious and divine, / Too rich a pearl for carnal swine.
For use almost can change the stamp of Nature, / And either curb the devil or throw him out / With wondrous potency.
For us, the winds do blow, / The earth doth rest, heaven move, and fountains flow; / Nothing we see but means our good, / As our delight, or as our treasure; / The whole is either our cupboard of food, / Or cabinet of pleasure.
For virtue's sake I am here; but if a man,
for his task, forgets and sacrifices all, why shouldst not thou?
For virtue's self may too much zeal be had; / The worst of madmen is a saint run mad.
For want of a block a man will stumble at a straw.
For want of a nail the shoe was lost, for want of a shoe the horse was lost, and for want of a horse the rider was lost.
For wealth is all things that conduce / To man's destruction or his use; / A standard both to buy and sell / All things from heaven down to hell.
For what are men who grasp at praise sublime, /
But bubbles on the rapid stream of time, / That rise and fall, that swell and are no more, / Born and forgot, ten thousand in an hour.
For what are they all in their high conceit, / When man in the bush with God may meet?
For what thou hast not, still thou striv'st to get, / And what thou hast, forgetst.
For when disputes are wearied out, / 'Tis interest still resolves the doubt.
For where is any author in the world / Teaches such beauty as a woman's eye?
For while a youth is lost in soaring thought, /
And while a mind grows sweet and beautiful, / And while a spring-tide coming lights the earth, / And while a child, and while a flower is born, / And while one wrong cries for redress and finds / A soul to answer, still the world is young.
For whom ill is fated, him it will strike.
For whom the heart of man shuts out, / Straightway the heart of God takes in, / And fences them all round about / With silence 'mid the world's loud din.
For who to dumb forgetfulness a prey, / This pleasing anxious being e'er resigned, / Left the warm precincts of the cheerful day, / Nor cast one longing lingering look behind?
For who would lose, / Though full of pain, this intellectual being, / Those thoughts that wander through eternity; / To perish rather, swallowed up and lost, / In the wide womb of uncreated night?
For wisdom cries out in the streets, and no man regards it.
For youth no less becomes / The light and
careless livery that it wears, / Than settled age his sables and his weeds, / Importing health and graveness.
Forbear to judge, for we are sinners all.
Forbearance is not acquittance.
Forbid a fool do a thing, and that he will do.
Forbidden fruit is sweetest.
Force and right rule everything in this world;
force till right is ready.
Force can never annul right.
Force is no argument.
Forced love does not last.
Forced prayers are no gude for the soul.
Force n'a pas droit
Force rules the world, and not opinion, but opinion is that which makes use of force.
Force without forecast is of little avail.
Foresight is indeed necessary in trusting, but still more necessary in distrusting.
Forewarned, forearmed.
Forget the hours of thy distress, but never
forget what they taught thee.
Forget thyself to marble.
Forgetting of a wrong is a mild revenge.
Forgetting one's self, or knowing one's self, around these everything turns.
Forgiveness is better than revenge; for forgiveness is the sign of a gentle nature, but revenge the sign of a savage nature.
Forgiveness is commendable, but apply not
ointment to the wound of an oppressor.
Forgiveness is the divinest of victories.
Forgiveness to the injured does belong, / But they ne'er pardon who have done the wrong.
Forgiveness is not forgotten.
Forgotten pains, when follow gains.
Forma bonum fragile est
Forma viros neglecta decet
Formerly it was the fashion to preach the natural; now it is the ideal.
Formerly the richest countries were those in which Nature was most bountiful; now the richest countries are those in which man is most active.
Formerly when great fortunes were only made in war, war was business; but now when great fortunes are only made by business, business is war.
Formidabilior cervorum exercitus, duce leone,
quam leonum cervo
Formosa facies muta commendatio est
Formosos sæpe inveni pessimos, / Et turpi facie multos cognovi optimos
Forms which grow round a substance will be true, good; forms which are consciously put round a substance, bad.
Formulas are the very skin and muscular tissue of a man's life; and a most blessed indispensable thing, so long as they have vitality withal, and are a living skin and tissue to him.
Forsake not God till you find a better maister.
Forsan et hæc olim meminisse juvabit; Durate, et vosmet rebus servate secundis
Forsan miseros meliora sequentur
Fors et virtus miscentur in unum
Forte è l'aceto di vin dolce
Forte et fidele
Fortem facit vicina libertas senem
Fortem posce animum mortis terrore carentem, / Qui spatium vitæ extremum inter munera ponat / Naturæ
Fortes creantur fortibus et bonis: / Est in juvencis, est in equis patrum / Virtus, nec imbellem feroces / Progenerant aquilæ columbam
Forte scutum salus ducum
Fortes fortuna adjuvat
Fortes in fine assequendo et suaves in modo assequendi simus
Forti et fideli nihil difficile
Fortify courage with the true rampart of patience.
Fortify yourself with moderation; for this is an impregnable fortress.
Fortior et potentior est dispositio legis quam hominis
Fortis cadere, cedere non potest
Fortis et constantis animi est, non perturbari in rebus asperis
Fortis sub forte fatiscet
Fortiter et recte
Fortiter ferendo vincitur malum quod evitari non potest
Fortiter, fideliter, feliciter
Fortiter geret crucem
Fortiter in re, suaviter in modo
Fortitude is the guard and support of the
other virtues.
Fortitude is the marshal of thought, the armour of the will, and the fort of reason.
Fortitude is to be seen in toils and dangers; temperance in the denial of sensual pleasures; prudence in the choice between good and evil; justice in awarding to every one his due.
Fortitude rises upon an opposition; and, like a river, swells the higher for having its course stopped.
Fortitudini
Fortuito quodam concursu atomorum
Fortunæ cætera mando
Fortunæ filius
Fortunæ majoris honos, erectus et acer
Fortuna favet fatuis
Fortuna favet fortibus
Fortuna magna magna domino est servitus
Fortunam debet quisque manere suam
Fortuna meliores sequitur
Fortuna miserrima tuta est
Fortuna multis dat nimium, nulli satis
Fortuna nimium quem fovet, stultum facit
Fortuna non mutat genus
Fortuna obesse nulli contenta est semel
Fortuna opes auferre, non animum potest
Fortuna parvis momentis magnas rerum commutationes
efficit
Fortuna sequatur
Fortunato omne solum patria est
Fortunatas et ille deos qui novit agrestes
Fortunatus' purse
Fortuna vitrea est, tum cum splendet frangitur
Fortune brings in some boats that are ill-steered.
Fortune can take from us nothing but what she gave.
Fortune does not change men; it only unmasks them.
Fortune favours the brave, as the old proverb says, but forethought much more.
Fortune has rarely condescended to be the
companion of genius.
Fortune hath something of the nature of a woman, who, if she be too closely wooed, goes commonly the farther off.
Fortune is like a mirror--it does not alter men; it only shows men just as they are.
Fortune is like the market, where many times, if you can stay a little, the price will fall.
Fortune is merry, and in this mood will give us anything.
Fortune is not content to do a man one ill
turn.
Fortune is the rod of the weak, and the staff of the brave.
Fortune makes folly her peculiar care.
Fortune makes him a fool whom she makes her darling.
Fortune often knocks at the door, but the fool does not invite her in.
Fortune reigns in the gifts of the world, not in
the lineaments of nature.
Fortune! There is no fortune; all is trial, or punishment, or recompense, or foresight.
Fortune turns round like a mill-wheel, and he that was yesterday at the top lies to-day at the bottom.
Forward, forward let us range, / Let the great world spin for ever down the ringing grooves of change.
Forwardness spoils manners.
Foster the beautiful, and every hour thou
callest new flowers to birth.
Foul cankering rust the hidden treasure frets; / But gold that's put to use, more gold begets.
Foul deeds will rise, / Though all the earth o'erwhelm them, to men's eyes.
Fou (full) o' courtesy, fou o' craft.
Four eyes see more than two.
Four hostile newspapers are more to be feared than a thousand bayonets.
Foxes have holes, and the birds of the air have nests; but the Son of Man hath not where to lay his head.
Foy est tout
Foy pour devoir
Frae saving comes having.
Fragili quærens illidere dentem / Offendet solido
Fraile que pide por Dios pide por dos
Frailty, thy name is woman.
Frame your mind to mirth and merriment, / Which bars a thousand harms and lengthens life.
Frangas, non flectes
Frappe fort
Fraternité ou la Mort
Frauen, richtet nur nie des Mannes einzelne Thaten; / Aber über den Mann sprechet das richtende Wort
Frauen und Jungfrauen soll man loben, es sei wahr oder erlogen
Fraus est celare fraudem
Frau und Mond leuchten mit fremden Licht
Freedom and slavery, the one is the name of virtue, the other of vice, and both are acts of the will.
Freedom and whisky gang thegither! / Tak' aff your dram.
Freedom consists not in refusing to recognise anything above us, but in respecting something which is above us.
Freedom exists only with power.
Freedom has a thousand charms to show, / That slaves, howe'er contented, never know.
Freedom is a new religion--the religion of our time.
Freedom is not caprice, but room to enlarge.
Freedom is only granted us that obedience may be more perfect.
Freedom is only in the land of dreams, and the
beautiful only blooms in song.
Freedom is the eternal youth of nations.
Freedom's sun cannot set so long as smiths hammer iron.
Free governments have committed more flagrant acts of tyranny than the most perfect despotic governments which we have ever known.
Free-livers on a small scale, who are prodigal within the compass of a guinea.
Freends are like fiddle-strings; they maunna
be screwed ower tight.
Freethinkers are generally those who never think at all.
Free will I be in thought and in poetry; in action the world hampers us enough.
Freie Kirche im freien Staat
Freilich erfahren wir erst im Alter, was uns in der Tugend begegnete
Frei muss ich denken, sprechen und atmen
Gottes Luft, / Und wer die drei mir raubet, der legt mich in die Gruft
Freits
Frei von Tadel zu sein ist der niedrigste Grad und der höchste, / Denn nur die Ohnmacht führt oder die Grösse dazu
Freiwillige Abhängigkeit ist der schönste Zustand, und wie wäre der möglich ohne Liebe?
Fremde Kinder, wir lieben sie nie so sehr als die eignen; / Irrtum das eigne Kind, ist uns dem Herzen so nah
Fremdes Pferd und eigene Sporen haben bald
den Wind verloren
Freno indorato non megliora il cavallo
Frequent and loud laughter is the characteristic of folly and ill-manners.
Fresh as a bridegroom, and his chin, new reap'd, / Show'd like a stubble-field at harvest-home; / He was perfuméd like a milliner, / And 'twixt his finger and his thumb he held / A pouncet-box, which ever and anon / He gave his nose, and took 't away again.
Fret not over the irretrievable, but ever act as if thy life were just begun.
Fret not thyself because of evil men, neither
be thou envious at the wicked; for there shall be no reward to the evil man; the candle of the wicked shall be put out.
Fretting cares make grey hairs.
Freude hat mir Gott gegeben
Freud' muss Leid, Leid muss Freude haben
Freundschaft ist ein Knotenstock auf Reisen, / Lieb' ein Stäbchen zum Spazierengehn
Friar Modest never was prior.
Friend after friend departs; / Who hath not lost a friend? / There is no union here of hearts / That finds not here an end.
Friend, hast thou considered the "rugged, all-nourishing earth," as Sophocles well names her; how she feeds the sparrow on the housetop, much more her darling, man?
Friend, however thou camest by this book, I will assure thee thou wert least in my thoughts when I writ it.
"Friend, I never gave thee any of my jewels!" "No, but you have let me look at them, and that is all the use you can make of them yourself; moreover, you have the trouble of watching them, and that is an employment I do not much desire."
Friends and acquaintances are the surest passports to fortune.
Friends are lost by calling often and calling seldom.
Friends are ourselves.
Friends are rare, for the good reason that men are not common.
Friends are the leaders of the bosom, being more ourselves than we are, and we complement our affections in theirs.
Friends, like mushrooms, spring up in out-of-the-way places.
Friends may meet, / But mountains never greet.
Friends reveal to each other most clearly
exactly that upon which they are silent.
Friends should associate friends in grief and woe.
Friends should be weighed, not told.
Friends show me what I can do; foes teach me what I should do.
Friends, such as we desire, are dreams and fables.
Friends will be much apart. They will respect
more each other's privacy than their communion, for therein is the fulfilment of our high aims and the conclusion of our arguments.... The hours my friend devotes to me were snatched from a higher society.

Friendship can originate and acquire permanence (Neigung), 
 (gleichen Schri

Friendship can originate and acquire permanence (Neigung),  to friendship. True, active, productive friendship consists in this, that we keep the same approves of my aims, as I of his, and that whatever may be the difference otherwise between our ways of thinking and living.
Friendship canna stand a' on ae side.
Friendship, in the old heroic sense of that term, no longer exists; except in the cases of kindred or other legal affinity, it is in reality no longer expected or recognised as a virtue among men.
Friendship is a plant which one must water often.
Friendship is a vase, which, when it is flawed
by heat, or violence, or accident, may as well be broken at once; it never can be trusted after.
Friendship is but a name.
Friendship is communion.
Friendship is constant in all other things, / Save in the office and affairs of love; / Therefore, all hearts in love use their own tongues; / Let every eye negotiate for itself, / And trust no agent.
Friendship is infinitely better than kindness.
Friendship is like a debt of honour; the
moment it is talked of, it loses its real name, and assumes the more ungrateful form of obligation.
Friendship is love with understanding.
Friendship is love without its flowers or veil.
Friendship is love without its wings.
Friendship is no plant of hasty growth.
Friendship is one soul in two bodies.
Friendship is stronger than kindred.
Friendship is the greatest bond in the world.
Friendship is the ideal; friends are the reality; the reality always remains far apart from the ideal.
Friendship is the marriage of the soul.
Friendship is the shadow of the evening,
which strengthens with the setting sun of life.
Friendship is too pure a pleasure for a mind cankered with ambition or the lust of power and grandeur.
Friendship, like love, is but a name, / Unless to one you stint the flame.
Friendship, like love, is self-forgetful.
Friendship, like the immortality of the soul, is too good to be believed.
Friendship made in a moment is of no moment.
Friendship often ends in love; but love in friendship--never.
Friendship should be surrounded with ceremonies and respects, and not crushed into corners.
Friendship, unlike love, which is weakened by fruition, grows up, thrives, and increases by enjoyment; and being of itself spiritual, the soul is reformed by the habit of it.
Friendships are discovered rather than made.
Friendship's as it's kept.
Friendship's full of dregs.
Friendships that are disproportioned ever terminate in disgust.
Friendship's the privilege / Of private men.
Friendship's the wine of life; but friendship new is neither strong nor pure.
Friendships which are born in misfortune are
more firm and lasting than those which are formed in happiness.
Frigidam aquam effundere
Frisch gewagt ist halb gewonnen
From a bad paymaster get what you can.
From a closed door the devil turns away.
From camp to camp, through the foul womb of night, / The hum of either army stilly sounds, / That the fix'd sentinels almost receive / The secret whispers of each other's watch; / Fire answers fire, and through their paly flames / Each battle sees the other's umber'd face; / Steed threatens steed in high and boastful neighs, / Piercing the night's dull ear, and from the tents / The armourers, accomplishing the knights, / With busy hammers closing rivets up, / Give dreadful note of preparation.
From every moral death there is a new birth; / in this wondrous course of his, man may indeed linger, but cannot retrograde or stand still.
From every spot on earth we are equally near heaven and the infinite.
From grave to gay, from lively to severe.
From great folks great favours are to be
expected.
From hand to mouth will never make a worthy man.
From hearing comes wisdom, from speaking repentance.
From Helicon's harmonious springs / A thousand rills their mazy progress take.
From his cradle / He was a scholar, and a ripe and good one; / Exceeding wise, fair-spoken, and persuading; / Lofty and sour to them that loved him not, / But to those men who sought him, sweet as summer; / And to add greater honours to his age / Than man could give; he died fearing God.
From ignorance our comfort flows; / The only
wretched are the wise.
From kings and priests and statesmen war arose, / Whose safety is man's deep embittered woe, / Whose grandeur his debasement.
From labour health, from health contentment springs.
From lowest place where virtuous things proceed, / The place is dignified by the doer's deed.
From obedience and submission spring all other virtues, as all sin does from self-opinion.
From our ancestors come our names, from our
virtues our honours.
From out the throng and stress of lies, / From out the painful noise of sighs, / One voice of comfort seems to rise, / It is the meaner part that dies.
From pillar to post
From saying "No," however cleverly, no good can come.
From seeming evil still educing good.
From servants hasting to be gods.
From small beginnings come great things.
From stratagem to stratagem we run, / And he knows most who latest is undone; / An honest man will take a knave's advice, / But idiots only will be cozened twice.
From the beginning and to the end of time, Love reads without letters and counts without arithmetic.
From the deepest desire oftentimes ensues the deadliest hate.
From thee, great God, we spring, to thee we
tend, / Path, motive, guide, original and end.
"From the height of these pyramids forty centuries look down on you."
From the lowest depth there is a path to the loftiest height.
From the low prayer of want and plaint of woe / O never, never turn away thine ear! / Forlorn is this bleak wilderness below, / Ah! what were man should heaven refuse to hear!
From the same flower the bee extracts honey and the wasp gall.
From the summit of power men no longer turn
their eyes upward, but begin to look about them.
From the sum / Of duty, blooms sweeter and more divine / The fair ideal of the race, than comes / From glittering gains of learning.
From time to time in history men are born a whole age too soon.
From within or from behind, a light shines through us upon things, and makes us aware that we are nothing, but the light is all.
From women's eyes this doctrine I derive: / They sparkle still the right Promethean fire; / They are the books, the arts, the academes, / That show, contain, and nourish all the world; / Else none at all in aught proves excellent.
From yon blue heaven above us bent, / The
grand old gardener and his wife / Smile at the claims of long descent.
Fromm, Klug, Weis, und Mild, gehört in des Adels Schild
Fromme Leute wohnen weit auseinander
Frömmigkeit ist kein Zweck, sondern ein Mittel, um durch die reinste Gemüthsruhe zur höchsten Cultur zu gelangen
Fronti nulla fides
Frost and fraud both end in foul.
Frost is God's plough.
Fructu non foliis arborem æstima
Frugality, and even avarice, in the lower orders of mankind are true ambition. These afford the only ladder for the poor to rise to preferment.
Frugality is an estate.
Frugality is founded on the principle that all
riches have limits.
Frugality is good, if liberality be joined with it.
Frugality may be termed the daughter of prudence, the sister of temperance, and the parent of liberty.
Fruges consumere nati
Frühe Hochzeit, lange Liebe
Fruit is seed.
Frustra fit per plura, quod fieri potest per pauciora

Fuge magna; licet sub paupere tecto / Reges

Fuimus

Fules are aye fond o' flittin'.

minus ignotos generosis
Full little knowest thou that hast not tried / What hell it is in suing long to bide; / To lose good days that might be better spent, / To waste long nights in pensive discontent.
Full many a day for ever is lost / By delaying its work till to-morrow; / The minutes of sloth have often cost / Long years of bootless sorrow.
Full many a gem of purest ray serene / The dark unfathom'd caves of ocean bear; / Full many a flower is born to blush unseen, / And waste its sweetness on the desert air.
Full many a stoic eye and aspect stern / Masks hearts where grief has little left to learn; / And many a withering thought lies hid, not lost, / In smiles that least befit who wears them most.
Full of sound and fury, / Signifying nothing.
Full oft have letters caused the writers / To curse the day they were inditers.
Full of wise saws and modern instances.
Full seldom doth a man repent, or use / Both grace and will to pick the vicious quitch / Of blood and custom wholly out of him, / And make all clean, and plant himself afresh.
Full twenty times was Peter fear'd / For once that Peter was respected.
Full vessels give the least sound.
Full wise is he that can himselven knowe.
Fully to possess and rule an object, one must first study it for its own sake.
Fumos vendere
Fumum, et opes, strepitumque Romæ
Functus officio
Fundamentum est justitiæ fides
Fungar vice cotis, acutum / Reddere quæ ferrum valet, exsors ipsa secandi
Fürchterlich / Ist einer der nichts zu verlieren hat
Für den Dialektiker ist die Welt ein Begriff, für den Schöngeist ein Bild, für den Schwärmer ein Traum, für den Forscher Wahrheit
Für eine Nation ist nur das gut was aus ihrem
eignen Kern und ihrem eignen allgemeinen Bedürfniss hervorgegangen, ohne Nachäffung einer andern
Für einen Leichnam bin ich nicht zu Haus; / Mir geht es wie der Katze mit der Maus
Für ewig ist ja nicht gestorben, was man für diese Welt begräbt
Für Gerechte giebt es keine Gesetze

Further I will not flatter you, / That all I see in you is worthy love, / Than this; that nothing do I see in you / That should merit hate.
Fury wasteth, as patience lasteth.
Futurity is impregnable to mortal kin; no
prayer pierces through heaven's adamantine walls.
Futurity is the great concern of mankind.
Futurity still shortens, and time present sucks in time to come.
Fuyez les procès sur toutes les choses, la conscience s'y intéresse, la santé s'y altère, les biens s'y dissipent
Gäb es keine Narren, so gäb es keine Weisen
Gaieté de cœur
Gaiety is often the reckless ripple over depths of despair.
Gaiety is the soul's health; sadness is its poison.
Gaiety overpowers weak spirits; good-humour recreates and revives them.
Gaiety pleases more when we are assured that it does not cover carelessness.
Gain at the expense of reputation should be
called loss.
'Gainst the tooth of time / And rasure of oblivion.
Galea spes salutis
Galeatum sero duelli pœnitet
Gallantry thrives most in a court atmosphere.
Gallicè
Gallus in sterquilinio suo plurimum potest
Gambling is the child of avarice, but the parent of prodigality.
Gambling with cards, or dice, or stocks, is all one thing; it is getting money without giving an equivalent for it.
Game is a civil gunpowder, in peace / Blowing up houses with their whole increase.
Games of chance are traps to catch school-boy novices and gaping country squires, who begin with a guinea and end with a mortgage.
Gaming finds a man a cully and leaves him a knave.

Gaming has been resorted to by the affluent as may succeed for a moment, but, like other stimuli, it produces indirect debility.
Gaming is the destruction of all decorum; the prince forgets at it his dignity, and the lady her modesty.

Gang to bed wi' the lamb and rise wi' the laverock

Garments that have once a rent in them are
subject to be torn on every nail, and glasses that are once cracked are soon broken; such is a good man's name once tainted with just reproach.
Garrit aniles / Ex re fabellas
Gar Vieles lernt man, um es wieder zu vergessen; / Um an den Ziel zu stehen, muss man die Bahn durchmessen

Gâter une chandelle pour trouver une épingle
Gather gear by every wile that's justified by
honour; / Not for to hide it in a hedge, nor for a train attendant; / But for the glorious privilege of being independent.
Gather the rosebuds while ye may, / Old Time is still a-flying, / And this same flower that smiles to-day, / To-morrow will be dying.
Gathering gear
Gathering her brows like gathering storm, / Nursing her wrath to keep it warm.

Gay hope is theirs by fancy fed, / Less pleasing when possest; / The tear forgot as soon as shed, / The sunshine of the breast.
Gear is easier gained than guided.
Geben ist Sache des Reichen
Gebrade duijven vliegen niet door de lucht

Geese are plucked as long as they have any feathers.
Gefährlich ist's, den Leu zu wecken, / Verderblich ist des Tigers Zahn; / Jedoch der schrecklichste der Schrecken, / Das ist der Mensch in seinem Wahn
Gefährlich ist's ein Mordgewehr zu tragen / Und auf den Schützen springt der Pfeil zurück
Gefährlich ist's mit Geistern sich gesellen
Gefährte munter kürzt die Meilen
Gefühl ist alles; / Name ist Schall und Rauch / Umnebelnd Himmelsglut

Geld ist der Mann
Geld im Beutel vertreibt die Schwermuth
Gelegenheit macht den Dieb
Gelehrte Dummkopf
Gemeen goed, geen goed
Gemsen steigen hoch und werden doch gefangen
General abstract truth is the most precious of all blessings; without it man is blind; it is the eye of reason.
General infidelity is the hardest soil which the propagators of a new religion can have to work upon.
General suffering is the fruit of general misbehaviour,
general dishonesty.
General truths are seldom applied to particular occasions.
Generally all warlike people are a little idle, and love danger better than travail.
Generally speaking, an author's style is a faithful copy of his mind. If you would write a lucid style, let there first be light in your own mind; and if you would write a grand style, you ought to have a grand character.
Generations are as the days of toilsome mankind; death and birth are the vesper and the matin bells that summon mankind to sleep, and to rise refreshed for new advancement.
Generosity during life is a very different thing
from generosity in the hour of death; one proceeds from genuine liberality and benevolence, the other from pride or fear.
Generosity is catching: and if so many escape it, it is somewhat for the same reason that countrymen escape the small-pox--because they meet with no one to give it to them.
Generosity is the flower of justice.
Generosity is the part of the soul raised above the vulgar.
Generosity should never exceed ability.
Generosity, wrong placed, becomes a vice.
A princely mind will undo a private family.
Generous souls are still most subject to credulity.
Geniesse, wenn du kannst, und leide, wenn du musst, / Vergiss den Schmerz, erfrische das Vergnügen
Genius and virtue, like diamonds, are best plain set.
Genius always gives its best at first, prudence at last.
Genius begins great works, labour alone finishes
them.
Genius believes its faintest presentiment against the testimony of all history, for it knows that facts are not ultimates, but that a state of mind is the ancestor of everything.
Genius borrows nobly.
Genius can never despise labour.
Genius cannot escape the taint of its time more than a child the influence of its begetting.
Genius can only breathe freely in an atmosphere
of freedom.
Genius counts all its miracles poor and short.
Genius does not need a special language; it newly uses whatever tongue it finds.
Genius does what it must, and talent does what it can.
Genius easily hews out its figure from the block, but the sleepless chisel gives it life.
Genius, even as it is the greatest good, is the
greatest harm.
Genius ever stands with nature in solemn union, and what the one foretells the other will fulfil.
Genius finds its own road and carries its own lamp.
Genius grafted on womanhood is like to overgrow it and break its stem.
Genius has privileges of its own; it selects an orbit for itself; and be this never so eccentric, if it is indeed a celestial orbit, we mere star-gazers must at last compose ourselves, must cease to cavil at it, and begin to observe it and calculate its laws.
Genius in poverty is never feared, because
Nature, though liberal in her gifts in one instance, is forgetful in another.
Genius invents fine manners, which the baron and the baroness copy very fast, and, by the advantage of a palace, better the instruction. They stereotype the lesson they have learned into a mode.
Genius is always ascetic, and piety and love.
Genius is always a surprise, but it is born with great advantages when the stock from which it springs has been long under cultivation.
Genius is always consistent when most audacious.
Genius is always impatient of its harness; its
wild blood makes it hard to train.
Genius is always more suggestive than expressive.
Genius is always sufficiently the enemy of genius by over-influence.
Genius is a nervous disease.
Genius is ever a secret to itself.
Genius is ever the greatest mystery to itself.
Genius is inconsiderate, self-relying, and, like unconscious beauty, without any intention to please.
Genius is intensity of life; an overflowing vitality which floods and fertilises a continent or a hemisphere of being; which makes a nature many-sided and whole, while most men remain partial and fragmentary.
Genius is lonely without the surrounding presence of a people to inspire it.
Genius is mainly an affair of energy.
Genius is not a single power, but a combination
of great powers. It reasons, but it is not reasoning; it judges, but it is not judgment; imagines, but it is not imagination; it feels deeply and fiercely, but it is not passion. It is neither, because it is all.
Genius is nothing but a great capacity for patience.
Genius is nothing but labour and diligence.
Genius is nothing more than our common faculties refined to a greater intensity.
Genius is nothing more than the effort of the idea to assume a definite form.
Genius is nourished from within and without.
Genius is only as rich as it is generous.
Genius is religious.
Genius is that in whose power a man is.
Genius is that power of man which by its deeds and actions gives laws and rules; and it does not, as used to be thought, manifest itself only by over-stepping existing laws, breaking established rules, and declaring itself above all restraint.
Genius is the gold in the mine; talent is the
miner who works and brings it out.
Genius is the power of carrying the feelings of childhood into the powers of manhood.
Genius is the transcendent capacity of taking trouble first of all.
Genius is the very eye of intellect and the wing of thought; it is always in advance of its time, and is the pioneer for the generation which it precedes.
Genius is to other gifts what the carbuncle is to the precious stones. It sends forth its own light, whereas other stones only reflect borrowed light.
Genius loci
Genius makes its observations in shorthand; talent writes them out at length.
Genius may at times want the spur, but it stands as often in need of the curb.
Genius melts many ages into one.... A work
of genius is but the newspaper of a century, or perchance of a hundred centuries.
Genius must be born, and never can be taught.
Genius of a kind is necessary to make a fortune, and especially a large one.
Genius only commands recognition when it has created the taste which is to appreciate it.
Genius only leaves behind it the monuments of its strength.
Genius should be the child of genius, and every
child should be inspired.
Genius, the Pythian of the beautiful, leaves its large truths a riddle to the dull.
Genius unexerted is no more genius than a bushel of acorns is a forest of oaks.
Genius will reconcile men to much.
Genius works in sport, and goodness smiles to the last.

Gens de bureau
Gens de condition

Gens de langues
Gens de lettres
Gens de lois
Gens de même famille

Gens togata
Gentility is nothing else but ancient riches.
Gentility without ability is waur
Gentle passions brighten the horizon of our existence, move without wearying, warm without consuming, and are the badges of true strength.
Gentle words, quiet words, are, after all, the most powerful words. They are more convincing, more compelling, more prevailing.
Gentleman, in its primal, literal, and perpetual
meaning, is a man of pure race.
Gentleman is a term which does not apply to any station, but to the mind and the feelings in every station.
Gentlemanliness is just another word for intense humanity.
Gentlemen have to learn that it is no part of their duty or privilege to live on other people's toil; that there is no degradation in the hardest manual or the humblest servile labour, when it is honest.
"Gentlemen of the jury, you will now consider your verdict."
Gentleness corrects whatever is offensive in
our manners.
Gentleness! more powerful than Hercules.
Gentleness, when it weds with manhood, makes a man.
Gently comes the world to those / That are cast in gentle mould.
Gently didst thou ramble round the little circle of thy pleasures, jostling no creature in thy way: for each one's sorrows thou hadst a tear; for each man's need thou hadst a shilling.
Gently, gently touch a nettle, / And it stings
you for your pains; / Grasp it like a man of mettle, / And it soft as silk remains.
Genug ist über einer Sackvoll
Genuine morality depends on no religion, though every one sanctions it and thereby guarantees to it its support.
Genuine religion is matter of feeling rather than matter of opinion.
Genuine simplicity of heart is a healing and cementing principle.
Genus et proavos et quæ non fecimus ipsi, /
Vix ea nostra voco
Genus humanum superavit
Genus immortale manet, multosque per annos / Stat fortuna domus, et avi numerantur avorum

mehr die weibliche Tugend

Gesetzlose Gewalt ist die furchbarste Schwäche
Gespenster sind für solche Leute nur / Die sehn sie wollen
Get a good name and go to sleep.
Get money, honestly if you can, but get money.
Get once into the secret of any Christian act, and you get practically into the secret of Christianity itself.
Get on the crupper of a good stout hypothesis,
and you may ride round the world.
Get place and wealth, if possible, with grace; / If not, by any means get wealth and place.
Get spindle and distaff ready, and God will send the flax.
Get thee to a nunnery!
Get to live; / Then live and use it; else it is not true / That thou hast gotten.
Get what ye can and keep what ye hae.
Get your enemies to read your works in order to mend them, for your friend is so much your second self that he will judge too like you.
Geteilte Freud' ist doppelt Freude
Gewalt ist die beste Beredsamkeit
Gewinnen ist leichter als Erhalten
Gewöhne dich, da stets der Tod dir dräut, /
Dankbar zu nehmen, was das Leben beut
Gewöhnlich glaubt Mensch, wenn er nur Worte hört, / Es müsse sich dabei doch auch was denken lassen
Ghosts! There are nigh a thousand million walking the earth openly at noontide; some half-hundred have vanished from it, some half-hundred have arisen in it, ere thy watch ticks once.
Giant Antæus in the fable acquired new strength every time he touched the earth; so some brave minds gain fresh energy from that which depresses and crushes others.
Gibier de potence
Gie a bairn his will and a whelp his fill, an'
neither will do well.
Gie a beggar a bed, and he'll pay you with a louse.
Gie him tow enough and he'll hang himsel'
Gie me a canny hour at e'en, / My arms about my dearie, O, / An' warl'ly cares an' warl'ly men / May a' gang tapsalteerie, O.
Gie me ae spark o' Nature's fire! / That's a' the learning I desire; / Then though I drudge through dub and mire, / At pleugh or cart, / My Muse, though hamely in attire, / May touch the heart.
Gie me a peck o' oaten strae, / An' sell your wind
for siller.
Gie the deil his due, an' ye'll gang till him.
Gie the greedy dog a muckle bane.
Gie wealth to some be-ledger'd cit, / In cent. per cent.; / But gie me real, sterling wit, / And I'm content.
Gie your heart to God and your awms
to the poor.
Gie your tongue mair holidays than your head.
Giebt es Krieg, so macht der Teufel die Hölle weiter
Giebt's schönre Pflichten für ein edles Herz / Als ein Verteidiger der Unschuld sein, / Das Recht der unterdrückten zu beschirmen?
Gierigheid is niet verzadigd voor zij den mond vol aarde heeft
Giff-gaff maks gude friends
Gift of prophecy has been wisely denied to
man. Did a man foresee his life, and not merely hope it and grope it, and so by necessity and free-will make and fabricate it into a reality, he were no man, but some other kind of creature, superhuman or subterhuman.
Gifts are as gold that adorns the temple; grace is like the temple that sanctifies the gold.
Gifts are often losses.
Gifts come from on high in their own peculiar forms.
Gifts from the hand are silver and gold, but the heart gives that which neither silver nor gold can buy.
Gifts make their way through stone walls.
Gifts weigh like mountains on a sensitive heart.
Gigni pariter cum corpore, et una / Crescere sentimus pariterque senescere mentem
Gin
Giovine santo, diavolo vecchio
Gird your hearts with silent fortitude, / Suffering
yet hoping all things.
Girls we love for what they are; young men for what they promise to be.
Give a boy address and accomplishments, and you give him the mastery of palaces and fortunes where he goes.
Give a dog an ill name and hang him.
Give a hint to a man of sense and consider the thing done.
Give alms, that thy children may not ask
them.
Give a man luck and throw him into the sea.
Give ample room and verge enough.
Give an ass oats, and it runs after thistles.
Give, and it shall be given to you.
Give and spend, / And God will send.
Give and take.
Give a rogue rope enough, and he will hang himself.
Give, but, if possible, spare the poor man the shame of begging.
Give every flying minute / Something to keep in store.
Give every man his due.
Give every man thine ear, but few thy voice; /
Take each man's censure, but reserve thy judgment.
Give from below what ye get from above, / Light for the heaven-light, love for its love, / A holy soul for the Holy Dove.
Give God the margin of eternity to justify Himself in.
Give him an inch and he'll take an ell.
Give him a present! give him a halter.
Give me again my hollow tree, / A crust of
bread, and liberty.
Give me a look, give me a face, / That makes simplicity a grace, / Robes loosely flowing, hair as free; / Such sweet neglect more taketh me, / Than all the adulteries of art; / They strike mine eyes, but not my heart.
Give me but / Something whereunto I may bind my heart; / Something to love, to rest upon, to clasp / Affection's tendrils round.
Give me health and a day, and I will make the pomp of emperors ridiculous.
Give me insight into to-day, and you may have the antique and future worlds.... This idea has inspired the genius of Goldsmith, Burns, Cowper, and, in a newer time, of Goethe, Wordsworth, and Carlyle. Their writing is blood-warm.
Give me my Romeo: and, when he shall die, /
Take him and cut him out in little stars, / And he will make the face of heaven so fine / That all the world will be in love with night, / And pay no homage to the garish sun.
Give me that man / Who is not passion's slave, and I will wear him / In my heart's core, ay, in my heart of hearts.
Give me the avow'd, th' erect, the manly foe, / Bold I can meet, perhaps may turn, his blow; / But of all plagues, good Heaven, thy wrath can send, / Save, save, oh! save me from the candid friend.
Give me the eloquent cheek, where blushes burn and die.
Give me the liberty to know, to think, to believe, and to utter freely, according to conscience, above all other liberties.
Give neither counsel nor salt till you are asked
for it.
Give not that which is holy to the dogs, neither cast ye your pearls before swine.
Give only so much to one that you may have to give to another.
Give orders, but no more, and nothing will be done.
Give pleasure to the few; to please many is vain.
Give ruffles to a man who wants a shirt.
Give sorrow words; the grief that does not speak, / Whispers the o'erfraught heart, and bids it break.
Give the devil his due.
Give the devil rope enough and he will hang himself.
Give thy need, thine honour, and thy friend his due.
Give thy thoughts no tongue, / Nor any unproportioned
thought his act. / Be thou familiar, but by no means vulgar. / The friends thou hast, and their adoption tried, / Grapple them to thy soul with hoops of steel; / But do not dull thy palm with entertainment / Of each new-hatch'd unfledged comrade.
Give to a gracious message / An host of tongues; but let ill tidings tell / Themselves when they be felt.
Give to him that asketh of thee, and from him that would borrow of thee turn not thou away.
Give to the masses nothing to do, and they will topple down thrones and cut throats; give them the government here, and they will make pulpits useless, and colleges an impertinence.
Give tribute, but not oblation, to human wisdom.
Give unto me, made lowly wise, / The spirit of
self-sacrifice; / The confidence of reason give; / And in the light of truth thy bondman let me live.
Give us the man who sings at his work! Be his occupation what it may, he will be equal to any of those who follow the same pursuit in silent sullenness. He will do more in the same time; he will do it better; he will persevere longer.
Give way to your betters.
Give you a reason on compulsion? If reasons were as plenty as blackberries, I would give no man a reason upon compulsion.
Give your tongue more holiday than your hands or eyes.
Given a living man, there will be found clothes
for him; he will find himself clothes; but the suit of clothes pretending that it is both clothes and man--
Given a world of knaves, to educe an Honesty from their united action, is a problem that is becoming to all men a palpably hopeless one.
Given the men a people choose, the people itself, in its exact worth and worthlessness, is given.
Gives not the hawthorn bush a sweeter shade / To shepherds, looking on their silly sheep, / Than doth a rich embroider'd canopy / To kings that fear their subjects' treachery.
Giving alms never lessens the purse.
Giving away is the instrument for accumulated
treasures; it is like a bucket for the distribution of the waters deposited in the bowels of a well.
Giving to the poor increaseth a man's store.
Gladiator in arena consilium capit
Glänzendes Elend
Glasses and lasses are brittle ware.
Glaube nur, du hast viel gethan / Wenn dir Geduld gewöhnest an
Glebæ ascriptus
Gleiches Blut, gleiches Gut, und gleiche Jahre machen die besten Heirathspaare
Gleich sei keiner dem andern; doch gleich sei jeder dem Höchsten. Wie das zu machen? Es sei jeder vollendet in sich
Gleich und Gleich gesellt sich gern, sprach der Teufel zum Köhler
Gleichheit est immer das festeste Band der Liebe
Gleichheit ist das heilige Gesetz der Menschheit
Gli alberi grandi fanno più ombra che frutto
Gli amici legano la borsa con un filo di ragnatelo
Gli uomini alla moderna, e gli asini all' antica
Gli uomini fanno la roba, e le donne la conservano
Gli uomini hanno gli anni che sentono, e le
donne quelli che mostrano
Gli uomini hanno men rispetto di offendere uno che si facci amare che uno che si facci temere
Gloria in excelsis Deo
Gloria vana florece, y no grana
Gloria virtutis umbra
Gloriæ et famæ jactura facienda est, publicæ
utilitatis causa
Gloriam qui spreverit, veram habet
Glories, like glow-worms, afar-off shine bright, / But looked at near, have neither heat nor light.
Glorious men are the scorn of wise men, the admiration of fools, the idols of parasites, and the slaves of their own vaunts.
Glory and gain the industrious tribe provoke; / And gentle dulness ever loves a joke.
Glory fills the world with virtue, and, like a
beneficent sun, covers the whole earth with flowers and fruits.
Glory grows guilty of detested crimes.
Glory is like a circle in the water, / Which never ceaseth to enlarge itself, / Till, by broad spreading, it disperse to naught.
Glory is safe when it is deserved; not so popularity; the one lasts like mosaic, the other is effaced like a crayon drawing.
Glory is so enchanting that we love whatever we associate with it, even though it be death.
Glory is the fair child of peril.
Glory is the unanimous praise of good men.
Glory long has made the sages smile, / 'Tis something, nothing, words, illusion, wind, / Depending more upon the historian's style / Than on the name a person leaves behind.
Glory relaxes often and debilitates the mind; censure stimulates and contracts--both to an extreme.
Glück auf dem Weg
Glück macht Mut
Glück und Weiber haben die Narren lieb
Glücklich, glücklich nenn' ich den / Dem des Daseins letzte Stunde / Schlägt in seiner Kinder Mitte
Glücklich wer jung in jungen Tagen, / Glücklich wer mit Zeit gestählt, Gelernt des Lebens Ernst zu tragen
Gluttony and drunkenness have two evils attendant on them; they make the carcass smart as well as the pocket.
Gluttony is the source of all our infirmities
and the fountain of all our diseases. As a lamp is choked by a superabundance of oil, a fire extinguished by an excess of fuel, so is the natural health of the body destroyed by intemperate diet.
Gluttony kills more than the sword.
Gluttony, where it prevails, is more violent, and certainly more despicable, than avarice itself.
Gnarling sorrow hath less power to bite / The man that mocks at it and sets it light.
Gnats are unnoticed whereso'er they fly, / But eagles gazed upon by every eye.
Go deep enough, there is music everywhere.
Go down the ladder when thou marriest a wife; go up when thou choosest a friend.
Go, miser, go; for lucre sell thy soul; / Truck wares for wares, and trudge from pole to pole. / That men may say, when thou art dead and gone: / "See what a vast estate he left his son!"
Go, poor devil, get thee gone; why should I hurt thee? This world, surely, is wide enough to hold both thee and me.
Go to Jericho and let your beards grow.
Go to the ant, thou sluggard; consider her ways, and be wise.
Go to your bosom; / Knock there, and ask your heart what it doth know / That's like my brother's fault; if it confess / A natural guiltiness, such as his is, / Let it not sound a thought upon your tongue / Against my brother's life.
Go where you may, you still find yourself in
a conditional world.
Go whither thou wilt, thou shalt find no rest but in humble subjection to the government of a superior.
Go, wondrous creature, mount where science guides. / Go, measure earth, weigh air, and state the tides; / Instruct the planets in what orbs to run, / Correct old Time, and regulate the sun; / Go, teach Eternal Wisdom how to rule, / Then drop into thyself and be a fool.
Go you and try a democracy in your own house.
Go, you may call it madness, folly; / You shall not chase my gloom away; / There's such a charm in melancholy, / I would not, if I could, be gay.
Gobe-mouches
God alone can properly bind up a bleeding heart.
God alone is true; God alone is great; alone is God.
God answers sharp and sudden on some prayers, / And thrusts the thing we have prayed for in our face, / A gauntlet with a gift in it.
God asks no man whether he will accept life. That is not the choice. You must take it; the only choice is how.
God asks not what, but whence, thy work is:
from the fruit / He turns His eye away, to prove the inmost root.
God assists those who rise early in the morning.
God blesses still the generous thought, / And still the fitting word He speeds, / And truth, at His requiring taught, / He quickens into deeds.
God blesses the seeking, not the finding.
God builds His temple in the heart and on the ruins of churches and religions.
God comes at last, when we think He is
farthest off.
God comes in distress, and distress goes.
God comes to see us without bell.
God comes with leaden feet, but strikes with iron hands.
God created man in his own image.
God deals His wrath by weight, but His
mercy without weight.
God deceiveth thee not.
God defend me from the man of one book.
God desireth to make your burden light to you, for man hath been created weak.
God does not measure men by inches.
God does not pay every week, but He pays at
the end.
God does not require us to live on credit; He pays what we earn as we earn it, good or evil, heaven or hell, according to our choice.
God does not smite with both hands.
God does not weigh criminality in our scales. God's measure is the heart of the offender, a balance so delicate that a tear cast in the other side may make the weight of error kick the beam.
God does with His children as a master does with his pupils; the more hopeful they are, the more work He gives them to do.
God enters by a private door into every individual.
God estimates us not by the position we are in, but by the way in which we fill it.
God gave thy soul brave wings; put not those feathers / Into a bed to sleep out all ill weathers.
God gives all things to industry.
God gives birds their food, but they must fly for it.
God gives every bird its nest, but does not
throw it into the nest.
God gives his angels charge of those who sleep, / But He Himself watches with those who wake.
God gives sleep to the bad, in order that the good may be undisturbed.
God gives strength to bear a great deal, if we only strive ourselves to endure.
God gives the will; necessity gives the law.
God gives us love. Something to love / He
lends us; but when love is grown / To ripeness, that on which it throve / Falls off, and love is left alone.
God giveth speech to all, song to the few.
God grant you fortune, my son, for knowledge avails you little.
God hands gifts to some, whispers them to others.
God hangs the greatest weights on the smallest wires.
God has been pleased to prescribe limits to His
own power, and to work out His ends within these limits.
God has commanded time to console the unhappy.
God has connected the labour which is essential to the bodily sustenance with the pleasures which are healthiest for the heart; and while He made the ground stubborn, He made its herbage fragrant and its blossoms fair.
God has delegated Himself to a million deputies.
God has given a prophet to every people in its own tongue.
God has given nuts to some who have no teeth.
God has given us wit and flavour, and brightness and laughter, and perfumes to enliven the days of man's pilgrimage, and to charm his pained steps over the burning marl.
God has His little children out at nurse in many a home.
God has lent us the earth for our life; it is a great entail.
God has made man to take pleasure in the use
of his eyes, wits, and body; and the foolish creature is continually trying to live without looking at anything, without thinking about anything, and without doing anything.
God has made sunny spots in the heart; why should we exclude the light from them?
God has not said all that thou hast said.
God has sunk souls in dust, that by that means they may burst their way through errors to truth, through faults to virtue, and through sufferings to bliss.
God hath anointed thee to free the oppressed and crush the oppressor.
God hath given to man a short time here upon
earth, and yet upon this short time eternity depends.
God hath given you one face, and you make yourselves another: you jig, you amble, and you lisp, and you nickname God's creatures, and make your wantonness your ignorance.
God hath many sharp-cutting instruments and rough files for the polishing of His jewels.
