He that doeth truth cometh to the light.
He that doth not plough at home won't plough abroad.
He that doth the ravens feed, / Yea, providently caters for the sparrow, / Be comfort to my age.
He that eats longest lives longest.
He that endureth is not overcome.
He that, ever following her (Duty's) commands, / On with toil of heart and knees and hands, / Thro' the long gorge to the far light has won / His path upward, and prevail'd, / Shall find the toppling crags of Duty scaled, / Are close upon the shining tablelands / To which our God Himself is moon and sun.
He that falls into sin, is a man; that grieves at it, is a saint; that boasteth of it, is a devil; yet some glory in that shame, counting the stains of sin the best complexion of their souls.
He that feareth is not made perfect in love.
He that fights and runs away / May live to fight another day.
He that filches from me my good name / Robs
me of that which not enriches him, / And makes me poor indeed.
He that finds something before it is lost will die before he falls ill.
He that flees not will be fled from.
He that gallops his horse on Blackstone edge / May chance to catch a fall.
He that gets gear
He that gets patience, and the blessing which /
Preachers conclude with, hath not lost his pains.
He that gives to the poor lends to the Lord.
He that goes a-borrowing goes a-sorrowing.
He that goes softly goes safely.
He that grasps at too much holds nothing fast.
He that has a head of wax should not walk in
the sun.
He that has a head will not want a hat.
He that has a wife has a master.
 (re
He that has an ill wife likes to eat butter
He that has been taught only by himself has
had a fool for a master.
He that has just enough can soundly sleep; / The o'ercome only fashes fowk to keep.
He that has light within his own clear breast may sit in the centre and enjoy bright day.
He that has lost his faith, what staff has he left?
He that has muckle would aye hae mair.
He that has no head needs no hat.
He that has no sense at thirty will never have any.
He that has no shame has no conscience.
He that has siller in his purse canna want
a head on h
He that has to choose has trouble.
He that hateth gifts shall live.
He that hath a beard is more than a youth, and he that hath no beard is less than a man.
He that hath a satirical vein, as he maketh others afraid of his wit, so he hath need to be afraid of others' memory.
He that hath a trade hath an estate, and he that hath a calling hath an office of profit and honour.
He that hath a wife and children hath given hostages to fortune; for they are impediments to great enterprises, either of virtue or mischief.
He that hath but gained the title of a jester,
let him assure himself the fool is not far off.
He that hath care of keeping days of payment is lord of another man's purse.
He that hath ears to hear, let him hear.
He that hath gained an entire conquest over himself will find no mighty difficulties to subdue all other opposition.
He that hath knowledge spareth his words.
He that hath mercy on the poor, happy is he.
He that hath no rule over his own spirit is like a city that is broken down and without walls.
He that hath pity upon the poor lendeth to the Lord.
He that hath sense hath strength.
He that hears much and speaks not at all, / Shall be welcome both in bower and hall.
He that high growth on cedars did bestow, /
Gave also lowly mushrooms leave to grow.
He that hinders not a mischief is guilty of it.
He that humbles himself shall be exalted.
He that imposes an oath makes it, / Not he that for convenience takes it.
He that increaseth knowledge increaseth sorrow.
He that invented the Maiden, first hanselled it
He that is a friend to himself is a friend to all men.
He that is born of a hen must scrape for a living.
He that is courteous at all, will be courteous to all.
He that is discontented and troubled is tossed with divers suspicions; he is neither quiet himself, nor suffereth others to be quiet.
He that is doing nothing is seldom without helpers.
He that is down needs fear no fall; / He that
is low no pride.
He that is down, the world cries "Down with him!"
He that is embarked with the devil must sail with him.
He that is faithful in that which is least is faithful also in much; and he that is unjust in the least, is unjust also in the much.
He that is full of himself is very empty.
He that is ill to himself will be good to nobody.
He that is not against us is on our part.
He that is not handsome at twenty, strong at thirty, rich at forty, nor wise at fifty, will never be handsome, strong, wise, or rich.
He that is not open to conviction is not qualified for discussion.
He that is not with me is against me.
He that is of a merry heart hath a continual
feast.
He that is proud eats up himself; pride is his own glass, his own trumpet, his own chronicle; and whatever praises itself but in the deed devours the deed in the praise.
He that is robb'd, not wanting what is stolen, / Let him not know 't, and he's not robb'd at all.
He that is ready to slip is as a lamp despised in the thought of him that is at ease.
He that is slow to anger is better than the mighty; and he that ruleth his spirit, than he that taketh a city.
He that is slow to wrath is of great understanding.
He that is spiritual judgeth all things, yet he himself is judged of no man.
He that is surety for another, is never sure himself.
He that is the inferior of nothing can be the superior of nothing, the equal of nothing.
He that is tied with one slender string, such as one resolute struggle would break, is prisoner only to his own sloth; and who would pity his thraldom?
He that is to-day a king, to-morrow shall die.
He that is violent in the pursuit of pleasure won't mind to turn villain for the purchase.
He that is well-ordered and disposed within himself careth not for the strange and perverse behaviour of men.
He that keeks
He that keepeth his way preserveth his soul.
He that kills a man when he is drunk must be
hanged for it when he is sober.
He that knoweth not that which he ought to know, is a brute beast among men; he that knoweth no more than he hath need of, is a man among brute beasts; and he that knoweth all that may be known, is a god amongst men.
He that knows a little of the world will admire it enough to fall down and worship it; he that knows it most will most despise it.
He that knows, and knows not that he knows, is asleep. Arouse him.
He that knows, and knows that he knows, is wise. Follow him.
He that knows is strong.
He that knows not, and knows not that he knows not, is stupid. Shun him.
He that knows not, and knows that he knows not, is good. Teach him.
He that lacks time to mourn lacks time to mend.
He that lies down with dogs will rise up with fleas.
He that lives in perpetual suspicion lives the
life of a sentinel, of a sentinel never relieved.
He that lives longest sees most.
He that lives must grow old; and he that would rather grow old than die, has God to thank for the infirmities of old age.
He that lives upon hopes will die fasting.
He that lives with cripples learns to limp.
He that lives with wolves will learn to howl.
He that loses his conscience has nothing left that is worth keeping.
He that loves Christianity better than truth will soon love his own sect or party better than Christianity.
He that loves God aright must not desire that God should love him in return
He that loveth a book will never want a faithful friend, a wholesome counsellor, a cheerful companion, an effectual comforter.
He that loveth danger shall perish therein.
He that loveth father and mother more than me is not worthy of me.
He that loveth not his brother, whom he hath seen, how can he love God, whom he hath not seen?
He that loveth pleasure shall be a poor man.
He that loveth silver shall not be satisfied with silver; nor he that loveth abundance with increase.
He that maketh haste to be rich shall not be
innocent.
He that marries before he is wise will die before he thrive.
He that marries for money sells his liberty.
He that meddleth with strife belonging not to him is like one that taketh a dog by the ears.
He that needs five thousand pound to live, / Is full as poor as he that needs but five.
He that never thinks can never be wise.
He that observeth the wind shall not sow;
and he that regardeth the clouds shall not reap.
He that on pilgrimages goeth ever, / Becometh holy late or never.
He that oppresseth the poor to increase his riches, and he that giveth to the rich, shall surely come to want.
He that pities another minds himsel'.
He that prieth in at her windows shall also hearken at her doors.
He that promises too much means nothing.
He that purposes to be happy by the affection or acquaintance of the best, the greatest man alive, will always find his mind unsettled and perplexed.
He that questioneth much will learn much.
He that revels in a well-chosen library has innumerable dishes, and all of admirable flavour.
He that ruleth among men must be just, ruling in the fear of God.
He that runs in the dark may well stumble.
He that runs may read.
He that seeks others to beguile, / Is oft o'ertaken in his own wile.
He that seeks to have many friends never has any.
He that serves the altar should live by the altar.
He that shuts his eyes against a small light
would not be brought to see that which he had no mind to see, let it be placed in never so clear a light and never so near him.
He that sows in the highway loses his corn.
He that sows iniquity shall reap sorrow.
He that spares the bad injures the good.
He that spares the rod spoils the child.
He that speaks the thing he should not / Must
often hear the thing he would not.
He that speaks the truth will find himself in sufficiently dramatic situations.
He that spends his gear
He that stands upon a slippery place / Makes nice of no vain hold to stay him up.
He that steals a preen
He that steals for others will be hanged for
himself.
He that strikes with the sword shall perish by the sword.
He that studieth revenge keepeth his own wounds green.
He that takes away reason to make way for revelation puts out the light of both.
He that talks deceitfully for truth must hurt it more by his example than he promotes it by his arguments.
He that talks much errs much.
He that talks much lies much.
He that tholes
He that tilleth his land shall have plenty of bread.
He that turns not from every sin, turns not aright from any one sin.
He that undervalues himself will undervalue
others, and he that undervalues others will oppress them.
He that voluntarily continues ignorant is guilty of all the crimes which ignorance produces.
He that waits long at the ferry will get over some time.
He that walketh uprightly walks surely.
He that walketh with wise men shall be wise; but a companion of fools shall be destroyed.
He that wants good sense is unhappy in having
learning, for he has thereby only more ways of exposing himself; and he that has sense knows that learning is not knowledge, but rather the art of using it.
He that wants money, means, and content is without three good friends.
He that will be angry for anything will be angry for nothing.
He that will believe only what he can fully comprehend must have a very long head or a very short creed.
He that will carry nothing about him but gold will be every day at a loss for readier change.
He that will have his son have a respect for
him must have a great reverence for his son.
He that will lose his friend for a jest, deserves to die a beggar by the bargain.
He that will love life and see good days, let him refrain his tongue from evil, and his lips that they speak no guile.
He that will not reason is a bigot; he that cannot, is a fool; and he that dare not, is a slave.
He that will not when he may, / When he will he shall have nay.
He that will not work shall not eat.
He that will to Cupar, maun to Cupar
He that will watch Providence will never want a Providence to watch.
He that winketh with the eye causeth sorrow.
He that winna be counselled canna be helped.
He that winna save a penny will ne'er hae
ony.
He that won't plough at home won't plough abroad.
He that would be rich in a year will be hanged in half a year.
He that would be singular in his apparel had need of something superlative to balance that affectation.
He that would have eggs must endure the cackling of the hens.
He that would have his virtue published is not the servant of virtue, but of glory.
He that would live in peace and rest / Must hear, and see, and say the best.
He that would reap well must sow well.
He that would reckon up all the accidents preferments depend upon, may as well undertake to count the sands or sun up infinity.
He that would relish success to purpose should keep his passion cool and his expectation low.
He that would reproach an author for obscurity should look into his own mind to see whether it is quite clear there. In the dusk the plainest writing is illegible.
He that wrestles with us strengthens our nerves and sharpens our skill.
He that wrongs his friend / Wrongs himself
more, and ever bears about / A silent court of justice in his breast, / Himself the judge and jury, and himself / The prisoner at the bar, ever condemned.
He the cross who longest bears / Finds his sorrow's bounds are set.
He thinks no evil who means no evil.
He thinks too much; such men are dangerous.
He thought as a sage though he felt as a man.
He thought he thought, and yet he did not
think, / But only echoed still the common talk, / As might an empty room.
He thought the World to him was known, / Whereas he only knew the Town; / In men this blunder still you find, / All think their little set--Mankind.
He travels safe and not unpleasantly who is guarded by poverty and guided by love.
He trudged along, unknowing what he sought, / And whistled as he went, for want of thought.
He wants wit that wants resolved will.
He was a bold man that first ate an oyster.
He was a man, take him for all in all, / I shall not look upon his like again.
He was a scholar, and a ripe and good one; / Exceeding wise, fair spoken, and persuading; / Lofty and sour to them that loved him not; / But to those men that sought him, sweet as summer.
He was exhaled; his great Creator drew / His spirit, as the sun the morning dew.
He was my friend, faithful and just to me.
He was not of an age, but for all Time, / Sweet
Swan of Avon.
He was perfumed like a milliner, / And 'twixt his finger and his thumb he held / A pouncet-box, which ever and anon / He gave his nose, and took 't away again.
He was scant o' news that told that his father was hanged.
He was the Word that spake it; / He took the bread and brake it; / And what that Word did make it, / I do believe and take it.
He wears his faith but as the fashion of his hat.
He wha eats but
the doctor.
He who asks a favour for another has the confidence which a sense of justice inspires; while he who solicits for himself experiences all the embarrassment and shame of one appealing for mercy.
He who avoids the temptation avoids the sin.
He who begins with trusting every one will end with estimating every one a knave.
He who breaks confidence has for ever forfeited it.
He who can at all times sacrifice pleasure to
duty approaches sublimity.
He who can conceal his joys is greater than he who can conceal his griefs.
He who can enjoy the intimacy of the great, and on no occasion disgust them by familiarity or disgrace them by servility, proves that he is as perfect a gentleman by nature as his companions are by rank.
He who cannot bear foes deserves no friend.
He who cannot profit you as a friend may at any time injure you as an enemy.
He who carries his heart on his tongue runs
the risk of expectorating it.
He who ceases to grow greater grows smaller.
He who ceases to pray ceases to prosper.
He who coldly lives to himself and his own will may gratify many a wish, but he who strives to guide others well must be able to dispense with much.
He who combines every defect will be more likely to find favour in the world than the man who is possessed of every virtue.
He who comes up to his own ideal of greatness
must always have had a very low standard of it in his mind.
He who commits injustice is ever made more wretched than he who suffers it.
He who conforms to the rule which the genius of the human understanding whispers secretly in the ear of every new-born being, viz., to test action by thought and thought by action, cannot err; and if he errs, he will soon find himself again in the right way.
He who considers too much will accomplish little.
He who deals with honey will sometimes be licking his fingers.
He who despises mankind will never get the
best out of either others or himself.
He who did well in war just earns the right / To begin doing well in peace.
He who does a good deed is instantly ennobled; he who does a mean deed, is by the action itself contracted.
He who does evil that good may come, pays a toll to the devil to let him into heaven.
He who does me good teaches me to be good.
He who does not advance falls backward.
He who does not expect a million of readers should not write a line.
He who does not help us at the needful moment never helps; he who does not counsel at the needful moment never counsels.
He who does not imagine in stronger and better lineaments, and in stronger and better light than his perishing mortal eye can see, does not imagine at all.
He who does not know foreign languages knows nothing of his own.
He who does not lose his wits over certain
matters has none to lose.
He who does not think too highly of himself is more than he thinks.
He who does nothing for others does nothing for himself.
He who doth not speak an unkind word to his fellow-creatures is master of the whole world to the extremities of the ocean.
He who dwells in temporary semblances and does not penetrate into the eternal substance, will not answer the sphinx-riddle of to-day or of any day.
He who enquires into a matter has often
found more at a glance than he wished to find.
He who entereth uncalled for, unquestioned speaketh much, and regardeth himself with satisfaction, to his prince appeareth one of a weak judgment.
He who esteems trifles for themselves is a trifler; he who esteems them for the conclusions he draws from them or the advantage to which they can be put, is a philosopher.
He who exercises wisdom exercises the knowledge which is about God.
He who fears not death fears not threats.
He who fears nothing is not less powerful than
he whom all fear.
He who feeds the ravens / Will give His children bread.
He who feels he is right is stronger than king's hosts; he who doubts he is not right has no strength whatever.
He who finds a God in the physical world will also find one in the moral, which is History.
He who formeth a connection with an honest man from his love of truth, will not suffer thereby.
He who gives up the smallest part of a secret
has the rest no longer in his power.
He who goes alone may start to-day; but he who travels with another must wait till that other is ready.
He who has a bonnie wife needs mair than twa een.
He who has a thousand friends has not a friend to spare, / And he who has one enemy will meet him everywhere.
"He who has been born has been a first man," has had lying before his young eyes, and as yet unhardened into scientific shapes, a world as plastic, infinite, divine, as lay before the eyes of Adam himself.
He who has been once very foolish will never
be very wise.
He who has done enough for the welfare
of his own time has lived for a
He who has imagination without learning has wings without feet.
He who has less than he desires should know that he has more than he deserves.
He who has lost confidence can lose nothing more.
He who has love in his heart has spurs in his
heels.
He who has made no mistakes in war has never made war.
He who has most of heart knows most of sorrow.
He who has no ear for poetry is a barbarian, be he who he may.
He who has no opinion of his own, but depends upon the opinion and taste of others, is a slave.
He who has no passions has no principle, nor
motive to act.
He who has no vision of Eternity will never get a true hold of Time.
He who has no wish to be happier is the happiest of men.
He who has not been a servant cannot become a praiseworthy master; it is meet that we should plume ourselves rather on acting the part of a servant properly than that of the master, first towards the laws, and next towards our elders.
He who has not known poverty, sorrow, contradiction, and the rest, and learned from them the priceless lessons they have to teach, has missed a good opportunity of schooling.
He who has not the weakness of friendship
has not the strength.
He who has nothing to boast of but his ancestry is like a potato; the only good belonging to him is underground.
He who has published an injurious book sins in his very grave, corrupts others while he is rotting himself.
He who has reason and good sense at his command needs few of the arts of the orator.
He who imitates what is evil always exceeds; he who imitates what is good always falls short.
He who in any way shows us better than we
knew before that a lily of the fields is beautiful, does he not show it us as an effluence of the fountain of all beauty--as the handwriting, made visible there, of the great Maker of the universe?
He who indulges his senses in any excesses renders himself obnoxious to his own reason; and, to gratify the brute in him, displeases the man, and sets his two natures at variance.
He who, in opposition to his own happiness, delighteth in the accumulation of riches, carrieth burdens for others and is the vehicle of trouble.
He who intends to be a great man ought to love neither himself nor his own things, but only what is just, whether it happens to be done by himself or by another.
He who is a fool and knows it is not very far from being a wise man.
He who is conscious of guilt cannot bear the
innocence of others: he tries to reduce other characters to his own level.
He who is deficient in the art of selection may, by showing nothing but the truth, produce all the effect of the grossest falsehood. It perpetually happens that one writer tells less truth than another, merely because he tells more truth.
He who is destitute of principles is governed, theoretically and practically, by whims.
He who is firm in his will moulds the world to himself.
He who is good has no kind of envy.
He who is in disgrace with the sovereign is
disrespected by all.
He who is lord of himself, and exists upon his own resources, is a noble but a rare being.
He who is most slow in making a promise is the most faithful in the performance of it.
He who is moved to tears by every word of a priest is generally a weakling and a rascal when the feeling evaporates.
He who is not possessed of such a book as will dispel many doubts, point out hidden treasures, and is, as it were, a mirror of all things, is even an ignorant man.
He who is of no use to himself is of no use to
any one.
He who is one with himself is everything.
He who is only half instructed speaks much, and is always wrong; he who knows it wholly, is content with acting, and speaks seldom or late.
He who is only just is stern; he who is only wise lives in gloom.
He who is servant to
 
He who is suave with all
gets on with none: he pleases no one who tries to please thousands.
He who is the master of all opinions never can be the bigot of any.
He who is too much afraid of being duped has lost the power of being magnanimous.
He who is weighty is willing to be weighed.
He who is willing to work finds it hard to wait.
He who knows himself well will very soon
learn to know all other men: it is all reflection
He who knows how to sunder jest and earnest is a wise man, and who by cheerful playfulness reinvigorates himself for strenuous diligence.
He who knows not the world, knows not his own place in it.
He who knows right principles is not equal to him who loves them.
He who laughs at crooked men should need walk very straight.
He who laughs can commit no deadly sin.
He who lays out for God lays up for himself.
He who learns and makes no use of his learning is a beast of burden with a load of books.
He who learns the rules of wisdom without conforming to them in his life, is like a man who labours in his fields but does not sow.
He who likes borrowing dislikes paying.
He who lives, and strives, and suffers for others
dear to him, is to be envied; he who lives only for himself is poor.
He who lives to no purpose lives to a bad purpose.
He who lives wisely to himself and his own heart looks at the busy world through the loopholes of retreat, and does not want to mingle in the fray.
He who loses wealth loses much, who loses a friend loses more, who loses his spirits loses all.
He who loves goodness harbours angels, reveres reverence, and lives with God.
He who loves not books before he comes to
thirty years of age will hardly love them enough afterwards to understand them.
He who loves with purity considers not the gift of the lover, but the love of the giver.
He who makes claims
He who makes constant complaint gets little compassion.
He who makes religion his first object makes it his whole object.
He who means to teach others may indeed
often suppress the best of what he knows, but he must not himself be half-instructed.
He who mistrusts humanity is quite as often deceived as he who trusts men.
He who mocks the infant's faith / Shall be mock'd in age and death.
He who never in his life was foolish was never a wise man.
He who obeys is almost always better than he who commands.
He who offers God a second place offers Him
no place.
He who ordained the Sabbath loves the poor.
He who overcomes his egoism rids himself of the most stubborn obstacle that blocks the way to all true greatness and all true happiness.
He who partakes in another's joys is more humane than he who partakes in his griefs.
He who parts with his property before his death may prepare himself for bitter experiences.
He who pleased everybody died before he was born.
He who praises everybody praises nobody.
He who promises runs in debt.
He who reaches the goal receives the crown, and often he who deserves it goes without it.
He who receives a sacrament does not perform a good work; he receives a benefit.
He who reforms himself has done more towards reforming the public than a crowd of noisy impotent patriots.
He who says, "I sought, yet I found not,"
be sure he lies; he who says, "I sought not and found," be sure he deceives; he who says, "I sought and found," him believe--he speaks true.
He who says what he likes must hear what he does not like.
He who scrubs every pig he sees will not long be clean himself.
He who seeks only for applause from without has all his happiness in another's keeping.
He who seeks the truth should be of no country.
He who seeth not the filthiness of evil wanteth
a great foil to perceive the beauty of virtue.
He who sends mouths will send meat.
He who serves God serves a good Master.
He who serves the public serves a fickle master.
He who serves under reason anticipates necessity.
He who speaks sows; he who keeps silence
reaps.
He who spends himself for all that is noble, and gains by nothing but what is just, will hardly be notably wealthy or distressfully poor.
He who stays in the valley will never cross the mountain.
He who steals an egg would steal an ox.
He who strikes terror into others is himself in continual fear.
He who tastes every man's broth often burns
his mouth.
He who tells a lie is not sensible how great a task he undertakes, for he must be forced to invent twenty more to maintain that one.
He who tells the failings of others to you will be ready to tell your failings to others.
He who the sword of Heaven will bear / Should be as holy as severe.
He who thinks for himself, and imitates rarely, is a free man.
He who thinks his place below him will certainly
be below his place.
He who thinks to save anything by his religion besides his soul will be a loser in the end.
He who thinks too much will accomplish little.
He who traces nothing of God in his own soul will never find God in the world of matter--mere circlings of force there of iron regulation, of universal death and merciless indifferency.
He who travels to be amused, or to get somewhat which he does not carry, travels away from himself, and grows old even in youth among old things.
He who trusts a secret to his servant makes
his own man his master.
He who waits for dead men's shoes may go barefoot.
He who wants any help or prop, in addition to the internal evidences of its truth for his belief, never was and never will be a Christian.
He who wants everything must know many things, do many things to procure even a few; different from him whose indispensable knowledge is this only, that a finger will pull the bell!
He who will be great must collect himself; only in restriction does the master show himself.
He who will deaden one half of his nature to
invigorate the other half will become at best a distorted prodigy.
He who will do faithfully needs to believe firmly.
He who will eat the nut must crack it.
He who will not be ruled by the rudder must be ruled by the rock.
He who will sell his fame will also sell the public interest.
He who will work aright must not trouble
himself about what is ill done, but only do well himself.
He who wills all, wills in effect nothing, and brings it to nothing.
He who wishes to secure the good of others has already secured his own.
He who works with symbols merely is a pedant, a hypocrite, and a bungler.
He who would be everywhere will be nowhere.
He who would bring home the wealth of the
Indies must carry the wealth of the Indies with him.
He who would climb the ladder must begin at the bottom.
He who would gather honey must brave the sting of the bees.
He who would gather roses must not fear thorns.
He who would not be frustrate of his hope to write well hereafter in laudable things ought himself to be a true poem.
He who would pry behind the scenes oft sees
a counterfeit.
He who would rule must hear and be deaf, must see and be blind.
He who would write heroic poems must make his whole life a heroic poem.
He whom God has gifted with a love of retirement possesses, as it were, an extra sense.
He whom God steers sails safely.
He whom the inevitable cannot overcome is
unconquerable.
He whom toil has braced or manly play, / As light as air each limb, each thought as clear as day.
He whose actions sink him even beneath the vulgar has no right to those distinctions which should be the reward only of merit.
He whose days are passed away without giving or enjoying, puffing like the bellows of a blacksmith, liveth but by breathing.
He whose goodness is part of himself is what is called a real man.
He whose sympathy goes lowest is the man
from whom kings have the most to fear.
He whose understanding can discern what is, and judge what should or should not be applied to prevent misfortune, never sinketh under difficulties.
He whose word and deed you cannot predict, who answers you without any supplication in his eye, who draws his determination from within, and draws it instantly,--that man rules.
He whose work is on the highway will have many advisers.
He will never have true friends who is afraid of making enemies.
He will never set the Thames on fire.
He would fain fly, but wants wings.
He works hard who has nothing to do.
He wrought all kind of service with a noble ease / That graced the lowliest act in doing it.
He's a blockhead who wants a proof of what he can't perceive, / And he's a fool who tries to make such a blockhead believe.
He's a man who dares to be / Firm for truth
when others flee.
He's a silly body that's never missed.
He's a wise man wha can take care o' himsel'.
He's armed without that's innocent within.
He's idle that may be better employed.
He's looking for the blade o' corn in the stack
o' chaff.
He's most truly valiant / That can wisely suffer the worst that man / Can breathe; and make his wrongs his outsides: / To wear them like his raiment, carelessly, / And ne'er prefer his injuries to his heart, / To bring it into danger.
He's only great who can himself command.
He's well worth
He's wise that's wise in time.
Headstrong liberty is lashed with woe.
Health and cheerfulness mutually beget each other.
Health consists with temperance alone.
Health is better than wealth.
Health is the condition of wisdom, and the sign is cheerfulness--an open and noble temper.
Health is the first of all liberties, and happiness
gives us the energy which is the basis of health.
Health lies in labour, and there is no royal road to it but through toil.
Health, longevity, beauty are other names for personal purity, and temperance is the regimen for all.
Healthy action is always a balance of forces; and all extremes are dangerous; the excess of a good thing being often more dangerous in its social consequences than the excess of what is radically bad.
Hear God, and God will hear you.
Hear it not, Duncan; for it is a knell / That
summons thee to heaven or to hell.
Hear much and speak little; for the tongue is the instrument of the greatest good and the greatest evil that is done in this world.
Hear one side, and you will be in the dark; hear both, and all will be clear.
Hear ye not the hum / Of mighty workings?
Hearsay is half lies.
Hearts are flowers; they remain open to the
softly falling dew, but shut up in the violent downpour of rain.
Hearts are stronger than swords.
Hearts grow warmer the farther you go / Up to the North with its hills and snow.
Hearts may agree though heads differ.
Hearts philanthropic at times have the trick / Of the old hearts of stone.
Heart's-ease is a flower which blooms from
the grave of desire.
Heat and darkness, and what these two may breed.
Heat cannot be separated from fire, or beauty from the eternal.
Heat not a furnace for your foe so hot / That it doth singe yourself.
Heaven and God are best discerned through tears; scarcely, perhaps, are discerned at all without them.
Heaven and yourself / Had part in this fair
maid
Heaven bestows / At home all riches that wise Nature needs.
Heaven doth with us as we with torches do, / Not light them for themselves; for if our virtues / Did not go forth of us, 'twere all alike / As if we had them not.
Heaven finds means to kill your joys with love.
Heaven from all creatures hides the book of fate, / All but the page prescribed--their present state.
Heaven has no rage like love to hatred turned, / Nor hell a fury like a woman scorned.
Heaven hath many tongues to talk of it, more eyes to behold it, but few hearts that rightly affect it.
Heaven is above all yet; there sits a Judge /
That no king can corrupt.
Heaven is as near by sea as by land.
Heaven is in thy faith; happiness in thy heart.
Heaven is never deaf but when man's heart is dumb.
Heaven is not always angry when He strikes, / But most chastises those whom most He likes.
Heaven lies about us in our infancy.
Heaven never helps the man that will not act.
Heaven often regulates effects by their causes, and pays the wicked what they have deserved.
Heaven trims our lamps while we sleep.
Heaven, which really in one sense is merciful to sinners, is in no sense merciful to fools, but even lays pitfalls for them and inevitable snares.
Heaven's above all; and there be souls that
must be saved, and there be souls that must not be saved.
Heavens! can you then thus waste, in shameful wise, / Your few important days of trial here? / Heirs of eternity! yborn to rise / Through endless states of being, still more near / To bliss approaching, and perfection clear.
Heaven's eternal wisdom hath decreed that man of man should ever stand in need.
Heaven's fire confounds when fann'd with folly's breath.
Heaven's gates are not so highly arched as princes' palaces; they that enter there must go upon their knees.
Heavens! if privileged from trial, / How cheap
a thing were virtue!
Heaven's Sovereign saves all beings but Himself that hideous sight--a naked human heart.
Heav'n finds an ear when sinners find a tongue.
Heav'n is for thee too high; be lowly wise.
Heav'n is not always got by running.
Heav'n is not day'd. Repentance is not dated.
Hebt mich das Glück, so bin ich froh, / Und sing in dulci jubilo; / Senkt sich das Rad und quetscht mich nieder, / So denk' ich: nun, es hebt sich wieder
Hectora quis nosset, si felix Troja fuisset? / Publica virtuti per mala facta via est
Hectors Liebe stirbt im Lethe nicht
Hedges between keep friendship green.
Hedgerows and Hercules-pillars, however perfect,
are to be reprobated as soon as they diminish the free world of a future man.
Heilig sei dir der Tag; doch schätze das Leben nicht höher / Als ein anderes Gut, und alle Güter sind trüglich
Hei mihi! difficile est imitari gaudia falsa! / Difficile est tristi fingere mente jocum
Hei mihi! qualis erat! quantum mutatus ab illo / Hectore, qui redit, exuvias indutus Achilli
Heitern Sinn und reine Zwecke / Nun, man kommt wohl eine Strecke
"Hélas! que j'en ai vu mourir de jeunes filles"
Hell and destruction are never full, so the eyes of men are never satisfied.
Hell is on both sides of the tomb, and a devil may be respectable and wear good clothes.
Hell is paved with good intentions.
Hell is paved with the skulls of priests.
Hell lies near, / Around us, as does heaven,
and in the world, / Which is our Hades, still the chequered souls, / Compact of good and ill--not all accurst, / Nor altogether blest--a few brief years / Travel the little journey of their lives, / They know not to what end.
Helluo librorum
Help others and seek to avenge no injury.
Help which is long on the road is no help.
Help yourself and your friends will help you.
Helpless mortal! Thine arm can destroy
thousands at once, but cannot enclose even two of thy fellow-creatures at once in the embrace of love and sympathy.
Hence, babbling dreams; you threaten here in vain; / Conscience, avaunt, Richard's himself again.
Her angel's face, / As the great eye of heaven, shined bright, / And made a sunshine in the shady place.
Her eyes are homes of silent prayer.
Her feet, beneath her petticoat, / Like little mice stole in and out, / As if they fear'd the light; / But oh! she dances such a way, / No sun upon an Easter-day / Is half so fine a sight.
Her own person, / It beggar'd all description.
Her sun is gone down while it was yet day.
Her voice was ever soft, / Gentle, and low--an excellent thing in woman.
Hercules himself must yield to odds; / And
many strokes, though with a little axe, / Hew down and fell the hardest-timber'd oak.
Here eyes do regard you / In Eternity's stillness; / Here is all fulness, / Ye brave, to reward you. / Work and despair not.
Here have we no continuing city, but we seek one to come.
Here have we war for war, and blood for blood, / Controlment for controlment.
Here I and sorrows sit; / Here is my throne; bid kings come bow to it.
Here I lay, and thus I bore my point.
Here in the body pent, / Absent from Him I roam, / Yet nightly pitch my moving tent / A day's march nearer home.
Here lies Johnny Pigeon! / What was his religion, / Wha e'er desires to ken / To some ither warl' / Maun follow the carl, / For here Johnny Pigeon had nane.
Here lies one whose name was writ in water.
Here lies our sovereign lord the king, / Whose word no man relies on; / He never says a foolish thing, / Nor ever does a wise one.
Here lieth one, believe it if you can, / Who,
though an attorney, was an honest man!
Here, on earth we are as soldiers fighting in a foreign land, that understand not the plan of the campaign, and have no need to understand it, seeing well what is at our hand to be done.
Here or nowhere is America.
Here our souls / Though amply blest, / Can never find, although they seek, / A perfect rest.
Here was a Caesar! when comes such another?
Here's a sigh for those who love me, / And a
smile for those who hate, / And whatever sky's above me, / Here's a heart for every fate.
Hereditary bondsmen! know ye not, / Who would be free, themselves must strike the blow?
Hereditary honours are a noble and a splendid treasure to descendants.
Heroes are much the same, the point's agreed, / From Macedonia's madman to the Swede.
Heroism is an obedience to a secret impulse of an individual's character.
Heroism is the brilliant triumph of the soul
over fear; fear of poverty, of suffering, of calumny, of sickness, of isolation and death.... It is the dazzling and glorious concentration of courage.
Heroism is the self-devotion of genius manifesting itself in action.
Heroism, the Divine relation which, in all times, unites a great man to other men.
Hero-worship exists, has existed, and will for ever exist, universally among mankind.
Herradura que chacotea clavo le falta
Herrenlos ist auch der Freiste nicht
Herrschaft gewinn ich, Eigentum; / Die That ist alles, nichts der Ruhm

Heu nihil invitis fas quenquam fidere divis
Heu pietas! Heu prisca fides

vultu!

Heu! quam miserum est ab eo lædi, de quo non ausis queri
Heu quantum fati parva tabella vehit!
Heu! totum triduum!

Heureux commencement est la moitié de l'œuvre
