Hic est aut nusquam quod quærimus
Hic est mucro defensionis tuæ
Hic et nunc
Hic et ubique
Hic finis fandi
Hic funis nihil attraxit
Hic gelidi fontes, hic mollia prata, Lycori, / Hic nemus, hic toto tecum consumerer ævo
Hic hæret aqua!
Hic jacet
Hic locus est partes ubi se via findit in ambas
Hic murus aheneus esto, / Nil conscire sibi, nulla pallescere culpa
Hic niger est; hunc tu, Romane, caveto
Hic nigræ succus loliginis, hæc est / Ærugo
mera
Hic patet ingeniis campus, certusque merenti / Stat favor: ornatur propriis industria donis
Hic Rhodos, hic salta
Hic rogo, non furor est ne moriare mori?
Hic situs est Phaëton currus auriga paterni; / Quem si non tenuit, magnis tamen excidit ausis
Hic transitus efficit magnum vitæ compendium
Hic ubi nunc urbs est, tum locus urbis erat
Hic ver assiduum, atque alienis mensibus æstas
Hic victor cæstus artemque repono
Hic vigilans somniat
Hic vivimus ambitiosa / Paupertate omnes
Hid jewels are but lost.
Hier bin ich Mensch, hier darf ich's sein
Hier ist die Zeit durch Thaten zu beweisen, / Dass Manneswürde nicht der Götterhöhe weicht
Hier ist keine Heimat--Jeder treibt / Sich an dem andern rasch und fremd vorüber, / Und fragt nicht nach seinem Schmerz
Hier sitz' ich auf Rasen mit Veilchen bekränzt
Hier stehe ich! Ich kann nicht anders. Gott helfe mir! Amen
Hier steht einer, der wird mich rächen
High air-castles are cunningly built of words, the words well-bedded in good logic mortar; wherein, however, no knowledge will come to lodge.
High birth is an accident, not a virtue.
High erected thoughts seated in the heart of
courtesy.
High houses are usually empty in the upper storey.
High is the head of the stag on the mountain crag.
High station has to be resigned in order to be appreciated.
Hilarisque tamen cum pondere virtus
Hilft Gott uns nicht, kein Kaiser kann uns
helfen
Hills peep o'er hills; and alps on alps arise.
Hilo y aguja, media vestidura
Him only pleasure leads and peace attends, / Him, only him, the shield of Jove defends, / Whose means are fair and spotless as his ends.
Him who makes chaff of himself the cows will eat.
Hin ist die Zeit, da Bertha spann
Hin ist hin! Verloren ist verloren
Hinc illæ lachrymæ
Hinc lucem et pocula sacra
Hinc omne principium, huc refer exitum
Hinc subitæ mortes atque intestata senectus
Hinc totam infelix vulgatur fama per urbem
Hinc usura vorax, avidumque in tempore fænus, / Et concussa fides, et multis utile bellum
Hinc venti dociles resono se carcere solvunt, / Et cantum accepta pro libertate rependunt
His bark is waur nor
His Christianity was muscular.
His failings lean'd to virtue's side.
His kissing is as full of sanctity as the touch of holy bread.
His imagination resembled the wings of an ostrich. It enabled him to run, though not to soar.
His lachrymis vitam damus, et miserescimus ultro
His legibus solutis respublica stare non potest
His life was gentle, and the elements / So
mix'd in him, that Nature might stand up, / And say to all the world: This was a man!
His nature is too noble for the world; / He would not flatter Neptune for his trident, / or Jove for his power to thunder.
His nunc præmium est, qui recta prava faciunt
His opinion who does not see spiritual agency in history is not worth any man's reading.
His own character is the arbiter of every one's fortune.
His rash, fierce blaze of riot cannot last, / For
violent fires soon outburn themselves.
His saltem accumulem donis, et fungar inani munere
His speech was like a tangled chain; / Nothing impaired, but all disordered.
His thoughts look through his words.
His time is for ever, everywhere his place.
His tongue could make the worse appear the
better reason.
His tongue / Dropp'd manna, and could make the worse appear / The better reason, to perplex and dash / Maturest counsels.
His very foot has music in 't, / As he comes up the stair.
His wit invites you by his looks to come, / But when you knock, it never is at home.
His words are bonds, his oaths are oracles.
Historia quo quomodo scripta delectat
Histories are as perfect as the historian is wise, and is gifted with an eye and a soul.
Histories make men wise; poets, witty; the mathematics, subtle; natural philosophy, deep; morals, grave; logic and rhetoric, able to contend.
History and experience prove that the most passionate characters are the most fanatically rigid in their feelings of duty, when their passion has been trained to act in that direction.
History, as it lies at the root of all science, is also the first distinct product of man's spiritual nature, his earliest expression of what may be called thought.
History ensures for youth the understanding
of the ancients.
History has only to do with what is true, and what is only probable should be relegated to the imaginary domain of romance and poetical fiction.
History is a cyclic poem written by Time upon the memories of man.
History is always written
History is an impertinence and an injury, if it be anything more than a cheerful apologue or parable of my being and becoming.
History is an imprisoned epic, nay, an imprisoned
psalm and prophecy.
History is but a fable agreed on.
History is but the unrolled scroll of prophecy.
History is indeed little more than the register of the crimes, follies, and misfortunes of mankind.
History is like sacred writing, for truth is essential to it.
History is made up of the bad actions of
extraordinary men. All the most noted destroyers and deceivers of our species, all the founders of arbitrary governments and false religions, have been extraordinary men, and nine-tenths of the calamities which have befallen the human race had no other origin than the union of high intelligence with low desires.
History is only a confused heap of facts.
History is philosophy teaching by examples.
History is properly nothing but a satire on mankind.
History is the true poetry.
History shows that the majority of the men
who have done anything great have passed their youth in seclusion.
History teems with instances of truth put down by persecution; if not suppressed for ever, it may be thrown back for centuries.
Hitch your waggon to a star.
Hitherto all miracles have been wrought by thought, and henceforth innumerable will be wrought; whereof we, even in these days, witness some.
Hitherto doth love on fortune tend; / For who not needs, shall never lack a friend; / And who in want a hollow friend doth try, / Directly seasons him his enemy.
Hitherto shalt thou come, but no further; and
here shall thy proud waves be stayed.
Hizonos Dios, y maravillámonos nos
Hobbes clearly proves that every creature / Lives in a state of war by nature.
"Hoc age" is the great rule, whether you are serious or merry; whether ... learning science or duty from a folio, or floating on the Thames. Intentions must be gathered from acts.
Hoc age
Hoc erat in more majorum
Hoc erat in votis; modus agri non ita magnus; / Hortus ubi, et tecto vicinus juris aquæ fons, / Et paulum silvæ super his foret
Hoc est quod palles? cur quis non prandeat, hoc est?
Hoc est / Vivere bis, vita posse priore frui
Hoc fonte derivata clades, / In patriam, populumque fluxit
Hoc genus omne
Hoc Herculi Iovis satu edito' potuit fortasse contingere, nobis non item
Hoc loco
Hoc maxime officii est, ut quisquis maxime opus indigeat, ita ei potissimum opitulari
Hoc opus, hic labor est
Hoc patrium est, potius consuefacere filium /
Sua sponte recte facere, quam alieno metu
Hoc pretium ob stultitiam fero
Hoc scito, nimio celerius / Venire quod molestum est, quam id quod cupide petas
Hoc signo vinces
Hoc virtutis opus
Hoc volo, hoc jubeo; sit pro ratione voluntas
Hodie mihi, cras tibi
Hodie nihil, cras credo
Hodie vivendum amissa præteritorum cura
Hoi polloi
Hoist up the sail while gale doth last--/ Tide
and wind wait no man's pleasure! / Seek not time when time is past--/ Sober speed is wisdom's leisure!
Hold all the skirts of thy mantle extended when heaven is raining gold.
Hold the living dear and honour the dead.
Hold their farthing candle to the sun.
Hold thou the good; define it well.
Hold up thy head; the taper lifted high /
Will brook the wind when lower tapers die.
Holy fields, / Over whose acres walked those blessed feet / Which fourteen hundred years ago were nail'd, / For our advantage, on the bitter cross.
Holy men at their death have good inspirations.
Hombre de barba
Hombre pobre todo es trazas
Home, in one form or another, is the great
object of life.
Home is heaven for beginners.
Home is home, be it never so homely.
Home is the place of Peace; the shelter, not only from all injury, but from all terror, doubt, and division.
Home should be an oratorio of the memory, singing to all our after life melodies and harmonies of old-remembered joy.
Home, the nursery of the infinite.
Home-keeping youth have ever homely wits.
Homer's Epos has not ceased to be true; yet is no longer our Epos, but shines in the distance, if clearer and clearer, yet also smaller and smaller, like a receding star. It needs a scientific telescope, it needs to be reinterpreted and artificially brought near us, before we can so much as know that 'twas a sun.... For all things, even celestial luminaries, much more atmospheric meteors, have their rise, their culmination, their decline.
Homine imperito nunquam quidquam injustius / Qui, nisi quod ipse fecit, nihil rectum putat
Hominem non odi sed ejus vitia
Hominem pagina nostra sapit
Hominem quæro
Homines ad deos nulla re propius accedunt quam salutem hominibus dando
Homines amplius oculis quam auribus credunt: longum iter est per præcepta, breve et efficax per exempla
Homines nihil agendo discunt male agere
Homines plus in alieno negotio videre, quam
in suo
Homines proniores sunt ad voluptatem, quam ad virtutem
Homines, quo plura habent, eo cupiunt ampliora
Homini necesse est mori
Homini ne fidas nisi cum quo modium satis absumpseres
Hominibus plenum, amicis vacuum
Hominis est errare, insipientis perseverare
Hominum sententia fallax
Homme assailli à demi vaincu
Homme chiche jamais riche
Homme d'affaires
Homme d'esprit
Homme d'état
Homme d'honneur
Homme instruit
Homo ad res perspicacior Lynceo vel Argo, et oculeus totus
Homo antiqua virtute ac fide
Homo constat ex duabus partibus, corpore et anima, quorum una est corporea, altera ab omni materiæ concretione sejuncta
Homo doctus in se semper divitias habet
Homo extra est corpus suum cum irascitur
Homo fervidus et diligens ad omnia paratur
Homo homini aut deus aut lupus
Homo is a common name to all men.
Homo multarum literarum
Homo multi consilii et optimi
Homo nullius coloris
Homo qui erranti comiter monstrat viam, / Quasi lumen de suo lumine accendit, facit; / Nihilominus ipsi luceat, cum illi accenderit
Homo solus aut deus aut demon
Homo sum, et nihil humani a me alienum puto
Homo toties moritur, quoties amittit suos
Homo trium literarum
Homo unius libri
Homunculi quanti sunt, cum recogito
Honest labour bears a lovely face.
Honest men marry soon, wise men never.
Honesta mors turpi vita potior
Honesta paupertas prior quam opes malæ
Honesta quædam scelera successus facit
Honesta quam splendida
Honestum non est semper quod licet
Honestum quod vere dicimus, etiamsi a nullo laudatur, laudabile est sua natura
Honesty is like an icicle; if it once melts, that is the last of it.
Honesty is the best policy.
Honesty is the poor man's pork and the rich man's pudding.
Honesty may be dear bought, but can ne'er be
an ill pennyworth.
Honi soit qui mal y pense
Honnêtes gens
Honneur et patrie
Honor Deo
Honor est præmium virtutis
Honor fidelitatis præmium
Honor sequitur fugientem
Honores mutant mores
Honos alit artes, omnesque incenduntur ad studia gloria
Honour a physician with the honour due unto
him for the uses which ye may have of him, for the Lord hath created him.
Honour all men. Love the brotherhood. Fear God. Honour the king.
Honour and ease are seldom bedfellows.
Honour hath no skill in surgery.... Honour is a mere scutcheon.
Honour is nobler than gold.
Honour is not a virtue in itself; it is the mail
behind which the virtues fight more securely.
Honour is unstable, and seldom the same; for she feeds upon opinion, and is as fickle as her food.
Honour is venerable to us because it is no ephemeris.
Honour to whom honour is due.
Honour travels in a strait so narrow, / Where one but goes abreast.
Honour won't patch.
Honourable
and implies much more than most people attach to it.
Honours, like impressions upon coin, may give an ideal and local value to a bit of base metal; but gold and silver will pass all the world over, without any other recommendation than their own weight.
Honours to one in my situation are something like ruffles to a man that wants a shirt.
Honour's the moral conscience of the great.
Honteux comme un renard qu'une poule aurait pris
Hope deferred maketh the heart sick.
Hope is a curtail dog in some affairs.
Hope is a good anchor, but it needs something to grip.
Hope is a lover's staff; walk hence with that, / And manage it against despairing thoughts.
Hope is a pleasant acquaintance but an unsafe friend. He'll do on a pinch for your travelling companion, but he's not the man for your banker.
Hope is a waking man's dream.
Hope is itself a species of happiness, and perhaps the chief happiness which this world affords; but, like all other pleasures, its excesses must be expiated by pain; and expectations improperly indulged must end in disappointment.
Hope is not the man for your banker, though he may do for your travelling companion.
Hope is the best part of our riches.
Hope is the only good which is common to all men.
Hope is the ruddy morning ray of joy, recollection
is its golden tinge; but the latter is wont to sink amid the dews and dusky shades of twilight, and the bright blue day which the former promises breaks indeed, but in another world and with another sun.
Hope never comes that comes to all.
Hope never spread her golden wings but in unfathomable seas.
Hope not wholly to reason away your troubles; but do not feed them with attention, and they will die imperceptibly away.
Hope, of all ills that men endure, / The only cheap and universal cure.
Hope springs eternal in the human breast; /
Man never is, but always to be, blest.
Hope springs exulting on triumphant wing.
Hope thou not much, and fear thou not at all.
Hope to joy is little less in joy / Than hope enjoyed.
Hoping and waiting is not my way of doing things.
Hora e sempre
Horæ cedunt, et dies, et menses, et anni, nec præteritum tempus unquam revertitur
Horæ / Momento cita mors venit, aut victoria læta
Horas non numero nisi serenas
Horrea formicæ tendunt ad inania nunquam; / Nullus ad amissas ibit amicus opes
Horresco referens
Horribile dictu
Horror ubique animos, simul ipsa silentia terrent
Horror vacui
Hors de combat
Hors de propos
Hortus siccus
Hos successus alit; possunt quia posse videntur
Hospice d'accouchement
Hospice d'allaitement
Hospitality must be for service, not for show,
or it pulls down the host.
Hostis est uxor invita quæ ad virum nuptum datur
Hostis honori invidia
Hôtel de ville
Hôtel Dieu
Household words.
Housekeeping without a wife is a lantern without a light.
Houses are built to live in, and not to look on.
How are riches the means of happiness? In acquiring they create trouble, in their loss they occasion sorrow, and they are the cause of endless divisions amongst kindred!
How beautiful is death, seeing that we die in a world of life and of creation without end!
How beautiful is youth! how bright it gleams, /
With its allusions, aspirations, dreams! / Book of beginnings, story without end, / Each maid a heroine, and each man a friend.
How beautiful to die of a broken heart on paper! Quite another thing in practice! Every window of your feeling, even of your intellect, as it were begrimed, so that no pure ray can enter; a whole drug-shop in your inwards; the foredone soul drowning slowly in a quagmire of disgust.
How bitter a thing it is to look into happiness through another man's eyes!
How blessed might poor mortals be in the straitest circumstances, if only their wisdom and fidelity to Heaven and one another were adequately great.
How blessings brighten as they take their flight!
How blest the humble cotter's fate! / He woos his simple dearie; / The silly bogles, wealth, and state, / Can never make them eerie.
How can a man be concealed? How can a man be concealed?
How can he be godly who is not cleanly?
How can man love but what he yearns to help?
How can we expect a harvest of thought
who have not had a seed-time of character?
How can we learn to know ourselves? Never by reflection, but only through action. Essay to do thy duty, and thou knowest at once what is in thee.
How charming is divine philosophy!
How creatures of the human kind shut their eyes to the plainest facts, and by the mere inertia of oblivion and stupidity live at ease in the midst of wonders and terrors.
How difficult it is to get men to believe that any other man can or does act from disinterestedness.
How dire is love when one is so tortured; and
yet lovers cannot exist without torturing themselves.
How doth the little busy bee / Improve each shining hour, / And gather honey all the day / From every opening flower.
How dull it is to pause, to make an end, / To rust unburnish'd, not to shine in use, / As though to breathe were life.
How enormous appear the crimes we have not committed!
How far that little candle throws his beams! / So shines a good deed in a naughty world.
How fast has brother followed / From sunshine
to the sunless land.
How few think justly of the thinking few; / How many never think, who think they do!
How foolish and absurd, nay, how hurtful and destructive a vice is ambition, which, by undue pursuit of honour, robs us of true honour!
How forcible are right words!
How fortunate beyond all others is the man who, in order to adjust himself to fate, is not required to cast away his whole preceding life!
How full of briers is this working-day world!
How glorious a character appears when it is penetrated with mind and soul.
How good is man's life, the mere living! how fit to employ / All the heart, and the soul, and the senses for ever in joy!
How happy could I be with either, / Were t'other dear charmer away!
How happy is he born or taught / That serveth not another's will; / Whose armour is his honest thought, / And simple truth his utmost skill.
How happy is the blameless vestal's lot! /
The world forgetting, by the world forgot.
How happy is the prince who has counsellors near him who can guard him against the effects of his own angry passions; their names shall be read in golden letters when the history of his reign is perused.
How happy should we be ... / If we from self could rest, / And feel at heart that One above, / In perfect wisdom, perfect love, / Is working for the best!
How hard it is
whose ear is quick for celestial messages, to "take no counsel with flesh and blood," and instead of living and writing for the day that passes over them, live and write for the eternity that rests and abides over them!
How hardly man the lesson learns, / To smile, and bless the hand that spurns: / To see the blow, to feel the pain, / And render only love again!
How hardly shall they who have riches enter
into the kingdom of God!
How ill white hairs become a fool and a jester.
How indestructibly the good grows, and propagates itself, even among the weedy entanglements of evil!
How is each of us so lonely in the wide bosom of the All?
How is it possible to expect that mankind will take advice, when they will not so much as take warning.
How little do the wantonly or idly officious
think what mischief they do by their malicious insinuations, indirect impertinence, or thoughtless babblings!
How little is the promise of the child fulfilled in the man.
How long halt ye between two opinions?
How long I have lived, how much lived in vain! / How little of life's scanty span may remain! / What aspects old Time in his progress has worn! / What ties cruel fate in my bosom has torn! / How foolish, or worse, till our summit is gain'd! / And downward, how weaken'd, how darken'd, how pain'd!
How many ages hence / Shall this our lofty scene be acted over / In states unborn and accents yet unknown!
How many causes that can plead for themselves
in the courts of Westminster, and yet in the general court of the universe and free soul of man, have no word to utter!
How many cowards, whose hearts are all as false / As stairs of sand, wear yet upon their chins / The beards of Hercules and frowning Mars! / Who, inward searched, have livers white as milk.
How many honest words have suffered corruption since Chaucer's days!
How many illustrious and noble heroes have lived too long by a day!
How many men live on the reputation of the reputation they might have made!
How many people make themselves abstract
to appear profound! The greatest part of abstract terms are shadows that hide a vacuum.
How many things by season season'd are / To their right praise and true perfection!
How many things, just and unjust, have no higher sanction than custom!
How much a dunce that has been sent to roam / Excels a dunce that has been kept at home!
How much better is it to get wisdom than gold! and to get understanding rather to be chosen than silver!
How much better it is to weep at joy than to
joy at weeping!
How much easier it is to be generous than just!
How much lies in laughter, the cipher-key wherewith we decipher the whole man.
How much the wife is dearer than the bride!
How narrow our souls become when absorbed in any present good or ill! It is only the thought of the future that makes them great.
How noble is heroic insight without words in
comparison to the adroitest flow of words without heroic insight!
How noiseless is thought! No rolling of drums, no tramp of squadrons, or immeasurable tumult of baggage-waggons, attends its movements; in what obscure and sequestered places may the head be meditating which is one day to be crowned with more than imperial authority; for kings and emperors will be among its ministering servants; it will rule not over, but in all heads, and bend the world to its will.
How oft do they their silver bowers leave / To come to succour us that succour want!
How one is vexed with little things in this life! The great evils one triumphs over bravely, but the little eat away one's heart.
How paint to the sensual eye what passes in the holy-of-holies of man's soul; in what words, known to these profane times, speak even afar-off of the unspeakable?
How poor are they that have not patience! /
What wound did ever heal but by degrees?
How poor, how rich, how abject, how august, / How complicate, how wonderful is man!
How prone to doubt, how cautious are the wise!
How quick to know, but how slow to put in practice, is the human creature!
How quickly Nature falls into revolt / When gold becomes her object!
How rarely reason guides the stubborn
choice, / Rules the bold hand or prompts the suppliant voice.
How ready some people are to admire in a great man the exception rather than the rule of his conduct! Such perverse worship is like the idolatry of barbarous nations, who can see the noonday splendour of the sun without emotion, but who, when he is in eclipse, come forward with hymns and cymbals to adore him.
How rich a man is, all desire to know, / But none enquire if good he be or no.
How sad a path it is to climb and descend another's stairs!
How science dwindles, and how volumes swell, / How commentators each dark passage shun, / And hold their farthing candle to the sun!
How shall a man escape from his ancestors, or
draw off from his veins the black drop which he drew from his father's or his mother's life?
How shall he give kindling in whose inward man there is no live coal, but all is burnt out to a dead grammatical cinder?
How shall we know whether you are in earnest, if the deed does not accompany the word?
How sharper than a serpent's tooth it is / To have a thankless child!
How small a part of time they share / That are so wondrous sweet and fair!
How small, of all that human hearts endure, /
That part which laws or kings can cause or cure! / Still to ourselves, in every place consigned, / Our own felicity we make or find.
How should he be easy who makes other men's cares his own?
How should thy virtue be above the shocks and shakings of temptation, when even the angels kept not their first estate, and man in Paradise so soon fell from innocence?
How silver-sweet sound lovers' tongues by night, / Like softest music to attending ears!
How soon "not now" becomes "never!"
How sour sweet music is, when time is broke
and no proportion kept! So is it in the music of men's lives.
How still the evening is, / As hushed on purpose to grace harmony!
How sweet it is to hear one's own convictions from a stranger's mouth!
How sweet the moonlight sleeps upon this bank! / Here will we sit and let the sounds of music / Creep in our ears: soft stillness and the night / Become the touches of sweet harmony.
How the sight of means to do ill deeds / Make deeds ill done!
How the world wags!
How they gleam like spirits through the shadows of innumerable eyes from their thrones in the boundless depths of heaven!
How use doth breed habit in a man!
How vainly seek / The selfish for that happiness denied / To aught but virtue!
How we clutch at shadows
as if they were substances, and sleep deepest while fancying ourselves most awake!
How weary, stale, flat, and unprofitable /
Seem to me all the uses of this world.
How well he's read, to reason against reading!
How were friendship possible? In mutual devotedness to the good and true, otherwise impossible; except as armed neutrality or hollow commercial league.
How wonderful is Death, / Death and his brother Sleep! / One, pale as yonder waning moon, / With lips of lurid blue; / The other, rosy as the morn, / When, throned on ocean's wave, / It blushes o'er the world: / Yet both so passing wonderful.
How wounding a spectacle is it to see those who were by Christ designed for fishers of men, picking up shells on the shore, and unmanly wrangling about them too!
How wretched is the man that hangs on by the favours of the great!
Howe'er it be, it seems to me / 'Tis only noble
to be good. / Kind hearts are more than coronets, / And simple faith than Norman blood.
However, an old song, though to a proverb an instance of insignificance, is generally the only coin a poet has to pay with.
However brilliant an action, it should not be esteemed great unless the result of a great motive.
However far a man goes, he must start from his own door.
However varied the forms of destiny, the same element are always present.
Howsoever thou actest, let heaven be moved
with thy purpose; let the aim of thy deeds traverse the axis of the earth.
Huc propius me, / Dum doceo insanire omnes, vos ordine adite
Huic maxime putamus malo fuisse nimiam opinionem ingenii atque virtutis
Huic versatile ingenium sic pariter ad omnia fuit, ut natum ad id unum diceres, quodcunque ageret
Human action is a seed of circumstances
scattered in the dark land of the future and hopefully left to the powers that rule human destiny.
Human beliefs, like all other natural growths,
elude the barriers of system.
Human brutes, like other beasts, find snares and poison in the provisions of life, and are allured by their appetites to their destruction.
Human courage should rise to the height of human calamity.
Human creatures will not go quite accurately together, any more than clocks will.
Human felicity is lodged in the soul, not in the flesh.
Human intellect, if you consider it well, is the
exact summary of human worth.
Human judgment is finite, and it ought always to be charitable.
Human knowledge is the parent of doubt.
Human life is a constant want, and ought to be a constant prayer.
Human life is everywhere a state in which much is to be endured and little to be enjoyed.
Human life is more governed by fortune than
by reason.
 (_nou
Human nature in its fulness is necessarily human; without love, it is inhuman; without inhuman.
Human nature ... / Is not a punctual presence, but a spirit / Diffused through time and space.
Human nature
we owe to education.
Human reason is like a drunken man on horseback; set it up on one side, and it tumbles over on the other.
Human society is made up of partialities.
Humani nihil alienum
Humanität sei unser ewig Ziel
Humanitati qui se non accommodat, / Plerumque pœnas oppetit superbiæ
Humanity is about the same all the world over.
Humanity is better than gold.
Humanity is constitutionally lazy.
Humanity is great but men are small.
Humanity is never so beautiful as when praying for forgiveness, or else forgiving another.
Humanity is one, and not till Lazarus is cured of his sores will Dives be safe.
Humanity is the virtue of a woman, generosity
of a man.
Humanum amare est, humanum autem ignoscere est
Humanum est errare
Humble wedlock is far better than proud virginity.
Humbleness is always grace, always dignity.
Humiles laborant ubi potentes dissident
Humility disarms envy and strikes it dead.
Humility is a virtue all preach, none practise, and yet everybody is content to hear. The master thinks it good doctrine for his servant, the laity for the clergy, and the clergy for the laity.
Humility is a virtue of so general, so exceeding good influence, that we can scarce purchase it too dear.
Humility is often a feigned submission which we employ to supplant others.
Humility is the altar upon which God wishes that we should offer Him His sacrifices.
Humility is the hall-mark of wisdom.
Humility is the only true wisdom by which we prepare our minds for all the possible vicissitudes of life.
Humility is the solid foundation of all the virtues.
Humility, that low, sweet root / From which
all heavenly virtues shoot.
Humour has justly been regarded as the finest perfection of poetic genius. He who wants it, be his other gifts what they may, has only half a mind; an eye for what is above him, not for what is about him or below him.
Humour is a sort of inverse sublimity, exalting, as it were, into our affections what is below us, while sublimity draws down into our affections what is above us.
Humour is consistent with pathos, while wit is not.
Humour is of a genial quality and is closely allied to pity.
Humour is properly the exponent of low
things; that which first renders them poetical to the mind.
Humour is the mistress of tears.
Humour, warm and all-embracing as the sunshine, bathes its objects in a genial and abiding light.
Hundreds of people can talk for one who can think, but thousands can think for one who can see. To see clearly is poetry, prophecy, and religion all in one.
Hunger and cold betray a man to his enemy.
Hunger is a good cook.
Hunger is the best sauce.
Hunger will break through stone walls.
Hungry bellies have no ears.
Hunt half a day for a forgotten dream.
Hunters generally know the most vulnerable
part of the beast they pursue by the care which every animal takes to defend the side which is weakest.
Hunting was the labour of savages in North America, but the amusement of the gentlemen of England.
Hurtar el puerco, y dar los pies por Dios
Husbands can earn money, but only wives can save it.
Hyperion to a satyr; so loving to my mother, / That he might not beteem the winds of heaven / Visit her face too roughly.
Hypotheses non fingo
Hypothesen sind Wiegenlieder, womit der Lehrer seine Schüler einlullt
Hysteron proteron
I am a man / More sinned against than sinning.
I am afraid to think what I have done; / Look
on't again I dare not.
I am always afraid of a fool; one cannot be sure that he is not a knave as well.
I am always as happy as I can be in meeting a man in whose society feelings are developed and thoughts defined.
I am always ill at ease when tumults arise among the mob--people who have nothing to lose.
I am amazed, methinks, and lose my way / Among the thorns and dangers of the world.
I am as free as Nature first made man, / Ere
the base laws of servitude began, / When wild in woods the noble savage ran.
I am black, but I am not the devil.
I am bound to find you in reasons, but not in brains.
I am but a gatherer and disposer of other men's stuff.
I am constant as the northern star, / Of whose true-fix'd and resting quality / There is no fellow in the firmament.
I am convinced that the Bible always becomes
more beautiful the better it is understood, that is, the better we see that every word which we apprehend in general and apply in particular had a proper, peculiar, and immediately individual reference to certain circumstances, certain time and space relations
more beautiful the better it is understood, that is, the better we see that every word which we apprehend in general and apply in particular had a proper, peculiar, and immediately individual reference to certain circumstances, certain time and space relations _i.e._, 
more beautiful the better it is understood, that is, the better we see that every word which we apprehend in general and apply in particular had a proper, peculiar, and immediately individual reference to certain circumstances, certain time and space relations _i.e._,  the spiritual life of the time in which it was written.
I am equally an enemy to a female dunce and a female pedant.
I am fortune's fool.
I am fully convinced that the soul is indestructible, and that its activity will continue through eternity. It is like the sun, which, to our eyes, seems to set in night; but it has in reality only gone to diffuse its light elsewhere.
I am monarch of all I survey, / My right there is none to dispute; / From the centre all round to the sea, / I am lord of the fowl and the brute.
I am more afraid of my own heart than of the
Pope and all his cardinals. I have within me the great pope, self.
I am neither so weak as to fear men, so proud as to despise them, or so unhappy as to hate them.
I am never merry when I hear sweet music.
I am no herald to inquire of men's pedigrees; it sufficeth me if I know their virtues.
I am no orator, as Brutus is; / But as you know me all, a plain blunt man, / That loves my friend.
I am not mad; I would to heaven I were! /
For then 'tis like I should forget myself.
I am not what I am.
I am nothing if not critical.
"I am searching for a man."
I am Sir Oracle, / And when I ope my lips, let no dog bark.
I am sorry to see how small a piece of religion
will make a cloak.
I am very content with knowing, if only I could know.
I am very fond of the company of ladies. I like their beauty; I like their delicacy; I like their vivacity; and I like their silence.
I and time against any two.
I augur better of a youth who is wandering on a path of his own than of many who are walking aright upon paths which are not theirs.
I awoke one morning and found myself famous.
I believe in great men, but not in demigods.
I believe more follies are committed out of complaisance to the world than in following our own inclinations.
I believe there are few persons who, if they please to reflect on their past lives, will not find that had they saved all those little sums which they have spent unnecessarily they might at present have been masters of a competent fortune.
I beseech you, dear brethren, think it possible that you may be wrong.
I bide my time.
I can but trust that good shall fall / At last--far off--at last, to all.
"I can call spirits from the vasty deep." "Why, so can I, or so can any man; but will they come when you do call for them?"
I can count a stocking-top while a man 's getting 's tongue ready; an' when he out wi' his speech at last, there's little broth to be made on't.
I can teach you to command the devil, / And I can teach you to shame the devil, / By telling truth.
I can tell you, honest friend, what to believe:
believe life; it teaches better than book and orator.
I cannot call riches better than the baggage of virtue.... It cannot be spared or left behind, but it hindereth the march.
I cannot hide what I am; I must be sad when I have cause, and smile at no man's jests; eat when I have stomach, and wait for no man's leisure; sleep when I am drowsy, and tend on no man's business; laugh when I am merry, and claw no man in his humour.
I cannot love thee as I ought, / For love reflects the thing beloved; / My words are only words, and move / Upon the topmost froth of thought.
I cannot praise a fugitive and cloistered virtue, unexercised and unbreathed, that never sallies out and seeks her adversary, but slinks out of the race where that immortal garland is to be run for, not without dust and heat.
I cannot think of any character below the
flatterer, except he that envies him.
I can't work for nothing, and find thread.
I care not though the cloth of state should be / Not of rich Arras, but mean tapestry.
I charge thee, fling away ambition; / By that sin fell the angels.
I chatter, chatter, as I flow / To join the brimming river, / For men may come and men may go, / But I go on for ever.
I contented myself with endeavouring to make
your home so easy that you might not be in haste to leave it.
I could a tale unfold, whose lightest word / Would harrow up thy soul, freeze thy young blood, / Make thy two eyes, like stars, start from their spheres, / Thy knotted and combined locks to part, / And each particular hair to stand on end, / Like quills upon the fretful porcupine.
I could have better spared a better man.
I could not but smile at a woman who makes her own misfortunes and then deplores the miseries of her situation.
I count life just a stuff / To try the soul's strength on.
I cuori fanciulli non vestone a bruno
I danari del comune sono come l'acqua benedetta, ognun ne piglia
I dare do all that may become a man; / Who dares do more, is none.
I dare to be honest, and I fear no labour.
I, demens! et sævas curre per Alpes, / Ut pueris placeas, et declamatio fias
I desire no future that will break the ties of
the past.
I die by the help of too many physicians.
I do but sing because I must, / And pipe but as the linnets sing.
I do know of these / That therefore only are reputed wise / For saying nothing.
I do know, / When the blood burns, how prodigal the soul / Lends the tongue vows.
I do not like "but yet," it does allay / The
good precedence; fie upon "but yet:" / "But yet" is as a jailer to bring forth / Some monstrous malefactor.
I do not love a man who is zealous for nothing.
I do not love thee, Dr. Fell, / The reason why I cannot tell; / But this alone I know full well, / I do not love thee, Dr. Fell.
I do not need philosophy at all.
I do pity unlearned gentlemen on a rainy day.
"I don't care," is a deadly snare.
I earn that I eat, get that I wear; owe no man hate, envy no man's happiness; glad of other men's good, content with my harm.
I esteem that wealth which is given to the worthy, and which is day by day enjoyed; the rest is a reserve for one knoweth not whom.
I fatti sono maschii, le parole femine
I favoriti dei grandi oltre all' oro di regali,
e l'incenso delle lodi, tocca loro anche la mirra della maldicenza
I fear God, and, next to God, I chiefly fear him who fears Him not.
I fear thy nature; / It is too full of the milk of human kindness / To catch the nearest way.
I feel within me a peace above all earthly dignities, a still and quiet conscience.
I find nonsense singularly refreshing.
I for ever pass from hand to hand, / And each
possessor thinks me his own land. / All of them think so, but they all are wrong; / To none but Fortune only I belong.
I found Rome brick, I left it marble.
I gaed a waefu' gate yestreen, / A gate, I fear, I'll dearly rue; / I got my death frae twa sweet een, / Twa lovely een o' bonnie blue.
"I go at last out of this world, where the heart must either petrify or break."
I go through my appointed daily stage, and I care not for the curs who bark at me along the road.
I gran dolori sono muti
I grieve that grief can teach me nothing, nor carry me one step into real nature.
I grudge the dollar, the dime, the cent I give to such men as do not belong to me and to whom I do not belong; (but) there is a class of persons to whom, by all spiritual affinity, I am bought and sold; for them I will go to prison if need be.
I guadagni mediocri empiono la borsa
I had as lief not be, as live to be / In awe of such a thing as I myself.
I had better never see a book than be warped
by its attraction clean out of my own orbit and made a satellite instead of a system.
I had rather be a dog, and bay the moon, / Than such a Roman.
"I had rather be first here than second in Rome."
I had rather be Mercury, the smallest among seven (planets), revolving round the sun, than the first among five (moons) revolving round Saturn.
I had rather believe all the fables in the legends, the Talmud, and the Koran, than that this universal frame is without a mind.
I had rather dwell in the dim fog of superstition
than in air rarified to nothing by the air-pump of unbelief.
I had rather have a fool to make me merry than experience to make me sad.
I had rather people laugh at me while they instruct me than praise me without benefiting me.
I hae a penny to spend, / There--thanks to naebody; / I hae naething to lend--/ I'll borrow frae naebody.
I hate a style that slides along like an eel, and never rises to what one can call an inequality.
I hate bungling as I do sin, but particularly
bungling in politics, which leads to the misery and ruin of many thousands and millions of people.
I hate ingratitude more in a man / Than lying, vainness, babbling, drunkenness, / Or any taint of vice whose strong corruption / Inhabits our frail blood.
I have a kind of alacrity in sinking.
I have a very poor opinion of a man who talks to men what women should not hear.
I have all I have ever enjoyed.
I have always been a quarter of an hour
before my time, and it has made a man of me.
I have always despised the whining yelp of complaint, and the cowardly, feeble resolve.
I have always found that the road to a woman's heart lies through her child.
I have been reasoning all my life, and find that all argument will vanish before one touch of Nature.
I have been tempted by opportunity, and seconded by accident.
I have been too much occupied with things
themselves to think either of their beginning or their end.
I have bought / Golden opinions from all sorts of people.
I have ever held it as a maxim never to do that through another which it was possible for me to execute myself.
I have, God wot, a largë field to ear; / And weakë the oxen in my plough.
I have great hope of a wicked man, slender hope of a mean one.
I have known some men possessed of good
qualities which were very serviceable to others, but useless to themselves; like a sun-dial on the front of a house, to inform the neighbours and passengers, but not the owner within.
I have learned in whatsoever state I am therewith to be content.
I have little knowledge which I find not some way useful to my highest ends.
I have lost the ring, but I have my finger still.
I have never been able to conquer this ferocious wild beast
I have never seen a greater monster or miracle in the world than myself.
I have no idea of the courage that braves Heaven.
I have no notion of a truly great man that could not be all sorts of men.
I have no other but a woman's reason; / I
think him so because I think him so.
I have no spur / To prick the sides of my intent.
I have no words, / My voice is in my sword.
I have saved the bird in my bosom
I have seen some nations, like overloaded asses, / Kick off their burdens, meaning the higher classes.
I have seldom known any one who deserted
truth in trifles that could be trusted in matters of importance.
I have set my life upon a cast, / And I will stand the hazard of the die.
I have that within which passeth show; / These but the trappings and the suits of woe.
I have this great commission, / From that supernal judge that stirs good thoughts / In any breast of strong authority, / To look into the blots and stains of right.
I have thought some of Nature's journeymen had made men, and not made them well; they imitated humanity so abominably.
I hear, yet say not much, but think the more.
I hold ambition of so airy and light a quality, that it is but a shadow's shadow.
I hold every man a debtor to his profession.
I hold it cowardice / To rest mistrustful where a noble heart / Hath pawn'd an open hand in sign of love.
I hold it truth, with him who sings / To one clear harp in divers tones, / That men may rise on stepping-stones / Of their dead selves to higher things.
I hold the world but as the world, Gratiano; /
A stage, where every man must play a part, / And mine a sad one.
I hope I don't intrude.
I humbly trust I should not change my opinions and practice, though it rained garters and coronets as the reward of apostasy.
I jouk
As well's I may; / Sworn foe to sorrow, care, or prose, / I rhyme away.
I know but of one solid objection to absolute monarchy; the difficulty of finding any man adequate to the office.
I know enough to hold my tongue, but not
to speak.
I know no evil death can show, which life / Has not already shown to those who live / Embodied longest.
I know no evil so great as the abuse of the understanding and yet there is no one vice more common.
I know no judgment of the future but by the past.
I know nothing sublime which is not some modification of power.
I know only one thing sweeter than making a
book, and that is to project one.
I know that dancin' 's nonsense; but if you stick at everything because its nonsense, you wonna go far in this life.
"I know that it is in me, and out it shall come."
I know that my Redeemer liveth.



I labour, and you get the pearl.
I let every one follow his own bent, that I may be free to follow mine.
I like a good hater.
I live in the crowd of jollity, not so much to enjoy company as to shun myself.
I live not in myself, but I become / Portion of that around me; and to me / High mountains are a feeling.
I look upon an able statesman out of business
like a huge whale, that will endeavour to overturn the ship unless he has an empty cask to play with.
I love a hand that meets mine own with a grasp that causes some sensation.
I love everything that's old--old friends, old tunes, old manners, old books, old wine.
I love God and little children.
I love him not, nor fear him; there's my creed.
I love my friends well, but myself better.
I love sometimes to doubt, as well as to know.
I love / The name of honour more than I fear death.
I love to browse in a library.
I'll make assurance doubly sure, / And take a bond of fate.
I made all my generals out of mud.
I make the most of my enjoyments; and as for my troubles, I pack them in as little compass as I can for myself, and never let them annoy others.
I might have my hand full of truth, and open only my little finger.
I mourn not those who lose their vital breath; / But those who, living, live in fear of death.
I must be cruel, only to be kind.
"I must sleep now."
I must work the work of Him that sent me while it is day; the night cometh when no man can work.
I'm never less at leisure than when at leisure, nor less alone than when alone.
I'm not denyin' the women are foolish; God Almighty made 'em to match the men.
I'm not one of those who can see the cat i' the dairy an' wonder what she's come after.

I'm sure sma' pleasure it can gie, / E'en to a like me, / An' hear us squeel.
I never could believe that Providence had
sent a few men into the world ready booted and spurred to ride, and millions ready saddled and bridled to be ridden.
I never could tread a single pleasure under foot.
I never heard tell of any clever man that came of entirely stupid people.
I never knew a man of letters ashamed of his profession.
I never knew any man grow poor by keeping an orderly table.
I never knew any man in my life who could
not bear another's misfortunes perfectly as a Christian.
I never saw, heard, or read that the clergy were beloved in any nation where Christianity was the religion of the country.
I never whisper'd a private affair / Within the hearing of cat or mouse, / No, not to myself in the closet alone, / But I heard it shouted at once from the top of the house; / Everything came to be known.
I only look straight before me at each day as it comes, and do what is nearest me, without looking further afield.
I picciol cani trovano, ma i grandi hanno la lepre
I pick up favourite quotations and store them
in my mind as ready armour, offensive or defensive, amid the struggle of this turbulent existence. Of these there is a very favourite one from Thomson: "Attach thee firmly to the virtuous deeds / And offices of life; to life itself, / With all its vain and transient joys, sit loose."
I pity men who occupy themselves exclusively with the transitory in things and lose themselves in the study of what is perishable, since we are here for this very end that we may make the perishable imperishable, which we can do only after we have learned how to appreciate both.
I pity the man who can travel from Dan to Beersheba, and cry: 'Tis all barren.
I pounce on what is mine wherever I find it.
I prize the soul that slumbers in a quiet eye.
I quote others only in order the better to
express myself.
I renounce the friend who eats what is mine with me, and what is his own by himself.
I say beware of all enterprises that require new clothes, and not rather a new wearer of clothes.
I say the acknowledgment of God in Christ, / Accepted by thy reason, solves for thee / All questions on the earth and out of it.
I scorn the affectation of seeming modesty to cover self-conceit.
I secundo omine
I see my way as birds their trackless way.
I see that sensible men and conscientious men all over the world are of the one religion of well-doing and daring.
I see thy vanity through the holes of thy coat.
I seek divine simplicity in him who handles things divine.
I seek not to wax great by others' waning.
"I shall go to-morrow," said the king. "You shall wait for me," quoth the wind.
I shall light a candle of understanding in thine heart which shall not be put out.
I shall perhaps tremble in my death-hour, but before shall I never.
I should be glad were all the meadows on the earth left in a wild state, if that were the consequence of men's beginning to redeem themselves.
I stay here on my bond.
I stout and you stout, who will carry the dirt out?
I take it to be a principal rule of life not to be too much addicted to any one thing.
I talk of chalk and you of cheese.
I think a lock and key a security at least equal to the bosom of any friend whatever.
I think it is as scandalous for a woman not
to know how to use a needle as for a man not to know how to use a sword.
I think nothing is to be hoped from you if this bit of mould under your feet is not sweeter to you than any other in this world.
I think sculpture and painting have an effect to teach us manners and abolish hurry.
I think women have an instinct of dissimulation; they know by nature how to disguise their emotions far better than the most consummate male courtiers can do.
I tremble for my country when I reflect that God is just.
I very much fear that our little terraqueous
globe is the lunatic asylum of the universe.
I've had my say out, and I shall be th' easier for't all my life.
I've never any pity for conceited people, because I think they carry their comfort about with them.
I've wandered east, I've wandered west, / Through many a weary way; / But never, never can forget / The love of life's young day.
I waive the quantum o' th sin, / The hazard of concealing; / But oh! it hardens a' within, / And petrifies the feeling.
I want that glib and oily art, / To speak and purpose not; since what I well intend, / I'll do't before I speak.
I was not born for courts or great affairs; / I pay my debts, believe, and say my prayers.
I was well, would be better, took physic and died.
I wasted time, and now doth time waste me.
I watch the wheels of Nature's mazy plan, /
And learn the future by the past of man.
I were but little happy if I could say how much.
I will a round unvarnish'd tale deliver / Of my whole course of love.
I will be as harsh as truth and as uncompromising as justice.
I will chide no breather in the world but myself, against whom I know most faults.
I will divide my goods; / Call in the wretch
and slave: / None shall rule but the humble, / And none but toil shall have.
I will get it from his purse or get it from his skin.
I will give thrice as much to any well-deserving friend; but in the way of bargain, mark me, I will cavil on the ninth part of a hair.
I will lay a stone at your door
I will listen to any one's convictions, but pray keep your doubts to yourself; I have plenty of my own.
I will move the world.
I will speak daggers to her, but use none.
I will wear my heart upon my sleeve / For daws to peck at.
I wish there were some cure, like the lover's leap, for all heads of which some single idea has obtained an unreasonable and irregular possession.
I would applaud thee to the very echo, that should applaud again.
I would choose to have others for my acquaintance,
but Englishmen for my friends.
I would condone many things in one-and-twenty now, that I dealt hardly with at middle age. God Himself, I think, is very willing to give one-and-twenty a second chance.
I would desire for a friend the son who never resisted the tears of his mother.
I would fain avoid men; we can give them no help, and they hinder us from helping ourselves.
I would give all my fame for a pot of ale and safety.
I would have been glad to have lived under
my woodside, to have kept a flock of sheep, rather than undertaken such a government as this.
"I"
I would it were bed-time, Hal, and all well.
I would not enter on my list of friends ... the man / Who needlessly sets foot upon a worm.
I would not for much that I had been born richer.
I would rather be found suffering than doing
what is unjust.
I would rather be the author of one original thought than conqueror of a hundred battles.
I would rather make my name than inherit it.
Ibi omnis / Effusus labor
