Ibis, redibis non morieris in bello
Ibit eo quo vis, qui zonam perdidit
Iceland is the finest country on which the sun shines.
Ich bin des trocknen Tons nun satt, / Muss wieder recht den Teufel spielen
Ich bin ein Mensch gewesen, / Und das heisst ein Kämpfer sein
Ich bin es müde, über Sklaven zu herrschen
Ich bin zu alt, um nur zu spielen; / Zu jung, um ohne Wunsch zu sein
Ich denke so: / Was nicht zusammen kann / Bestehen, ist am besten sich zu lösen
Ich dien
Ich finde nicht die Spur, / Von einem Geist, und alles ist Dressur
Ich fühl' ein ganzes Heer in meiner Brust
Ich fühle Mut, mich in die Welt zu wagen / Der Erde Weh, der Erde Glück zu tragen
Ich glaube, dass alles was das Genie, als Genie thut, unbewusst geschieht
"Ich glaube an einen Gott." Das ist ein schönes löbliches Wort; aber Gott anerkennen, wo und wie er sich offenbare, das ist eigentlich die Seligkeit auf Erden
Ich habe es öfters rühmen hören, / Ein Komödiant könnte einen Pfarrer lehren
Ich habe genossen das irdische Glück; / Ich habe gelebt und geliebet
Ich habe gethan, was ich nicht lassen konnte
Ich habe hier bloss ein Amt und keine Meinung
Ich habe nichts als Worte, und es ziemt / Dem edlen Mann, der Frauen Wort zu achten
Ich heisse der reichste Mann in der getauften
Welt: Die Sonne geht in meinem Staat nicht unter
Ich möcht mich gleich dem Teufel übergeben, / Wenn ich nur selbst kein Teufel wär
Ich muss, das ist die Schrank', in welcher mich die Welt, / Von einer, die Natur von andrer Seite hält
Ich schweige zu vielem still; denn ich mag die Menschen nicht irre machen, und bin wohl zufrieden, wenn sie sich freuen, da wo ich mich ärgere
Ich setze die Souveränität fest wie einen eisernen Felsen
Ich singe, wie der Vogel singt, / Der in den
Zweigen wohnet / Das Lied, das aus der Kehle dringt, / Ist Lohn, der reichlich lohnet
Ich stehe in Gottes Hand, und ruh' in Gottes Schooss / Vor ihm fühl' ich mich klein, in ihm fühl' ich mich gross
Ich thue recht und scheue keinen Feind
Ici l'honneur m'oblige, et j'y veux satisfaire
Id arbitror / Adprime in vitâ esse utile, ne quid nimis
Id cinerem, aut manes credis curare sepultos?
Id commune malum; semel insanivimus omnes
Id demum est homini turpe, quod meruit pati
Id est
Id facere laus est quod decet, non quod licet
Id genus omne
Id maxime quemque decet, quod est cujusque maxime suum
Id mutavit, quoniam me immutatum videt
Id nobis maxime nocet, quod non ad rationis lumen sed ad similitudinem aliorum vivimus
Ideals are the world's masters.
Ideals can never be completely embodied in
practice; and yet ideals exist, and if they be not approximated to at all, the whole matter goes to wreck.
Ideas must work through the brains and arms of good and brave men, or they are no better than dreams.
Ideas often flash across our minds more complete than we could make them after much labour.
Idem
Idem quod
Idem velle et idem nolle ea demum firma
amicitia est
Idle folks lack no excuses.
Idle people have the least leisure.
Idleness and pride tax with a heavier hand than kings and parliaments.
Idleness in the midst of unattempted tasks is always proud.
Idleness is an appendix to nobility.
Idleness is many gathered miseries in one name.
Idleness is only the refuge of weak minds and the holiday of fools.
Idleness is the badge of gentry, the bane of body and mind, the nurse of naughtiness, the step-mother of discipline, the chief author of mischief, one of the seven deadly sins, the cushion on which the devil chiefly reposes, and a great cause not only of melancholy, but of many other diseases.
Idleness is the greatest prodigality in the world.
Idleness is the root of all evil.
Idleness is the sepulchre of a living man.
Idleness rusts the mind.
Idolatry is simply the substitution of an "Eidolon," phantasm, or imagination of good for that which is real and enduring, from the highest Living Good which gives life, to the lowest material good which ministers to it.
Idoneus homo
If a barrel-organ in a slum can but drown
a curse, let no Christian silence it.
If a beard were all, the goat would be winner.
If a book come from the heart, it will contrive to reach other hearts.
If a book is worth reading, it is worth buying.
If a cause be good, the most violent attack of its enemies will not injure it so much as an injudicious defence of it by its friends.
If a dog has a man to back him, he will kill a baboon.
If a donkey bray at you, don't bray at him.
If a God did not exist, it would be necessary to invent one.
If a great thing can be done at all, it can be done easily; but it is in that kind of ease with which a tree blossoms after long years of gathered strength.
If a house be divided against itself, that house cannot stand.
If a man be born in a stable, that does not make him a horse.
If a man cannot be a Christian in the place
where he is, he cannot be a Christian anywhere.
If a man could bequeath his virtues by will, and settle his sense and learning upon his heirs as certainly as he can his lands, a noble descent would then indeed be a valuable privilege.
If a man deceives me once, shame on him; if he deceives me twice, shame on me.
If a man do not erect in this age his tomb ere he dies, he will live no longer in monument than the bell rings and the widow weeps.
If a man empties his purse into his head, no man can take it from him.
If a man fear or reverence God, he must hate
covetousness; and if he fear or reverence covetousness, he must hate God.
If a man hath too mean an opinion of himself, it will render him unserviceable both to God and man.
If a man have freedom enough to live healthily and work at his craft, he has enough; and so much all can easily obtain.
If a man have not a friend, he may quit the stage.
If a man is not virtuous, he becomes vicious.
If a man knows the right way, he need not
trouble himself about wrong paths.
If a man makes himself a worm, he must not complain when trodden on.
If a man makes me keep my distance, the comfort is he keeps his own at the same time.
If a man once fall, all will tread on him.
If a man read little, he had need of much cunning to seem to know that he doth not.
If a man speaks or acts with a pure thought,
happiness follows him like a shadow that never leaves him.
If a man wishes to become rich, he must appear rich.
If a man with the material of enjoyment around him and virtually within his reach walks God's earth wilfully and obstinately with a gloomy spirit, ... making misery his worship, we feel assured he is contravening his Maker's design in endowing him with life.
If a man would be alone, let him look at the stars.
If a man wound you with injuries, meet him with patience; hasty words rankle the wound, soft language dresses it, forgiveness cures it, and oblivion takes away the scar.
If a man write a book, let him set down only
what he knows. I have guesses enough of my own.
If a man s gaun doun the brae, ilka ane gi'es him a jundie
If a noble soul is rendered tenfold beautifuller by victory and prosperity, an ignoble one is rendered tenfold and a hundredfold uglier, pitifuller.
If a people will not believe, it must obey.
If a pig could give his mind to anything, he wouldn't be a pig.
If a word be worth one shekel, silence is worth
two.
If ae sheep loup
will 
If aged and life-weary men have called to their neighbours: "Think of dying!" we younger and life-loving men may well keep encouraging and reminding one another with the cheerful words: "Think of wandering!"
If all be well within, ... the impertinent censures of busy, envious men will make no very deep impression.
If all dogs on this earth should bark, / It will not matter if you do not hark.
If all the misfortunes of mankind were cast
into a public stock in order to be equally distributed among the species, those who now think themselves the most unhappy would prefer the share they have already to that which would fall to them by such a division.
If all the world were falcons, what of that? / The wonder of the eagle were the less, / But he not less the eagle.
If all the year were playing holidays, / To sport would be as tedious as to work.
If all were rich, gold would be penniless.
If an ass goes a-travelling, he'll not come home a horse.
If an ass kicks me, shall I strike him again?
If an ass looks in, you cannot expect an apostle to look out.
If an idiot were to tell you the same story every day for a year, you would end by believing him.
If any false step be made in the more momentous concerns of life, the whole scheme of ambitious designs is broken.
If any man minister, let him do it as of the ability which God giveth.
If any man will come after me, let him deny
himself, and take up his cross and follow me.
If any one tells you that a man has changed his character, don't believe it.
If any speak ill of thee, fly home to thy own conscience and examine thy heart. If thou art guilty, it is a fair correction; if not guilty, it is a fair instruction.
If any would not work, neither should he eat.
If blushing makes ugly people so beautiful, ought it not to make the beautiful still more beautiful?
If coals do not burn, they blacken.
If cheerfulness knocks for admission, we should
open our hearts wide to receive it, for it never comes inopportunely.
If children grew up according to early indications, we should have nothing but geniuses.
If cut
talent, so does the colour betoken temper and heart.
If destructive criticism is injurious in anything, it is in matters of religion, for here everything depends upon faith, to which we cannot return when we have once lost it.
If each one does his duty as an individual, and if each one works rightly in his own vocation, it will be well with the whole.
If ever a fool's advice is good, a prudent man
must carry it out.
If every fool wore a crown, we should all be kings.
If everybody knew what one says of the other, there would not be four friends left in the world.
If evil be said of thee, and if it be true, correct thyself; if it be a lie, laugh at it.
If fame is only to come after death, I am in no hurry for it.
If folly were a pain, there would be crying in
every house.
If fortune favour you, be not elated; if she frown, do not despond.
If fortune give thee less than she has done, / Then make less fire, and walk more in the sun.
If fortune would make a man estimable, she gives him virtues; if she would have him esteemed, she gives him success.
If frequent failure convince you of that mediocrity of nature which is incompatible with great actions, submit wisely and cheerfully to your lot.
If friendship is to rob me of my eyes, if it is
to darken the day, I will have none of it.
If fun is good, truth is still better, and love most of all.
If happiness ha'e not her seat / And centre in the breast, / We may be wise, or rich, or great, / But never can be blest.
If heraldry were guided by reason, a plough in a field arable would be the most noble and ancient arms.
If Hercules and Lichas play at dice / Which is the better man, the greater throw / May turn by fortune from the weaker hand; / So is Alcides beaten by his page.
If honour calls, where'er she points the
way, / The sons of honour follow and obey.
If I am anything, which I much doubt, I made myself so merely by labour.
If I am master and you are master, who shall drive the asses?
If I am not worth the wooing, I surely am not worth the winning.
If I am right, Thy grace impart / Still in the right to stay; / If I am wrong, O teach my heart to find the better way.
If I ascend up into heaven, Thou art there; if
I make my bed in hell, behold Thou art there; if I take the wings of the morning, and dwell in the uttermost parts of the sea, even there shall Thy hand lead me, and Thy right hand shall hold me.
If I be dear to some one else, / Then I should be to myself more dear.
If I call bad bad, what do I gain? But if I call good bad, I do a great deal of mischief.
If I can catch him once upon the hip, / I will feed fat the ancient grudge I bear him.

If I choose to take jest in earnest, no one shall put me to shame for doing so; and if I shall be always myself
If I do lose thee
none but fools would keep; a breath thou art, / Servile to all the skyey influences, / That do this habitation, where thou keep'st / Hourly inflict.
If I for my opinion bleed, / Opinion shall be surgeon to my hurt.
If I had read as much as other men, I would have been as ignorant as they are.
If I had wit enough to get out of this wood, I have said enough to serve mine own turn.
If I knew the way of the Lord, truly I would be only too glad to walk in it; if I were led into the temple of truth
I would not, with the hel
go ou
If I lose mine honour, I lose myself.
If I love thee, what is that to thee?
If I'm designed yon lordling's slave, / By Nature's law designed, / Why was an independent wish / E'er planted in my mind?
If I must die, / I will encounter darkness as a bride / And hug it in my arms.
If I seek an interest of my own detached from that of others, I seek an interest which is chimerical, and can never have existence.
If I should say nothing, I should say much
(much being included in my love); though my love be such, that if I should say much, I should yet say nothing, it being, as Cowley says, equally impossible either to conceal or to express it.
If I wish for a horse-hair for my compass-sight, I must go to the stable; but the hair-bird, with her sharp eyes, goes to the road.
If ill thoughts at any time enter into the mind of a good man, he doth not roll them under his tongue as a sweet morsel.

If in the course of our life we see that done by others for which we ourselves at one time felt a vocation, and which we were, with much else, compelled to relinquish, then the noble feeling comes in, that only humanity altogether is the true man, and that the individual can only rejoice and be happy when whole.
If in youth the universe is majestically unveiling, and everywhere heaven revealing itself on earth, nowhere to the young man does this heaven on earth so immediately reveal itself as in the young maiden.
"If" is the only peacemaker--much virtue in "if."
If it be a bliss to enjoy the good, it is still
greater happiness to discern the better; for in art the best only is good enough.
If it be asked, What is the improper expectation which it is dangerous to indulge, experience will quickly answer that it is such expectation as is dictated not by reason but by desire--an expectation that requires the common course of things to be changed, and the general rules of action to be broken.
If it be aught toward the general good, / Set honour in one eye, and death i' the other, / And I will look on both indifferently; / For, let the gods so speed me, as I love / The name of honour more than I fear death.
If it be possible, as much as lieth in you, live peaceably with all men.
If it is a happiness to be nobly descended, it is not less to have so much merit that nobody inquires whether we are so or not.
If it is disgraceful to be beaten, it is only a
shade less disgraceful to have so much as fought.
If it rains--well! If it shines--well!
If it were done when 'tis done, then 'twere well / It were done quickly ... that but this blow / Might be the be all and the end all here.
If it were not for hope, the heart would break.
If it were not for respect to human opinions, I would not open my window to see the Bay of Naples for the first time, whilst I would go five hundred leagues to talk with a man of genius whom I had not seen.
If Jack were better, Jill would not be so bad.
If ladies be but young and fair, / They have the gift to know it.
If life, like the olive, is a bitter fruit, then grasp both with the press and they will yield the sweetest oil.
If man had a higher idea of himself and his destiny, he would neither call his business amusement nor amuse himself instead of transacting business.
If man is not kin to God by his spirit, he is a base and ignoble creature.
If men duly felt the greatness of God, they
would be dumb, and for very veneration unwilling to name Him.
If money be not thy servant, it will be thy master. The covetous man cannot so properly be made to possess wealth as that it may be said to possess him.
If money go before, all ways do lie open.
If music be the food of love, play on; / Give me excess of it, that, surfeiting, / The appetite may sicken, and so die.
If my person be crooked, my verses shall be straight.
If Nature is one and a living indivisible
whole, much more is mankind, the image that reflects and creates Nature, without which Nature were not.
If new-got gold is said to burn the pockets till it be cast forth into circulation, much more may new truth.
If, of all words of tongue and pen, / The saddest are, "It might have been," / More sad are these we daily see: "It is, but hadn't ought to be."
If once you find a woman gluttonous, expect from her very little virtue; her mind is enslaved to the lowest and grossest temptation.
If one advances confidently in the direction of his dreams, and endeavours to live the life which he has imagined, he will meet with a success unexpected in common hours.
If one age believes too much, it is but a natural
reaction that another age should believe too little.
If one door shuts, another will open.
If one sees one's fellow-creature following damnable error, by continuing in which the devil is sure to get him at last, are you to let him go towards such consummation, or are you not rather to use all means to save him?
If one were to think constantly of death, the business of life would stand still.
If our era is an era of unbelief, why murmur at it? Is there not a better coming--nay, come?
If people did not flatter one another, there
would be little society.
If people take no care for the future, they will soon have sorrow for the present.
If people were constant, it would surprise me. For see, is not everything in the world subject to change? Why then should our affections continue?
If people would whistle more and argue less, the world would be much happier and probably just as wise.
If poverty is the mother of crimes, want of sense is the father of them.
If poverty makes a man groan, he yawns in
opulence.
If reasons were as plenty as blackberries, I would give no man a reason upon compulsion.
If Satan ever laughs, it must be at hypocrites; they are the greatest dupes he has.
If she be not fit for me, / What care I for whom she be?
If solid happiness we prize, / Within our breast this jewel lies, / And they are fools who roam. / The world has nothing to bestow; / From our own selves our joys must flow, / And that dear hut, our home.
If sorrow falls, / Take comfort still in deeming there may be / A way to peace on earth by woes of ours.
If speculation tends to a terrific unity, in
which all things are absorbed, action tends directly backwards to diversity.
If that God give, the deil daurna reave
If that thy fame with every toy be posed, / 'Tis a thin web which poisonous fancies make; / But the great soldier's honour was composed / Of thicker stuff, which would endure a shake.
If the Almighty waited six thousand years for a man to see what He has made, I may well wait two hundred for others to see what I have seen.
If the ancients left us ideas, to our credit be it spoken, we moderns are building houses for them.
If the beard were all, the goat might preach.
If the blind lead the blind, both shall fall into the ditch.
If the cap fit, wear it.
If the chaff-cutter had the making of us, we should all be straw, I reckon.
If the counsel be good, no matter who gave it.
If the deil were dead, folk would do little for
God's sake.
If the devil takes a less hateful shape to us than to our fathers, he is as busy with us as he was with them.
If the doctor cures, the sun sees it; if he kills, the earth hides it.
If the East loves infinity, the West delights in boundaries.
If the eye were not of a sunny nature
how could it see the sun? If God's own power did not exist within us, how could the godlike delight us?
If the farmer cannot live who drives the plough,
how can he live who drives a fast-trotting mare?
If the heart of a man is depressed with cares, / The mist is dispelled when a woman appears.
If the hungry lion
is to feast at all, it cannot be on the chickenweed, but only on the chickens.
If the king is in the palace, nobody looks at the walls. It is when he is gone, and the house is filled with grooms and gazers, that we turn from the people to find relief in the majestic men that are suggested by the pictures and the architecture.
"If the Lord tarry, yet wait for Him," for He "will surely come" and heal thee.
If the mountain will not come to Mahomet,
Mahomet will go to the mountain.
If the nose of Cleopatra had been a little shorter, it would have changed the history of the world.
If the paternal cottage still shuts us in, its roof still screens us; and with a father we have as yet a prophet, priest, and king, and an obedience that makes us free.
If the pills were pleasant, they would not be gilded.
If the poet have nothing to interpret and reveal, it is better that he remain silent.
If the poor man cannot always get meat, the
rich man cannot always digest it.
If the profession you have chosen has some unexpected inconveniences, console yourself by reflecting that no profession is without them.
If the single man plant himself indomitably on his instincts, and there abide, the huge world will come round to him.
If the sun shines on me, what matters the moon?
If the sky fall, we shall catch larks.
If the time don't suit you, suit yourself to the
time.
If the tongue had not been formed for articulation, man would still be a beast in the forest.
If the true did not possess an objective value, human curiosity would have died out centuries ago.
If the weather don't happen to be good for my work to-day, it's good for some other man's, and will come round to me to-morrow.
If the world were put into one scale and my mother into the other, the world would kick the beam.
If the young knew, if the old could, there's
nothing but would be done.
If there be / A devil in man, there is an angel too.
If there be light, then there is darkness; if cold, heat; if height, depth; if solid, fluid; if hard, soft; if rough, smooth; if calm, tempest; if prosperity, adversity; if life, death.
If there be no enemy, no fight; if no fight, no victory; if no victory, no crown.
If there be not a religious element in the relations of men, such relations are miserable and doomed to ruin.
If there were no clouds, we should not enjoy
the sun.
If there were no falsehood in the world, there would be no doubt; if no doubt, no inquiry; and if no inquiry, no wisdom, no knowledge, no genius.
If there were no fools, there would be no knaves.
If there were only one religion in the world, it would be haughtily and licentiously despotic.
If there's a hole in a' your coats, / I rede ye tent it: / A chiel's amang you takin' notes, / And faith he'll prent it.
If they do these things in the green tree, what shall be done in the dry?
If they hear not Moses and the Prophets, neither will they be persuaded though one rose from the dead.
If thou art a master, be sometimes blind; if a servant, sometimes deaf.
If them art rich, thou art poor; / For, like an ass whose back with ingots bows, / Thou bear'st thy heavy riches but a journey, / And death unloads thee.
If thou art wise, thou knowest thine own
ignorance; and thou art ignorant, if thou knowest not thyself.
If thou be a severe, sour-complexioned man, then here I disallow thee to be a competent judge.
If thou be master-gunner, spend not all / That thou canst speak at once, but husband it.
If thou bear the cross cheerfully, it will bear thee.
If thou canst let others alone in their matters, they likewise will not hinder thee in thine.
If thou cast away one cross, without doubt
thou shalt find another, and that perhaps more heavy.
If thou deniest to a laborious man and a deserving, thou killest a bee; if thou givest to other than such, thou preservest a drone.
If thou doest well, shalt thou not be accepted?
If thou faint in the day of adversity, thy strength is small.
If thou hast fear of those who command thee, spare those who obey thee.
If thou hast run with the footmen, and they
have wearied thee, then how canst thou contend with horses? and if in the land of peace, wherein thou trustedst, they wearied thee, then how wilt thou do in the swelling of Jordan?
If thou love learning, thou shalt be learned.
If thou seest the oppression of the poor, ... marvel not at the matter; for He that is higher than the highest regardeth; and there be higher than they.
If thou sustain injustice, console thyself; the true unhappiness is in doing it.
If thou wouldst profit by thy reading, read humbly, simply, honestly, and not desiring to win a character for learning.
If thou wouldst reap in love, / First sow in
holy fear; / So life a winter's morn may prove / To a bright endless year.
If thy estate be good, match near home and at leisure; if weak, far off and quickly.
If thy son can make ten pound his measure, / Then all thou addest may be called his treasure.
If to do were as easy as to know what were good to do, chapels had been churches and poor men's cottages princes' palaces.
If truth be with thy friend, be with them both.
If vain our toil, we ought to blame the culture,
not the soil.
If virtue keep court within, honour will attend without.
If we are not famous for goodness, we are practically infamous.
If we are rich with the riches which we neither give nor enjoy, we are rich with the riches which are buried in the caverns of the earth.
If we are told a man is religious, we still ask what are his morals; but if we hear he has honest morals, we seldom think of the other question, whether he be religious.
If we are wise, we may thank ourselves; if we
are great, we must thank fortune.
If we bear what we must bear with murmuring and grudging, we do but gall our shoulders with the yoke, and render that a heavy unprofitable load which might be fruitful and glorious.
If we ... / Cannot defend our own doors from the dog, / Let us be worried, and our nation lose / The name of hardiness and policy.
If we cannot help committing errors, we must build none.
If we cannot live so as to be happy, let us at least live so as to deserve happiness.
If we cast off one burden, we are immediately
pursued and oppressed by another.
If we clear the metaphysical element out of modern literature, we shall find its bulk amazingly diminished, and the claims of the remaining writers, or of those whom we have thinned by this abstraction of their straw-stuffing, much more easily adjusted.
If we could have a little patience, we should escape much mortification. Time takes away as much as it gives.
If we could read the secret history of our enemies, we should find in each man's life sorrow and suffering enough to disarm all hostility.
If we do not find happiness in the present moment, in what shall we find it?
If we do not now reckon a great man literally
divine, it is that our notions of the divine are ever rising higher; not altogether that our reverence for the divine, as manifested in our like, is getting lower.
If we do well here, we shall do well there.
If we engage into a large acquaintance and various familiarities, we set open our gates to the invaders of most of our time.
If we examine our thoughts, we shall find them always occupied with the past and the future.
If we fail to conquer smaller difficulties, what will become of us when assaulted by greater?
If we hope for what we are not likely to possess, we act and think in vain, and make life a greater dream and shadow than it really is.
If we live truly, we shall see truly.
If we love those we lose, can we altogether lose those we love?
If we reflect on the number of men we have seen and know, and consider how little we have been to them and they to us, what must our feelings be?
We meet with the man 
If we reflect on the number of men we have seen and know, and consider how little we have been to them and they to us, what must our feelings be? (_Geistreich_) 
If we reflect on the number of men we have seen and know, and consider how little we have been to them and they to us, what must our feelings be? (_Geistreich_)  with the scholar without learning from him, with the traveller without gaining information from him, the amiable man without making ourselves agreeable to him. And this, alas! happens not merely with passing acquaintances; society and families conduct themselves similarly towards their dearest members, cities towards their worthiest citizens, peoples towards their most excellent princes, and nations towards their most eminent men.
If we saw all the things that really surround
us, we should be imprisoned and unable to move.
If we should all bring our misfortunes into one place, most of us would be glad to take our own home again rather than take a proportion out of the common stock.
If we shut Nature out at the door, she will come in at the window.
If we sit down sullen and inactive, in expectation that God should do all, we shall find ourselves miserably deceived.
If we will disbelieve everything because we cannot certainly know all things, we shall do much as wisely as he who would not use his legs, but sit still and perish because he had no wings.
If we wish to do good to men, we must pity
and not despise them.
If we would amend the world, we should mend ourselves and teach our children what they should be.
If we would endeavour like brave men to stand in the battle, surely we should feel the assistance from Heaven.
If we would have a genuine torment, let us wish for too much time.
If we would put ourselves in the place of other people, the jealousy and dislike which we often feel towards them would depart, and if we put others in our place, our pride and self-conceit would very much decrease.
If what happens does not make us richer, we
must bid it welcome if it make us wiser.
If "wise memory" is ever to prevail, there is need of much "wise oblivion" first.
If within the sophisticated man there is not an unsophisticated one, then he is but one of the devil's angels.
If women were humbler, men would be honester.
If wrong our hearts, our heads are right in vain.
If ye believe a' ye hear, ye may eat a' ye see.
If ye gi'e a woman a' her will, / Guid faith, she'll soon o'ergang ye.
If you agree to carry the calf, they'll make you carry the cow.
If you anticipate your inheritance, you can at last inherit nothing.
If you are idle, be not solitary; if you are solitary, be not idle.
If you cannot bite, never show your teeth.
If you cannot drive the engine, you can clear the road.
If you cannot have the best, make the best of what you have.
If you cannot make a man think as you do, make him do as you think.
If you can't get a loaf, don't throw away a cake.
If you can't heal the wound, don't tear it open.
If you can't pay for a thing, don't buy it. If you can't get paid for it, don't sell it. So you will have calm days, drowsy nights, and all the good business you have now, and none of the bad.
If you command wisely, you'll be obeyed cheerfully.
If you criticise a fine genius, the odds are that you are out of your reckoning, and instead of the poet, are censuring your own caricature of him.
If you desire faith, then you've faith enough.
If you desire to enjoy my light, you must supply
oil to my lamp.
If you dinna see the bottom, don't wade
If you dissemble sometimes your knowledge of that you are thought to know, you shall be thought, another time, to know that you know not.
If you do anything for the sake of the world, it will take good care that you shall not do it a second time.
If you do not err, you do not attain to understanding.
If you do not wish a man to do a thing, you
had better get him to talk about it; for the more men talk, the more likely they are to do nothing else.
If you don't do better to-day, you'll do worse to-morrow.
If you don't touch the rope, you won't ring the bell.
If you eat, eat a portion; do not eat all.
If you have a good seat, keep it.
If you have a special weakness, do not expose
it by attempting to do things which will bring it out.
If you have built castles in the air, your work need not be lost; that is where they should be. Now put the foundations under them.
If you have lived one day, you have seen all.
If you have tears, prepare to shed them now.
If you have time, don't wait for time.
If you know how to spend less than you get, you have the philosopher's stone.
If you lie upon roses when young, you will lie upon thorns when old.
If you listen to David's harp, you shall hear as many hearse-like airs as carols.
If you live among men, the heart must either break or turn to brass.
If you make a law against dancing-masters
imitating the fine gentleman, you should with as much reason enact, that no fine gentleman shall imitate the dancing-master.
If you pity rogues, you are no great friend of honest men.
If you pull one pig by the tail, all the rest will squeak.
If you put a chain around the neck of a slave, the other end fastens itself around your own.
If you raise one ghost, you will have the churchyard in motion.
If you read the Bible with a predetermination to
pick out every text you approve of, on these terms you will find it entirely intelligible and wholly delightful; but if you read it with a real purpose of trying to understand it, and obey, and so read it all through steadily, you will find it, out and out, the crabbedest and most difficult book you ever tried.
If you resolve to do right, you will soon do wisely; but resolve only to do wisely, and you will never do right.
If you run after two hares, you will catch neither.
If you say nothing, nobody will repeat it.
If you seek warmth of affection from a similar motive to that from which cats and dogs and slothful persons hug the fire, you are on the downward road.
If you sell the cow, you sell her milk too.
If you sit down a mere philosopher, you will rise almost an atheist.
If you tell me all you see, you'll tell what will make you feel shame.
If you throw all your money into the sea, yet count it before you let it go.
If you trust before you try, / You may repent before you die.
If you want a pretence to whip a dog, say
that he ate the frying-pan.
If you want learning, you must work for it.
If you want to gain a reputation for eccentricity and to be universally dreaded, blurt out the plain truth on all occasions.
If you want to know a man, make a solitary journey with him.
If you want work done, go to the man who is already fully occupied.
If you were as eager to discover good as evil,
and had the same delight in spreading the report of it; if good examples were made public as the bad ones always are, do you not think that the good would weigh down the balance? But gratitude speaks so low, and indignation so loudly, that you cannot hear but the last.
If you wish a wise answer, you must put a rational question.
If you wish to astonish the whole world, tell the simple truth.
If you would be a smith, begin with blowing the fire.
If you would be pungent, be brief, for it is with words as with sunbeams, the more they are condensed the deeper they burn.
If you would be well served, you must serve
yourself.
If you would cease to dislike a man, try to get nearer his heart.
If you would create something, you must be something.
If you would ensure a peaceful old age, be careful of the acts of each day of your youth; for with youth the deeds thereof are not to be left behind.
If you would eschew pain, eschew pleasure.
If you would have a faithful servant and one
you like, serve yourself.
If you would have it well done, you must do it yourself; you must not leave it to others.
If you would know and not be known, live in a city.
If you would learn to write, it is the street you must learn it in.
If you would love mankind, you should not expect too much from them.
If you would make Fortune your friend; when
people say money is to be got here and money is to be got there, take no notice; mind your own business; stay where you are; and secure all you can get, without stirring.
If you would rule the world quietly, you must keep it amused.
If you would slip into a round hole, you must make a ball of yourself.
If you would succeed, you must not be too good.
If you would understand an author, you must understand his age.
If you would work any man, know his nature
and fashions, and so lead him.
If your mind and its affections be pure, and sincere, and moderate, nothing shall have the power to enslave you.
If your wife is short, stoop to her.
Ignavis semper feriæ sunt
Ignavissimus quisque, et, ut res docuit, in periculo non ausurus, nimio verbis et lingua ferox
Ignavum fucos pecus a præsepibus arcent
Ignem gladio scrutare modo
Ignem ne gladio fodito
Ignis aurum probat, miseria fortes viros
Ignis fatuus
Ignis sacer
Ignobile vulgus
Ignoramus
Ignorance is a heavy burden.
Ignorance is a prolonged infancy, only deprived of its charm.
Ignorance is bold, and knowledge reserved.
Ignorance is the curse of God, knowledge the wing wherewith we fly to heaven.
Ignorance is the dominion of absurdity.
Ignorance is the mother of devotion.
Ignorance is the mother of impudence.
Ignorance is the night of the mind, but a night without moon or star.
Ignorance is the primary source of all misery and vice.
Ignorance is preferable to error.
Ignorance never settles a question.
Ignorance shuts its eyes and believes it is right.
Ignorant of guilt, I fear not shame.
Ignorantia facti excusat
Ignorantia legis excusat neminem
Ignoratio elenchi
Ignoratione rerum bonarum et malarum, maxime hominum vita vexatur
Ignorent populi, si non in morte probaris, / An scires adversa pati
Ignoscas aliis multa, nil tibi
Ignoti nulla cupido
Ignotis errare locis, ignota videre / Flumina
gaudebat, studio minuente laborem
Ignotum argenti pondus et auri
Ignotum per ignotius
Ihr Kinder, lernet jetzt genug, / Ihr lernt nichts mehr in alten Zeiten
Ihr sagt es sei nichts als Glück / Zu siegen ohne die Tacktick / Doch besser ohne Tacktick siegen / Als mit derselben unterliegen
Ihr sucht die Menschen zu benennen, /
und glaubt am Namen sie zu kennen; / Wer tiefer sieht, gesteht sich frei, / Es ist das Anonymes dabei
Il a inventé l'histoire
Il a la mer à boire
Il a la tête près du bonnet
Il a le diable au corps
Il a le verbe haut
Il a le vin mauvais
Il a les yeux à fleur de tête
Il a mangé son pain blanc le premier
Il a plus que personne l'esprit que tout le monde a
Il a travaillé pour le roi de Prusse
Il a vu le loup
Il aboye à tout le monde
Il arrive comme Mars en Carème
Il attend, que les alouettes lui tombent toutes rôties
Il buon mercato vuota la borsa
Il buono è buono, ma il meglio vince
Il can battuto dal bastone ha paura dell' ombra
Il castigo puo differirsi ma non si toglie
Il conduit bien sa barque
Il connaît l'univers et ne se connaît pas
Il coûte peu à amasser beaucoup de richesse, et beaucoup à en amasser peu
Il diavolo tenta tutti, ma l'ozioso tenta il diavolo
Il donne des entrailles à tous les mots
Il en est d'un homme qui aime, comme d'un moineau, pris à la glu; plus il se débat, plus il s'embarrasse
Il en fait ses choux gras
Il est aisé d'ajouter aux inventions des autres
Il est aisé d'aller à pied, quand on tient son cheval par la bride
Il est aux anges
Il est avis à vieille vache qu'elle ne fût oncques veau
Il est bien aisé à ceux qui se portent bien de
donner des avis aux malades
Il est bien difficile de garder un trésor dont tous les hommes ont la clef
Il est bien fou qui s'oublie
Il est bon d'être ferme par tempérament et flexible par réflexion
Il est bon d'être habile, mais non pas de le paraître
Il est comme l'oiseau sur la branche
Il est peu de distance de la roche Tarpéienne au Capitole
Il est plus aisé d'être sage pour les autres que pour soi-même
Il est plus honteux de se défier de ses amis que d'en être trompé
Il est souvent plus court et plus utile de cadrer aux autres que de faire que les autres s'adjustent à nous
Il est temps d'être sage quand on a la barbe au
menton
Il est tout prêché qui n'a cure de bien faire
Il est trop difficile de penser noblement, quand on ne pense que pour vivre
Il faisoit de necessité vertu
Il fallait un calculateur, ce fut un danseur qui l'obtint
Il faut attendre le boiteux
Il faut avaler bien de la fumée aux lampes avant que de devenir bon orateur
Il faut avoir pitié des morts
Il faut avoir une âme
Il faut de plus grandes vertus pour soutenir la bonne fortune que la mauvaise
Il faut en affrontant l'orage / Penser, vivre et
mourir en roi
Il faut hurler avec les loups
Il faut laver son linge sale en famille
Il faut payer de sa vie
Il faut perdre un véron pour pêcher un saumon
Il faut qu'une porte soit ouverte ou fermée
Il faut savoir s'ennuyer
Il faut sortir de la vie ainsi que d'un banquet, / Remerciant son hôte, et faisant son paquet
Il fuoco non s'estingue con fuoco
Il fut historien pour rester orateur
Il me faut du nouveau, n'en fût-il point au
monde
Il meglio è l'inimico del bene
Il meurt connu de tous et ne se connaît pas
Il mondo è di chi ha pazienza
Il mondo è fatto a scale; / Chi le scende, e chi le sale
Il mondo sta con tre cose: fare, disfare, e dare
ad intendere
Il monta sur ses grands chevaux
Il nage entre deux eaux
Il n'a ni bouche ni éperon
Il n'a pas inventé la poudre
Il n'a pas l'air, mais la chanson
Il n'appartient qu'aux grands hommes, d'avoir de grands défauts
Il n'attache pas ses chiens avec des saucisses
Il n'avait pas précisément des vices, mais il était rongé d'une vermine de petits défauts, dont on ne pouvait l'épurer
Il n'est d'heureux que qui croit l'être
Il n'est orgueil que de pauvre enrichi
Il n'est pas d'homme nécessaire
Il n'est pas échappé qui traîne son lien
Il n'est rien d'inutile aux personnes de sens
Il n'est sauce que d'appétit
Il ne fait rien, et nuit à qui veut faire
Il ne faut jamais se moquer des misérables, / Car qui peut s'assurer d'être toujours heureux?
Il ne faut pas nous fâcher des choses passées
Il ne faut pas parler latin devant les Cordeliers
Il ne faut pas voler avant que d'avoir des ailes
Il ne faut point parler de corde dans la famille d'un pendu
Il ne sait plus de quel bois faire flèche
Il ne sait sur quel pied danser
Il n'y a de nouveau que ce qui a vieilli
Il n'y a de nouveau que ce qui est oublié
Il n'y a de sots si incommodes que ceux qui ont de l'esprit
Il n'y a pas à dire
Il n'y a pas de cheval si bon qu'il ne bronche pas
Il n'y a pas de gens plus affairés que ceux qui
n'ont rien à faire
Il n'y a pas de petit ennemi
Il n'y a peut-être point de vérité qui ne soit à quelque esprit faux matière d'erreur
Il n'y a plus de Pyrénées
Il n'y a point au monde un si pénible métier que celui de se faire un grand nom. La vie s'achève que l'on a à peine ébauché son ouvrage
Il n'y a point de chemin trop long à qui marche
lentement et sans se presser, il n'y a point d'avantages trop éloignés à qui s'y prépare par la patience
Il n'y a point de plus cruelle tyrannie que celle que l'on exerce à l'ombre des lois et avec les couleurs de la justice
Il n'y a que la vérité qui blesse
Il n'y a que le matin en toutes choses
Il n'y a que le premier pas qui coûte
Il n'y a que les honteux qui perdent
Il n'y a que les morts qui ne reviennent pas
Il n'y a rien de si puissant qu'une république où l'on observe les lois, non pas par crainte, non pas par raison, mais par passion
Il n'y a rien que la crainte et l'espérance ne persuadent aux hommes
Il paraît qu'on n'apprend pas à mourir en tuant les autres
Il passa par la gloire, il passa par le crime, et il
n'est arrivé qu'au malheur
Il penseroso
Il plaît à tout le monde et ne saurait se plaire
Il porte le deuil de sa blanchisseuse
Il riso fa buon sangue
Il rit bien qui rit le dernier
Il sabio muda conscio, il nescio no
Il se fait entendre, à force de se faire écouter
Il se faut entr'aider; c'est la loi de nature
Il sent le fagot
Il tacer non fu mai scritto
Il tempo è un galant 'uomo
Il tempo buono viene una volta sola
Il tempo è una lima sorda
Il trouverait à tondre sur un œuf
Il va du blanc au noir
Il vaut mieux avoir affaire à Dieu qu'à ses saints
Il vaut mieux être fou avec tous, que sage tout seul
Il vaut mieux être marteau qu'enclume
Il vaut mieux être singe perfectionné qu'un Adam dégénéré
Il vaut mieux faire envie que pitié
Il vaut mieux tâcher d'oublier ses malheurs que d'en parler
Il vero punge, e la bugia unge
Il villano en su tierra, y el hidalgo donde quiera
Il volto sciolto, i pensieri stretti
Il y a anguille sous roche
Il y a bien des gens qu'on estime, parce qu'on ne les connaît point
Il y a dans la jalousie plus d'amour-propre que d'amour
Il y a des gens à qui la vertu sied presque
aussi mal que le vice
Il y a des gens auxquels il faut trois cent ans pour commencer voir une absurdité
Il y a des gens dégoûtants avec du mérite, et d'autres qui plaisent avec des défauts
Il y a des gens qui ressemblent aux vaudevilles, qu'on ne chante qu'un certain temps
Il y a des reproches qui louent, et des louanges qui médisent
Il y a des vérités qui ne sont pas pour tous
les hommes et pour tous les temps
Il y a encore de quoi glaner
Il y a fagots et fagots
Il y a plus de quarante ans que je dis de la prose sans que j'en susse rien
Il y a plus fous acheteurs que de fous vendeurs
Il y a quelque chose dans les malheurs de nos
meilleurs amis qui ne nous déplaît pas
Il y a souvent de l'illusion, de la mode, du caprice dans le jugement des hommes
Il y a une espèce de honte d'être heureux à la vue de certaines misères
Il y en a peu qui gagnent à être approfondis
Il y va de la vie
Iliacos intra muros peccatur et extra
Ilicet infandum cuncti contra omina bellum / Contra fata deum, perverso numine poscunt
Ilka
Ilka dog has his day.
Ilk happing bird, wee, helpless thing, / That, in the merry months of spring, / Delighted me to hear thee sing, / What comes o' thee? / Where wilt thou cower thy chittering wing, an' close thy e'e?
Ill bairns are best heard at hame.
Ill begun, ill done.
Ill can he rule the great that cannot reach the small.
Ill comes upon war's back.
Ill-doers are ill thinkers.
Ill fares the land, to hastening ills a prey, /
Where wealth accumulates and men decay.
Ill fortune never crushes that man whom good fortune deceived not.
Ill got, ill spent.
Ill-gotten wealth seldom descends to the third generation.
Ill habits gather by unseen degrees, / As brooks make rivers, rivers run to seas.
Ill hearing mak's ill rehearsing.
Ill-humour is nothing more than an inward feeling of our own want of merit, a dissatisfaction with ourselves.
Ill luck comes by pounds and goes away by ounces.
Ill news comes apace.
Ill weeds are not hurt by frost.
Ill weeds grow apace.
Illa dolet vere quæ sine teste dolet
Illa est agricolæ messis iniqua suo
Illa laus est, magno in genere et in divitiis maximis, / Liberos hominem educare, generi monumentum et sibi
Illa placet tellus in qua res parva beatum / Me facit, et tenues luxuriantur opes
Illa victoria viam ad pacem patefecit
Illæso lumine solem
Illam, quicquid agit, quoque vestigia flectit, /
Componit furtim, subsequiturque decor
Ille crucem sceleris pretium tulit, hic diadema
Ille igitur nunquam direxit brachia contra / Torrentem; nec civis erat qui libera posset / Verba animi proferre, et vitam impendere vero
Ille per extentum funem mihi posse videtur / Ire poeta, meum qui pectus inaniter angit / Irritat mulcet falsis terroribus implet / Ut magus: et modo me Thebis, modo ponit Athenis
Ille potens sui / Lætusque degit, cui licet in diem / Dixisse, Vixi: cras vel atra / Nube polum pater occupato / Vel sole puro
Ille sinistrorsum, hic dextrorsum, abit: unus
utrique / Error, sed variis illudit partibus
Ille terrarum mihi præter omnes / Angulus ridet
Ille vir, haud magna cum re, sed plenus fidei
Illi inter sese multa vi brachia tollunt / In numerum, versantque tenaci forcipe massam
Illi robur et æs triplex / Circa pectus erat, qui fragilem truci / Commisit pelago ratem / Primus
Illic apposito narrabis multa Lyæo
Illud amicitiæ sanctum ac venerabile nomen / Nunc tibi pro vili sub pedibusque jacet

Illustrious acts high raptures do infuse, / And every conqueror creates a muse.

Ils veulent être libres et ne savent pas être justes

Im Becher ersaufen mehr als im Meer

Imaginary evils soon become real ones by indulging our reflections on them.
Imagination is always the ruling and divine power, and the rest of the man is only the instrument which it sounds, or the tablet on which it writes.
Imagination is a mettled horse that will break the rider's neck when a donkey would have carried him to the end of his journey, slow but sure.
Imagination is but a poor matter when it has to part company with understanding.
Imagination is central; fancy, superficial.
Imagination is Eternity.
Imagination is the eye of the soul.
Imagination is the mightiest despot.
Imagination is too often accompanied with a somewhat irregular logic.
Imagination rules the world.
Imitation is born with us, but what we ought to imitate is not easily found.
Imitation is the sincerest flattery.
Imitation is suicide.
Immediate are the acts of God, more swift / Than time or motion.

Imperfection is in some sort essential to all that we know of life. It is the sign of life in a mortal body, that is, of a state of progress and change.
Imperfection means perfection hid, / Reserved in part to grace the after-time.

Might stop a hole to keep the wind away.

In a calm sea, every man is a pilot.

behaviour in a storm commends the wisdom of the pilot.
In a free country there is much complaining but little suffering; under a despotism, much suffering but little complaining.

In a great soul everything is great.
In a healthy state of the organism all wounds have a tendency to heal.
In a lawsuit nothing is certain but the expense.
In a leopard the spots are not observed.
In a lottery, where there is (at the lowest computation) ten thousand blanks to one prize, it is the most prudent choice not to venture.

more a man expands, the larger his aims.
In a noble race, levity without virtue is seldom found. In a mine of rubies, when shall we find pieces of glass?
In a poem there should be not only the poetry of images, but also the poetry of ideas.
In a symbol there is concealment and yet revelation, silence and speech acting together, some embodiment and revelation of the infinite, made to blend itself with the finite, to stand visible, and, as it were, attainable there.

making others suffer for us, did nobleness ever lie.

In æternum
In all battles, if you await the issue, each
fighter has prospered according to his right. His right and his might, at the close of the account, were the same.
In all faiths there is something true / ... Something that keeps the Unseen in view, / ... And notes His gifts with the worship due.
In all human action, those faculties will be strong which are used.
In all human narrative, it is the battle only, and not the victory, that can be dwelt on with advantage.
In all literary history there is no such figure as Dante, no such homogeneousness of life and works, such loyalty to ideas, such sublime irrecognition of the unessential.
In all matters prefer the less evil to the
greater, and solace yourself under any ill with the reflection that it might be worse.
In all provinces there are artists and artisans; men who labour mechanically in a department, without eye for the whole, not feeling that there is a whole; and men who inform and ennoble the humblest department with an idea of the whole, and habitually know that only in the whole is the partial to be truly discerned.
In all science error precedes the truth, and it is better it should go first than last.
In all situations
In all straits the good behave themselves with meekness and patience.
In all things that live there are certain irregularities
and deficiencies, which are not only signs of life, but sources of beauty.
In all things, to serve from the lowest station upwards is necessary.
In all times it is only individuals that have advanced science, not the age.
In all true work, were it but true hand-labour, there is something of divineness.
In all vital action the manifest purpose and effort of Nature is, that we should be unconscious of it.... Nature so meant it with us; it is so we are made.

In ambiguo
In America you can get tea, and coffee, and meat every day. But the only true America is that country where you are at liberty to pursue such a mode of life as may enable you to do without these.
In an aristocratical institution like England, not trial by jury, but the dinner is the capital institution. It is the mode of doing honour to a stranger to invite him to eat, and has been for many a hundred years.

every jacket there is a man.

In every country the sun rises in the morning.
In every creed there are two elements--the Divine substance and the human form. The form must change with the changing thoughts of men; and even the substance may come to shine with clearer light, and to reveal unexpected glories, as God and man come nearer together.

we are not like our fathers.

In every great epoch there is some one idea at work which is more powerful than any other, and which shapes the events of the time and determines their ultimate issues.

fiery war; occasion needs but fan them, and they blaze.

in sickness, hate trouble, seek quiet and rest.

In Heaven's sight the mere wish to pray is prayer.
In her eyes that never weep, lightnings are laid asleep.

In all the others, all she loves is love.

In limine

In loco parentis

In love we are all fools alike.

In matters of conscience, first thoughts are best; in matters of prudence, last thoughts are best.

In mediæval art, truth is first, beauty second; in modern art, beauty is first, truth second.

In memoriam
In men we various ruling passions find; / In
women, two almost divide the mind; / Those, only fix'd, they first or last obey, / The love of pleasure and the love of sway.
In mercatura facienda multæ fallaciæ et quasi præstigiæ exercentur
In misfortune, in error, and when the time appointed for certain affairs is about to elapse, a servant who hath his master's welfare at heart ought to speak unasked.
In moderating, not in satisfying desires, lies peace.
In modern England the ordinary habits of life and modes of education produce great plainness of mind in middle-aged women.
In morals, as in art, saying is nothing, doing
is all.
In morals good-will is everything, but in art it is ability.
In morals, what begins in fear usually ends in wickedness; in religion, what begins in fear usually ends in fanaticism.
In much corn is some cockle.
In much wisdom is much grief, and he that increaseth knowledge increaseth sorrow.
In my Father's house are many mansions.
In my virtue
In Nature there's no blemish but the mind; / None can be called deformed but the unkind.
In Nature things move violently to their places, and calmly in their place; so virtue in ambition is violent, in authority settled and calm.
In Nature we never see anything isolated, but everything in connection with something else which is before it, beside it, under it, and over it.
In necessariis unitas, in dubiis libertas, in
omnibus charitas
In nine cases out of ten, the evil tongue belongs to a disappointed man.
In no time or epoch can the Highest be spoken of in words--not in many words, I think, ever.
In nocte consilium
In nomine
In nomine Domini incipit omne malum
In nubibus
In nuce Ilias
In obscuro
In old age nothing any longer astonishes us.
In old times men used their powers of painting
to show the objects of faith; in later times they used the objects of faith to show their powers of painting.
In omni re vincit imitationem veritas
In omnia paratus
In omnibus quidem, maxime tamen in jure, æquitas est
In one thing men of all ages are alike; they have believed obstinately in themselves.
In oratory the will must predominate.
In order to do great things, it is necessary to live as if one were never to die.
In order to love mankind, we must not expect too much of them.
In order to manage an ungovernable beast, he must be stinted in his provender.
In our age of down-pulling and disbelief, the very devil has been pulled down; you cannot so much as believe in a devil.
In our fine arts, not imitation, but creation, is
the aim.
In our judgment of human transactions the law of optics is reversed; we see the most indistinctly the objects which are close around us.
In our own breast, there or nowhere flows the fountain of true pleasure.
In pace leones, in prælio cervi
In pain is a new time born.
In pari materia
In partibus infidelium
In peace, there's nothing so becomes a man / As modest stillness and humility; / But when the blast of war blows in our ears, / Then imitate the action of the tiger; / Stiffen the sinews, summon up the blood, / Disguise fair Nature with hard-favour'd rage, / Then lend the eye a terrible aspect; / Let it pry through the portage of the head / Like the brass cannons.
In peace, who is not wise?
In perfect wedlock, the man, I should say, is the head, but the woman the heart, with which he cannot dispense.
In perpetuam rei memoriam
In pertusum ingerimus dicta dolium
In petto
In pios usus
In Plato's opinion, man was made for philosophy; in Bacon's opinion, philosophy was made for man.
In pleno
In politics, as in life, we must above all things wish only for the attainable.
In politics, merit is rewarded by the possessor being raised, like a target, to a position to be fired at.
In politics, what begins in fear usually ends
in folly.
In pontificalibus
In portu quies
In posse
In practical life, the wisest and soundest men avoid speculation.
In præsenti
In pretio pretium est; dat census honores, / Census amicitias; pauper ubique jacet
In pride, in reasoning pride, our error lies; / All quit their sphere and rush into the skies.
In principatu commutando, civium / Nil præter domini nomen mutant pauperes
In private grieve, but with a careless scorn; / In public seem to triumph, not to mourn.
In proportion as one simplifies his life, the
laws of the universe will appear less complex, and solitude will not be solitude, nor poverty poverty, nor weakness weakness.
In propria persona
In prosperity caution, in adversity patience.
In prosperity no altars smoke.
In puris naturalibus
In quietness and in confidence shall be your
strength.
In quite common things much depends on choice and determination, but the highest which falls to our lot comes from no man knows whence.
In radiant, all-irradiating insight, a burning interest, and the glorious, melodious, perennial veracity that results from these two, lies the soul of all worth in all speaking men.
In re
In referenda gratia, debemus imitari agros fertiles qui plus multo afferunt quam acceperunt
In regard to a book, the main point is what it
brings me, what it suggests to me.
In regard to virtue, each one finds certainty by consulting his own heart.
In religion as in friendship, they who profess most are ever the least sincere.
In religion, the sentiment is all; the ritual or ceremony indifferent.
In religion / What damnéd error but some sober brow / Will bless it and approve it with a text?
In rerum natura
In resolving to do our work well, is the only sound foundation of any religion whatsoever; and by that resolution only, and what we have done, and not by our belief, Christ will judge us, as He has plainly told us He will.
In reverence is the chief joy and power of life.
In Rome the Ten Commandments consist of the ten letters, Da pecuniam, Give money.
In sæcula sæculorum
In sanguine fœdus
In saying aye or no, the very safety of our country and the sum of our well-being lies.
In science read the newest works; in literature, the oldest.
In science the new is an advance; but in morals, as contradicting our inner ideals and historic idols, it is ever a retrogression.
In science we have to consider two things: power and circumstance.
In se magna ruunt
In seipso totus, teres, atque rotundus
In self-trust all the virtues are comprehended.
In serum rem trahere
In service, care or coldness / Doth ratably thy fortunes mar or make.
In situ
In small proportion we just beauties see, / And in short measures life may perfect be.
In so complex a thing as human nature, we must consider it hard to find rules without exceptions.
In solitude the mind gains strength and learns to lean upon itself.
In solo Deo salus
In solo vivendi causa palato est
In some men a certain mediocrity of mind helps to make them wise.
In some men there is a malignant passion to destroy the works of genius, literature, and freedom.
In some sort, love is greater than God.
In some things all, in all things none, are crossed.
In spite of all his faults, there is no creature
worthier of affection than man.
In spite of all misfortunes, there is still enough to satisfy one.
In spite of all the evil that is said of the unfortunates, kings sometimes have their good qualities too.
In spite of seeming difference, men are all of one pattern.
In statu quo
In stinting wisdom, greatest wisdom lies.
In such a world as this a man who is rich in himself is like a bright, warm, happy room at Christmastide, while without are the frost and snow of a December night.
In taking revenge, a man is but even with his enemy; but in passing it over, he is superior.
In tale or history your beggar is ever the first antipode to your king.
In tenui labor, at tenuis non gloria
In terrorem
In that fire-whirlwind
creation and destruction proceed together; ever as the ashes of the old are blown out, do organic filaments of the new mysteriously spin themselves; and amid the rushing and waving of the whirlwind element come tones of a melodious death-song, which end not but in tones of a more melodious birth-song.
In the adversity of our best friends we always find something that does not altogether displease us.
In the balance, hero dust / Is vile as vulgar clay: / Thou, mortality, art just / To all that pass away.

In the career of nations no less than of men,
the error of their intellect and the hardening of their hearts may be accurately measured by their denial of spiritual power.
In the catalogue ye go for men.
In the childhood of nations speaking was singing; let this be repeated in the childhood of the individual.
In the coldest flint there is hot fire.
In the confidence of youth man imagines that very much is under his control; in the disappointment of old age, very little.
In the darkest spot on earth / Some love is
found.
In the degree in which you delight in the life of any creature, you can see it; not otherwise.
In the denial of self is the beginning of all that is truly generous and noble.
In the destitution of the wild desert does our young Ishmael acquire for himself the highest of all possessions, that of self-help.
In the divine commandment, "Thou shalt not steal," if well understood, is comprised the whole Hebrew decalogue, with Solon's and Lycurgus's constitutions, Justinian's pandects, the Code Napoleon, and all codes, catechisms, divinities, moralities whatsoever that man has devised (and enforced with altar-fire and gallows-ropes) for his social guidance.
In the division of the inheritance, friendship
standeth still.
In the dullest existence there is a sheen of inspiration or of madness (thou partly hast it in thy choice which of the two) that gleams in from the circumambient eternity, and colours with its own hues our little islet of time.
In the dusk the plainest writing is illegible.
In the end / Things will mend.
In the end we retain from our studies only that which we practically apply.
In the evening one may praise the day.
In the exact proportion in which men are bred capable of warm affection, common-sense, and self-command, and are educated to love, to think, and to endure, they become noble, live happily, die calmly, are remembered with perpetual honour by their race, and for the perpetual good of it.
In the eye of the Supreme, dispositions hold the place of actions.
In the face of every human being his history stands plainly written, his innermost nature steps forth to the light; yet they are the fewest who can read and understand.
In the fact that hero-worship exists, has existed, and will for ever exist universally among mankind, mayest thou discern the cornerstone of living rock, whereon all politics for the remotest time may stand secure.
In the family where the house-father rules
secure, there dwells the peace
thou wilt in vain seek for elsewhere in the wide world outside.
In the field none other can supply our place, each must stand alone,--on himself must rely.
In the fine arts, as in many other things, we know well only what we have not learned.
In the fog of good and evil affections, it is hard for man to walk forward in a straight line.
In the godlike only has man strength and freedom.
In the good as well as in the evil of life, less
depends upon what befalls us than upon the way in which we take it.
In the great duel
In the great hand of God I stand.
In the grimmest rocky wildernesses of existence there are blessed well-springs, there is an everlasting guiding star.
In the hands of genius the driest stick becomes an Aaron's rod, and buds and blossoms out in poetry.
In the husband, wisdom; in the wife, gentleness.
In the interchange of thought use no coin but gold and silver.
In the land of promise a man may die of hunger.
In the lexicon of youth, which fate reserves for a bright manhood, there is no such word as fail.
In the meanest hut there is a romance, if you knew the hearts there.
In the midst of life we are in death.
In the midst of the sun is the light, in the midst of the light is the truth, and in the midst of the truth is the imperishable being.
In the mind, as in a field, though some things may be sown and carefully brought up, yet what springs naturally is the most pleasing.
In the mirror we see the face; in wine, the
heart.
In the modesty of fearful duty / I read as much as from the rattling tongue / Of saucy and audacious eloquence.
In the morning mountains; / In the evening fountains.
In the morning of life, work; in the mid-day, give counsel; in the evening, pray.
In the morning sow thy seed, and in the evening withhold not thine hand: for thou knowest not whether shall prosper, either this or that, or whether they both shall be alike good.
In the multitude of words there wanteth not
sin.
In the ordinary concerns of life, moral energy is more serviceable than brilliant parts; while in the more important, these latter are of little weight without it, evaporating only in brief and barren flashes.
In the perishable petals of the flower there resides more spirit and life than in the lumpish granite boulder that has defied the tear and wear of thousands of years.
In the place where the tree falleth, there it shall lie.
In the pursuit of intellectual pleasure lies every virtue; of sensual, every vice.
In the religion of Christ, as in the philosophy
of Hegel, the negative principle is the creative, or determinative, principle. Christianity begins in No, subsists in No, and survives in No, to the spirit of the world; this it at first peremptorily spurns, and then calmly disregards as of no account.
In the same measure in which you wish to receive, you must give. If you wish for a whole heart, give a whole life.
In the smallest cottage there is room enough for two lovers.
In the spiritual world, as in the astronomical, it is the earth that turns and produces the phenomena of the heavens.
In the spiritual world there is properly no in and no out.
In the state nobody can enjoy life in peace,
but everybody must govern; in art, nobody will enjoy what has been produced, but every one wants to reproduce on his own account.
In the sweat of thy brow shalt thou eat thy bread.
In the true Utopia, man will rather harness himself with his oxen to his plough, than leave the devil to drive it.
In the unhappy man forget the foe.
In the utmost solitudes of Nature, the existence of hell seems to me as legibly declared by a thousand spiritual utterances as that of heaven.
In the way of righteousness is life; and in the
pathway thereof there is no death.
In the wilderness of life there are springs and palm-trees.
In the winter, warmth stands for all virtue.
In the works of many celebrated authors men are mere personifications. We have not a jealous man, but jealousy; not a traitor, but perfidy; not a patriot, but patriotism. The mind of Bunyan, on the contrary, was so imaginative that personifications, when he dealt with them, became men.
In the world's opinion marriage, as in a play, winds up everything; whereas it is, in fact, the beginning of everything.
In the world-strife now waging, the victory
cannot be by violence; and every conquest under the Prince of War retards the standards of the Prince of Peace.
In the wreck of noble lives / Something immortal still survives.
In theatro ludus
In these days, whether we like it or not, the power is with the tongue.
In these sick days, when the born of heaven first descries himself in a world such as ours, richer than usual in two things, in truths grown obsolete, and trades grown obsolete--what can the fool think but that it is all a den of lies, wherein whoso will not speak lies and act lies must stand idle and despair?
In these times we fight for ideas, and newspapers
are our fortresses.
In things pertaining to enthusiasm, no man is sane who does not know how to be insane on proper occasions.
In things that may have a double sense, it is good to think the better was intended; so shall we still both keep our friends and quietness.
In this blunder still you find, / All think their little set mankind.
In this theatre of man's life, it is reserved only for God and angels to look on.
In this wild element of a life, man has to
struggle onwards; now fallen, deep-abased; and ever, with tears, repentance, with bleeding heart, he has to rise again, struggle again, still onwards. That his struggle be a faithful, unconquerable one--that is the question of questions.
In this world, full often our joys are only the tender shadows which our sorrows cast.
In this world it is not what we take up, but what we give up, that makes us rich.
In this world there is one godlike thing, the essence from first to last of all of godlike in it--the veneration done to human worth by the hearts of men.
In thy breast are the stars of thy fate.
In thy thriving still misdoubt some evil: / Lest
gaining gain on thee, and make thee dim / To all things else.
In time comes he whom God sends.
In time the savage bull doth bear the yoke.
In time we hate that which we often fear.
In times of anarchy one may seem a despot in order to be a saviour.
In times of danger it is proper to be alarmed
until danger be near at hand; but when we perceive that danger is near, we should oppose it as if we were not afraid.
In times of misfortune men's understandings even are sullied.
In times of necessity the words of the wise are worthy to be observed.
In too much disputing truth is lost.

In toto
In toto et pars continetur
In transitu
In treachery it is not the fraud, but the cold-heartedness, that is chiefly dreadful.
In trinitate robur
In true marriage lies / Nor equal, nor unequal:
each fulfils / Defect in each, and always thought in thought, / Purpose in purpose, will in will, they grow, / The single pure and perfect animal, / The two-cell'd heart beating, with one full stroke, / Life.

In vacuo

In vain does the mill clack / If the miller his
hearing lack.

In veritate victoria
In vino veritas
In vitium ducit culpæ fuga

the heart of another.
In well-regulated civil society there is scarcely a more melancholy suffering to be undergone than what is forced on us by the neighbourhood of an incipient player on the flute or violin.
In wenig Stunden / Hat Gott das Rechte gefunden
In wonder all philosophy began; in wonder it ends; and admiration fills up the interspace.
In wonder the spirits fly not as in fear, but only settle.
In working well, if travail you sustain, / Into
the wind shall lightly pass the pain, / But of the deed the glory shall remain.
In works of labour or of skill, / I would be busy too, / For Satan finds some mischief still / For idle hands to do.
In writing readily, it does not follow that you write well; but in writing well, you must be able to write readily.
In your own country your name, in other countries your appearance.
In youth and beauty wisdom is but rare.
In youth it is too early, in old age it is too late
to marry.
In youth, one has tears without grief; in age, grief without tears.
Inactivity cannot be led to good.
Inanis verborum torrens
Incedis per ignes / Suppositos cineri doloso
Incedit in Scyllam qui vult vitare Charybdim
Incendit omnem feminæ zelus domum
Incense is a tribute for gods only but a poison for mortals.
Inceptis gravibus plerumque et magna professis, / Purpureus, late qui splendeat, unus et alter / Adsuitur pannus

Incerti sunt exitus belli
Incertum est quo te loco mors expectet; itaque in omni loco illam expecta

Incessu patuit Dea
Incidents ought not to govern policy; but
policy, incidents.
Inclusio unius est exclusio alterius
Incoctum generoso pectus honesto
Inconsiderate persons do not think till they they speak; or they speak, and then think.
Inconsistencies of opinion, arising from changes of circumstances, are often justifiable.
Increased means and increased leisure are the two civilisers of men.
Incrédules les plus crédules
Incudi reddere
Inde datæ leges ne fortior omnia posset
Inde iræ et lacrimæ
Indecision and delay are the parents of failure.
Independence, in all kinds, is rebellion; if unjust
rebellion, why parade it and everywhere prescribe it.
Independence, in all kinds, is rebellion. Were your superiors worthy to govern, and you worthy to obey, reverence for them were even your only possible freedom.
Independence, like honour, is a rocky island without a beach.
Independence you had better cease to talk of, for you are dependent not only on every act of people whom you never heard of, who are living round you, but on every past act of what has been dust for a thousand years.
Index expurgatorius
Indica tigris agit rabida cum tigride pacem /
Perpetuam: sævis inter se convenit ursis. / Ast homini ferrum letale incude nefanda / Produxisse parum est
Indictum sit
Indigestion is the devil--nay, 'tis the devil and all. It besets a man in every one of his senses.
Indigna digna habenda sunt hæres quæ facit
Indignant good sense is often the perfection of absurdity.
Indignante invidia florebit justus
Indigne vivit per quem non vivit alter
Indignor quidquam reprehendi, non quia crasse / Compositum, illepideve putetur, sed quia nuper
Individuality is everywhere to be spared and respected, as the root of everything good.
Individuality is of far more account than nationality.
Individually man is a weak being, but strong
in union with others.
Individuals may form communities, but it is institutions alone can create a nation.
Individuals must be modest, but modesty degrades nations.
Indocilis pauperiem pati
Indocilis privata loqui
Indocti discant, et ament meminisse periti
Indolence and stupidity are first cousins.
Indolence is the paralysis of the soul.
Indolence is the sleep of the mind.
Industria floremus
Industriæ nil impossibile
Industry is Fortune's right hand, and Frugality her left.
Industry is the parent of success.
Industry is the parent of virtue.
Industry need not wish.
Indutus virtute ab alto
Inest et formicæ sua bilis
Inest sua gratia parvis
Inest virtus et mens interrita lethi
Infancy is the perpetual Messiah, which comes into the arms of fallen men, and pleads with them to return to Paradise.
Infancy presents body and spirit in unity; the
body is all animated.
Infandum, regina, jubes renovare dolorem
Infecta pace
Inferior poetry is an injury to the good, inasmuch as it takes away the freshness of rhymes, blunders upon and gives a wretched commonality to good thoughts, and, in general, adds to the weight of human weariness in a most woeful and culpable manner.
Infidelity is not always built upon doubt, for this is diffident; nor philosophy always upon wisdom, for this is meek; but pride is neither.
Infidelity, like death, admits of no degrees.
Infinite is the help man can yield to man.
Infinite pity, yet also infinite rigour of law; it is so Nature is made.
Infinite toil would not enable you to sweep away a mist; but, by ascending a little, you may often overlook it altogether.
Inflatum plenumque Nerone propinquo
Inflict not on an enemy every injury in your
power, for he may afterwards become your friend.
Influence is to be measured not by the extent of surface it covers, but by its kind.
Infra dignitatem
Ingenii largitor venter
Ingeniis patuit campus, certusque merenti / Stat favor: ornatur propriis industria donis

Ingenio non ætate adipiscitur sapientia
Ingenio stat sine morte decus

Ingenium ingens / Inculto latet hoc sub corpore
Ingenium mala sæpe movent
Ingenium res adversæ nudare solent, celare secundæ
Ingens telum necessitas
Ingentes animos angusto in corpore versant
Ingenuas didicisse fideliter artes / Emollit mores, nec sinit esse feros
Ingrata patria, ne ossa quidem habebis
Ingratis servire nefas
Ingratitude and compassion never cohabit in the same breast.
Ingratitude drieth up wells, / And time bridges fells.
Ingratitude is a crime so shameful, that the man was never yet found who would acknowledge himself guilty of it.
Ingratitude! thou marble-hearted fiend, / More
hideous, when thou show'st thee in a child, / Than the sea-monster.
Ingratus est qui remotis testibus agit gratiam
Ingratus unus miseris omnibus nocet
Inimicus et invidus vicinorum oculus
Iniqua nunquam regna perpetua manent

Initium est salutis, notitia peccati

Injuriæ spretæ exolescunt, si irascaris agnitæ videntur
Injuriam qui facturus est jam facit
Injuriarum remedium est oblivio
Injuries come only from the heart.
Injusta ab justis impetrare non decet; / Justa autem ab injustis petere, insipientia est
Inmost things are all melodious, naturally utter themselves in song. The meaning of song goes deep.
Innocence has a friend in heaven.
Innocence is a flower which withers when touched, and blooms not again though watered with tears.
Inopem me copia fecit
Inopi beneficium bis dat, qui dat celeriter
Inops, potentem dum vult imitari, perit

Inquisitiveness as seldom cures jealousy as drinking in a fever quenches the thirst.

Insanity is often the logic of an accurate
mind overtasked.
Insanus omnis furere credit cæteros

Insipientis est dicere, Non putarem

Insita mortalibus natura, propere sequi quæ piget inchoare
