Insouciance
Insperata accidunt magis sæpe quam quæ speres
Inspicere, tanquam in speculum, in vitas omnium / Jubeo, atque ex aliis sumere exemplum sibi
Inspiration must find answering inspiration.
Inspirations that we deem our own are our
divine foreshadowing and foreseeing of things beyond our reason and control.
Inspiring bold John Barleycorn! / What dangers thou canst make us scorn!
Instar omnium
Instead of the piteous and frightful figure of Death, stepping whip to hand by the peasant's side in the field, ... place there a radiant angel, sowing with full hands the blessed grain in the smoking furrow.
Instead of watching the bird as it flies above our heads, we chase his shadow along the ground; and, finding we cannot grasp it, we conclude it to be nothing.
Instinct is a great matter; I was a coward on
instinct.
Instinct is intelligence incapable of self-consciousness.
Instruction does much, but encouragement everything.
Intaminatis fulget honoribus
Integer vitæ scelerisque purus / Non eget Mauris jaculis neque arcu
Integrity gains strength by use.
Integrity is the shortest and nearest way to our end, carrying us thither in a straight line, and will hold out and last longest.
Integrity without knowledge is weak and useless, and knowledge without integrity is dangerous and dreadful.
Intellect annuls fate; so far as a man thinks, he is free.
Intellect is aristocratic; charity is democratic.
Intellect is not speaking and logicising; it
is seeing and ascertaining.
Intellect lies behind genius, which is intellect constructive.
Intellectual fairness is often only another name for indolence and inconclusiveness of mind, just as love of truth is sometimes a fine phrase for temper.
Intellectual tasting of life will not supersede muscular activity.
Intelligabilia, non intellectum, fero
Intemperans adolescentia effetum corpus
tradet senectuti
Intemperate wits will spare neither friend nor foe, and make themselves the common enemies of mankind.
Intense study of the Bible will keep any man from being vulgar in point of style.
Inter alia
Inter amicos omnium rerum communitas
Inter arma leges silent
Inter canem et lupum
Inter cetera mala, hoc quoque habet stultitia proprium, semper incipit vivere
Inter delicias semper aliquid sævi nos strangulat
Inter Græcos græcissimus, inter Latinos latinissimus
Inter malleum et incudem
Inter nos
Inter nos sanctissima divitiarum / Majestas
Inter pueros senex
Inter spem curamque, timores inter et iras, / Omnem crede diem tibi diluxisse supremum: / Grata superveniet quæ non sperabitur hora
Inter sylvas Academi quærere verum
Inter utrumque tene
Inter vivos
Interdum lacrymæ pondera vocis habent
Interdum stultus bene loquitur
Interdum vulgus rectum videt, est ubi peccat
Interea gustus elementa per omnia quærunt, / Nunquam animo pretiis obstantibus; interius si / Attendas, magis illa juvant, quæ pluris emuntur
Interest blinds some people and enlightens others.
Interest is the spur of the people, but glory that of great souls.
Interest reipublicæ ut quisque re sua bene utatur
Interest speaks all sorts of tongues, and plays
all sorts of parts, even the part of the disinterested.
Interim fit aliquid
Into a mouth shut flies fly not.
Into contradicting / Be thou never led away; / When with the ignorant they strive, / The wise to folly fall away.
Into each life some rain must fall, / Some days must be dark and dreary.
Intolerabilius nihil est quam fœmina dives
Intra muros
Introite, nam et hic dii sunt
Intuition is the clear conception of the whole
at once. It seldom belongs to man to say without presumption, "I came, I saw, I conquered."
Intus et in cute novi hominem
Intus et in jecore ægro / Nascuntur domini
Intus si recte, ne labora
Intuta quæ indecora
Inveni portum, Spes et Fortuna valete, / Sat
me lusistis, ludite nunc alios
Invent first, and then embellish.
Invention breeds invention.
Invention is the talent of youth, and judgment of age.
Inventions have all been invented over and over fifty times. Man is the arch-machine, of which all these shifts drawn from himself are toy models.
Invia virtuti nulla est via
Invidia gloriæ comes
"Invidia," jealousy of your neighbour's good, has been, since dust was first made flesh, the curse of man; and "charitas," the desire to do your neighbour grace, the one source of all human glory, power and material blessing.
Invidia Siculi non invenere tyranni / Tormentum majus
Invidiam ferre aut fortis aut felix potest
Invidiam placare paras, virtute relicta?
Invidus alterius macrescit rebus opimis
Invidus, iracundus, iners, vinosus, amator, / Nemo adeo ferus est, ut non mitescere possit, / Si modo culturæ patientem commodet aurem
Invisa nunquam imperia retinentur diu
Invisa potentia, atque miseranda vita eorum, qui se metui quam amari malunt
Invita Minerva
Invitat culpam qui peccatum præterit
Invitum qui servat idem facit occidenti
Invitum sequitur honos
Inward cheerfulness is an implicit praise and thanksgiving to Providence under all its dispensations.
Ipsæ rursum concedite sylvæ
Ipse dixit
Ipse docet quid agam: fas est et ab hoste doceri
Ipse Jupiter, neque pluens omnibus placet, neque abstinens
Ipse pavet; nec qua commissas flectat habenas, / Nec scit qua sit iter; nec, si sciat, imperet illis
Ipsissima verba
Ipso facto
Ipso jure
Ir por lana, y volver trasquilado
Ira furor brevis est; animum rege, qui, nisi paret, / Imperat: hunc frenis, hunc tu compesce catena
Ira quæ tegitur nocet; / Professa perdunt
odia vindictæ locum
Irarum tantos volvis sub pectore fluctus?
Iratus cum ad se redit, sibi tum irascitur
Ire tamen restat, Numa quo devenit et Ancus
Iron sharpeneth iron; so a man sharpeneth the countenance of his friend.
Iron with often handling is worn to nothing.
Irony is an insult conveyed in the form of a compliment.
Irony is jesting hidden behind gravity.
Irremeabilis unda
Irresolution loosens all our joints; like an ague, it shakes not this limb or that limb, but all the body is at once in a fit. The irresolute man hatches nothing, but addles all his actions.
Irritabis crabrones
Irritation, like friction, is likely to generate heat instead of progress.
Irrthum verlässt uns nie; doch ziehet ein höher Bedürfniss immer den strebenden Geist leise zur Wahrheit hinan
Is a man one whit the better because he is grown great in other men's esteem?
Is any place so inaccessible that an ass laden with gold cannot penetrate?
Is beauty vain because it will fade? Then are earth's green robe and heavens light vain.
Is cadet ante senem, qui sapit ante diem
Is common opinion the standard of merit?
Is habitus animorum fuit, ut pessimum facinus auderent pauci, plures vellent, omnes paterentur
Is it in destroying and pulling down that skill is displayed? The shallowest understanding, the rudest hand, is more equal to that task.
Is it not astonishing that the love of repose keeps us in continual agitation?
Is it not strange that men should be so ready
to fight for religion and so reluctant to observe its precepts?
Is it not the same to whoso wears a shoe as if the earth were thatched all over with leather?
Is it right to despair, and shall truth make us sad?
Is maxime divitiis utitur, qui minime divitiis indiget
Is mihi demum vivere et frui anima videtur, qui aliquo negotio intentus, præclari facinoris aut artis bonæ famam quærit
Is mihi videtur amplissimus qui sua virtute in
altiorem locum pervenit
Is not belief the true God-announcing miracle?
Is not cant the
which all falsehoods, imbecilities, abominations body themselves, from which no true thing can come?
Is not light greater than fire? It is the same element in a state of purity.
Is not marriage an open question when it is alleged, from the beginning of the world, that such as are in the institution wish to get out, and such as are out wish to get in?
Is not shame the soil of all virtue, of all good
manners and good morals?
Is ordo vitio careto, cæteris specimen esto
Is sapiens qui se ad casus accommodet omnes; / Stultus pugnat in adversis ire natator aquis
Is that a wonder which happens in two hours; and does it cease to be wonderful if happening in two millions?
 (Chri
Is the God present, felt in my own heart, a thing which Herr von Voltaire will dispute out of me or dispute into me? To the "worship origin and genesis thou pleasest, has not that worship originated and been generated; is it not here? Feel it in thy heart and then say whether it is of God!
Is the jay more precious than the lark because
his feathers are more beautiful?
Is there anything of its own nature beautiful or not beautiful? The beauty of a thing is even that by which it shineth.
Is there evil in a city, and the Lord hath not done it?
Is there for honest poverty / That hangs his head, and a' that? / The coward slave we pass him by, / We dare be poor for a' that.
Is there no God, then? but at best an absentee God, sitting idle, ever since the first Sabbath, at the outside of His universe, and seeing it go?
Is there no stoning save with flint and rock?
Is there no way to bring home a wandering sheep but by worrying him to death?
Is this a dagger which I see before me, / The handle toward my hand? Come, let me clutch thee.
Is thy complexion sour? / Then keep such company.
Is your trumpeter dead, that you are obliged to praise yourself?
Isaac's fond blessing may not fall on scorn, /
Nor Balaam's curse on love which God hath blest.
Island ez hinn besta haud sun solinn shinnar uppà
Isolation is the sum-total of wretchedness to a man.
Ist's Gottes Werk, so wird's besteh'n / Ist's Menschenwerk, wird's untergeh'n
Ista decens facies longis vitiabitur annis; / Rugaque in antiqua fronte senilis erit
Istæc in me cudetur faba
Istuc est sapere, non quod ante pedes modo est / Videre, sed etiam illa quæ futura sunt / Prospicere
Istuc est sapere, qui, ubicunque opus sit, animum possis flectere
It
It belongs to great men to have great defects.
It can do us no harm to look at what is extraordinary with our own eyes.
It chanceth in an hour that cometh not in seven years.
It costs more to revenge injuries than to bear
them.
It dawns no sooner for one's early rising.
It exalteth a man from earthly things to love those that are heavenly.
It happens as with cages, the birds without despair to get in, and those within despair of getting out.
It happens to men of learning as to ears of corn; they shoot up and raise their heads high while they are empty; but when full and swelled with grain, they begin to flag and droop.
It has been well said that our anxiety does
not empty to-morrow of its sorrows, but only empties to-day of its strength.
It is a bad trade that of censor; he is sure to incur the hatred of those he censures, without finding them improved by the correction.
It is a beautiful trait in the lover's character, that he thinks no evil of the object loved.
It is a beggarly conception to judge as if poetry should always be capable of a prose rendering.
It is a brave act of valour to contemn death; but when life is more terrible than death, it is then the truest valour to dare to live.
It is a characteristic of true genius to disturb
all settled ideas.
It is a clear gain to sacrifice pleasure in order to avoid pain.
It is a common error to think that in politics legislation is everything and administration nothing.
It is a common failing of old men to attribute all wisdom to themselves.
It is a common law of Nature, which no time will ever change, that superiors shall rule their inferiors.
It is a custom / More honoured in the breach
than the observance.
It is a damnable audacity to bring forth that torturing Cross, and the Holy One who suffers on it, and to expose them to the light of the sun, which hid its face when a reckless world forced such a sight on it; to take these mysterious secrets, in which the divine depth of sorrow lies hid, and play with them, fondle them, trick them out, and rest not till the most reverend of all solemnities appears vulgar and paltry.
It is a delusion
makes man better. As well believe that the rust makes the knife sharp, dirt promotes purity, and mud clarifies the stream.
"It is a devout imagination."
It is a fair and holy office to be a prophet of Nature.
It is a fine thing to command, though it were
but a herd of cattle.
It is a foul bird that dirties its own nest.
It is a golden rule not to judge men according to their opinions, but according to the effect these opinions have on their character.
It is a good divine that follows his own instructions.
It is a good horse that never stumbles, and a good wife that never grumbles.
It is a good thing to stay away till one's company
is desired, but not so good to stay after it is desired.
It is a grave offence to bind a Roman citizen, a crime to flog him, almost the act of a parricide to put him to death; what shall I call crucifying him? Language worthy of such an enormity it is impossible to find.
It is a great ease to have one in our own shape a species below us, and who, without being enlisted in our service, is by nature of our retinue.
It is a great journey to life's end.
It is a great misfortune not to possess talent enough to speak well, or sense enough to hold one's tongue.
It is a great mistake to think that because
you have read a masterpiece once or twice or ten times, therefore you have done with it.... You ought to live with it and make it part of your daily life.
It is a great piece of folly to sacrifice the inner for the outer man.
It is a great pity when the man who should be the head figure is a mere figure-head.
It is a great point of wisdom to find out one's own folly.
It is a great shame to a man to have a poor heart and a rich purse.
It is a great sin to swear unto a sin, / But a
greater still to keep a sinful oath.
It is a great step in finesse to make people under-estimate your acuteness.
It is a hard winter when one wolf eats another.
It is a kindly spirit which actually constitutes the human element in man.
It is a long lane that has no turning.
It is a long way from granite to the oyster;
farther yet to Plato, and the preaching of the immortality of the soul.
It is a low benefit to give me something; it is a high benefit to enable me to do somewhat of myself.
It is a lucky eel that escapes skinning.
It is a main lesson of wisdom to know your own from another's.
It is a man's sincerity and depth of vision that makes him a poet.
It is a mathematical fact that the casting of a pebble from my hand alters the centre of gravity of the universe.
It is a maxim of those who are esteemed perfect, that abundance is the perverter of reason.
It is a mere and miserable solitude to want true friends, without which the world is but a wilderness.
It is a moral impossibility that any son or daughter of Adam can stand on any ground that mortal treads, and gainsay the healthy tenure on which we hold our existence.
It is a poor art that the artisan can't live by.
It is a poor heart that never rejoices.
It is a poor horse that is not worth its oats.
It is a poor mouse that has but one hole.
It is a poor sport that is not worth the candle.
It is a profound error to presume that everything
has been discovered; it is to take the horizon which bounds the eye for the limit of the world.
It is a proof of mediocrity of intellect to be addicted to relating stories.
It is a rare thing, except it be from a perfect and entire friend, to have counsel given us, but such as shall be bowed and crooked to some ends which he hath that giveth it.
It is a reproach to be the first gentleman of one's race, but greater to be the last.
It is a sad house where the hen crows louder than the cock.
It is a shame for a man to desire honour because
of his ancestors, and not to deserve it by his own virtue.
It is a sign that your reputation is small or sinking if your own tongue must praise you.
It is a sin against hospitality to open your doors and shut up your countenance.
It is a small virtue to keep silence on matters, but a grave fault to speak of what should be kept silent.
It is a sorry goose that will not baste itself.
It is a strange habit of wise humanity to speak
in enigmas only.
It is a universal weakness of human nature to have an inordinate faith in things unseen and unknown, and to be affected unduly by them.
It is a very good world to live in, / To lend, or to spend, or to give in; / But to beg, or to borrow, or to get a man's own, / It is the very worst world that ever was known.
It is a very risky, nay, a fatal thing, to be sociable.
It is a virtue in hermits to forgive their enemies as well as their friends; but it is a fault in princes to show clemency towards those who are guilty.
It is a wise father that knows his own child.
It is absurd to contend for any sense of words in opposition to usage; for all senses are founded upon usage, and upon nothing else.
It is advisable that a man should know at least three things:--first, where he is; secondly, where he is going; thirdly, what he had best do under the circumstances.
It is all in my eye
It is allowed by the laws of war to deceive an enemy by feints, false colours, spies, false intelligence, or the like; but by no means in treaties, truces, signals of capitulation or surrender.
It is always an ease, and sometimes a happiness,
to have nothing.
It is always by adventurers that great deeds are done, and not by the sovereigns of great empires.
It is always good when a man has two irons in the fire.
It is always necessary to show some good opinion of those whose good opinion we solicit.
It is always term time in the court of conscience.
It is always the individual, not the age, that
stands up for the truth.
It is always vitally important to ourselves to be scrupulously true.
It is an argument of great wisdom to do nothing rashly, nor to be obstinate and inflexible in our opinions.
It is an assured sign of a worthy and generous spirit whom honour amends; for honour is, or should be, the place of virtue.
It is an egregious error to go by the exception instead of the rule.
It is an equal failing to trust everybody and
to trust nobody.
It is an honour for a man to cease from strife.
It is an ill sign to see a fox lick a lamb.
It is an ill wind that blows nobody good.
It is as difficult to appropriate the thoughts of others as to invent.
It is as easy to be a scholar as a gamester.
It is as easy to deceive one's self without perceiving it, as it is difficult to deceive others without their finding it out.
It is as great a point of wisdom to hide ignorance, as to discover knowledge.
It is as little the part of a wise man to reflect much on the nature of beings above him as of beings beneath him.
It is as much a part of true temperance to be pleased with the little that we know and the little that we can do as with the little that we have.
It is as much intemperance to weep too much
as to laugh too much.
It is as natural for the old to be prejudiced as for the young to be presumptuous; and in the change of centuries each generation has something to judge for itself.
It is as rare as it is pleasant to meet an old man whose opinions are not ossified.
It is as sport to a fool to do mischief.
It is at least fatal to the philosophic pretension of a line or stanza if, when it is fairly reduced to prose, the prose discloses that it is nonsense.
It is bad, having once known the right, / And the impulse of nobleness prized, / To accept the less worthy, and order the fight / For a cause that is meaner, and walk by a light / That you once had despised.
It is beneath the dignity of a soul that has but a grain of sense to make chance, and winds, and waves the arbitrary disposers of happiness.
It is best not to be angry; and best, in the next
place, to be quickly reconciled.
It is best to rise from life as from a banquet, neither thirsty nor drunken.
It is best to take half in hand and the rest by and by.
It is best to take with thankfulness and admiration from each man what he has to give.
It is better and kinder to flog a man to his work than to leave him idle till he robs and flog him afterwards.
It is better for a young man to blush than to
turn pale.
It is better for the man whom God helps than for him who rises early.
It is better living on a little than outliving a great deal.
It is better not to live at all than to live dishonoured.
It Is better to be a self-made man, filled up according to God's original pattern, than to be half a man, made after some other man's pattern.
It is better to be affected with a true penitent
sorrow for sin than to be able to resolve the most difficult cases about it.
It is better to be lost than to be saved all alone.
It is better to be nothing than a knave.
It is better to be the hammer than the anvil.
It is better to be the head o' the commonalty than the tail o' the gentry.
It is better to be wrong by rule than to be
wrong with nothing but the fitful caprice of our disposition to impel us.
It is better to cleanse ourselves of our sins now, than to reserve them to be cleansed at some future time.
It is better to create than to be learned. Creating is the essence of life.
It is better to die once than live always in fear of death.
It is better to do well than to say well.
It is better to dwell in a corner of the housetop
than with a brawling woman in a wide house.
It is better to fight for the good than to rail at the ill.
It is better to go to the house of mourning, than to go to the house of feasting.
It is better to have a lion at the head of an army of sheep than a sheep at the head of an army of lions.
It is better to have friends in our passage through life than grateful dependants; and as love is a more willing, so it is a more lasting tribute than extorted obligation.
It is better to have loved and lost than never
to have loved at all.
It is better to have one's evil days when one is young than when one is old.
It is better to have to do with God than with His saints.
It is better to hear the rebuke of the wise than for a man to hear the song of fools.
It is better to live by begging one's bread than to gratify the mouth at the expense of others.
It is better to live in a haunted forest ... than
to live amongst relations after the loss of wealth.
It is better to live on the crust of your own industry than on the fruits of other people's.
It is better to make friends than adversaries of a conquered race.
It is better to trust the eye than the ear.
It is bitter fare eating one's own words.
It is but the outer hem of God's great mantle
our poor stars do gem.
It is but vain to waste honey on those that will be caught with gall.
It is by attempting to reach the top by a single leap that so much misery is produced in the world.
It is by being conversant with the inventions of others that we learn to invent, as by reading the thoughts of others we learn to think.
It is by faith that poetry as well as devotion soars above this dull earth.
It is by his personal conduct that any man of
ordinary power will do the greatest amount of good that is in him to do.
It is by imitation, more than by precept, that we learn anything.
It is by presence of mind in untried circumstances that the native metal of a man is tested.
It is by study that we become contemporaries of every age and citizens of the world.
It is certain my belief gains quite infinitely the moment I can convince another mind thereof.
It is certain that either wise bearing or
ignorant carriage is caught as men take diseases, one of another.
It is character which builds an existence out of circumstance. Our strength is measured by our plastic power.
It is cheap enough to say, "God help you."
It is common to esteem most what is unknown.
It is commonly the imagination which is wounded first, rather than the heart; it is so much more sensitive.
It is courage that conquers in war, and not good weapons.
It is cowardly to quit the post the gods elect for us before they permit us.
It is delightful, after wandering in the thick darkness of metaphysics, to behold again the fair face of Truth.
It is delightful to transport one's self into the spirit of the past, to see how a wise man has thought before us, and to what a glorious height we have at last reached.
It is difficult to act a part long, for where
truth is not at the bottom, nature will peep out and betray itself one time or other.
It is difficult to descend with grace without seeming to fall.
It is difficult to do good without multiplying the sources of evil.
It is difficult to feel deep veneration and great affection for one and the same person.
It is difficult to know at what moment love begins; it is less difficult to know that it has begun.
It is difficult to say whether irresolution renders
a man the more unhappy or the more despicable; also whether it is productive of worse consequences to make a bad resolution, or none at all.
It is difficulties that give birth to miracles.
It is dreary
It is doubt
It is downright madness to contend where we are sure to be worsted.
It is easier for a wit to keep fire in his mouth,
than to hold in a witty saying that he is burning to tell.
It is easier not to begin to go wrong than it is to turn back and do better after beginning.
It is easier to carry the world in one's thoughts than on one's shoulders.
It is easier to know man in general than men in particular.
It is easier to suppress the first desire than to satisfy all that follow it.
It is easier to worship than to obey.
It is easier to write an indifferent poem than to understand a good one.
It is easy for a man who sits idle at home, and has nobody to please but himself, to ridicule or censure the common ways of mankind.
It is easy for men to write and talk like philosophers; but to act with wisdom, there's the rub.
It is easy in the world to live after the world's opinion; easy in solitude to live after our own; but the great man is he who in the midst of the crowd keeps with perfect sweetness the independence of solitude.
It is easy to be a spendthrift with other people's
property.
It is easy to condemn; it is better to pity.
It is easy to criticise an author, but it is difficult to appreciate him.
It is easy to give offence, though it is hard to appease.
It is easy to open a shop, but hard to keep it open.
It is easy to screw one's self up into high and
ever higher altitudes of Transcendentalism, and see nothing under one but the everlasting snows of Himalaya, the earth shrinking into a planet, and the indigo firmament sowing itself with daylight stars; but whither does it lead? One dreads always to inanity and mere injuring of the lungs.
It is enough for thee to know what each day wills; and what each day wills the day itself will tell.
It is exactly in the treatment of trifles that a man shows what he is.
It is exceedingly difficult for a man to be as narrow as he could have been had he lived a century ago.
It is excellent / To have a giant's strength, but tyrannous / To use it like a giant.
It is falling in with their own mistaken ideas
that makes fools and beggars of the half of mankind.
It is fancy, not the reason of things, that makes us so uneasy.
It is far better to give work which is above the men than to educate the men to be above their work.
It is far easier to make a great rush than to plod steadily on through a long life.
It is far from universally true that to get a thing you must aim at it. There are some things which can only be gained by renouncing them.
It is far more difficult to be simple than to be
complicated; far more difficult to sacrifice skill and ease exertion in the proper place, than to expend both indiscriminately.
It is folly to lay out money in the purchase of repentance.
It is folly to live in Rome and strive with the Pope.
It is folly to pretend that one ever wholly recovers from a disappointed passion. Such wounds always leave a scar.
It is for the sake of him
of those like him that the earth exists and maintains itself in being.
It is for truth that God created genius.
It is for want of application, rather than of means, that men fail of success.
It is force and right that determine everything in the world; force till right is ready.
It is fortune, not wisdom, that rules man's life.
It is from books that wise men derive consolation in the troubles of life.
It is from the difference we feel between the
finitude of fact and the infinitude of fantasy that all the evils spring which torment humanity.
It is fruition, and not possession, that renders us happy.
It is generally a sign of a small mind to think differently from great minds.
It is given us to live only once in the world.
It is good for a man to be driven, were it by never such harsh methods, into looking at this great universe with his own eyes, for himself and not for another, and trying to adjust himself truly there.
It is good that we sometimes be contradicted,
and that we always bear it well; for perfect peace cannot be had in this world.
It is good to do nothing bad, but better to wish nothing bad.
It is good to fear the worst; the best can save itself.
It is good to lend to God and the soil; they pay good interest.
It is good to rub and polish our brains against that of others.
It is great, it is manly, to disdain disguise.
It is great prudence to gain as many friends as we honestly can, especially when it may be done at so easy a rate as a good word.
It is hard even to the most miserable to die.
It is hard for an empty sack to stand upright.
It is hard to be poor and honest.
It is hard to carry a full cup.
It is hard to kick against the pricks.
It is hard to maintain the truth, but much harder to be maintained by it.
It is hard to put old heads on young shoulders.
It is hard to suffer wrong and pay for it too.
It is harder to avoid censure than to gain applause;
for this may be done by one great or wise action in an age; but to escape censure, a man must pass his whole life without saying or doing one ill or foolish thing.
It is harder to marry a daughter well than to bring her up well.
It is harder to weave than to gather wool.
It is harder work to resist vices and passions, than to toil in bodily labours.
It is his excess of sensibility that distinguishes man from other animals.
It is his moral sentences on mankind or the
state that rank the prose writer among the sages.
It is his restraint which is honourable to a man, not his liberty.
It is human nature to hate him whom you have injured.
It is idleness that creates impossibilities; and where men care not to do a thing, they shelter themselves under a persuasion that it cannot be done.
It is ill standing in dead men's shoes.
It is ill to take out of the flesh what is bred in
the bone.
It is impossible completely to understand what we do not love.
It is impossible for any man to form a right judgment of his neighbour's sufferings.
It is impossible that an ill-natured man can have a public spirit; for how should he love ten thousand men who never loved one?
It is impossible that anything so natural, so necessary, and so universal as death should ever have been designed by Providence as an evil to mankind.
It is impossible to be a hero in anything unless
one is first a hero in faith.
It is impossible to be just, if one is not generous.
It is in great perils we see great acts of daring.
It is in human nature soon to relax when not impelled by personal advantage or disadvantage.
It is in the politic as in the human constitution; if the limbs grow too large for the body, their size, instead of improving, will diminish, the vigour of the whole.
It is in the soul of man, when reverence, love,
intelligence, magnanimity have been developed there, that the Highest can disclose itself face to face in sun-splendour, independent of all cavils and jargonings;--there, of a surety, and nowhere else.
It is in the world that a man, devout or other, has his life to lead, his work waiting to be done.
It is in trifles that the mind betrays itself.
It is in vain for a man to be born fortunate, if he be unfortunate in his marriage.
It is incalculable what by arranging, commanding, and regimenting you can make of men.
It is inconceivable how much wit it requires
to avoid being ridiculous.
It is incredible how much the mind can do to sustain the body.
It is indeed all twilight in this world, a trifle more or less.
It is indeed only in old age that intellectual men attain their sublime expression.
It is infamy to die and not be missed.
It is invariably found that the contented man
is a weak man.
It is joy to think the best we can of human kind.
It is just those who grope with the mole and cling with the bat who are vainest of their sight and of their wings.
It is less difficult to bear misfortunes than to remain uncorrupted by pleasure.
It is madness to make fortune the mistress of events, because in herself she is nothing, but is ruled by prudence.
It is matter of the commonest remark how a
timid man who is in love will show courage, or an indolent man will show diligence.
It is meet / That noble minds keep ever with their likes; / For who so firm that cannot be seduced?
It is mere cowardice to take safety in negations.
It is mere Philistinism on the part of private individuals to bestow too much interest on matters that do not concern them.
It is more blessed to give than to receive.
It is more difficult, and calls for higher energies
of the soul, to live a martyr than to die one.
It is more honourable to be raised to a throne than be born to one; fortune bestows the one, merit obtains the other.
It is more important to discover a new source of happiness on earth than a new planet in the sky.
It is more kindly to laugh at human life than to grin at it.
It is more painful to do nothing than something.
It is more pleasing to see smoke brightening
into flame than flame sinking into smoke.
It is much easier to be critical than to be correct.
It is much easier to bind on a wreath than to find a head worthy to wear it.
It is much easier to recognise error than to find truth; the former lies on the surface, the latter rests in the depths.
It is much more easy to inspire a passion than a faith.
It is much safer to obey than to govern.
It is natural to a man to believe what he wishes to be true, and to believe it because be wishes it.
It is natural to man to regard himself as the final cause of creation.
It is naught, it is naught, saith the buyer; but when he is gone his way, then he boasteth.
It is never permitted to any one in heaven to stand behind another and look at the back of his head: for then the influx which is from the Lord is disturbed.
It is never too late to mend.
It is never wise to slip the bonds of discipline.
It is no man's business whether he has genius or not: work he must, whatever he is, but quietly and steadily; and the natural and unforced results of such work will always be the things that God meant him to do, and will be his best.
It is no mean happiness to be seated in the mean.
It is no more in our power to love always than it was not to love.
It is no more possible to prevent thought from
reverting to an ideal than the sea from returning to the shore.
It is no small commendation to manage a little well. He is a good waggoner that can turn in a little room.
It is no such heinous matter to fall afflicted, as, being down, to lie dejected.
It is no wonder man's religion has much suffering in it; no wonder he needs a suffering God.
It is nobler to become great than to be born great.
It is nobler to convert souls than to conquer
kingdoms.
It is not a question how much a man knows, but what use he can make of what he knows.
It is not advisable to reward where men have the tenderness not to punish.

It is not always necessary that the true should around spiritually and produce accordance

It is not always necessary that the true should around spiritually and produce accordance 
It is not always necessary that the true should around spiritually and produce accordance  tones like the sound of bells.
It is not an unhealthy
philosophy, but a sturdy morality that is of any profit to us.
It is not because of his toils that I lament for
the poor; we must all toil, or steal, which is worse; no faithful workman finds his task a pastime.... But what I do mourn over is that the lamp of his soul should go out; that no ray of heavenly, or even earthly, knowledge should visit him; but only in the haggard darkness, like two spectres, Fear and Indignation bear him company.
It is not by shirking difficulties that we can remove them or escape them.
It is not enough that a poet possess inspiration; his inspiration must be that of a cultured spirit.
It is not enough to aim; you must hit.
It is not enough to know how to steal; one must know also how to conceal.
It is not enough to know, one must also apply;
it is not enough to will to do, one must also do.
It is not enough to speak, but to speak true.
It is not enough to take steps which may some day lead to a goal; each step must be itself a goal and a step likewise.
It is not every man that can afford to wear a shabby coat.
It is not everybody one would set to choose a horse or a pig; how much less a member of Parliament?
It is not everybody who can bend the bow of
Ulysses, and most men only do themselves a mischief by trying to bend it.
It is not fit to tell others anything but what they can take up. A man understands nothing but what is commensurate with him.
It is not from masters, but from their equals, that youths learn a knowledge of the world.
It is not from nature, but from education and habits, that our wants are chiefly derived.
It is not given to the world to be contented.
It is not good for man to be, especially to work,
alone.
It is not good to have an oar in every one's boat.
It is not good to meddle with divine mysteries.
It is not good to pass by that we dislike, even to gain that which we like; for the water of life becometh mortal when mixed with a poison.
It is not he who gives abuse or blows who affronts, but the view we take of these things as insulting.
It is not his own individual sins that the hero atones for, but original sin
It is not history which educates the conscience;
it is conscience which educates history.
It is not in man that walketh to direct his steps.
It is not juggling that is to be blamed, but much juggling; for the world cannot be governed without it.
It is not lost that comes at last.
It is not merely by virtue of the sunlight that falls now, and the rain and dew which it brings, that we continue here, but by virtue of the sunlight of æons of past ages.
It is not metre, but metre-making agreement
that makes a poem, a thought so passionate and alive, that, like the spirit of a plant or an animal, it has an architect of its own, and adorns nature with a new thing.
It is not poetry, but prose run mad.
It is not possible to buy obedience with money.
It is not proper to place confidence in one who cometh without any apparent cause.
It is not propositions, not new dogmas and a logical exposition of the world, that are our first need; but to watch and tenderly cherish the intellectual and moral sensibilities, those fountains of right thought, and woo them to stay and make their home with us.
It is not quite so easy to do good as those may
imagine who never try.
It is not so much our neighbour's interest as our own that we love him.
It is not so much the being exempt from faults, as the having overcome them, that is an advantage to us.
It is not strength, but art obtains the prize.
It is not the beard that makes the philosopher.
It is not the custom when a prince doth sneeze
to say, as to other persons, "God help you," but only to make a low reverence.
It is not the face which deceives; it is we who deceive ourselves in reading in it what is not there.
It is not the fact that a man has riches which keeps him from the kingdom of heaven, but the fact that riches have him.
It is not the fraud, but the cold-heartedness which is chiefly dreadful in treachery.
It is not the greatness of a man's means that makes him independent, so much as the smallness of his wants.
It is not the insurrections of ignorance that
are dangerous, but the revolts of intelligence.
It is not the knowledge, but the use which is made of it that is productive of real benefit.
It is not the loss of heritage / That makes life poor; It is that, stage by stage, / Some leave us with a lessening faith in man, / And less of love than when our life began.
It is not the manner of noble minds to leave anything half done.
It is not the number of facts he knows, but how much of a fact he is himself, that proves the man.
It is not the punishment, but the crime that is
the disgrace.
It is not the quantity, but the quality of knowledge which determines the mind's dignity.
It is not the reading of many books that is necessary to make a man wise and good, but the well-reading of a few.
It is not the stamp on the coin that gives it its value, though on the bank-note it is.
It is not the victory that constitutes the joy of noble souls, but the combat.
It is not thy works, which are all mortal,
infinitely little, ... but only the spirit thou workest in, that can have worth or continuance.
It is not titles that reflect honour on men, but men on their titles.
It is not to taste sweet things, but to do noble and true things, and vindicate himself under God's heaven as a God-made man, that the poorest son of Adam dimly longs.
It is not, truly speaking, the labour that is divided, but the men; divided into mere segments of men, broken into small fragments and crumbs of life; so that all the little piece of intelligence that is left in a man is not enough to make a pin or a nail, but exhausts itself in making the point of a pin or the head of a nail.
It is not want, but rather abundance that creates avarice.
It is not want of good fortune, want of happiness,
but want of wisdom that man has to dread.
It is not well to make great changes in old age.
It is not what he has, nor even what he does, which directly expresses the worth of a man, but what he is.
It is not wisdom, but ignorance which teaches men presumption.
It is not with saying, "Honey, honey," that sweetness comes into the mouth.
It is not work that kills men, it is worry.
It is not the revolution that destroys the machinery, but the friction.
It is of more importance to teach manners and customs than to establish laws and tribunals.
It is of no use running; to set out betimes is the main point.
It is of some consequence for a man to forego his own inclinations, even in matters of no great importance.
It is often because an author proceeds from the thought to the expression, and the reader from the expression to the thought, that a clear writer is obscure.
It is often easier, as well as more advantageous, to conform to the opinions of others than to persuade them into ours.
It is often even wise to reveal what cannot long remain concealed.
It is one of the wretchednesses of the great
that they have no approved friends.
It is one soul which animates all men.
It is one thing to be tempted, another thing to fall.
It is one thing to see that a line is crooked, and another thing to be able to draw a straight one.
It is one thing to speak much, and another to speak pertinently.
It is only a part of art that can be taught; the
artist needs the whole.
It is only at the first encounter that a face makes its full impression upon us.
It is only because they are not used to taste of what is excellent that the generality of people take delight in silly and insipid things, provided they be new.
It is only by labour that thought can be made healthy, and only by thought that labour can be made happy.
It is only by universals, and never by singulars, that we can think.
It is only God's business to make laws, and
the lawyer's to read and enforce them.
It is only in society that a man's powers can have full play.
It is only in their misery that we recognise the hand and finger of God leading good men to good.
It is only kindred griefs that draw forth our tears, and each weeps really for himself.
It is only men collectively that live the life of man.
It is only necessary to grow old to become
indulgent. I see no fault committed that I have not committed myself.
It is only on reality that any power of action can be based.
It is only people who possess firmness that can possess true gentleness.
It is only reason that teaches silence. The heart teaches us to speak.
It is only rogues who feel the restraints of law.
It is only strict precision of thought that confers
facility of expression.
It is only the finite that has wrought and suffered; the infinite lies stretched in smiling repose.
It is only time that possesses full reality, and our existence lies in it exclusively.
It is only when a man is alone that he is really free.
It is only when it is bent that the bow shows its strength.
It is only with renunciation that life, strictly
speaking, can be said to begin.
It is our relation to circumstances that determines their influence over us. The same wind that carries one vessel into port may blow another off shore.
It is petty expenses that empty the purse.
It is pleasant to die if there be gods, and sad to live if there be none.
It is possible to sin against charity, when we do not sin against truth.
It is precisely in accepting death as the end
of all and in laying down, on that sorrowful condition, his life for his friends, that the hero and patriot of all time has become the glory and safety of his country.
It is profound ignorance that inspires a degenerate tone.
It is proof of a high culture to say the greatest matters in the simplest way.
It is proper and beneficial sometimes to be left to thyself.
It is prudent to be on the reserve even with your best friend, when he betrays a too eager curiosity to worm out your secret.
It is rare indeed that there is not ample
occasion for grumbling.
It is religion that has formed the Bible, not the Bible that has formed religion.
It is sad to have to live in a place where all our activity must simmer within ourselves.
It is sad to see how an extraordinary man so often strangles himself, struggling in vain with himself, his circumstances, and his time, without once coming upon a green branch.
It is said no man is a hero to his valet. The reason is that it requires a hero to recognise a hero. The valet, however, will probably know well enough how to estimate his equals.
It is so much easier to do what one has done
before than to do a new thing, that there is a perpetual tendency to a set mode.
It is St. Christopher that carries Christ, not Christ St. Christopher
It is sure to be dark if you shut your eyes.
It is the ambiguous distracted training which they are subject to that makes men uncertain; it awakens wishes when it should quicken tendencies.
It is the best sign of a great nature, that it opens a foreground, and, like the breath of morning landscapes, invites us onward.
It is the best use of fate to teach a fatal courage.
It is the bright day that brings forth the adder, / And that craves wary walking.
It is the cause, not the death, that makes the martyr.
It is the common error of builders and parents to follow some plan they think beautiful (and perhaps is so) without considering that nothing is beautiful which is displaced.
It is the common wonder of all men how, among so many millions of faces, there should be none alike.
It is the company, and not the charge that makes the feast.
It is the condition of humanity to design what
never will be done, and to hope what never will be attained.
It is the curse of kings to be attended / By slaves, that take their humours for a warrant.

It is the curse of talent, that, though it works more surely and persistently than genius, it reaches no goal; while genius, hovering for round, smiling, far above.
It is the dim haze of mystery that adds enchantment to pursuit.
It is the fate of a woman / Long to be patient and silent, to wait like a ghost that is speechless, / Till some questioning voice dissolves the spell of its silence.
It is the fate of the great ones of the earth to
begin to be appreciated by us only after they are gone.
It is the first of all problems for a man to find out what kind of work he is to do in this universe.
It is the first principle of economy to make use of available vital power first, then the inexpensive natural forces, and only at last to have recourse to artificial power.
It is the flash that murders; the poor thunder never harm'd head.
It is the frog's own croak that betrays him.
It is the glistening and softly-spoken lie, ...
the patriotic lie of the historian, the provident lie of the politician, the zealous lie of the partisan, the merciful lie of the friend, and the careless lie of each man to himself, that cast the black mystery over humanity, through which we thank any man who pierces, as we would thank one who had dug a well in the desert.
It is the glorious doom of literature that the evil perishes and the good remains.
It is the great error of reformers and philanthropists in our time to nibble at the consequences of unjust power, instead of redressing the injustice itself.
It is the greatest invention man has ever made, this of marking down the unseen thought that is in him by written characters.
It is the heart that makes the critic, not the nose.
It is the height of folly to throw up attempting
because you have failed. Failures are wonderful elements in developing the character.
It is the inspiration of the Almighty that giveth man understanding.
It is the law of fate that we shall live in part by our own efforts, but in the greater part by the help of others; and that we shall also die in part for our own faults, but in the greater part for the faults of others.
It is the life in literature that acts upon life.
It is the little rift within the lute / That by and by will make the music mute, / And, ever widening, slowly silence all.
It is the lot of man to suffer.
It is the mark of a great man to treat trifles as trifles, and important matters as important.
It is the master-wheel which makes the mill go round.
It is the monotony of his own nature that makes solitude intolerable to a man.
It is the music in the ear that finds and interprets the music of the orchestra.
It is the nature of despair to blind us to all
means of safety.
It is the nature of extreme self-lovers, as they will set an house on fire, an it were but to roast their eggs.
It is the nature of parties to retain their original enmities far more firmly than their original principles.
It is the office of the Church to teach, not to train.
It is the ordinary way of the world to keep folly at the helm, and wisdom under the hatches.
It is the part of a good man to do great and
noble deeds, though he risks everything.
It is the part of a wise man to resist pleasures, but of a foolish one to be a slave to them.
It is the poet's function to keep before the minds of the people not only the underlying truths and beauties of all Nature, but the high and pure ideal of humanity which all should strive to attain.
It is the possession of a great heart or a great head, and not the mere fame of it, which is of worth and conducive to happiness.
It is the power of thought which gives man the mastery over Nature, the thoughts go forth into the world.
It is the privilege of every human work which
is well done, to invest the doer with a certain haughtiness.
It is the privilege of genius that to it life never grows common-place, as to the rest of us.
It is the property of every hero to come back to reality; to stand upon things, not shows of things.
It is the secret of the world that all things subsist, and do not die, but only retire a little from sight, and afterwards return again.
It is the setting up of a claim to happiness that ruins everything in the world.
It is the strange fate of man that even in the
greatest evils the fear of worse continues to haunt him.
It is the temper of the highest hearts, like the palm-tree, to strive most upwards when it is most burdened.
It is the thought writ down we want, / Not its effect, not likenesses of likenesses; / And such descriptions are not, more than gloves / Instead of hands to shake, enough for us.
It is the treating of the common-place with the feeling of the sublime that gives to art its true power.
It is the unseen and spiritual in man that determines the outward and actual.
It is the vain endeavour to make ourselves
what we are not that has strewn history with so many broken purposes and lives left in the rough.
It is the wise alone who are capable of discerning that impartial justice is the truest mercy.
It is the witness still of excellency / To put a strange face on his own perfection.
It is the work of a philosopher to be every day subduing his passions and laying aside his prejudices.
It is through the feeling of wonder that men philosophise.
It is time enough to answer questions when
they are asked.
It is time enough to doff your hat when you see the man.
It is time to fear when tyrants seem to kiss.
It is to be doubted whether he will ever find the way to heaven who desires to go thither alone.
It is too late to husband when all is spent.
It is too late to spare when the bottom is bare.
It is true greatness to have in one the frailty of a man and the security of a god.
It is truth that makes a man angry.
It is useless to attempt to reason a man out of a thing he was never reasoned into.
It is useless to deny with the tongue that which man gives credence to with the heart.
It is very easy to obey a noble ruler who convinces
while h
It is very good to be left alone with the truth sometimes, to hear with all its sternness what it will say to one.
It is very little that we can ever know of the ways of Providence or the laws of existence; but that little is enough, and exactly enough.
It is war's prize to take all advantages, / And ten to one is no impeach of valour.
It is we that are blind, not Fortune.
It is well that there is no one without a fault,
for he would not have a friend in the world. He would seem to belong to a different species.
It is well to go for a light to another man's fire, but by no means to tarry by it.
It is when the hour of conflict is over, that history comes to a right understanding of the strife, and is ready to exclaim: "Lo! God is here, and we knew it not."
It is wholesomer for the moral nature to be restrained, even by arbitrary power, than to be allowed to exercise arbitrary power.
It is wisdom alone that can recognise wisdom.
It is wise not to know a secret, and honest
not to reveal it.
It is with a fine genius as with a fine fashion; all those are displeased at it who are not able to follow it.
It is with diseases of the mind as with those of the body; we are half dead before we understand our disorders, and half cured when we do.
It is with history as it is with nature, as it is with everything profound, past, present, or future; the deeper we earnestly search into them, the more difficult are the problems that arise. He who does not fear these, but boldly confronts them, will, with every step or advance, feel himself both more at his ease and more highly educated.
It is with ideas as with pieces of money; those of least value generally circulate the best.
It is with narrow-soul'd people as with narrow-neck'd
bottles; the less they have in them the more noise they make in pouring it out.
It is with our thoughts as with flowers. Those whose expression is simple carry their seed with them; those that are double, by their richness and pomp charm the mind, but produce nothing.
It is with words as with sunbeams; the more they are condensed, the deeper they burn.
It makes a great difference to the force of any sentence whether there be a man behind it or no. In the learned journal, in the influential newspaper, I discern no form; only some irresponsible shadow; oftener some moneyed corporation, or some dangler, who hopes, in the mask and robes of his paragraph, to pass for somebody.
It matters less to a man where he is born than where he can live.
It matters little whether a man be mathematically,
or philologically, or artistically cultivated, so he be cultivated.
It matters not how a man dies, but how he lives.
It matters not that a woman is well dressed if her manners be bad; ill-breeding mars a fine dress more than dirt.
It matters not whether our good-humour be construed by others into insensibility, or even idiotism; it is happiness to ourselves.
It may be we shall touch the Happy Isles, / And see the great Achilles whom we knew.
It may indeed be that man is frightfully threshed at times by public and domestic ill-fortune, but the ruthless destiny, if it smites the rich sheaves, only crumples the straw; the grains feel nothing of it, and bound merrily hither and thither on the threshing-floor, unconcerned whether they wander into the mill or the cornfield.
It must be bad indeed if a book has a more demoralising effect than life itself.
It needs a man to perceive a man.
It ne'er was wealth, it ne'er was wealth, / That coft contentment, peace, or pleasure; / The bands and bliss o' mutual love, / O that's the chiefest warld's treasure!
It never occurs to fools that merit and good
fortune are closely united.
It never rains but it pours.
It never smokes but there's fire.
It offends me to the soul to hear a robustious periwig-pated fellow tear a passion to tatters, to very rags, to split the ears of the groundlings, who for the most part are capable of nothing but inexplicable dumb show and noise.
It oft falls out to have what we would have; we speak not what we mean.
It requires a great deal of boldness and a
great deal of caution to make a great fortune, and when you have got it, it requires ten times as much wit to keep it.
It requires a great deal of poetry to gild the pill of poverty.
It requires a long time to know any one.
It requires more than mere genius to be an author.
It requires much courage not to be down-hearted in the world.
It requires no preterhuman force of will in any
young man or woman ... to get at least half an hour out of a solid busy day for good and disinterested reading.
It seems a law of society to despise a man who looks discontented because its requirements have compelled him to part with all he values in his life.
It seems as if them as aren't wanted here are th' only ones as aren't wanted i' the other world.
It should not be suspected of a man, whose life hath been spent in noble deeds, that his reason is lost, when he is only involved in trouble. A fire may be overturned, but its flames will never descend.
It so falls out, / That what we have we prize not to the worth / Whiles we enjoy it; but being lack'd and lost, / Why then we rack the value.
It takes a good many spadefuls of earth to
bury the truth.
It takes a great deal of living to get a little deal of learning.
It takes a great man to make a good listener.
It takes much more penetration to discover a fool than a clever man.
It takes ten pounds of common-sense to carry one pound of learning.
It was a stroke / Brought the stream from the
flinty rock.
It was alway yet the trick of our English nation, if they have a good thing, to make it too common.
It was always the aim of the artists as well as the wise men of antiquity, to mean much though they might say little.
It was for beauty that the world was made.
It was the nightingale, and not the lark / That pierced the fearful hollow of thine ear.
It was the wisdom of the ancients to regard
the most useful as the most illustrious.
It were better to be of no church than bitter for any.
It were easier to stop Euphrates at its source than one tear of a true and tender heart.
It were good for a man to have some anchorage deeper than the quicksands of this world; for these drift to and fro so as to baffle all conjecture.
It were no virtue to bear calamities if we did not feel them.
It will be all the same a hundred years hence.
It will be an ill web to bleach.
It will have blood; they say, blood will have blood; / Stones have been known to move, and trees to speak.
It will never out of the flesh that's bred in the bone.
It would be better that we should not exist, than that we should guiltily disappoint the purposes of existence.
It would be some advantage to live a primitive
and frontier life, though in the midst of an outward civilisation, if only to learn what are the gross necessaries of life, and what methods have been taken to obtain them.
It's a gude heart that says nae ill, but a better that thinks nane.
It's a poor man that always counts his sheep.
It's a poor sport that's not worth the candle.
It's a sair field where a's slain.
It's a small joke sets men laughing when they
sit a-staring at one another wi' a pipe i' their mouths.
It's a weary warld, and naebody bides in't.
It's all very well having a ready-made rich man, but it may happen he'll be a ready-made fool.
It's an ill wind that blaws naebody gude.
It's aye the cheapest lawyer's fee / To taste the barrel.
It's bad flesh that won't take salt; worse is
the body that won't take warning.
It's difficult to give sense to a fool.
It's dogged as does it.
It's good sheltering under an old hedge.
It's hard sailing when there is no wind.
It's hard to take the twist out of an oak that grew in the sapling.
It's hard to tell which is Old Harry when everybody's got boots on.
It's harder work getting to hell than to heaven.
It's hardly in a body's power / To keep, at times, frae being sour, / To see how things are shared.
It's height makes Grantham steeple stand awry.
It's ill livin' in a hen-roost for them as doesn't like fleas.
It's ill living where everybody knows everybody.
It's ill talking between a full man and a fasting.
It's ill wool that will take no dye.
It's lang ere the devil dee by the dyke-side.
It's never too late to learn.
It's no in titles nor in rank; / It's no in wealth like London bank, / To purchase peace and rest: / It's no in makin' muckle mair, / It's no in books, it's no in lear, / To mak' us truly blest.

It's no use filling your pocket full of money if you have got a hole in the corner.
It's no use killing nettles to grow docks.
It's no use pumping a dry well.
It's not "What has she?" but "What is she?"
It's poor eating where the flavour of the meat
lies in the cruets.
It's poor friendship that needs to be constantly bought.
It's pride that puts this country down; / Man, take thine old cloak about thee.
It's sin, and no poverty, that maks a man miserable.
It's them as take advantage that get advantage i' this world, I think; folks have to wait long enough before it's brought to 'em.
It's too late to cast anchor when the ship is
on the rocks.
It's wiser being good than bad; / It's safer being meek than fierce; / It's fitter being sane than mad. / My own hope is, a sun will pierce / The thickest cloud earth ever stretch'd; / That after last returns the first, / Though a wide compass round be fetch'd; / That what began best can't end worst, / Nor what God blessèd once prove accurst.
It's your dead chicks take the longest hatchin'.
Ita lex scripta
Ivory does not come from a rat's mouth.
J'ai bonne cause
J'ai en toujours pour principe de ne faire jamais par autrui ce que je pouvais faire par moi-même

J'ai graissé la patte au concierge
J'ai ris, me voilà désarmé
J'ai toujours vu que, pour réussir dans le

J'ai vécu
J'ai voulu voir, j'ai vu

J'évite d'être long, et je deviens obscur

Jack at a pinch.
Jack is as good as Jill.
Jack-o'-both sides is, before long, trusted by nobody, and abused by both parties.
Jack of all trades and master of none.
Jack shall pipe and Jill shall dance.
Jack will never be a gentleman.
Jack's as good as his master.
Jacta alea est
Jactitatio
Jam nunc minaci murmure cornuum / Perstringis
aures; jam litui strepunt
Jam pauca aratro jugera regiæ / Moles relinquent
Jam portum inveni, Spes et Fortuna valete! / Nil mihi vobiscum est, ludite nunc alios
Jam redit et Virgo, redeunt Saturnia regna
Jam seges est ubi Troja fuit, resecandaque falce / Luxuriat Phrygio sanguine pinguis humus
Jam summa procul villarum culmina fumant
Jamais abattu
Jamais arrière
Jamais l'innocence et le mystère n'habitèrent long tems ensemble
Jamais la cornemuse ne dit mot si elle n'a le ventre plein
Jamais long nez n'a gâté beau visage
Jamais nous ne goûtons de parfaite allégresse; / Nos plus heureux succès sont mêlés de tristesse
Jamais on ne vaincra les Romains que dans Rome
Jamque opus exegi, quod nec Jovis ira, nec ignis, / Nec poterit ferrum, nec edax abolere vetustas

Januis clausis
Jardin des plantes
Jasper fert myrrham, thus Melchior, Balthazar aurum. / Hæc quicum secum portet tria nomina regum, / Solvitur a morbo, Domini pietate, caduco
Je allseitiger, je individueller
Je cognois tout, fors que moy-mesme
Je crains Dieu, cher Abner, et n'ai pas d'autre
crainte
Je crains l'homme d'un seul livre
Je fetter der Floh, je magerer der Hund
Je jouis des ouvrages qui surpassent les miens
Je laisse à penser la vie / Que firent ces deux amis
Je le tiens
Je m'en vais chercher un grand peut-être; tirez le rideau, la farce est jouée
Je m'en vais voir le soleil pour la dernière fois!
Je m'estonne fort pourquoy / La mort osa songer a moy / Qui ne songeais jamais à elle
Je maintiendrai le droit
Je me fie en Dieu
Je mehr der Brunnen gebraucht wird, desto mehr giebt er Wasser
Je mehr Gesetze, je weniger Recht
Je mehr man das Ich versteckt, je mehr Welt hat man
Je mets en fait que, si tous les hommes savaient ce qu'ils disent les uns des autres, il n'y aurait pas quatre amis dans le monde
Je minder sich der Kluge selbst gefällt, / Um
desto mehr schätzt ihn die Welt
Je n'ai fait celle-ci plus longue que parceque je n'ai pas eu le loisir de la faire plus courte
Je n'ai mérité / Ni cet excès d'honneur ni cette indignité
Je n'ai point d'ennemis que ceux de l'état
Je n'oublierai jamais
Je ne change qu'en mourant
Je ne changerois pas mon répos pour tous les trésors du monde
Je ne cherche qu'un
Je ne connais que trois moyens d'exister dans la société: être ou voleur, ou mendiant, ou salarié
Je ne puis pas me refondre
Je ne sais quoi
Je pense
Je pense plus
Je plie et ne romps pas
Je prends mon bien où je le trouve
Je sais à mon pot comment les autres bouillent
Je schöner die Wirthin, je schwerer die Zeche
Je sens qu'il y a un Dieu, et je ne sens pas
qu'il n'y en ait point; cela me suffit
Je suis assez semblable aux girouettes, qui ne se fixent que quand elles sont rouillées
Je suis oiseau, voyez mes ailes! / Je suis souris; vivent les rats
Je suis prêt
Je suis riche des biens dont je sais me passer
Je t'aime d'autant plus que je t'estime moins
Je veux de bonne guerre
Je veux le droit
Je veux que, le dimanche, chaque paysan ait sa poule au pot
Je vis en espoir
Je vois, je sais, je crois, je suis désabusé
Je voudrais voir un homme sobre, modéré. chaste, équitable prononcer qu'il n'y-a point de Dieu; il parlerait du moins sans intérêt; mais cet homme ne se trouve point
Je vous apprendrai à vivre
Je vous ferai voir de quel bois je me chauffe
Je weniger die Worte, je besser Gebet
Jealous in honour, sudden and quick in quarrel, /
Seeking the bubble reputation / Even in the cannon's mouth.
Jealousy dislikes the world to know it.
Jealousy / Hath in it an alchemic force to fuse / Almost into one metal love and hate.
Jealousy is a painful passion; yet without some share of it, the agreeable affection of love has difficulty to subsist in its full force and violence.
Jealousy is always born with love, but it does not always die with it.
Jealousy is cruel as the grave; the coals
thereof are coals of fire, which hath a most vehement flame.
Jealousy is love's bed of burning snarl.
Jealousy is often the helpmate of sweet love.
Jealousy is the forerunner of love, and sometimes its awakener.
Jealousy is the rage of a man.
Jealousy is the sister of love, as the devil is
the brother of the angel.
Jealousy: / It is the green-eyed monster that doth mock / The meat it feeds on.
Jealousy lives upon doubts; it becomes madness or ceases entirely as soon as we pass from doubt to certainty.
Jean a étudié pour être bête
Jean s'en alla comme il était venu
Jeddart justice: First hang a man, and syne
t
Jede grosse Zeit erfasst den ganzen Menschen
Jede Macht, welche wir über andere Gegenstände ausüben, hängt von der Macht ab, die wir über uns selbst besitzen
Jede That der Weltgeschichte / Zeugt auch wieder eine That
Jede Unthat, / Trägt ihren eignen Racheengel schon, / Die böse Hoffnung unter ihrem Herzen
Jedem das Seine ist nicht zu viel
Jedem redlichen Bemühn / Sel Beharrlichkeit verliehn.
Jeden anderen Meister erkennt man an dem, was er ausspricht; was er weiss, verschweigt, zeigt mir den Meister des Styls
Jeder ausserordentliche Mensch hat eine gewisse Sendung, die er zu vollführen berufen ist
Jeder freut sich seiner Stelle, / Bietet dem Verächter Trutz
Jeder gilt so viel als er hat
Jeder ist seiner Worte bester Ausleger
Jeder Jüngling sehnt sich so zu lieben. / Jedes
Mädchen so geliebt zu sein: / Ach, der heiligste von unsern Trieben / Warum quillt aus ihm die grimme Pein?
Jeder Krämer lobt seine Ware
Jeder Mensch muss nach seiner Weise denken: denn er findet auf seinem Wege immer ein Wahres, oder eine Art von Wahrem, die ihm durchs Leben hilft; nur darf er sich nicht gehen lassen; er muss sich controliren; der blosse nackte Instinct geziemt nicht dem Menschen
Jeder Morgen ruft zu, das Gehörige zu thun, und das Mögliche zu erwarten
Jeder muss der Natur seine Schuld bezahlen
Jeder muss ein Paar Narrenschuhe zerreissen,
zerreisst er nicht mehr
Jeder, sieht man ihn einzeln, ist leidlich klug und verständig; / Sind sie in corpori, gleich wird euch ein Dummkopf daraus
Jeder stirbt / Und sterben ist die grösste That für jedem
Jeder Tag hat seine Plage / Und die Nacht hat ihre Lust
Jeder Weg zum rechten Zwecke / Ist auch recht in jeder Strecke
Jeder Zustand, ja jeder Augenblick, ist von
unendlichem Werth, denn er ist der Repräsentant einer ganzen Ewigkeit
Jedes ausgesprochene Wort erregt den Eigensinn
Jedes Weib will lieber schön als fromm sein
Jedes Weibes / Fehler ist des Mannes Schuld
Jedwede Tugend / Ist fleckenrein bis auf den Augenblick / Der Probe
Jedwede Zeit hat ihre Wehen
Jedweder ist des dunkeln Schicksals Knecht
Jeer not others upon any occasion.
Jeerers must be content to taste of their own broth.
Jejunus raro stomachus vulgaria temnit
Jeshurun waxed fat and kicked.
Jess would have been an omnivorous reader of books had it not been her conviction that reading was idling.
Jest not with the eye, nor religion.
Jest so that it may not become earnest.
Jest with an ass, and he will flap you in the face with his tail.
Jest with your equals.
Jesters do oft prove prophets.
Jesting brings serious sorrows.
Jesting lies bring serious sorrows.
Jesting Pilate, asking, "What is truth?" had not the smallest chance to ascertain it. He could not have known it had a god shown it to him.
Jesus Christ belonged to the true race of prophets.
He saw with open eye the mystery of the soul. Drawn by its severe harmony, ravished with its beauty, He lived in it, and had His being there.
Jesus hominum salvator
Jesus of Nazareth, and the life He lived and the death He died;--through this, as through a miraculous window, the heaven of Martyr Heroism, the "divine depths of sorrow," of noble labour, and the unspeakable silent expanses of eternity, first in man's history disclose themselves.
Jesus of Nazareth was not poor, though He had not where to lay His head.
Jesus speaks always from within, and in a degree that transcends all others. In that is the miracle.
Jet d'eau
Jeter le manche après la cognée
Jetzt giebt es keine Riesen mehr; Gewalt / Ist für den Schwachen jederzeit ein Riese

Jeu de hazard

Jeune, on conserve pour sa vieillesse; vieux, on épargne pour la mort
Jewels five words long, / That on the stretch'd forefinger of all time / Sparkle for ever.

Jo argere Skalk, je bedre Lykke

Joan is as good as my lady in the dark.
John Gilpin kiss'd his loving wife; / O'erjoy'd was he to find / That, though on pleasure she was bent, / She had a frugal mind.
Johnsons are rare; yet, Boswells are perhaps still rarer.
Join hands with God to make a man to live.
Joindre les mains, c'est bien; les ouvrir, c'est mieux

Journalists are like little dogs; whenever anything stirs they immediately begin to bark.
Journeys end in lovers' meeting, / Every wise man's son doth know.
Jove tonante cum populo agi non est fas
Jovis omnia plena
Joy? a moon by fits reflected in a swamp or watery bog.
Joy and grief are never far apart.
Joy and sorrow / Are to-day and to-morrow.
Joy descends gently upon us like the evening dew, and does not patter down like a hailstorm.
Joy has this in common with pain, that it robs
men of reason.
Joy, in a changeable subject, must necessarily change as the subject changeth.
Joy is a guest who generally comes uninvited.
Joy is a sunbeam between two clouds.
Joy is as a raiment fine, / Spun of magic threads divine; / Which as you are in act to don, / The wearer and the robe are gone.
Joy is buyable--by forsaking all that a man
hath.
Joy is like the ague; one good day between two bad ones.
Joy is more divine than sorrow; for joy is bread, and sorrow is medicine.
Joy is the best of wine.
Joy is the mainspring in the whole round of universal Nature; joy moves the wheels of the great timepiece of the world; she it is that loosens flowers from their buds, suns from their firmaments, rolling spheres in distant space not seen by the glass of the astronomer.
Joy is the sweet voice, joy the luminous cloud.
Joy may elevate, ambition glorify, but sorrow alone can consecrate.
Joy must have sorrow; sorrow, joy.
Joy never feasts so high as when the first course is of misery.
Joy ruled the day and love the night.
Joy shared is joy doubled.
Joy surfeited turns to sorrow.
Joy wholly from without is false, precarious and short. Joy from within is like smelling the rose on the tree; it is more sweet, and fair, and lasting.
Joy's a subtle elf; / I think man's happiest when he forgets himself.
Joys are for the gods; / Man's common course of nature is distress; / His joys are prodigies; and like them too, / Portend approaching ill. The wise man starts / And trembles at the perils of a bliss.
Joys are our wings, sorrows are our spurs.
Joys carried too far change into sorrows.
Joy's recollection is no longer joy, while sorrow's memory is a sorrow still.
Joys shared with others are more enjoyed.
Joys, tender and true, / Yet all with wings.
Joyful to live, yet not afraid to die.
Joyfulness
Jubilate Deo
Jucunda est memoria præteritorum malorum
Jucunda et idonea dicere vitæ
Jucunda rerum vicissitudo
Jucundi acti labores
Jucundum et carum sterilis facit uxor amicum
Judex damnatur cum nocens absolvitur
Judex non potest esse testis in propria causa
Judge before friendship, then confide till death, / Well for thy friend, but nobler far for thee.
Judge me, ye powers; let fortune tempt or frown, I am prepared; my honour is my own.
Judge not according to the appearance, but
judge righteous judgment.
Judge not of men and things at first sight.
Judge not, that ye be not judged.
Judge not the Lord by feeble sense, / But trust Him for His grace.
Judge not the play before the play is done; / Her plot has many changes; every day / Speaks a new scene; the last act crowns the play.
Judge not the preacher.... Do not grudge /
To pick out treasures from an earthen pot. / The worst speak something good; if all want sense, / God takes a text and preacheth patience.
Judge of the pleasure of the heart by the pleasure of the eye.
Judge thou me by what I am, / So shalt thou find me fairest.
Judge thyself with a judgment of sincerity, and thou wilt judge others with a judgment of charity.
Judges and senates have been bought for gold; / Esteem and love were never to be sold.
Judges are but men, and are swayed, like other
men, by vehement prejudices.
Judges ought to be more learned than witty, more reverent than plausible, and more advised than confident. Above all things, integrity is their portion and proper virtue.
Judgment for an evil thing is many times delayed some day or two, some century or two, but it is sure as life, it is sure as death.
Judgment is forced upon us by experience.
Judgment is not a swift-growing plant; it requires time and culture to mature it.
Judgment is turned away backward, and justice
standeth afar off; for truth is fallen in the street, and equity cannot enter.
Judgment must sway the feelings and keep them in their right place, or harm will be done where good was intended.
Judgments are prepared for scorners, and stripes for the back of fools.
Judgments that are made on the wrong side of the danger amount to no more than an affectation of skill, without either credit or effect.
Judicandum est legibus, non exemplis
Judicata res pro veritate accipitur
Judice te mercede caret, per seque petenda est / Externis virtus incomitata bonis
Judicia Dei sunt ita recondita ut quis illa scrutari nullatenus possit
Judicio acri perpendere
Judicious persons will think all the less of us because of the ill-judged praises of our silly friends.
Judicis est innocentiæ subvenire
Judicis est judicare secundum allegata et probata
Judicis est jus dicere non dare
Judicis officium est, ut res, ita tempora rerum quærere
Judicium a non suo judice datum nullius est momenti
Judicium Dei
Judicium parium aut leges terræ
Judicium subtile videndis artibus
Jugez un homme par ses questions, plutôt que par ses réponses
Jugulare mortuos
Juncta juvant
Junctæque Nymphis Gratiæ decentes

Junger Spieler, alter Bettler

Jusqu'où les hommes ne se portent-ils point par l'intérêt de la religion, dont ils sont si peu persuadés, et qu'ils pratiquent si mal?
Just a kind word and a yielding manner, and anger and complaining may be avoided.
Just a path that is sure, / Thorny or not, / And a heart honest and pure / Keeping the path that is sure, / That be my lot.
Just and true are thy ways, thou King of saints.
Just are the ways of God, / And justifiable to
men; / Unless there be who think not God at all.
Just as a moth gnaws a garment, so doth envy consume a man.
Just as "dirt is something in its wrong place," so social evils are mainly wrong applications of right powers.
Just as gymnastic exercise is necessary to keep the body healthy, so is musical exercise necessary to keep the soul healthy; the proper nourishment of the intellect and passions can no more take place without music than the proper functions of the stomach and the blood without exercise.
Just as the flint contains the spark, unknown to itself, which the steel alone can wake into life, so adversity often reveals to us hidden gems which prosperity or negligence would cause for ever to lie hid.
Just at the age 'twixt boy and youth, / When
thought is speech, and speech is truth.
Just enou', and nae mair, like Janet Howie's shearers' meat.
Just hatred of scoundrels, fixed, irreconcilable, inexorable enmity to the enemies of God; this, and not love of them, is the backbone of any religion whatsoever, let alone the Christian.
Just knows, and knows no more, her Bible true, / A truth the brilliant Frenchman never knew.
Just laws are no restraint upon the freedom of the good, for the good man desires nothing which a just law will interfere with.
Just plain duty to know, / Irksome or not, /
And truer and better to grow / In doing the duty I know, / That I have sought.
Justa razon engañar el engañador
Justæ causæ facilis est defensio
Juste milieu
Justi ut sidera fulgent
Justice always is, whether we define or not.
Everything done, suffered, or proposed in Parliament, or out of it, is either just or unjust; either is accepted by the gods and eternal facts, or is rejected by them.
Justice and humanity have been fighting their way, like a thunderstorm, against the organised selfishness of human nature. God has given manhood but one clue to success--utter and exact justice.
Justice and judgment are the habitation of God's throne.
