Make it an invariable and obligatory law to yourself never to mention your own mental diseases. When you talk of them, it is plain that you want either praise or pity; for praise there is no room, and pity will do you no good.
Make knowledge circle with the winds; / But let her herald, Reverence, fly / Before her to whatever sky / Bear seed of men and growth of minds.
Make no enemies; he is insignificant indeed that can do thee no harm.
Make not a bosom friend of a melancholy sad
soul.... He goes always heavy-loaded, and thou must bear half.
Make not another's shoes by your own foot.
Make not thy friend too cheap to thee, nor thyself to thy friend.
Make not thy sport abuses; for the fly, / That feeds on dung, is coloured thereby.
Make not thy tail broader than thy wings.
Make not two sorrows of one.
Make short the miles with talk and smiles.
Make temperance thy companion, so shall health sit on thy brow.
Make the most and the best of your lot, and compare yourself not with the few that are above you, but with the multitudes which are below you.
Make the most of time, it flies away so fast; yet method will teach you to win time.
Make the night night, and the day day, and
you will have a pleasant time of it.
Make the plaster as large as the sore.
Make thee my knight? my knights are sworn to vows / Of utter hardihood, utter gentleness, / And, loving, utter faithfulness in love, / And uttermost obedience to the king.
Make thick my blood, / Stop up the access and passage to remorse, / That no compunctious visitings of Nature / Shake my fell purpose.
Make thy claim of wages for this world, and all worlds, at zero--at nothing; thus, and thus only, hast thou the world at thy feet.
Make your educational laws strict, and your
criminal ones may be gentle; but leave youth its liberty, and you will have to dig dungeons for age.
Make your hay as best you may.
Make your mark, but mind what your mark is.
Make yourself an ass, and you'll have every man's sack on your shoulders.
Make yourself an honest man, and then you may be sure that there is one rascal less in the world.
Make yourself necessary to the world and
mankind will give you bread.
Make yourselves necessary to somebody.
Mal à propos
Mala causa silenda est
Mala fides
Mala gallina, malum ovum
Mala grammatica non vitiat chartam
Mala mali malo mala contulit omnia mundo
Mala mens, malus animus
Mala merx hæc, et callida est
Mala ultro adsunt
Maladie du pays
Male cuncta ministrat / Impetus
Male imperando summum imperium amittitur
Male parta male dilabuntur
Male partum male disperit
Male secum agit æger, medicum qui hæredem facit
Male verum examinat omnis / Corruptus judex
Male vivunt qui se semper victuros putant
Malebranche saw all things in God, and M. Necker saw all things in Necker.
Maledicus a malefico non distat nisi occasione
Malesuada fames
Malheureux celui qui est en avance de son siècle
Mali principii malus finis
Malice is a passion so impetuous and precipitate, that it often involves the agent and the patient.
Malice sucks up the greatest part of our own venom, and poisons herself.
Malim indisertam prudentiam, quam stultitiam loquacem
Malim inquietam libertatem quam quietum servitium
Malis avibus
Malo benefacere tantumdem est periculum / Quantum bono malefacere
Malo cum Platone errare, quam cum aliis recte sentire
Malo mihi male quam molliter esse
Malo mori quam fœdari
Malo nodo malus quærendus cuneus
Malorum facinorum ministri quasi exprobrantes aspiciuntur
Malum consilium consultori pessimum
Malum est consilium quod mutari non potest
Malum in se
Malum nascens facile opprimitur; inveteratum
fit robustius
Malum prohibitum
Malum vas non frangitur
Malus bonum ubi se simulat, tunc est pessimus
Malus est enim custos diuturnitatis metus, contraque benevolentia fidelis vel ad perpetuitatem
Malus usus est abolendus
Mammon has enriched his thousands, and has damned his ten thousands.
Mammon, the least erected spirit that fell / From heaven.
Mammon wins his way where seraphs might despair.
Man alone is born crying, lives complaining, and dies disappointed.
Man always worships something; always he
sees the infinite shadowed forth in something finite; and indeed can and must so see it in any finite thing, once tempt him well to fix his eyes thereon.
Man am I grown, a man's work must I do. / Follow the deer? follow the Christ, the King, / Live pure, speak true, right wrong, follow the King--/ Else wherefore born?
Man and man only can do the impossible; / ... He to the moment endurance can lend.
Man becomes greater in proportion as he learns to know himself and his faculty. Let him once become conscious of what he is, and he will soon also learn to be what he should.
Man becomes man only by the intelligence, but he is man only by the heart.
Man, behind his everlasting blind, which he
only colours differently, and makes no thinner, carries his pride with him from one step to another, and on the higher step blames only the pride of the lower.
Man can dispense with much but not with men.
Man can elect the universal man, / And live in life that ends not with his breath.
Man can invent nothing nobler than humanity.
Man can only learn to rise from the consideration of that which he cannot surmount.
Man cannot be a naturalist, until he satisfies all the demands of the spirit.
Man cannot choose his duties.
Man cannot live without his formulas.
Man carries under his hat a private theatre,
wherein a greater drama is acted than ever on the mimic stage, beginning and ending in eternity.
Man consists in truth. If he exposes truth, he exposes himself. If he betrays truth, he betrays himself. We speak not here of lies, but of acting against conviction.
Man could direct his ways by plain reason, and support his life by tasteless food; but God has given us wit, and flavour, and brightness, and laughter, and perfumes, to enliven the day of man's pilgrimage, and to charm his pained steps over the burning marl.
Man creeps into childhood, bounds into youth, sobers into manhood, and softens into age.
Man darf nur sterben, um gelobt zu werden
Man delights not me; no, nor woman neither.
Man disputirt mehr über die Schaale, als über den Kern
Man does not willingly submit himself to reverence; or rather, he never so submits himself: it is a higher sense which must be communicated to his nature, which only in some peculiarly favoured individuals unfolds itself spontaneously, who on this account too have of old been looked upon as saints and gods.
Man does not wish to be told the truth.
Man doth what he can, and God what He will.
Man dreams of fame while woman wakes to
love.
Man ever tends to reckon his own insight as final, and goes upon it as such.
Man everywhere is the born enemy of lies.
Man findet tausend Gelehrte, bis man auf einen weisen Mann stösst
Man for the field and woman for the hearth; / Man for the sword and for the needle she: / Man with the head and woman with the heart: / Man to command and woman to obey; / All else confusion.
Man, forget not death, for death certainly forgets
not thee.
Man gives up all pretension to the infinite while he feels here that neither with thought nor without it is he equal to the finite.
Man had not a hammer to begin, not a syllabled articulation; they had it all to make--and they have made it.
Man has a brief flowering season and a long fading.
Man has a silent and solitary literature written by his heart upon the tables of stone in Nature; and next to God's finger, a man's heart writes the most memorable things.
Man has a soul as certainly as he has a body;
nay, much more certainly; properly it is the course of his unseen spiritual life, which informs and rules his external visible life, rather than receives rule from it, in which spiritual life the true secret of his history lies.
Man has always humour enough to make merry with what he cannot help.
Man has ever been a striving, struggling, and, in spite of wide-spread calumnies to the contrary, a veracious creature.
Man has in his own soul an Eternal; can read something of the Eternal there, if he will look.
Man has not a greater enemy than himself.
Man has quite a peculiar pleasure in making
proselytes; in causing others to enjoy what he enjoys, in finding his own likeness represented and reflected back to him.
Man has seldom an offer of kindness to make to a woman but she has a presentiment of it some moments before.
Man has two and a half minutes here below--one to smile, one to sigh, and half a one to love; for in the midst of this minute he dies.
Man, if he compare himself with all he can see, is at the zenith of his power; but if he compare himself with all he can conceive, he is at the nadir of his weakness.
Man is a born owl.
Man is a bundle of habits.
Man is a darkened being; he knows not whence he comes, nor whither he goes; he knows little of the world and least of himself.
Man is a fallen god, who remembers heaven, his former dwelling-place.
Man is a forked radish with head fantastically carved.
Man is a forked straddling animal with bandy legs.
Man is a military animal, / Glories in gunpowder
and loves parade.
Man is a noble animal, splendid in ashes, and pompous in the grave.
Man is a poetical animal, and delights in fiction.
Man is a spirit, and bound by invisible bonds to all men.
Man is a stream whose source is hidden.
Man is a substance clad in shadows.
Man is a sun; his senses are the planets.
Man is a tool-using animal; ... without tools he is nothing, with tools he is all.
Man is actually here, not to ask questions but to do work; in this time, as in all times, it must be the heaviest evil for him if his faculty of action lie dormant, and only that of sceptical inquiry exert itself.
Man is an animal that cooks his victuals.
Man is an animal that makes bargains; no other animal does this.
Man is an imitative creature, and whoever is foremost leads the herd.
Man is, and always was, a blockhead and dullard; much readier to feel and digest than to think and consider.
Man is, beyond dispute, the most excellent of created beings, and the vilest animal is a dog; but the sages agree that a grateful dog is better than an ungrateful man.
Man is born not to solve the problems of the
universe, but to find out where the problem begins, and then to restrain himself within the limits of the comprehensible.
Man is born unto trouble, as the sparks fly upward.
Man is but a little thing in the midst of the objects of nature, yet, by the moral quality radiating from his countenance, he may abolish all considerations of magnitude, and, in his manners, equal the majesty of the world.
Man is but a reed, the weakest thing in nature, but he is a reed that thinks.
Man is created free, is free, even if he were born in chains.
Man is created to fight; he is perhaps best of
all definable as a born soldier; his life "a battle and a march" under the right generals.
Man is emphatically a proselytising creature.
Man is ever the most interesting object to man, and perhaps should be the only one to interest him.
Man is explicable by nothing less than all his history.
Man is fire and woman tow; the devil comes and sets them in a blaze.
Man is first a spirit, bound by invisible bonds
to all men; and secondly, he wears clothes, which are the visible emblems of that fact.
Man is for ever the born thrall of certain men, born master of certain other men, born equal of certain others, let him acknowledge the fact or not.
Man is for ever the brother of man.
Man is free as the bird is in its cage: he can move about within certain limits.
Man is God's image; but a poor man is / Christ's stamp to boot: both images regard. / God reckons for him, counts the favour His.
Man is greater than a world, than systems of
worlds; there is more mystery in the union of soul with the physical than in the creation of a universe.
Man is his own star, and the soul that can / Render an honest and a perfect man, / Commands all light, all influence, all fate; / Nothing to him falls early or too late.
Man is intended for a limited condition; objects that are simple, near, determinate, he comprehends, and he becomes accustomed to employ such means as are at hand; but on entering a wider field he now knows neither what he would nor what he should.
Man is like the worker at Gobelins, who weaves on the wrong side a tapestry of which he does not see the design.
Man is made great or little by his own will.
Man is man by virtue of willing, not by virtue
of knowing and understanding; and as he is, so he sees.
Man is man everywhere.
Man is man only as he makes life and nature happier to us.
Man is more often injured than helped by the means he uses.
Man is more than constitutions.
Man is neither an angel nor a brute, and it is
his evil destiny if he aspires to be the former, to sink into the latter.
Man is neither the vile nor the excellent being which he sometimes imagines himself to be.
Man is not a piece of clay to be moulded, but a plant to be cultivated.
Man is not as God, / But then most godlike, being most a man.
Man is not born to be free, and for the noble there is no fairer fortune than to serve a prince whom he honours.
Man is not God, but hath God's end to serve, /
A master to obey, a course to take, / Somewhat to cast off, somewhat to become.
Man is not made to question, but adore.
Man is not the creature of circumstances; circumstances are the creatures of men. We are free agents, and man is more powerful than matter.
Man is nothing but contradiction; the less he knows it the more dupe he is.
Man is of the earth, but his thoughts are with the stars. A pigmy standing on the outward crest of this small planet, his far-reaching spirit stretches outward to the infinite, and there alone finds rest.
Man is often a wolf to man, a serpent to God,
and a scorpion to himself.
Man is one, and he hath one great heart.
Man is one world, and hath / Another to attend him.
Man is only truly great when he acts from his passions; never irresistible but when he appeals to the imagination.
Man is only what he becomes, but he becomes only what he is.
Man is physically as well as metaphysically a
thing of shreds and patches, borrowed unequally from good and bad ancestors, and a misfit from the start.
Man is placed in this world as a spectator; when he is tired with wondering at all the novelties about him, and not till then, does he desire to be made acquainted with the causes that create those wonders.
Man is properly an incarnated word; the word that he speaks is the man himself.
Man is, properly speaking, based upon Hope, he has no other possession but Hope; this world of his is emphatically the Place of Hope.
Man is quite sufficiently saddened by his own passions and destiny, and need not make himself more so by the darkness of a barbaric past. He needs enlightening and cheering influences, and should therefore turn to those eras in art and literature during which remarkable men obtained perfect culture.
Man is so inconsistent a creature that it is impossible to reason from his belief to his conduct, or from one part of his belief to another.
Man is so prone to occupy himself with what is most common, the soul and the senses are so easily blunted to the impressions of the beautiful and perfect, that one ought by all means to preserve the capability of feeling it. We ought every day at least to hear a little song, read a good poem, see an excellent painting, and, if possible, speak a few reasonable words.
Man is that noble endogenous plant which grows, like the palm, from within outward.
Man is the arch-machine of which all these
shifts drawn from himself are toy models. He helps himself on each emergency by copying or duplicating his own structure, just so far as the need is
Man is the circled oak, woman the ivy.
Man is the dwarf of himself.
Man is the end towards which all the animal creation has tended.
Man is the favourite
in the sense that Nature has done everything for him, but that she has given him the power of doing everything for himself
Man is the higher sense of our planet, the
star which connects it with the upper world, the eye which it turns towards heaven
Man is the jewel of God, who has created this material world to keep his treasure in.
Man is the maker of expedients, but not of laws. In his solicitude as to his approaching lot, he has neither time nor desire to raise his eyes to the heavens to watch and record their phenomena; no leisure to look upon himself and consider what and where he is. In the imperious demand for a present support, he dare not venture on speculative attempts at ameliorating his state; he is doomed to be a helpless, isolated, spellbound savage, or, if not isolated, the companion of other savages as careworn as himself.
Man is the merriest species of the creation.
Man is the Messiah of Nature.
Man is the meter of all things; the hand is
the instrument of instruments, and the mind is the form of forms
Man is the Missionary of Order; he is the servant not of the devil and chaos, but of God and the universe.
Man is the nobler growth our realms supply, / And souls are ripened in our northern sky.
Man is the slave of beneficence.
Man is the sum-total of all the animals.
Man is the sun of the world; more than the
real sun. The fire of his wonderful heart is the only light and heat worth gauge or measure. Where he is, are the tropics; where he is not, the ice-world
Man is the weeping animal born to govern all the rest.
Man is the whole encyclopedia of facts. The creation of a thousand forests is in one acorn; and Egypt, Greece, Rome, Gaul, Britain, America, lie enfolded already in the first man.
Man is the will and woman is the sentiment. In this ship of humanity, Will is the rudder and Sentiment the sail; when woman affects to steer, the rudder is only a masked sail.
Man is to man the sorest, surest ill.... / Earth trembles ere her yawning jaws devour; / And smoke betrays the wide-consuming fire; / Ruin from man is most conceal'd when near, / And sends the dreadful tidings in the blow.
Man is too near all kinds of beasts--a fawning
dog, a roaring lion, a thieving fox, a robbing wolf, a dissembling crocodile, a treacherous decoy, a rapacious vulture
Man ist nur eigentlich lebendig, wenn man sich des Wohlwollens Anderer freut
Man, it's surely a pity that thou should'st sit yonder, with nothing but the eye of Omniscience to see thee, and thou with such gift to speak.
Man kan geen loopend paard beslaan
Man kann den Menschen nicht verwehren, / Zu denken, was sie wollen
Man kann ein klarer Denker ohne Gefühl
aber kein starker, kühner Denker ohne dasselbe sein
Man kann in wahrer Freiheit leben / Und doch nicht ungebunden sein
Man kann nicht stets das Fremde meiden, / Das Gute liegt uns oft so fern. / Ein echter deutscher Mann mag keinen Franzen leiden, / Doch ihre Weine trinkt er gern
Man kann nicht wider sein Geshick
Man knows nothing but what he has learned from experience.
Man kommt zu schaun, Man will am liebsten
sehn
Man lebt nur einmal in der Welt
Man, like the gen'rous vine, supported, lives;/ The strength he gains is from the embrace he gives.
Man little knows what calamities are beyond his patience to bear till he tries them.
Man lives in Time, has his whole earthly being, endeavour, and destiny shaped for him by Time; only in the transitory Time-symbol is the ever-motionless eternity we stand on made manifest.
Man lives where he acts.
Man, living, feeling man, is the easy sport of the overmastering present.
Man lobt den Künstler dann erst recht, wenn
man über sein Werk sein Lob vergisst
Man löst sich nicht allmählich von dem Leben!
Man loves before he sees; his heart is open before his eyes; love must irradiate his world for him before he well knows he is in it, what it is made of, and what to make of it.
Man loves little and often, woman much and rarely.
Man, made of the dust of the world, does not forget his origin; and all that is yet inanimate will one day speak and reason.
Man mag Amphion sein und Fels und Wald
bewegen, / Deswegen kann man doch nicht Bauern widerlegen
Man may doubt here and there, but mankind does not doubt.
Man muss die Menschen nur mit dem Krämergewicht, keinesweges mit der Goldwage wiegen
Man muss handeln können, wie man will, um zu handeln, wie man soll
Man muss keinem Menschen trauen, der bei seinen Versicherungen die Hand auf's Herz legt
Man muss nicht reicher scheinen wollen, als
man ist
Man muss seine Irrthümer theuer bezahlen, wenn man sie los werden will, und dann hat man noch von Glück zu sagen
Man muss, will man ein Glück geniessen, / Die Freiheit zu behaupten wissen
Man must hold fast by the belief that the incomprehensible is comprehensible, otherwise he would not search.
Man must serve his time to every trade / Save censure; critics all are ready made.
Man never comprehends how anthropomorphic
he is.
Man, never so often deceived, still watches for the arrival of a brother who can hold him steady to a truth until he has made it his own.
Man, on the dubious waves of error tost.
Man only can create music, for nothing is perfect until, in some way, it touches or passes through man.
Man only mars kind Nature's plan, / And turns the fierce pursuit on man.
Man ought always to have something which
he prefers to life.
Man partly is and wholly hopes to be.
Man perfected by society is the best of all animals; he is the most terrible of all when he lives without law and without justice.
Man proposes, God disposes.
Man, proud man, / Dress'd in a little brief authority; / Most ignorant of what he's most assur'd, / His glassy essence, like an angry ape, / Plays such fantastic tricks before high heaven, / As make the angels weep.
Man reconciles himself to almost every event,
however trying, if it happens in the ordinary course of nature. It is the extraordinary that he rebels against.
Man rettet gern aus trüber Gegenwart / Sich in das heitere Gebiet der Kunst, / Und für die Kränkungen der Wirklichkeit / Sucht man sich Heilung in des Dichters Träumen
Man schont die Alten, wie man die Kinder schont
Man shall not live by bread alone, but by every word that proceedeth out of the mouth of God.
Man should let alone other's prejudices and examine his own.
Man should not be over-anxious for a subsistence,
for it is provided by the Creator. The infant no sooner droppeth from the womb than the breasts of the mother begin to stream.
Man sieht sich, lernt sich kennen, / Liebt sich, muss sich trennen
Man soll die Stimmen wägen und nicht zählen
Man soll kein Buch nach dem Titelblatt beurtheilen
Man soll nicht mehr Teufel rufen, als man bannen kann
Man spends his life in reasoning on the past,
complaining of the present, and trembling for the future.
Man spricht selten von der Tugend, die man hat; aber desto öfter von der, die uns fehlt
Man spricht vergebens viel, nur zu versagen, / Der and're hört von allem nur das Nein!
Man spricht vom vielen Trinken stets, / Doch nie vom vielen Durste
Man steigt den grünen Berg des Lebens hinauf, um oben auf dem Eisberge zu sterben
Man steigt nicht ungestraft vom Göttermahle / Herunter in den Kreis der Sterblichen
Man supposes that he directs his life and
governs his actions, when his existence is irretrievably under the control of destiny.
Man, that is born of a woman, is of few days, and full of trouble.
Man, the aristocrat amongst the animals.
Man, the little god of this world, is still ever of the same stamp, and is as whimsical as on the first day.
Man the peasant is a being of more marked national character than man the educated and refined.
Man thee for the high endeavour, / Shun the
crowd's ignoble ease! / Fails the noble spirit never, / Wise to think and prompt to seize.
Man thereby
though based to all seeming on the small visible, does nevertheless extend down into the infinite deeps of the Invisible, of which Invisible, indeed, his life is properly the bodying forth.
Man thinks he has an estate of reputation, and is glad to see one that will bring any of it home to him; it is no matter how dirty a bag it is conveyed to him in, or by how clownish a messenger, so the money is good.
Man! / Thou pendulum betwixt a smile and a tear.
Man, though, as Swift has it, "a forked straddling animal with bandy legs," yet is also a spirit, and unutterable mystery of mysteries.
Man unconnected is at home everywhere,
unless he may be said to be at home nowhere.
Man verändert sich oft und bessert sich selten
Man wants but little here below, / Nor wants that little long.
Man was created to work--not to speculate, or feel, or dream.
Man were better relate himself to a statue or picture than to suffer his thoughts to pass in smother.
Man, while he loves, is never quite depraved.
Man, who lives to die, dies to live well, / So if he guide his ways by blamelessness / And earnest will to hinder not, but help, / All things both great and small which suffer life.
Man wird nie betrogen; man betrügt sich selbst
Man without patience is the lamp without oil, and pride in a rage is a bad counsellor.
Man without self-restraint is like a barrel without hoops, and tumbles to pieces.
Man yields to custom as he bows to fate, /
In all things ruled--mind, body, and estate; / In pain, in sickness, we for cure apply / To them we know not, and we know not why.
Man's activity is all too fain to relax; he soon gets fond of unconditional repose.
Man's best candle is his understanding.
Man's body and his mind are exactly like a jerkin and a jerkin's lining--rumple the one, you rumple the other.
Man's conviction should be strong, and so well timed that worldly advantages may seem to have no share in it.
Man's extremity is God's opportunity.
Man's first care should be to avoid the reproaches of his own heart; his next, to escape the censures of the world.
Man's grand fault is, and remains, that he has so many small ones.
Man's grief is but his grandeur in disguise, and discontent is immortality.
Man's gullability is not his worst blessing.
Man's heart eats all things, and is hungry
still.
Man's highest merit always is as much as possible to rule external circumstances, and as little as possible to let himself be ruled by them.
Man's history is little else than a narrative of designs that have failed and hopes that have been disappointed.
Man's inhumanity to man makes countless thousands mourn.
Man's liberty ends, and it ought to end, when that liberty becomes the curse of his neighbours.
Man's life and nature is as it was, and as it
will ever be.
Man's life is a progress, and not a station.
Man's life is an appendix to his heart.
Man's life is filed by his foe.
Man's life is never anything but an ever-vanishing present.
Man's life is not an affair of mere instinct, but
of steady self-control.
Man's life never was a sport to him; it was a stern reality--altogether a serious matter to be alive.
Man's life now, as of old, is the genuine work of God; wherever there is a man, a God also is revealed, and all that is godlike; a whole epitome of the Infinite, with its meanings, lies enfolded in the life of every man.
Man's love is of man's life a thing apart; / 'Tis woman's whole existence.
Man's obligations do not tend toward the past. We know of nothing that binds us to what is behind: our duty lies ahead.
Man's only true happiness is to live in Hope of something to be won by him, in Reverence of something to be worshipped by him, and in Love of something to be cherished by him, and cherished--for ever.
Man's own heart must be ever given to gain that of another.
Man's own judgment is the proper rule and measure of his actions.
Man's philosophies are usually the "supplement
of his practice;" some ornamental logic-varnish, some outer skin of articulate intelligence, with which he strives to render his dumb instinctive doings presentable when they are done.
Man's second childhood begins when a woman gets hold of him.
Man's spiritual nature is essentially one and indivisible.
Man's true, genuine estimate, / The grand criterion of his fate, / Is not--Art thou high or low? / Did thy fortune ebb or flow?
Man's unhappiness, as I construe, comes of his greatness; it is because there is an Infinite in him, which, with all his cunning, he cannot quite bury under the finite.
Man's walk, like all walking, is a series of
falls.
Man's word is God in man.
Man's work lasts till set of sun; / Woman's work is never done.
Manche gingen nach Licht und stürzten in tiefere Nacht nur; sicher im Dämmerschein wandelt die Kindheit dahin
Mancher wähnt sich frei, und siehet / Nicht die Bande, die ihn schnüren

Manebant vestigia morientis libertatis
Manège
Manet alta mente repostum, / Judicium Paridis spretæque injuria formæ
Mange-tout
Manhood begins joyfully and hopefully, not
when we have made a truce with necessity, or even surrendered to it, but only when we have reconciled ourselves to it, and learned to feel that in necessity we are free.
Manhood, when verging into age, grows thoughtful, / Full of wise saws and modern instances.
Manibus pedibusque
Manibus victoria dextris
Manifold is human strife, / Human passion, human pain; / Yet many blessings still are rife, / And many pleasures still remain.
Mankind are earthen jugs with spirits in them.
Mankind are unco' weak, / And little to be trusted; / If self the wavering balance shake, / It's rarely right adjusted.
Mankind at large alway resemble frivolous children; they are impatient of thought, and wish to be amused.
"Mankind follow their several bell-wethers; and if you hold a stick before the wether, so that he is forced to vault in his passage, the whole flock will do the like when the stick is withdrawn; and the thousandth sheep will be seen vaulting impetuously over air, as the first did over an otherwise impassable barrier."
Mankind in general agree in testifying their devotion, their gratitude, their friendship, or their love, by presenting whatever they hold dearest.
Mankind is a science that defies definitions.
 (
Mankind suffer to this hour, and will for long, as is like, because they do not know what to make of the fire of Prometheus. He dared to purloin from the gods and commit into the hands of ordinary men an only gods and their wise-hearted offspring can with safety handle.
Mankind will never lack obstacles to give it trouble, and the pressure of necessity to develop its powers.
Manliana
Männer richten nach Gründen; des Weibes Urteil ist seine Liebe; wo es nicht liebt, hat schon gerichtet das Weib
Manners are not idle, but the fruit / Of loyal
nature and of noble mind.
Manners are of more importance than laws; upon them in a great measure laws depend.
Manners are stronger than laws.
Manners are the happy ways of doing things; each once a stroke of genius or of love, now repeated and hardened into a usage.
Manners are the root, laws only the branches.
Manners are the shadows of virtues, the
momentary display of those qualities which our fellow-creatures love and respect.
Manners carry the world for the moment, character for all time.
Manners easily and rapidly mature into morals.
Manners make laws, manners likewise repeal them.
Manners make the man.
Manners must adorn knowledge, and smooth its way through the world. Like a great rough diamond, it may do very well in a closet by way of curiosity, and also for its intrinsic value.
Männliche, tüchtige Geister werden durch Erkennen eines Irrthums erhöht und gestärkt
Mantua me genuit, Calabri rapuere, tenet nunc / Parthenope. Cecini pascua, rura, duces
Mantua, væ! miseræ nimium vicina Cremonæ
Manu forti
Manu scriptum
Manufacture is intelligible but trivial; creation is great and cannot be understood.
Manum de tabula!
Manum non verterim, digitum non porrexerim
Manus e nubibus
Manus hæc inimica tyrannis
Manus manum lavat
Many a cow stands in the meadow and looks wistfully at the common.
Many a dangerous temptation comes to us
in fine gay colours that are but skin-deep.
Many a discord betwixt man and man the returning seasons soften by degrees into sweetest harmony; but that which bridges over the greatest gap is Love, whose charm unites the earth with heaven above.
Many a father might say, ... "I put in gold into the furnace, and there came out this calf."
Many a fine dish has nothing on it.
Many a genius has been of slow growth. Oaks, that flourish for a thousand years, do not spring up into beauty like a reed.
Many a good cow hath a bad calf.
Many a good drop of broth may come out of an old pot.
Many a good father hath but a bad son.
Many a hand moulded by Nature to give elegance of form to a kid glove is "stinted of its fair proportion" by grubbing toil.
Many a man is mad in certain instances, and goes through life without having perceived it.
Many a man settleth more by an inch of his
will than by an ell of his thrift.
Many a man's vices have at first been nothing worse than good qualities run wild.
Many a meandering discourse one hears, in which the preacher aims at nothing, and--hits it.
Many a one is good because he can do no mischief.
Many a one labours for the day he will never live to see.
Many a one threatens while he quakes for
fear.
Many a seeming farce played on the great stage of the world is in reality a tragedy, if we could but see into the heart of it.
Many a true word is spoken in jest.
Many a young damsel has been ruined by a fine copy of verses, which she would have laughed at if she had known it had been stolen from Mr. Waller.
Many acquaintances, but few friends.
Many acres will not make a wiseacre.
Many an honest man stands in need of help that has not the face to beg it.
Many an irksome noise, when a long way off, is heard as music.
Many and many a heart of woman, who has not uttered a word during her whole life, has felt more truly and intensely than the poet that has sung most sweetly.
Many are called but few chosen.
Many are idly busy. Domitian was busy, but
then it was catching flies.
Many are wise in jest but fools in earnest.
Many arrive at second masters / Upon their first lord's neck.
Many beat the sack, and mean the miller.
Many books owe their success to the good memories of their authors and the bad memories of their readers.
Many by-walks, many balks; many balks,
much stumbling.
Many can argue, not many converse.
Many can bear adversity, but few contempt.
Many can brook the weather that love not the wind.
Many can make bricks, but cannot build.
Many causes that can plead well for themselves
in the courts of Westminster, have yet in the general court of the universe and free soul of man no word to utter.
Many children, many cares; no children, no felicity.
Many commit sin and blame Satan.
Many cooks spoil the broth.
Many cut broad thongs out of other people's leather.
Many deceive themselves, imagining to find
happiness in change.
Many delight more in giving of presents than in paying their debts.
Many estates are spent in the getting, / Since women, for tea, forsook spinning and knitting, / And men, for their punch, forsook hewing and splitting.
Many find fault without any end, / And yet do nothing at all to mend.
Many flowers open to the sun, but only one follows him constantly. Heart, be thou the sunflower, not only open to receive God's blessing, but constant in looking to Him.
Many get into a dispute well that cannot get out well.
Many go in quest of wool, and come back shorn.
Many go out for clothes, and come home stript.
Many good purposes lie in the churchyard.
Many hands make light work.
Many have been harmed by speech; through thinking, few or none.
Many have been ruined by buying good penny-worths.
Many have been ruined by their fortunes; many have escaped ruin by the want of fortune. To obtain it, the great have become little, and the little great.
Many have come to port after a great storm.
Many have genius, / But, wanting art, are for
ever dumb.
Many have the talents which would make them poets if they had the genius; a few have the genius yet want the talents.
Many have too much, but none enough.
Many hope that the tree may be felled who expect to gather chips by the fall.
Many indifferent things which men originally did from a motive of some sort, they continue to do from habit.
Many kinds of books are permissible, but
there is one kind that is not permissible, the kind that has nothing in it
Many kiss the hand they wish cut off.
Many lick before they bite.
Many littles make a mickle.
Many are fain to praise what is right and do what is wrong.
Many men and women spend their lives in
unsuccessful attempts to spin the flax God sends them upon a wheel they can never use.
Many men attain a knowledge of what is perfect, and of their own insufficiency, and go on doing things by halves to the end of their days.
Many men fancy that what they experience they also understand.
Many men have been capable of doing a wise thing, more a cunning thing, but very few a generous thing.
Many men, in all ages, have triumphed over death, and led it captive; converting its physical victory into a moral victory for themselves, into a zeal and immortal consecration for all that their past life had achieved.
Many men involve themselves deeper in temptations
by being too solicitous to decline them.
Many men know how to flatter; few men know how to praise.
Many men love in themselves what they hate in others.
Many men spend their lives in gazing at their own shadows, and so dwindle away into shadows thereof.
Many of our troubles are God dragging us, and they would end if we would stand upon our feet, and go whither He would have us.
Many of sounding name from Jamblicus down
to Aubrey have wasted their time in devising imaginary remedies for non-existing diseases.
Many of the supposed increasers of knowledge have only given a new name, and often a worse, to what was well known before.
Many old camels carry the skins of the young ones to the market.
Many people are sincere without being simple. They do not wish to be taken for other than they are; and they always fear lest they should be taken for what they are not.
Many people place virtue more in regretting than in amendment.
Many people take no care of their money till
they have come nearly to an end of it, and others do just the same with their time.
Many people think of knowledge as of money. They would like knowledge, but cannot face the perseverance and self-denial that go to the acquisition of it.
Many readers judge of the power of a book by the shock it gives their feelings.
Many rendings need many mendings.
Many sacrifices have been made just to enjoy the feeling of vengeance, without any intention of causing an amount of injury equivalent to what one has suffered.
Many see more with one eye than others with
two.
Many shall run to and fro, and knowledge shall be increased.
Many so spend their whole term, and in ever-new expectation, ever-new disappointment, shift from enterprise to enterprise, and from side to side, till at length, as exasperated striplings of threescore and ten, they shift into their last enterprise, that of getting buried.
Many speak the truth when they say that they despise riches and preferment; but they mean the riches and preferment possessed by other men.
Many strokes, though with a little axe, / Hew down and fell the hardest timber'd oak.
Many talk like philosophers and live like fools.
Many that are first shall be last, and the last shall be first.
Many there be that buy nothing with their money but repentance.
Many things are too delicate to be thought; many more to be spoken.
Many things difficult to design prove easy of performance.
Many things there are / That we may hope to
win with violence; / While others only can become our own / Through moderation and wise self-restraint. / Such is virtue; such is love.
Many times death passeth with less pain than the torture of a limb; for the most vital parts are not the quickest of sense.
Many ventures make a full freight.
Many walk into the battle and are carried out of it.
Many waters cannot quench love, neither can the floods drown it.
Many words hurt more than swords.
Many would be cowards if they had courage enough.
Many would have been worse if their estates had been better.
Many young persons believe themselves natural when they are really ill-mannered and coarse.
Mar not what, marred, cannot be mended.
March dust is a thing / Worth ransom of a
king.
March winds and April showers.
Marchand qui perd ne peut rire
Marchandise de rencontre
Marchandise qui plait est à demie vendue

Mare clausum
Mare cœlo miscere
Mare ditat, rosa decorat
Mare quidem commune certo est omnibus
Margarita e stercore
Maria montesque polliceri cœpit
Mariage de convenance
Marie ton fils quand tu voudras, mais ta fille quand tu pourras
Mark if his birth makes any difference, if to his words it adds one grain of sense.
Mark what another says; for many are /
Full of themselves, and answer their own notion. / Take all into thee; then with equal care / Balance each chain of reason, like a potion.
Marmoreo Licinus tumulo jacet, at Cato parvo, / Pompeius nullo. Quis putet esse deos? / Saxa premunt Licinum, levat altum Fama Catonem, / Pompeium tituli. Credimus esse deos
Marriage, by making us more contented, causes us often to be less enterprising.
Marriage comes unawares, like a soot-drop.
Marriage, indeed, may qualify the fury of his passion, but it very rarely mends a man's manners.
Marriage is a desperate thing. The frogs in
Æsop were extremely wise; they had a great mind to some water, but they would not leap into the well, because they could not get out again.
Marriage is the best state for man in general; and every man is a worse man in proportion as he is unfit for the married state.
Marriage is the bloom or blight of all men's happiness.
Marriage is the feast where the grace is better than the dinner.
Marriage is the mother of the world, and preserves kingdoms, and fills cities and churches, and heaven itself.
Marriage must be a relation either of sympathy
or of conquest.
Marriage with peace is the world's paradise; with strife, this life's purgatory.
Marriages are best of dissimilar material.
Marriages are made in heaven.
Married couples resemble a pair of scissors, often moving in opposite directions, yet always punishing any one who comes between them.
Married in haste, we may repent at leisure.
Marry above your match, and you get a master.
Marry and grow tame.
Marry for love and work for siller.
Marry for love, but only love that which is lovely.
Marrying is easy, but housekeeping is hard.
Mars gravior sub pace latet
Martem accendere cantu
Mas vale buen amigo que pariente primo
Masses are rude, lame, unmade, pernicious in their demands and influence, and need not to be flattered, but to be schooled.
Mässigkeit und klarer Himmel sind Apollo
und die Musen
Masters are mostly the greatest servants in the house.
Masters should be sometimes blind and sometimes deaf.
Masters two / Will not do.
Mastery passes often for egotism.
Match-makers often burn their fingers.
Mater artium necessitas
Mater familias
Materia medica
Materia prima
Materialism coarsens and petrifies everything;
makes everything vulgar, and every truth false.
Materiem, qua sis ingeniosus, habes
Materiem superabat opus
Mathematic form is eternal in the reasoning memory; living form is eternal existence.
Mathematics can remove no prejudices and soften no obduracy. It has no influence in sweetening the bitter strife of parties, and in the moral world generally its action is perfectly null.
Matinée
Matrimony, the high sea for which no compass has yet been invented.
Matter exists only spiritually, and to represent some idea and body it forth.
Matter, were it never so despicable, is spirit, the manifestation of spirit: were it never so honourable, can it be more?
Mature fieri senem, si diu velis esse senex

Voreltern Pferde waren

Mauvais ton
Maxim or aphorism, let us remember that this wisdom of life is the true salt of literature; that those books are most nourishing which are most richly stored with it, and that it is one of the main objects ... which men ought to seek in the reading of books.

Maxima illecebra est peccandi impunitatis spes
Maxima quæque domus servis est plena superbis
Maximas virtutes jacere omnes necesse est,
voluptate dominante
Maxims are to the intellect what laws are to actions; they do not enlighten, but they guide and direct.
Maximum remedium iræ dilatio est!
Maximus in minimis
Maximus novator tempus

master.
May cauld ne'er catch you but a hap, / Nor hunger but in plenty's lap.
May never wicked fortune touzle

May the idea of pureness, extending itself even to the very morsel which I take into my mouth, become ever dearer and more luminous within me.

Me justum esse gratis oportet

Me, poor man, my library was dukedom large enough.
Me (they will kill) when they are mad, but you when they recover their reason.
Mea virtute me involvo
Meal is finer than grain; women are finer than men.
Meals and matins minish never.
Mean spirits under disappointment, like small beer in a thunderstorm, always turn sour.
Measure men around the heart.
Measure not by a scale of perfection the meagre product of reality.
Measure three times before you cut once.
Measure your cloth ten times; you can cut
it but once.
Measures, not men, have always been my mark.
Meat and matins hinder no man's journey.
Meat is devoured by the birds in the air, by the beasts in the fields, and by the fishes in the waters; so, in every situation, there is plenty.
Meat is more than its carving, and truth is more than oratory.
Mecum facile redeo in gratiam
Medici, causa morbi inventa, curationem inventam putant
Medicines are not meant to feed on.
Medio de fonte leporam / Surgit amari aliquid
quod in ipsis floribus angat
Medio tutissimus ibis
Médiocre et rampant, et l'on arrive à tout
Mediocria firma
Mediocribus esse poetis / Non Di, non homines, non concessere columnæ
Mediocrity can talk, but it is for genius to observe.
Mediocrity is not allowed to poets either by gods or men.
Mediocrity of enjoyment only is allowed to
man.
Meditation has taught all men in all ages that this world is after all but a show--a phenomenon or appearance, no real thing.
Meditation is a busy search in the storehouse of phantasy for some ideas of matters to be cast in the moulds of resolution into some forms of words and action; in which search I find this is the best conclusion, that to meditate on the best is the best of meditations, and a resolution to make a good end is a good end of my resolutions.
Meditation is the life of the soul; action, the soul of meditation; honour, the reward of action.
Meditation is the soul's perspective glass, whereby in her long removes she discerneth God as if he were nearer at hand.
Medium tenuere beati!
Meekness is not mere white-facedness, a mere contemplative virtue; it is maintaining peace and patience in the midst of pelting provocations.
Meekness is not weakness.
Meekness is the bridle of anger.
Meekness is the cherish'd bent / Of all the truly great and all the innocent.
Meglio amici da lontano che nemici d'appresso
Meglio solo che mal accompagnato
Meglio tardi che mai
Mehr Leute beten die aufgehende, als die untergehende Sonne an
Mehr Licht!
Meikle crack fills nae sack.
Mein einz'ger Wunsch ist meiner Wünsche Ruhe
Mein erst Gesetz ist, in der Welt / Die Frager zu vermeiden
Mein Herz gleicht ganz dem Meere, / Hat Sturm und Ebb' und Flut, / Und manche schöne Perle / In seiner Tiefe ruht
Mein Leben ist für Gold nicht feil
Mein Leipzig lob' ich mir! / Es ist klein Paris, und bildet seine Leute
Mein Pathos brächte dich gewiss zum Lachen, / Hätt'st du dir nicht das Lachen abgewöhnt
Mein Ruh' ist hin, / Mein Herz ist schwer; / Ich finde sie nimmer / Und nimmermehr
Mein Sohn, nichts in der Welt ist unbedeutend. / Das erste aber und Hauptsächlichste / Bei allem ird'schen Ding ist Ort und Stunde
Mein Wille ist rein, das weitere gebe ich der
Vorsehung anheim!
Meine Herren, did you never hear of the man that vilified the sun because it would not light his cigar?
Meine Zeit in Unruhe, meine Hoffnung in Gott!
Meiner Idee nach ist Energie die erste und einzige Tugend des Menschen
Meines Lebens Wunsch ist stiller Friede
Mel in ore, verba lactis, / Fel in corde, fraus in
factis
Melancholy advanceth men's conceits more than any humour whatever.
Melancholy attends on the best joys of a merely ideal life.
Melancholy is the pleasure of being sad.
Melancholy spreads itself betwixt heaven and earth, like envy between man and man, and is an everlasting mist.
Melior est conditio possidentis
Melior tutiorque est certa pax, quam sperata victoria
Meliora sunt ea quæ natura, quam quæ arte perfecta sunt
Meliores priores
Melioribus auspiciis
Melius est pati semel, quam cavere semper
Melius est peccata cavere quam mortem fugere
Melius, pejus, prosit, obsit, nil vident nisi quod libuerit
Mellitum venenum, blanda oratio
Membra reformidant mollem quoque saucia tactum; / Vanaque sollicitis incutit umbra metum
Même quand l'oiseau marche, on sent qu'il a des ailes
Meminerunt omnia amantes
Memini etiam quæ nolo: oblivisci non possum quæ volo
Memor et fidelis
Memorabilia
Memorem immemorem facit, qui monet quod memor meminit
Memoria in æterna
Memoria minuitur, nisi eam exerceas
Memoriter
Memory always obeys the commands of the heart.
Memory, and thou, Forgetfulness, not yet / Your powers in happy harmony I find; / One oft recalls what I would fain forget, / And one blots out what I would bear in mind.
Memory is a Muse in herself; or rather the
mother of the Muses.
Memory is like a purse: if it be over-full, that it cannot be shut, all will drop out of it.
Memory is not so brilliant as hope, but it is more beautiful, and a thousand times more true.
Memory is the cabinet of imagination, the treasury of reason, the registry of conscience, and the council-chamber of thought.
Memory is the conservative faculty.
Memory is the friend of wit, but the treacherous
ally of invention.
Memory is the golden thread linking all the mental gifts and excellencies together.
Memory
Memory is the primary and fundamental power, without which there could be no other intellectual operation.
Memory is the scribe of the soul.
Memory, of all things good remind us still: /
Forgetfulness, obliterate all that's ill.
Memory tempers prosperity, mitigates adversity, controls youth, and delights old age.
Memory, the warder of the brain.
Men and communities in this world are often in the position of Arctic explorers, who are making great speed in a given direction, while the ice-floe beneath them is making greater speed in the opposite.
Men and cucumbers are worth nothing as soon as they are ripe.
Men and pyramids are not made to stand on
their head.
Men and women who "grill" over the petty annoyances incident to existence, and inseparable from it, go to ruin like a careworn cat.
Men apt to promise are apt to forget.
Men are April when they woo, December when they wed.
Men are as the time is.
Men are at best only stewards, and they are
very select men indeed who are elected of heaven to this honour. The most want the necessary discrimination, and are in their place only when, like Athenian maidens, "bearers of the basket."
Men are but children of a larger growth; / Our appetites are apt to change as theirs, / And full as craving too, and full as vain.
Men are content to be brushed like flies from the path of a great person, so that justice shall be done by him to that common nature which it is the dearest desire of all to see enlarged and glorified.
Men are contented to be laughed at for their wit, but not for their folly.
Men are enlisted for the labour that kills; let them be enlisted for the labour that feeds; and let the captains of the latter be held as much gentlemen as the captains of the former.
Men are eternally divided into the two classes
of poet (or believer, maker, and praiser), and dunce (or unbeliever, unmaker, and dispraiser).
Men are everything, measures are comparatively nothing.
Men are generally more careful of the breed of their horses and dogs than of their children.
Men are happy in proportion as their range of vision, their sphere of action, and their points of contact with the world are restricted and circumscribed.
Men are impatient and for precipitating things; but the Author of Nature appears deliberate throughout his operations, accomplishing his natural ends by slow successive steps.
Men are in general so tricky, so envious, and
so cruel, that when we find one who is only weak, we are too happy.
Men are led by trifles.
Men are less afraid of injuring one who awakens love than one who inspires fear.
Men are like flies--for men are insects too, / Little in mind, howe'er our bodies run!--/ We're all in sects: in sects that hate each other, / And deem it love of God to hate one's brother.
Men are like sheep, of which a flock is more easily driven than a single one.
Men are made by nature unequal: it is vain, therefore, to treat them as if they were equal.
Men are men; the best sometimes forget.
Men are more inclined to ask curious questions than to obtain necessary instruction.
Men are most apt to believe what they least understand.
Men are mostly so slow, their thoughts overrun
'em, an' they can only catch 'em by the tail.
Men are much in disposition and feelings according to the nature of the country which they inhabit.
Men are much more prone (the greater is the pity) both to speak and believe ill than well of their neighbours.
Men are never so easily deceived as while they are endeavouring to deceive others.
Men are never wise but returning from law.
Men are not always what they seem to be.
Men are not influenced by things, but by their thoughts about things.
Men are not leaning willows, but can and must detach themselves.
Men are not put into this world to be everlastingly fiddled on by the fingers of joy.
Men are not so ungrateful as they are said to be. If they are often complained of, it generally happens that the benefactor claims more than he has given.
Men are not to be measured by inches.
Men are often capable of greater things than they perform. They are sent into the world with bills of credit, and seldom draw to their full extent.
Men are oftener treacherous through weakness than design.
Men are readier to forgive calumny than admonition
Men are respectable only as they respect.
Men are seldom blessed with good fortune and
good sense at the same time.
Men are seldom more innocently employed than when they are making money.
Men are so constituted that everybody would rather undertake himself what he sees done by others, whether he has aptitude for it or not.
Men are solitary among each other; no one will help his neighbour; each has even to assume a defensive attitude lest his neighbour should hinder him.
Men are tatooed with their special beliefs like so many South Sea islanders; but a real human heart, with divine love in it, beats with the same glow under all the patterns of all earth's thousand tribes.
Men are the sport of circumstances, when
the circumstances seem the sport of men.
Men are unwiser than children; they do not know the hand that feeds them.
Men are very generous with that which costs them nothing.
Men are we, and must grieve when even the shade / Of that which once was great is passed away.
Men are what their mothers made them.
Men are wiser than they know.
Men at most differ as heaven and earth, / But women, worst and best, as heaven and hell.
Men at some time are masters of their fate.
Men blush less for their crimes than for their weaknesses and vanities.
Men can be estimated by those who know them not, only as they are represented by those who know them.
Men / Can counsel, and speak comfort to that
grief / Which they themselves not feel; but, tasting it, / Their counsel turns to passion, which before / Would give preceptial medicine to rage, / Fetter strong madness in a silken thread, / Charm ache with air and agony with words.
Men can make an idol of the Bible.
Men can see through a barn-door, they can. Perhaps that's the reason they can see so little o' this side on't.
Men cannot be well educated without the Bible.
Men cannot benefit those that are with them as they can benefit those that come after them; and of all the pulpits from which the human voice is ever sent forth, there is none from which it reaches so far as from the grave.
Men cannot live by lending money to each
other.
Men cannot live isolated; we are all bound together, for mutual good or else for mutual misery, as living nerves in the same body. No highest man can disunite himself from any lowest.
Men carry the head erect indeed, yet how mean and cringing are the thoughts within.
Men cease to interest us when we find their limitations.
Men chew not when they have no bread.
Men commonly think according to their inclinations,
speak according to their learning and imbibed opinions, but generally act according to custom.
Men complain of not finding a place of repose. They are in the wrong; they have it for seeking. What they indeed should complain of is, that the heart is an enemy to that very repose they seek.
Men contemplate distinctions because they are stupefied with ignorance
Men deal with life as children with their play, / Who first misuse, then cast their toys away.
Men deride what they do not understand, and snarl at the good and beautiful because it lies beyond their sympathies.
Men descend to meet.
Men do not make their homes unhappy because they have genius, but because they have not enough genius.
Men don't and can't live by exchanging articles, but by producing them: they don't live by trade but by work.
Men dream in courtship, but in wedlock wake.
Men, elevated above all states, are now the
educators of states--dead men, for instance, like Plato.
Men err from selfishness, women because they are weak.
Men fear death as children fear to go in the dark.
Men fear only him who does not know them, and he who shuns them will soon misjudge them.
Men feed themselves rather upon illusion than upon truth.
Men find it more easy to flatter than to praise.
Men have been wise in very different modes; but they have always laughed the same way.
Men have but too much cause to secure themselves from men.
Men have come to speak of the revelation as somewhat long ago given and done, as if God were dead.
Men have many faults; / Poor women have but two; / There's nothing good they say, / And nothing right they do.
Men have their metal, as of gold and silver.
Men in all ways are better than they seem.
Men in general experience a great joy in colour. The eye needs it as much as it does light. Let any one recall the refreshing sensation one experiences when on a gloomy day the sun shines out on a particular spot on the landscape, and makes the colours of it visible. That healing powers were ascribed to coloured precious stones may have arisen out of the deep feeling of this inexpressible pleasure.
Men in great place are thrice servants--servants of the sovereign or state, servants of fame, and servants of business.
Men, in spite of all their failings, best deserve our affections of all that exists.
Men learn behaviour, as they take diseases,
one of another.
Men like advising the women better than doing right themselves.
Men, like bullets, go farthest when they are smoothest.
Men, like musical instruments, seem made to be played upon.
Men, like peaches and pears, grow sweet a little while before they begin to decay.
Men look to what people think of them;
women to what they say.
Men love at first, and most warmly; women love last and longest. This is natural enough, for nature makes women to be won, and men to win.
Men love in haste, but they detest at leisure.
Men love things best; women love persons best.
Men love to nurse their cares, and seem as uneasy without some fret, as an old friar would be without his hair-girdle.
Men love us, or they need our love.
Men make the best friends.
Men may live fools, but fools they cannot die.
Men may rise on stepping-stones / Of their dead selves to higher things.
Men might live quiet and easy enough, if they would be careful not to give themselves trouble, and forbear meddling with what other people do and say, in which they are in no way concerned.
Men more easily renounce their interests than
their tastes.
Men must be taught as though you taught them not.
Men must endure / Their going hence, even as their coming hither: / Ripeness is all.
Men must have righteous principles in the first place, and then they will not fail to perform virtuous actions.
Men must leave the ingle-nook, / And for a larger wisdom brook / Experience of a harder law, / And learn humility and awe.
Men must work, and women must weep, /
Though storms be sudden, and waters deep, / And the harbour bar be moaning.
Men no longer wholly believe; in this age of blindness and scientific pride, no one is any longer seen bowing before his god on both his knees.
Men no sooner find their appetites unanswered than they complain the times are injurious.
Men of age object too much, consult too long, adventure too little, repent too soon, and seldom drive business home to the full period, but content themselves with a mediocrity of success.
Men of courage, men of sense, and men of letters are frequent; but a true gentleman is what one seldom sees.
Men of few words are the best men.
Men of genius are dull and inert in society; as the blazing meteor, when it descends to the earth, is only a stone.
Men of genius are rarely much annoyed by the company of vulgar people, because they have a power of looking at such persons as objects of amusement of another race altogether.
Men of genius do not excel in any profession because they labour in it, but they labour in it because they excel.
Men of genius have acuter feelings than common men; they are like the wind-harp, which answers to the breath that touches it, now low and sweet, now rising into wild swell or angry scream, as the strings are swept by some passing gust.
Men of God have always, from time to time, walked among men, and made their commission felt in the heart and soul of the commonest hearer.
Men of great gifts you will easily find, but symmetrical men never.
Men of great intellect live in the world without really belonging to it.
Men of great learning or genius are too full to be exact, and therefore choose to throw down their pearls in heaps before the reader, rather than be at the pains of stringing them.
Men of great parts are often unfortunate in
the management of public business, because they are apt to go out of the common road by the quickness of their imagination.
Men of humour are always in some degree men of genius; wits are rarely so, although a man of genius may, amongst other gifts, possess wit, as Shakespeare.
Men of most renowned virtue have sometimes by transgressing most truly kept the law.
Men of science should leave controversy to the little world below them.
Men of sense esteem wealth to be the assimilation of nature to themselves, the converting of the sap and juices of the planet to the incarnation and nutriment of their design.
Men of sense often learn from their enemies.
 (_
Men of the first quality learn nothing, and become wise; men of the second rank become of the third sort remain stupid, and learn words.
Men of the greatest abilities are most fired with ambition, and, on the contrary, mean and narrow minds are the least actuated by it.
Men of true wisdom and goodness are contented to take persons and things as they are, without complaining of their imperfections or attempting to amend them.
Men of uncommon abilities generally fall into eccentricities when their sphere of life is not adequate to their powers.
Men only associate in parties by sacrificing
their opinions, or by having none worth sacrificing; and the effect of party government is always to develop hostilities and hypocrisies, and to extinguish ideas.
Men only rightly know themselves as far as they have experimented on things.
Men ought to find the difference between saltness and bitterness.
Men possessed with an idea cannot be reasoned with.
Men possessing small souls are generally the authors of great evils.
Men prize the thing ungained more than it is.
Men rate the virtues of the heart at almost nothing, while they idolise endowments of body and intellect.
Men rattle their chains to show that they are free.
Men run away to other countries because they are not good in their own, and run back to their own because they pass for nothing in the new places.
Men say their pinnacles point to heaven. Why, so does every tree that buds, and every bird that rises as it sings. Men say their aisles are good for worship. Why, so is every mountain glen and rough seashore. But this they have of distinct and indisputable glory,--that their mighty walls were never raised, and never shall be, but by men who love and aid each other in their weakness.
Men seek within the short span of life to
satisfy a thousand desires, each of which alone is insatiable.
Men seem to be led by their noses, but in reality it is by their ears.
Men should be prized, not for their exemption from fault, but the size of those virtues they are possessed of.
Men should be what they seem; / Or those that be not, would they might seem none.
Men should keep their eyes wide open before marriage, and half-shut afterwards.
Men should not be told of the faults which
they have mended.
Men show their character in nothing more clearly than by what they think laughable.
Men, some to business, some to pleasure take; / But every woman is at heart a rake; / Men, some to quiet, some to public strife; / But every lady would be queen for life.
Men speak but little when vanity does not induce them to speak.
Men spend their lives in the service of their passions instead of employing their passions in the service of their lives.
Men still are what they always have been, a
medley
often obedient to reason, and oftener to passion; so have they come down the stream of time for six thousand years, and mostly in such shape as the moment has fashioned them.
Men that are ruined are ruined on the side of their natural propensities.
Men that hazard all / Do it in hope of fair advantages.
Men that make / Envy and crooked malice nourishment / Dare bite the best.
Men think highly of those who rise rapidly in the world; whereas nothing rises quicker than dust, straw, and feathers.
Men think they are quarrelling with one
another, and both sides feel that they are in the wrong.
Men think to mend their condition by a change of circumstances. They might as well hope to escape their shadows.
Men tire themselves in pursuit of rest.
Men trust rather to their eyes than to their ears; the effect of precepts is therefore slow and tedious, whilst that of examples is summary and effectual.
Men understand not what is among their hands; as calmness is the characteristic of strength, so the weightiest causes may be the most silent.
Men use, if they have an evil turn, to write it in marble, and whoso doth us a good turn we write it in dust.
Men, who are knaves individually, are in the mass very honourable people.
Men who begin by losing their independence will end by losing their energy.
Men who, being always bred in affluence,
see the world only on one side, are surely improper judges of human nature.
Men who earn nothing but compliments are not likely to be very diligent in so unprofitable a service.
Men who form their judgment upon sense often err.
Men who know the same things are not long the best company for each other.
Men who make money rarely saunter; men who save money rarely swagger.
Men who their duties know, / But know their
rights, and, knowing, dare maintain.
Men will always act according to their passions. Therefore the best government is that which inspires the nobler passions and destroys the meaner.
Men will blame themselves for the purpose of being praised.
Men will die for an opinion as soon as for anything else.
Men will face powder and steel, because they cannot face public opinion.
Men will forget what we suffer, and not what
we do.
Men will marry a fool that sings, sooner than one that has learned to scoff.
Men will wrangle for religion, write for it, fight for it, die for it--anything but live for it.
Men work themselves into atheistical judgments by atheistical practice.
Men would be angels, angels would be gods.
Men would not live long in society, were they
not the mutual dupes of each other.
Men's actions are not to be judged of at first sight.
Men's actions are too strong for them. Show me a man who has acted, and who has not been the victim and slave of his action.
Men's best successes come after their disappointments.
Men's evil manners live in brass; their virtues / We write in water.
Men's hearts ought not to be set against one
another, but set with one another, and all against the evil thing only.
Men's ignorance makes the priest's pot boil.
Men's muscles move better when their souls are making merry music.
Men's natures wrangle with inferior things, / Though great ones are their object.
Men's prosperity is in their own hands, and no forms of government are, in themselves, of the least use.
Men's souls 'twixt sorrow and love are cast.
Men's thoughts and opinions are, in a great degree, vassals of him who invents a new phrase or reapplies an old epithet.
Men's thoughts are much according to their inclinations; their discourses and speeches, according to their learning and infused opinions.
Men's vows are women's traitors.
Menace-moi de vivre et non pas de mourir
Ménage
Mendacem memorem esse oportet
Mendaces, ebriosi, verbosi
Mendaci homini, ne verum quidem dicenti credere solemus
Mendici, mimi, balatrones, et hoc genus omne
Mendico ne parentes quidem amici sunt
Mendings are honourable, rags are abominable.
Mens æqua rebus in arduis
Mens agitat molem
Mens bona regnum possidet
Mens conscia recti
Mens cujusque est quisque
Mens immota manet; lachrymæ volvuntur inanes
Mens interrita lethi
Mens invicta manet
Mens peccat, non corpus, et unde consilium
