Mens sana in corpore sano
Mens sine pondere ludit
Mensa et toro
Menschenkenntniss ist Unglaube an Tugend und Redlichkeit
Menschlich ist es bloss zu strafen, / Aber
göttlich zu verzeihn
Mensque pati durum sustinet ægra nihil
Mensuraque juris / Vis erat
Mental courage, infinitely rarer than valour, presupposes the most eminent qualities.
Mental pleasures never cloy: unlike those of the body, they are increased by repetition, approved of by reflection, and strengthened by enjoyment.
Mental prayer
and excludes all religions, and only in a few God-favoured men permeates the whole course of life, develops itself in most men as only a blazing, beatific feeling of the moment, immediately after the vanishing of which the man, thrown in upon himself unsatisfied and unoccupied, lapses back into the most utter and absolute weariness.
Mentally and bodily endowed men are the
most modest, while, on the other hand, all who have some peculiar mental defect think a great deal more of themselves.
Mentis gratissimus error
Mentis penetralia
Menu
Menus plaisirs
Meo sum pauper in ære
Merces virtutis laus est
Mercy and truth are met together; righteousness and peace have kissed each other.
Mercy but murders, pardoning those that kill.
Mercy is above this sceptred sway, / It is enthronéd in the hearts of kings, / It is an attribute to God himself; / And earthly power doth then show likest God's / When mercy seasons justice.
Mercy is not itself, that oft looks so; / Pardon
is still the nurse of second woe.
Mercy, misericordia, does not in the least mean forgiveness of sins, but pity of sorrows.
Mercy to him that shows it is the rule.
Mercy turns her back to the unmerciful.
Mercy's gate opens to those who knock.
Mere bashfulness without merit is awkward,
and merit without modesty insolent; but modest merit has a double claim to acceptance.
Mere family never made a man great. Thought and deed, not pedigree, are the passports to enduring fame.
Mere madness, to live like a wretch and die rich.
Mere pleasure ought not to be the prime motive of action.
Mere sensibility is not true taste, but sensibility to real excellence is.
Mere wishes are bony fishes.
Merit and good works is the end of man's motion, and conscience of the same is the accomplishment of man's rest.
Merit, however inconsiderable, should be sought for and rewarded.
Merit in appearance is oftener rewarded than merit itself.
Merit is never so conspicuous as when coupled with an obscure origin, just as the moon never appears so lustrous as when it emerges from a cloud.
Merit lives from man to man.
Merry be the first, / And merry be the last, / And merry be the first of August.
Merry larks are ploughmen's clocks.
Merx ultronea putret
Mésalliance
Messe tenus propria vive
Metaphysicians and philosophers are, on the whole, the greatest troubles the world has got to deal with.... Busy metaphysicians are always entangling good and active people, and weaving cobwebs among the finest wheels of the world's business, and are, as much as possible, by all prudent persons, to be brushed out of their way.
Metaphysics, with which physics cannot dispense, is that wisdom of thought which was before all physics, lives with it, and will endure after it.
Method is the very hinge of business.
Method will teach you to win time.
Methods are the masters of masters.
Methought I heard a voice cry, Sleep no more!
Métier d'auteur, métier d'oseur
Metiri se quemque suo modulo ac pede verum
est
Mettre les pieds dans le plat
Metuenda corolla draconis
Meum et tuum
Meus mihi, suus cuique est carus
Mezzo termine
Micat inter omnes
Mich dräng'st den Grundtext aufzuschlagen, / Mit redlichem Gefühl einmal / Das heilige Original / In mein geliebtes Deutsch zu übertragen
Mich hat mein Glaube nicht betrogen!
Mich plagen keine Scrupel noch Zweifel, / Fürchte mich weder vor Hölle noch Teufel
Mich schuf aus gröberm Stoffe die Natur, / Und zu der Erde zieht mich die Begierde
Mid pleasures and palaces though we may roam, / Be it ever so humble, there's no place like home; / A charm from the skies seems to hallow us there, / Which, sought through the world, is ne'er met with elsewhere.
Midst the crowd, the hum, the shock of men, / To hear, to see, to feel, and to possess, / And roam along, the world's tired denizen, / With none who bless us, none whom we can bless; / ... This is to be alone; this, this is solitude!
Mieux nourri qu'instruit
Mieux serra
Mieux vaut glisser du pied que de la langue
Mieux vaut perdre la laine que la brebis
Mieux vaut un bon renom, que du bien plein la maison
Mieux vaut un "Tiens" que deux "Tu l'auras"
Mieux vaut une once de fortune qu'une livre
de sagesse
Mieux vaut voir un chien enragé, qu'un soleil chaud en Janvier
Might and right do differ frightfully from hour to hour; but give them centuries to try it in, they are found to be identical.
Mightier far / Than strength of nerve or sinew, or the sway / Of magic, potent over sun and star, / Is Love, though oft to agony distrest, / And though his favourite seat be feeble woman's breast.
Mightiest powers by deepest calms are fed, / And sleep, how oft, on things that gentlest be.
Mighty events turn on a straw; the crossing
of a brook decides the conquest of the world.
Migravit ab aure voluptas / Omnis
Mihi est propositum in taberna mori
Mihi forsan, tibi quod negarit, / Porriget hora
Mihi istic nec seritur nec metitur
Mihi res, non me rebus, subjungere conor
Mihi tarda fluunt ingrataque tempora
Mildness governs more than anger.
Militat omnis amans
Militiæ species amor est
Mille hominum species et rerum discolor usus; /
Velle suum cuique est, nec voto vivitur uno
Mille verisimili non fanno un vero
Millia frumenti tua triverit area centum, / Non tuus hinc capiet venter plus ac meus
Millions of spiritual creatures walk the earth / Unseen, both when we wake and when we sleep.
Minatur innocentibus qui parcit nocentibus
Mind and body are intimately related; if the
former is joyful, the latter feels free and well; and many an evil flies before cheerfulness.
Mind and body--that beauteous couple--exercise much and variously, but at home, at home, indoors, and about things indoors; for God is there too.
Mind is stronger than matter; mind is the creator and shaper of matter; not brute force, but only persuasion and faith is the king of this world.
Mind is the great lever of all things; human thought is the process by which human ends are ultimately answered.
Mind is the partial side of men; the heart is everything.
Mind not high things, but condescend to men
of low estate.
Mind unemployed is mind unenjoyed.
Mind your P's and Q's.
Mind your work, and God will find your wages.
Minds are of celestial birth; / Make we then a heaven of earth.
Minds that have nothing to confer / Find little
to perceive.
Minds that never rest are subject to many digressions.
Mind the corner where life's road turns.
Mine honour my life is; both grow in one; / Take honour from me, and my life is done.
Minimæ vires frangere quassa valent
Minima de malis
Minister flicken am Staate, / Die Richter flicken am Rate, / Die Pfarrer an dem Gewissen, / Die Aerzte an Händen und Füszen! O Jobsen! was flickest denn du? / Weit besser! Gerissene Schuh!
Minor est quam servus, dominus qui servos timet
Minorities lead and save the world, and the world knows them not till long afterwards.
Minuentur atræ / Carmine curæ
Minuit præsentia famam
Minus afficit sensus fatigatio quam cogitatio
Minuti / Semper et infirmi est animi exiguique voluptas / Ultio
Minutiæ
Mir gäb' es keine gröss're Pein, / Wär' ich im Paradies allein
Mir wird bei meinem kritischen Bestreben / Doch oft um Kopf und Busen bang
Mira quædam in cognoscendo suavitas et delectatio
Mirabile dictu!
Mirabile visu!
Miracles are ceased, and therefore we must needs admit the means, how things are perfected.
Miracles do not serve to convert, but condemn.
Miramur ex intervallo fallentia
Miremur te non tua
Mirth is God's medicine.
Mirth is like a flash of lightning, that breaks through a gloom of clouds, and glitters for a moment; cheerfulness keeps up a kind of daylight in the mind, and fills it with a steady and perpetual serenity.
Mirth is short and transient, cheerfulness fixed and permanent.
Misce stultitiam consiliis brevem
Miscellaneous reading avoid.
Mischief, thou art afoot; / Take thou what
course thou wilt.
Mise en scène
Misera contribuens plebs!
Misera est magni custodia census
Misera est servitus ubi jus est aut vagum aut incognitum
Miserable beyond all names of wretchedness
is that unhappy pair who are doomed to reduce beforehand to the principles of abstract reason all the details of each domestic day.
Miseram pacem vel bello bene mutari
Misericordia Domini inter pontem et fontem
Miseros prudentia prima relinquit
Miserrima est fortuna quæ inimico caret
Miserum est aliorum incumbere famæ / Ne
collapsa ruant subductis tecta columnis
Misery acquaints a man with strange bedfellows.
Misery and ruin to thousands are in the blast that announces the destructive demon
Misery doth part / The flux of company.
Misery is like love; to speak its language truly, the author must have felt it.
Misery is trodden down by many, / And, being
low, never relieved by any.
Misery that I miss is a new mercy.
Misfortune is never mournful to the soul that accepts it; for such do always see that every cloud is an angel's face.
Misfortune sprinkles ashes on the head of the man, but falls like dew on the head of the woman, and brings forth germs of strength of which she herself had no conscious possession.
Misfortune, when we look upon it with our eyes, is smaller than when our imagination sinks the evil down into the recesses of the soul.
Misfortunes come on wings and depart on foot.
Misfortunes have their dignity and their redeeming power.
Misfortunes never come single.
Misfortunes when asleep are not to be wakened.
Mislike me not for my complexion, / The shadow'd livery of the burnish'd sun, / To whom I am a neighbour and near bred.
Misreckoning is no payment.
Mist of words, / Like halos round the moon, though they enlarge / The seeming size of thoughts, make the light less / Doubly.
Mistake not, man; the devil never sleeps.
Mistrust the man who finds everything good, and the man who finds everything evil, and still more the man who is indifferent to everything.
Misunderstanding brings lies to town.
Misunderstanding goes on like a fallen stitch
in a stocking, which in the beginning might have been taken up with a needle.
Mit deinem Meister zu irren ist dein Gewinn
Mit dem Genius steht die Natur im ewigen Bunde! / Was der eine verspricht, leistet die andre gewiss
Mit dem Wissen wächst der Zweifel
Mit der Dummheit kämpfen Götter selbst vergebens
Mit Frauen soll man sich nie unterstehn zu scherzen
Mit fremdem Gut ist leicht ein Prasser sein
Mit Kleinen thut man kleine Thaten, / Mit Grossen wird der Kleine gross
Mit seltsamen Geberden / Giebt man sich
viele Pein; / Kein Mensch will etwas werden, / Ein jeder will schon was sein
Mit vier Strangschlägern zu fahren ist gefährlich, aber ich werde es versuchen
Mit Worten lässt sich trefflich streiten / Mit Worten ein System bereiten, / An Worten lässt sich trefflich glauben, / Von einem Wort lässt sich kein Iota rauben
Mit Worten nicht, mit Thaten lasst mich danken
Mitgefühl erweckt Vertrauen; / Und Vertrauen ist der Schlüssel / Der des Herzens Pforte öffnet
Mittagsschlaf ist ein brennend Licht am Tage
Mitte hanc de pectore curam
Mittimus
Mobilis et varia est ferme natura malorum
Mobilitate viget, viresque acquirit eundo
Mobilium turba Quiritium
Mock me not with the name of free, when you have but knit up my chains into ornamental festoons.
Mockery is the fume of little hearts.
Moderari animo et orationi, cum sis iratus, non mediocris ingenii est
Moderata durant
Moderate lamentation is the right of the dead,
excessive grief the enemy to the living.
Moderate riches will carry you; if you have more, you must carry them.
Moderation and judgment are, for most purposes, more than the flash and the glitter even of genius.
Moderation is good, but moderation alone is no virtue
Moderation is the inseparable companion of wisdom, but with genius it has not even a nodding acquaintance.
Moderation is the silken string running through
the pearl chain of all virtues.
Moderation is the virtue best adapted to the dawn of prosperity.
Modern education has devoted itself to the teaching of impudence, and then we complain we can no more manage our mobs.
Modern education too often covers the fingers with rings, and at the same time cuts the sinews at the wrists.
Modern poets put a great deal of water in their ink.
Modern Protestantism sees in the cross, not a
furca to which it is to be nailed, but a raft on which it, and all its valuable properties, are to be floated into Paradise.
Modern revolution has nothing grand about it; it is merely the resolution of society into its component atoms.
Modern science gives lectures on botany, to show there is no such thing as a flower; on humanity, to show there is no such thing as a man; and on theology, to show there is no such thing as a God. No such thing as a man, but only a mechanism. No such thing as a God, but only a series of forces.
Modest demeanour's the jewel of a'!
Modest dogs miss much meat.
Modest doubt is called / The beacon of the
wise, the tent that searches / To the bottom of the worst.
Modest expression is a beautiful setting to the diamond of talent and genius.
Modest humility is beauty's crown, for the beautiful is a hidden thing, and shrinks from its own power.
Modeste tamen et circumspecto judicio de tantis viris pronunciandum est, ne, quod plerisque accidit, damnent quæ non intelligunt
Modesty and presumption are moral things of so spiritual a nature, that they have little to do with the body.
Modesty is a quality in a lover more praised
by the women than liked.
Modesty is a very good thing, but a man in this country may get on very well without it.
Modesty is so pleased with other people's doings that she has no leisure to lament her own.
Modesty is the beauty of women.
Modesty is the colour of virtue.
Modesty is the sweet song-bird which no open
cage-door can tempt to flight.
Modesty is to merit what the shadows are to the figures on a picture; it imparts to it force and relief.
Modesty ruins all that bring it to court.
Modesty seldom resides in a breast that is not enriched with nobler virtues.
Modesty when she goes, is gone for ever.
Modo et forma
Modo me Thebis, modo ponit Athenis
Modo vir, modo femina
Modus operandi
Mögt ihr Stück für Stück bewitzeln, / Doch das Ganze zieht euch an
Moi, moi, dis je, et c'est assez
Moins on pense plus on parle
Moles and misers live in their graves.
Molesta et importuna salutantium frequentia
Molle meum levibus cor est violabile telis
Mollis educatio nervos omnes et mentis et
corporis frangit
Mollissima corda / Humano generi dare se natura fatetur, / Quæ lachrymas dedit: hæc nostri pars optima sensus
Mollissima tempora fandi
Molliter austerum studio fallente laborem
Molliter ossa cubent
Momento mare vertitur; / Eodem die ubi
luserunt, navigia sorbentur
Mon âme a son secret, ma vie a son mystère
Mon cœur aux dames, / Ma vie au roi, / A Dieu mon âme, / L'honneur pour moi
Mon Dieu est ma roche
Mon frère a mis son bonnet de travers
Monarchy is a merchantman, which sails well,
but will sometimes strike on a rock and go to the bottom; whilst a republic is a raft, which would never sink, but then your feet are always in water.
Monday is the key of the week.
Monday religion is better than Sunday profession.
Mone sale
Money answers everything, / Save a guilty conscience sting.
Money begets money.
Money borrowed is soon sorrowed.
Money calls, but does not stay: / It is round and rolls away.
Money is a bottomless sea, in which honour, conscience, and truth may be drowned.
Money is a good servant, but a dangerous master.
Money is human happiness in the abstract;
he, then, who is no longer capable of enjoying human happiness in the concrete, devotes his heart entirely to money.
Money is like an icicle, soon found at certain seasons, and soon melted under other circumstances.
Money is not required to buy one necessity of the soul.
Money is the fruit of evil as often as the root of it.
Money is the god of our time, and Rothschild is his prophet.
Money is the most envied, but the least enjoyed;
health is the most enjoyed, but the least envied.
Money is the ruin of many.
Money is the sinew of love as well as of war.
Money, like manure, does no good till it is spread.
Money makes the mare to go.
Money masters all things.
Money never made a man happy yet, nor will it. There is nothing in its nature to produce happiness. The more a man has, the more he wants.
Money often costs too much.
Money often unmakes the men who make it.
Money refused loses its brightness.
Money spent on the brain is never spent in
vain.
Moniti, meliora sequamur
Monkeys, as soon as they have brought forth their young, keep their eyes fastened on them, and never weary of admiring their beauty; so amorous is Nature of whatever she produces.
Monstro quod ipse tibi possis dare: semita certe / Tranquillæ per virtutem patet unica vitæ
Monstrum horrendum, informe, ingens, cui lumen ademptum
Monstrum nulla virtute redemptum / A vitiis
Mont de piété
Montes auri pollicens
Montesquieu, with his cause-and-effect philosophy, is but a clever infant spelling letters from a hieroglyphical prophetic Book, the lexicon of which lies in eternity, in Heaven.
Monuments, like men, submit to fate.
Monuments themselves memorials need.
Mony an honest man needs that hasna the
face to seek it.
Mony ane speirs the gate
they ken fu' weel.
Mony kinsfolk, but few freends.
Moonlight is sculpture.
Moping melancholy.
Mora omnis odio est, sed facit sapientiam
Moral culture must begin with a change
in the way of thinking, and with the founding of a character.
Moral education begins in making the creature to be educated clean and obedient; and it is summed up when the creature has been made to do its work with delight, and thoroughly.
Moral inability aggravates our guilt.
Moral prejudices are the stopgaps of virtue; and, as is the case with other stopgaps, it is often more difficult to get either out or in through them than through any other part of the fence.
Moral qualities rule the world, but at short
distances the senses are despotic.
Morality is a curb, not a spur.
Morality is but the vestibule of religion.
Morality sticks faster when presented in brief sayings than when presented in long discourses.
Morals are generated as the atmosphere is. 'Tis a secret the genesis of either; but the springs of justice and courage do not fail any more than salt or sulphur springs.
Morceau
Morceau d'ensemble
More are drowned in the beaker than in the sea.
More are made good by exercitation than by nature.
More credit may be thrown down in a moment than can be built up in an age.
More hearts pine away in secret anguish for
unkindness from those who should be their comforters than for any other calamity in life.
More helpful than all wisdom is one draught of simple human pity that will not forsake us.
More is got from one book on which the thought settles for a definite end in knowledge, than from libraries skimmed over by a wandering eye. A cottage flower gives honey to the bee, a king's garden none to the butterfly.
More knave than fool.
More light, more life, more love.
More majorum
More matter with less art.
More meat and less mustard.
More pleased we are to see a river lead / His gentle streams along a flowery mead, / Than from high banks to hear loud torrents roar, / With foamy waters on a muddy shore.
More potatoes and fewer potations.
More servants wait on man / Than he'll take
notice of.
More sinn'd against than sinning.
More springs up in the garden than the gardener sows there.
More suo
More than all things, avoid fault-finding and a habit of criticism.
More than kisses letters mingle souls.
More than we use is more than we want.
More things are wrought by prayer / Than this world dreams of.
More water glideth by the mill / Than wots the miller of.
Mores amici noveris, non oderis
Mores multorum vidit
Morgen können wir's nicht mehr, / Darum lasst uns heute leben!
Morgen, morgen, nur nicht heute! / Sprechen immer träge Leute
Morgenstunde hat Gold im Munde
Moriamur, et in media arma ruamus
Moribus antiquis res stat Romana virisque
Moribus et forma conciliandus amor
Morituri morituros salutant
Morose thoughts one should never send to a distance.
Moroseness is the evening of turbulence.
Mors et fugacem persequitur virum
Mors ipsa refugit sæpe virum!
Mors janua vitæ
Mors laborum ac miseriarum quies est!
Mors potius macula
Mors sola fatetur / Quantula sint hominum
corpuscula
Mors ultima linea rerum est
Mortales inimicitias, sempiternas amicitias
Mortalia acta nunquam Deos fallunt
Mortalia facta peribunt, / Nedum sermonum stet honos et gratia vivax
Mortality is beset on every side with crosses, and exposed to suffering every moment.
Mortalium rerum misera beatitudo
Morte carent animæ, semperque priore relicta / Sede novis domibus vivunt habitantque receptæ
Mortem effugere nemo potest!
Mortuo leoni et lepores insultant
Mos pro lege
Moses and Mahomet were not men of speculation,
but men of action; and it is the stress they laid upon the latter that has given them the power they wield over the destinies of mankind.
Most authors steal their works, or buy.
Most dangerous / Is that temptation that doth goad us on / To sin in loving virtue.
Most felt, least said.
Most joyful let the poet be; / It is through him that all men see.
Most men and most women are merely one
couple more.
Most men do not know what is in them till they receive the summons from their fellows; their hearts die within them, sleep settles upon them--the lethargy of the world's miasmata; there is nothing for which they are so thankful as for that cry, "Awake, thou that sleepest."
Most men forget God all day, and ask Him to remember them at night.
Most men I ask little from; I try to render them much, and to expect nothing in return, and I get very well out of the bargain.
Most men make the voyage of life as if they carried sealed orders which they were not to open till they were fairly in mid-ocean.
Most men never reach the glorious epoch, that
middle stage between despair and deification, in which the comprehensible appears to us common and insipid.
Most men of action incline to fatalism, and most men of thought believe in Providence.
Most men take no notice of what is plain, as if that were of no use; but puzzle their thoughts to be themselves in those vast depths and abysses which no human understanding can fathom.
Most men think indistinctly, and therefore cannot speak with exactness.
Most men will proclaim every one his own goodness: but a faithful man who can find?
Most men write now as if they expected that
their works should live no more than a month.
Most natures are insolvent; cannot satisfy their own wants, have an ambition out of all proportion to their practical force, and so do lean and beg day and night continually.
Most of our evils come from our vices.
Most of the appearing mirth in the world is not mirth, but art; the wounded spirit is not seen, but walks under a disguise.
Most of the luxuries, and many of the so-called comforts of life, are not only not indispensable, but positive hindrances, to the elevation of mankind.
Most of the mischief in the world would never
happen if men would only be content to sit still in their parlours.
Most people think now-a-days the only hopeful way of serving your neighbour is to make a profit out of him; whereas, in my opinion, the hopefulest way of serving him is to let him make a profit out of me.
Most people, when they come to you for advice, come to have their own opinions strengthened, not corrected.
Most people who ask advice of others have already resolved to act as it pleases them.
Most potent, effectual for all work whatsoever, is wise planning, firm combining and commanding among men.
Most powerful is he who has himself in his
power.
Most religion-mongers have bated their paradises with a bit of toasted cheese. They have tempted the body with large promises of possessions in their transmortal El Dorado.
Most strange that men should fear, / Seeing that death, a necessary end, / Will come when it will come.
Most subject is the fattest soil to weeds.
Most terrors are but spectral illusions.
Most things have two handles, and a wise
man takes hold of the best.
Most women have no characters at all.
Most wretched men / Are cradled into poetry by wrong; / They learn in suffering what they teach in song.
Mot à mot
Mot à mot on fait les gros livres
Mot d'ordre
Mot pour rire
Mother, a maiden is a tender thing, / And best by her that bore her understood.
Mother's darlings are but milksop heroes.
Mother's love is the cream of love.
Mother's truth keeps constant youth.
Motives are better than actions.
Motives are symptoms of weakness, and supplements for the deficient energy of the living principle, the law within us.
Motley's the only wear.
Mots d'usage
Motu proprio
Mountains interposed / Make enemies of nations, who had else / Like kindred drops been mingled into one.
Mountains never shake hands. Their roots may touch; they may keep company some way up; but at length they part company, and rise into individual, isolated peaks. So it is with great men.
Mourning only lasts till morning with the children of the morning.
Mourning tendeth to mending.
Movet cornicula risum / Furtivis nudata coloribus
Moving accidents by flood and field.
Mrs. Chatterbox is the mother of mischief.
Much bruit, little fruit.
Much corn lies under the straw that is not seen.
Much debating goes on about the good that
has been done and the harm by the free circulation of the Bible. To me this is clear: it will do harm, as it has done, if used dogmatically and fancifully; and do good, as it has done, if used didactically and feelingly.
Much exists under our very noses which has no name, and can get none.
Much food is in the tillage of the poor.
Much in the world may be done by severity, more by love, but most of all by discernment and impartial justice.
Much learning is a weariness of the flesh.
Much learning shows how little mortals know;
much wealth, how little worldlings can enjoy.
Much lies among us convulsively, nay, desperately, struggling to be born.
Much meat, much disease.
Much might be said on both sides.
Much of the good or evil that befalls persons arises from the well or ill managing of their conversation.
Much of the pleasure, and all the benefit of
conversation, depends upon our own opinion of the speaker's veracity.
Much of this world's wisdom is still acquired by necromancy--by consulting the oracular dead.
Much of what is great, and to all men beneficial, has been wrought by those who neither intended nor knew the good they did; and many mighty harmonies have been discoursed by instruments that had been dumb and discordant but that God knew their stops.

Much reading makes one haughty and pedantic; wise, sociable, and helpful.
Much religion, but no goodness.
Much rust needs a rough file.
 (_Missver
Much there is that appears unequal in our life, yet the balance is soon and unexpectedly restored. In eternal alternation a weal counterbalances the woe, and swift sorrows our joys. Nothing is constant. Many an roll on, is gradually and imperceptibly dissolved in harmony. And ah! love knows how to reconcile the greatest discrepancy and unite earth with heaven.
Mucho sabe la zorra, pero mas el que la toma
Mud chokes no eels.
Mudar costumbre a par de muerte
Muddy spring, muddy stream.
Mugitus labyrinthi
Mules deliver great discourses because their ancestors were horses.
Mulier cupido quod dicit amanti, / In vento et rapida scribere oportet aqua
Mulier profecto nata est ex ipsa mora
Mulier quæ sola cogitat male cogitat
Mulier recte olet ubi nihil olet
Multa cadunt inter calicem supremaque labra
Multa dies, variusque labor mutabilis ævi, / Retulit in melius
Multa docet fames
Multa fero ut placeam genus irritabile vatum
Multa ferunt anni venientes commoda secum; / Multa recedentes adimunt
Multa gemens
Multa me docuit usus, magister egregius
Multa novit vulpis, sed felis unam magnum
Multa paucis
Multa petentibus / Desunt multa
Multa quidem scripsi; sed quæ vitiosa putavi, / Emendaturis ignibus ipse dedi
Multa renascentur quæ jam cecidere, cadentque / Quæ nunc sunt in honore vocabula, si volet usus, / Quem penes arbitrium est, et jus, et norma loquendi
Multa rogant utenda dari; data reddere nolunt
Multa senem circumveniunt incommoda
Multa tacere loquive paratas
Multa tulit, fecitque puer, sudavit et alsit
Multæ manus onus levius faciunt
Multæ regum aures et oculi
Multæ terricolis linguæ, cœlestibus una
Multarum palmarum causidicus
Multas amicitias silentium diremit
Multi adorantur in ara qui cremantur in igne
Multi / Committunt eadem diverso crimina fato, / Ille crucem sceleris pretium tulit, hic diadema
Multi mortales, dediti ventri atque somno, indocti incultique vitam sicuti peregrinantes transiere; quibus profecto contra naturam corpus voluptati, anima oneri
Multi multa, nemo omnia novit
Multi nil rectum nisi quod placuit sibi ducunt
Multi te oderint si teipsum ames
Multis ille bonis flebilis occidit / Nulli flebilior quam tibi
Multis minatur, qui uni facit injuriam
Multis parasse divitias non finis miseriarum fuit, sed mutatio; non est in rebus vitium sed in animo
Multis terribilis caveto multos
Multitudinem decem faciunt
Multo plures satietas quam fames perdidit viros
Multos castra juvant, et lituo tubæ / Permistus sonitus, bellaque matribus / Detestata
Multos in summa pericula misit / Venturi timor ipse mali
Multos ingratos invenimus, plures facimus
Multos qui conflictari adversis videantur, beatos; ac plerosque, quanquam magnas per opes, miserrimos
Multum abludit imago
Multum demissus homo
Multum in parvo
Multum, non multa
Multum sapit qui non diu desipit
Mundæque parvo sub lare pauperum / Cœnæ, sine aulæis et ostro, / Sollicitam explicuere frontem
Munditiæ, et ornatus, et cultus hæc feminarum insignia sunt, his gaudent et gloriantur
Munditiis capimur
Mundus est Dei viva statua!
Mundus universus exercet histrionem
Mundus vult decipi; ergo decipiatur
Munera accipit frequens, remittit nunquam
Munera, crede mihi, capiunt hominesque deosque; / Placatur donis Jupiter ipse datis!
Munificence is not quantity, but quality.
Munit hæc, et altera vincit
Munus Apolline dignum
Munus ornare verbis
Murder, though it have no tongue, will speak / With most miraculous organ.
Murder will out.
Muras æneus conscientia sana
Mus in pice
Mus non uni fidit antro
Music fills up the present moment more decisively than anything else, whether it awakens thought or summons to action.
Music hath charms to soothe the savage
breast.
 (_Neuh
Music in the best sense has little need of it is, the more one is accustomed to it, the greater is the effect it produces.
Music, in the works of its greatest masters, is more marvellous, more mysterious, than poetry.
Music is a kind of inarticulate unfathomable speech, which leads us to the edge of the infinite, and lets us for moments gaze that.
Music is a language directed to the passions; but the rudest passions put on a new nature and become pleasing in harmony.
Music is a prophecy of what life is to be, the rainbow of promise translated out of seeing into hearing.
Music is an invisible dance, as dancing is a silent music.
Music is but wild sounds civilised into time and tune.
Music is our fourth great material want--first
food, then raiment, then shelter, then music.
Music is the art of the prophets, the only art which can calm the agitations of the soul.
Music is the crystallisation of sound.
Music is the mediator between the spiritual and the sensual life.
Music is the most immediate means possessed by the will for the manifestation of its inner impulses.
Music is the only one of the fine arts in which
not only man, but all other animals, have a common property.
Music is the only sensual gratification which mankind may indulge in to excess without injury to their moral and religious feelings.
Music is the poor man's Parnassus.
Music is the true universal speech of mankind.
Music makes people milder and gentler, more moral and more reasonable.
Music, of all the arts, has the greatest influence
over the passions, and the legislator ought to give it the greatest encouragement.
Music of the spheres.
Music oft hath such a charm / To make bad good, and good provoke to harm.
Music, once admitted into the soul, becomes a sort of spirit, and never dies.
Music so softens and disarms the mind, / That not an arrow does resistance find.
Music stands in a much closer connection with
pure sensation than any of the other arts.
Music washes away from the soul the dust of everyday life.
Music, when healthy, is the teacher of perfect order; and also when depraved, the teacher of perfect disorder.
Music will not cure the toothache.
Music wraps us in melancholy, and elevates in joy.
Musik ist der Schlüssel vom weiblichen Herzen
Musik ist die wahre allgemeine Menschensprache
Muss ist eine harte Nuss
Müsset im Naturbetrachen / Immer eins wie alles achten; / Nichts ist drinnen, nichts ist draussen, / Denn was innen, das ist aussen. / So ergreifet ohne Säumness / Heilig öffentlich Geheimniss
Müssiggang ist aller Laster Anfang
Must is a hard nut to crack, but it has a sweet
kernel.
"Must" is hard, but by "must" alone can man show what his inward condition is. Any one can live unrestrainedly.
Must not a great history be always an epic?
Mutability is the badge of infirmity.
Mutare vel timere sperno
Mutatis mutandis
Mutato nomine, de te / Fabula narratur
Mutum est pictura poema
My alms-people are to be the ablest bodied I can find, the ablest minded I can make, and every day will be a duty ... shall stand with tools at work, mattock or flail, axe or hammer.
My ancient but ignoble blood / Has crept through scoundrels ever since the Flood.
My better half.
My bounty is as boundless as the sea, / My love as deep; the more I give to thee, / The more I have, for both are infinite.
My dame fed her hens on thanks, but they laid no eggs.
My days are in the yellow leaf; / The flowers and fruits of love are gone; / The worm, the canker, and the grief / Are mine alone.
"My family begins with me, yours ends with you."
My fate cries out, / And makes each petty
artery in this body / As hardy as the Nemean lion's nerve.
My first and last secret of Art is to get a thorough intelligence of the fact to be painted, represented, or, in whatever way, set forth--the fact deep as Hades, high as heaven, and written so, as to the visual face of it on this poor earth.
My grief lies onward, and my joy behind.
"My hand," said Napoleon, "is immediately connected with my head," but the sacred courage is connected with the heart.
My heart leaps up when I behold / A rainbow in the sky: / So was it when my life began, / So is it now I am a man; / So be it when I shall grow old, / Or let me die.
My heart is true as steel.
My heart resembles the ocean; has storm, and ebb, and flow; / And many a beautiful pearl / Lies hid in its depths below.
My heart's in the Highlands, my heart is not here.
My highest wish is to find within the God whom I find everywhere without.
My house is my castle.
My house, my house, though thou art small, / Thou art to me the Escurial.
"My ideal of a society is one in which I would
be guillotined as a Conservative."
My inheritance how wide and fair! / Time is my seed-field, to Time I'm heir.
My joy in friends, those sacred people, is my consolation.
My joy is death;--/ Death, at whose name I oft have been afeared, / Because I wish'd this world's eternity.
My mind can take no hold on the present world, nor rest in it a moment, but my whole nature rushes onward with irresistible force towards a future and better state of being.
My mind to me a kingdom is, / Such perfect joy
therein I find.
My name is Norval; on the Grampian hills my father feeds his flock.
My notions of life are much the same as they are about travelling; there is a good deal of amusement on the road, but, after all, one wants to be at rest.
My offence is rank; it smells to heaven.
My only books / Were woman's looks,--/ And folly's all they've taught me.
My opinion, my conviction, gains infinitely in
strength and sureness the moment a second mind has adopted it.
My pen was never dipped in gall.
My perception of a fact is as much a fact as the sun.
My pulse, as yours, doth temperately keep time, / And makes as healthful music.
My purposes lie in the churchyard.
My rigour relents: I pardon something to the
spirit of liberty.
My son, be not now negligent, for the Lord hath chosen thee to stand before Him.
My son is my son till he have got him a wife, / But my daughter's my daughter all the days of her life.
My soul, what's lighter than a feather? Wind. / Than wind? The fire. And what than fire? The mind. / What's lighter than the mind? A thought. Than thought? / This bubble world. What than this bubble? Nought.
My strength is as the strength of ten, because my heart is pure.
My way of life / Is fall'n into the sere, the yellow
leaf; / And that which should accompany old age, / As honour, love, obedience, troops of friends, / I must not look to have; but in their stead, / Curses, not loud, but deep, mouth-honour, breath / Which the poor heart would fain deny, but dare not.
My words fly up, my thoughts remain below; /
Words, without thoughts, never to heaven go.
My yoke is easy and my burden light.
Myn leeren is spelen, myn spelen is leeren
Mysteries are due to secrecy.
Mysteries which must explain themselves are
not worth the loss of time which a conjecture about them takes up.
Mysterious to all thought, / A mother's prime of bliss, / When to her eager lips is brought / Her infant's thrilling kiss.
Mystery magnifies danger, as a fog the sun; the hand that warned Belshazzar derived its horrifying influence from the want of a body.
Mystic, deep as the world's centre, are the roots a man has struck into his native soil; no tree that grows is rooted so.
Mysticism consists in the mistake of an accidental and individual symbol for a universal one.
Mythology is not religion. It may rather be
regarded as the ancient substitute, the poetical counterpart, for dogmatic theology.
N'aboyez pas à la lune
N'est on jamais tyran qu'avec un diadème?
N'importe
N'oubliez
Naboth was right to hold on to his home.
There were garnered memories that all the wealth of Ahab could not buy.
Nace en la huerta lo que no siembra el hortelano
Nach Canossa gehen wir nicht
Nach Ehre geizt die Jugend; / Lass dich den Ehrgeiz nicht verführen
Nach Freiheit strebt der Mann, das Weib nach Sitte
Nach Golde drängt, / Am Golde hängt, / Doch
alles. Ach, wir Armen!
Nach Gottes Wesenheit ist gar nicht dein Beruf zu forschen; forsche du nach Wesen, die er schuf
Nacheifern ist beneiden
Nachgeben stillt allen Krieg
Nacht muss es sein, wo Friedlands Sterne strahlen
Næ amicum castigare ob meritam noxiam / Immune est facinus
Nae butter 'll stick to my bread,
Nae freen' like the penny.
Nae fules like auld fules.
Nae man can be happy without a friend, nor
be sure of him till he's unhappy.
Nae man can live at peace unless his neighbours let him.
Nae man can mak' his ain hap
Nae man can tether time or tide.
Nae man can thrive unless his wife will let him.
Nae man has a tack
Nae man is wise at a' times, nor wise on a' things.
Nae treasures nor pleasures / Could mak' us happy lang, / The heart aye's the part aye / That mak's us right or wrang.
Nae wonder ye're auld like; ilka thing fashes

Naething is a man's truly but what he cometh by duly.
Naething is got without pains but an ill name.
Naething is got without pains except dirt and long nails.
Naething is ill said if it's no ill ta'en.
Nager entre deux eaux
Naiv muss jedes wahre Genie sein, oder es ist keines
Naked truth is out of place before the eyes of
the profane vulgar; it can only make its appearance thickly veiled.
Nakedness is uncomely, as well in mind as body; and it addeth no small reverence to men's manners and actions if they be not altogether open.
Nam de mille fabæ modiis dum surripis unum, / Damnum est, non facinus mihi pacto lenius isto
Nam dives qui fieri vult, / Et cito vult fieri
Nam ego illum periisse duco, cui quidem periit pudor
Nam et majorum instituta tueri, sacris cerimoniisque
retinendis, sapientis est
Nam neque divitibus contingunt gaudia solis, / Nec vixit male qui natus moriensque fefellit
Nam nunc mores nihil faciunt quod licet, nisi quod lubet
Nam pro jucundis aptissima quæque dabunt Di. / Carior est illis homo quam sibi
Nam quæ inscitia est adversum stimulum calces
Nam quum magna malæ superest audacia
causæ, / Creditur a multis fiducia
Nam scelus intra se tacitum qui cogitat ullum / Facti crimen habet
Nam tua res agitur, paries cum proximus ardet!
Nam vitiis nemo sine nascitur; optimus ille est, / Qui minimis urgetur
Namen nennen dich nicht! Dich bilden Griffel und Pinsel sterblicher Künstler nicht nach!
Names alter, things never alter.
Nane are so weel but they hope to be better.
Napoleon affords us an example of the danger of elevating one's self to the Absolute, and sacrificing everything to the carrying out of an idea.
Napoleon, for the sake of a great name, broke in pieces almost half a world.
Narrative is linear, but Action, having breadth and depth as well as length, is solid.
Narratur et prisci Catonis / Sæpe mero caluisse
virtus
Nascentes morimur, finisque ab origine pendet
Nascimur poetæ, fimus oratores
Natales grate numeras? ignoscis amicis? / Lenior et melior fis accedente senecta?
Natio comœda est
National character varies as it fades under invasion
or corruption; but if ever it glows again into a new life, that life must be tempered by the earth and sky of the country itself.
National enthusiasm is the great nursery of genius.
National suffering is, if thou wilt understand the words, verily a judgment of God; it has ever been preceded by national crime.
Nations and empires flourish and decay, / By turns command, and in their turn obey.
Nations and men are only the best when they are the gladdest, and deserve heaven when they enjoy it.
Nations are only transitional forms of humanity; they must undergo obliteration, as do the transitional forms offered by the animal series. There is no more an immortality for them than there is an immobility for an embryo or any one of the manifold forms passed through in its progress of development.
Nations, like individuals, are born, proceed through a predestined growth, and die. One comes to its end at an early period and in an untimely way; another, not until it has gained maturity. One is cut off by feebleness in its infancy, another is destroyed by civil disease, another commits political suicide, another lingers in old age. But for every one there is an orderly way of progress to its final term, whatever that term may be.
Natur und Kunst, sie scheinen sich zu fliehen, / Und haben sich, eh' man es denkt, gefunden
Natura beatis / Omnibus esse dedit, si quis cognoverit uti
Natura il fece, e poi roppe la stampa
Natura ipsa valere, et mentis viribus excitari, et quasi quodam divino spiritu afflari
Natura naturans
Natura naturata
Natura nihil agit frustra
Natura non facit saltus
Natura, quam te colimus inviti quoque
Natural abilities are like natural plants, that need pruning by study; and studies themselves do give forth directions too much at large, except they be bounded in by experience.
Natural abilities can almost make up for the want of every kind of cultivation, but no cultivation for want of natural abilities.
Natural knowledge is come at by the continuance and progress of learning and of liberty, and by particular persons attending to, comparing, and pursuing intimations scattered up and down it, which are overlooked and disregarded by the generality of the world.
Natural objects always did and do weaken,
deaden, and obliterate imagination in me.
Natural selection is the principle by which each slight variation, if useful, is preserved.
Naturalia non sunt turpia
Naturam expellas furca, tamen usque recurret
Nature abhors a vacuum.
Nature admits no lie.
Nature acts towards us like an Oriental potentate with Mamelukes under him, whom he employs for some mysterious purpose, but to whom he never shows himself in person.
Nature alone is antique, and the oldest art a mushroom.
Nature alone is permanent.
Nature alone knows what she means.
Nature always leaps to the surface, and manages
to show what she is.
Nature always speaks of spirit.
Nature always wears the colours of the spirit. To a man labouring under calamity the heat of his own fire hath sadness in it.
Nature and art are too grand to go forth in pursuit of aims; nor is it necessary that they should, for there are relations everywhere, and relations constitute life.
Nature and books belong to the eyes that see them. It depends on the mood of the man whether he shall see the sunset or the fine poem.
Nature and Heaven command you, at your
peril, to discern worth from unworth in everything, and most of all in man.
Nature and love cannot be concealed.
Nature and Nature's laws lay hid in night; / God said, "Let Newton be!" and all was light.
Nature and truth, though never so low or vulgar, are yet pleasing when openly and artlessly represented.
Nature builds upon a false bottom, seeks herself what she values in others, and is oftentimes deceived and disappointed. Grace reposes her whole hope and love in God, and is never mistaken, never deluded by false expectations.
Nature cannot be surprised in undress. Beauty
breaks in everywhere.
Nature cannot but always act rightly, quite unconcerned as to what may be the consequences.
Nature counts nothing that she meets with base, / But lives and loves in every place.
Nature, crescent, does not grow alone / In thews and bulk; but, as this temple waxes, / The inward service of the mind and soul / Grows wide withal.
Nature does more than supply materials; she also supplies powers.
Nature does not cocker us; we are children,
not pets; she is not fond; everything is dealt to us without fear or favour, after severe, universal laws.
Nature does not like to be observed, and likes that we should be her fools and playmates.
Nature does not make all great men, more than all other men, in the self-same mould.
Nature draws with greater force than seven oxen.
Nature ever provides for her own exigencies.
Nature fashions no creature without implanting in it the strength needful for its action and duration.
Nature forces on our heart a Creator; history, a Providence.
Nature gives healthy children much; how much! Wise education is a wise unfolding of this; often it unfolds itself better of its own accord.
Nature gives you the impression as if there were nothing contradictory in the world; and yet, when you return back to the dwelling-place of man, be it lofty or low, wide or narrow, there is ever somewhat to contend with, to battle with, to smooth and put to rights.
Nature glories in death more than in life. The
month of departure is more beautiful than the month of coming.... Every green thing loves to die in bright colours.
Nature goes her own way; and all that to us seems an exception, is really according to order.
Nature had made occupation a necessity; society makes it a duty; habit may make it a pleasure.
Nature has directly formed woman to be a mother, only indirectly to be a wife; man, on the contrary, is rather made to be a husband than a father.
Nature has given to each one all that as a man he needs, which it is the business of education to develop, if, as most frequently happens, it does not develop better of itself.
Nature has lent us tears--the cry of suffering
when the man at last can bear it no longer.
Nature has made man's breast no windows / To publish what he does within doors, / Nor what dark secrets there inhabit, / Unless his own rash folly blab it.
Nature has made provision for all her children; the meanest is not hindered in its existence even by that of the most excellent.
Nature has no feeling; the sun gives his light to good and bad alike, and moon and stars shine out for the worst of men as for the best.
Nature has no moods; they belong to man alone.
Nature has planted passions in the heart of
man for the wisest purposes both of religion and life.
Nature has sometimes made a fool, but a coxcomb is always of man's own making.
Nature hath framed strange fellows in her time. / Some that will evermore peep through their eyes / And laugh like parrots at a bagpiper; / And other of such vinegar aspect / That they'll not show their teeth in way of smile, / Though Nestor swear the jest be laughable.
Nature hath made nothing so base but can / Read some instruction to the wisest man.
Nature here shows art, / That through thy bosom makes me see thy heart.
Nature holds an immense uncollected debt
over every man's head.
Nature in women is so nearly allied to art.
Nature in you stands on the very verge / Of her confine.
Nature is a friend to truth.
Nature is a frugal mother, and never gives without measure.
Nature is a mutable cloud, which is always
and never the same.
Nature is a Sibyl, who testifies beforehand to what has been determined from all eternity, and was not to be realised till late in time.
Nature is a vast trope, and all particular natures are tropes.
Nature is always kind enough to give even her clouds a humorous lining.
Nature is always lavish, even prodigal.
Nature is always like herself.
Nature is always mysterious.
 (_am gründlichsten_
Nature is always right, and most profoundly least comprehend her.
Nature is an Æolian harp, a musical instrument whose tones are the re-echo of higher strings within us.
Nature is avariciously frugal; in matter it allows no atom to elude her grasp; in mind no thought or feeling to perish. It gathers up the fragments that nothing be lost.
Nature is beyond all teaching.
Nature is but a name for an effect whose cause is God.
Nature is commanded by obeying her.
Nature is content with little, grace with less, but lust with nothing.
Nature is despotic, and will not be fooled or abated of any jot of her authority by the pertest of her sons.
Nature is full of freaks, and now puts an old
head on young shoulders, and then a young heart beating under fourscore winters.
Nature is good, but intellect is better, as the lawgiver is before the law-receiver.
Nature is good, but she is not the best.
Nature is indeed adequate to Fear, but to Reverence not adequate.
Nature is just towards men. It recompenses them for their sufferings; it renders them laborious, because to the greatest toils it attaches the greatest rewards.
Nature is no spendthrift, but takes the shortest
way to her ends.
Nature is not an Aggregate but a Whole.
Nature is not fixed, but fluid; spirit alters, moulds, makes it.
Nature is rich; those two eggs you ate to breakfast this morning might, if hatched, have peopled the world with poultry.
Nature is sometimes subdued, but seldom extinguished.
Nature is still the grand agent in making
poets.
Nature is the art of God.
Nature is the best posture-master.
Nature is the immense shadow of man.
Nature is the living, visible garment of God.
Nature is the only book that teems with meaning on every page.
Nature knows how to convert evil to good; Nature utilises misers, fanatics, showmen, egotists to accomplish her ends; but we must not think better of the foible for that.
Nature knows no equality; her sovereign
law is subordination and dependence.
Nature knows no pause in progress and development, and attaches her curse on all inaction.
Nature listening stood whilst Shakespeare play'd, / And wonder'd at the work herself had made.
Nature made every fop to plague his brother, / Just as one beauty mortifies another.
Nature makes us vagabonds, the world makes us respectable.
Nature meant to make woman her masterpiece,
but committed a mistake in the choice of the clay; she took it too fine.
Nature must obey necessity.
Nature, mysterious even under the light of day, is not to be robbed of her veil; and what she does not choose to reveal you will not extort from her with levers and screws.
Nature needs little, fancy
Nature never did betray / The heart that loved her.
Nature never hurries; atom by atom, little
by little, she achieves her work.
Nature never made an unkind creature; ill-usage and bad habits have deformed a fair and lovely creation.
Nature never sends a great man into the planet without confiding the secret to another soul.
Nature owns no man who is not a martyr withal.
Nature passes nurture.
Nature respects race and not hybrids.
Nature sent women into the world that they might be mothers and love children, to whom sacrifices must ever be offered, and from whom none can be obtained.
Nature smiles as sweet, I ween, / To shepherds as to kings.
Nature stretches out her arms to embrace man; only let his thoughts be of equal greatness.
Nature, study, and practice must combine to ensure proficiency in any art.
Nature suffers nothing to remain in her kingdom
which cannot help itself.
Nature takes as much pains in the forming of a beggar as an emperor.
Nature teaches beasts to know their friends.
Nature transcends all our moods of thought, and its secret we do not yet find.
Nature trips us up when we strut.
Nature understands no jesting; she is always
true, always serious, always severe; she is always right, and the errors and faults are always those of man. Him who is incapable of appreciating her she despises, and only to the apt, the pure, and the true, does she resign herself and reveal her secrets.
"Nature veils God," but what I see of Him in nature is not veiled.
Nature, which is the Time-vesture of God, and reveals Him to the wise, hides Him from the foolish.
Nature will not be Buddhist; she resents generalising, and insults the philosopher in every moment with a million of fresh particulars.
Nature without discipline is of small force, and discipline without nature more feeble.
Nature without learning is like a blind man;
learning without Nature, like a maimed one; practice without both, incomplete.
Nature works after such eternal, necessary, divine laws, that the Deity himself could alter nothing in them.
Nature works on the method of all for each and each for all.
Nature works very hard, and only hits the white once in a million throws. In mankind, she is contented if she yields one master in a century.
Nature's above art.
Nature's chief masterpiece is writing well.
Nature's shadows are ever varying.
Nature's tears are Reason's merriment.
Natures that have much heat, and great and violent desires and perturbations, are not ripe for action till they have passed the meridian of their years.
Natürlicher Verstand kann fast jeden Grad von Bildung ersetzen, aber keine Bildung den natürlichen Verstand
Natus nemo
Natus sum; esuriebam, quærebam; nunc repletas requiesco
Naufragium in portu facere
Nay! evermore, / All things and thoughts, both new and old, are writ / Upon the unchanging human heart and soul.
Nay, let us seek at home to find / Fit harvest for the brooding mind, / And find, since thus the world grows fair, / Duty and pleasure everywhere.
Nay, that's past praying for.
Nay, then, farewell! / I have touch'd the highest point of all my greatness, / And, from that full meridian of my glory, / I haste now to my setting: I shall fall / Like a bright exhalation in the evening, / And no man see me more.

Ne cede malis, sed contra audentior ito
Ne depugnes in alieno negotio
Ne exeat regno

foisonne: / Est-il besoin d'exécuter? / L'on ne rencontre personne

Ne Hercules quidem contra duos
Ne Jupiter quidem omnibus placet

Ne obliviscaris

Né pour la digestion
Ne quid detrimenti respublica capiat
Ne quid falsi dicere audeat, ne quid veri non

Ne te quæsiveris extra

Ne tentes, aut perfice

Near and far do not belong to the eternal world, which is not of space and time.
Near is my shirt, but nearer is my skin.
Nearer the kirk the farther frae grace.
Nearly all our powerful men in this age of the world are unbelievers; the best of them in doubt and misery; the plurality in plodding hesitation, doing, as well as they can, what practical work lies ready to their hands.
Neat, not gaudy.
Nec aspera terrent
Nec caput nec pedes
Nec cui de te plusquam tibi credas
Nec cupias, nec metuas
Nec deus intersit, nisi dignus vindice nodus
Nec domo dominus, sed domino domus honestanda est
Nec est ad astra mollis e terris via
Nec habeo, nec careo, nec curo
Nec lusisse pudet, sed non incidere ludum
Nec male notus eques
Nec meus audet / Rem tentare pudor, quam vires ferre recusent
Nec minor est virtus, quam quærere, parta
tueri: / Casus inest illic; hic erit artis opus
Nec mora, nec requies
Nec morti esse locum
Nec obolum habet unde restim emat
Nec omnia, nec semper, nec ab omnibus
Nec placida contentus quiete est
Nec pluribus impar
Nec prece nec pretio
Nec, quæ præteriit, iterum revocabitur unda; / Nec, quæ præteriit, hora redire potest
Nec quærere nec spernere honorem
Nec regi nec populo, sed utrique
Nec scire fas est omnia
Nec si non obstatur propterea etiam permittitur
Nec sibi, sed toti genitum se credere mundo
Nec soli cedit
Nec temere nec timide
Nec tibi quid liceat, sed quid fecisse decebit / Occurrat
Nec timeo, nec sperno
Nec Veneris pharetris macer est, aut lampade fervet: / Inde faces ardent, veniunt a dote sagittæ
Nec verbum verbo curabis reddere fidus / Interpres
Nec vidisse semel satis est, juvat usque morari, / Et conferre gradum, et veniendi discere causas
Nec vultu destrue dicta tuo
Necessary patience in seeking the Lord is
better than he that leadeth his life without a guide.
Necesse est cum insanientibus furere, nisi solus relinqueris
Necesse est ut multos timeat, quem multi timent
Necessità 'l c' induce, e non diletto
Necessitas non habet legem
Necessity does everything well.
Necessity is cruel, but it is the only test of inward strength. Every fool may live according to his own likings.
Necessity is the mistress of the arts.
Necessity is the mother of invention.
Necessity is the plea for every infringement of human freedom. It is the argument of tyrants, it is the creed of slaves.
Necessity makes even cowards brave.
Necessity reforms the poor, and satiety the rich.
Necessity unites hearts.
Necessity urges desperate measures.
Necio es quien piensa que otros no piensan
Need mak's an auld wife trot.
Needles and pins, needles and pins! / When a man marries his trouble begins.
Needs must when the devil drives.
Ne'er grudge and carp, / Though fortune use you hard and sharp.
Ne'er let your gear owergang ye
Ne'er linger, ne'er o'erhasty be, / For time
moves on with measured foot.
Ne'er put a sword in a wud man's
hand.
Ne'er tak' a wife till ye ken what to do wi' her.
Ne'er the rose without the thorn.
Ne'er trust muckle to an auld enemy or a new freend.
Neglecta solent incendia sumere vires
Negligence is the rust of the soul, that corrodes through all her best resolves.
Negligere quid de se quisque sentiat, non solum arrogantis est, sed omnino dissoluti
Nehmt die Gottheit auf in euren Willen, / Und sie steigt von ihrem Weltenthron
Nehmt die Stimmung wahr, / Denn sie kommt so selten
Neid zu fühlen, ist menschlich; Schadenfreude
zu geniessen, teuflisch
Neither a borrower nor a lender be; / For loan oft loses both itself and friend.
Neither borrow money of a neighbour nor a friend, but of a stranger, where, paying for it, thou shalt hear no more of it.
Neither crow nor croak.
Neither exalt your pleasures, nor aggravate your vexations, beyond their real and natural state.
Neither heat, nor frost, nor thunder / Shall
wholly do away, I ween, / The marks of that which once hath been.
Neither hew down the whole forest, nor come home without wood.
Neither lead nor drive.
Neither our virtues nor vices are all our own.
Neither painting nor fighting feed men; nor can capital, in the form of money or machinery, feed them.
Neither praise nor blame is the object of true
criticism. Justly to discriminate, firmly to establish, wisely to prescribe, and honestly to award--these are the true aims and duties of criticism.
Neither rhyme nor reason.
Neither seek nor shun the fight.
Neither sign a paper without reading it, nor drink water without seeing it.
Neither wise men nor fools / Can work without tools.
Neither woman nor man, nor any kind of creature
in the universe, was born for the exclusive, or even the chief, purpose of falling in love or being fallen in love with.... Except the zoophytes and coral insects of the Pacific Ocean, I am acquainted with no creature with whom it is the one or grand object.
Neither women nor linen by candlelight.
Nem. con.
Nem. diss.
Nemesis checks, with cubit-rule and bridle, /
Immoderate deeds, and boastings rash and idle.
Nemesis is lame, but she is of colossal stature, like the gods.
Nemo allegans suam turpitudinem audiendus est
Nemo dat quod non habet
Nemo debet bis puniri pro uno delicto
Nemo debet bis vexari pro una et eadem causa
Nemo debet esse judex in propria causa
Nemo doctus mutationem consilii inconstantiam dixit esse
Nemo est tam senex qui se annum non putat posse vivere
Nemo ex proprio dolo consequitur actionem
Nemo impetrare potest a papa bullam nunquam moriendi
Nemo ita pauper vivit, quam pauper natus est
Nemo læditur nisi a seipso
Nemo malus felix, minime corruptor
Nemo mathematicus genium indemnatus habebit
Nemo me impune lacessit
Nemo mortalium omnibus horis sapit
Nemo patriam in qua natus est exuere nec ligeantiæ debitum ejurare possit
Nemo potest mutare consilium suum in alterius injuriam
Nemo potest nudo vestimenta detrahere
Nemo potest personam diu ferre fictam
Nemo præsumitur alienam posteritatem suæ
prætulisse
Nemo punitur pro alieno delicto
Nemo quam bene vivat, sed quamdiu, curat: quum omnibus possit contingere ut bene vivat, ut diu nulli
Nemo repente fuit turpissimus
Nemo sibi nascitur
Nemo solus sapit
Nemo tenetur se ipsum accusare
Nemo vir magnus sine aliquo afflatu divino unquam fuit
Nequaquam satis in re una consumere curam
Neque culpa neque lauda teipsum
Neque fœmina, amissa pudicitia, alia abnuerit
Neque mala vel bona quæ vulgus putet
Neque opinione sed natura constitutum est jus
Neque quies gentium sine armis neque arma sine stipendiis neque stipendia sine tributis haberi queunt
Neque semper arcum / Tendit Apollo
Nequicquam sapit qui sibi non sapit
Nervus rerum
Nescia mens hominum fati sortisque futuræ, / Et servare modum, rebus sublata secundis
Nescio qua natale solum dulcedine captos / Ducit, et immemores non sinit esse sui
Nescio qua præter solitum dulcedine læti
Nescire autem quid antea quam natus sis acciderit, id est semper esse puerum. Quid enim est ætas hominis, nisi memoria rerum veterum cum superioribus contexitur?
Nescis tu quam meticulosa res sit ire ad judicem
Nescit vox missa reverti
Nessun maggior dolore / Che ricordarsi del tempo felice / Nella miseria
Nessuno nasce maestro
Neu Regiment bringt neue Menschen auf, / Und früheres Verdienst veraltet schnell
Neutral men are the devil's allies.
Never a tear bedims the eye / That time and patience will not dry; / Never a lip is curved in pain / That can't be kissed into smiles again.
Never anger / Made good guard for itself.
Never anything can be amiss / When simpleness and duty tender it.
Never ask a favour of a man until he has had his dinner.
Never be afraid to doubt, if only you have the disposition to believe.
Never bray at an ass.
Never burn your fingers to snuff another man's candle.
Never buy a pig in a poke.
Never by reflection, only by doing what it lies on him to do, is self-knowledge possible to any man.
Never cackle till your egg is laid.
Never confuse a myth with a lie.... The
thoughts of all the greatest and wisest men hitherto have been expressed through mythology.
Never deal in mistakes; they aye bring mischances.
Never deceive a friend.
Never desire to appear clever and make a show of your talents before men. Be honest, loving, kindly, and sympathetic in all you say and do. Cleverness will flow from you naturally if you have it, and applause will come to you unsought from those who know what to applaud; but the applause of fools is to be shunned.
Never despise the day of small things.
Never disregard what your enemies say.
Never do anything of the rectitude of which you have a doubt.
Never do that by proxy which you can do yourself.
Never do things by halves.
Never durst poet touch a pen to write / Until his ink were temper'd with love's sighs; / O, then his lines would ravish savage ears, / And plant in tyrants mild humility.
Never elated when one man's oppress'd; /
Never dejected while anothers bless'd.
Never fall out with your bread and butter.
Never find fault with the absent.
Never fish in troubled waters.
Never forget St. Paul's sentence, "Love is the fulfilling of the law." This is the steam of the social machine; but the steam requires regulation; it is regulated by intelligence and moderation.
Never fry a fish till it's caught.
Never give up the ship.
Never grudge a penny for a pennyworth.
Never grumble nor mumble.
Never hang a man twice for one offence.
Never have an idle hour, or an idle pound.
Never hold a candle to the devil.
Never indulge the notion that you have any absolute right to choose the sphere or the circumstances in which you are to put forth your powers of social action.
Never is a lang term.
Never is a long day.
Never king dropped out of the clouds.
Never lean on a broken staff.
Never leave a certainty for an uncertainty.
Never leave that till to-morrow which you can do to-day.
Never let any one see the bottom of your purse or your mind.
Never let Fortune be thy mistress, nor Misfortune
thy maid.
Never let us be discouraged with ourselves. It is not when we are conscious of our faults that we are the most wicked; on the contrary, we are less so.
Never let your zeal outrun your charity; the former is but human, the latter is divine.
Never look a gift-horse in the mouth.
Never look for a knot in a bulrush.
Never look for birds of this year in the nests
of the last.
Never make a jest of any Scripture expressions.
Never meet trouble half way.
Never mind the future: be what you ought to be; the rest is God's affair.
Never mind who was your grandfather. What are you?
Never morning wore / To evening, but some
heart did break.
Never neglect small matters and expenses.
Never offer to teach fish to swim.
Never preach beyond your experience.
Never put your arm out farther than you can draw it back again.
Never put your hand into a wasp's nest.
Never read borrowed books. To be without books of your own is the abyss of penury. Don't endure it. And when you have to buy them, you'll think whether they're worth reading; which you had better, on all accounts.
Never repeat old grievances.
Never risk a joke, even the least offensive in its nature and the most common, with a person who is not well-bred, and possessed of sense to comprehend it.
Never say die! / Up, man, and try!
Never say of another what you would not have
him hear.
Never seek to tell thy love, / Love that never told can be, / For the gentle wind doth move / Silently, invisibly.
Never shirk the hardest work.
Never sigh, but send.
Never since Aaron's rod went out of practice, or even before it, was there such a wonder-working tool as a pen; greater than all recorded miracles have been performed by pens.
Never speak ill of those whose bread you eat.
Never speak of love with scorn; / Such were direst treason; / Love was made for eve and morn, / And for every season.
Never spur a willing horse.
Never stint soap and water.
Never swap horses while crossing a stream.
Never talk half a minute without pausing and giving others an opportunity to strike in.
Never tell in the parlour what you heard in the kitchen.
Never tell your resolution before-hand.
Never that I could in searching find out, has man been, by time which devours much, deprived of any faculty whatsoever that he in any era was possessed of.
Never throw a hen's egg at a sparrow.
Never till now did young men, and almost children, take such a command in human affairs.
Never title yet so mean could prove, / But there was eke a mind which did that title love.
Never too old to turn; never too late to learn.
Never trouble yourself with trouble till trouble troubles you.
Never trust a wolf with the care of lambs.
Never try to prove what nobody doubts.
Never venture all in one bottom.
Never was scraper
Never waste pains on bad ground; let it remain rough. Though properly looked after and cared for, it will be of best service so.
Never write anything that does not give you great pleasure; emotion is easily propagated from the writer to the reader.
Never write on a subject without having first read yourself full on it; and never read on a subject till you have thought yourself hungry on it.
Never write what you dare not sign.
Never yet created eye / Could see across eternity.
Never yet has it been our fortune to fall in with any man of genius whose conclusions did not correspond better with his premises, and not worse, than those of other men; whose genius, once understood, did not manifest itself in a deeper, fuller, truer view of all things human and divine, than the clearest of your so-called laudable "practical men" had claim to.
Never yet, since the proud selfish race / Of men began to jar, did passion give, / Nor can it ever give, a right decision.
Never yet / Was noble man but made ignoble talk.
New acquests are more burden than strength.
New brooms sweep clean.
New, daring, and inspiring ideas are engendered only in a clear head over a glowing heart, as the richest wines grow over the volcanoes.
New laws, new frauds.
New lords, new laws.
New-made honour doth forget men's names; / 'Tis too respective and too sociable, / For your conversion.
New presbyter is but old priest writ large.
New religion! We already, in our dim heads, know truths (of religion) by the thousand; and, yet in our dead hearts, we will not perform them by the ten, by the unit.
New scenes impress new ideas, enrich the imagination, and enlarge the power of reason.
Newspapers always excite curiosity. No one ever lays one down without a feeling of disappointment.
Next in importance to the matter of books are their titles.
"Next to a lost battle, nothing is so sad as
a battle that has been won."
Next to Christmas Day the most pleasant annual epoch in existence is the advent of the New Year.
Next to excellence is the appreciation of it.
Next to nae wife, a gude wife is the best.
Next to religion, let your care be to promote justice.
Next to the assumption of power is the responsibility
of relinquishing it.
Next to the consciousness of doing a good action, that of doing a civil one is the most pleasing.
Next to the gods, of all man's possessions his soul is the mightiest, being the most his own.
Next to the originator of a good sentence is the first quoter of it.
Next to the satisfaction I receive in the prosperity of an honest man, I am best pleased with the confusion of a rascal.
Next to theology I give to music the highest
place and honour; and we see how David and all the saints have wrought their godly thoughts into verse, rhyme, and song.
Ni l'or ni la grandeur ne nous rendent heureux
Ni l'un ni l'autre
Ni trop haut, ni trop bas; c'est le souverain style
Nice distinctions are out of the question upon occasions like those of speech, which return every hour.
Nicht alle sind Diebe, die der Hund anbellt
Nicht alles Wünschenswerte ist erreichbar; nicht alles Erkennenswerte ist erkennbar
Nicht an die Güter hänge dein Herz, / Die das Leben vergänglich zieren! / Wer besitzt, der lerne verlieren; / Wer im Glück ist, der lerne den Schmerz!
Nicht der Besitz, nur das Enthüllen, / Das leise Finden nur ist süss
Nicht der ist auf der Welt verwaist, / Dessen Vater und Mutter gestorben, / Sondern der für Herz und Geist / Keine Lieb' und kein Wissen erworben
Nicht die Kinder bloss speist man / Mit Märchen ab
Nicht draussen im Strudel verrauschender Lust / Erwarte, das Glück dir zu finden: / Die Seligkeit wohnt in der eigenen Brust, / Hier musst du sie ewig begründen!
Nicht grösseren Vortheil wüsst' ich zu nennen /
Als des Feindes Verdienst erkennen
Nicht immer am besten erfahren ist, / Wer am ältesten an Jahren ist, / Und wer am meisten gelitten hat, / Nicht immer die besten Sitten hat!
Nicht immer macht das Kleid den Mann
Nicht in die ferne Zeit verliere dich! / Den Augenblick ergreife, der ist dein
Nicht in kalten Marmorsteinen, / Nicht in Tempeln dumpf und tot, / In den frischen Eichenhainen / Webt und rauscht der deutsche Gott
Nicht jede Besserung ist Tugend
Nicht Kunst and Wissenschaft allein, / Geduld will bei dem Werke sein
Nicht Rosen bloss, auch Dornen hat der Himmel
Nicht so redlich wäre redlicher
Nichts Abgeschmackters find' ich auf der Welt / Als einen Teufel, der verzweifelt
Nichts Böses thun ist gut; / Nichts Böses
wollen ist besser
Nichts führt zum Guten, was nicht natürlich ist
Nichts halb zu thun ist edler Geister Art
Nichts ist dem Menschen so schwer zu tragen, / Als eine Reihe von guten Tagen
Nichts ist göttlich, als was vernünftig ist
Nichts ist höher zu schätzen, als der Wert des
Tages
Nichts ist so elend als ein Mann, / Der alles will, und der nichts kann
Nichts stirbt, was wirklich gut und göttlich war
Nichts thun lehrt Uebel thun
Nichtswürdig ist die Nation, die nicht / Ihr Alles freudig setzt an ihre Ehre
Nick does not pretend to be a gentleman.
Nicknames stick to people, and the most ridiculous are the most adhesive.
Nie kommt das Unglück ohne sein Gefolge
Niemand ist frei, der nicht über sich selbst Herr ist
Niemand ist mehr Sklave, als der sich für frei hält ohne es zu sein
Niemand weiss, wie weit seine Kräfte gehen,
bis er sie versucht hat
Niggardliness is not good husbandry.
Night is a good herdsman; she brings all creatures home.
Night is the mither
Night is the Sabbath of mankind, / To rest the body and the mind.
Night! that great shadow and profile of the
day.
Night's candles are burnt out, and jocund day / Stands tiptoe on the misty mountain-tops.
Night's deepest gloom is but a calm, / That soothes the wearied mind; / The labour'd day's restoring balm, / The comfort of mankind.
Nightingales will not sing in a cage.
Nihil a Deo vacat; opus suum ipse implet
Nihil ad rem
Nihil agit qui diffidentem verbis solatur suis; / Is est amicus qui in re dubia re juvat, ubi re est opus
Nihil aliud necessarium ut sis miser, quam ut te miserum credas
Nihil cum fidibus graculo
Nihil enim legit, quod non excerperet. Dicere etiam solebat, nullum esse librum tam malum, ut non aliqua parte prodesset
Nihil eripit fortuna nisi quod et dedit
Nihil est ab omni / Parte beatum
Nihil est annis velocius!
Nihil est aptius ad delectationem lectoris,
quam temporum varietates, fortunæque vicissitudines
Nihil est quod credere de se / Non possit
Nihil est quod Deus efficere non possit.
Nihil est tam utile, quod in transitu prosit
Nihil est tam volucre quam maledictum, nihil facilius emittitur, nihil citius excipitur, nihil latius dissipatur
Nihil hic nisi carmina desunt
Nihil honestum esse potest, quod justitia vacat
Nihil largiundo gloriam adeptus est
Nihil morosius hominum judiciis
Nihil potest rex nisi quod de jure potest
Nihil quod est inconveniens est licitum
Nihil scire est vita jucundissima
Nihil scriptum miraculi causa
Nihil simul inventum est et perfectum
Nihil tam absurdum dici potest ut non dicatur a philosopho
Nihil tam firmum est, cui periculum non sit
etiam ab invalido
Nihil tam munitum est, quod non expugnari pecunia possit
Nihil turpius est quam gravis ætate senex, qui nullum aliud habet argumentum, quo se probet diu vixisse, præter ætatem
Nihil unquam peccavit, nisi quod mortua est
Nil actum credens, dum quid superesset agendum
"Nil admirari" is the motto which men of the
world always affect, thinking it vulgar to wonder or be enthusiastic.
Nil admirari prope est res una, Numici, / Solaque, quæ possit facere et servare beatum
Nil æquale homini fuit illi
Nil agit exemplum litem quod lite resolvit
Nil consuetudine majus
Nil cupientium / Nudus castra peto
Nil debet
Nil desperandum
Nil desperandum Teucro duce et auspice Teucro
Nil dicit
Nil dictu fœdum visuque hæc limina tangat, /
Intra quæ puer est
Nil dictum quod non dictum prius
Nil ego contulerim jucundo sanus amico
Nil erit ulterius quod nostris moribus addat / Posteritas; eadem cupient facientque minores: / Omne in præcipiti vitium stetit
Nil feret ad manes divitis umbra suos
Nil fuit unquam sic impar sibi
Nil habet infelix paupertas durius in se, / Quam quod ridiculos homines facit
Nil homini certum est
Nil me officit unquam, / Ditior hic, aut est quia doctior; est locus uni / Cuique suus
Nil mortalibus arduum est
Nil nisi cruce
Nil oriturum alias, nil ortum tale fatentes
Nil peccant oculi, si oculis animus imperet
Nil proprium ducas quod mutari potest
Nil rectum nisi quod placuit sibi ducunt
Nil sine magno / Vita labore dedit mortalibus
Nil sine te mei prosunt honores
Nil sole et sale utilius
Nil spernat auris, nec tamen credat statim
Nil tam difficile est quod non solertia vincat
Nil tam inæstimable est quam animi multitudinis
Nil temere novandum
Nil unquam longum est, quod sine fine placet
Nimia cura deterit magis quam emendat
Nimia est voluptas, si diu abfueris a domo / Domum si redieris, si tibi nulla est ægritudo animo obviam
Nimia illæc licentia / Profecto evadet in aliquod magnum malum
Nimia subtilitas in jure reprobatur, et talis
certitudo certitudinem confundit
Nimirum insanus paucis videatur, eo quod / Maxima pars hominum morbo jactatur eodem
Nimis uncis / Naribus indulges
Nimium altercando veritas amittitur
Nimium ne crede colori
Nimius in veritate, et similitudinis quam pulchritudinis
amantior
Nimm alles leicht! das Träumen lass und Grübeln! / So bleibst du wohlbewahrt vor tausend Uebeln
Nimm die Welt, wie sie ist, nicht wie sie seyn sollte
Nimm wahr die Zeit; sie eilet sich, / Und kommt nicht wieder ewiglich
Nine tailors cannot make a man.
Nine-tenths of existing books are nonsense,
and the clever books are the refutation of that nonsense.
Nine-tenths of our critics have told us little more of Shakespeare than what honest Franz Horn says his neighbours used to tell of him, "he was a great spirit, and stept majestically along."
Nine things to sight required are: / The power to see, the light, the visible thing, / Being not too small, too thin, too nigh, too far; / Clear space, and time, the form distinct to bring.
Nine times out of ten it is over the Bridge of Sighs that we pass the narrow gulf from youth to manhood. That interval is usually occupied by an ill-placed or disappointed affection. We recover and we find ourselves a new being. The intellect has become hardened by the fire through which it has passed. The mind profits by the wrecks of every passion, and we may measure our road to wisdom by the sorrows we have undergone.
Nine tithes of times / Face-flatterer and back-biter are the same.
Nineteen nay-says are half a grant.
Nisi caste, saltem caute
Nisi Dominus, frustra
Nisi prius
Nisi utile est quod facias, stulta est gloria
Nitimur in vetitum semper, cupimusque negata
Nitor in adversum, nec me, qui cætera vincit / Impetus, et rapido contrarius evehor orbi
"No," a monosyllable, the easiest learned by the child, but the most difficult to practise by the man, contains within it the import of a life, the weal or woe of an eternity.
No accidents are so unlucky that the prudent may not draw some advantage from them.
No affections and a great brain; these are the men to command the world.
No age ever seemed the age of Romance to
itself.
No age, sex, or condition is above or below the absolute necessity of modesty; but without it one is vastly beneath the rank of man.
No answer is also an answer.
