No art can be noble which is incapable of expressing thought, and no art is capable of expressing thought which does not change.
No artist-work is so high, so noble, so grand, so enduring, so important for all time, as the making of character in a child.
No ashes are lighter than those of incense, and few things burn out sooner.
No atheist denies a divinity, but only some name of a divinity; the God is still present there, working in that benighted heart, were it only as a god of darkness.
No author can be as moral as his works, as no preacher is as pious as his sermons.
No author ever spared a brother; / Wits are
gamecocks to one another.
No author is a man of genius to his publisher.
No autumn fruit without spring blossoms.
No beast so fierce but knows some touch of pity.
No bees, no honey; / No work, no money.
No belief of ours will change the facts or
reverse the laws of the spiritual universe; and it is our first business to discover the laws and to learn how the facts stand.
No belief which is contrary to truth can be really useful.
No bird ever flew so high but it had to come to the ground for food.
No blank, no trifle, Nature made or meant.
No book is worth anything which is not worth much; nor is it serviceable until it has been read, and re-read, and loved, and loved again.
No book that will not improve by repeated
readings deserves to be read at all.
No book was ever written down by any but itself.
No ceremony that to great one 'longs, / Not the king's crown, nor the deputed sword, / The marshal's truncheon nor the judge's robe, / Become them with one half so good a grace / As mercy does.
No chair is so much wanted (in our colleges) as that of a professor of books.
No chaos can continue chaotic with a soul in it.
No character was ever rightly understood
until it had been first regarded with a certain feeling, not of tolerance only, but of sympathy.
No cheerfulness can ever be produced by effort which is itself painful.
No cloth is too fine for moth to devour.
No compound of this earthly ball / Is like another all in all.
No conflict is so severe as his who labours to subdue himself.
No conquest can ever become permanent
which does not withal show itself beneficial to the conquered as well as to the conquerors.
No corn without chaff.
No; creation, one would think, cannot be easy; your Jove has severe pains, and fire flames, in the head out of which an armed Pallas is struggling.
No creature smarts so little as a fool.
No crime is so great as daring to excel.
No cross, no crown.
No diga la lengua par do pague la cabeza
No distance breaks the tie of blood: / Brothers are brothers evermore; / Nor wrong, nor wrath of deadliest mood, / That magic may o'erpower.
No doubt but ye are the people, and wisdom shall die with you.
No doubt every person is entitled to make and to think as much of himself as possible, only he ought not to worry others about this, for they have enough to do with and in themselves, if they too are to be of some account, both now and hereafter.
No dynamite will ever be invented that can
rule; it can but dissolve and destroy. Only the word of God and the heart of man can govern.
No earnest man, in any time, ever spoke what was wholly meaningless.
No earnest thinker is a plagiarist pure and simple. He will never borrow from others that which he has not already, more or less, thought out for himself.
No entertainment is so cheap as reading, nor any pleasure so lasting.
No errors are so mischievous as those of great men.
No evil can touch him who looks on human
beauty; he feels himself at one with himself and with the world.
No evil dies so soon as that which has been patiently sustained.
No evil is felt till it comes, and when it comes no counsel helps. Wisdom is always too early and too late.
No evil is without its compensation.
No evil propensity of the human heart is so powerful that it may not be subdued by discipline.
No experiment is dangerous the result of which
we have the courage to meet.
No expression of politeness but has its root in the moral nature of man.
No eye to watch, and no tongue to wound us, / All earth forgot, and all heaven around us.
No fact in nature but carries the whole sense of nature.
No falsehood can endure / Touch of celestial temper.
No fathers or mothers think their own children
ugly.
No fishing like fishing in the sea.
No flattery, boy; an honest man can't live by 't; / It is a little sneaking art, which knaves / Use to cajole and soften fools withal.
No fool was ever so foolish, but some one thought him clever.
No fountain so small but that heaven may be imaged in its bosom.
No friend a friend until he shall prove a friend.
No frost can freeze Providence.
No gains without pains.
No ghost was ever seen by two pair of eyes.
No girl who is well bred, kind, and modest is ever offensively plain; all real deformity means want of manners or of heart.
No golden age ever called itself golden, but only expected one.
No good book or good thing of any sort shows its best face at first; nay, the commonest quality in a true work of art, if its excellence have any depth and compass, is that at first sight it occasions a certain disappointment.
No good doctor ever takes physic.
No good is ever done to society by the pictorial representation of its diseases.
No good lawyer ever goes to law himself.
No good or lovely thing exists in this world without its correspondent darkness; and the universe presents itself continually to mankind under the stern aspect of warning, or of choice, the good and the evil set on the right hand and the left.
No good work whatever can be perfect; and the demand for perfection is always a sign of a misunderstanding of the ends of art.
No government is safe unless fortified by goodwill.
No grace can save any man unless he helps himself.
No grain of sand / But moves a bright and million-peopled land, / And hath its Eden and its Eves, I deem.
No grand doer in this world can be a copious speaker about his doings.
No great composition was ever produced but with the same heavenly involuntariness in which a bird builds her nest.
No great intellectual thing was ever done
by great effort.
No great man was ever other than a genuine man.
No great truth is allowed by Nature to be demonstrable to any person who, foreseeing its consequences, desires to refuse it.
No greater hell than to be a slave to fear.
No greater men are now than ever were.
No greater misfortune can befall a man than
to be the victim of an idea which has no hold on his life, still more which detaches him from it.
No greater promisers than those who have nothing to give.
No hand can make the clock strike for me the hours that are past.
No hay dulzura sin sudor
No hay tal razon como la del baston
No heart opens to sympathy without letting
in delicacy.
No Hecuba, by aid of rouge and ceruse, is a Helen made.
No herb will cure love.
No heroine can create a hero through love of one, but she may give birth to one.
No honestly exerted force can be utterly lost.
No horse so blind as the blind mare.
No house without mouse; no throne without thorn.
No human capacity ever yet saw the whole of a thing; but we may see more and more of it the longer we look.
No human face is exactly the same in its lines on each side, no leaf perfect in its lobes, no branch in its symmetry.
No idea can succeed except at the expense of sacrifices; no one ever escapes without a stain from the struggle of life.
No intellectual images are without use.
No iron chain, or outward force of any kind, can ever compel the soul of a man to believe or to disbelieve.
"No" is a surly, honest fellow--speaks his mind rough and round at once. "But" is a sneaking, evasive, half-bred, exceptuous sort of conjunction, which comes to pull away the cup just when it is at your lips.
No joy so great but runneth to an end; / No hap so hard but may in time amend.
No joy without alloy.
No knowledge is lost, but perfected, and
changed for much nobler, sweeter, greater knowledge.
No labour is hard, no time is long, wherein the glory of eternity is the mark we level at.
No law can be finally sacred to me but the law of my own nature.
No leaf moves but as God wills it.
No legacy is so rich as honesty.
No lie you can speak or act, but it will come,
after longer or shorter circulation, like a bill drawn on Nature's reality, and be presented there for payment, with the answer: "No effects."
No literature is complete until the language in which it is written is dead.
No longer pipe, no longer dance.
No lover should have the insolence to think of being accepted at once, nor should any girl have the cruelty to refuse at once, without severe reasons.
No lying knight or lying priest ever prospered in any age, but certainly not in the dark ones. Men prospered then only in following openly-declared purposes, and preaching candidly-beloved and trusted creeds.
No man at bottom means injustice; it is always
for some obscure distorted image of a right that he contends.
No man at the head of affairs always wishes to be explicit.
No man bathes twice in the same river.
No man beholdeth prosperity who doth not encounter danger; but having encountered danger, if he surviveth, he beholdeth it.
No man but a blockhead ever wrote except for money.
No man can antedate his experience.
No man can answer for his courage who has never been in danger.
No man can be a good poet without first being a good man.
No man can be a poet / That is not a good cook, to know the palates / And several tastes of the time.
No man can be a hero in anything who is not first of all a hero in faith.
No man can be brave who considers pain to be
the greatest evil of life; nor temperate, who considers pleasure to be the highest good.
No man can be good, or great, or happy, except through inward efforts of his own.
No man can be said to have the spirit who does not walk in it, or to be born of the spirit until the spirit is born of him.
No man can be so entirely a devil as to extinguish in himself the last ray of light.
No man can become largely rich by his personal toil, but only by discovery of some method of taxing the labour of others.
No man can buy anything in the market with
gentility.
No man can, for a length of time, be wholly wretched, if there is not a disharmony (a folly and wickedness) within himself; neither can the richest Crœsus, and never so eupeptic, be other than discontented, perplexed, unhappy, if he be a fool.
No man can force the harp of his own individuality into the people's heart; but every man may play upon the chords of the people's heart, who draws his inspiration from the people's instinct.
No man can gather cherries in Kent at the season of Christmas.
No man can judge another, because no man knows himself; for we censure others but as they disagree with that humour which we fancy laudable in ourselves, and commend others but for that wherein they seem to quadrate and consent with us.
No man can learn what he has not preparation
for learning, however near to his eyes the object may be.
No man can live half a life when he has genuinely learned that it is only half a life. The other half, the higher half, must haunt him.
No man can lose what he never had.
No man can make a good coat with bad cloth.
No man can produce great things who is not thoroughly sincere in dealing with himself.
No man can quite emancipate himself from his
age and country, or produce a model in which the education, the religion, the politics, the usages, and the arts of his times shall have no share.
No man can read with profit that which he cannot learn to read with pleasure.
No man can say in what degree any other person, besides himself, can be, with strict justice, called wicked.
No man can see over his own height.
No man can serve two masters.
No man can thoroughly master more than one
art or science.
No man can transcend his own individuality.
No man doth safely appear abroad but he who can abide at home.
No man doth safely rule but he that hath learned gladly to obey.
No man doth safely speak but he who is glad to hold his peace.
No man ever became, or can become, largely
rich merely by labour and economy.
No man ever did or ever will become truly eloquent without being a constant reader of the Bible, and an admirer of the purity and sublimity of its language.
No man ever prayed heartily without learning something.
No man ever stated his griefs as lightly as he might.
No man ever worked his passage anywhere in a dead calm. Let no man wax pale, therefore, because of opposition.
No man flatters the woman he truly loves.
No man had ever a point of pride but was injurious to him.
No man has a claim to credit upon his own word, when better evidence, if he had it, may be easily produced.
No man has a prosperity so high and firm but two or three words can dishearten it.
No man has a right to say to his own generation, turning quite away from it, "Be damned."
No man has a worse friend than he brings
with him from home.
No man has any data for estimating, far less right of judging, the results of a life of resolute self-denial, until he has had the courage to try it himself.
No man has come to true greatness who has not felt in some degree that his life belongs to his race, and that what God gives him he gives him for mankind.
No man has worked, or can work, except religiously.
No man hath a thorough taste of prosperity to whom adversity never happened.
No man hath a velvet cross.
No man hath a virtue that he has not a glimpse of; nor any man an attaint, but he carries some stain of it.
No man, having put his hand to the plough, and looking back, is fit for the kingdom of God.
No man is a good physician who has never been sick.
No man is a hero to his valet-de-chambre.
No man is always wise except a fool.
No man is born into this world whose work is not born with him; there is always work, and tools to work withal, for those who will; and blessed are the horny hands of toil.
No man is born wise or learned.
No man is either worthy of a good home here or a heaven hereafter that is not willing to be in peril for a good cause.
No man is esteemed for gay garments but by fools and women.
No man is ever good for much who has not been carried off his feet by enthusiasm between twenty and thirty.
No man is ever hurt but by himself.
No man is ever paid for his real work, or should
ever expect or demand angrily to be paid; all work properly so called is an appeal from the seen to the unseen--a devout calling upon higher powers; and unless they stand by us, it will not be a work, but a quackery.
No man is free who cannot command himself.
No man is good but as he wishes the good of others.
No man is justified in resisting by word or deed the authority he lives under for a light cause, be such authority what it may.
No man is nobler born than another, unless he is born with better abilities and a more amiable disposition.
No man is poor who does not think himself so.
But if in a full fortune with impatience he desires more, he proclaims his wants and his beggarly condition.
No man is quite sane; each has a slight determination of blood to the head, to make sure of holding him hard to some one point which Nature has taken to heart.
No man is rich whose expenditures exceed his means; and no one is poor whose incomings exceed his outgoings.
No man is so free as a beggar, and no man more solemnly a servant than an honest land-owner.
No man is so happy as never to give offence.
No man is so old but thinks he may live
another day.
No man is so sufficient as never to need assistance.
No man is so tall that he need never stretch, nor so small that he need never stoop.
No man is so worthy of envy as he that can be cheerful in want.
No man is such a conqueror as the man who has defeated himself.
No man is the wiser for his learning.... Wit
and wisdom are born with a man.
No man is the worse for knowing the worst of himself.
No man is to be deemed free who has not perfect self-command.
No man is wise enough or good enough to be intrusted with unlimited power.
No man is wise or safe but be that is honest.
No man is without enemies.
No man is without his load of trouble.
No man lives so poor as he was born.
No man loves to frustrate expectations which have been formed in his favour.
No man loveth his fetters, be they made of gold.
No man needs money so much as he who
despises it.
No man needs to study history to find out what is best for his own culture.
No man or woman of the humblest sort can really be strong, gentle, pure, and good, without the world being better for it, without somebody being helped and comforted by the very existence of that goodness.
No man perhaps suspects how large and important the region of unconsciousness in him is; what a vast, unknown territory lies there back of his conscious will and purpose, and which is really the controlling power of his life.
No man praises happiness as he would justice, but calls it blessed, as being something more divine and excellent.
No man regards an eruption upon the surface
when the noble parts are invaded, and he feels a mortification approaching to his heart.
"No man," said Pestalozzi, "in God's wide universe, is either willing or able to help any other man." Help must come from the bosom alone.
No man sees far; the most see no farther than their noses.
No man should be so much taken up in the search of truth, as thereby to neglect the more necessary duties of active life.
No man should enter into alliance with his enemy, even with the tightest bonds of union. Water made ever so hot will still quench fire.
No man should ever be ashamed to own he
has been in the wrong, which is but saying, in other words, that he is wiser to-day than he was yesterday.
No man should ever display his bravery who is unprepared for battle; nor bear the marks of defiance, until he hath experienced the abilities of his enemy.
No man should form an acquaintance, nor enter into any amusements, with one of an evil character. A piece of charcoal, if it be hot, burneth; and if it be cold, blackeneth the hand.
No man should part with his own individuality and become that of another.
No man should strive to precede his fellows; for, should the work succeed, the booty is equal, and if it fail, the leader is punished.
No man should think so highly of himself as
to think he can receive but little light from books, nor so meanly as to believe he can discover nothing but what is to be learned from them.
No man talks of that which he is desirous to conceal, and every man desires to conceal that of which he is ashamed.
No man thoroughly understands a truth until he has contended against it.
No man troubleth the beggar with questioning his religion or politics.
No man was ever as rich as all men ought to be.
No man was ever scolded out of his sins.
No man was ever so much deceived by another as by himself.
No man was ever written out of reputation but by himself.
No man was more foolish when he had not a pen in his hand, or more wise when he had.
No man whatever believes, or can believe, exactly what his grandfather believed.
No man who does not choose, enter into and
walk in some narrow way of life, will ever have any moral character, any clearness of purpose, any wisdom of intelligence, or any tenderness or strength of heart.
No man who has once heartily and wholly laughed can be altogether irreclaimably bad.
No man who is wretched in his own heart and feeble in his own work can rightly help others.
No man who needs a monument ever ought to have one.
No man's conscience can tell him the rights of another man.
No man's pie is freed / From his ambitious
finger.
No man's religion ever survives his morals.
No mata la carga sino la sobrecarga
No matter how much faculty of idle seeing a man has, the step from knowing to doing is rarely taken.
No matter what his rank or position may be, the lover of books is the richest and happiest of the children of men.
No might nor greatness in mortality / Can censure
'scape; back-wounding calumny / The whitest virtue strikes.
No mill, no meal.
No more can you distinguish of a man / Than of his outward show; which, God he knows, / Seldom or never jumpeth with the heart.
No more dangerous snare is set by the fiends for human frailty than the belief that our enemies are also the enemies of God.
No more of your titled acquaintances boast, / And in what lordly circles you've been: / An insect is still but an insect at most, / Though it crawl on the head of a queen.
No more subtle master under heaven / Than
is the maiden-passion for a maid, / Not only to keep down the base in man, / But teach high thought, and amiable words / And courtliness, and the desire of fame, / And love of truth, and all that makes a man.
No morning can restore what we have forfeited.
No mortal can both work and do good talking in Parliament or out of it; the feat is impossible as that of serving two hostile masters.
No mortal has a right to wag his tongue, much less to wag his pen, without saying something.
No mortal's endeavour or attainment will, in the smallest, content the as unendeavouring, unattaining young gentleman; but he could make it all infinitely better, were it worthy of him.
No mother worthy of the name ever gave herself
thoroughly for her child who did not feel that, after all, she reaped what she had sown.
No nation can be destroyed while it possesses a good home life.
No nation can bear wealth that is not intelligent first.
No nation can reform itself, as the English are now trying to do, by what their newspapers call "tremendous cheers." Reform is not joyous, but grievous; no single man can reform himself without stern suffering and stern working; how much less can a nation of men! Medea, when she made men young again, was wont to hew them in pieces with meat-axes; cast them into caldrons, and boil them for a length of time. How much handier could they have but done it by "tremendous cheers" alone!
No need to teach your grandames to suck eggs.
No news is good news.
No, no! I am but shadow of myself; / You are deceived, my substance is not here.
No noble task was ever easy.
No nobler feeling than this of admiration for one higher than himself, dwells in the breast of man.
No, not even faith, or hope, or any other virtue, is accepted by God without charity and grace.
No oath that binds to wrong can ever bind.
No one can bake cakes for the whole world.
No one can be a great thinker who does not recognise that, as a thinker, it is his first duty to follow his intellect to whatever conclusions it may lead.
No one can be despised by another until he has learned to despise himself.
No one can be in perfect accord with any one but himself.
No one can feel and exercise benevolence towards
another who is ill at ease with himself.
No one can find himself in himself or others; in fact, he has himself to spin, from the centre of which he exercises his influence.
No one can obtain what he does not bring with him.
No one can teach religion who has it not.
No one can teach you anything worth learning but through manual labour; the very bread of life can only be got out of the chaff of it by rubbing it in your hands.
No one claims kindred with the poor.
No one easily arrives at the conclusion that reason and a brave will are given us that we may not only hold back from evil, but also from the extreme of good.
No one eats goldfish.
No one ever impoverished himself by almsgiving.
No one ever possessed superior intellectual qualities without knowing them.
No one ever teaches well who wants to teach,
or governs well who wants to govern.
No one falls low unless he attempt to climb high.
No one gets into trouble without his own help.
No one has ever learned fully to know himself.
No one has ever yet succeeded in deceiving the whole world, nor has the world ever combined to deceive any individual.
No one has seen to-morrow.
No one is a slave whose will is free.
No one is by nature noble, respected of any one, nor a wretch. His own actions conduct him either to wretchedness or to the reverse.
No one is free who is not master of himself.
No one is more profoundly sad than he who laughs too much.
No one is qualified to converse in public who is
not highly contented without such conversation.
No one is qualified to entertain, or receive entertainment from others, who cannot entertain himself alone with satisfaction.
No one is rich enough to do without his neighbour.
No one is so hardy as to say God is in his debt, that he owed him a nobler being, for existence must be antecedent to merit.
No one knows how far his powers go till he has tried.
No one knows the weight of another's burden.
No one knows what he is doing while he is acting rightly, but of what is wrong we are always conscious.
No one knows when he is well off.
No one knows where the shoe pinches but him who wears it.
No one knows whether death, which men in their fear apprehend to be the greatest evil, may not be the greatest good.
No one likes to bell the cat.
No one shall look for effectual help to another; but each shall rest content with what help he can afford himself.
No one will become anything, every one will already be something.
No one would respect thee in a beggar's coat. What is the respect paid to woollen cloth, not to thee?
No one would talk much in society if he only knew how often he misunderstands others.
No orator can measure in effect with him who
can give good nicknames.
No order or profession of men is so sacred, no place so remote or solitary, but that temptations and troubles will find them out and intrude upon them.
No outward tyranny can reach the mind.
No padlocks, bolts, or bars can secure a maiden so well as her own reserve.
No pain, no palm; no thorns, no throne; no gall, no glory; no cross, no crown.
No pains, no gains.
No passions are without their use, none without their nobleness, when seen in balanced unity with the rest of the spirit which they are charged to defend.
No patient will ever recover his health merely from the description of a medicine.
No pay is receivable by any true man; but power is receivable by him in the love and faith you give him.
No peace was ever won from fate by subterfuge or agreement; no peace is ever in store for any of us but that which we shall win by victory over shame or sin--victory over the sin that oppresses, as well as over that which corrupts.
No penny, no paternoster.
No people at the present day can be explained by their national religion. They do not feel responsible for it; it lies far outside of them.
No person is either so happy or so unhappy as he imagines.
No pillow so soft as God's promise.
No pin's point can you mark within the wide circle of the All where God's laws are not.
No place, no company, no age, no person is
temptation-free; let no man boast that he was never tempted; let him not be high-minded, but fear, for he may be surprised in that very instant wherein he boasteth that he was never tempted at all.
No power of genius has ever yet had the smallest success in explaining existence.
No power of good can be obtained by doing nothing and by knowing nothing.
No prayer, no religion, or at least only a dumb and lame one.
No principle is more noble, as there is none more holy, than that of a true obedience.
No productiveness of the highest kind, no remarkable
discovery, no great thought which bears fruit and has results, is in the power of any one; such things are exalted above all earthly control. Man must consider them as an unexpected gift from above, as pure children of God, which he must receive and venerate with joyful thanks, ... as a vessel found worthy for the reception of such divine influence.
No profit canst thou gain / By self-consuming care.
No profit grows where is no pleasure ta'en: / In brief, sir, study what you most affect.
No property is eternal but God the Maker's: Whom Heaven permits to take possession, his is the right; Heaven's sanction is such permission--while it lasts.
No real happiness is found / In trailing purple o'er the ground.
No really great man ever thought himself so.
No receiver, no thief.
No reckoning made, but sent to my account / With all my imperfections on my head.
No reports are more readily believed than those which disparage genius and soothe envy of conscious mediocrity.
No rest is worth anything except the rest that is earned.
No revenge is more heroic than that which torments envy by doing good.
No road is long with good company.
No sadder proof can be given by man of his
own littleness than disbelief in great men.
No safe wading in an unknown water.
No sensible person ever made an apology.
No si puo volar senza ale
No single action creates, however it may exhibit, a man's character.
No slave, to lazy ease resign'd, / E'er triumphed
over noble foes; / The monarch, Fortune, most is kind / To him who bravely dares oppose.
No slave's vote is other than a nuisance, whensoever, or wheresoever, or in what manner soever, it is given.
No smaller spirit can vanquish a greater.
No smoke, in any sense, but can become flame and radiance.
No society can be upheld in happiness and honour without the sentiment of religion.
No sooner is a temple built to God, but the
devil builds a chapel close by.
No soul to strong endeavour yoked for ever, / Works against the tide in vain.
No sound is dissonant which tells of life.
No speculation in those eyes / Which thou dost glare with!
No statesman e'er will find it worth his pains / To tax our labours and excise our brains.
No stronger castle than a poor man's.
No surer does the Auldgarth bridge, that his father helped to build, carry the traveller over the turbulent water beneath it, than Carlyle's books convey the reader over chasms and confusions, where before there was no way, or only an inadequate one.
No sword bites so fiercely as an evil tongue.
No tale so good but may be spoiled in the telling.
No teaching is spiritually profitable, that is of true vital avail, translateable into flesh and blood, unless with the teaching we imbibe the spirit that dictates it.
No theatre for virtue is equal to the consciousness
of it.
No theological absurdities so glaring that they have not sometimes been embraced by men of the greatest and most cultivated understanding. No religious precepts so rigorous that they have not been adopted by the most voluptuous and most abandoned of men.
No thoroughly occupied man was ever yet very miserable.
No thought is beautiful which is not just, and no thought can be just which is not founded on truth.
No thought is contented. The better sort, / As thoughts of things divine, are intermixed / With scruples, and do set the word itself / Against the word.
No trial is dangerous which there is courage
to meet.
No trouble, cross, or death / E'er shall silence faith and praise.
No truly great man ever founded, wilfully intended founding, a sect.
No two on earth in all things can agree; / All have some darling singularity.
No two virtues, whatever relation they claim, / Nor even two different shades of the same, / Though like as was ever twin-brother to brother, / Possessing the one shall imply you've the other.
No useless coffin enclosed his breast, / Not in
sheet nor in shroud we wound him; / But he lay like a warrior taking his rest, / With his martial cloak around him.
No vice goes alone.
No victory worth having was ever won without cost.
No violent extreme endures.
No visor does become black villany / So well as soft and tender flattery.
No weather's ill when the wind's still.
No weeping for shed milk.
No whip cuts so sharply as the lash of conscience.
No wild beast more to be dreaded than a communicative man having nothing to communicate.
No wild enthusiast ever yet could rest / Till half mankind were like himself possess'd.
No wind is of service to him who is bound for
nowhere.
No wise combatant underrates his antagonist.
No wise man can have a contempt for the prejudices of others; and he should even stand in a certain awe of his own, as if they were aged parents and monitors. They may in the end prove wiser than he.
No wise man ever wished to be younger.
No wise man should make known the loss of fortune, any malpractices in his house, his being cheated, or his having been disgraced.
No woman can be handsome by the force of
features alone, any more than she can be witty only by the help of speech.
No woman is educated who is not equal to the successful management of a family.
No woman is so bad but we may rejoice when her heart thrills to love, for then God has her by the hand.
No woman shall succeed in Salique land.
No wonder is greater than any other wonder, and if once explained, it ceases to be a wonder.
No wonder lasts over three days.
No wonder we are all more or less pleased with mediocrity, since it leaves us at rest, and gives the same comfortable feeling as when one associates with his equals.
No word is ill spoken if it be not ill taken.
No words suffice the secret soul to show, / For truth denies all eloquence to woe.
No work, no recompense.
No working world, any more than a fighting
world, can be led on without a noble chivalry of work, and laws and fixed rules which follow out of that--far nobler than any chivalry of fighting war.
No worth, known or unknown, can die even on this earth.
Nobilitatis virtus non stemma character
Nobility is a river that sets with a constant and undeviating current directly into the great Pacific Ocean of Time; but, unlike all other rivers, it is more grand at its source than at its termination.
Nobility of nature consists in doing good for the good's sake.
Nobility without virtue is a fine setting without
a gem.
Nobis non licet esse tam disertis, / Qui Musas colimus severiores
Noble art is nothing less than the expression of a great soul; and great souls are not common things.
Noble housekeepers need no doors.
Noble spirits war not with the dead.
Nobler is a limited command, / Given by the
love of all your native land, / Than a successive title, long and dark, / Drawn from the mouldy rolls of Noah's ark.
Noblesse oblige
Nobody calls himself rogue.
Nobody can continue easy in his own mind who does not endeavour to become least of all and servant of all.
Nobody can find work easy if much work do lie in him.
Nobody can live by teaching any more than
by learning; both teaching and learning are proper duties of human life, or pleasures of it, but have nothing whatever to do with the support of it.
Nobody contents himself with rough diamonds, or wears them so. When polished and set, then they give a lustre.
Nobody has a right to have opinions, but only knowledge.
Nobody knows who may be listening; say nothing which you would not wish put in the daily paper.
Nobody should be rich but those who understand it.
Nobody will persist long in helping those who
will not help themselves.
Nobody will use other people's experience, nor has any of his own till it is too late to use it.
Nobody would be afraid if he could help it.
Noces de Gamache
Nocet empta dolore voluptas
Noch ist es Tag, da rühre sich der Mann, /
Die Nacht tritt ein, wo niemand wirken kann
Noch lebt ein Gott, der meines Elends denkt!
Noch niemand entfloh dem verhängten Geschick
Noctemque diemque fatigat
Nocturna versate manu, versate diurna
Nodum in scirpo quæris
Noisome weeds that without profit suck / The soil's fertility from wholesome flowers.
Nolens volens
Noli irritare leones
Noli me tangere
Nolle prosequi
Nolo barbam vellere mortuo leoni
Nolo episcopari
Nom de guerre
Nom de plume
Nomen amicitia est; nomen inane fides
Nomen atque omen
Non adeo cecidi, quamvis abjectus, ut infra / Te quoque sim; inferius quo nihil esse potest
Non ætate verum ingenio adipiscitur sapientia
Non agitur de vectigalibus, non de sociorum
injuriis; libertas et anima nostra in dubio est
Non amo te, Sabidi, nec possum dicere quare; / Hoc tantum possum dicere, non amo te
Non Angli, sed angeli
Non aqua, sed ruina
Non assumpsit
Non bene conveniunt, nec in una sede morantur
/ Majestas et amor
Non bene imperat, nisi qui paruerit imperio
Non bene junctarum discordia semina rerum
Non c' è il peggior frutto di quello che non matura mai
Non ci è fumo senza fuoco
Non compos mentis
Non constat
Non convivere, nec videre saltem, / Non audire licet; nec Urbe tota / Quisquam est tam prope, tam proculque nobis
Non credo tempori
Non cuicunque datum est habere nasum
Non cuivis homini contingit adire Corinthum
Non decipitur qui scit se decipi
Non deerat voluntas, sed facultas
Non deficit alter
Non destare il can che dorme
Non è in alcun luogo chi è per tutto
Non è si tristo cane che non meni la coda
Non è uomo chi non sa dir di nò
Non è ver che sia la morte / Il peggior di tutti i mali; / E un sollievo pei mortali / Che non stanchi di soffrir
Non eadem est ætas, non mens
Non eadem ratio est, sentire et demere morbos: / Sensus inest cunctis; tollitur arte malum
Non ebur neque aureum / Mea renidet in domo
lacunar
Non ego avarum / Cum te veto fieri, vappam jubeo ac nebulonem
Non ego illam mihi dotem esse puto, quæ dos dicitur, / Sed pudicitiam, et pudorem, et sedatam cupidinem
Non ego mordaci distrinxi carmine quenquam; / Nec meus ullius crimina versus habet
Non ego omnino lucrum omne esse utile homini existimo
Non ego ventosæ venor suffragia plebis
Non enim gazæ neque consularis / Summovet lictor miseros tumultus / Mentis et curas laqueata circum / Tecta volantes
Non equidem invideo, miror magis
Non equidem studeo, bullatis ut mihi nugis / Pagina turgescat, dare pondus idonea fumo
Non erat his locus
Non esse cupidum pecunia est: non esse
emacem vectigal est
Non est ad astra mollis a terris via
Non est bonum ludere cum Diis
Non est de pastu omnium quæstio, sed de lana
Non est de sacco tanta farina tuo
Non est ejusdem et multa et opportuna dicere
Non est jocus esse malignum
Non est nostri ingenii
Non est vivere, sed valere, vita
Non exercitus, neque thesauri, præsidia regni sunt, verum amici
Non fa buon mangiar cireggie con signori
Non fumum ex fulgore, sed ex fumo dare lucem
Non generant aquilæ columbas
Non giudicar la nave stando in terra
Non hæc sine numine
Non han speranza di morte
Non hoc ista sibi tempus spectacula poscit
Non hominis culpa, sed ista loci
Non id quod magnum est pulchrum est, sed id quod pulchrum magnum
Non ignara mali miseris succurrere disco.
Non illa colo calathisve Minervæ / Femineas
assueta manus
Non immemor beneficii
Non in caro nidore voluptas / Summa, sed in teipso est, tu pulmentaria quære / Sudando
Non intelligitur quando obrepit senectus
Non intelligunt homines quam magnum vectigal sit parsimonia
Non la philosophie, mais le philosophisme causera des maux à la France
Non liquet
Non magni pendis, quia contigit
Non me pudet fateri nescire quod nesciam
Non mihi sapit qui sermone, sed qui factis sapit
Non mihi si linguæ centum sint oraque centum, / Ferrea vox, omnes scelerum comprendere formas / Omnia pœnarum percurrere nomina possim
Non missura cutem, nisi plena cruoris hirudo
Non multa, sed multum
Non nobis, Domine
Non nobis solum nati sumus
Non nostrum inter vos tantas componere lites
Non obstante veredicto
Non olet
Non omnes eadem mirantur amantque
Non omnia possumus omnes
Non omnibus dormio
Non omnis error stultitia est dicendus
Non omnis moriar; multaque pars mei / Vitabit Libitinam
Non opus est magnis placido lectore poetis; / Quamlibet invitum difficilemque tenent
Non placet quem scurræ laudant, manipulares mussitant
Non posse bene geri rempublicam multorum imperiis
Non possidentem multa vocaveris / Recte
beatum. Rectius occupat / Nomen beati, qui Deorum / Muneribus sapienter uti, / Duramque callet pauperiem pati, / Pejusque leto flagitium timet
Non possum ferre, Quirites, / Græcam urbem
Non potest severus esse in judicando, qui alios in se severos esse judices non vult
Non progredi est regredi
Non pronuba Juno, / Non Hymenæus adest, non illi Gratia lecto; / Eumenides stravere torum
Non purgat peccata qui negat
Non quam diu, sed quam bene vixeris refert
Non qui soletur, non qui labentia tarde / Tempora narrando fallat, amicus adest
Non ragioniam di lor; ma guarda, e passa
Non revertar inultus
Non satis est pulchra esse poëmata; dulcia
sunto, / Et quocumque volent animum auditoris agunto
Non scholæ, sed vitæ discimus
Non scribit, cujus carmina nemo legit
Non semper erit æstas
Non semper erunt Saturnalia
Non sequitur
Non si male nunc, et olim sic erit
Non sibi sed patriæ
Non sine numine
Non sum qualis eram
Non tali auxilio, nec defensoribus istis / Tempus
eget
Non tu corpus eras sine pectore. Di tibi formam, / Di tibi divitias dederant, artemque fruendi
Non usitata, nec tenui ferar penna
Non uti libet, sed uti licet, sic vivamus
Non v'è peggior ladro d'un cattivo libro
Non vixit male, qui natus moriensque fefellit
Nonchalance
Nondum omnium dierum sol occidit
None acts a friend by a deputy, or can be familiar by proxy.
None are all evil; quickening round his heart, / One softer feeling would not yet depart.
None are fair but who are kind.
None are more unjust in their judgments of
others than those who have a high opinion of themselves.
None are rash when they are not seen by anybody.
None are so desolate but something dear, / Dearer than self, possesses or possess'd / A thought, and claims the homage of a tear.
None are so fond of secrets as those who don't mean to keep them; such persons covet secrets as a spendthrift covets money--for the purpose of circulation.
None are so hopelessly enslaved as those who falsely believe they are free.
None are so seldom found alone, and are so
soon tired of their own company, as those coxcombs who are on the best terms with themselves.
None are so well shod but they may slip.
None but a fool is always right.
None but a fool would measure his satisfaction by what the world thinks of it.
None but a Goethe, at the sun of earthly happiness, can keep his Phœnix wings unsinged.
None but an author knows an author's cares, /
Or Fancy's fondness for the child she bears.
None but himself can be his parallel.
None but men of strong passions are capable of rising to greatness.
None but the brave deserve the fair.
None can cure their harms by wailing them.
None can pray well but he who lives well.
None ever saw the pillars of the firmament; yet it is supported.
None ever was a great poet that applied himself much to anything else.
None is so deaf as he who will not hear.
None is so wasteful as the scraping dame; / She loseth three for one--her soul, rest, fame.
None is so wretched as the poor man who maintains
the semblance of wealth.
None lie that would not steal.
None more impatiently suffer injuries than those that are most forward in doing them.
None of the affections have been noted to fascinate and bewitch but envy.
None of those who own the land own the landscape; only he whose eye can integrate all the parts, that is, the poet.
None of us can wrong the universe.
None of you can tell where the shoe pinches me.
None shun the light but criminals and evil spirits.
None so blind as they who will not see.
None so miserable as a man who wills everything and can do nothing.
None so wise but the advice of others may, at
some time or other, be useful and necessary for him.
None think the great unhappy but the great.
None without hope e'er loved the brightest fair; / But love can hope where reason would despair.
Nor are those empty-hearted whose low sound / Reverbs no hollowness.
Nor by the wayside ruins let us mourn / Who have th' eternal towers for our appointed bourne.
Nor can either thy own resentment of misfortunes
within, or the violence of any calamity without, give thee sufficient grounds, from the terrible face thy present circumstances wear, to pronounce that all hope of escape and better days are past.
Nor deem the irrevocable past / As wholly wasted, wholly vain, / If, rising on its wrecks, at last / To something nobler we attain.
Nor e'en the tenderest heart, and next our own, / Knows half the reasons why we smile and sigh!
Nor e'er was to the bowers of bliss conveyed / A fairer spirit or more welcome shade.
Nor Fame I slight, nor for her favours call; / She comes unlook'd for, if she comes at all.
Nor grieve to die when far from home; you'll
find / To Hades everywhere a favouring wind.
Nor is it possible to thought / A greater than itself to know.
Nor less I deem that there are powers / Which of themselves our minds impress; / That we can feel this mind of ours / In a wide passiveness.
Nor love thy life, nor hate, but what thou liv'st / Live well, how long or short permit to heaven.
Nor sequent centuries could hit / Orbit and sum of Shakespeare's wit.
Nor sink those stars in empty night; / They
hide themselves in heaven's own light.
Noris quam elegans formarum spectator fiem
Nos duo turba sumus
Nos hæc novimus esse nihil
Nos nostraque Deo
Nos numerus sumus et fruges consumere nati
Nos patriæ fines et dulcia linquimus arva
Nos te, / Nos facimus, Fortuna, deam
Nosce tempus
Noscenda est mensura sui spectandaque rebus / In summis minimisque
Noscitur a sociis
Nosse omnia hæc salus est adolescentulis
Nosse volunt omnes, mercedem solvere nemo
Nostra nos sine comparatione delectant; nunquam
erit felix quem torquebit felicior
Not a drum was heard, not a funeral note, / As his corse to the rampart we hurried: / Not a soldier discharged his farewell shot, / O'er the grave where our hero we buried.
Not a flower, not a flower sweet, / On my black coffin let there be strewn; / Not a friend, not a friend greet / My poor corpse, where my bones shall be thrown; / A thousand, thousand sighs to save, / Lay me (what you will) O where / Sad lover ne'er find my grave, / To weep there.
Not a man, for being simply man, / Hath any honour, but honour for those honours / That are without him, as place, riches, favour, / Prizes of accident, as oft as merit.
Not a man of iron, but of live oak.
Not a Red Indian, hunting by Lake Winnipeg,
can quarrel with his squaw, but the whole world must smart for it. Will not the price of beaver rise?
Not a single shaft can hit / Till the God of love sees fit.
Not a vanity is given in vain.
Not all that heralds rake from coffin'd clay, / Nor florid prose, nor honeyed lines of rhyme, / Can blazon evil deeds or consecrate a crime.
Not all the water in the rough rude sea / Can wash the balm from an anointed king; / The breath of worldly men cannot depose / The deputy elected by the Lord.
Not alone to know, but to act according to
thy knowledge, is thy destination.
Not as a vulture, but a dove, / The Holy Ghost came from above.
Not body enough to cover his mind decently with; his intellect is improperly exposed.
Not brute force, but only persuasion and faith is the king of this world.
Not by levity of floating, but by stubborn force of swimming, shalt thou make thy way. A grand "vis inertiæ" in thee, Mr. Bull.
Not by might, nor by power, but by my spirit,
saith the Lord.
Not by the law of force, but by the law of labour, has any man right to the possession of the land.
Not enjoyment, and not sorrow, / Is our destined end or way; / But to act that each to-morrow / May find us farther than to-day.
Not every parish priest can wear Dr. Luther's shoes.
Not fame, but that which it merits, is what a man should esteem.
Not for fellowship in hatred, but in love am I
here.
Not he that commendeth himself is approved, but whom the Lord commendeth.
Not he who has many ideas, but he who has one conviction may become a great man.
Not heaven itself upon the past has power; / But what has been, has been, and I have had my hour.
Not in a man's having no business with men, but in having no unjust business with them, and in having all manner of true and just business, can either his or their blessedness be found possible, and this waste world become, for both parties, a home and peopled garden.
Not in nature, but in man is all the beauty
and the worth he sees. The world is very empty, and is indebted to this gilding, exalting soul for its pride.
Not in pulling down, but in building up, does man find pure joy.
Not in the achievement, but in the endurance, of the human soul, does it show its divine grandeur and its alliance with the infinite God.
Not kings alone--the people too have their flatterers.
Not less in God's sight is the end of the day than the beginning.
Not liberty, but duty, is the condition of existence.
Not lost, but gone before.
Not many words are needed to refuse; by the refused the "no" alone is heard.
Not marble, nor the gilded monuments of princes, shall outlive this powerful rhyme.
Not misgovernment, nor yet no government; only government will now serve.
Not once or twice in our rough island-story, /
The path of duty was the way to glory: / He that walks it, only thirsting / For the right, and learns to deaden / Love of self, before his journey closes / He shall find the stubborn thistle bursting / Into glossy purples, which outredden / All voluptuous garden-roses.
Not one false man but does unaccountable mischief; how much, in a generation or two, will twenty-seven millions, mostly false, manage to accumulate?
Not one of our faculties that it is not a delight to exercise.
Not one of our senses that, in its healthy state, is not an avenue to enjoyment.
Not one word of any book is readable by you, except so far as your mind is one with its author's; and not merely his words like your words, but his thoughts like your thoughts.
Not only all common speech, but science, poetry itself, is no other, if thou consider it, than right naming.
Not only has the unseen world a reality, but
the only reality; the rest being, not metaphorically, but literally and in scientific strictness, "a show."
Not our logical, mensurative faculty, but our imaginative one is king over us; I might say, priest and prophet to lead us heavenward, or magician and wizard to lead us hellward.
Not so easily can a man tear up the roots of his old life, and transplant himself into a new soil and a foreign atmosphere.
Not that I loved Cæsar less, but that I loved Rome more.
Not the cry, but the flight of a wild duck, rouses the flock to fly and follow.
Not the glittering weapon fights the fight, but
the hero's heart.
Not the maker of plans and promises, but rather he who offers faithful service in small matters is most welcome to one who would achieve what is good and lasting.
Not this man and that man, but all men make up mankind, and their united tasks the task of mankind.
Not to attempt a gallant deed for which one has the impulse may be braver than the doing of it.
Not to believe in God, but to acknowledge Him when and wheresoever He reveals Himself, is the one sole blessedness of man on earth.
Not to desire or admire, if a man could learn
it, were more / Than a walk all day like the sultan of old in a garden of spice.
Not to know me argues yourselves unknown.
Not to know what has been transacted in former times is to continue always a child.
Not to return one good office for another is inhuman; but to return evil for good is diabolical.
Not to see the wood for the trees
Not to speak your opinion well, but to have a
good and just opinion worth speaking; for every Parliament, as for every man, this latter is the point.
Not to talk of thy doing, and become the envy of surrounding flunkeys, but to taste of the fruit of thy doings themselves, is thine.
Not towards the impossibility, self-government of a multitude by a multitude; but towards some possibility, government by the wisest, does bewildered Europe now struggle.
Not what I Have, but what I Do is my Kingdom.
Not what the man knows, but what he wills, determines his worth or unworth, his strength or weakness, his happiness or misery.
Not what we wish, but what we want, / Oh,
let thy grace supply.
Not when I rise above, only when I rise to, something, do I approve myself.
Not where they dash ashore and break and moan are waters deadliest.
Not without a shudder may a human hand clutch into the mysterious urn of destiny.
Note bene
Notandi sunt tibi mores
Note how the falcon starts at every sight, / New from his hood, but what a quiet eye / Cometh of freedom.
Noth bricht Eisen-
Noth kennt kein Gebot
Noth lehrt beten
Nothing altogether passes away without result.
We are here to leave that behind us which will never die.
Nothing amuses more harmlessly than computation, and nothing is oftener applicable to real business or speculative inquiries. A thousand stories which the ignorant tell and believe die away at once when the computist takes them in his grip.
Nothing astonishes men so much as common sense and plain dealing.
Nothing at bottom is interesting to the majority of men but themselves.
Nothing becomes him ill that he would well.
Nothing but a handful of dust will fill the eye
of man.
Nothing but ourselves can finally beat us.
Nothing can atone for the want of modesty, without which beauty is ungraceful and wit detestable.
Nothing can be beautiful which is not true.
Nothing can be done at once hastily and prudently.
Nothing can be hostile to religion which is
agreeable to justice.
Nothing can be made of nothing; he who has laid up no material can produce no combinations.
Nothing can be more fatal in politics than a preponderance of the philosophical, or in philosophy than a preponderance of the political, spirit.
Nothing can be preserved but what is good.
Nothing can be so injurious to progress as to be altogether blamed or altogether praised.
Nothing can be termed mine own but what I
make my own by using well.
Nothing can bring you peace but yourself; nothing, but the triumph of principles.
Nothing can come out of a sack that is not in it.
Nothing can ferment itself to clearness in a colander.
Nothing can need a lie; / A fault, which needs it most, grows two thereby.
Nothing can overtake an untruth if it has a
minute's start.
Nothing can work me damage except myself.
Nothing comes amiss, so money comes withal.
Nothing comes amiss to a hungry man.
Nothing contributes so much to cheerfulness as health, or so little as riches.
Nothing costs less or is cheaper than compliments
of civility.
Nothing deepens and intensifies family traits like poverty and toil and suffering. It is the furnace heat that brings out the characters, the pressure that makes the strata perfect.
Nothing destroyeth authority so much as the unequal and untimely interchange of power pressed too far and relaxed too much.
Nothing dies, nothing can die. No idlest word thou speakest but is a seed cast into time, and grows through all eternity.
Nothing does so much honour to a woman as her patience, and nothing does her so little as the patience of her husband.
Nothing done by man in the past has any
deeper sense than what he is doing now.
Nothing doth so fool a man as extreme passion.
Nothing emboldens sin so much as mercy.
Nothing endears so much a friend as sorrow for his death. The pleasure of his company has not so powerful an influence.
Nothing exceeds in ridicule, no doubt, / A fool in fashion, save a fool that's out; / His passion for absurdity's so strong, / He cannot bear a rival in the throng.
Nothing exposes us more to madness than
distinguishing ourselves from others, and nothing more contributes to maintain our common-sense than living in community of feeling with other people.
Nothing extenuate, / Nor set down aught in malice; then must you speak / Of one, that loved not wisely, but too well ... of one, whose hand / Like the base Indian, threw a pearl away, / Richer than all his tribe.
Nothing for nothing.
Nothing for nothing, and very little for a halfpenny.
Nothing gives such a blow to friendship as the detecting another in an untruth. It strikes at the root of our confidence ever after.
Nothing good bursts forth all at once. The
lightning may dart out of a black cloud; but the day sends his bright heralds before him to prepare the world for his coming.
Nothing great is lightly won, nothing won is lost; / Every good deed nobly done will repay the cost.
Nothing hath got so far / But man hath caught and kept it as his prey; / His eyes dismount the highest star; / He is in little all the sphere.
Nothing hitherto was ever stranded, cast aside; but all, were it only a withered leaf, works together with all; is borne forward on the bottomless, shoreless flood of action, and lives through perpetual metamorphoses.
Nothing in haste save catching fleas.
Nothing in his life / Became him like the
leaving it; he died / As one that had been studied in his death / To throw away the dearest thing he owed, / As 'twere a careless trifle.
Nothing in itself deformed or incongruous can give us any real satisfaction.
Nothing in love can be premeditated; it is as a power divine, that thinks and feels within us, unswathed by our control.
Nothing in Nature, much less conscious being, / Was e'er created solely for itself.
Nothing in the dealings of Heaven with Earth is so wonderful to me as the way in which the evil angels are allowed to spot, pervert, and bring to nothing, or to worse, the powers of the greatest men: so that Greece must be ruined, for all that Plato can say; Geneva, for all that Calvin can say; England, for all that Sir Thomas More and Bacon can say; and only Gounod's "Faust" to be the visible outcome to Europe of the school of Weimar.
Nothing in the world is more haughty than a
man of moderate capacity when once raised to power.
Nothing is a misery, / Unless our weakness apprehend it so; / We cannot be more faithful to ourselves / In anything that's manly, than to make / Ill-fortune as contemptible to us / As it makes us to others.
Nothing is at last sacred but the integrity of your own mind. Absolve yourself to yourself, and you shall have the suffrage of the world.
Nothing is but what is not.
Nothing is cheap if you don't want it.
Nothing is constant but a virtuous mind.
Nothing is denied to well-directed labour; nothing is ever to be attained without it.
Nothing is difficult; it is only we who are indolent.
Nothing is easier than to clear debts by borrowing.
Nothing is endless but inanity.
Nothing is fair or good alone.
Nothing is farther than earth from heaven, and nothing is nearer than heaven to earth.
Nothing is given so ungrudgingly as advice.
Nothing is good for a nation but that which arises from its core and its own general wants.
Nothing is good I see without respect.
Nothing is good or bad, but thinking makes it so.
Nothing is graceful that is not our own.
Nothing is high because it is in a high place, and nothing low because it is in a low one.
Nothing is impossible to the man who can
will.
Nothing is insipid to the wise; / To thee insipid all but what is mad; / Joy season'd high and tasting strong of guilt.
Nothing is lasting that is feigned.
Nothing is less in our power than the heart, and, far from commanding it, we are forced to obey it.
Nothing is law that is not reason.
Nothing is more active than thought, for it
flies over the universe; nothing stronger than necessity, for all must submit to it.
Nothing is more binding than the friendship of companions-in-arms.
Nothing is more certain than that great poets are no sudden prodigies, but slow results.
Nothing is more characteristic of a man than his behaviour towards fools.
Nothing is more common than mutual dislike, where mutual approbation is particularly expected.
Nothing is more common than to express exceeding
zeal in amending our neighbours, ... while at the same time we neglect the beginning at home.
Nothing is more deeply punished than the neglect of the affinities by which alone society should be formed, and the insane levity of choosing associates by others' eyes.
Nothing is more disgusting than the crowing about liberty by slaves.
Nothing is more easy than to clear debts by borrowing.
Nothing is more free than the imagination of man.
Nothing is more hurtful to a truth than an
old error.
Nothing is more natural than that we should grow giddy at a great sight which comes unexpectedly before us, to make us feel at once our littleness and our greatness. But there is not in the world any truer enjoyment than at the moment when we are thus made giddy for the first time.
Nothing is more ruinous for a man than when he is mighty enough in any part to right himself without right.
Nothing is more significant of the philosophy of a man than the footing on which he stands with his body. The Cynic neglects it, the Sybarite makes profit out of it, the Trappist disowns it, and the Idealist forgets it.
Nothing is more surprising than the easiness with which the many are governed by the few.
Nothing is more terrible than ignorance in
action.
Nothing is more unjust or capricious than public opinion.
Nothing is more vulgar than haste.
Nothing is more offensive to reason
than an appeal to the majority; it consists of a few powerful leaders, of rogues who accommodate themselves, of weaklings who assimilate themselves, and of the mass who follow confusedly, without in the least knowing what they would be at.
Nothing is new; we walk where others went; / There's no vice now but has its precedent.
Nothing is of any value in books excepting the
transcendental and extraordinary.
Nothing is old but the mind.
Nothing is perfect until, in some way, it touches or passes through man.
Nothing is permanently helpful to any race or condition of men but the spirit that is in their own hearts, kindled by the love of their native land.
Nothing is pleasant that is not spiced with variety.
Nothing is poetry which does not transport;
the lyre is a winged instrument.
Nothing is profane that serveth to holy things.
Nothing is quite beautiful alone; nothing but is beautiful in the whole.
Nothing is rarer than the use of a word in its exact meaning.
Nothing is safe from fault-finders.
Nothing is secret that shall not be made
manifest; neither anything hid that shall not be known.
Nothing is so atrocious as fancy without taste.
Nothing is so beautiful to the eye as truth is to the mind; nothing so deformed and irreconcilable to the understanding as a lie.
Nothing is so perfectly amusement as a total change of ideas.
Nothing is so conceivable
child, nothing seems to be so natural to him, as the marvellous or supernatural.
Nothing is so dangerous as an ignorant friend.
Nothing is so difficult as to help a friend in matters which do not require the aid of friendship, but only a cheap and trivial service, if your friendship wants the basis of a thorough practical acquaintance.
Nothing is so envied as genius, nothing so hopeless of attainment by labour alone. Though labour always accompanies the greatest genius, without the intellectual gift labour alone will do little.
Nothing is so grand as truth, nothing so forcible, nothing so novel.
Nothing is so great an instance of ill-manners as flattery. If you flatter all the company, you please none; if you flatter only one or two, you affront the rest.
Nothing is so narrowing, contracting, hardening,
as always to be moving in the same groove, with no thought beyond what we immediately see and hear close around us.
Nothing is so new as what has been long forgotten.
Nothing is so uncertain as the minds of the multitude.
Nothing is superficial to a deep observer. It is in trifles that the mind betrays itself.
Nothing is there to come, and nothing past, / But an eternal now does always last.
Nothing is thoroughly approved but mediocrity.
The majority has established this, and it fixes its fangs on whatever gets beyond it either way.
Nothing is thought rare / Which is not new and followed; yet we know / That what was worn some twenty years ago / Comes into grace again.
Nothing is to be preferred before justice.
Nothing is too high for a man to reach, but he must climb with care and confidence.
Nothing is true but what is simple.
Nothing is truly elegant but what unites use
with beauty.
Nothing leads to good which is not natural.
Nothing lovelier can be found / In woman than to study household good, / And good works in her husband to promote.
Nothing makes love sweeter and tenderer than a little previous scolding and freezing, just as the grape-clusters acquire by a frost before vintage thinner skins and better flavour.
Nothing makes the earth seem so spacious as to have friends at a distance; they make the latitudes and longitudes.
Nothing marks the character of a young man
more than a failure.
Nothing more readily pleases a vulgar mind than to find anomalies in conduct or character.
Nothing noble or godlike in the world but has in it something of "infinite sadness."
Nothing not a reality ever yet got men to pay bed and board to it for long.
Nothing on earth is without difficulty. Only the inner impulse, the pleasure it gives and love enable us to surmount obstacles; to make smooth our way, and lift ourselves out of the narrow grooves in which other people sorrowfully distress themselves.
Nothing on earth is without significance, but
the first and most essential in every matter is the place where and the hour when.
Nothing, or almost nothing, is certain to me, except the Divine Infernal character of this universe I live in, worthy of horror, worthy of worship.
Nothing pleaseth but rare accidents.
Nothing preaches better than the ant, and she says nothing.
Nothing precludes sympathy so much as a perfect indifference to it.
Nothing really pleasant or unpleasant subsists
by nature, but all things become so by habit.
Nothing recommends a man more to the female mind than courage.
Nothing remains to man, nothing is possible to him of true joy, but in the righteous love of his fellows, in the knowledge of the laws and the glory of God, and in the daily use of the faculties of soul and body with which God has endowed him.
Nothing resembles pride so much as discouragement.
Nothing right can be accomplished in art without enthusiasm.
Nothing seems important to me but so far as
it is connected with morals.
Nothing so difficult as a beginning / In poesy, except perhaps the end; / For oftentimes when Pegasus seems winning / The race, he sprains a wing, and down we tend, / Like Lucifer, when hurl'd from heaven for sinning.
Nothing so effectively disconcerts the schemes of sinister people as the tranquillity of great souls.
Nothing so endures as a truly spoken word.
Nothing so lifts a man from all his mean imprisonments, were it but for moments, as true admiration.
Nothing so much contents us as that which
confounds us.
Nothing so much prevents our being natural as the desire of appearing so.
Nothing stands in need of lying but a lie.
Nothing stings so bitterly as loss of money.
Nothing succeeds like success.
Nothing that has ever lived is lost; nothing is
useless; not a sigh, a joy, or a sorrow which has not served its purpose.
Nothing that is violent is permanent.
Nothing that lives is or can be rigidly perfect; part of it is decaying, part nascent. The foxglove blossom--a third part bud, a third part past, a third part in full bloom--is a type of the life of this world.
Nothing truly can be made mine own but what I make mine own by using well.
Nothing venture, nothing win.
Nothing weighs lighter than a promise.
Nothing which is unjust can hope to continue in this world.
Nothing will be mended by complaints.
Nothing's more dull and negligent / Than an old lazy government, / That knows no interest of state, / But such as serves a present strait, / And, to patch up or shift, will close, / Or break alike, with friends or foes.
Notre défiance justifie la tromperie d'autrui
Notre vie est du vent tissu
Notwithstanding this great proximity of man to himself, we still remain ignorant of many things concerning ourselves.
Nought can be gained by a Sabbath profaned.
Nought else there is / But that weird beat of Time, which doth disjoin / To-day from Hellas.
Nought is so vile that on the earth doth live, / But to the earth some special good doth give; / Nor aught so good, but, strain'd from that fair use, / Revolts from true birth, stumbling on abuse.
Nought so stockish, hard, and full of rage, / But music for the time doth change its nature.
Nought treads so silent as the foot of time.
Nourri dans le sérail, j'en connais les détours
Nous avons changé tout cela
Nous avons tous assez de force pour supporter les maux d'autrui
Nous dansons sur un volcan
Nous désirerions peu de choses avec ardeur, si nous connaissions parfaitement ce que nous désirons
Nous maintiendrons
Nous n'écoutons d'instincts que ceux qui sont
les nôtres, / Et ne croyons le mal que quand il est venu
Nous ne savons ce que c'est que le bonheur ou le malheur absolu
Nous ne sommes hommes, et nous tenons les uns aux autres, que par la parole
Nous ne trouvons guère de gens de bon sens que ceux qui sont de notre avis
Nous ne vivons jamais, mais nous esperons de vivre
Nous sommes assemblés par la volonté nationale,
nous ne sortirons que par la force
Nous sommes mieux seul qu'avec un sot
Nous verrons, dit l'aveugle
Novacula in cotem
Novels are tales of adventures which did not occur in God's creation, but only in the waste chambers (to be let unfurnished) of certain human heads, and which are part and parcel only of the sum of nothings; which, nevertheless, obtain some temporary remembrance, and lodge extensively at this epoch of the world in similar, still more unfurnished, chambers.
Novels are the journal or record of manners;
and the new importance of these books derives from the fact that the novelist begins to penetrate the surface, and treat this part of life more worthily.
Novels for most part instil into young minds false views of life.
Novelty has something in it that inebriates the fancy, and not unfrequently dissipates and fumes away like other intoxication, and leaves the poor patient, as usual, with an aching heart.
Novelty is only in request; and it is as dangerous to be aged in any kind of course, as it is virtuous to be constant in any undertaking.
Novi ego hoc sæculum, moribus quibus siet
Novi ingenium mulierum, / Nolunt ubi velis,
ubi nolis cupiunt ultro
Novos amicos dum paras, veteres cole
Novum et ad hunc diem non auditum
Novus homo
Now an incredible deal is demanded, and every avenue is barred.
Now farewell light, thou sunshine bright, /
And all beneath the sky! / May coward shame distain his name, / The wretch that dares not die.
Now, good digestion wait on appetite, / And health on both.
Now is now, and Yule's in winter.
"Now" is the watchword of the wise.
Now! it is gone. Our brief hours travel post, / Each with its thought or deed, its Why or How; / But know, each parting hour gives up a ghost / To dwell within thee--an eternal Now!
Now join your hands, and with your hands
your hearts, / That no dissension hinder government.
Now morn her rosy steps in th' eastern clime, / Advancing, sowed the earth with orient pearl.
Now our fates from unmomentous things / May rise like rivers out of little springs.
Now see that noble and most sovereign reason, / Like sweet bells jangled, out of tune, and harsh; / That unmatch'd form and feature of blown youth / Blasted with ecstacy: O, woe is me, / To have seen what I have seen, see what I see.
Now the heart is so full that a drop overfills it; / We are happy now, because God wills it.
Now 'tis the spring, and weeds are shallow-rooted;
/ Suffer them now, and they'll o'ergrow the garden, / And choke the herbs for want of husbandry.
Now you have feathered your nest.
Nowadays compromise and indifference rule supreme, and instead of solid grit we have putty or wax.
Nowadays truth is news.
Nowhere can a man get real root-room, and spread out his branches till they touch the morning and the evening, but in his own house.
Nox atra cava circumvolat
Noxiæ pœna par esto
Nuda veritas
Nudum pactum
Nugæ canoræ
Nugis addere pondus
Nul n'aura de l'esprit, / Hors nous et nos amis
Nul n'est content de sa fortune, ni mécontent de son esprit
Nulla ætas ad perdiscendum est
Nulla dies sine linea
Nulla falsa doctrina est, quæ non permisceat aliquid veritatis
Nulla fere causa est, in qua non fœmina litem moverit
Nulla fides regni sociis, omnisque potestas / Impatiens consortis erit
Nulla pallescere culpa
Nulla placere diu, vel vivere carmina possunt /
Quæ scribuntur aquæ potoribus
Nulla res tantum ad discendum profuit quantum scriptio
Nulla unquam de vita hominis cunctatio longa est
Nulli jactantius mœrent, quam qui maxime lætantur
Nulli secundus
Nulli te facias nimis sodalem, / Gaudebis
minus et minus dolebis
Nullius addictus jurare in verba magistri, / Quo me cunque rapit tempestas, deferor hospes
Nullius boni sine socio jucunda possessio
Nullius in verba
Nullum est jam dictum quod non dictum sit prius
Nullum est malum majus, quam non posse
ferre malum
Nullum est sine nomine saxum
Nullum magnum ingenium sine mixtura dementiæ fuit
Nullum magnum malum quod extremum est
Nullum numen abest si sit prudentia
Nullum numen habes si sit prudentia; nos te /
Nos facimus, Fortuna, deam cœloque locamus
Nullum quod tetigit non ornavit
Nullum simile quatuor pedibus currit
Nullum tempus occurrit regi
Nullus argento color est, / Nisi temperato / Splendeat usu
Nullus commodum capere potest de injuria sua
propria
Nullus dolor est quem non longinquitas temporis minuat ac molliat
Nullus est liber tam malus, ut non aliqua parte prosit
Numbers err in this: / Ten censure wrong for one who writes amiss.
Numerical inquiries will give you entertainment in solitude by the practice, and reputation in public by the effect.
Nunc animis opus, Ænea, nunc pectore firmo
Nunc aut nunquam
Nunc dimittis
Nunc est bibendum, nunc pede libero, / Pulsanda tellus!
Nunc patimur longæ pacis mala; sævior armis / Luxuria incubuit, victumque ulciscitur orbem
Nunc positis novus exuviis nitidusque juventa
Nunc vino pellite curas!
Nunquam aliud natura, aliud sapientia dicit
Nunquam erit alienis gravis, qui suis se concinnat levem
Nunquam est fidelis cum potente societas
Nunquam libertas gratior extat / Quam sub
rege pio
Nunquam nimis dicitur, quod nunquam satis discitur
Nunquam non paratus
Nunquam retrorsum
Nunquam se plus agere, quam nihil quum ageret; nunquam minus solum esse, quam quum solus esset
Nunquam vir æquus dives evasit cito
Nuptial love maketh mankind; friendly love perfecteth it; but wanton love corrupteth and embaseth it.
Nur aus vollendeter Kraft blicket die Anmuth hervor
Nur das Gemeine / Verkennt man selten. Und
das Seltene / Vergisst man schwerlich
Nur das Leben hasst, der Tod versöhnt
Nur das zu thun, was alle wollen, / Ist das Geheimniss jeder Macht
Nur dem Fröhlichen blüht der Baum des Lebens, / Dem Unschuldigen rinnt der Born der Jugend / Auch noch im Alter
Nur dem vertrau' ich völlig, nur der imponirt nachhaltig, der über sich zu lächeln fähig ist
Nur der Freundschaft Harmonie / Mildert die
Beschwerden; / Ohne ihre Sympathie / Ist kein Glück auf Erden
Nur der Glaube aller stärkt den Glauben, / Wo Tausende anbeten und verehren, / Da wird die Glut zur Flamme, und beflügelt / Schwingt sich der Geist in alle Himmel auf
Nur der Irrthum ist das Leben, / Und das Wissen ist der Tod
Nur der Irrthum ist unser Teil, und Wahn ist unsre Wissenschaft
Nur der ist wahrhaft arm, der weder Geist noch Kraft hat
Nur der Starke wird das Schicksal zwingen, /
Wenn der Schwächling untersinkt
Nur die Hoffenden leben
Nur die Lumpe sind bescheiden, / Brave freuen sich der That
Nur eine Mutter weiss allein, / Was lieben heisst und glücklich sein
Nur eine Schmach weiss ich auf dieser Erde. / Und die heisst: Unrecht thun
Nur eine Weisheit führt zum Ziele, / Doch
ihrer Sprüche giebt es viele
Nur Helios vermag's zu sagen, / Der alles Irdische bescheint
Nur immer zu! wir wollen es ergründen, / In deinem Nichts hoff' ich das All zu finden
Nur in der eignen Kraft ruht das Schicksal jeder Nation
Nur in der Schule selbst ist die eigentliche Vorschule
Nur in schwülen Prüfungsstunden / Sprosst
die Palme, die den Sieger krönt
Nur in Träumen wohnt das Glück der Erde
Nur Liebe darf der Liebe Blume brechen
Nur stets zu sprechen, ohne was zu sagen, / Das war von je der Redner grösste Gabe
Nur vom Edeln kann das Edle stammen
Nur vom Nutzen wird die Welt regiert
Nur was wir selber glauben, glaubt man uns
Nur wer die Last wirklich selbst trägt, kennt ihr Gewicht
Nur wer die Sehnsucht kennt / Weiss, was ich leide!
Nur wer sich recht des Lebens freut, / Trägt leichter, was es Schlimmes beut
Nur wer vor Gott sich fühlet klein / Kann vor
den Menschen mächtig sein
Nur zwei Tugenden giebt's. O, wären sie immer vereinigt, / Immer die Güte auch gross, immer die Grösse auch gut!
Nursing her wrath to keep it warm.
Nusquam tuta fides
Nutrimentum spiritus
Nutritur vento, vento restinguitur ignis: / Lenis alit flammas, grandior aura necat!
Nuts are given us, but we must crack them ourselves.
Nymph, in thy orisons / Be all my sins remembered.
O banish the tears of children! Continual rains upon the blossoms are hurtful.
O bitte um Leben noch! du fühlst, mit deinen
Mängeln, / Dass du noch wandeln kannst nicht unter Gottes Engeln
O blicke nicht nach dem was jedem fehlt; / Betrachte, was noch einem jeden bleibt
O cæca nocentum / Consilia, O semper timidum scelus!
O cives, cives, quærenda pecunia primum est; /
Virtus post nummos
O Corydon, Corydon, secretum divitis ullum / Esse putas? Servi ut taceant, jumenta loquentur, / Et canis, et postes, et marmora
O cunning enemy, that, to catch a saint, / With saints dost bait thy hook.
O curvæ in terris animæ et cœlestium inanes!
O das Leben hat Reize, die wir nie gekannt
O das Leben ist ein langer, langer Seufzer
vor dem Ausgehen des Athmens
O dass die Weisheit halb so eifrig wäre / Nach Schülern und Bekehrten, als der Spott
O dass es ewig bliebe, / Das Doppelglück der Töne wie der Liebe
O dass sie ewig' grünen bliebe / Die schöne Zeit der jungen Liebe
O dearest, dearest boy, my heart / For better love would seldom yearn, / Could I but teach the hundredth part / Of what from thee I learn.
O der Magnet des Wahns zieht mächtig
O ein Fürst hat keinen Freund, kann keinen Freund haben
O faciles dare summa Deos, eademque tueri / Difficiles
O fallacem hominum spem
O flesh, flesh, how thou art fishified.
O formose puer, nimium ne crede colori
O fortunate adolescens, qui tuæ virtutis Homerum præconem inveneris
O fortunatos nimium, sua si bona norint, / Agricolas, quibus ipsa, procul discordibus armis, / Fundit humo facilem victum justissima tellus
O foulest Circæan draught! thou poison of popular applause; madness is in thee, and death; thy end is bedlam and the grave.
O glücklich! wer noch hoffen kann, / Aus diesem Meer des Irrtums aufzutauchen. / Was man nicht weiss, das eben brauchte man, / Und was man weiss, kann man nicht brauchen
O God, that bread should be so dear, / And
flesh and blood so cheap!
O Gott! das Leben ist doch schön
O Gott, wie schränkt sich Welt und Himmel ein, / Wenn unser Herz in seinen Schranken banget
O guard thy roving thoughts with jealous care, for speech is but the dial-plate of thought; and every fool reads plainly in thy words what is the hour of thy thought.
O' guid advisement comes nae ill.
O Heaven! were man / But constant, he were
perfect; that one error / Fills him with faults; makes him run through all sins.
O Herz, versuch' es nur! so leicht ist's gut zu sein: / Und es zu scheinen ist so eine schwere Pein
O homines ad servitutem paratos!
O how full of briars is this working-day world.
O how wretched / Is that poor man that hangs on princes' favours! / There is betwixt that smile he would aspire to, / That sweet aspect of princes, and their ruin, / More pangs and fears than wars or women have; / And when he falls, he falls like Lucifer, / Never to hope again.
O hush the noise, ye men of strife, / And hear the angels sing!
O, if this were seen, / The happiest youth--viewing his progress through / What perils past, what crosses to ensue--/ Would shut the book and sit him down and die.
O ja, dem Herrn ist alles Kinderspiel
O judgment, thou art fled to brutish beasts, / And men have lost their reason!
O kaum bezwingen wir das eigne Herz; / Wie soll die rasche Jugend sich bezähmen!
