O l'amour d'une mère! amour que nul n'oublie! / Pain merveilleux, que Dieu partage et multiplie! / Table toujours servie au paternel foyer! / Chacun en a sa part, et tous l'ont tout entier
O Leben, wie bist du so bitter und hart
O let my books be then the eloquence / And
dumb presagers of my speaking breast.
O let thy vow, / First made to heaven, first be to heaven perform'd.... It is religion that doth make vows kept.
"O Liberty, what crimes have been committed in thy name!"
O Life, an age to the miserable, a moment to the happy.
O life! how pleasant is thy morning, / Young Fancy's rays the hills adorning! / Cold-pausing Caution's lessons scorning, / We frisk away, / Like schoolboys at th' expected warning, / To joy and play.
O life! thou art a galling load / Along a rough,
a weary road, / To wretches such as I!
O Lord, that lend'st me life, / Lend me a heart replete with thankfulness!
O love, be moderate, allay thy ecstasy; / In measure rain thy joy; scant this excess; / I feel too much thy blessing! Make it less, / For fear I surfeit.
O magna vis veritatis, quæ ... facile se per se ipsa defendit
O major tandem, parcas, insane, minori
O mighty Cæsar! dost thou lie so low? / Are all thy conquests, glories, triumphs, spoils, / Shrunk to this little measure?
O mihi præteritos referat si Jupiter annos!
O miseras hominum mentes! O pectora cæca!
O miseri quorum gaudia crimen habent!
O most lame and impotent conclusion!
O munera nondum / Intellecta Deum
O my prophetic soul! mine uncle.
O Nature! Ha! why do I not name thee God? Art thou not the "living garment of God?" O Heavens! is it, in very deed, He then that ever speaks through thee; that lives and loves in thee, that lives and loves in me?
O never / Shall sun that morrow see.
O nimium nimiumque oblite tuorum
O nimm der Stunde wahr, eh' sie entschlüpft. / So selten kommt der Augenblick im Leben / Der wahrhaft wichtig ist und gross
O noctes cœnæque deum!
O passi graviora!
O place and greatness, millions of false eyes / Are stuck upon thee! Volumes of report / Run with these false and most contrarious quests / Upon thy doings! thousand scapes of wit / Make thee the father of their idle dreams, / And rack thee in their fancies.
O pudor! O pietas!
O purblind race of miserable men! / How many among us at this very hour / Do forge a lifelong trouble for ourselves, / By taking true for false, or false for true; / Here, thro' the feeble twilight of this world / Groping, how many, until we pass and reach / That other, where we see as we are seen!
O qualis facies et quali digna tabella!
O quanta species cerebrum non habet!
O quantum in rebus inane!
O ruin'd piece of nature! This great world / Shall so wear out to nought.
O rus quando te aspiciam? quandoque licebit / Nunc veterum libris, nunc somno et inertibus horis / Ducere sollicitæ jucunda oblivia vitæ?
O sancta damnatio!
O sancta simplicitas!
O si tacuisses, philosophus mansisses
O sleep, / It is a gentle thing, / Beloved from
pole to pole!
O sleep, O gentle sleep, / Nature's soft nurse! how have I frighted thee, / That thou no more wilt weigh my eyelids down, / And steep my senses in forgetfulness!
O sons of earth, attempt ye still to rise, / By mountains piled on mountains, to the skies? / Heav'n still with laughter the vain toil surveys, / And buries madmen in the heaps they raise.
O sprich mir nicht von jener bunten Menge / Bei deren Anblick uns der Geist entflieht
O süsse Stimme! Willkommener Ton / Der Muttersprach in einem fremden Lande!
O tempora, O mores!
O that estates, degrees, and offices / Were not derived corruptly, and that clear honour / Were purchased by the merit of the wearer! / How many then would cover that stand bare; / How many be commanded that command; / How much low peasantry would then be glean'd / From the true seed of honour; and how much honour, / Pick'd from the chaff and ruin of the times, / To be new-varnish'd.
O that men's ears should be / To counsel deaf, but not to flattery!
O that way madness lies.
O that you could turn your eyes toward the napes of your necks, and make but an interior survey of your good selves!
O the depth of the riches both of the wisdom
and knowledge of God! How unsearchable are His judgments, and His ways past finding out!
O the wound of conscience is no scar, and Time cools it not with his wing, but merely keeps it open with his scythe.
O these deliberate fools, when they do choose / They have the wisdom by their wit to lose.
O these naughty times / Put bars between the owners and their rights.
O Thor, wer nicht im Augenblick den wahren Augenblick ergreift, / Wer, was er liebt, im Auge, und dennoch nach der Seite schweift
O Thou, / Passionless bride, divine Tranquillity,
/ ... Thou carest not / How roughly men may woo thee, so they win!
O thou who hast still a father and a mother, thank God for it in the day when thy soul is full of joyful tears, and needs a bosom wherein to shed them.
O thoughts of men accurst! / Past and to come seem best; things present, worst.
O Tugend, Tugend, wie schön bist du! / Welch' göttlich Meisterstück sind Seelen, / Die sich hinauf bis zu dir erheben
O wad some pow'r the giftie gie us / To see oursels as others see us! / It wad frae mony a blunder free us, / And foolish notion; / What airs in dress and gait wad lea'e us, / And e'en devotion!
O Wahrheit, deinen edeln Wein / Musst du
mit Wasser mischen; / Denn willst du ihn rein auftischen, / So nimmt er den Kopf den Gästen ein
O was im Traum die innre Stimme spricht / Das wird uns Wahrheit, wenn die Sonne leuchtet
O was müssen wir der Kirche Gottes halber leiden, rief der Abt, als ihm das gebratene Huhn die Finger versengte
O was sind wir Grossen auf der Woge der Menschheit? Wir glauben sie zu beherrschen, und sie treibt uns auf und nieder, hin und her
O well for him whose will is strong! / He suffers, but he will not suffer long; / He suffers, but he cannot suffer wrong.
O wer weiss, / Was in der Zeiten Hintergrunde
schlummert?
O what a goodly outside falsehood hath!
O what a noble mind is here o'erthrown! / The courtier's, soldier's, scholar's eye, tongue, sword; / The expectancy and rose of the fair state, / The glass of fashion, and the mould of form, / The observed of all observers, quite, quite down!
O what a tangled web we weave / When first we practise to deceive.
O what a world is this, when what is comely / Envenoms him that bears it!
O what a world of vile ill-favoured faults /
Looks handsome in three hundred pounds a-year!
O what men dare do! what men may do! / What men daily do, not knowing what they do!
O woman! in our hours of ease / Uncertain, coy, and hard to please, / And variable as the shade / By the light of quivering aspen made; / When pain and anguish wring the brow, / A ministering angel thou.
O ye loved ones, that already sleep in the noiseless Bed of Rest, whom in life I could only weep for and never help; and ye who, wide-scattered, still toil lonely in the monster-bearing desert, dyeing the flinty ground with your blood,--yet a little while, and we shall all meet There, and our Mother's bosom will screen us all; and Oppression's harness, and Sorrow's fire-whip, and all the Gehenna bailiffs that patrol and inhabit ever-vexed Time, cannot thenceforth harm us any more.
O yet we trust that somehow good / Will be the final goal of ill.
Oaks fall when reeds stand.
Oars alone can ne'er prevail / To reach the
distant coast; / The breath of heav'n must swell the sail, / Or all the toil is lost.
Oaths are straws, ... and holdfast is the only dog.
Ob es vom Herzen kommt, das magst du leicht verstehen: / Denn was vom Herzen kommt, muss dir zum Herzen gehen
Obedience alone gives the right to command.
Obedience is better than sacrifice.
Obedience is our universal duty and destiny;
wherein whoso will not bend must break.
Obedience is the bond of rule.
Obedience is woman's duty on earth; hard endurance is her heavy lot; by severe service she must be purified; but she who has served here is great up yonder.
Obey something, and you will have a chance of finding out what is best to obey. But if you begin by obeying nothing, you will end by obeying Beelzebub and all his seven invited friends.
Obey thy parents; keep thy word justly; swear not; set not thy sweet heart on proud array.
Obiter cantare
Obiter dicta
Obiter dictum
Objects close to the eye shut out much larger objects on the horizon; and splendours born only of the earth eclipse the stars. So a man sometimes covers up the entire disc of eternity with a dollar, and quenches transcendent glories with a little shining dust.
Objects imperfectly discerned take forms from the hope or fear of the beholder.
Objects in pictures should be so arranged as
by their very position to tell their own story.
Oblatam occasionem tene
Obligation is thraldom, and thraldom is hateful.
Oblivion is the dark page whereon memory writes her light-beam characters and makes them legible; were it all light, nothing could be read there, any more than if it were all darkness.
Oblivion is the rule, and fame the exception, of humanity.
Oblivion is the second death, which great
minds dread more than the first.
Obreros a no ver dineros a perder
Obruat illud male partum, male retentum, male gestum imperium
Obscuris vera involvens
Obscurity and affectation are the two great faults of style.
Obscurity and Innocence, twin-sisters, escape
temptations which would pierce their gossamer armour in contact with the world.
Obscurum per obscurius
Obsequium amicos, veritas odium parit
Observe this short but certain aphorism, "Forsake all, and thou shalt find all."
Observe thyself as thy greatest enemy would do; so shalt thou be thy greatest friend.
Observation is an old man's memory.
Observation may trip now and then without throwing you, for her gait is a walk; but inference always gallops, and if she stumbles, you are gone.
Observation more than books, experience rather than persons, are the prime educators.
Obstinacy and heat in argument are surest proofs of folly.
Obstinacy is ever most positive when it is most in the wrong.
Obstinacy is the result of the will's forcing
itself into the place of the intellect.
Obstinacy is the strength of the weak.
Obstupui, steteruntque comæ, et vox faucibus hæsit
Obtuseness is sometimes a virtue.
Occasio facit furem
Occasion reins the motions of the stirring
mind.
Occasionem cognosce
Occasions do not make a man frail, but they show what he is.
Occidit miseros crambe repetita magistros
Occupation is the scythe of Time.
Occupet extremum scabies!
Ocean is a mighty harmonist.
Oculi tanquam speculatores altissimum locum obtinent
Oculis magis habenda fides quam auribus
Oculus domini saginat equum
Oderint dum metuant
Oderunt hilarem tristes, tristemque jocosi, /
Sedatum celeres, agilem gnavumque remissi
Oderunt peccare boni virtutis amore
Odi profanum vulgus et arceo
Odi puerulos præcoci ingenio
Odi, vedi, e taci, se vuoi viver in pace
Odia qui nimium timet, regnare nescit
Odimus accipitrem quia semper vivit in armis
Odium theologicum
Odora canum vis
O'ercome thyself, and thou may'st share / With Christ His Father's throne, and wear / The world's imperial wreath.
Of a life of luxury the fruit is luxury.
Of a thoroughly crazy and defective artist we may indeed say he has everything from himself; but of an excellent one, never.
Of all actions of a man's life, his marriage does least concern other people; yet of all actions of our life, 'tis most meddled with by other people.
Of all attainable liberties, be sure first to strive for leave to be useful.
Of all blinds that shut up men's vision the worst is self.
Of all days, the one that is most wasted is that
on which one has not laughed.
Of all earthly music, that which reaches the farthest into heaven is the beating of a loving heart.
Of all evils in story-telling, the humour of telling tales one after another in great numbers is the least supportable.
Of all God's gifts to the sight of man, colour is the holiest, the most divine, the most solemn.
Of all great poems Love is the absolute and the essential foundation.
Of all man's work of art, a cathedral is greatest.
A vast and majestic tree is greater than that.
Of all men, a philosopher should be no swearer; for an oath, which is the end of controversies in law, cannot determine any here, where reason only must induce.
Of all plagues, good Heaven, thy wrath can send, / Save, save, O save me from the candid friend!
Of all pleasures, the fruit of labour is the sweetest.
Of all points of faith the being of a God is encompassed with most difficulty, and yet borne in upon our minds with most power.
Of all rights of man, the right of the ignorant
man to be guided by the wiser, to be gently or forcibly held in the true course by him, is the indisputablest.
Of all studies, study your present condition.
Of all the cants which are canted in this canting world,--though the cant of hypocrites may be the worst,--the cant of criticism is the most tormenting!
Of all the characters of cruelty, I consider that as the most odious which assumes the garb of mercy.
Of all the great masters, there is not one who did not paint his own present world, plainly and truly.
Of all the marvellous works of the Deity, perhaps
there is nothing that angels behold with such supreme astonishment as a proud man.
Of all the passions that possess mankind, / The love of novelty rules most the mind; / In search of this, from realm to realm we roam, / Our fleets come fraught with every folly home.
Of all the possessions of a man, next to the gods, his soul is the mightiest, being the most his own.
Of all the pulpits from which human voice is ever sent forth, there is none from which it reaches so far as from the grave.
Of all the superstitions which infest the brains of weak mortals, the belief in prophecies, presentiments, and dreams, seems to me amongst the most pitiful and pernicious.
Of all the tyrants that the world affords, / Our
own affections are the fiercest lords.
Of all thieves, fools are the worst; they rob you of time and temper.
Of all things, knowledge is esteemed the most precious treasure; because of its incapacity to be stolen, to be given away, or even to be consumed.
Of all those arts in which the wise excel, / Nature's chief masterpiece is writing well.
Of all wild beasts, preserve me from a tyrant; and of all tame, a flatterer.
Of big words and feathers many go to the
pound.
Of error we can talk for ever, but truth demands that we should lay it to heart and apply it.
Of four things every man has more than he knows--of sins, and debts, and years, and foes.
Of God's light I was not utterly bereft, if my as yet sealed eyes, with their unspeakable longing, could nowhere see Him; nevertheless in my heart He was present and His heaven-written law still stood legible and sacred there.
Of great men no one should speak but one who is as great as they, so as to be able to see all round them.
Of great riches there is no real use, except it be in the distribution; the rest is but conceit.
Of hasty counsel take good heed, for very rarely haste is speed.
Of how few lives does not stated duty claim the greater part?
Of illustrious men all the earth is the sepulchre,
and it is not the inscribed column in their own land which is the record of their virtues, but the unwritten memory of them in the hearts and minds of all mankind.
Of its own unity, the soul gives unity to whatso it looks on with love.
Of making many books there is no end; and much study is a weariness of the flesh.
Of more than earth can earth make none possesst; / And he that least / Regards this restless world, shall in this world find rest.
Of other tyrants short the strife, / But Indolence is king for life: / The despot twists, with soft control, / Eternal fetters round the soul.
Of pleasures, those which occur most rarely
give the greatest delight.
Of real evils the number is great; of possible evils there is no end.
Of the Beautiful we are seldom capable, oftener of the Good; and how highly should we value those who endeavour, with great sacrifices, to forward that good among their fellows!
Of the eyes that men do glare withal, so few can see.
Of the soul, the body form doth take, / For soul is form, and doth the body make.
Of the three requisitions of genius, the first
is soul; the second, soul; and the third, soul.
Of the wealth of the world each has as much as he takes.
Of the Wrong we are always conscious, of the Right never.
Of thorns men do not gather figs, nor of a bramble bush gather they grapes.
Of thy word unspoken thou art master; thy spoken word is master of thee.
Of two evils choose the least.
Of unwise admiration much may be hoped, for much good is really in it; but unwise contempt is itself a negation; nothing comes of it, for it is nothing.
Of what does not concern you say nothing, good or bad.
Of what significance are the things you can forget?
Of wild creatures, a tyrant; and of tame ones, a flatterer.
Off with his head! so much for Buckingham.
Offenders never pardon.
Offerir molto è spezie di negare
Oft have I heard, and now believe it true, / Whom man delights in, God delights in too.
Oft kommt ein nützlich Wort aus schlechtem Munde
Oft leiden kranke Seelen durch selbstgeschaffnen
Wahn
Oft schiessen trifft das Ziel
Oft sogar es ist weise, zu entdecken, / Was nicht verschwiegen bleiben kann
Oft when blind mortals think themselves secure, in height of bliss, they touch the brink of ruin.
Oft zum Dichter macht die Liebe; / Selbst ein Wunder, zeugt sie Wunder
Ofte er Skarlagens Hierte under reven Kaabe
Often a man's own angry pride / Is cap-and-bells for a fool.
Often the cock-loft is empty in those whom Nature hath built many storeys high.
Oftentimes the gods send strong delusions to ensnare too credulous hearts.
Oftentimes, to win us to our harm, / The instruments of darkness tell us truths; / Win us with honest trifles, to betray us / In deepest consequence.
Ofttimes nothing profits more / Than self-esteem,
grounded on just and right.
Ofttimes the pupil goes beyond his master.
Ogni cosa è d'ogni anno
Ogni debole ha sempre il suo tiranno
Ogni medaglio ha il suo riverso
Ogni monte ha la sua valle
Ogni vero non è buono a dire
Ognuno vede quel che tu pari, pochi sentono quel che tu sei
Oh, be he king or peasant, he is happiest / Who in his home finds peace.
Oh, call my brother back to me! / I cannot play alone; / The summer comes with flower and bee,--/ Where is my brother gone?
Oh, Death! the poor man's dearest friend--/
The kindest and the best! / Welcome the hour my aged limbs / Are laid with thee at rest! / The great, the wealthy fear thy blow, / From pomp and pleasure torn! But oh! a bless'd relief to those / That weary-laden mourn!
Oh, for a lodge in some vast wilderness, / Some boundless contiguity of shade, / Where rumour of oppression and deceit, / Of unsuccessful or successful war, / May never reach me more.
Oh, ... for a man with heart, head, hand. / ... Whatever they call him, what care I, / Aristocrat, democrat, autocrat--one / Who can rule and dare not lie!
Oh, how sweet it is to hear our own conviction from another's lips!
Oh, it is excellent / To have a giant's strength, but it is tyrannous / To use it like a giant.
Oh! Kritisieren, lieber Herr, ist federleicht, / Doch Bessermachen schwierig
Oh, love for ever lost, / And with it faith gone out! what is't remains / But duty, though the path be rough and trod / By bruised and bleeding feet?
Oh, Love, how perfect is thy mystic art, /
Strengthening the weak, and trampling on the strong!
Oh, Love! no habitant of earth thou art--/ An unseen seraph, we believe in thee.
Oh, no! we never mention her; / Her name is never heard; / My lips are now forbid to speak / That once familiar word.
Oh, nostra folle / Mente, ch'ogn aura di fortuna estolle
Oh, that mine adversary had written a book.
Oh, that my lot might lead me in the path of
holy purity of thought and deed, the path which august laws ordain--laws which in the highest heaven had their birth; ... The power of God is mighty in them, and doth not wax old.
Oh, that this too too solid flesh would melt, / Thaw and resolve itself into a dew! / Or that the Everlasting had not fix'd / His canon 'gainst self-slaughter.
Oh! the dulness and the hardness of the heart of man, which contemplates only the present, and does not rather provide for the future.
Oh, the heart is a free and a fetterless thing-- / A wave of the ocean, a bird on the wing.
Oh, there is something in marriage like the veil of the temple of old, / That screened the Holy of Holies with blue and purple and gold; / Something that makes a chamber where none but the one may come, / A sacredness too, and a silence, where joy that is deepest is dumb.
Oh, were I seated high as my ambition, / I'd
place this naked foot on necks of monarchs.
Oh, what a fall was there, my countrymen! / Then I, and you, and all of us fell down, / Whilst bloody treason flourish'd over us.
Oh, what damned minutes tells he o'er, / Who dotes, yet doubts; suspects, yet soundly loves.
Oh, what is death but parting breath? / On mony a bloody plain / I've dared his face, and in this place / I scorn him yet again.
Oh, whistle and I'll come to ye, my lad.
Oh, woman, lovely woman! Heaven designed
you / To temper man! We had been brutes without you.
Oh, worse than all! Oh, pang all pangs above, / Is kindness counterfeiting absent love!
Oh, would they stay aback frae courts, / And please themsels wi' country sports, / It wad for every ane be better, / The laird, the tenant, and the cottar.
Ohe! jam satis est
Ohne Begeisterung schlafen die besten Kräfte des Gemüths. Es ist ein Zunder in uns, der Funken will

Ohne dich, Hellas, was wäre die Welt?

Ohne Haut

Ohne Wissen, ohne Sünde
Oil, wine, and friends improve by age.
Old age comes on suddenly, and not gradually, as is thought.
Old age, especially an honoured old age, has so great authority, that it is of more value than all the pleasures of youth.
Old age is a heavy burden.
Old age is a tyrant, who forbids, under pain of death, the pleasures of youth.
Old age is honourable.
Old age is not in itself matter for sorrow. It is matter for thanks if we have left our work done behind us.
Old age is sad
Old age is the repose of life, the rest which precedes
the rest that remains.
Old age is wise for itself, but not wise for the community.
Old age--the words are comparative, not positive.
Old age, though despised, is coveted by all.
Old age was naturally more honoured in times when people could not know much more than they had seen.
Old birds are hard to pluck.
Old birds are not caught with chaff.
Old books, as you well know, are books of the world's youth, and new books are fruits of its age.
Old-fashioned poetry, but choicely good.
Old friends are best.
Old friends burn dim, like lamps in noisome
air; / Love them for what they are; nor love them less; / Because to thee they are not what they were.
Old head and young hand.
Old head upon young shoulders.
Old heads will not suit young shoulders.
Old houses mended / Cost little less than new before they're ended.
Old long-vexed questions, not yet solved in
logical words or parliamentary laws, are fast solving themselves in facts, somewhat unblessed to behold.
Old men are twice children.
Old men lose one of the most precious rights of man, that of being judged by their peers.
Old men should have more care to end life well than to live long.
Old men's lives are lengthened shadows; their evening sun falls coldly on the earth, but the shadows all point to the morning.
Old minds are like old horses; you must exercise
them if you wish to keep them in working order.
Old ovens are soon heated.
Old oxen have stiff horns.
Old shoes are easiest.
Old signs do not deceive.
Old wood to burn, old books to read, old wine
to drink, and old friends to converse with.
Old wounds soon bleed.

Oleum adde camino

Olla male fervet
Olim meminisse juvabit
Oliver Cromwell, dead two hundred years ago, does yet speak; nay, perhaps, now first begins to speak.
Omina sunt aliquid
Omne actum ab agentis intentione judicandum
Omne ævum curæ: cunctis sua displicet ætas
Omne animal seipsum diligit

omne corpus mortale sit
Omne epigramma sit instar apis, aculeus illi, / Sint sua mella, sit et corporis exigui
Omne in præcipiti vitium stetit
Omne malum nascens facile opprimitur: inveteratum fit plerumque robustius
Omne nimium vertitur in vitium
Omne scibile
Omne solum forti patria est
Omne tulit punctum qui miscuit utile dulci / Lectorem delectando, pariterque monendo
Omnem crede diem tibi diluxisse supremum
Omnem movere lapidem
Omnes amicos habere operosum est; satis est
inimicos non habere
Omnes composui
Omnes eodem cogimur; omnium / Versatur urna serius, ocius, / Sors exitura, et nos in æternum / exsilium impositura cymbæ
Omnes homines, qui de rebus dubiis consultant, ab odio, amicitia, ira, atque misericordia vacuos esse decet
Omnes omnium caritates patria una complectitur
Omnes, quibus res sunt minus secundæ, magis sunt, nescio quomodo / Suspiciosi: ad contumeliam omnia accipiunt magis; / Propter suam impotentiam se credunt negligi
Omnes sapientes decet conferre et fabulari
Omnes una manet nox, / Et calcanda semel via lethi
Omni ætati mors est communis
Omnia bonos viros decent
Omnia conando docilis solertia vincit
Omnia cum amico delibera, sed de te ipso prius
Omnia desuper
Omnia ejusdem farinæ
Omnia fert ætas, animum quoque
Omnia Græce! / Cum sit turpe magis nostris nescire Latine
Omnia inconsulti impetus cœpta, initiis valida, spatio languescunt
Omnia jam fient, fieri quæ posse negabam: / Et nihil est de quo non sit habenda fides
Omnia mala exempla bonis principiis orta sunt
Omnia mea mecum porto
Omnia mutantur, nihil interit
Omnia mutantur, nos et mutamur in illis
Omnia non pariter rerum sunt omnibus apta
Omnia orta occident
Omnia perdidimus, tantummodo vita relicta est
Omnia perversas possunt corrumpere mentes
Omnia præclara rara
Omnia præsumuntur rite et solenniter esse acta
Omnia prius experiri, quam armis, sapientem
decet
Omnia profecto, cum se a cœlestibus rebus referet ad humanas, excelsius magnificentiusque et dicet et sentiet
Omnia quæ nunc vetustissima creduntur, nova fuere ... et quod hodie exemplis tuemur, inter exempla erit
Omnia rerum principia parva sunt
Omnia Romæ / Cum pretio
Omnia serviliter pro dominatione
Omnia subjecisti sub pedibus, oves et boves
Omnia sunt hominum tenui pendentia filo; / Et subito casu, quæ valuere, ruunt
Omnia tuta timens
Omnia venalia Romæ
Omnia vincit amor, nos et cedamus amori
Omnibus bonis expedit rempublicam esse salvam
Omnibus hoc vitium est cantoribus, inter amicos / Ut nunquam inducant animum cantare rogati, / Injussi nunquam desistant
Omnibus hostes / Reddite nos populis, civile avertite bellum
Omnibus in terris, quæ sunt a Gadibus usque / Auroram et Gangem, pauci dignoscere possunt / Vera bona, atque illis multum diversa, remota / Erroris nebula
Omnibus modis, qui pauperes sunt homines,
miseri vivunt; / Præsertim quibus nec quæstus est, nec didicere artem ullam
Omnis ars imitatio est naturæ
Omnis commoditas sua fert incommoda secum
Omnis dolor aut est vehemens, aut levis; si levis, facile fertur, si vehemens, certe brevis futurus est
Omnis enim res / Virtus, fama, decus, divina humanaque pulchris / Divitiis parent; quas qui construxerit, ille / Clarus erit, fortis, justus
Omnis pœna corporalis, quamvis minima, major est omni pœna pecuniaria, quamvis maxima
Omnis stultitia laborat fastidio sui
Omnium consensu capax imperii, nisi imperasset
Omnium horarum homo
Omnium rerum, ex quibus aliquid acquiritur, nihil est agricultura melius, nihil uberius, nihil dulcius, nihil homine libero dignius
Omnium rerum, heus, vicissitudo est
On a beau prêcher à qui n'a cure de bien faire
On a long journey even a straw is heavy.
On a souvent besoin d'un plus petit que soi
On a winged word hath hung the destiny of nations.
On affaiblit toujours tout ce qu'on exagère
On aime bien à deviner les autres, mais l'on
aime pas à être deviné
On aime sans raison, et sans raison l'on hait
On apprend en faillant
On attrape plus de mouches avec du miel qu'avec du vinaigre
On avale à pleine gorgée le mensonge qui nous flatte, et l'on boit goute à goute une vérité qui nous est amère

fripon
On connaît les amis au besoin
On devient innocent quand on est malheureux
On dit
On dit de gueux qu'ils ne sont jamais dans leur chemins, parce qu'ils n'ont point de demeure fixe. Il en est de même de cause qui disputent, sans avoir des notions déterminées
On dit, est souvent un grand menteur
On dit, et sans horreur je ne puis le redire
On dit que Dieu est toujours pour les gros bataillons
On doit être heureux sans trop penser à l'être
On doit des égards aux vivants; on ne doit aux morts que la vérité
On donne des conseils, mais on ne donne point
la sagesse d'en profiter
On eagles' wings immortal scandals fly, / While virtuous actions are but born to die.
On entre et on crie, / Et voilà la vie! / On crie et on sort, / Et voilà la mort!
On est aisément dupé par ce qu'on aime
On est, quand on le veut, le maître de son sort
On every stage the foes of peace attend /
Hate dogs their flight, and insult mocks their end.
On every thorn delightful wisdom grows; / In every rill a sweet instruction flows.
On fait souvent tort à la vérité par la manière dont on se sert pour la défendre
On fait toujours le loup plus gros qu'il n'est
On gagne peu de choses par habileté
On God and godlike men we build our trust.
On his own saddle one rides safest.
On jette enfin de la terre sur la tête, et en voilà pour jamais
On life's vast ocean diversely we sail, / Reason the card, but passion is the gale.
On Monday morning don't be looking for Saturday night.
On n'a jamais bon marché de mauvaise marchandise
On n'a rien pour rien
On n'aime plus comme on aimait jadis
On n'auroit guère de plaisir, si l'on ne se flattoit point
On n'est jamais si bien servi que par soi-même
On n'est jamais si heureux, ni si malheureux
qu'on se l'imagine
On n'est jamais si riche que quand on déménage
On n'est jamais si ridicule par les qualités que l'on a que par celles que l'on affecte d'avoir
On n'est jamais trahi que par ses siens
On n'est souvent mécontent des autres que parce qu'on l'est de soi-même
On ne considère pas assez les paroles comme
des faits
On ne cherche point à prouver la lumière
On ne doit pas juger du mérite d'un homme par ses grandes qualités, mais par l'usage qu'il en sait faire
On ne donne rien si libéralement que ses conseils
On ne gouverne les hommes que en les servant; la règle est sans exception
On ne jette des pierres qu'à l'arbre chargé de
fruits
On ne loue d'ordinaire que pour être loué
On ne lui fait pas prendre des vessies pour des lanternes
On ne méprise pas tous ceux qui ont des vices, mais on méprise tous ceux qui n'ont aucune vertu
On ne perd les états que par timidité
On ne peut contenter tout le monde et son
père
On ne peut faire qu'en faisant
On ne peut sonner les cloches et aller à la procession
On ne prête qu'aux riches
On ne ramène guère un traître par l'impunité, au lieu que par la punition l'on en rend mille autres sages
On ne réussit dans ce monde qu'à la pointe de
l'épée, et on meurt les armes à la main
On ne sait pour qui on amasse
On ne se blame que pour être loué
On ne sent bien que ses propres maux
On ne trouve jamais l'expression d'un sentiment que l'on n'a pas; l'esprit grimace et le style aussi
On ne va jamais si loin que lorsqu'on ne sait
pas où l'on va
On ne vaut dans ce monde que ce qu'on veut valoir
On ne vit dans la mémoire du monde que par des travaux pour le monde
On pardonne aisément un tort que l'on partage
On parle peu quand la vanité ne fait pas parler
On perd tout le temps qu'on peut mieux employer
On peut attirer les cœurs par les qualités qu'on montre, mais on ne les fixe que par celles qu'on a
On peut dire que son esprit brille aux dépens de sa mémoire
On peut dominer par la force, mais jamais par la seule adresse
On peut être plus fin qu'un autre, mais non
pas plus fin que tous les autres
On peut mépriser le monde, mais on ne peut pas s'en passer
On prend le peuple par les oreilles, comme on fait un pot par les anses
On prend son bien où on le trouve
On prend souvent l'indolence pour la patience
On Reason build Resolve! / That column of
true majesty in man.
On respecte un moulin, on vole une province!
On revient toujours à ses premiers amours
On se heurte toujours où l'on a mal
On se persuade mieux pour l'ordinaire par les raisons qu'on a trouvées soi-même, que par celles qui sont venues dans l'esprit des autres
On some men's bread butter will not stick.
On spécule sur tout, même sur la famine
On termine de longs procès / Par un peu de guerre civile
On the beaten road there is tolerable travelling; but it is sore work, and many have to perish, fashioning a way through the impassable.
On the brink of the waters of life and truth we are miserably dying.
On the day of the resurrection, those who
have indulged in ridicule will be called to the door of Paradise, and have it shut in their faces when they reach it.
On the field of foughten battle still, / Woe knows no limits save the victor's will.
On the neck of the young man sparkles no gem so gracious as enterprise.
On the pinnacle of fortune man does not stand long firm.
On the sea sail, on the land settle.
On the soft bed of luxury most kingdoms have
expired.
On the stage man should stand a step higher than in life.
On this account is the Bible a book of eternally effective power, because, as long as the world lasts, no one will step forward and say: I comprehend it in the whole and understand it in the particular; but we modestly say: In the whole it is venerable, and in the particular practicable
On veut avoir ce qu'on n'a pas, / Et ce qu'on a cesse de de plaire
On voit mourir et renaître les roses; il n'en est pas ainsi de nos beaux jours
On wrong / Swift vengeance waits; and art
subdues the strong.
Once a knave, always a knave.
Once a man and twice a child.
Once for all, beauty remains undemonstrable; it appears to us as in a dream, when we behold the works of the great poets and painters, and, in short, of all feeling artists.
Once is no custom.
Once is no rule.
Once resolved, the trouble is over.
Once sufficiently enforce the eighth commandment, the whole "rights of man" are well cared for; I know no better definition of the rights of man: "Thou shalt not steal; thou shalt not be stolen from." What a society were that! Plato's Republic, More's Utopia mere emblems of it.
Once thoroughly our own, knowledge ceases to give us pleasure.
Once to every man and nation comes the moment to decide, / In the strife of truth with falsehood, for the good or evil side.
Once true, still more twice true, in the life of
the spirit is always true.
Ond Gierning har Vidne i Barmen
Ondt bliver aldrig godt för halv værre kommer
One abides not long on the summit of fortune.
One, although not possessed of a mine of gold, may find the offspring of his own nature, that noble ardour, which hath for its object the accomplishment of the whole assemblage of virtues.
One always has time enough if one will apply
it well.
One and God make a majority.
One anecdote is worth a volume of biography.
One barking dog sets all the street a-barking.
One beats the bush, and another catches the bird.
One Bible I know, of whose plenary inspiration
doubt is not so much as possible; nay, with my own eyes I saw the God's hand writing it; whereof all other Bibles are but leaves, say, in picture-writing, to assist the weaker faculty.
One born on the glebe comes by habit to belong to it; the two grow together, and the fairest ties are spun from the union.
One can be very happy without demanding that others should agree with one.
One can bear to be rebuked, but not to be laughed at.
One can live in true freedom, and yet not be unbound.
One can live on little, but not on nothing.
One can never know at the first moment what may, at a future time, separate itself from the rough experience as true substance.
One cannot help doing a good office when it comes in one's way.
One cannot say that the rational is always beautiful; but the beautiful is always rational, or at least ought to be so.
One cannot speak the truth with false words.
One can't shoe a runaway horse.
One chick keeps a hen busy.
One cloud is enough to eclipse all the sun.
One could not commit a greater crime against public interests than to show indulgence to those who violate them.
One could not wish any man to fall into a fault; yet it is often precisely after a fault, or a crime even, that the morality which is in a man first unfolds itself, and what of strength he as a man possesses, now when all else is gone from him.
One could take down a book from a shelf ten times more wise and witty than almost any man's conversation.
One crime is everything; two, nothing.
One crow never pulls out another's eyes.
One crowded hour of glorious life / Is worth an age without a name.
One does not love the heaven's lightning
in the way of care
One dog can drive a flock of sheep.
One doth not know / How much an ill word may empoison liking.
One drop of hatred left in the cup of joy
turns the most blissful draught into poison.
One enemy is too many, and a hundred friends too few.
One enemy may do us more harm than a hundred friends can do us good.
One eye of the master does more than both his hands.
One eye-witness is better than ten hearsays.
One false move may lose the game.
One feels clearly that it is a kindly spirit which actually constitutes the human element in man.
One finds human nature everywhere great and little, beautiful and ugly.... Go on bravely working.
One fire burns out another's burning; / One pain is lessen'd by another's anguish.
One fool makes many.
One futile person, that maketh it his glory to
tell, will do more hurt than many that know it their duty to conceal.
One gets easier accustomed to a silken bed than to a sack of leaves.
One God, one law, one element, / And one far-off divine event, / To which the whole creation moves.
One good deed dying tongueless / Slaughters a thousand, waiting upon that.
One good head is better than a hundred strong hands.
One good mother is worth a hundred schoolmasters.
One good turn deserves another.
One good way I know of to find happiness is not by boring a hole to fit the plug.
One grain fills not a sack, but helps his fellows.
One hair of a woman draws more than a team of horses.
One half of the world knows not how the
other half lives.
One half of the world must sweat and groan that the other half may dream.
One half the world laughs at the other.
One hand full of money is more persuasive than two full of truth.
One hand washes another.
One hard word brings on another.
One head cannot hold all wisdom.
One hour in the execution of justice is worth seventy years of prayer.
One hour's sleep before midnight is worth two after.
One impulse from a vernal wood / May teach you more of man, / Of moral evil and of good, / Than all the sages can.
One is always making good use of one's time
when engaged with a subject that daily forces one to make advances in self-culture.
One is not a whit the happier when he attains what he has wished for.
One is scarcely sensible of fatigue whilst he marches to music.
One jeer seldom goeth forth but it bringeth back its equal.
One keep-clean is better than ten make-cleans.
One learns taciturnity best among those people
who have none, and loquacity among the taciturn.
One lie makes many.
One lie needs seven lies to wait upon it.
One life--a little gleam of time between two eternities.
One link broken, the whole chain is broken.
One loss brings another.
One man is born to money, and another to the purse.
One man makes a chair, and another man sits in it.
One man may lead a horse to the water, but twenty cannot make him drink.
One man may steal a horse more safely than another may look at him over a hedge.
One man receives crucifixion as the reward of
his villainy; another a regal crown.
One man that has a higher wisdom in him is not stronger than ten men, or than ten thousand, but than all men that have it not.
One man's eyes are spectacles to another to read his heart with.
One man's justice is another man's injustice; one man's beauty, another's ugliness; one man's wisdom, another's folly; as one beholds the same objects from a higher point.
One man's meat is another man's poison.
One man's opinion is no man's opinion.
One may forsake a person to save a family; one may desert a whole family for the sake of a village; and sacrifice a village for the safety of the community; but for one's self one may abandon the whole world.
One may give him a hundred instances from Holy Writ that he should not dispute; still, it is the character of a fool to make a disturbance without a cause.
One may make the house a palace of sham, or he can make it a home--a refuge.
One may often find as much thought on the reverse of a medal as in a canto of Spenser.
One may see that with half an eye.
One may smile, and smile, and be a villain.
One may summon his philosophy when he is beaten in battle, not till then.
One misfortune is the vigil of another.
One monster there is in this world: the idle man.
One mother is more venerable than a thousand fathers.
One murder made a villain; / Millions, a hero.
One must be careful in announcing great happiness.
One must be somebody in order to have an enemy. One must be a force before he can be resisted by another force.
One must be something in order to do something.
One must believe in simplicity, in what is simple, in what is originally productive, if one wants to go the right way. This, however, is not granted to every one; we are born in an artificial state, and it is far easier to make it more artificial still than to return to what is simple.
One must have lived greatly whose record
would bear the full light of day from its beginning to its close.
One must not look a gift horse in the mouth.
One must not swerve in one's self, not even a hair's breadth from the highest maxims of art and life; but in empiricism, in the movement of the day, I would rather allow what is mediocre to pass than mistake the good, or even find fault with it.
One must take a pleasure in the shell till one has the happiness to arrive at the kernel.
One must weigh men by avoirdupois weight, and not by the jeweller's scales.
One need only take a thing properly in hand
for it to be done.
One need only utter something that flatters indolence and conceit to be sure of plenty of adherents among commonplace people.
One never goes farther than when he does not know whither he is going.
One never needs his wit so much as when he argues with a fool.
One of the best rules in conversation is, never say a thing which any of the company can reasonably wish we had left unsaid.
One of the chief misfortunes of honest people
is that they are cowardly.
One of the most fatal sources of the prevailing misery and crime lies in the generally accepted quiet assumption that because things have long been wrong, it is impossible they should ever be right.
One of the most singular gifts, or, if abused, most singular weaknesses, of the human mind, is its power of persuading itself to see whatever it chooses; a great gift if directed to the discernment of the things needful and pertinent to its own work and being; a great weakness if directed to the discovery of things profitless or discouraging.
One of the noblest qualities in our nature is that we are able so easily to dispense with greater perfection.
One of the old man's miseries is that he cannot easily find a companion able to partake with him of the past.
One of the sublimest things in the world is
plain truth.
One of the worst diseases to which the human creature is liable is its disease of thinking. If it would only just look at a thing instead of thinking what it must be like, or do a thing instead of thinking it cannot be done, we should all get on far better.
One of these days is none of these days.
One on God's side is a majority.
One ought not to praise a great man unless he is as great as he.
One pair of heels is often worth two pair of
hands.
One pirate gets nothing of another but his cask.
One ploughs, another sows; / Who will reap, no one knows.
One power rules another, but no power can cultivate another; in each endowment, and not elsewhere, lies the force that must complete it.
One precedent creates another. They soon accumulate and constitute law. What yesterday was fact to-day is doctrine. Examples are supposed to justify the most dangerous measures; and where they do not suit exactly, the defect is supplied by analogy.
One rarely sees how deeply one is in debt till
one comes to settle one's accounts.
One really gains nothing from such interests
One religion after another fades away; but the religious sense, which created them all, can never become dead to humanity.
One says more, and with more heart, in an hour than is written in years.
One science only can one genius fit, / So vast is art, so narrow human wit.
One scream of fear from a mother may resound
through the whole life of her daughter.
One sheep follows another.
One should abandon that country wherein there is neither respect, nor employment, nor connections, nor the advancement of science.
One should never ask anybody if one means to write anything.
One should never risk a joke, even of the mildest and most unexceptionable character, except among people of culture and wit.
One should never think of death. One should think of life: that is real piety.
One should not lift the rod against our enemies upon the private information of another.
One should not neglect from time to time to renew friendly relations by personal intercourse.
One shriek of hate would jar all the hymns of heaven: / True Devils with no ear, they howl in tune / With nothing but the Devil!
One sickly sheep infects the flock.
One sin opens the door to another.
One single moment is decisive both of man's life and his whole future. However he may reflect, each resolution he forms is but the work of a moment; the prudent alone seize the right one.
One sinner destroyeth much good.
One solitary philosopher may be great, virtuous, and happy in the depth of poverty, but not a whole people.
One soul may have a decided influence upon
another merely by means of its silent presence.
One soweth and another reapeth.
One step above the sublime makes the ridiculous, and one step above the ridiculous makes the sublime again.
One stumble is enough to deface the character of an honourable life.
One sun by day, by night ten thousand shine.
One swallow does not make a summer.
One sword keeps another in the scabbard.
One "Take this" is better than two "I will give you."
"One thing above all others," says Goethe, "I have never thought about thinking." What a thrift of thinking faculty there; thrift almost of itself equal to a fortune in these days.
One thing at a time, all things in succession. That which grows fast withers as rapidly; that which grows slowly endures.
One thing is needful.
One thing there is which no child brings into the world with him; and yet it is on this one thing that all depends for making man in every point a man;--and that is Reverence
One thorn of experience is worth a whole wilderness of warning.
One thought includes all thought, in the sense that a grain of sand includes the universe.
One tires of a page of which every sentence sparkles with points, of a sentimentalist who is always pumping the tears from his eyes or your own.
One to another cannot be a perfect physician.
One to-day is worth two to-morrows.
One tongue is sufficient for a woman.
One touch of Nature makes the whole world kin.
One 'ud think, an' hear some folk talk, as the men war cute enough to count the corns in a bag o' wheat wi' only smelling at it.
One who, either in conversation or in letters,
affects to shine and to sparkle always, will not please long.
One who has nothing to admire, nothing to love, except his own poor self, may be reckoned a completed character; (but) he is in the minimum state of moral perfection--no more can be made of him.
One who is master of ever so little art may be able, on a great occasion, to root up trees with as much ease as the current of a river the reeds and grass.
One who is out of his own country is defeated by a very trifling enemy.
One woe doth tread upon another's heel, / So fast they follow.
One word with two meanings is the traitor's
shield and shaft.
One wrong step may give you a great fall.
One's morning indolence is soon gone when one has once persuaded one's self to put a foot out of bed.
One's piety is best displayed in his pursuits.
One's too few, three's too many.
Oneness and otherness. It is impossible to
speak or think without embracing both.
Only a Christ could have conceived a Christ.
Only a great pride, that is, a great and reverential repose in one's own being, renders possible a noble humility.
Only a sweet and virtuous soul, / Like seasoned timber, never gives: / But when the whole world turns to coal, / Then chiefly lives.
Only action gives life strength; only moderation gives it a charm.
Only an artist can interpret the meaning of
life.
Only an inventor knows how to borrow, and every man is, or should be, an inventor.
Only by joy and sorrow does a man know anything about himself and his destiny, learn what he ought to seek and what to shun.
Only by pride cometh contention; but with the well-advised is wisdom.
Only great men have any business with great defects.
Only great souls know the grandeur there is
in charity.
Only he can be trusted with gifts who can present a face of bronze to expectations.
Only he deserves freedom who has day by day to fight for it.
Only he helps who unites with many at the proper hour; a single individual helps not.
Only I discern / Infinite passion, and the pain / Of finite hearts that yearn.
Only in complicated critical cases do men find
out what is within them.
Only in looking heavenward, take it in what sense you may, not in looking earthward, does what we call union, mutual love, society, begin to be possible.
Only in the world I fill up a place, which may be better supplied when I have made it empty.
Only learn to catch happiness, for happiness is ever by you.
Only lofty character is worth describing at all.
Only people who possess firmness can possess
true gentleness.
Only regard for law can give us freedom.
Only so far as a man is happily married to himself is he fit for married life and family life generally.
Only such persons interest us, Spartans, Romans, Saracens, English, Americans, who have stood in the jaws of need, and have by their own wit and might extricated themselves, and made man victorious.
Only suffering draws / The inner heart of song, and can elicit / The perfumes of the soul.
Only that good profits which we can taste with
all doors open, and which serves all men.
Only that is poetry which purifies and mans me.
Only the actions of the just / Smell sweet and blossom in the dust.
Only the idle among the poor revolt against their state; the brave workers die passively, and give no sign.
Only the man of worth can recognise worth in men.
Only the person should give advice in a
matter where he himself will co-operate.
Only the word of God and the heart of man can govern.
Only they who have hope live.
Only those books come down which deserve to last.
Only those live who do good.
Only those who love with the heart can animate
the love of others.
Only to the apt, the pure, and the true does Nature resign herself and reveal her secrets.
Only truth can be polished.
Only what of the past was true will come back to us; that is the one asbestos that survives all fire.
Only when man weeps he should be alone, not because tears are weak, but they should be secret.
Onus probandi
Onus segni impone asello
Open not your door when the devil knocks.
Open rebuke is better than secret love.
Opera illius mea sunt
Operæ pretium est
Opere in longo fas est obrepere somnum
Operosa parvus carmina fingo
Operose nihil agunt
Opes regum, corda subditorum
Opiferque per orbem dicor
Opinion is a medium between knowledge and ignorance.
Opinion is, as it were, the queen of the world, but force is its tyrant.
Opinion is the main thing which does good or harm in the world. It is our false opinions that ruin us.
Opinion is the mistress of fools.
Opinion rules the world.
Opinions concerning acts are not history; acts themselves alone are history.
Opinions, like showers, are generated in high places, but they invariably descend into lower ones.
Opinionum enim commenta delet dies, naturæ judicia confirmat
Opportunities, like eggs, come one at a time.
Opportunities neglected are irrecoverable.
Opportunity has hair in front, but is bald behind; if you meet her, seize her by the forelock, for Jove himself cannot catch her again if once let slip.
Opportunity is more powerful even than conquerors and prophets.
Opportunity makes desire.
Opportunity makes us known to others, but
more to ourselves.
Oppose not rage while rage is in its force, but give it way awhile and let it waste.
Opposition always enflames the enthusiast, never converts him.
Oppress'd with grief, oppress'd with care, / A burden more than I can bear, / I sit me down and sigh; / O Life, thou art a galling load, / Along a rough and weary road, / To wretches such as I.
Oppression is more easily borne than insult.
Opprobrium medicorum
Optat ephippia bos piger; optat arare caballus
Optics sharp it needs, I ween, / To see what is not to be seen.
Optima quæque dies miseris mortalibus ævi / Prima fugit; subeunt morbi tristisque senectus, / Et labor; et duræ rapit inclementia mortis
Optimi consiliarii mortui
Optimum obsonium labor
Opum furiata cupido
Ora et labora
Oracles speak.
Oral delivery aims at persuasion, at making
the listener believe he is convinced. Few persons are capable of being convinced; the majority allow themselves to be persuaded.
Orando laborando
Orandum est ut sit mens sana in corpore sano
Orate pro anima
Orationis summa virtus est perspicuitas
Orator improbus leges subvertit
Oratory is a warrior's eye flashing from under a philosopher's brow.
Oratory, like a drama, abhors lengthiness; like the drama, it must be kept doing.
Order all thy actions, so as readily and meekly to comply with the commands of thy superiors, the desires of thy equals, the requests of thy inferiors; so to do for all what thou lawfully mayest.
Order and quiet are good things when they can be had without the sacrifice of things that are better.
Order is a great man's need, and his true well-being.
Order is heaven's first law.
Order is power.
Order is the sanity of the mind, the health of the body, the peace of the city, the security of the state. As the beams to a house, as the bones to the microcosm of man, so is order to all things.
Order is truth, each thing standing on the basis that belongs to it.
Order, thou eye of action.
Ordinary people think merely of spending time; a man with any brains, of using it.
Ore e sempre
Ore tenus
Organic laws can only be serviceable to, and, in general, will only be written by, a public of honourable citizens, loyal to their state and faithful to each other.
Originality is a thing we constantly clamour for and constantly quarrel with, as if any, observes Jean Paul, but our own could be expected to content us.
Originality is simply a fresh pair of eyes.
Originality is the one thing which unoriginal minds cannot feel the use of.
Originality provokes originality.
Ornament is but the guilèd shore / To a most
dangerous sea; the beauteous scarf / Veiling an Indian beauty; in a word, / The seeming truth which cunning times put on / To entrap the wisest.
Ornaments were invented by modesty.
Oro è che oro vale
Orthodoxy is my doxy; heterodoxy another man's doxy.
Orthodoxy is the Bourbon of the world of thought; it learns not, neither can it forget.
Os, orare, vale, communio, mensa negatur
Ostentation is the signal flag of hypocrisy.
Otez un vilain du gibet, il vous y mettra
Othello's occupation's gone!
Other exercises develop single powers and muscles, but dancing, like a corporeal poesy, embellishes, exercises, and equalises all the muscles at once.
Other heights in other lives, God willing.
Other men are lenses through which we read our own minds.
Other men laboured, and ye are entered into their labours.
Others apart sat on a hill retired, / In thoughts more elevate, and reason'd high / Of Providence, fore-knowledge, will, and fate, / Fix'd fate, free-will, fore-knowledge absolute; / And found no end, in wand'ring mazes lost.
Others, more aspiring than achieving, / Achieve all in suggestion, ... / More helpful by their infinite reaching forth / Than all completed thinking.
Otia si tollas, periere Cupidinis arcus
Otiosis nullus adsistit Deus
Otium cum dignitate
Otium sine literis mors est, et hominis vivi sepultura
Où peut-on être mieux qu'au sein de sa famille?
Où sont les neiges d'antan?
Oublier d'éclairer sa lanterne
Oublier ne puis
Oui et Non sont bien courts à dire, mais avant que de les dire, il y faut penser long-temps
Our acts our angels are, or good or ill, / Our
fatal shadows that walk by us still.
Our admiration of the antique is not admiration of the old, but of the natural.
Our affections are but tents of a night.
Our affections, as well as our bodies, are in perpetual flux.
Our age is really up to nothing better than sweeping out the gutters--a scavenger age. Might it but do that well! It is the indispensable beginning of all.
Our age knows nothing but reactions, and
leaps from one extreme to another.
Our ambiguous dissipating education awakens wishes when it should be animating tendencies; instead of forwarding our real capacities, it turns our efforts towards objects which are frequently discordant with the mind that aims at them.
Our ancestors are very good kind o' folks; but they are the last people I should choose to have a visiting acquaintance with.
Our attachment to every object around us increases, in general, from the length of our acquaintance with it.
Our best history is still poetry.
Our best resolutions are frail when opposed
to our predominant inclinations.
Our best thoughts come from others.
Our better mind / Is as a Sunday's garment, then put on / When we have nought to do; but at our work / We wear a worse for thrift.
Our birth is but a sleep and a forgetting.
Our books are false by being fragmentary; the sentences are "bon mots," and not parts of natural discourse; childish expressions of surprise or pleasure in nature--or worse.
Our bounty, like a drop of water, disappears
when diffused too widely.
Our brains are seventy-year clocks. The angel of life winds them up once for all, then closes the case, and gives the key into the hands of the angel of the resurrection.
Our charity indeed should be universal, and extend to all mankind; but it is by no means convenient that our friendships and familiarities should do so too.
Our chief comforts often produce our greatest anxieties, and an increase of our possessions is but an inlet to new disquietudes.
Our chief experiences have been casual.
Our chief want in life is somebody who shall
make us do what we can.
Our clock strikes when there is a change from hour to hour; but no hammer in the Horologe of Time peals through the universe when there is a change from era to era.
Our compell'd sins / Stand more for number than accompt.
Our complaint is the largest tribute heaven receives, and the sincerest part of our devotion.
Our content / Is our best having.
Our corn's to reap, for yet our tilth's to sow.
Our country is wherever we are well off.
Our dead are never dead to us until we have forgotten them.
Our decrees / Dead to infliction, to themselves are dead; / And liberty plucks justice by the nose, / The baby beats the nurse, and quite athwart / Goes all decorum.
Our deeds are fetters that we forge ourselves.
Our deeds are like children born to us; they
live and act apart from our own will. Children may be strangled, but deeds never.
Our deeds determine us as much as we determine our deeds.
Our delight in reason degenerates into idolatry of the herald.
Our dissatisfaction with any other solution is the blazing evidence of immortality.
Our domestic service is usually a foolish fracas of unreasonable demand on the one side and striking on the other.
Our doubts are traitors, / And make us lose the
good we oft might win / By fearing to attempt.
Our dreams drench us in sense, and sense steeps us again in dreams.
Our echoes roll from soul to soul, / And grow for ever and for ever.
Our energies are actually cramped by over-anxiety for success, and by straining our mental faculties beyond due bounds.
Our esteem of great powers, or amiable qualities newly discovered, may embroider a day or a week, but a friendship of twenty years is interwoven with the texture of life.
Our expense is almost all for conformity.
Our experiences of life sway and bow us either with joy or sorrow. They plant everything about us with heart-seeds. Thus a house becomes sacred. Every room has a thousand memories.
Our eyes see all around in gloom or glow--/ Hues of their own, fresh borrowed from the heart.
Our fear commonly meets us at the door by which we think to run from it.
Our feelings are always purest and most glowing in the hour of meeting and of farewell; like the glaciers, which are transparent and rosy-hued only at sunrise and sunset.
Our first ideas of life are generally taken from fiction rather than fact.
Our flatterers are our worst enemies.
Our friends see not our faults, or conceal them, or soften them.
Our God is a household God, as well as a
heavenly one. He has an altar in every man's dwelling; let men look to it when they rend it lightly, and pour out its ashes.
Our grand business is not to see what lies dimly at a distance, but to do what lies clearly at hand.
Our greatest, being also by nature our quietest, are perhaps those that remain unknown.
Our greatest glory consists not in never falling, but in rising every time we fall.
Our greatest misfortunes come to us from ourselves.
Our hand we open of our own free will, and the
good flies which we can never recall.
Our hap is lost, our hope but sad despair.
Our happiness in this world depends on the affections we are able to inspire.
Our happiness should not be laid on a too broad foundation.
Our hearts, frequently warmed by the contact of those whom we wish to resemble, will undoubtedly catch something of their way of thinking; and we shall receive in our own bosoms some radiation at least of their fire and splendour.
Our heavenward progress is something like
that of the Jerusalem pilgrims of old, who for three steps forward took one backward.
Our high respect for a well-read man is praise enough of literature.
Our hoard is little, but our hearts are great.
Our hopes are but our memories reversed.
Our human laws are but the copies, more or less imperfect, of the eternal laws so far as we can read them.
Our humanity were a poor thing but for the
divinity that stirs within us.
Our ideals are our better selves.
Our ideas, like pictures, are made out of lights and shadows.
Our life contains a thousand springs, / And dies if one be gone; / Strange that a harp of thousand strings / Should keep in tune so long.
Our life is compassed round with necessity; yet is the meaning of life itself no other than freedom, than voluntary force.
Our life is no dream, but it may and will perhaps
become one.
Our life is not a mutual helpfulness; but rather, cloaked under due laws of war, named "fair competition," and so forth, it is a mutual hostility.
Our life might be much easier and simpler than we make it.
Our life should feed the springs of fame / With a perennial wave, / As ocean feeds the bubbling founts / Which find in it their grave.
Our Lord God commonly gives riches to foolish people, to whom He gives nothing else.
Our Lord has written the promise of the resurrection,
not in books alone, but in every leaf in spring-time.
Our love is inwrought in our enthusiasm, as electricity is inwrought in the air, exalting its power by a subtle presence.
Our love of truth is evinced by our ability to discover and appropriate what is good wherever we come upon it.
Our memories are independent of our wills.
Our minds cannot be empty; and evil will break in upon them if they are not pre-occupied by good.
Our minds should be habituated to the contemplation
of excellence.
Our moral impressions invariably prove strongest in those moments when we are most driven back upon ourselves.
Our most exalted feelings are not meant to be the common food of daily life. Contentment is more satisfying than exhilaration; and contentment means simply the sum of small and quiet pleasures.
Our narrow ken / Reaches too far, when all that we behold / Is but the havoc of wide-wasting Time, / Or what he soon shall spoil.
Our nature is inseparable from desires, and the very word "desire" (the craving for something not possessed) implies that our present felicity is not complete.
Our natures are like oil; compound us with
anything, yet still we strive to swim upon the top.
Our notion of the perfect society embraces the family as its centre and ornament. Nor is there a paradise planted till the children appear in the foreground to animate and complete the picture.
Our own heart, and not other men's opinions, forms our true honour.
Our passions and principles are steady in frenzy; but begin to shift and waver, as we return to reason.
Our passions are like convulsion fits, which, though they make us stronger for the time, leave us weaker ever after.
Our passions are true phœnixes; when the
old one is burnt out, the new one rises straightway from its ashes.
Our path of glory / By many a cloud is darken'd and unblest.
Our patience will achieve more than our force.
Our peasant
us, "a soul like an Æolian harp, in whose strings the vulgar wind, as it passed through them, changed itself into articulate melody."
Our pleasures are short, and can only charm at intervals; love is a method of protracting our greatest pleasure.
Our pleasures travel by express; our pains by parliamentary.
Our poetry of the eighteenth century was prose; our prose of the seventeenth, poetry.
Our poets are men of talents who sing, and not the children of music.
Our present time is indeed a criticising and a critical time, hovering between the wish and the inability to believe.
Our purity of taste is best tested by its universality,
for if we can only admire this thing or that, we may be sure that our cause for liking is of a finite and false nature.
Our purses shall be proud, our garments poor.
Our ravings and complaints are but like arrows shot up into the air at no mark, and so to no purpose, but only to fall back upon our own heads and destroy ourselves.
Our relation to things outside of ourselves forms, and at the same time robs us of, our existence, and yet we have to do our best to adapt ourselves to circumstances; for to isolate one's self is also not advisable.
Our relations are far too artificial and complicated, our nutriment and mode of life are without their proper nature, and our social intercourse is without proper love and goodwill. Every one is polished and courteous, but no one has the courage to be hearty and true.
Our relations are ours by lot, our friends by
election.
Our religion assumes the negative form of rejection. Out of love of the true, we repudiate the false; and the religion is an abolishing criticism.
Our religion is meant to root out our vices, but it covers, nourishes, and excites them.
Our remedies oft in ourselves do lie, / Which we ascribe to heaven.
Our sacrifices are rarely of an active kind; we, as it were, abandon what we give away. It is not from resolution, but despair, that we renounce our property.
Our self-made men are the glory of our institutions.
Our senses will not admit of anything extreme: too much noise confuses us, too much light dazzles us.
Our social forms are very far from truth and equity.
Our sorrows are like thunder-clouds, which seem black in the distance, but grow lighter as they approach.
Our souls much farther than our eyes can see.
Our souls must become expanded by the contemplation
of Nature's grandeur before we can fully comprehend the greatness of man.
Our spiritual maladies are but of opinion; we are but fettered by chains of our own forging, and which ourselves also can rend asunder.
Our spontaneous action is always the best.
Our stomach for good fortune is bottomless, but the entrance to it is narrow.
Our strength lies in our weakness
Our temperaments differ in capacity of heat,
or we boil at different degrees.
Our thinking is a pious reception.
Our thoughts are often worse than we are, just as they are often better.
Our thoughts take wildest flight / Even at the moment when they should array themselves in pensive order.
Our time is fixed, and all our days are numbered; / How long, how short, we know not: this we know, / Duty requires we calmly wait the summons, / Nor dare to stir till Heaven shall give permission.
Our torment is unbelief, the uncertainty as to
what we ought to do, the distrust of the value of what we do, and the distrust that the necessity which we all at last believe in is fair and beneficial.
Our valours are our best gods.
Our vanity is the constant enemy of our dignity.
Our very hopes belied our fears, / Our fears our hopes belied; / We thought her dying when she slept, / And sleeping when she died.
Our virtues are dearer to us the more we have had to suffer for them. It is the same with our children. All profound affection admits a sacrifice.
Our virtues depend on our failings as their
root, and the latter send forth as strong and manifold branches underground as the former do in the open light.
Our / Virtues lie in the interpretation of the time.
Our virtues would be proud if our faults whipped them not; and our crimes would despair if they were not cherished by our virtues.
Our whole existence is passed into words, and words, by means of tongue and ears, pass so easily into the soul.
Our whole life is but a chamber which we are frescoing with colours, that do not appear while being laid on wet, but which will shine forth afterwards when finished and dry.
Our whole terrestrial being is based on Time
and built of Time; it is wholly a movement, a Time-impulse; Time is the author of it, the material of it.
Our wills and fates do so contrary run, / That our devices still are overthrown; / Our thoughts are ours, their ends none of our own.
Our work must be done honourably and thoroughly, because we are now men; whether we ever expect to be angels, or ever were slugs, being practically no matter. We are now human creatures, and must, at our peril, do human, that is to say, affectionate, honest, and earnest work.
Our works are presentiments of our capabilities.
Our works decay and disappear, / God's frailest works abide, and look / Down on the ruins we toil to rear.
Our worst misfortunes never happen, and most miseries lie in anticipation.
Our yesterday's to-morrow now is gone, / And still a new to-morrow does come on. / We by to-morrow draw out all our store, / Till the exhausted well can yield no more.
Our young men are terribly alike.
Ourselves are easily provided for; it is nothing but the circumstantials of human life that cost so much.
Out at sea, the universe has dwindled to a
little circle of crumpled water, that journeys with you day after day, and to which you seem bound by some enchantment.
Out of debt, out of danger.
Out of difficulties grow miracles.
Out of Evil comes Good; and no Good that is possible but shall one day be real.
Out of my stony griefs / Bethel I'll raise.
Out of Plato come all things that are still
written and debated about among men of thought.
Out of sight out of mind.
Out of the abundance of the heart the mouth speaketh.
Out of the eater cometh forth meat; out of the strong cometh forth sweetness.
Out of the frying-pan into the fire.
Out of the suffering comes the serious mind;
out of the salvation, the grateful heart; out of endurance, fortitude; out of deliverance, faith.
Out of this nettle danger we pluck this flower safety.
Out upon the tempest of anger, the acrimonious gall of fretful impatience, the sullen frost of lowring resentment, or the corroding poison of withered envy! They eat up the immortal part of a man!... like traitor Iscariot, betray their lord and master.
Outward judgment often fails, inward justice never.
Outward religion originates by society; society
becomes possible by religion.
Ouvrage de longue haleine
Over the events of life we may have a control, but none whatever over the law of its progress.
Over the Time thou hast no power; solely over one man therein hast thou a quite absolute, uncontrollable power; him redeem, him make honest.
Over there it will not be otherwise than it is here.
Overcome evil with good.
Overdone is worse than underdone.
Ovid finely compares a man of broken fortune to a falling column; the lower it sinks, the greater weight it is obliged to sustain.
Owe no man anything, but to love one another; for he that loveth another hath fulfilled the law.
Oysters are not good in a month that hath not an R in it.
Pabulum Acherontis
Pace tanti viri
Pacem hominibus habe, bellum cum vitiis
Pacta conventa
Pacte de famille
Pactum non pactum est; non pactum pactum
est; quod vobis lubet
Paga lo que debes, sabrás lo que tienes
"Pagan self-assertion" is one of the elements of human worth as well as "Christian self-denial."
Pain has its own noble joy, when it kindles a strong consciousness of life, before stagnant and torpid.
Pain is less subject than pleasure to capricious expression.
Pain is so uneasy a sentiment that very little
of it is enough to corrupt every enjoyment.
Pain is the deepest thing we have in our nature, and union through pain has always seemed more real and holy than any other.
Pain is the positive element in life, and pleasure its negation.
Pain past is pleasure.
Pain pays the income of each precious thing.
Painful for man is rebellious independence
when it has become inevitable; only in loving companionship with his fellows does he feel safe; only in reverently bowing down before the Higher does he feel himself exalted.
Pains of love be sweeter far / Than all other pleasures are.
Paint costs nothing.
"Paint me as I am."
Painters draw their nymphs in thin and airy habits, but the weight of gold and of embroideries is reserved for queens and goddesses.
Painting does not proceed so much by intelligence
as by sight and feeling and invention.
Painting is silent poetry, and poetry speaking painting.
Painting is the intermediate between a thought and a thing.

Pardon is the choicest flower of victory.
Parents are commonly more careful to bestow
wit on their children than virtue, the art of speaking well than of doing well; but their manners ought to be the great concern.
Parents' blessings can neither be drowned in water nor consumed in fire.
Parents we can have but once; and he promises himself too much who enters life with the expectation of finding many friends.
Pares cum paribus ut est in veteri proverbio facillime congregantur

Passion depraves, but also ennobles.
Passion drives the man, passions the woman;
him a stream, her the winds.
Passion is the drunkenness of the mind.
Passion is universal humanity. Without it religion, history, romance, art, would be useless.
Passion looks not beyond the moment of its existence.
Passion makes the best observations and the sorriest conclusions.
Passion makes the will lord of the reason.
Passion often makes a fool of the most ingenious man, and often makes the greatest blockhead ingenious.
Passion, though a bad regulator, is a powerful spring.
Passionate people are like men who stand upon their heads; they see all things in the wrong way.
Passions are likened best to floods and streams; / The shallow murmur, but the deep are dumb.
Passions are the gales of life.
Passions are the vices or virtues in their highest powers.
Passions existed before principles; they came into the world with us.
Passions may not unfitly be termed the mob of the man, that commits a riot upon his reason.
Passions spin the plot; we are betrayed by what is false within.
Past and to come seem best, things present
worst.
Pastime, like wine, is poison in the morning.
Patch and long sit, / Build and soon flit.
Patch grief with proverbs.

Patience and perseverance overcome the greatest difficulties.

Patience had no sooner placed herself by the mount of sorrows, but the whole heap sunk to such a degree, that it did not appear a third part so big as it was before.
Patience is a necessary ingredient of genius.
Patience is a plaister for all sores.
Patience is a remedy for every sorrow.
Patience is a stout horse, but it will tire at the last.
Patience is bitter, but its fruit is sweet.
Patience is even more rarely manifested in the intellect than in the temper.
Patience is genius.
Patience is good for poltroons.
Patience is sister to meekness, and humility is its mother.
Patience is the art of hoping.
Patience is the ballast of the soul, that will keep it from rolling and tumbling in the greatest storms.
Patience is the key of content.
Patience is the key of Paradise.
Patience is the support of weakness; impatience, the ruin of strength.
Patience, money, and time bring all things to pass.
Patience of obscurity is a duty which we owe not more to our happiness than to the quiet of the world at large.

pause; / They can be meek that have no other cause.
Patience wears out stones.
Patience, when it is a divine thing, is active, not passive.

Patient waiters are no losers.

Patriotism depends as much on mutual suffering
as on mutual success.
Patriotism has its roots deep in the instincts and the affections. Love of country is the expansion of filial love.
Patriotism is the last refuge of a scoundrel.
Patriotism is the vital condition of national permanence.
Patriotism must be founded on great principles and supported by great virtue.
Patroclus is dead, who was better by far than thou.
Patronage, that is, pecuniary or other economic furtherance, has been pronounced to be twice cursed, cursing him that gives and him that takes.

Pay as you go is the philosopher's stone.
Pay beforehand if you would have your work ill done.
Pay good wages, or your servants will pay themselves.
Pay not before thy work be done; if thou dost, it will never be well done, and thou wilt have but a pennyworth for twopence.
Pay the reckoning over-night, and you won't be troubled in the morning.
Pay well when you are served well.
Pay what you owe, and what you're worth you'll know.
Pay without fail, / Down on the nail.
Pazza è chi non sa da che parte vien il vento
Peace hath her victories, / No less renown'd than war.
Peace is liberty in tranquility.
Peace is rarely denied to the peaceful.
Peace is the happy natural state of man; war his corruption, his disgrace.
Peace is the masterpiece of reason.
Peace, justice, and the word of God must be given to the people, not sold.
Peace, of all worldly blessings, is the most
valuable.
Peace with a cudgel in hand is war.
Peacefully and reasonably to contemplate is at no time hurtful, and while we use ourselves to think of the advantages of others, our own mind comes insensibly to imitate them; and every false activity to which our fancy was alluring us is then willingly abandoned.

Pedantry is properly overrating any kind of knowledge we pretend to.
