People abuse freedom only where they have asserted it, not where it has been given them.
People are always expecting to get peace in heaven; but you know whatever peace they get there will be ready-made. Whatever of making peace they can be blest for must be on the earth here.
People are only accustomed to revolve around themselves.
People are rendered sociable by their inability to endure their own society.
People are wise for the past day in the evening,
but never wise enough for the coming one.
People, crushed by laws, have no hopes but from power. If laws are their enemies, they will be enemies to laws; and those who have much to hope and nothing to lose will always be dangerous, more or less.
 (_Bibelverbre
People dispute a great deal about the good that is done and the harm by disseminating this is clear: the Bible will do harm if, as hitherto, it is used dogmatically and interpreted fancifully, and it will do good if it is treated feelingly and applied didactically.
People do not care to give alms without some security for their money; and a wooden leg or a withered arm is a sort of draft upon heaven for those who choose to have their money placed to account there.
People do not lack strength; they lack will.
People do not mind their faults being spread
out before them, but they become impatient if called upon to give them up.
People in adversity should preserve laudable customs.
People (in authority) are accustomed merely to forbid, to hinder, to refuse, but rarely to bid, to further, and to reward. They let things go along till some mischief happens; then they fly into a rage, and lay about them.
People love to have all rash actions done in a hurry.
People may live as much retired from the world as they like, but sooner or later they find themselves debtor or creditor to some one.
People must begin before they attempt to finish or improve.
People seem to think themselves in some
ways superior to heaven itself, when they complain of the sorrow and want round about them; and yet it is not the devil for certain who puts pity into their hearts.
People should never sit talking till they don't know what to talk about.
People that are like-minded
can never for any length be disunited
they always come together again; whereas those that are not like-minded
they always come together again; whereas those that are not like-minded (_Widergesinnten_) 
they always come together again; whereas those that are not like-minded (_Widergesinnten_)  the essential discord between them will be sure to break out some day.
People that have nothing to do are quickly tired of their own company.
People that make puns are like wanton boys that put coppers on the railroad tracks. They amuse themselves and other children, but their little trick may upset a freight train of conversation for the sake of a battered witticism.
People that will crowd about bonfires may
sometimes very fairly, get their beards singed; it is the price they pay for such illumination; natural twilight is safe and free to all.
People throw stones only at trees which have fruit on them.
People who are always taking care of their health are like misers, who are hoarding up a treasure which they have never spirit enough to enjoy.
People who are too sharp cut their own fingers.
People who can't be witty exert themselves to be pious and affectionate.
People who do not know how to laugh are always
pompous and self-conceited.
People who have little to do are great talkers. The less they think the more they talk, and so women talk more than men. A nation where women determine the fashion is always talkative.
People who honestly mean to be true really contradict themselves much more rarely than those who try to be consistent.
People who live in glass houses should never throw stones.
People who never have any time are those who do least.
People will not look forward to posterity who
never look backward to their ancestors.
People would do well if, tarrying here for years together, they observed a while a Pythagorean silence.
People would do well if they would keep piety, which is so essential and lovable in life, distinct from art, where, owing to its very simplicity and dignity, it checks their energy, allowing only the very highest mind freedom to unite with, if not actually to master, it.

Perfect existence can only be where spirit and body are one; an embodied spirit, a spiritual body.
Perfect experience must itself embrace theoretical knowledge.
Perfect life is ever in one's acts to deal with innocence, which proves itself in doing wrong to no one but itself.
Perfect light / Would dazzle, not illuminate, the sight; / From earth it is enough to glimpse at heaven.
Perfect love canna be without equality.
Perfect love casteth out fear.
Perfect love holds the secret of the world's perfect liberty.
Perfect woman, nobly planned, / To warn, to
comfort, and command; / And yet a spirit still, and bright / With something of an angel light.
Perfect works are rare, because they must be produced at the happy moment when taste and genius unite: and this rare conjunction, like that of certain planets, appears to occur only after the revolution of several cycles, and only lasts for an instant.
Perfecting is our destiny, but perfection is never our lot.
Perfection is not the affair of the scholar; it is enough if he practises.

Perhaps the early grave / Which men weep over may be meant to save.

Permanence is what I advocate in all human relations; nomadism, continual change, is prohibitory of any good whatsoever.
Permanence, perseverance, persistence in spite
of hindrances, discouragements, and "impossibilities:" it is this that in all things distinguishes the strong soul from the weak; the civilised burgher from the nomadic savage--the species Man from the genus Ape.
Permanence, persistence, is the first condition of all fruitfulness in the ways of men.
Permissu superiorum
Permitte divis cætera
Perpetual solitude, in a place where you see nothing to raise your spirits, at length wears them out, and conversation falls into dull and insipid.
Perpetuus nulli datur usus, et hæres / Hæredem
alterius, velut unda supervenit undam
Persecution is a tribute the great must ever pay for pre-eminence.
Persecution is not wrong because it is cruel; it is cruel because it is wrong.
Persecution to persons in high rank stands them in the stead of eminent virtue.
Perseverance and audacity generally win.
Perseverance and tact are the two great
qualities most valuable for all men who would mount, but especially for those who have to step out of the crowd.
Perseverance, dear, my lord, / Keeps honour bright. To have done is to hang / Quite out of fashion, like a rusty mail, / In monumental mockery.
Perseverance is a Roman virtue that wins each godlike act, and plucks success even from the spear-proof crest of rugged danger.
Perseverance performs greater works than strength.
Perseverance, self-reliance, energetic effort, are doubly strengthened when you rise from a failure to battle again.
Perseverando
Perseverantia
Persevere and never fear.
Persevere in the fight, struggle on, do not let go, think magnanimously of man and life, for man is good and life is affluent and fruitful.
Persist, persevere, and you will find most things attainable that are possible.
Personæ mutæ
Personal attachment is no fit ground for public conduct, and those who declare they will take care of the rights of the sovereign because they have received favours at his hand, betray a little mind and warrant the conclusion that if they did not receive those favours they would be less mindful of their duties, and act with less zeal for his interest.
Personal force never goes out of fashion.
Personality is everything in art and poetry.
Persons are love's world, and the coldest philosopher cannot recount the debt of the young soul, wandering here in nature to the power of love, without being tempted to unsay, as treasonable to nature, aught derogatory to the social instincts.
Persons of fine manners make behaviour the first sign of force,--behaviour, and not performance, or talent, or, much less, wealth.
Persons who are very plausible and excessively
polite have generally some design upon you, as also religionists who call you "dear" the first time they see you.
Perspicuity is the offset of profound thoughts.
Persuasion is better than force.
Peter's in, Paul's out.

Petitioners for admittance into favour must
not harass the condescension of their benefactor.

Petty laws breed great crimes.

Peu de chose nous console, parceque peu de

Peuples libres, souvenez-vous de cette maxime: on peut acquérir la liberté, mais on ne la retrouve jamais
Phaeton was his father's heir; born to attain the highest fortune without earning it; he had built no sun-chariot (could not build the simplest wheel-barrow), but could and would insist on driving one; and so broke his own stiff neck, sent gig and horses spinning through infinite space, and set the universe on fire.
Pharmaca das ægroto, aurum tibi porrigit æger, / Tu morbum curas illius, ille tuum
Philanthropy, like charity, must begin at home.
"Philistine" must have originally meant, in the mind of those who invented the nickname, a strong, dogged, unenlightened opponent of the children of the light.
Philologists, who chase / A panting syllable through time and space, / Start it at home, and hunt it in the dark / To Gaul, to Greece, and into Noah's ark.
Philosophers are only men in armour after all.
Philosophers call God "the great unknown." "The great misknown" would be more correct.
Philosophia simulari potest, eloquentia non potest
Philosophy and theology are become theorem, brain-web and shadow, wherein no earnest soul can find solidity for itself. Shadow, I say; yet shadow projected from an everlasting reality within ourselves. Quit the shadow, seek the reality.
Philosophy can add to our happiness in no other manner but by diminishing our misery; it should not pretend to increase our present stock, but make us economists of what we are possessed of.
Philosophy can bake no bread; but she can
procure for us God, freedom, immortality. Which, then, is more practical--philosophy or economy?
Philosophy does not regard pedigree; she did not receive Plato as a noble, but she made him so.
Philosophy dwells aloft in the Temple of Science, the divinity of its inmost shrine; her dictates descend among men, but she herself descends not; whoso would behold her must climb with long and laborious effort, nay, still linger in the forecourt, till manifold trial have proved him worthy of admission into the interior solemnities.
Philosophy easily triumphs over past and future ills, but present ills triumph over philosophy.
Philosophy goes no further than probabilities, and in every assertion keeps a doubt in reserve.
Philosophy has given several plausible rules
for attaining peace and tranquillity, but they fall very much short of bringing men to it.
Philosophy is a bully that talks very loud when the danger is at a distance; but the moment she is hard pressed by the enemy, she is not to be found at her post, but leaves the brunt of the battle to be borne by her humbler but steadier comrade, Religion.
Philosophy is a good horse in a stable, but an arrant jade on a journey.
Philosophy is an elegant thing, if any one modestly meddles with it; but, if he is conversant with it more than is becoming, it corrupts the man.
Philosophy is but a continual battle against custom; an ever-renewed effort to transcend the sphere of blind custom, and so become transcendental.
Philosophy is no more than the art of making ourselves happy; that is, of seeking pleasure in regularity, and reconciling what we owe to society with what is due to ourselves.
Philosophy is nothing but discretion.
Philosophy is properly home-sickness; the wish to be everywhere at home.
Philosophy is reason with the eyes of the soul.
Philosophy is to poetry what old age is to youth; and the stern truths of philosophy are as fatal to the fictions of the one as the chilling testimonies of experience are to the hopes of the other.
Philosophy, rightly defined, is simply the love of wisdom.
Philosophy teaches us to do willingly and
from conviction what others do under compulsion.
Philosophy, when superficially studied, excites doubt; when thoroughly explored, it dispels it.
Philosophy, while it soothes the reason, damps the ambition.
Philosophy will clip an angel's wings.
Phœnices primi, famæ si creditur, ausi / Mansuram
rudibus vocem signare figuris
Physic, for the most part, is nothing else but the substitute of exercise and temperance.
Physic is of little use to a temperate person, for a man's own observation on what he finds does him good or what hurts him, is the best physic to preserve health.
Physical courage, which despises all danger, will make a man brave in one way; and moral courage, which defies all opinion, will make a man brave in another.
Physical science has taught us to associate Deity with the normal rather than with the abnormal.
Physician, heal thyself.
Physicians, of all men, are most happy; whatever good success soever they have, the world proclaimeth; and what faults they commit, the earth covereth.
Pia fraus
Pick out of mirth, like stones out of thy ground, / Profaneness, filthiness, abusiveness.
Pickpockets and beggars are the best practical physiognomists, without having read a line of Lavater, who, it is notorious, mistook a philosopher for a highwayman.
Pictoribus atque poetis / Quidlibet audendi
semper fuit æqua potestas
Pictures and shapes are but secondary objects, and please or displease but in memory.
Pie repone te
Pièce de position
Pièce de résistance
Pièces de théâtre
Piety is a kind of modesty. It makes us cast down our thoughts, just as modesty makes us cast down our eyes in presence of whatever is forbidden.
Piety is not a religion, although it is the soul of all religions.
Piety is only a means whereby, through purest inward peace, we may attain to highest culture.
Piety, like wisdom, consists in the discovery of the rules under which we are actually placed, and in faithfully obeying them.
Piety, stretched beyond a certain point, is the
parent of impiety.
Pigmæi gigantum humeris impositi plusquam ipsi gigantes vident
Pigmies are pigmies still, though perched on Alps; / And pyramids are pyramids in vales.
Pigs grow fat where lambs would starve.
Pigs grunt about everything and nothing.
Pigs when they fly go tail first.
Pikes are caught when little fish go by.
Pillen muss man schlingen, nicht kauen
Pin thy faith to no man's sleeve; hast thou not two eyes of thy own?
Pinguis venter non gignit sensum tenuem
Pis-aller
Pitch a lucky man into the Nile and he will come up with a fish in his mouth.
Pitch thy behaviour low, thy projects high; / So shalt thou humble and magnanimous be.
Pith's gude at a' play but threadin' o' needles.
Pity and friendship are passions incompatible with each other.
Pity and need make all flesh kin. There is no
caste in blood / Which runneth of one hue; nor caste in tears, which trickle salt with all.
Pity him who has his choice, and chooses the worse.
Pity is a thing often avowed, seldom felt; hatred is a thing often felt, seldom avowed.
Pity is imagination or fiction of future calamity to ourselves proceeding from the sense of another man's calamity.
Pity is the virtue of the law, / And none but tyrants use it cruelly.
Pity makes the world / Soft to the weak and
noble for the strong.
Pity only with new objects stays, / But with the tedious sight of woe decays.
Pity shapes not into syllogisms; / Nor can affection ape philosophy.
Pity, the tenderest part of love.
Pity those whom Nature abuses, never those who abuse Nature.
Pity weakness and ignorance, bear with the
dulness of understandings, or perverseness of tempers.
Più ombra che frutto fanno gli arberi grandi
Più sa il matto in casa sua che il savio in casa d'altri
Più vale il fumo di casa mia, che il fuoco dell'altrui
Place moral heroes in the field, and heroines will follow them as brides.
Placeat homini quidquid Deo placuit
Plagiarists are always suspicious of being stolen from.
Plagiarists, at least, have the merit of preservation.
Plain dealing is dead, and died without issue.
Plain dealing's a jewel, but they that use it die beggars.
Plain living and high thinking.
Plants are children of the earth; we are children of the ether. Our lungs are properly our root; we live when we breathe: we begin our life with breathing.
Plaster thick, / Some will stick.
Plate sin with gold, / And the strong lance of justice hurtless breaks; / Arm it in rags, a pigmy's straw does pierce it.
Plato enim mihi unus est instar omnium
Plato's scheme was impossible even in his own
day, as Bacon's "New Atlantis" in his day, as Calvin's reform in his day, as Goethe's "Academe" in his. Out of the good there was in all these men, the world gathered what it could find of evil, made its useless Platonism out of Plato, its graceless Calvinism out of Calvin, determined Bacon to be the meanest of mankind, and of Goethe gathered only a luscious story of seduction, and daintily singable devilry.
Plausibus ex ipsis populi, lætoque furore, / ingenium quodvis incaluisse potest
Plausus tunc arte carebat
Play not for gain, but sport.
Play, that is, activity, not pleasures, will keep children cheerful.
Play the man.
Pleasant tastes depend, not on the things themselves, but their agreeableness to this or that particular palate.
Pleasant words are as an honeycomb; sweet to the soul, and health to the bones.
Pleas'd with a rattle, tickl'd with a straw.
Pleasure and action make the hours seem short.
Pleasure and pain, though directly opposite,
are yet so contrived by nature as to be constant companions.
Pleasure and revenge / Have ears more deaf than adders to the voice / Of any true decision.
Pleasure and sympathy in things is all that is real and again produces reality; all else is empty and vain.
Pleasure can be supported by illusion; but happiness rests upon truth.
Pleasure is a wanton trout; / An ye drink but deep ye'll find him out.
Pleasure is far sweeter as a recreation than a
business.
Pleasure is nothing else but the intermission of pain, the enjoying of something I am in great trouble for till I get it.
Pleasure is the greatest incentive to evil.
Pleasure is the reflex of unimpeded energy.
Pleasure itself is painful at bottom.
Pleasure of every kind quickly satisfies.
Pleasure preconceived and preconcerted ends in disappointment; but disappointment, when it involves neither shame nor loss, is as good as success; for it supplies as many images to the mind, and as many topics to the tongue.
Pleasure soon exhausts us, and itself also but endeavour never does.
Pleasure which cannot be obtained but by unreasonable and unsuitable expense, must always end in pain.
Pleasure which must be enjoyed at the expense of another's pain, can never be such as a worthy mind can fully delight in.
Pleasure's couch is virtue's grave.
Pleasures are like poppies spread, / You seize the flower, its bloom is shed; / Or, like the snowflake in the river, / A moment white, then melts for ever.
Pleasures lie thickest where no pleasures seem; / There's not a leaf that falls upon the ground / But holds some joy of silence or of sound, / Some sprite begotten of a summer dream.
Pleasures waste the spirits more than pains.
Pledges taken of faithless minds, / I hold them but as the idle winds / Heard and forgot.
Plenty, and peace, breeds cowards; hardness
ever of hardiness is mother.
Plenty makes dainty.
Plerique enim lacrimas fundunt ut ostendant; et toties siccos oculos habent, quoties spectator definit
Plerumque modestus / Occupat obscuri speciem, taciturnus acerbi
Ploratur lacrymis amissa pecunia veris
Ploravere suis non respondere favorem / Speratum meritis
Plough deep while sluggards sleep.
Plough or not plough, you must pay your rent.
Plunge boldly into the thick of life, and seize it where you will, it is always interesting.
Plura faciunt homines e consuetudine quam e ratione
Plura sunt quæ nos terrent, quam quæ premunt; et sæpius opinione quam re laboramus
Plures adorant solem orientem quam occidentem
Plures crapula quam gladius
Plurima mortis imago
Plurima sont quæ / Non audent homines pertusa dicere læna
Pluris est oculatus testis unus quam auriti decem. / Qui audiunt, audita dicunt: qui vident, plane sciunt
Plus aloes quam mellis habet
Plus dolet quam necesse est, qui ante dolet
quam necesse est
Plus etenim fati valet hora benigni / Quam si nos Veneris commendet epistola Marti
Plus fait douceur que violence
Plus impetus, majorem constantiam, penes miseros
Plus in amicitia valet similitudo morum quam affinitas
Plus in posse quam in actu
Plus je vis l'étranger, plus j'aimai ma patrie
Plus on approche des grands hommes, plus on trouve qu'ils sont hommes
Plus on lui ôte, plus il est grand
Plus ratio quam vis cæca valere solet
Plus salis quam sumptus
Plus une pierre est jétée de haut, plus elle fait d'impression où elle tombe
Plus vetustis nam favet / Invidia mordax, quam bonis præsentibus
Plutarch warns young men that it is well to go for a light to another man's fire, but by no means to tarry by it, instead of kindling a torch of their own.
Plutôt une défaite au Rhin que l'abandon du Pape!
Poco daño espanta, y mucho amansa
Poem (a) is a thought so passionate and alive, that, like the spirit of a plant or an animal, it has an architecture of its own, and adorns nature with a new thing.
Poems that are great, books that are great, all of them, if you search the first foundation of their greatness, have been veridical, the truest they could get to be.
Poesie ist tiefes Schmerzen, / Und es kommt das echte Lied / Einzig aus dem Menschenherzen / Das ein tiefes Leid durchglüht
Poesy is love's chosen apostle, and the very almoner of God. She is the home of the outcast, and the wealth of the needy.
Poesy is of so subtle a spirit, that in pouring
out of one language into another it will evaporate.
Poeta nascitur, non fit
Poetica surgit / Tempestas
Poetry comes nearer to vital truth than history.
Poetry creates life.
Poetry has given me the habit of wishing to
discover the good and the beautiful in all that meets and surrounds me.
Poetry implies the whole truth, philosophy expresses a particle of it.
Poetry incorporates those spirits which, like angels, can never assume the body of an outward act; and sheds the perfume of those flowers which spring up but never bear any seed.
Poetry interprets in two ways: by expressing with magical felicity the physiognomy and movements of the outer world; and by expressing with inward conviction the ideas and laws of the inward.
Poetry is a spirit, not disembodied, but in the flesh, so as to affect the senses of living men.
Poetry is always a personal interpretation of
life.
Poetry is an art, the easiest to dabble in, and the hardest in which to reach true excellence.
Poetry is an attempt man makes to render his existence harmonious.
Poetry is faith.
Poetry is inestimable as a lonely faith, a lonely protest in the uproar of atheism.
Poetry is inspiration; has in it a certain spirituality
and divinity which no dissecting knife will discover; arises in the most secret and most sacred region of man's soul, as it were in our Holy of Holies; and as for external things, depends only on such as can operate in that region; among which it will be found that Acts of Parliament and the state of Smithfield Markets nowise play the chief parts.
Poetry is music in words, and music is poetry in sound; both excellent sauce, but they have lived and died poor that made them their meal.
Poetry is musical thought, thought of a mind that has penetrated into the inmost heart of a thing, detected the melody that lies hidden in it, ... the heart of Nature being everywhere music, if you can only reach it.
Poetry is only born after painful journeys into the vast regions of thought.
Poetry is right royal. It puts the individual for the species, the one above the infinite many.
Poetry is something to make us wiser and
better by continually revealing those types of beauty and truth which God has set in all men's souls.
Poetry is the art of substantiating shadows and of lending existence to nothing.
Poetry is the art of uniting pleasure with truth by calling imagination to the help of reason.
Poetry is the breath and finer spirit of all knowledge; it is the impassioned expression which is the countenance of all science.
Poetry is the exquisite expression of exquisite impressions.
Poetry is the first and last of all knowledge--it
is as immortal as the heart of man.
Poetry is the key to the hieroglyphics of nature.
Poetry is the language of feeling.
Poetry is the morning dream of great minds.
Poetry is the music of the soul; and, above all, of great and feeling souls.
Poetry is the offspring of the rarest beauty,
begot by imagination upon thought, and clad by taste and fancy in habiliments of grace.
Poetry is the only verity, the expression of a sound mind speaking after the ideal, and not after the apparent.
Poetry is the perpetual endeavour to express the spirit of the thing; to pass the brute body, and search the life and reason which cause it to exist; to see that the object is always flowing away, whilst the spirit or necessity which causes it subsists.
Poetry is the record of the best and happiest moments of the happiest and best minds.
Poetry is the utterance of truth,--deep, heartfelt truth. The true poet is very near the oracle.
Poetry is the worst mask in the world behind
which folly and stupidity could attempt to hide their features.
Poetry itself is strength and joy, whether it be crowned by all mankind, or left alone in its own magic hermitage.
Poetry must first be good sense, though it is something better.
Poetry ought to go straight to the heart, because it has come from the heart; and aim at the man in the citizen, and not the citizen in the man.
Poetry says more and in fewer words than prose.
Poetry should be great and unobtrusive.
Poetry should be vital, either stirring our blood by its divine movements, or snatching our breath by its divine perfection.
Poetry uses the rainbow tints for special effects, but always keeps its essential object in the purest white light of truth.
Poetry was given to us to hide the little discords of life and to make man contented with the world and his condition.
Poetry, were it the rudest, so it be sincere, is the attempt which man makes to render his existence harmonious, the utmost he can do for that end; it springs therefore from his whole feelings, opinions, activity, and takes its character from these. It may be called the music of the whole inner being.
Poets and heroes are of the same race; the
latter do what the former conceive.
Poets and painters ha'e leave to lee.
Poets are all who love, who feel great truths, and tell them.
Poets are liberating gods; they are free and make free.
Poets are natural sayers, sent into the world for the end of expression.
Poets are never young in one sense. Their
delicate ear hears the far-off whispers of eternity, which coarser souls must travel towards for scores of years before their dull sense is touched by them. A moment's insight is sometimes worth a life's experience.
Poets are the hierophants of an unapprehended inspiration, the mirrors of the gigantic shadows which futurity casts upon the present.
Poets are the unacknowledged legislators of the world.
Poets lose half the praise they should have got, / Could it be known what they discreetly blot.
Poets of old date, being privileged with senses, had also enjoyed external Nature; but chiefly as we enjoy the crystal cup which holds good or bad liquor for us; that is to say, in silence, or with slight incidental commentary; never, as I compute, till after the "Sorrows of Werter" was there man found who would say: Come, let us make a description: Having drunk the liquor, Come, let us eat the glass.
Poets should be lawgivers; that is, the boldest lyric inspiration should not chide and insult, but should announce and lead the civil code, the day's work.
Poets should turn philosophers in age, as Pope did. We are apt to grow chilly when we sit out our fire.
Poets utter great and wise things which they do not themselves understand.
Point d'argent, point de Suisse
Policy sits above conscience.
Polished steel will not shine in the dark; no more can reason, however refined, shine efficaciously but as it reflects the light of Divine truth shed from heaven.
Politeness is benevolence in small things.
Politeness is real kindness kindly expressed.
Politeness is the flower of humanity.
Politeness is to goodness what words are to
thoughts.
Politeness makes a man appear outwardly as he should be within.
Political liberty is to be found only in moderate governments.
Politicians think that by stopping up the chimney they can stop its smoking. They try the experiment; they drive the smoke back, and there is more smoke than ever.
Politics is a deleterious profession, like some poisonous handicrafts.
Politics is the science of exigencies.
Pompa mortis magis terret quam mors ipsa
Ponamus nimios gemitus; flagrantior æquo /
Non debet dolor esse viri, nec vulnere major
Ponderanda sunt testimonia, non numeranda
Pone seram, cohibe; sed quis custodiet ipsos / Custodes? cauta est, et ab illis incipit uxor
Pons asinorum
Ponto nox incubat atra, / Intonuere poli et crebris micat ignibus æther
Poor and content is rich and rich enough; /
But riches fineless is as poor as winter / To him that ever fears he shall be poor.
Poor folk hae neither ony kindred nor ony freends.
Poor folk seek meat for their stomachs, and rich folks stomachs for their meat.
Poor folks are glad of porridge.
Poor folks must say "Thank ye" for little.
Poor folk's wisdom goes for little.
Poor in abundance, famished at a feast, man's grief is but his grandeur in disguise, and discontent is immortality.
Poor is the triumph o'er the timid hare.
Poor love is lost in men's capacious minds; / In women's it fills all the room it finds.
Poor men do penance for rich men's sins.
Poor men, when Yule is cold, / Must be content
to sit by little fires.
Poor men's tables are soon placed.
Poor naked wretches, wheresoe'er you are, / That bide the pelting of this pitiless storm, / How shall your houseless heads and unfed sides, / Your looped and windowed raggedness, defend you / From seasons such as these? O I have ta'en / Too little care of this!


Poor tenant bodies, scant o' cash, / How they stamp and threaten, curse and swear, / He'll apprehend them, poind their gear; / While An' hear it a', and fear and tremble!
Poor the raiment you may wear, / Scanty fare at best be thine; / Let the soul within be clothed / With a majesty divine.
Poor though I am, despised, forgot, / Yet God,
my God, forgets me not; / And he is safe, and must succeed, / For whom the Lord vouchsafes to plead.
Poor, wandering, wayward man! Art thou not tired, and beaten with stripes, even as I am? Ever, whether thou bear the royal mantle or the beggar's gaberdine, art thou so weary, so heavy-laden; and thy bed of rest is but a grave.
Poor when I have, poor when I haven't, poor will I ever be.
Poortith
Popular glory is a perfect coquette; her lovers must toil, feel every inquietude, indulge every caprice, and perhaps at last be jilted into the bargain.
Popular opinion is the greatest lie in the world.
Popular opinions, on subjects not palpable to sense, are often true, but seldom or never the whole truth.
Popularity is a blaze of illumination, or alas! of conflagration, kindled round a man; showing what is in him; not putting the smallest item more into him; often abstracting much from him; conflagrating the poor man himself into ashes and "caput mortuum."
Populus me sibilat; at mihi plaudo / Ipse domi, simul ac nummos contemplor in arca
Populus vult decipi; decipiatur
Por mucho madrugar, no amanéce mas aina
Porcus Epicuri
Porro unum est necessarium
Porte fermée, le diable s'en va
Portrait-painting may be to the painter what the practical knowledge of the world is to the poet, provided he considers it as a school by which he is to acquire the means of perfection in his art, and not as the object of that perfection.
Portraiture is the basis and the touchstone of historic painting.
Positive happiness is constitutional and incapable of increase; misery is artificial, and generally proceeds from our folly.
Positiveness is a good quality for preachers and orators, because whoever would obtrude his thoughts and reasons upon a multitude, win convince others the more as he appears convinced himself.
Posse comitatus
Possession is nine-tenths of the law.
Possession of land implies the duty of living on it, and by it, if there is enough to live on; then ... if there is more land than enough for one's self, the duty of making it fruitful and beautiful for as many more as can live on it.
Possunt quia posse videntur
Post bellum auxilium
Post cineres gloria sera venit
Post epulas stabis vel passus mille meabis
Post equitem sedet atra cura
Post hoc; ergo propter hoc
Post mediam noctem visus quum somnia vera
Post nubila Phœbus
Post prælia præmia
Post tenebras lux
Post tot naufragia portum
Posthumous charities are the very essence of selfishness, when bequeathed by those who, when alive, would part with nothing.
Postulata
Pot! don't call the kettle black.
Potatoes don't grow by the side of the pot.
Potentissimus est, qui se habet in potestate
Potter is jealous of potter, and craftsman of craftsman; and poor man has a grudge against poor man, and poet against poet.
Pound an almond, and the clear white colour will be altered into a dirty one, and the sweet taste into an oily one.
Pour avoir du goût, il faut avoir de l'âme
Pour bien connaître un homme il faut avoir mangé un boisseau de sel avec lui
Pour bien désirer
Pour bien instruire, il ne faut pas dire tout ce
qu'on sait, mais seulement ce qui convient à ceux qu'on instruit
Pour comble de bonheur
Pour connaître le prix de l'argent, il faut être obligé d'en emprunter
Pour connaître les autres, il faut se connaître soi-même
Pour couper court
Pour dompter les anglais, / Il faut bâtir un
pont / Sur le Pas-de-Calais
Pour encourager les autres
Pour être assez bon, il faut l'être trop
Pour exécuter de grandes choses il faut vivre comme si on ne devait jamais mourir
Pour faire de l'esprit
Pour faire rire
Pour faire un bon ménage il faut que l'homme soit sourd et la femme aveugle
Pour forth thy fervours for a healthful mind, / Obedient passions, and a will resigned; / For love, which scarce collective man can fill; / For patience, sovereign o'er transmuted ill; / For faith, that, panting for a happier seat, / Counts death kind Nature's signal of retreat.
Pour grands que soient les rois, ils sont ce que nous sommes; / Ils peuvent se tromper comme les autres hommes
Pour l'ordinaire la fortune nous vend bien chèrement, ce qu'on croit qu'elle nous donne
Pour parvenir à bonne foy
Pour qui ne les croit pas, il n'est pas de prodiges
Pour ranger le loup, il faut le marier
Pour savoir quelles étoient véritablement les opinions des hommes, je devois plutôt prendre garde à ce qu'ils pratiquoient qu'à ce qu'ils disoient
Pour se faire valoir
Pour s'établir dans le monde, on fait tout ce que l'on peut pour y paraître établi
Pour soutenir les droits que le ciel autorise, / Abîme tout plutôt; c'est l'esprit de l'église
Pour tromper un rival l'artifice est permis: /
On peut tout employer contre ses ennemis
Pour un plaisir mille douleurs
Pour y parvenir
Povertà non ha parenti
Poverty and hunger have many learned disciples.
Poverty breeds strife.
Poverty breeds wealth, and wealth in its turn breeds poverty. The earth to form the mould is taken out of the ditch; and whatever may be the height of the one will be the depth of the other.
Poverty consists in feeling poor.
Poverty demoralises.
Poverty ever comes at the call.
Poverty has no greater foe than bashfulness.
Poverty, incessant drudgery, and much worse evils, it has often been the lot of poets and wise men to strive with, and their glory to conquer.
Poverty is but as the pain of piercing the ears of a maiden, and you hang jewels in the wound.
Poverty is in want of much, avarice of everything.
Poverty is no crime and no credit.
Poverty is not a shame, but the being ashamed
of it is.
Poverty is often concealed in splendour, and often in extravagance. It is the care of a great part of mankind to conceal their indigence from the rest. They support themselves by temporary expedients, and everyday is lost in contriving for to-morrow.
Poverty is the mither
Poverty is the only load which is the heavier the more loved ones there are to assist in supporting it.
Poverty is the reward of idleness.
Poverty makes people satirical--soberly, sadly,
bitterly satirical.
Poverty of soul is irreparable.
Poverty often deprives a man of all spirit and virtue. It is hard for an empty bag to stand upright.
Poverty palls the most generous spirits; it cows industry and casts resolution itself into despair.
Poverty persuades a man to do and suffer everything that he may escape from it.
Poverty should engender an honest pride, that
it may not lead and tempt us to unworthy actions.
Poverty sits by the cradle of all our great men, and rocks them up to manhood.
Poverty snatches the reins out of the hands of piety.
Poverty takes away so many means of doing good, and produces so much inability to resist evil, both natural and moral, that it is by all virtuous means to be avoided.
Poverty treads upon the heels of great and unexpected riches.
Poverty wants some, luxury many, and avarice
all things.
Power and permanence reside only in limitations.
Power belongeth unto God.
Power cannot have too gentle an expression.
Power exercised with violence has seldom been of long duration, but temper and moderation generally produce permanence in all things.
Power, in its quality and degree, is the
measure of manhood.
Power is according to quality, not quantity. How much more are men than nations?
Power is ever stealing from the many to the few.
Power is no blessing in itself, but when it is employed to protect the innocent.
Power is nothing but as it is felt, and the delight of superiority is proportionate to the resistance overcome.
Power is so characteristically calm, that calmness
in itself has the aspect of strength.
Power, like a desolating pestilence, / Pollutes whate'er it touches; and obedience, / Bane of all genius, virtue, freedom, truth, / Makes slaves of men, and of the human frame a mechanized automaton.
Power, like the diamond, dazzles the beholder, and also the wearer; it dignifies meanness; it magnifies littleness; to what is contemptible, it gives authority; to what is low, exaltation.
Power to do good is the true and lawful end of aspiring.
Power will intoxicate the best hearts, as wine the strongest heads. No man is wise enough, no man good enough, to be trusted with unlimited power.
Power's footstool is opinion, and his throne the
human heart.
Powerful attachment will give a man spirit and confidence which he could by no means call up or command of himself; and in this mood he can do wonders which would not be possible to him without it.
Practically men have come to imagine that the laws of this universe, like the laws of constitutional countries, are decided by voting; that it is all a study of division-lists, and for the universe too depends a little on the activity of the whippers-in.
Practice aims at what is immediate; speculation at what is remote. In practical life, the wisest and soundest men avoid speculation, and ensure success, because, by limiting their range, they increase the tenacity with which they grasp events, while in speculative life the course is exactly the reverse, since in that department the greater the range the greater the command.
Practice in time becomes second nature.
Practice is everything.
Practice makes perfect.
Practice must settle the habit of doing without reflecting on the rule.
Practise thrift, or else you'll drift.
Præcedentibus insta
Præcepta ducunt, at exempla trahunt
Præmia virtutis honores
Præsis ut prosis
Præsto et persto
Praise a fool and you may make him useful.
Praise a fool, and you water his folly.
Praise follows truth afar off, and only overtakes
her at the grave. Plausibility clings to her skirts and holds her back till then.
Praise from an enemy is the most pleasing of all commendations.
Praise God more, and blame neighbours less.
Praise is indeed the consequence and encouragement of virtue; but it is sometimes so unseasonably applied as to become its bane and corruption too.
Praise is so pleasing to the mind of man that it is the original motive of almost all our actions.
Praise is the tribute of men, but felicity the
gift of God.
Praise is virtue's shadow; who courts her doth more the handmaid than the dame admire.
Praise, like gold and diamonds, owes its value only to its scarcity.
Praise makes good men better, and bad men worse.
Praise Peter, but don't find fault with Paul.
Praise the bridge which carries you over.
Praise the hill, but keep below.
Praise the sea, but keep on land.
Praise undeserved is satire in disguise.
Pray devoutly, / And hammer stoutly.
Pray to God, but keep the hammer going.
Pray to God, sailor, but pull for the shore.
Prayer and practice is good rhyme.
Prayer and provender never hinder a journey.
Prayer is a groan.
Prayer is a powerful thing; for God has bound and tied himself thereto.
Prayer is a shield to the soul, a sacrifice to God, and a scourge to Satan.
Prayer is a study of truth,--a sally of the soul into the unfound infinite.
Prayer is a turning of one's soul, in heroic reverence, in infinite desire and endeavour, towards the Highest, the All-excellent, Supreme.
Prayer is intended to increase the devotion of
the individual, but if the individual himself prays he requires no formulæ.... Real inward devotion knows no prayer but that arising from the depths of its own feelings.
Prayer is the aspiration of our poor, struggling, heavy-laden soul towards its Eternal Father, and, with or without words, ought not to become impossible, nor need it ever. Loyal sons and subjects can approach the King's throne who have no "request" to make there except that they may continue loyal.
Prayer is the cable, at whose end appears / The anchor hope, ne'er slipp'd but in our fears.
Prayer is the Christian's vital breath, / The Christian's native air.
Prayer is the slender nerve that moves the muscles of Omnipotence.
Prayer is the soul's sincere desire, / Uttered
or unexpressed, / The motion of a hidden fire that trembles in the breast.
Prayer is the wing wherewith the soul flies to heaven; and meditation the eye with which we see God.
Prayer knocks till the door opens.
Prayer, like Jonathan's bow, returns not empty.
Prayer moves the hand that moves the universe.
Prayer must not come from the roof of the
mouth, but from the root of the heart.
Prayer purifies; it is a self-preached sermon.
Prayer should be the key of the day and the lock of the night.
Prayer that craves a particular commodity, anything less than all good, is vicious. As a means to effect a private end, it is meanness and theft.
Prayers are but the body of the bird; desires are its angel's wings.
Praying's the end of preaching.
Preaching is of much avail, but practice is far more effective. A godly life is the strongest argument that you can offer to the sceptic.
Preaching is the expression of the moral sentiment in application to the duties of life.
Précepte commence, exemple achève
Precepts or maxims are of great weight; and a few useful ones at hand do more toward a happy life than whole volumes that we know not where to find.
Preces armatæ
Precious beyond price are good resolutions. Valuable beyond price are good feelings.
Precious ointments are put in small boxes.
Predominant opinions are generally the
opinions of the generation that is vanishing.
Prefer loss before unjust gain; for that brings grief but once, this for ever.
Prejudice is a prophet which prophesies only evil.
Prejudice is the child of ignorance.
Prejudice squints when it looks, and lies when it talks.
Prejudice, which he pretends to hate, is man's
absolute lawgiver; mere use-and-wont everywhere leads him by the nose: thus let but a rising of the sun, let but a creation of the world happen twice, and it ceases to be marvellous, to be noteworthy or noticeable.
Prendre la clef des champs
Prendre les choses au pis
Prends le premier conseil d'une femme et non le second
Prends moi tel que je suis
Present fears / Are less than horrible imaginings.
Preserve the rights of inferior places, and think it more honour to direct in chief than to be busy in all.
Pressure alone causes water to rise and directs it.
Presumption is our natural and original disease.
Presumptuousness, which audaciously strides over all the steps of gradual culture, affords little encouragement to hope for any masterpiece.
Prêt d'accomplir
Prêt pour mon pays
"Pretty Pussy" will not feed a cat.
Prevention is better than cure.
Pria Veneziani, poi Christiane
Pride adds to a man's stature; vanity only
puffs him out.
Pride and grace ne'er dwell in ae place.
Pride and poverty are ill met, yet often live together.
Pride feels no cold.
Pride flows from want of reflection and ignorance of ourselves. Knowledge and humility come upon us together.
Pride goeth before destruction, and a haughty
spirit before a fall.
Pride hath no other glass to show itself but pride.
Pride, ill-nature, and want of sense are the three great sources of ill-manners; without some one of these defects no man will behave himself ill for want of experience, or what, in the language of fools, is called knowing the world.
Pride is a flower that grows in the devil's garden.
Pride is lofty, calm, immovable; vanity is uncertain, capricious, and unjust.
Pride is still aiming at the blest abodes; /
Men would be angels, angels would be gods; / Aspiring to be gods, if angels fell, / Aspiring to be angels, men rebel.
Pride is the source of a thousand virtues; vanity is that of nearly all vices and all perversities.
Pride must suffer pain.
Pride never leaves its master till he gets a fa'.
Pride of origin, whether high or low, springs from the same principle in human nature; one is but the positive, the other the negative, pole of a single weakness.
Pride, the never-failing vice of fools.
Pride will have a fall; for pride goeth before, and shame cometh after.
Pride with pride will not abide.
Pride would never owe, nor self-love ever pay.
Pride's chickens have bonny feathers, but bony bodies.
Priestcraft is no better than witchcraft.
Priesthoods that do not teach, aristocracies that do not govern; the misery of that, and the misery of altering that, are written in Belshazzar fire-letters on the history of France.
Priests pray for enemies, but princes kill.
Prima et maxima peccantium est pœna peccasse
Prima facie
Primo avulso non deficit alter / aureus
Primum mobile
Primus in orbe Deos fecit timor
Primus inter pares
Primus sapientiæ gradus est falsa intelligere
Princes and lords are but the breath of kings, /
"An honest man's the noblest work of God."
Princes and lords may flourish or may fade; / A breath can make them, as a breath has made.
Principes mortales, rempublicam æternam
Principibus placuisse viris non ultima laus est
Principiis obsta; sero medicina paratur, / Cum mala per longas convaluere moras
Principis est virtus maxima nosse suos
Principle is a passion for truth.
Principle is ever my motto, not expediency.
Prisoners of hope.
Pristinæ virtutis memores
Priusquam incipias consulto, et ubi consulueris mature facto opus est
Private affection bereaves us easily of a right judgment.
Private credit is wealth; public honour is security. The feather that adorns the royal bird supports its flight; strip him of his plumage, and you fix him to the earth.
Private judgment with the accent on "private" is self-will; but with the accent on "judgment," it is freedom, free-will.
Private opinion is weak, but public opinion is
almost omnipotent.
Private reproof is the best grave for private faults.
Private self-regard must have been wholly subordinated to, if not entirely cast out by, a higher principle of action and a purer affection before a man can become either truly moral or religious.
Privatorum conventio juri publico non derogat
Privatus illis census erat brevis, / Commune magnum
Privilegium est quasi privata lex

Pro rege et patria
Pro rege, lege, et grege

Pro tempore

Pro virtute felix temeritas
Probably imposture is of a sanative, anodyne nature, and man's gullibility not his worst blessing.
Probably men were never born demigods in any
century, but precisely god-devils as we see; certain of whom do become a kind of demigods.
Probatum est
Probitas laudatur, et alget
Probitas verus honos
Probitate et labore
Probity is as rarely in accord with interest as
reason is with passion.
Probum non pœnitet
Procellæ quanto plus habent virium tanto minus temporis

Procul a Jove, procul a fulmine.
Procul O! procul este, profani
Prodesse quam conspici
Prodigus et stultus donat quæ spernit et odit. / Hæc seges ingratos tulit, et feret omnibus annis
Productions (of a certain artistic quality) are at present possible which are nought
Productions (of a certain artistic quality) are at present possible which are nought 
 
Productions (of a certain artistic quality) are at present possible which are nought  nothing in them, and not bad, because a general form after some good model has of the author.
Profaneness is a brutal vice; he who indulges in it is no gentleman.
Professional critics are incapable of distinguishing
and appreciating either diamonds in the rough state or gold in bars. They are traders, and in literature know only the coins that are current. Their critical laboratory has scales and weights, but neither crucible nor touchstone.
Proffered service stinks
Profligacy consists not in spending years of time or chests of money, but in spending them off the line of your career.
Profound joy has more of severity than gaiety in it.
Progress begins with the minority.
Progress is the law of life--man is not man as
yet.
Progress, man's distinctive mark alone, / Not God's and not the beasts': God is, they are; / Man partly is, and wholly hopes to be.
Progress--the stride of God.
Prohibetur ne quis faciat in suo, quod nocere potest in alieno
Prolonged endurance tames the bold.
Promettre c'est donner, espérer c'est jouir
Promise is most given when the least is said.
Promises make debts, and debts make promises.
Promises may get friends, but it is performance that must nurse and keep them.
Proof of a God? A probable God! The smallest of finites struggling to prove to itself ... and include within itself, the Highest Infinite, in which, by hypothesis, it lives and moves and has its being! Man, reduced to wander about, in stooping posture, with painfully-constructed sulphur-match, and farthing rushlight, or smoky tar-link, searching for the sun.
Prope ad summum, prope ad exitum
Propensity to hope and joy is real riches; one to fear and sorrow, real poverty.
Proper words in proper places make the true
definition of a style.
Properly speaking, the land belongs to these two: to the Almighty God and to all His children of men that have ever worked well on it, or shall ever work well on it.
Properly thou hast no other knowledge but what thou hast got by working.
Property has its duties as well as its rights.
Property, O brother? Of my body I have but a liferent.... But my soul, breathed into me by God, my Me, and what capability is there, I call that mine and not thine. I will keep that, and do what work I can with it; God has given it me; the devil shall not take it away.
Property there is among us valuable to the
auctioneer; but the accumulated manufacturing, commercial, economic skill which lies impalpably warehoused in English hands and heads, what auctioneer can estimate?
Prophecy, not poetry, is the thing wanted in these days. How can we sing and paint when we do not yet believe and see?
Prophete rechts, Prophete links / Das Weltkind in der Mitten
Propositi tenax
Propriæ telluris herum natura, neque illum, / Nec me, nec quemquam statuit. Nos expulit ille: / Illum aut nequities, aut vafri inscitia juris, / Postremo expellet certe vivacior hæres
Propriety of thought and propriety of diction
are commonly found together. Obscurity and affectation are the two greatest faults of style.
Proprio motu
Proprio vigore
Proprium humani ingenii est odisse quem læseris
Proque sua causa quisque disertus erat
Prose, words in their best order; poetry, the
best words in the best order.
Prosperity destroys fools and endangers the wise.
Prosperity doth best discover vice, and adversity doth best discover virtue.
Prosperity is not without many fears and distastes; and adversity is not without comforts and hopes.
Prosperity is the blessing of the Old Testament; adversity is the blessing of the New, which carrieth the greater benediction and the clearer revelation of God's favour.
Prosperity is the touchstone of virtue; for it
is less difficult to bear misfortunes than to remain uncorrupted by pleasure.
Prosperity seems to be scarcely safe, unless it be mixed with a little adversity.
Prosperity tries the fortunate, adversity the great.
Prosperum et felix scelus / Virtus vocatur
Protectio trahit subjectionem, et subjectio protectionem
Protestantism is a revolt against false sovereigns;
the painful but indispensable first preparation for true sovereigns getting place among us.
Proud people are intolerably selfish, and the vain are gentle and giving.
Prove all things; hold fast that which is good.
Proverbs are easily made in cold blood.
Proverbs are mental gems gathered in the diamond-fields of the mind.
Proverbs are short sentences drawn from long
experience.
Proverbs are the abridgments of wisdom.
Proverbs are the daughters of daily experience.
Proverbs are the wisdom of ages.
Proverbs are the wisdom of the streets.
Proverbs cover the whole field of man as he is,
and life as it is, not of either as they ought to be.
Proverbs have been always dear to the true intellectual aristocracy of a nation.
Proverbs have, not a few of them, come down to us from remotest antiquity, borne safely upon the waters of that great stream of time which has swallowed so much beneath its waves.
Proverbs have pleased not one nation only, but many, so that they have made themselves a home in the most different lands.
Proverbs, like the sacred books of each nation, are the sanctuary of the intuitions.
Proverbs please the people, and have pleased
them for ages.
Proverbs possess so vigorous a principle of life, as to have maintained their ground, ever new and ever young, through all the centuries of a nation's existence.
Proverbs were anterior to books, and formed the wisdom of the vulgar, and in the earliest ages were the unwritten laws of morality.
Provide things honest in the sight of all men.
Providence certainly does not favour individuals, but the deep wisdom of its counsels extends to the instruction and ennoblement of all.
Providence conceals itself in the details of human affairs, but becomes unveiled in the generalities of history.
Providence gives the power, of which reason teaches the use.
Providence has a wild, rough, incalculable road to its end; and it is no use to try to whitewash its huge, mixed instrumentalities, to dress up that terrific benefactor in a clean shirt and white neckcloth of a student in divinity.
Providence has decreed that those common acquisitions--money, gems, plate, noble mansions, and dominion--should be sometimes bestowed on the indolent and unworthy; but those things which constitute our true riches, and which are properly our own, must be procured by our own labour.
Providence has given to the French the empire
of the land; to the English, that of the sea; to the Germans, that of--the air.
Providence is but another name for natural law.
Providence is my next-door neighbour.
Providence is not counteracted by any means which Providence puts into our power.
Providence may change, but the promise must stand.
Providence often puts a large potato in a little
pig's way.
Providence provides for the provident.
Provision is the foundation of hospitality, and thrift the fuel of magnificence.
Provocarem ad Philippum, inquit, sed sobrium
Proximorum incuriosi, longinqua sectamur
Proximus a tectis ignis defenditur ægre
Proximus ardet Ucalegon
Proximus sum egomet mihi
Prudence and greatness are ever persuading us to contrary pursuits. The one instructs us to be content with our station, and to find happiness in bounding every wish: the other impels us to superiority, and calls nothing happiness but rapture.
Prudence and love are not made for each other; as the love increases, prudence diminishes.
Prudence is a necessary ingredient in all the
virtues, without which they degenerate into folly and excess.
Prudence is that virtue by which we discern what is proper to be done under the various circumstances of time and place.
Prudence is the virtue of the senses, the science of appearances, the outmost action of the inward life, God taking thought for oxen.
Prudens futuri temporis exitum / Caliginosa nocte premit Deus; / Ridetque, si mortalis ultra / Fas trepidat
Prudens interrogatio quasi dimidium sapientiæ
Prudens qui patiens
Prudens simplicitas
Prudent and active men, who know their strength and use it with limitation and circumspection, alone go far in the affairs of the world.
Prudentia et constantia
Prudentis est mutare consilium; stultus sicut luna mutatur
Prüft das Geschick dich, weiss es wohl warum; /
Es wünschte dich enthaltsam! Folge stumm
Pshaw! what is this little dog-cage of an earth? what art thou that sittest whining there? Thou art still nothing, nobody; true, but who then is something, somebody?
Public affairs ought to progress quickly or slowly, but the people have always too much action or too little. Sometimes with their hundred thousand arms they will overthrow everything, and sometimes with their hundred thousand feet they will crawl along like insects.
Public feeling now is apt to side with the persecuted, and our modern martyr is full as likely to be smothered with roses as with coals.
Public instruction should be the first object of government.
Public opinion is a second conscience.
Public opinion is a weak tyrant compared with our own private opinion. What a man thinks of himself, that it is which determines, or rather indicates, his fate.
Public opinion is democratic.
Public opinion is the mixed result of the intellect of the community acting upon general feeling.
Publicum bonum privato est præferendum
Publicum meritorum præmium
Pulchre! bene! recte!
Pulvis et umbra sumus, fruges consumere nati
Punctuality is the soul of business.
Punishment follows hard upon crime.
Punishment is justice for the unjust.
Punishment is the last and the worst instrument in the hands of the legislator for the prevention of crime.
Punishment of a miser--to pay the drafts of his heir in his tomb.
Puras Deus non plenas adspicit manus
Purchase the next world with this; thus shalt
thou win both.
Pure enjoyment and true usefulness can only be reciprocal.
Pure love cannot merely do all, but is all.
Pure religion and undefiled before God and the Father is this: To visit the fatherless and widows in their affliction, and to keep himself unspotted from the world.
Pure truth, like pure gold, has been found unfit for circulation, because men have discovered that it is far more convenient to adulterate the truth than to refine themselves. They will not advance their minds to the standard, therefore they lower the standard to their minds.
Puridad de dos, puridad de Dios; puridad de
tres, de todos es
Purity and simplicity are the two wings with which man soars above the earth and all temporary nature. Simplicity is in the intention, purity in the affection; simplicity turns to God; purity unites with and enjoys Him.
Purity is the feminine, truth the masculine of honour.
Purity of mind and conduct is the first glory of a woman.
Purpose barred, it follows, / Nothing is done to purpose.
Purpose is what gives life a meaning.
Purposes, like eggs, unless they be hatched into action, will run into rottenness.
Pursuit of knowledge under difficulties.
Pushing any truth out very far, you are met by a counter-truth.
Put a knife to thy throat, if thou be a man given to appetite.
Put a stout heart to a stey
Put a tongue / In every wound of Cæsar that should move / The stones of Rome to rise and mutiny.
Put a young healthy soul full of life under the teaching of the Graces, and the soul's body and workmanship will become transparent of the soul's self.
Put armour on thine ears and on thine eyes.
Put money in thy purse.
Put no trust in money; put your money in
trust.
Put not all your crocks on one shelf.
Put not all your eggs in one basket.
Put not forth thyself in the presence of the king, and stand not in the place of great men; for better it is that it be said unto thee, Come up hither; than that thou shouldest be put lower in the presence of the prince whom thine eyes have seen.
Put the saddle on the right horse.
Put your best foot foremost.
Put your foot down where you mean to stand.
Put your hand no farther than your sleeve will reach.
Put your hand quickly to your hat and slowly to your purse, and you'll take no harm.
Put your own shoulder to the wheel.
Put your trust in God, and keep your powder
dry.
Putting out the natural eye of one's mind to see better with a telescope.
Qu'est ce donc que l'aristocratie? L'aristocratie! je vais vous le dire: l'aristocratie, c'est la ligue, la coalition de ceux qui veulent consommer sans produire, vivre sans travailler, occuper toutes les places sans être en état de les remplir, envahir tous les honneurs sans les avoir mérités: voilà l'aristocratie!
Qu'est-ce que le Tiers-Etat. Rien! Que veut-il être? Tout
Qu'est-ce qu'un noble? Un homme qui s'est donné la peine de naître
Qu'heureux est le mortel qui, du monde ignoré, /
Vit content de soi-même en un coin retiré!
Qu'il faut à chaque mois, / Du moins s'enyvre une fois
Qu'on me donne six lignes écrites de la main du plus honnête homme, j'y trouverai de quoi le faire pendre
Qu'on parle bien ou mal du fameux cardinal, / Ma prose ni mes vers n'en diront jamais rien; / Il m'a fait trop de bien pour en dire du mal, / Il m'a fait trop de mal pour en dire du bien
Qu'un joueur est heureux! sa poche est un trésor! / Sous ses heureuses mains le cuivre devient or
Qu'une nuit paraît longue à la douleur qui veille!
Qua vincit victos protegit ille manu
Quackery has no friend like gullibility.
Quadrupedante putrem sonitu quatit ungula
campum
Quæ amissa salva
Quæ e longinquo magis placent
Quæ fuerant vitia mores sunt
Quæ fuit durum pati / Meminisse dulce est
Quæ infra nos nihil ad nos
Quæ lucis miseris tam dira cupido?
Quæ peccamus juvenes ea luimus senes
Quæ regio in terris nostri non plena laboris?
Quæ sint, quæ fuerint, quæ mox ventura trahantur
Quæ supra nos nihil ad nos
Quæ sursum volo videre
Quæ te dementia cepit?
Quæ virtus et quanta, boni, sit vivere parvo!
Quæ volumus et credimus libenter, et quæ sentimus ipsi reliquos sentire putamus
Quæque ipse miserrima vidi et quorum pars
magna fui
Quære verum
Quærenda pecunia primum, / Virtus post nummos
Quærens quem devoret
Quæstio vexata
Quævis terra alit artificem
Qualem commendes etiam atque etiam aspice, ne mox / Incutiant aliena tibi peccata pudorem
Quales sunt summi civitatis viri talis est civitas
Qualis avis, talis cantus; qualis vir, talis oratio
Qualis rex, talis grex
Qualis sit animus, ipse animus nescit
Qualis vita, finis ita
Quality is better than quantity.
Quam continuis et quantis longa senectus / Plena malis!
Quam inique comparatum est, hi qui minus habent / Ut semper aliquid addant divitioribus!
Quam magnum vectigal sit parsimonia!
Quam parva sapientia regatur
Quam prope ad crimen sine crimine!
Quam temere in nosmet legem sancimus iniquam!
Quam veterrimus homini optimus est amicus
Quamvis digressu veteris confusus amici /
Laudo tamen
Quand celui à qui l'on parle ne comprend pas et celui qui parle ne se comprend pas, c'est de la métaphysique
Quand l'aveugle porte la bannière, mal pour ceux qui marchent derrière
Quand le peuple est en mouvement, on ne comprend pas par où le calme peut en y rentrer; et quand il est paisible, on ne voit pas par où le calme peut en sortir
Quand les sauvages de la Louisiane veulent avoir du fruit, ils coupent l'arbre au pied et cueillent le fruit; voilà le gouvernement despotique
Quand les vices nous quittent, nous nous flattons
que c'est nous qui les quittons
Quand on a tout perdu, quand on n'a plus d'espoir, / La vie est une opprobre, et la mort un devoir
Quand on est jeune, on se soigne pour plaire, et quand on est vieille, on se soigne pour ne pas déplaire
Quand on est mort, c'est pour longtemps
Quand on n'a pas ce que l'on aime, / Il faut aimer ce que l'on a
Quand on ne trouve pas son repos en soi-même, il est inutile de le chercher ailleurs
Quand on se fait aimer, on n'est pas inutile
Quand on se fait entendre on parle toujours bien
Quand on voit le style naturel, on est tout étonné et ravi; car on s'attendait de voir un auteur, et on trouve un homme
Quand sur une personne on prétend se régler / C'est par les beaux côtés qu'il lui faut ressembler
Quand tout le monde a tort, tout le monde a raison
Quand une fois j'ai pris ma résolution, je vais
droit à mon but, et je renverse tout de ma soutane rouge
Quand une lecture vous élève l'esprit et qu'elle vous inspire des sentiments nobles et courageux, il est bon, et fait de main d'ouvrier
Quando Dios amanece, para todos amanece
Quando el Español canta, ó rabia, ó no tiene blanca
Quando i furbi vanno in processione, il diabolo porta la croce
Quando non c'è, perde la chiesa

Quando vierás tu casa quemar llegate á escalentar
Quandoque bonus dormitat Homerus
Quanta est gula, quæ sibi totos / Ponit apros, animal propter convivia natum
Quanti est sapere!
Quanto la cosa è più perfetta, / Più senta il bene e cosi la doglienza
Quanto piace al mondo è breve sogno
Quanto quisque sibi plura negaverit, / A Dis plura feret
Quantum
Quantum est in rebus inane!
Quantum meruit
Quantum mutatus ab illo
Quantum nobis nostrisque hæc fabula de Christo profuerit notum est
Quantum quisque sua nummorum servat in arca / Tantum habet et fidei

Quarrelling with occasion.
Quarrels would not last long if the fault were only on one side.
Qué es la vida? Un frenesi. / Qué es la vida? Una ilusión. / Una sombra, una ficcion, / Y el mayor bien es pequeño; / Que toda la vida es sueño, / Y los sueños, sueños son!

alla prima

Quelques crimes toujours précèdent les grands crimes

Quem pœnitet peccasse pene est innocens

Quem te Deus esse jussit
Quemcunque miserum videris, hominem scias
Questi non hanno speranza di morte

among gentlemen.
Quey
Qui a bruit de se lever matin peut dormir jusqu'à diner
Qui a nuce nucleum esse vult, frangat nucem
Qui a vécu un seul jour a vécu un siècle
Qui a vu la cour, a vu du monde, ce qu'il y a
de plus beau, le plus spécieux, et le plus orné; qui méprise la cour après l'avoir vu méprise le monde
Qui aime bien, châtie bien
Qui alterum incusat probri eum ipsum se intueri oportet
Qui aura esté une fois bien fol ne sera nulle autre fois bien sage
Qui bene conjiciet, hunc vatem perhibeto optimum
Qui bene imperat, paruerit aliquando necesse
est
Qui brille au second rang s'éclipse au premier
Qui capit ille facit
Qui commence et ne parfait, sa peine perd
Qui conducit
Qui craindra la mort n'entreprendra rien sur
moi: qui méprisera la vie sera toujours maître de la mienne
Qui craint de souffrir, souffre de crainte
Qui de contemnenda gloria libros scribunt, nomen suum inscribunt
Qui dedit hoc hodie, cras, si volet, auferet
Qui est maître de sa soif est maître de sa santé
Qui est plus esclave qu'un courtisan assidu si
ce n'est un courtisan plus assidu?
Qui facit per alium facit per se
Qui fingit sacros auro vel marmore vultus, / Non facit ille deos: qui rogat, ille facit
Qui fit, Mæcenas, ut nemo, quam sibi sortem / Seu ratio dederit, seu fors objecerit, illa / Contentus vivat; laudet diversa sequentes?
Qui genus jactat suum aliena laudat
Qui homo mature quæsivit pecuniam, / Nisi
eam mature parcit, mature esurit
Qui invidet minor est
Qui jacet in terra non habet unde cadat
Qui jeune n'apprend, vieux ne saura
Qui jure suo utitur, neminem lædit
Qui legitis flores et humi nascentia fragra, /
Frigidus, O pueri fugite hinc, latet anguis in herba
Qui mange du pape, en meurt
Qui medice vivit, misere vivit
Qui mentiri aut fallere insuevit patrem, / Tanto magis is audebit cæteros
Qui mores hominum multorum vidit et urbes
Qui n'a, ne peut
Qui n'a pas l'esprit de son âge / De son âge a tout le malheur
Qui n'a plus qu'un moment à vivre / N'a plus rien à dissimuler
Qui n'a point d'amour n'a pas de beaux jours
Qui n'a point de sens à trente ans n'en aura
jamais
Qui n'a rien, ne craint rien
Qui ne craint point la mort ne craint point les menaces
Qui ne sait obéir, ne sait commander
Qui ne sait pas, trouvera à apprendre
Qui ne sait se borner, ne sut jamais écrire
Qui nescit dissimulare, nescit regnare
Qui nescit dissimulare nescit vivere
Qui nil molitur inepte
Qui nil potest sperare, desperet nihil
Qui nolet fieri desidiosus, amet
Qui non est hodie, cras minus aptus erit
Qui non laborat, non manducet
Qui non moderabitur iræ / Infectum volet esse, dolor quod suaserit et mens
Qui non proficit, deficit
Qui non prohibet quod prohibere potest assentire
videtur
Qui nunc it per iter tenebricosum, / Illuc unde negant redire quenquam
Qui parcit virgæ odit filium
Qui pardonne aisément invite à l'offenser
Qui patitur vincit
Qui peccat ebrius luat sobrius

Qui pense

Qui timide rogat, docet negare

Qui uti scit, ei bona
Qui veut la fin, veut les moyens

Qui veut voyager loin ménage sa monture
Qui vit sans folie, n'est pas si sage qu'il croit
Qui vive?
Qui vult decipi, decipiatur
Quick at meat, quick at work
Quick removals are slow prosperings.
Quick resentments are often fatal.
Quick returns make rich merchants.
Quick sensibility is inseparable from a ready understanding.
Quick steps are best over miry ground.
Quick to borrow is always slow to pay.
Quick to learn and wise to know.
Quicken yourself up to duty by the remembrance
of your station, who you are, and what you have obliged yourself to be.
Quicker by taking more time.
Quiconque a beaucoup de témoins de sa mort, meurt toujours avec courage
Quiconque est loup, agisse en loup
Quiconque rougit est déjà coupable; la vraie innocence n'a honte de rien
Quiconque s'imagine la pouvoir mieux écrire,
ne l'entend pas
Quicquid agas, prudenter agas, et respice finem
Quicquid agunt homines, votum, timor, ira, voluptas, / Gaudia, discursus, nostri est farrago libelli
Quicquid excessit modum / Pendet instabili loco
Quicunque turpi fraude semel innotuit, / Etiamsi verum dicit, amittit fidem

Quid clarius astris?

Quiet continuity of life is the principle of human happiness.
Quieta non movere
Quietly do the next thing that has to be done, and allow one thing to follow upon the other.
Quietness is best.

quoque prægravat una, / Atque affigit humo divinæ particulam auræ

Quit not certainty for hope.
Quit the world, and the world forgets you.
