Quotation confesses inferiority.
Quotation, like much better things, has its
abuses. One may quote till one compiles.
Quotations from profane authors, cold allusions, false pathetic, antitheses and hyperboles, are out of doors.
Quum Romæ fueris, Romano vivite more
Quum talis sis, utinam noster esses!
Racine passera comme le café
Rage avails less than courage.
Rage is for little wrongs; despair is dumb.
Rage is mental imbecility.
Raggio d'asino non arriva al cielo
Rags, which are the reproach of poverty, are the beggar's robes and graceful insignia of his profession, his tenure, his full dress, the suit in which he is expected to show himself in public.
Rail not in answer, but be calm, / For silence
yields a rapid balm; / Live it down!
Railing and praising were his usual themes; / And both, to show his judgment, in extremes; / So over-violent or over-civil, / That every man with him was god or devil.
Raillery is a mode of speaking in favour of one's wit against one's good nature.
Raillery is sometimes more insupportable than wrong; because we have a right to resent injuries, but it is ridiculous to be angry at a jest.
Railway travelling is not travelling at all; it is merely being sent to a place, and very little different from becoming a parcel.
Rainy days will surely come; / Take your
friend's umbrella home.
Raise nae mair deils than ye're able to lay.
Raison d'état
Raison d'être
Raisonner sur l'amour, c'est perdre la raison
Rake not into the bowels of unwelcome truth
to save a halfpenny.
Rami felicia poma ferentes
Rank and riches are chains of gold, but still chains.
Rank is a great beautifier.
Rank is but the guinea's stamp, / The man's the gowd for a' that.
Raphael wäre ein grosser Maler geworden,
selbst wenn er ohne Hände auf die Welt gekommen wäre
Rapiamus, amici, / Occasionem de die
Rapt with zeal, pathetic, bold, and strong, / Roll'd the full tide of eloquence along.
Rara avis in terris, nigroque similima cygno
Rara est adeo concordia formæ / Atque pudicitiæ
Rara fides pietasque viris qui castra sequuntur
Rara temporum felicitate, ubi sentire quæ
velis, et quæ sentias dicere licet
Rare benevolence, the minister of God.
Rari nantes in gurgite vasto
Rari quippe boni; numero vix sunt totidem quot / Thebarum portæ, vel divitis ostia Nili
Rarity imparts a charm; thus early fruits and winter roses are most prized; thus coyness sets off an extravagant mistress, while a door ever open tempts no suitor.
Rarity / Of Christian charity / Under the sun.
Raro antecedentem scelestum / Deseruit pede pœna claudo
Raro sermo illis, et magna libido tacendi
Rarus enim ferme sensus communis in illa / Fortuna
Rascals are always sociable, and the test of a man's nobility is the small pleasure he has in others' society.
Rasch tritt der Tod den Menschen an, / Es ist
ihm keine Frist gegeben, / Es stürzt ihn mitten in der Bahn, / Es reisst ihn fort vom vollen Leben. / Bereitet oder nicht; zu gehen, / Er muss vor seinen Richter stehen
Rashness is the faithful but unhappy parent of misfortune.
Rast' ich, so rost' ich
Rast macht Rost
Rathe Niemand ungebeten
Rathen ist leichter denn helfen
Rathen ist nicht zwingen
Rather an egg to-day than a hen to-morrow.
Rather assume thy right in silence and
than voice it with claims and cha
Rather bear those ills we have / Than fly to others that we know not of.
Rather find what beauty is than anxiously inquire
what it is.
Rather go to bed supperless than rise in debt.
Rather let my head stoop to the block than these knees bow to any save to the God of heaven.
Rather than be less, / Cared not to be at all.
Rather to do nothing than to do good is the lowest state of a degraded mind.
Ratio decidendi
Ratio et auctoritas, duo clarissima mundi lumina
Ratio et consilium propriæ ducis artes
Ratio justifica
Ratio quasi quædam lux lumenque vitæ
Ratio suasoria
Rauch ist alles irdsche Wesen; / Wie des Dampfes Säule weht, / Schwinden alle Erdengrössen, / Nur die Götter bleiben stät
Raum für alle hat die Erde
Raum, ihr Herrn, dem Flügelschlag / Einer freien Seele
Raum ist in der kleinsten Hütte / Für ein glücklich liebend Paar
Ravish'd with the whistling of a name.
Rays must converge to a point in order to glow intensely.
Re infecta
Re ipsa repperi, / Facilitate nihil esse homini melius, neque clementia
Re opitulandum non verbis
Re secunda fortis, dubia fugax
Read Homer once, and you can read no more, / For all books else appear so mean, so poor, / Verse will seem prose; but still persist to read, / And Homer will be all the books you need.
Read, mark, learn, and inwardly digest.
Read my little fable: / He that runs may read. / Most can raise the flowers now, / For all have got the seed.
Read not books alone, but men, and amongst them chiefly thyself; if thou find anything questionable there, use the commentary of a severe friend rather than the gloss of a sweet-lipped flatterer; there is more profit in a distasteful truth than deceitful sweetness.
Read not to contradict and confute, nor to
believe and take for granted, nor to find talk and discourse, but to weigh and consider.
Read nothing that you do not care to remember, and remember nothing you do not mean to use.
Read the book you do honestly feel a wish and curiosity to read.
Reader, attend--whether thy soul / Soars fancy's flights beyond the pole, / Or darkling grubs this earthly hole / In low pursuit; / Know, prudent, cautious self-control / Is wisdom's root.
Reader, if thou an oft-told tale wilt trust, / Thou'lt gladly do and suffer what thou must.
Reading Chaucer is like brushing through the
dewy grass at sunrise.
Reading furnishes us only with the materials of knowledge; it is thinking makes what we read ours.
Reading for the sense
will best bring out the rhythm.
Reading is thinking with another's head instead of one's own.
Reading makes a full man, conference a ready man, and writing an exact man. And therefore if a man write little, he had need have a great memory; if he confer little, have a present wit; and if he read little, have much cunning to seem to know that he doth not.
Reading without purpose is sauntering, not
exercise.
Real action is in silent moments.
Real friends are our greatest joy and our greatest sorrow.
Real happiness is cheap enough, yet how dearly we pay for its counterfeit!
Real knowledge consists not in an acquaintance with facts, which only makes a pedant, but in the use of facts, which makes a philosopher.
Real sorrow is almost as difficult to discover
as real poverty. An instinctive delicacy hides the rays of the one and the wounds of the other.
Real ugliness in either sex means always some kind of hardness of heart or vulgarity of education.
Real worth floats not with people's fancies, no more than a rock in the sea rises and falls with the tide.
Real worth requires no interpreter; its everyday deeds form its blazonry.
Reality, if rightly interpreted, is grander than fiction; nay, it is in the right interpretation of reality and history that poetry consists.
Reality is, no doubt, greater and more vital
to know, in so real a world and life, than any fiction; and the thoughts of God, which the facts are, are infinitely more precious than the fancies of men about them, or even according to them; yet is man's power of fancying, or fantasying, in harmony with the fact, the measure of his knowledge of it and vital relationship to it, and the divinely appointed means withal whereby the fact itself is brought home to our affections.
Reality surpasses imagination; and we see breathing, brightening, and moving before our eyes sights dearer to our hearts than any we ever beheld in the land of dreams.
Reason and experience both forbid us to expect that national morality can prevail in exclusion of religious principle.
Reason can never be popular. Passions and feelings may become popular; but reason always remains the sole property of a few eminent individuals.
Reason can no more influence the will and operate as a motive, than the eyes, which show a man his road, can enable him to move from place to place, or than a ship provided with a compass can sail without a wind.
Reason cannot show itself more reasonable
than to cease reasoning on things above reason.
Reason gains all men by compelling none.
Reason has done, what it can do, when it discovers and draws up the law; to execute this law is reserved for him who feels the obligation of it, and has the due firmness of purpose.
Reason has only to do with the becoming, the living; but understanding with the become, the already fixed, that it may make use of it.
Reason! how many eyes hast thou to see evils, and how dim--nay, blind--thou art in preventing them!
Reason is a bee, and exists only on what it
makes; its usefulness takes the place of beauty.
Reason is a historian, but the passions are the actors.
Reason is a very light rider, and easily shook off.
Reason is directed to the process
understanding to the product
The former is nowise concerned about the whither, or the latter about the whence.
Reason is like the sun, of which the light is constant, uniform, and lasting; fancy, a meteor of bright but transitory lustre, irregular in its motion and delusive in its direction.
Reason is progressive; instinct, stationary.
Five thousand years have added no improvement to the hive of the bee nor the house of the beaver.
Reason is the life of the law; nay, the common law itself is nothing else but reason.
Reason
Reason is the test of ridicule, not ridicule the test of truth.
Reason itself is true and just, but the reason of every particular man is weak and wavering.
Reason lies between bridle and spur.
Reason, looking upwards, and carried to the true above, realises a delight in wisdom, unknown to the other parts of our nature.
Reason raise o'er instinct as you can; / In this 'tis God directs, in that 'tis man.
Reason requires culture to expand it. It resembles the fire concealed in the flint, which only shows itself when struck with the steel.
Reason serves when pressed, but honest instinct comes a volunteer.
Reason should direct, and appetite obey.
Reason teaches us to be silent; the heart teaches us to speak.
Reason's a staff for age when Nature's gone; / But youth is strong enough to walk alone.
Reason's glimmering ray / Was lent, not to
assure our doubtful way, / But guide us upward to a better day.
Reason's whole pleasure, all the joys of sense, / Lie in three words,--health, peace, and competence.
Reasonable, or sensible, people are always the best Conversation's Lexicon.
Reasoning against a prejudice is like fighting against a shadow; it exhausts the reasoner, without visibly affecting the prejudice. Argument cannot do the work of instruction any more than blows can take the place of sunlight.
Reasoning banishes reason.
Reasons are the pillars of the fabric of a sermon,
but similitudes are the windows which give the best light.
Rebellentreue ist wankend
Rebellion to tyrants is obedience to God.
Rebuke ought to have a grain more of salt than of sugar.
Rebuke with soft words and hard arguments.
Rebus angustis animosus atque / Fortis appare;
sapienter idem / Contrahes vento nimium secundo / Turgida vela
Rebus in angustis facile est contemnere vitam; / Fortiter ille facit qui miser esse potest
Rebus secundis etiam egregios duces insolescere
Receive what cheer you may; / The night is long that never finds the day.
Receiving a new truth is adding a new sense.
Recepto / Dulce mihi furere est amico
Rechauffé
Recherché
Recht geht vor Macht
Recht stets behält das Schicksal, denn das Herz, / In uns ist sein gebietrischer Vollzieher
Recipiunt feminæ sustentacula a nobis
Reckless youth makes ruefu' age.
Reckon no vice so small that you may commit it, and no virtue so small that you may overlook it.
Reckon what is in a man, not what is on him, if you would know whether he is rich or poor.
Reckoners without their host must reckon
twice.
Recommending secrecy where a dozen of people are acquainted with the circumstance to be concealed, is only putting the truth in masquerade, for the story will be circulated under twenty different shapes.
Recompense injury with justice, and recompense kindness with kindness.
Recompense to no man evil for evil.
Recta actio non erit, nisi recta fuit voluntas, ab hac enim est actio. Rursus, voluntas non erit recta, nisi habitus animi rectus fuerit, ab hoc enim est voluntas
Recte et suaviter
Rectius vives, Licini, neque altum / Semper urgendo, neque, dum procellas / Cautus horrescis, nimium premendo / Littus iniquum
Rectus in curia
Reculer pour mieux sauter
Red as a roost-cock.
Reddere personæ scit convenientia cuique
Reddere qui voces jam scit puer, et pede certo / Signat humum, gestit paribus colludere, et iram / Colligit ac ponit temere, et mutatur in horas
Rede wenig, rede wahr. Zehre wenig, zahle baar
Redeat miseris, abeat fortuna superbis
Reden ist Silber und Schweigen ist Gold
Reden kommt von Natur, Schweigen vom
Verstande
Redeunt Saturnia regna
Redit agricolis labor actus in orbem, / Atque in se sua per vestigia volvitur annus
Redlichkeit gedeiht in jedem Stande
Reductio ad absurdum
Refinement that carries us away from our fellow-men is not God's refinement.
Reflect that life, like every other blessing, derives its value from its use alone.
Reflect upon your present blessings, of which every man has many--not on your past misfortunes, of which all men have some.
Reflection dissolves reverie and burns her delicate wings.
Reform is affirmative, conservatism negative;
conservatism goes for comfort, reform for truth.
Reform is not joyous but grievous; no single man can reform himself without stern suffering and stern working; how much less can a nation of men.
Reform, like charity, must begin at home. Once well at home, how will it radiate outwards, irrepressible, into all that we touch and handle, speak and work; kindling ever new light by incalculable contagion; spreading, in geometric ratio, far and wide; doing good only, wherever it spreads, and not evil.
Reformers

into the arena amid a flourish of drums and trumpets; they must make their debut rather under the badge of the cross, and have been cradled at their birth in a manger; poverty and a humble pedigree is all their inheritance, and their childhood is never touched world.
Reforms are generally most unpopular where most needed.
Refricare cicatricem
Regard not dreams, since they are but the images of our hopes and fears.
Regard not much who is for thee or who against thee; but give all thy care to this, that God be with thee in everything thou doest.
Reges dicuntur multis urgere culullis, / Et torquere mero, quem perspexisse laborent, / An sit amicitia dignus
Regia, crede mihi, res est, succurrere lapsis
Regibus boni quam mali suspectiores sunt,
semperque his aliena virtus formidolosa est
Régime
Regium donum
Regnare nolo, liber ut non sim mihi
Regum æquabat opes animis; seraque revertens / Nocte domum, dapibus mensas onerabat inemptis
Reichen giebt man, Armen nimmt man
Reine d'un jour
Reipublicæ forma laudari facilius quam evenire, et si evenit, haud diuturna esse potest
Reisst den Menschen aus seinen Verhältnissen; und was er dann ist, nur das ist er
Rejecting the miracles of Christ, we still have the miracle of Christ himself.
Rejoice in joyous things--nor overmuch / Let
grief thy bosom touch / Midst evil, and still bear in mind / How changeful are the ways of humankind.
Rejoice, O young man, in thy youth, and let thy heart cheer thee in the days of thy youth, and walk in the ways of thine heart, and in the sight of thine eyes; but know thou that for all these things God will bring thee into judgment.
Rejoice that you have still long to live before the thought comes to you that there is nothing more in the world to see.
Rejoice with them that do rejoice, and weep with them that weep.
Relata refero
Relegare bona religionibus
Relever des bagatelles
Relicta non bene parmula
Religentem esse oportet, religiosum nefas
Religion and education are not a match for evil without the grace of God.
Religion and morality, as they now stand,
compose a practical code of misery and servitude.... How would morality, dressed up in stiff stays and finery, start from her own disgusting image, should she look into the mirror of Nature!
Religion bids man prefer the endurance of a lesser evil before a greater, and nature itself does no less.
Religion, blushing, veils her sacred fires, / And unawares morality expires.
Religion cannot change, though we do.
Religion cannot rise above the state of the votary. Heaven always bears some proportion to earth.
Religion contains infinite sadness. If we are
to love God, he must be in distress
Religion des Kreuzes, nur du verknüpfest, in einem / Kranze der Demut und Kraft doppelte Palme zugleich
Religion gives part of its reward in hand, the present comfort of having done our duty; and for the rest, it offers us the best security that heaven can give.
Religion, if in heavenly truths attired, / Needs only to be seen to be admired.
Religion, if it be true, is central truth; and all knowledge which is not gathered round it, and quickened and illuminated by it, is hardly worth the name.
Religion implies revelation.
Religion is a fire which example keeps alive, and which goes out if not communicated.
Religion is a higher and supernatural life, mystical in its roots and practical in its fruits.
Religion is again here, for whoever will piously struggle upward, and sacredly, sorrowfully refuse to speak lies, which indeed will mostly mean refuse to speak at all on that topic.
Religion is an everlasting lodestar, that beams
the brighter in the heavens the darker here on earth grows the night.
Religion is as necessary to reason as reason to religion.
Religion is life, philosophy is thought.... We need both thought and life, and we need that the two shall be in harmony.
Religion is neither a theology nor a theosophy, but a discipline, a law, a yoke, an indissoluble engagement.
Religion is not a dogma nor an emotion, but a service.
Religion is not a doubt, but a certainty,--or
else a mockery and horror.
Religion is not a method, but a life.
Religion is not an end, but a means.
Religion is not in want of art; it rests on its own majesty.
Religion is nothing if it is not everything; if existence is not filled with it.
Religion is the basis of civil society.
Religion is the best armour in the world, but the worst cloak.
Religion is the eldest sister of philosophy; on whatever subjects they may differ, it is unbecoming in either to quarrel, and most so about their inheritance.
Religion is the highest humanity
of man.
Religion is the most gentlemanly thing in the world. It alone will gentilise, if unmixed with cant.
Religion is the only metaphysic that the multitude
can understand and adopt.
Religion is the spice which is meant to keep life from corruption.
Religion is universal, theology is exclusive; religion is humanitarian, theology is sectarian; religion unites mankind, theology divides it; religion is love--broad and all-comprising as God's love, theology preaches love and practises bigotry; religion looks to the moral worth of man, theology to his creed and denomination.
Religion lies more in walk than in talk.
Religion, like its votaries, while it exists on earth, must have a body as well as a soul.
Religion must always be a crab fruit; it cannot
be grafted and keep its wild beauty.
Religion or worship is the attitude of those who see that, against all appearances, the nature of things works for truth and right for ever.
Religion, poetry, is not dead; it will never die. Its dwelling and birthplace is in the soul of man, and it is eternal as the being of man. In any point of space, in any section of time, let there be a living man; and there is an infinitude above him and beneath him, and an eternity encompasses him on this hand and on that; and tones of sphere-music and tidings from loftier worlds will flit round him, if he can but listen, and visit him with holy influences, even in the thickest press of trivialities or the din of busiest life.
Religion presents few difficulties to the humble, many to the proud, innumerable ones to the vain.
Religion primarily means obedience; bending to something or some one. To be bound, or in bonds, as apprentice; to be bound, or in bonds, by military oath; to be bound, or in bonds, as a servant of man; to be bound, or in bonds, under the yoke of God.
Religion reveals the meaning of life, and science
only applies the meaning to the course of circumstances.
Religion should be the rule of life, not a casual incident in it.
Religion without morality is a superstition and a curse; and anything like an adequate and complete morality without religion is impossible.
Religion would frame a just man; Christ would make a whole man. Religion would save a man; Christ would make him worth saving.
Religionen sind Kinder der Unwissenheit, die ihre Mutter nicht lange überleben
Religions are not proved, are not established,
are not overthrown, by logic. They are, of all the mysteries of nature and the human mind, the most mysterious and inexplicable; they are of instinct, and not of reason.
Religious contention is the devil's harvest.
Religious zeal leads to cleanliness, cleanliness to purity, purity to godliness, godliness to humility, humility to the fear of sin.
Rem acu tetigit
Rem, facias rem, / Si possis recte, si non, quocunque modo rem
Rem tu strenuus auge
"Remain content in the station in which Providence has placed you," is on the whole a good maxim, but it is peculiarly for home use. That your neighbour should, or should not, remain content with his position is not your business; but it is very much your business to remain content with your own.
Remark how many are better off than you are; consider how many are worse.
Remember Atlas was weary.
Remember now thy creator in the days of thy youth.
Remember, now, when you meet your antagonist, to do everything in a mild agreeable manner. Let your courage be keen, but, at the same time, as polished as your sword.
Remember that all tricks are either knavish or childish.
Remember that the time once yours can never be so again.
Remember that with every breath we draw, an ethereal stream of Lethe runs through our whole being, so that we have but a partial recollection of our joys, and scarcely any of our sorrows.
Remember that you are an actor in a drama
of such sort as the Author chooses. If short, then in a short one; if long, then in a long one. If it be His pleasure that you should act a poor man, see that you act it well; or a cripple, or a ruler, or a private citizen. For this is your business, to act well the given part; but to choose it, belongs to another.
Remember this: that your conscience is not a law--no; God and reason made the law, and has placed conscience within you to determine.
Remember thy prerogative is to govern, and not to serve, the things of this world.
Remember your failures are the seed of your most glorious successes. Despond if you must, but don't despair.
Remembrance and reflection how allied! / What thin partitions sense from thought divide!
Remembrance
from which we cannot be driven.
Remembrance makes the poet; 'tis the past, / Lingering within him with a keener sense / Than is upon the thoughts of common men, / Of what has been, that fills the actual world / With unreal likenesses of lovely shapes, / That were and are not.
Remembrance wakes with all her busy train, / Swells at my breast, and turns the past to pain.
Remis velisque
Remis ventisque
Remorse is as the heart in which it grows: /
If that be gentle, it drops balmy dews / Of true repentance; but if proud and gloomy, / It is the poison tree that, pierced to the inmost, / Weeps only tears of poison.
Remorse is the echo of a lost virtue.
Remorse, the fatal egg by pleasure laid.
Remote from man, with God he passed his days; / Prayer all his business, all his pleasure praise.
Remove not the ancient land-mark.
Remove the cause, and the effect will cease.
Renascentur
Render to all their dues.
Render to Cæsar the things that are Cæsar's, and to God the things that are God's.
Renounce, thou must
is the song which sounds for ever in the ears of every one, which every hour sings to us hoarsely our whole life long.
Renovate animos
Renown is not to be sought, and all pursuit of it is vain. A person may, indeed, by skilful conduct and various artificial means, make a sort of name for himself; but if the inner jewel is wanting, all is vanity, and will not last a day.
Rente viagère
Rentes
Rentier
Repartee is perfect when it effects its purpose
with a double edge. It is the highest order of wit, as it bespeaks the coolest yet quickest exercise of genius, at a moment when the passions are roused.
Repentance clothes in grass and flowers the grave in which the past is laid.
Repentance costs very dear.
Repentance hath a purifying power, and every tear is of a cleansing virtue; but these penitential clouds must be still kept dropping; one shower will not suffice; for repentance is not one single action, but a course.
Repentance is accepted remorse.
Repentance is good, but innocence is better.
Repentance is heart's sorrow, and a clear life ensuing.
Repentance is nothing else but a renunciation of our will, and a controlling of our fancies, which lead us which way they please.
Repentance is the daughter of over-haste.
Repentance is the May of the virtues.
Repentance won't cure mischief.
Repente dives nemo factus est bonus
Reperit Deus nocentem
Reply with wit to gravity, and with gravity to wit.
Réponse sans réplique
Report makes crows blacker than they are.
Repose and cheerfulness are the badge of the gentleman--repose in energy. The Greek battle-pieces are calm; the heroes, in whatever violent actions engaged, retain a serene aspect.
Repose and happiness is what thou covetest, but these are only to be obtained by labour.
Repose is as necessary in conversation as in a picture.
Repose is the cradle of power.
Repose without stagnation is the state most
favourable to happiness. "The great felicity of life," says Seneca, "is to be without perturbation."
Reproof is a medicine like mercury or opium; if it be improperly administered, it will do harm instead of good.
Reproof never does a wise man harm.
Reproof on her lips, but a smile in her eye.
Reprove thy friend privately; commend him publicly.
Republics end with luxury; monarchies, with poverty.
Reputation is an idle and false imposition, oft
got without merit, and lost without deserving; you have lost no reputation at all unless you repute yourself such a loser.
Reputation is commonly measured by the acre.
Reputation is in itself only a farthing candle, of a wavering and uncertain flame, and easily blown out, but it is the light by which the world looks for and finds merit.
Reputation is rarely proportioned to virtue.
Reputation is what men and women think of us. Character is what God and angels know of us.
Reputation, reputation, reputation! O I have
lost my reputation. I have lost the immortal part of myself, and what remains is bestial.
Reputation serves to virtue as light does to a picture.
Requiem æternam dona eis, Domine
Requiescat in pace
Rerum cognitio vera, e rebus ipsis est
Res amicos invenit
Res angusta domi
Res est blanda canor; discant cantare puellæ
Res est ingeniosa dare
Res est sacra miser
Res est solliciti plena timoris amor
Res gestæ
Res in cardine est
Res judicata
Res nolunt diu male administrari
Res rustica
Res severa est verum gaudium
Res sunt humanæ flebile ludibrium
Resembles ocean into tempest wrought, / To waft a feather or to drown a fly.
Resentment gratifies him who intended an injury, and pains him unjustly who did not intend it.
Resentment, indeed, may remain, perhaps
cannot be quite extinguished in the noblest minds; but revenge never will harbour there.
Resentment seems to have been given us by Nature for defence, and for defence only; it is the safeguard of justice and the security of innocence.
Reserve the master-blow.
Resignation is putting God between one's self and one's grief.
Resist as much as thou wilt; heaven's ways are heaven's ways.
Resist not evil.
Resist the devil, and he will flee from you.
Resistance ought never to be thought of but when an utter subversion of the laws of the realm threatens the whole frame of our constitution, and no redress can otherwise be hoped for. It therefore does, and ought for ever, to stand in the eye and letter of the law as the highest offence.
Resolution is independent of great age, but without it one lives a hundred years in vain.
Resolution will sometimes relax, and diligence will sometimes be interrupted; but let no accidental surprise or deviation, whether short or long, dispose you to despondency.
Resolutions are well kept when they jump
with inclination.
Resolve, resolve, and to be men aspire. / Exert that noblest privilege, alone / Here to mankind indulged; control desire: / Let godlike Reason, from her sovereign throne, / Speak the commanding word "I will!" and it is done.
Resolved to ruin or to rule the state.
Respect a man, he will do the more.
Respect for one's parents is the highest of the duties of civil life.
Respect for others is the first condition of
"savoir-vivre."
Respect is better procured by exacting than soliciting it.
Respect the burden.
Respect us human, and relieve us poor.
Respect yourself, or no one else will respect you.
Respectable mediocrity offends nobody.
Respice finem
Respicere exemplar vitæ morumque jubebo / Doctum imitatorem, et veras hinc ducere voces
Respondeat superior
Responsibility walks hand in hand with capacity and power.
Rest and be thankful.
Rest and success are fellows.
Rest and undisturbed content have now no place on earth, nor can the greatest affluence of worldly good procure them, ... they are peculiar to the love and fruition of God alone.
Rest is for the dead.
Rest is good after the work is done.
Rest is the sweet sauce of labour.
Rest is won only by work.
Rest not in an ovation, but in a triumph over thy passions.
Rest not upon scattered counsels, for they will rather distract and mislead than settle and direct.
Rest! rest! Shall I not have all eternity to rest in?
Rest thy unrest in England's lawful earth.
Restat iter cœlo: cœlo tentabimus ire; / Da veniam cœpto, Jupiter alte, meo
Restore to God his due in tithe and time: /
A tithe purloined cankers the whole estate.
Restraint and discipline, examples of virtue and of justice, these are what form the education of the world.
Restraint and obstruction
Résumé
Resurgam
Retinens vestigia famæ
Return unto me, and I will return unto you, saith the Lord of hosts.
Revelation may not need the help of reason, but man does, even when in possession of revelation. Reason may be described as the candle in the man's hand, to which revelation brings the necessary flame.
Revelation nowhere burns more purely and more beautifully than in the New Testament.
Revenge, at first though sweet, bitter erelong back on itself recoils.
Revenge barketh only at the stars, and spite
spurns at that she cannot reach.
Revenge commonly hurts both the offerer and the sufferer; as we see in a foolish bee, which in her anger envenometh the flesh and loseth her sting, and so lives a drone ever after.
Revenge converts a little right into a great wrong.
Revenge has no limits, for sin has none.
Revenge is a debt, in the paying of which the greatest knave is honest and sincere, and, so far as he is able, punctual.
"Revenge is a kind of wild justice." It is so,
but without this wild austere stock there would be no justice in the world.
Revenge is a kind of wild justice, which, the more man's nature runs to, the more ought law to weed it out.
Revenge is an act of passion; vengeance, of justice.
Revenge is an inheritance of weak souls.
Revenge is barren of itself; itself is the dreadful food it feeds on; its delight is murder, and its satiety despair.
Revenge is the abject pleasure of an abject
mind.
Revenge of a wrong only makes another wrong.
Revenons à nos moutons
Reverence for human worth, earnest devout search for it, and encouragement of it, loyal furtherance and obedience to it, is the outcome and essence of all true religions, and was and ever will be.
Reverence the highest, have patience with the lowest. Let this day's performance of the meanest duty be thy religion. Are the stars too distant, pick up the pebble that lies at thy feet and from it learn the all.
Reverence
into the world along with him, is the one thing on which all depends for making a man in every point a man.
Reverie is the Sunday of thought.
Reverie, which is thought in its nebulous state, borders closely upon the land of sleep, by which it is bordered as by a natural frontier.
Reviewers are usually people who would have been poets, historians, biographers, if they could; they have tried their talents at one or the other, and have failed; therefore they turn critics.
Reviewers, with some rare exceptions, are a most stupid and malignant race. As a bankrupt thief turns thief-taker in despair, so an unsuccessful author turns critic.
Revocate animos, mœstumque timorem / Mittite
Revolutions are like the most noxious dung-heaps, which bring into life the noblest vegetables.
Revolutions are not made, they come. A revolution is as natural a growth as an oak. It comes out of the past. Its foundations are laid far back.
Revolutions never go backward.
Rex datur propter regnum, non regnum propter regem. Potentia non est nisi ad bonum
Rex est major singulis, minor universis
Rex est qui metuit nihil; / Rex est qui cupit nihil
Rex non potest fallere nec falli
Rex non potest peccare
Rex nunquam moritur
Rex regnat, sed non gubernat
Rhetoric is nothing but reason well dressed and argument put in order.
Rhetoric is the art of ruling the minds of men.
Rhetoric is the creature of art, which he who feels least will most excel in; it is the quackery of eloquence, and deals in nostrums, not in cures.
Rhyme that had no inward necessity to be rhymed; it ought to have told us plainly, without any jingle, what it was aiming at.
Rich gifts wax poor when givers prove unkind.
Rich men are indeed rather possessed by their money than possessors.
Rich men without wisdom and learning are but sheep with golden fleeces.
Rich, not gaudy.
Rich the treasure, / Sweet the pleasure; /
Sweet is pleasure after pain.
Rich with the spoils of time.
Richard's himself again!
Richer than rubies, / Dearer than gold, / Woman, true woman, / Glad we behold!
Riches amassed in haste will diminish; but those collected by hand and little by little will multiply.
Riches and favour go before wisdom and art.
Riches are as a stronghold in the imagination of the rich man.
Riches are for spending, and spending for honour and good actions.
 (lo
Riches are like bad servants, whose shoes are made of running leather, and will never tarry long with one master.
Riches are of little avail in many of the calamities
to which mankind are liable.
Riches are often abused, never refused.
Riches breed care, poverty is safe.
Riches bring cares.
Riches come better after poverty than poverty after riches.
Riches do not consist in having more gold and
silver, but in having more in proportion than our neighbours.
Riches do not exhilarate us so much by their possession as they torment us with their loss.
Riches fineless is as poor as winter / To him that ever fears he shall be poor.
Riches for the most part are hurtful to them that possess them.
Riches have made mair men covetous than covetousness has made men rich.
Riches have wings.
Riches profit not in the day of wrath.
Riches take peace from the soul, but rarely, if ever, confer it.
Riches take wings, comforts vanish, hope withers away, but love stays with us. Love is God.
Riches, though they may reward virtues, yet they cannot cause them; he is much more noble who deserves a benefit than he who bestows one.
Richt wrangs nae man.
Richter sollen zwei gleiche Ohren haben
Ride si sapis
Ridentem dicere verum / Quid vetat?
Ridere in stomacho
Rides in the whirlwind and directs the storm.
Ridet argento domus
Ridetur chorda qui semper oberrat eadem
Ridicule has ever been the most powerful enemy of enthusiasm, and properly the only antagonist that can be opposed to it with success.
Ridicule intrinsically is a small faculty; we may say, the smallest of all faculties that other men are at the pains to repay with any esteem. It is directly opposed to thought, to knowledge, properly so called; its nourishment and essence is denial, which hovers on the surface, while knowledge dwells far below.
Ridicule is a weak weapon when levelled at a
strong mind; but common men are cowards, and dread an empty laugh.
Ridicule, while it often checks what is absurd, fully as often smothers that which is noble.
Ridiculous modes, invented by ignorance and adopted by folly.
Ridiculum acri / Fortius ac melius magnas plerumque secat res
Ridiculus æque nullus est, quam quando esurit
Rien de plus éloquent que l'argent comptant
Rien de plus hautain qu'un homme médiocre devenu puissant
Rien n'a qui assez n'a
Rien n'arrive pour rien
Rien n'empêche tant d'être naturel que l'envie de la paraître
Rien n'est beau que le vrai; le vrai seul est
aimable
Rien n'est plus estimable que la civilité; mais rien de plus ridicule, et de plus à charge, que la cérémonie
Rien n'est plus rare que la véritable bonté; ceux même qui croient en avoir n'ont d'ordinaire que de la complaisance ou de la faiblesse
Rien n'est si dangereux qu'un indiscret ami; / Mieux vaudroit un sage ennemi
Rien ne déconcerte plus efficacement les desseins des pervers, que la tranquillité des grands cœurs
Rien ne m'est sûr que la chose incertaine
Rien ne manque à sa gloire; il manquait à la nôtre
Rien ne pèse tant qu'un secret

Rien ne réussit mieux que le succès

Rien ne s'arrête pour nous
Rien ne sert de courir: il faut partir à point
Rien ne vaut poulain s'il ne rompt son lien
Rien que s'entendre
Right actions for the future are the best apologies for wrong ones in the past.
Right ethics are central, and go from the soul outward. Gift is contrary to the law of the universe.
Right is more beautiful than private affection, and is compatible with universal wisdom.
Right is right, since God is God.
Right wrongs no man.
Righteousness exalteth a nation; but sin is a reproach to any people.
Righteousness keepeth him that is upright in the way.
Rightly, poetry is organic. We cannot know things by words and writing, but only by taking a central position in the universe and living in its forms.
Rightly to be great / Is not to stir without
great argument, / But greatly to find quarrel in a straw / When honour's at the stake.
Rigour pushed too far is sure to miss its aim, however good; as the bow snaps that is bent too stiffly.
Rinasce più gloriosa

Rise, Christopher! thou hast found thy King, and turn / Back to the earth, for I have need of thee. / Thou hast sustained the whole world, bearing me, / The Lord of earth and heaven.
Rise up before the hoary head, and honour
the face of the old man.
Rising genius always shoots forth its rays from among clouds and vapours, but these will gradually roll away and disappear as it ascends to its steady and meridian lustre.
Rising to great place is by a winding stair.

Rivers are roads which travel, and which carry us whither we wish to go.
Rivers cannot fill the sea, that, drinking, thirsteth still.
Rivers flow with sweet waters; but, having joined the ocean, they become undrinkable.
Rivers need a spring.
Roads are many; authentic finger-posts are few.
Roast meat at three fires; as soon as you've basted one, another's burnin'.
Rob not the poor, because he is poor.
Robbing Peter to pay Paul.

Rock of ages, cleft for me, / Let me hide myself in thee.
Rock'd in the cradle of the deep, / I lay me down in peace to sleep.
Rocks whereon greatest men have oftest wreck'd.

Rogues are always found out in some way.
Whoever is a wolf will act as a wolf; that is the most certain of all things.

Roland for an Oliver
Roll on, thou deep and dark blue ocean, roll! / Ten thousand fleets sweep over thee in vain; / Man marks the earth with ruin,--his control / Stops with the shore.

Romæ Tibur amem, ventosus, Tibure Romam
Romance and novel paint beauty in colours more charming than Nature, and describe a happiness that man never tastes. How delusive, how destructive are those pictures of consummate bliss!
Romance has been elegantly defined as the offspring of fiction and love.
Romance is the poetry of literature.
Romance is the truth of imagination and boyhood. Homer's horses clear the world at a bound. The child's eye needs no horizon to its prospect.... The palace that grew up in a night merely awakens a wish to live in it. The impossibilities of fifty years are the common-places of five.
Romance, like a ghost, eludes touching; it is
always where you are not, not where you are. The interview or conversation was prose at the time, but is poetry in memory.
Romam cuncta undique atrocia aut pudenda confluunt celebranturque
Rome
Rome n'est plus dans Rome; elle est toute où je suis
Rome was not built in one day.
Root away / The noisome weeds, which without
profit suck / The soil's fertility from wholesome flowers.

Roses fall, but the thorns remain.
Roses fair on thorns do grow: / And they tell me even so / Sorrows into virtues grow.
Roses grow among thorns.
Roses have thorns, and silver fountains mud; /
Clouds and eclipses stain both moon and sun.
Rough diamonds may sometimes be mistaken for pebbles.
Round numbers are always false.
Round the world, but never in it.

Ruin is most fatal when it begins from the bottom.
Ruins are mile-stones on the road of time.
Ruins are the broken eggshell of a civilisation which time has hatched and devoured.
Rule, Britannia, Britannia rules the waves; / Britons never shall be slaves.
Rule youth weel and age will rule itsel'.
Rules of society are nothing; one's conscience is the umpire.
Rumour is a pipe / Blown by surmises, jealousies, conjectures; / And of so easy and so plain a stop / That the blunt monster with uncounted heads, / The still-discordant wavering multitude, / Can play upon it.
Run here or there, thou wilt find no rest, but in humble subjection to the government of a superior.

Sabbath-days, quiet islands on the tossing sea of life.
Sabbath profaned, / Whate'er may be gained, / Is sure to be followed by sorrow.
Sabbath well spent / Brings a week of content.
Sacco pieno rizza l'orecchio
Sacred courage indicates that a man loves an idea better than all things in the world; that he is aiming neither at self nor comfort, but will venture all to put in act the invisible thought in his mind.
Sacrifice is the first element of religion, and resolves itself, in theological language, into the love of God.
Sacrifice still exists everywhere, and everywhere the elect of each generation suffers for the salvation of the rest.
Sacrifice, which is the passion of great souls,
has never been the law of societies.
Sacrificed his life to the delineating of life.
Sacrificio dell' intelletto
Sad natures are most tolerant of gaiety.
Sad souls are slain in merry company. / Grief best is pleased with grief's society; / True sorrow then is feelingly sufficed / When with like semblance it is sympathised.
Sad wise valour is the brave complexion /
That leads the van and swallows up the cities.
Sad with the whole of pleasure.
Sadness and gladness succeed each other.
Sae rantingly, sae wantonly, / Sae dauntingly gaed he; / He play'd a spring, and danced it round, / Beneath the gallows-tree.
Säen ist nicht so beschwerlich als ernten

Sæpe premente Deo, fert Deus alter opem

Said will be a little ahead, but Done should follow at his heel.
Saint cannot, if God will not.
Saints are sad, because they behold sin (even
when they speculate) from the point of view of the conscience, and not of the intellect.

Salon
Salt and bread make the cheeks red.
Salt is good, but if the salt have lost its savour, wherewith shall it be seasoned? It is neither fit for the land, nor yet for the dunghill; but men cast it out.
Salt is white and pure; there is something holy in salt.
Salt spilt is never all gathered up.
Saltabat elegantius, quam necesse est probæ

Salus populi suprema est lex
Salute thyself: see what thy soul doth wear. / Dare to look in thy chest, for 'tis thine own, / And tumble up and down what thou find'st there.

Sameness is the mother of disgust, variety the cure.

Samson was a strong man, but he could not pay money before he got it.
Sanan llagas, y no malas palabras

Sans le goût, le génie n'est qu'une sublime folie. Ce toucher sûr par qui la lyre ne rend que le son qu'elle doit rendre, est encore plus rare que la faculté qui crée

Sapping a solemn creed with solemn sneer.
Sarcasm I now see to be, in general, the language of the devil.
Sarcasm poisons reproof.
Sardonicus risus
Sartor resartus
Sat cito si sat bene
Sat pulchra, si sat bona
Satan finds some mischief still / For idle hands to do.
Satan's friendship reaches to the prison door.
Satan himself is now transformed into an angel of light.
Satan now is wiser than of yore, / And tempts by making rich, not making poor.
Satan trembles when he sees / The weakest saint upon his knees.
Satiety comes of riches, and contumaciousness of satiety.
Satire has a power of fascination that no other
written thing possesses.
Satire is a sort of glass wherein beholders do generally discover everybody's face but their own.
Satire should, like a polished razor keen, / Wound with a touch that is scarcely seen.
Satires run faster than panegyrics.
Satis diu vel naturæ vel gloriæ
Satis eloquentiæ, sapientiæ parum
Satis est orare Jovem, quæ donat et aufert; / Det vitam, det opes, æquum mi animum ipse parabo
Satis quod sufficit
Satis superque est
Satis superque me benignitas tua / Ditavit
Satis verborum
Satis vixi; invictus enim morior
Satisfaction consists in freedom from pain, which is the positive element of existence.
Satius est recurrere, quam currere male
Sauce for the goose is sauce for the gander.
Saucius ejurat pugnam gladiator, et idem / Immemor antiqui vulneris arma capit
Säume nicht, dich zu erdreisten, / Wenn die Menge zaudernd schweift; / Alles kann der Edle leisten / Der versteht und rasch ergreift

Sauve qui peut
Save a man from his friends, and leave him to struggle with his enemies.
Save a thief from the gallows, and he'll cut your throat.
Save me, and hover o'er me with your wings, / You heavenly guards.
Save something for a sore foot.
Savoir dissimuler est le savoir des rois
Savoir-faire
Savoir-vivre
Savor
shall, / Rede well thyself that other folks can rede, / And truth thee shalt deliver--'tis no drede.
Say little and say well.
Say nay, and take it.
Say no ill of the year till it be past.
Say not always what you know, but always know what you say.
Say not, I will do so to him as he hath done to me; I will render to the man according to his work.
Say not, / This with that lace will do well; /
But, This with my discretion will be brave.
Say not to-morrow; the tongue's slightest slip / Nemesis watches, ere it pass the lip.
Say not, We will suffer, for that ye must; say rather, We will act, for that ye must not
Say nothing, and none can criticise thee.
Say nothing good of yourself, you will be distrusted; say nothing bad of yourself, you wilt be taken at your word.
Say, O wise man, how thou hast come by such
knowledge? Because I never was ashamed to confess my ignorance and ask others.
"Say well" is good, but "Do well" is better.
Say well or be still.
Say, what is taste, but the internal pow'rs / Active and strong, and feelingly alive / To each fine impulse?
Saying and doing are two different things.
Scald not thy lips with another man's porridge.
Scandal breeds hatred, hatred begets divisions, division makes faction, and faction brings ruin.
Scandal ever improves by opposition.
Scandal is the sport of its authors, the dread of fools, and the contempt of the wise.
Scandal, like the Nile, is fed by innumerable streams, and it is extremely difficult to trace it to its source.
Scandal will not rub out like dirt when it is
dry.
Scandalum magnatum
Scarcely anything is perfectly plain but what is also perfectly common.
Scarcely love's utmost may in heaven be; / To hell it reacheth, so 'tis love at all.
Scarcely one man in a thousand is capable of tasting the happiness of others.
Scarceness is what there is the biggest stock
of in the country.
Scarceness o' victual 'ull keep; there's no need to be hasty wi' the cooking.
Scatter with one hand, gather with two.
Scelere velandum est scelus
Scepticism has never founded empires, established principles, or changed the world's heart. The great doers in history have always been men of faith.
Scepticism is not an end but a beginning, is as
the decay of old ways of believing, the preparation afar off for new, wider, and better.
Scepticism is the attitude assumed by the student in relation to the particulars which society adores; but which he sees to be reverent only in their tendency and spirit.
Scepticism is unbelief in cause and effect.
Scepticism means not intellectual doubt alone, but moral doubt; all sorts of infidelity, insincerity, and spiritual paralysis.
Scepticism, with its innumerable mischiefs, what is it but the sour fruit of a most blessed increase, that of knowledge; a fruit, too, that will not always continue sour.
Scepticism writing about belief may have great
gifts; but it is really
Schadet ein Irrtum wohl? Nicht immer! aber das Irren / Immer schadet's. Wie sehr, sieht man am Ende des Wegs
Schall und Rauch umnebeln Himmels-Gluth
Schäme dich deines Handwerks nicht
Schwärmerei
Scheiden, ach Scheiden, Scheiden thut weh!
Scherze nicht mit Ernst
Schick dich in die Zeit
Schicksal und eigene Schuld
Schlägt die Zeit dir manche Wunde, / Manche
Freude bringt ihr Lauf; / Aber eine sel'ge Stunde / Wiegt ein Jahr von Schmerzen auf
Schlägt dir die Hoffnung fehl, nie fehle dir das Hoffen! / Ein Thor ist zugethan, doch tausend sind dir offen
Schlagt ihn tot den Hund! Er ist Rezensent
Schlechtes sucht mit Gutem Streit
Schliesst eure Herzen sorgfältiger, als eure Thore
Schmerz und Liebe ist des Menschen Teil /
Der dem Weltgeschick nicht feig entwichen, / Zieht er aus dem Busen sich den Pfeil, / Ist er für die Welt und Gott verblichen
Scholars are frequently to be met with who are ignorant of nothing saving their own ignorance.
Scholarship, save by accident, is never the measure of a man's power.
Schön ist der Friede! Ein lieblicher Knabe / Liegt er gelagert am ruhigen Bach.... / Aber der Krieg auch hat seine Ehre, / Der Beweger des Menschensgeschicks
Schön sind die Rosen eurer Jugend; / Allein die Zeit zerstöret sie. / Nur die Talente, nur die Tugend / Veralten nicht und sterben nie
Schöne Blumen stehen nicht lange am Wege
Schönheit bändigt allen Zorn
Schrecklich blicket ein Gott, da wo Sterbliche weinen
Schuim is geen bier
Schweig, oder rede etwas, das ist besser denn Schweigen
Schweigen ist das Heiligthum der Klugheit.
Es birgt nicht bloss Geheimnisse, sondern auch Fehler
Schweigen können zeugt von Kraft, schweigen wollen von Nachsicht, schweigen müssen vom Geist der Zeit
Schwer ist es, aus dem Geschrei erhitzter Parteien die Stimme der Wahrheit zu unterscheiden
Science always goes abreast with the just elevation of the man, keeping step with religion and metaphysics; or, the state of science is an index of our self-knowledge.
Science corrects the old creeds ... and necessitates a faith commensurate with the grander orbits and universal laws which it discloses.
Science deals exclusively with things as they
are in themselves.
Science dissects death.
Science does not know its debt to imagination.
Science falsely so called.
Science must have originated in the feeling of something being wrong.
Science has been seriously retarded by the
study of what is not worth knowing and of what is not knowable.
Science has done much for us; but it is a poor science that would hide from us the great deep sacred infinitude of Nescience, on which all science swims as a mere superficial film.
Science has not solved difficulties, only shifted the points of difficulty.
Science is a first-rate piece of furniture for a man's upper chamber if he has common-sense on the ground-floor. But if a man has not got plenty of good common-sense, the more science he has the worse for his patient.
Science is an ocean. It is as open to the cockboat as the frigate. One man carries across it a freightage of ingots, another may fish there for herrings.
Science is busy with the hither-end of
things, not the thither-end.
Science / Is but an exchange of ignorance for that / Which is another kind of ignorance.
Science is for those who learn, poetry for those who know.
Science is nothing but trained and organised common sense.
Science is teaching man to know and reverence truth, and to believe that only so far as he knows and loves it can he live worthily on earth, and vindicate the dignity of his spirit.
Science is the knowledge of constant things,
not merely of passing events, and is properly less the knowledge of general laws than of existing facts.
Science is the systematic classification of experience.
Science lives only in quiet places, and with odd people, mostly poor.
Science rests on reason and experiment, and can meet an opponent with calmness; (but) a creed is always sensitive.
Science sees signs; Poetry, the thing signified.
Scientia nihil aliud est quam veritatis imago
Scientia popinæ
Scientia quæ est remota a justitia, calliditas
potius quam sapientia est appellanda
Scientific, like spiritual truth, has ever from the beginning been descending from heaven to man.
Scientific truth is marvellous, but moral truth is divine; and whoever breathes its air and walks by its light has found the lost paradise.
Scilicet expectes, ut tradet mater honestos / Atque alios mores, quam quos habet?
Scinditur incertum studia in contraria vulgus
Scio cui credidi
Scio: tu coactus tua voluntate es
Scire facias
Scire potestates herbarum usumque medendi
Scire tuum nihil est, nisi te scire hoc sciat alter
Scire ubi aliquid invenire possis, ea demum
maxima pars eruditionis est
Scire volunt omnes, mercedem solvere nemo
Scire volunt secreta domus, atque inde timeri
Scit genius, natale comes qui temperet astrum
Scoglio immoto contro le onde sta
Scorn no man's love, though of a mean degree; /
Love is a present for a mighty king,--/ Much less make any one thine enemy. As guns destroy, so may a little sling.
Scorn to trample upon a worm or to sneak to be an emperor.
Scorn'd, to be scorn'd by one that I scorn, / Is that a matter to make me fret? / That a calamity hard to be borne?
Scots, wha hae wi' Wallace bled, / Scots, wham Bruce has aften led, / Welcome to your gory bed, / Or to victory! / Now's the day and now's the hour; / See the front o' battle lour; / See approach proud Edward's power, / Chains and slavery.
Scotsmen reckon ay frae an ill hour.
Screw not the chord too sharply lest it snap.
Screw your courage to the sticking-place, / And we'll not fail.
Scribendi recte sapere est et principium et fons
Scribere scientes
Scribimus indocti doctique
Scripture, like Nature, lays down no definitions.
Scruples, temptations, and fears, and cutting perplexities of heart, are frequently the lot of the most excellent persons.
Sculpture and painting have an effect to teach us manners and abolish hurry.
Sculpture is not the mere cutting of the form of anything in stone; it is the cutting of the effect of it. Very often the true form, in the marble, would not be in the least like itself.
Sculpture, the tongue on the balance of expression.
S'échauffer au dépens du bon Dieu
Se a ciascuno l'interno affanno / Si leggesse in fronte scritto, / Quanti mai che invidia fanno / Ci farebbero pietà!
Se il giovane sapesse, se il vecchio potesse, e' non c' è cosa che non si facesse
Se'l sol mi splende, non curo la luna
Se la moglie pecca, non è il marito innocente
Se laisser prendre aux apparences
Se moquer de la philosophie, c'est vraiment philosopher
Se non è vero, è ben trovato
Se retirer dans un fromage de Hollande
Se tu segui tua stella
Sea Islanders; but a real human heart, with
Divine love in it, beats with the same glow under all the patterns of all earth's thousand tribes.
Sea things that be / On the hot sand fainting long, / Revive with the kiss of the sea.
Seamen have a custom when they meet a whale to fling out an empty tub by way of amusement, to divert him from laying violent hands upon the ship.
Search not to find what lies too deeply hid; / Nor to know things whose knowledge is forbid.
Search others for their virtues, and thyself for thy vices.
Searching of thy wound, I have by hard adventure found my own.
Second thoughts, they say, are best.
Secrecy has many advantages, for when you tell a man at once and straightforward the purpose of any object, he fancies there's nothing in it.
Secrecy is best taught by commencing with ourselves.
Secrecy is the chastity of friendship.
Secrecy is the element of all goodness; even virtue, even beauty is mysterious.
Secrecy is the soul of all great designs.
Secrecy of design, when combined with rapidity of execution, like the column that guided Israel in the desert, becomes the guardian pillar of light and fire to our friends, and a cloud of overwhelming and impenetrable darkness to our enemies.
Secret et hardi
Secreta hæc murmura vulgi
Secrete amicos admone, lauda palam
Secrets make a dungeon of the heart and a jailer of its owner.
Secrets travel fast in Paris.
Sects of men are apt to be shut up in sectarian ideas of their own, and to be less open to new general ideas than the main body of men.
Secundis dubiisque rectus
Secundo amne defluit
Secundum artem
Secundum genera
Secundum usum
Security, / Is mortals' chiefest enemy.
Security will produce danger.
Securus judicat orbis terrarum
Sed de me ut sileam
Sed nisi peccassem, quid tu concedere posses? / Materiam veniæ sors tibi nostra dedit
Sed notat hunc omnis domus et vicinia tota, /
Introrsum turpem, speciosum pelle decora
Sed quum res hominum tanta caligine volvi / Adspicerem, lætosque diu florere nocentes, / Vexarique pios: rursus labefacta cadebat / Religio
Sed tu / Ingenio verbis concipe plura meis?
Sed vatem egregium cui non sit publica vena, / Qui nihil expositum soleat deducere, nec qui / Communi feriat carmen triviale moneta, / Hunc qualem nequeo monstrare, et sentio tantum, / Anxietate carens animus facit
See deep enough, and you see musically; the heart of Nature being everywhere music, if you can only reach it.
See how many things there are which a man
cannot do himself; and then it will appear that it was a sparing speech of the ancients to say, "that a friend is another himself;" for that a friend is far more than himself.
See Naples, and then die.
See one promontory, one mountain, one sea, one river, and see all.
See that no man put a stumbling-block, or an occasion to fall, in his brother's way.
See that you come not to woo honour, but to wed it.
See the conquering hero comes! / Sound the
trumpet, beat the drums!
See this last and this hammer (said the poor cobbler); that last and this hammer are the two best friends I have in this world; nobody else will be my friend, because I want a friend.
See thou explain the infinite through the finite, and the unintelligible only through the intelligible, and not inversely.
See to it that each hour's feelings, and thoughts, and actions are pure and true; then will your life be such.
See what a scourge is laid upon your hate, / That Heaven finds means to kill your joys with love.
See, what is good lies by thy side.
Seein's believin', but feelin's the naked truth.
Seeing the root of the matter is found in me.
Seek, and ye shall find.
Seek but provision of bread and wine, / ... Fools to flatter, and raiment fine, / ... And nothing of God shall e'er be thine.
Seek judgment, relieve the oppressed, judge
the fatherless, plead for the widow.
Seek not thyself without thyself to find.
Seek not to know what must not be reveal'd; / Joys only flow where fate is most conceal'd; / Too busy man would find his sorrows more, / If future fortunes he should know before; / For by that knowledge of his destiny / He would not live at all, but always die.
Seek not to reform every one's dial by your own watch.
Seek one good, one end, so zealously, that nothing else may come into competition or partnership with it.
Seek the good of other men, but be not in bondage to their faces or fancies; for that is but facility or softness, which taketh an honest mind prisoner.
Seek till you find, and you'll not lose your labour.
Seek to be good, but aim not to be great; / A woman's noblest station is retreat.
Seek to make thy course regular, that men may know beforehand what they may expect.
Seek ye the Lord while he may be found, call
ye upon him while he is near.
Seek your salve where you got your sore.
Seekest thou great things? seek them not.
Seeking for a God there, and not here; everywhere outwardly in physical nature, and not inwardly in our own soul, where He alone is to be found by us, begins to get wearisome.
Seeking nothing, he gains all; foregoing self, the universe grows "I."
Seeking the bubble reputation, / Even in the
cannon's mouth.
Seele des Menschen, / Wie gleichst du dem Wasser! / Schicksal des Menschen, / Wie gleichst du dem Wind!
Seelenstärke ohne Seelengrösse bildet die bösartigen Charakters
Seem I not as tender to him / As any mother? / Ay, but such a one / As all day long hath rated at her child, / And vext his day, but blesses him asleep.
Seeming triumph o'er God's saints / Lasts but a little hour.
Seems, madam! nay, it is; I know not
"seems." / 'Tis not alone my inky cloak, good mother, / Nor customary suits of solemn black. / Nor windy suspiration of forced breath, / No, nor the fruitful river in the eye, / Nor the dejected 'haviour of the visage, / Together with all forms, modes, shows of grief, / That can denote truly; these, indeed, seem, / For they are actions that a man can play: / But I have that within, which passeth show; / These but the trappings and the suits of woe.
Seest thou a man diligent in his business? he shall stand before kings; he shall not stand before mean men.
Seest thou a man that is hasty in his words? there is more hope of a fool than of him.
Seest thou a man wise in his own conceit? there is more hope of a fool than of him.
Seest thou not, I say, what a deformed thief this fashion is? how giddily he turns about all the hot bloods between fourteen and five-and-thirty.
Segnius homines bona quam mala sentiunt
Segnius irritant animos demissa per aurem, / Quam quæ sunt oculis subjecta fidelibus
Sehr leicht zerstreut der Zufall was er sammelt; / Ein edler Mensch zieht edle Menschen an / Und weiss sie festzuhalten
Sei gefühllos! / Ein leichtbewegtes Herz / Ist ein elend Gut / Auf der wankenden Erde
Sei gut, und lass von dir die Menschen Böses sagen; / Wer eigne Schuld nicht trägt, kann leichter fremde tragen
Sei im Besitze, und du wohnst im Recht, /
Und heilig wird's die Menge dir bewahren
Sei was du sein willst
Sein Glaube ist so gross, dass, wenn er fällt, / Glaubt er: gefallen sei die ganze Welt
Sei hochbeseligt oder leide! / Das Herz bedarf ein zweites Herz. / Geteilte Freud' ist doppelt Freude, / Geteilter Schmerz ist halber Schmerz.
Selbst erfinden ist schön; doch glücklich von andern Gefundnes, / Fröhlich erkannt und geschätzt, nennst du das weniger dein?
Selbst gethan ist halb gethan
Seldom contented, often in the wrong, / Hard to be pleased at all, and never long.
Seldom ever was any knowledge given to keep but to impart; the grace of this rich jewel is lost in concealment.
Seldom he smiles, and smiles in such a sort, / As if he mock'd himself, and scorn'd his spirit, / That could be moved to smile at anything.
Seldom, in the business and transactions of ordinary life, do we find the sympathy we want.
Seldom is a life wholly wrecked but the cause
lies in some internal mal-arrangement, some want less of good fortune than of good guidance.
Self-complacence over the concealed destroys its concealment.
Self-confidence is either a petty pride in our own narrowness or a realisation of our duty and privilege as God's children.
Self-confidence is the first requisite to great undertakings.
Self-deception is one of the most deadly of all dangers.
Self-denial is indispensable to a strong character,
and the loftiest kind thereof comes only of a religious stock.
Self-denial is painful for a moment, but very agreeable in the end.
Self-distrust is the cause of most of our failures. In the assurance of strength there is strength, and they are the weakest, however strong, who have no faith in themselves or their powers.
Self-interest, that leprosy of the age, attacks us from infancy, and we are startled to observe little heads calculate before knowing how to reflect.
Self-knowledge comes from knowing other men.
Self-love exaggerates our faults as well as our
virtues.
Self-love is a balloon inflated with wind, from which storms burst forth when one makes a puncture in it.
Self-love is not so vile a sin / As self-neglecting.
Self-love is the instrument of our preservation.
Self-love may be, and as a fact often is, the first impulse that drives a man to seek to become morally and religiously better.
Self loves itself best.
Self-murder! name it not; our island's shame!
Self-respect, the corner-stone of all virtue.
Self-reverence, self-knowledge, self-control, / These three alone lead life to sovereign power. / Yet not for power (power of herself / Would come uncall'd for), but to live by law, / Acting the law we live by without fear; / And, because right is right, to follow right, / Were wisdom in the scorn of consequence.
Self-trust is the essence of heroism.
Self-trust is the first secret of success.
Self-will is so ardent and active that it will break a world to pieces to make a stool to sit on.
Selfishness is that detestable vice which no one will forgive in others, and no one is without in himself.
Selfishness, not love, is the actuating motive of the gallant.
Selig der, den er im Siegesglanze findet
Selig wer sich vor der Welt, / Ohne Hass
verschliesst, / Einen Freund am Busen hält / Und mit dem geniesst
Sell all thou hast, and give it to the poor, and follow me.

Semel malus, semper præsumitur esse malus
Semen est sanguis Christianorum
Semper ad eventum festinat
Semper Augustus
Semper avarus eget; certum voto pete finem
Semper bonus homo tiro
Semper eadem
Semper eris pauper, si pauper es, Æmiliane
Semper fidelis
