Semper honos, nomenque tuum, laudesque manebunt
Semper idem
Semper inops, quicunque cupit
Semper paratus
Semper tibi pendeat hamus; / Quo minime credas gurgite, piscis erit
Sempre il mal non vien per nuocere
Send a fool to France, and he'll come a fool back.
Send a fool to the market, and a fool he'll
return.
Send a wise man on an errand, and say nothing to him.
Send your charity abroad wrapt in blankets.
Send your son to Ayr; if he did weel here, he'll do weel there.
Senilis stultitia, quæ deliratio appellari solet, senum levium est, non omnium
Seniores priores
Sense can support herself handsomely, in most countries, for some eighteenpence a day; but for fantasy planets and solar systems will not suffice.
Sense hides shame.
Sense, shortness, and salt are the ingredients of a good proverb.
Sensibility would be a good portress if she had but one hand; with her right she opens the door to pleasure, but with her left to pain.
Sensitive ears are good signs of health in
girls as in horses.
Sensitiveness is closely allied to egotism; and excessive sensibility is only another name for morbid self-consciousness. The cure for tender sensibilities is to make more of our objects and less of ourselves.
Sensuality is the grave of the soul.
Sentences are like sharp nails, which force truth upon our memory.
Sentiment has a kind of divine alchemy, rendering grief itself the source of tenderest thoughts and far-reaching desires, which the sufferer cherishes as sacred treasures.
Sentiment is intellectualised emotion; emotion precipitated, as it were, in pretty crystals by the fancy.
Sentiment is the ripened fruit of fantasy.
Sentimental literature, concerned with the analysis and description of emotion, headed by the poetry of Byron, is altogether of lower rank than the literature which merely describes what it saw.
Sentimentalism is that state in which a man
speaks deep and true, not because he feels things strongly, but because he perceives that they are beautiful, and touching and fine to say them--things that he fain would feel, and fancies that he does feel.
Senza Cerere e Bacco, Venere e di ghiaccio
Septem convivium, novem convitium
Septem horas dormisse sat est juvenique, senique
Sepulchri / Mitte supervacuos honores
Sequiturque patrem non passibus æquis
Sequor nec inferior
Sera in fundo parsimonia
Serenity, health, and affluence attend the desire of rising by labour.
Seriatim
Series implexa causarum
Serit arbores quæ alteri sæculo prosint
Sermons in stones.
Sero clypeum post vulnera sumo
Sero sapiunt Phryges
Sero sed serio
Sero venientibus ossa
Serpens ni edat serpentem, draco non fiet
Serpentum major concordia; parcit / Cognatis maculis similis fera. Quando leoni / Fortior eripuit vitam leo?
Serum auxilium post prælium
Serus in cœlum redeas diuque / Lætus intersis
populo
Serva jugum
Servabo fidem
Servant of God, well done; well hast thou fought / The better fight.
Servants and houses should be suited to the situation. A gem should not be placed at the feet. The same is to be understood of an able man.
Servata fides cineri
Serve the great; stick at no humiliation; grudge no office thou canst render; be the limb of their body, the breath of their mouth; compromise thy egotism.
Servetur ad imum / Qualis ab incepto processerit, et sibi constet
Service is no inheritance.
Serviet æternum, quia parvo nescit uti
Servility and abjectness of humour is implicitly
involved in the charge of lying.
Serving one's own passions is the greatest slavery.
Servitude seizes on few, but many seize on servitude.
Ses rides sur son front ont gravé ses exploits
Sesquipedalia verba
Set a beggar on horseback and he'll ride to
the devil.
Set a beggar on horseback and he will ride a gallop.
Set a stout heart to a stey
Set a thief to catch a thief.
Set it down to thyself as well to create good precedents as to follow them.
Set not your loaf in till the oven's hot.
Set out so / As all the day thou mayst hold out to go.
Set your affections on things above, not on things on the earth.
Setz' dir Perrücken auf von Millionen Locken, / Setz' deinen Fuss auf ellenhohe Socken, / Du bleibst doch immer, was du bist
Seven cities warred for Homer being dead, / Who living had no roof to shroud his head.
Seven Grecian cities vied for Homer dead, /
Through which the living Homer begged his bread.
Seven hours to law, to soothing slumber seven, ten to the world allot, and all to heaven.
Seven times tried that judgment is / That did never choose amiss.
Severæ Musa tragœdiæ
Severity breedeth fear, but roughness breedeth hate.
Sewing at once a double thread, / A shroud as
well as a shirt.
Sex horas somno, totidem des legibus æquis: / Quatuor orabis, des epulisque duas. / Quod superest ultra, sacris largire Camenis
Sexu fœmina, ingenio vir
Shadow owes its birth to light.
Shadows fall on brightest hours.
Shadows to-night / Have struck more terror
to the soul of Richard / Than can the substance of ten thousand soldiers.
Shake off this downy sleep, death's counterfeit, / And look on death itself.
Shakespeare carries us to such a lofty strain of intelligent activity as to suggest a wealth that beggars his own; and we then feel that the splendid works which he has created, and which in other hours we extol as a sort of self-existent poetry, have no stronger hold of real nature than the shadow of a passing traveller on the rock.
Shakespeare does not look at a thing merely, but into it, through it, so that he constructively comprehends it, can take it asunder and put it together again; the thing melts, as it were, into light under his eye, and anew creates itself before him.
Shakespeare is dangerous to young poets; they cannot but reproduce him, while they imagine they are producing themselves.
Shakespeare is no sectarian; to all he deals
with equity and mercy; because he knows all, and his heart is wide enough for all. In his mind the world is a whole; he figures it as Providence governs it; and to him it is not strange that the sun should be caused to shine on the evil and the good, and the rain to fall on the just and the unjust.
Shakespeare is the greatest intellect who, in our recorded world, has left record of himself in the way of literature. I know not such power of vision, such faculty of thought in any other man, such calmness of depth; placid joyous strength; all things imaged in that great soul of his so true and clear, as in a tranquil unfathomable sea. A perfectly level mirror, that is to say withal, a man justly related to all things and men, a good man.
Shakespeare made his Hamlet as a bird weaves its nest.
Shakespeare must have seemed a dull man at times, he was so flashingly brilliant at others.
Shakespeare never permits a spirit to show itself but to men of the highest intellectual power.
Shakespeare says we are creatures that look
before and after; the more surprising that we do not look round a little and see what is passing under our very eyes.
Shakespeare stands alone. His want of erudition was a most happy and productive ignorance; it forced him back upon his own resources, which were exhaustless.
Shakespeare, the finest human figure, as I apprehend, that Nature has hitherto seen fit to make out of our widely-diffused Teutonic clay. I find no human soul so beautiful, these fifteen hundred known years--our supreme modern European man.
Shakespeare, the sage and seer of the human heart.
Shakespeare was forbidden of heaven to have any plans.... Not for him the founding of institutions, the preaching of doctrines, or the repression of abuses. Neither he, nor the sun, did on any morning that they rose together, receive charge from their Maker concerning such things. They were both of them to shine on the evil and good; both to behold unoffendingly all that was upon the earth, to burn unappalled upon the spears of kings, and undisdaining upon the reeds of the river.
Shakespeare

plays on subjects belonging to the preceding because there is no care about centuries in them, but a life which all men recognise for the human life of all time; ... a rogue in the fifteenth century being, at heart, what a rogue is in the nineteenth and was in the twelfth; and an honest or a knightly man being, in like manner, very similar to other such at any other time.
Shall horses run upon the rock? Will one plough there with oxen?
Shall we receive good at the hands of the Lord, and shall we not receive evil?
Shall we repine at a little misplaced charity, when an all-knowing, all-wise Being showers down every day his benefits on the unthankful and undeserving?
Shall workmen just repeat the sin of kings and conquerors? / As the nations cease from battle, shall the classes rouse the fray, / And scatter wanton sorrow for a shilling more a day?
Shallow men believe in luck, believe in circumstances....
Strong men believe in cause and effect.
Shallow streams make most din.
Shallow wits censure everything that is beyond their depth.
"Shalls" and "wills." Never trust a Scotch man or woman who does not come to grief among them.
Shame is a feeling of profanation.
Shame is like the weaver's thread; if it breaks
in the web, it is wholly imperfect.
Shame is worse than death.
Shame may restrain what law does not prohibit.

Shapes that come not at an earthly call / Will not depart when mortal voices bid.
Sharpness cuts slight things best; solid, nothing
cuts through but weight and strength; the same in the use of intellectuals.
She bears a duke's revenues on her back.
She
hold upon her: and happy is every one that retaineth her.
She is a wife who is the soul of her husband.
She is a woman, therefore may be wooed; she is a woman, therefore may be won.
She is a woman who can command herself.
She is not worthy to be loved that hath not
some feeling of her own worthiness.
She lived unknown, and few could know / When Lucy ceased to be; / But she is in her grave, and oh / The difference to me!
She looketh well to the ways of her household, and eateth not the bread of idleness.
She looks as if butter would not melt in her mouth.
She loved me for the dangers I had passed, / And I loved her that she did pity them. / This only is the witchcraft I have used.
She never told her love, / But let concealment,
like a worm i' the bud, / Feed on her damask cheek.
She
proportion to the fault the punishment it merits.
She pined in thought, / And with a green and yellow melancholy. / She sat like patience on a monument, / Smiling at grief.
She should be humble who would please, / And she must suffer who can love.
She speaks poniards, and every word stabs: if her breath were as terrible as her terminations, there were no living with her; she would infect to the north star.
She that is ashamed to eat at table eats in
private.
She that is born handsome is born married.
She that rails ye into trembling / Only shows her fine dissembling; / But the fawner to abuse ye, / Thinks ye fools, and so will use ye.
She that takes gifts herself she sells, / And she that gives them does nothing else.
She that will not when she may, / When she will, she shall have nay.
She watches him as a cat would watch a
mouse.
She wept to feel her life so desolate, / And wept still more because the world had made it / So desolate: yet was the world her all; / She loathed it, but she knew it was her all.
She who makes her husband and her children happy, who reclaims the one from vice, and trains up the other to virtue, is a much greater character than ladies described in romance, whose whole occupation is to murder mankind with shafts from their quiver or their eyes.
She's all my fancy painted her; / She's lovely, she's divine.
She's beautiful, and therefore to be woo'd; / She's a woman, and therefore to be won.
Sheathe thy impatience; throw cold water on
thy choler.
Short allowance of victual, and plenty of nothing but Gospel!
Short boughs, long vintage.
Short lived is all rule but the rule of God.
Short-lived wits do wither as they grow.
Short prayers reach heaven.
Short reckonings make long friends.
Short swallow-flights of song, that dip / Their wings in tears and skim away.
Should auld acquaintance be forgot, / And never brought to mind? / Should auld acquaintance be forgot, / And days o' lang syne?
Should envious tongues some malice frame, / To soil and tarnish your good name, / Live it down.
Should not the ruler have regard to the voice
of the people?
Should one suffer what is intolerable?
Show me one wicked man who has written poetry, and I will show you where his poetry is not poetry; or rather, I will show you in his poetry no poetry at all.
Show me the man who would go to heaven alone, and I will show you one who will never be admitted.
Show me the man you honour; I know by that symptom, better than by any other, what kind of man you yourself are. For you show me there what your ideal of manhood is; what kind of man you long inexpressibly to be, and would thank the gods, with your whole soul, for being if you could.
"Show some pity?" "I show it most of all
when I show justice."
Show the dullest clodpole, show the haughtiest featherhead, that a soul higher than himself is actually here; were his knees stiffened into brass, he must down and worship.
Shrine of the mighty! can it be / That this is all remains of thee?
Shrouded in baleful vapours, the genius of Burns was never seen in clear, azure splendour, enlightening the world; but some beams from it did, by fits, pierce through; and tinted those clouds with rainbow and orient colours into a glory and stern grandeur which men silently gazed on with wonder and tears.
Shun drugs and drinks which work the wit abuse: clear minds, clean bodies, need no Sôma juice.
Shut not thy purse-strings always against
painted distress.

Sigh no more, ladies, sigh no more! / Men were deceivers ever; / One foot in sea and one on shore, / To one thing constant never.
Sight before hearsay.
Sight must be reinforced by insight before
souls can be discerned as well as manners, ideas as well as objects, realities and relations as well as appearances and accidental connections.
Silence and discretion are specially becoming in a woman, and to remain quietly at home.
Silence at the proper season is wisdom, and better than any speech.
Silence gives
Silence is a friend that will never betray.
Silence is a solvent that destroys personality,
and gives us leave to be great and universal.
Silence is better than unmeaning words.
Silence is deep as eternity; speech is shallow as time.
Silence is more eloquent than words.
Silence is one of the great arts of conversation.
Silence is the best resolve for him who distrusts
himself.
Silence is the chaste blossom of love.
Silence is the consummate eloquence of sorrow.
Silence is the element in which great things fashion themselves together; that at length they may emerge, full-formed and majestic, into the daylight of life, which they are thenceforth to rule.
Silence is the eternal duty of man. He won't get to any real understanding of what is complex, and what is more than any other pertinent to his interests, without maintaining silence.
Silence is the mother of truth.
Silence is the perfectest herald of joy; I were but little happy, if I could say how much.
Silence is the sanctuary of discretion
It not only conceals secrets but also faults.
Silence is the sleep that nourishes wisdom.
Silence is wisdom, when speaking is folly.
Silence often expresses more powerfully than
speech the verdict and judgment of society.
Silence, silence; and be distant, ye profane, with your jargonings and superficial babblements, when a man has anything to do.
Silent leges inter arma
Silent men, like still waters, are deep and dangerous.
Silver from the living / Is gold in the giving: / Gold from the dying / Is but silver a-flying. / Gold and silver from the dead / Turn too often into lead.

Simile gaudet simili

Simpering is but a lay-hypocrisy: / Give it a corner and the clue undoes.
Simple as it seems, it was a great discovery
that the key of knowledge could turn both ways, that it could open, as well as lock, the door of power to the many.
Simple gratitude, untinctured with love, is all the return an ingenuous mind can bestow for former benefits. Love for love is all the reward we expect or desire.
Simplex sigillum veri
Simplicity in character, in manners, in style: in all things the supreme excellence is simplicity.
Simplicity is in the intention, purity in the affection; simplicity turns to God, purity unites with and enjoys him.
Simplicity is Nature's first step, and the last
of art.
Simplicity is, of all things, the hardest to be copied.
Simplicity is the straightforwardness of a soul which refuses to reflect on itself or its deeds. Many are sincere without being simple; they do not wish to be taken for other than they are, but they are always afraid of being taken for what they are not.
Sin every day takes out a patent for some new invention.
Sin has many tools, but a lie is the handle which fits them all.
Sin is like the bee, with honey in its mouth
but a sting in its tail.
Sin is not a monster to be mused on, but an impotence to be got rid of.
Sin is too dull to see beyond himself.
Sin seen from the thought is a diminution or loss; seen from the conscience or will, it is a pravity or bad.
Since every Jack became a gentleman, / There's many a gentle person made a Jack.
Since grief but aggravates thy loss, / Grieve
not for what is past.
Since not only judgments have their awards, but mercies their commissions, snatch not at every favour, nor think thyself passed by if they fall upon thy neighbour.
Since the invention of printing no state can now any longer be formed purely, slowly, and by degrees from itself.
Since time is not a person we can overtake when he is past, let us honour him with mirth and cheerfulness of heart while he is passing.
Since trifles make the sum of human things, / And half our misery from our foibles springs.
Since we have a good loaf, let us not look for
cheesecakes.
Sincere wise speech
corollary, and insignificant outer manifestation of sincere wise thought.
Sincerity, a deep, great, genuine sincerity, is the first characteristic of all men in any way heroic.
Sincerity gives wings to power.
Sincerity is impossible unless it pervades the whole being; and the pretence saps the very foundations of character.
Sincerity is the face of the soul, as dissimulation
is the mask.
Sincerity is the indispensable ground of all conscientiousness, and by consequence of all heartfelt religion.
Sincerity is the way to heaven. To think how to be sincere is the way of man.
Sincerity is true wisdom.
Sincerity makes the least man to be of more value than the most talented hypocrite.

Sink not in spirit: who aimeth at the sky / Shoots higher much than he that means a tree.
Sink the Bible to the bottom of the ocean, and man's obligations to God would be unchanged. He would have the same path to tread, only his lamp and his guide would be gone; he would have the same voyage to make, only his compass and chart would be overboard.
Sinks to the grave with unperceived decay, / while resignation gently slopes the way.

Six hours to sleep allot: to law be six addressed;

Skilful pilots gain their reputation from storms and tempests.
Skill is stronger than strength.
Skill is the united force of experience, intellect and passion in their operation on manual labour.
Skill to do comes of doing; knowledge comes
by eyes always open, and working hands; and there is no knowledge that is not power.
Sky is the part of creation in which Nature has done more for the sake of pleasing man, more for the sole and evident purpose of talking to him and teaching him, than in any other of her works, and it is just the part in which we least attend to her.
Slackness breeds worms; but the sure traveller, / Though he alight sometimes, still goeth on.
Slander and detraction can have no influence, can make no impression, upon the righteous Judge above. None to thy prejudice, but a sad and fatal one to their own.
Slander expires at a good woman's door.
Slander is a poison which extinguishes charity,
both in the slanderer and the person who listens to it.
Slander lives upon succession; / For ever housed, where it once gets possession.
Slander, / Whose edge is sharper than the sword, whose tongue / Out-venoms all the worms of Nile, whose breath / Rides on the parting winds, and doth belie / All corners of the world.
Slander's mark was ever yet the fair; / ... A crow that flies in heaven's sweetest air.
Slanderers do not hurt me, because they do not hit me.
Slave or free is settled in heaven for a man.
Slave to no sect, who takes no private road, / But looks through Nature up to Nature's God.
Slave to silver's but a slave to smoke.
Slavery is a weed that grows on every soil.
Slavery is an inherent inheritance of a large portion of the human race, to whom the more you give of their own free will, the more slaves they will make themselves.
Slaves cannot breathe in England; if their
lungs / Receive our air, that moment they are free; / They touch our country, and their shackles fall.
Sleep after toil, port after stormy seas, / Ease after war, death after life, doth greatly please.
Sleep and death, two twins of winged race, / Of matchless swiftness, but of silent pace.
Sleep, gentle sleep, / Nature's soft nurse, how have I frighted thee, / That thou no more wilt weigh my eyelids down, / And steep my senses in forgetfulness?
Sleep hath its own world, / A boundary between the things misnamed / Death and Existence.
Sleep is for the inhabitants of planets only; in
another time men will sleep and wake continually at once. The great part of our body, of our humanity, yet sleeps a deep sleep.
Sleep is the best cure for waking troubles.
Sleep is the sole reviver
Sleep is to a man what winding up is to a clock.
Sleep lingers all our lifetime about our eyes, as night hovers all day in the boughs of the fir-tree.
Sleep no more, / Macbeth does murder sleep.
Sleep seldom visits sorrow; when it doth, / It is a comforter.
Sleep, that knits up the ravell'd sleave of care, / The death of each day's life, sore labour's bath, / Balm of hurt minds, great nature's second course, / Chief nourisher in life's feast.
Sleep, that sometimes shuts up sorrow's eye.
Sleep, the antechamber of the grave.
Sleep the sleep that knows not breaking, / Morn of toil, nor night of waking.
Slight not the smallest loss, whether it be / In love or honour; take account of all: / Shine like the sun in every corner: see / Whether thy stock of credit swell or fall.
Slippery is the flagstone at the great house door.
Sloth is the key to poverty.
Sloth, like rust, consumes faster than labour wears, while the used key is always bright.
Sloth makes all things difficult, but industry all things easy.
Sloth never arrived at the attainment of a good wish.
Sloth turneth the edge of wit, study sharpeneth the mind; a thing, be it never so easy, is hard to the idle; a thing, be it never so hard, is easy to wit well employed.
Slovenly (a) and negligent manner of writing
is a disobliging mark of want of respect.
Slow and steady wins the race.
Slow fire makes sweet malt.
Slow-footed counsel is most sure to gain; / Rashness still brings repentance in her train.
Slow help is no help.
Slow rises worth by poverty depress'd.
Slow to resolve, but in performance quick.
Slowly and sadly we laid him down, / From the field of his fame fresh and gory: / We carved not a line, and we raised not a stone, / But we left him alone with his glory.
Sma' fish are better than nane.
Small cheer and great welcome make a merry feast.
Small curs are not regarded when they grin; /
But great men tremble when the lion roars.
Small curses upon great occasions are but so much waste of our strength and soul's health to no manner of purpose; they are like sparrow-shot fired against a bastion.
Small debts are like small shot--they are rattling on every side, and can scarcely be escaped without a wound. Great debts are like cannon of loud noise, but of little danger.
Small draughts of philosophy lead to atheism, but larger bring back to God.
Small faults indulged let in greater.
Small have continued plodders ever won / Save
bare authority from others' books.
Small herbs have grace, great weeds do grow apace.
Small is it that thou canst trample the earth with its injuries under thy foot, as old Greek Zeno trained thee: thou canst love the earth while it injures thee, and even because it injures thee; for this a Greater than Zeno was needed, and he too was sent.
Small Latin and less Greek.
Small-pot-soon-hot style of eloquence is what our county conventions often exhibit.
Small profits and quick returns.
Small rain lays great dust.
Small service is true service while it lasts. / Of humblest friends, bright creature! scorn not one: / The daisy, by the shadow that it casts, / Protects the lingering dewdrop from the sun.
Small thanks to the man for keeping his hands clean who would not touch the work but with gloves on.
Smallest of mortals, when mounted aloft by circumstances, come to seem great, smallest of phenomena connected with them are treated as important, and must be sedulously scanned, and commented on with loud emphasis.
Smelfungus in the grand portico of the Pantheon
says, "'Tis nothing but a huge cockpit."
Smile (Fortune), and we smile, the lords of many lands; / Frown, and we smile, the lords of our own hands; / For man is man and master of his fate.
Smiles are the language of love.
Smiles form the channel of a future tear.
Smiles from reason flow, / To brute denied, and are of love the food.
Smooth runs the water where the brook is
deep; / And in his simple show he harbours treason. / The fox barks not when he would steal the lamb.
Smooth waters run deep.
Smooth words make smooth ways.
Smuler ere og Bröd
Snarl if you please, but you shall snarl without.
Snatch from the ashes of your sires / The
embers of their former fires; / And he who in the strife expires / Will add to theirs a name of fear / That tyranny shall quake to hear, / And leave his sons a hope, a fame, / They too would rather die than shame.
So behave that the odour of your actions may enhance the general sweetness of the atmosphere.
So careful of the type she seems, / So careless of the single life.
So comes a reckoning when the banquet's o'er,--/ The dreadful reckoning, and men smile no more.
So dawning day has brought relief--/ Fareweel our night o' sorrow.
So dress and so conduct yourself that persons
who have been in your company will not recollect what you had on.
So far as a man thinks he is free.
So far is it from being true that men are naturally equal, that no two people can be half an hour together but one shall acquire an evident superiority over the other.
So full of shapes is fancy, that it alone is high-fantastical.
So gieb mir auch die Zeiten wieder, / Da ich noch selbst im Werden war
So, here hath been dawning / Another blue day; / Think wilt thou let it / Slip useless away. / Out of Eternity / This new day is born; / Into Eternity / At night doth return. / Behold it aforetime / No eye ever did: / So soon it for ever / From all eyes is hid. / Here hath been dawning, &c.
So I do my part to others, let them think of me what they will or can.... If I should regard such things, it were in another's power to defeat my charity, and evil should be stronger than good. But difficulties are so far from cooling Christians that they whet them.
So lang man lebt, sei man lebendig
So live with men, as if God saw you; so speak to God, as if men heard you.
So lonely 'twas, that God himself / Scarce seeméd there to be.
So long as a man is capable of self-renewal he is a living being.
So long as any Ideal (any soul of truth) does, in never so confused a manner, exist and work within the Actual, it is a tolerable business. Not so when the Ideal has wholly departed, and the Actual owns to no soul of truth any longer.
So long as the "Holy Place" in their souls
is left in possession of powerless opinions, men are practically without God in this world.
So long as you live and work, you will not escape being misunderstood; to that you must resign yourself once for all. Be silent.
So magnificent a thing is Will incarnated in a creature of like fashion with ourselves, that we run to witness all manifestations thereof.
So many servants, so many enemies.
So many slaves, so many enemies.
So may he rest; his faults lie gently on him.
So much in the world depends upon getting what we want. Prosperity is to the human heart like a sunny south wall to a peach.
So much of our time is preparation, so much is routine, and so much retrospect, that the pith of each man's genius contracts itself to a very few hours.
So much to do, / So little done, such things to be.
So nigh is grandeur to our dust, / So near is God to man, / When Duty whispers low, "Thou must," / The youth replies, "I can!"
So schaff' ich am sausenden Webstuhl der
Zeit / Und wirke der Gottheit lebendiges Kleid
So soon as one's heart is tender it is weak. When it is beating so warmly against the breast, and the throat is, as it were, tied tightly, and one strives to press the tears from one's eyes and feels an incomprehensible joy as they begin to flow, then we are so weak that we are fettered by chains of flowers, not because they have become strong through any magic chain, but because we tremble lest we should tear them asunder.
So soon as people try honestly to see all they can of anything, they come to a point where a noble dimness begins. They see more than others; but the consequence of their seeing more is, that they feel they cannot see at all; and the more intense their perception, the more the crowd of things which they partly see will multiply upon them.
So soon as sacrifice becomes a duty and necessity to man, I see no limit to the horizon which opens before him.
So spiritual
that we do springs out of mystery, spirit, invisible force; only like a little cloud-image, or Armida's palace, air-built, does the actual body itself forth from the great mystic deep.
So stirbt ein Held, anbetungsvoll
So study evermore is overshot; / While it doth study to have what it would, / It doth forget to do the thing it should; / And when it hath the thing it hunteth most, / 'Tis won as towns with fire,--so won, so lost.
So sweetly she bade me adieu, / I thought that she bade me return.
So teach us to number our days, that we may apply our hearts unto wisdom.
So thou be above it, make the world serve thy purpose, but do not thou serve it.
So thou be good, slander doth but approve /
Thy worth the greater.
So to living or dead let the solemn bell call; / Sleeping or waking, time passes with all.
So turns the faithful needle to the pole, / Though mountains rise between and oceans roll.
So we grew together, / Like to a double cherry, seeming parted, / But yet a union in partition; / Two lovely berries moulded on one stem. / So with two seeming bodies, but one heart.
So wise, so young, they say, do ne'er live long.
So wonderful is human nature, and its varied
ties / Are so involved and complicate, that none / May hope to keep his inward spirit pure, / And walk without perplexity through life.
So work the honey bees; / Creatures that, by a rule in Nature, teach / The art of order to a peopled kingdom.
Soar not too high to fall, but stoop to rise.
Sobald du dir vertraust, sobald weisst du zu leben
Sobriety, severity, and self-respect is the foundation of all true sociality.
Social intercourse makes us the more able to bear with ourselves and others.
Social order without liberty makes of man only a product; liberty makes him the citizen of a better world.
Societatis vinculum est ratio et oratio
Society always consists, in greatest part, of
young and foolish persons.
Society cannot do without cultivated men. As soon as the first wants are satisfied, the higher wants become imperative.
Society develops wit, but contemplation alone forms genius.
Society does not in any age prevent a man from being what he can be.
Society does not like to have any breath of question blown on the existing order.
Society does not love its unmaskers.
Society everywhere is in conspiracy against the manhood of every one of its members.
Society has always a destructive influence upon an artist:--by its sympathy with his meanest powers; secondly, by its chilling want of understanding of his greatest; and, thirdly, by its vain occupation of his time and thoughts.
Society has always under one or the other figure two authentic revelations, of a God and of a devil.
Society has only one law, and that is custom.
Society is a long series of uprising ridges,
which from the first to the last offer no valley of repose. Wherever you take your stand, you are looked down upon by those above you, and reviled and pelted by those below you.
Society is a masked ball, where every one hides his real character, and reveals it by hiding.
Society is a republic. When an individual endeavours to lift himself above his fellows, he is dragged down by the mass, either by ridicule or calumny.
Society is a troop of thinkers, and the best heads among them take the best places.
Society is a wave. The wave moves onward, but the water of which it is composed does not.... Its unity is only phenomenal.
Society is, and must be, based upon appearances,
and not upon the deepest realities.
Society is barbarous, until every industrious man can get his living without dishonest customs.
Society is composed of two great classes: those who have more dinners than appetite, and those who have more appetite than dinners.
Society is divisible into two classes: shearers and shorn.
Society is ever under the imperious necessity of moving onward in legal forms, nor can such forms be evaded without the most serious disasters forthwith ensuing.
Society is founded upon cloth.
Society is full of infirm people, who incessantly summon others to serve them. They contrive everywhere to exhaust for their single comfort the entire means and appliances of that luxury to which our invention has yet attained.
Society is infected with rude, cynical, restless, and frivolous persons, who prey upon the rest, and whom no public opinion concentrated into good manners, forms accepted by the sense of all, can reach.
Society is like the echoing hills; it gives back to the speaker his words, groan for groan, song for song.
Society is no comfort to one not sociable.
Society is servile from want of will, and therefore
the world wants saviours and religions.
Society is the atmosphere of souls, and we necessarily imbibe from it something which is either infectious or hurtful.
Society is the grandmother of humanity through her daughters the inventions.
Society is the standing wonder of our existence; a true region of the supernatural; as it were, a second all-embracing life, wherein our first individual life becomes doubly and trebly alive, and whatever of infinitude was in us bodes itself forth, and becomes visible and active.
Society is well governed when the people obey the magistrates, and the magistrates the laws.
Society lives by faith, and develops by science.
Society rests upon conscience, not upon science.
Society will pardon much to genius and special gifts; but, being in its nature conventional, it loves what is conventional.
Society wishes to be amused. I do not wish to be amused. I wish that life should not be cheap, but sacred; the days to be as centuries, loaded, fragrant.
Socius fidelis anchora tuta est
Socrates quidem quum rogaretur cujatem se
esse diceret, Mundanum, inquit. Totius enim mundi se incolam et civem arbitrabatur
Soft-heartedness, in times like these, / Shows softness in the upper storey.
Soft is the music that would charm for ever; / The flower of sweetest smell is shy and lowly.
Soft
Soft pity enters at an iron gate.
Soft words win hard hearts.
"Softly! softly!" caught the monkey.
Sogno d'infermi
Soi-disant
Sol crescentes decedens duplicat umbras
Sol occubuit; nox nulla secuta est
Sola Deo salus
Sola juvat virtus
Sola nobilitas virtus
Sola salus servire Deo
Sola virtus invicta
Solamen miseris socios habuisse doloris
Soldats! si les cornettes vous manquent, vous trouverez toujours mon panache blanc au chemin de l'honneur et de la gloire
Soldiers in peace are like chimneys in summer.
Soldiers
as of the sword.
Soldiers! what I have to offer you is fatigue, danger, struggle, and death; the chill of the cold night in the free air, and heat under the burning sun; no lodgings, no munitions, no provisions, but forced marches, dangerous watchposts, and the continual struggle with the bayonet against batteries. Those who love freedom and their country may follow me!
"Solem præ jaculorum multitudine et sagittarum non videbis." "In umbra igitur pugnabimus"
Solem quis dicere falsum audeat?
Soli Deo gloria
Soli Deo honor et gloria

Solicitude about the future never profits; we feel no evil till it comes; and when we feel always too early or too late.
Solid pudding against empty praise.
Solitude can be well applied and sit right upon but very few persons. They must have knowledge of the world to see the follies of it, and virtue enough to despise all the vanity.
Solitude cherishes great virtues and destroys little ones.
Solitude dulls the thought, too much company
dissipates it.
Solitude is a good school, but the world is the best theatre; the institution is best there, but the practice here; the wilderness hath the advantage of discipline, and society opportunities of perfection.
Solitude is as needful to the imagination as society is wholesome for the character.
Solitude is impracticable, and society fatal.
Solitude is not measured by the miles of space that intervene between a man and his fellows. The really diligent student in one of the crowded hives of Cambridge College is as solitary as a dervish in the desert.
Solitude is often the best society.
Solitude is the despair of fools, the torment of the wicked, and the joy of the good.
Solitude is the home of the strong; silence, their prayer.
Solitude sometimes is best society, / And short retirement urges sweet return.
Solitude, the safeguard of mediocrity, is to genius the stern friend, the cold, obscure shelter where moult the wings that will bear it farther than suns and stars. He who would inspire and lead his race must be defended from travelling with the souls of other men, from living, breathing, reading, and writing in the daily time-worn yoke of their opinions.
Solitudinem faciunt, pacem appellant
Sollen dich die Dohlen nicht umschrein, / Musst du nicht Knopf auf dem Kirchthurm sein
Sollicitæ mentes speque metuque pavent
Sollicitant alii remis freta cæca, ruuntque / In ferrum: penetrant aulas, et limina regum
Solo cedit, quicquid solo plantatur
Solo Deo salus
Solo e pensoso
Solvit ad diem
Solvitur ambulando
Solvuntur risu tabulæ
Some are atheists only in fair weather.
Some are born great, some achieve greatness, and some have greatness thrust upon them.
Some are cursed with the fulness of satiety; and how can they bear the ills of life when its very pleasures fatigue them?
Some are so intent upon acquiring the superfluities of life that they sacrifice its necessaries in this foolish pursuit.
Some books are drenched sands, on which a
great soul's wealth lies in heaps, like a wrecked argosy.
Some books are edifices to stand as they are built; some are hewn stones ready to form a part of future edifices; some are quarries from which stones are to be split for shaping and after use.
Some books are lees frae end to end, / And some big lees were never penn'd; / E'en ministers they hae been kenn'd, / In holy rapture, / A rousing whid at times to vend, / And nail't wi' Scripture.
Some books are to be tasted, others to be swallowed, and some few to be chewed and digested.
Some Cupid kills with arrows, some with traps.
Some dire misfortune to portend, / No enemy can match a friend.
Some drink because they're wet, and some
because they're dry.
Some evils are cured by contempt.
Some falls are means the happier to rise.
Some faults are so nearly allied to excellence that we can scarce weed out the vice without eradicating the virtue.
Some folk's tongues are like the clocks as run on strikin', not to tell you the time o' the day, but because there's summat wrong i' their inside.
Some for renown, on scraps of learning dote, /
And think they grow immortal as they quote.
Some friend is a companion at the table, and will not continue in the day of thy affliction.
Some glances of real beauty may be seen in the faces of those who dwell in true meekness.
Some grief shows much of love, / But much of grief shows still more want of wit.
Some hae meat that canna eat, / And some would eat that want it; / But we hae meat and we can eat, / Sae let the Lord be thankit.
Some have been thought brave because they
were afraid to run away.
Some men are born anvils, some are born hammers.
Some men are like nails, easily drawn; others are like rivets, not drawable at all.
Some men are wise, and some are otherwise.
Some men, at the approach of a dispute, neigh like horses. Unless there be an argument going on, they think nothing is doing.
Some men demand rough treatment everywhere.
Some men go through a forest and see no firewood.
Some men have just imagination enough to spoil their judgment.
Some men, like spaniels, will only fawn the more when repulsed, but will pay little heed to a friendly caress.
Some men weave their sophistry till their own reason is entangled.
Some men will believe nothing but what they
can comprehend; and there are but few things that such are able to comprehend.
Some men's sins are open beforehand, going before to judgement; and some men they follow after.
Some modern zealots appear to have no better knowledge of truth, nor better manner of judging it, than by counting noses.
Some must be great.
Some of our weaknesses are born in us, others are the result of education; it is a question which of the two gives us most trouble.
Some of the most famous books are least
worth reading. Their fame was due to their doing something that needed in their day to be done. The work done, the virtue of the book expires.
Some of your griefs you have cured, / And the sharpest you still have survived; / But what torments of pain you endured / From evils that never arrived!
Some old men, by continually praising the time of their youth, would almost persuade us that there were no fools in those days; but unluckily they are left themselves for examples.
Some people are all quality; you would think they were made up of nothing but title and genealogy. The stamp of dignity defaces in them the very character of humanity, and transports them to such a degree of haughtiness that they reckon it below themselves to exercise either good-nature or good manners.
Some people are so fond of ill-luck that they run half way to meet it.
Some people carry their hearts in their heads;
very many carry their heads in their hearts. The difficulty is to keep them apart, yet both actively working together.
Some people obtain fame, and others deserve it.
Some people pass through life soberly and religiously enough, without knowing why, or reasoning about it, but, from force of habit merely, go to heaven like fools.
Some people will never learn anything, because they understand everything too soon.
Some persons are so devotional they have not one bit of true religion in them.
Some persons, instead of making a religion for
their God, are content to make a god of their religion.
Some persons take reproof good-humouredly enough, unless you are so unlucky as to hit a sore place. Then they wince and writhe, and start up and knock you down for your impertinence, or wish you good morning.
Some philosophers seek to exalt man by display of his greatness, others to debase him by pointing to his miseries.
Some prayers, indeed, have a longer voyage than others, but then they return with richer lading at last.
Some read books only with a view to find fault, while others read only to be taught; the former are like venomous spiders, extracting a poisonous quality, where the latter, like the bees, sip out a sweet and profitable juice.
Some rise by sin, and some by virtue fall; /
Some run from brakes of vice and answer none, / And some condemnéd for a fault alone.
Some slaves are scourged to their work by whips, others by restlessness and ambition.
Some straw, a room, water, and in the fourth place, gentle words. These things are never to be refused in good men's houses.
Some talkers excel in the precision with which they formulate their thoughts, so that you get from them somewhat to remember; others lay criticism asleep by a charm.
Some tears belong to us because we are unfortunate; others, because we are humane; many, because we are mortal. But most are caused by our being unwise. It is these last only that of necessity produce more.
Some that speak no ill of any do no good to
any.
Some there be that shadows kiss, / Such have but a shadow's bliss.
Some to whom Heaven in wit has been profuse, / Want as much more to turn it to its use.
Some treasures are heavy with human tears, as an ill-stored harvest with untimely rain; and some gold is brighter in sunshine than in substance.
Some troops pursue the bloody-minded queen / That led calm Henry.
Some village Hampden, that with dauntless
breast / The little tyrant of his fields withstood, / Some mute inglorious Milton here may rest, / Some Cromwell guiltless of his country's blood.
Some virtues are only seen in affliction, and some in prosperity.
Some wee short hours ayont the twal.
Some work in the morning may trimly be done, / That all the day after may hardly be won.
Some would be thought to do great things who are but tools and instruments, like the fool who fancied he played upon the organ when he only blew the bellows.
Something attempted, something done, / Has
earned a night's repose.
Something between a hindrance and a help.
Something is rotten in the state of Denmark.
Something is wanting to science until it has been humanised.
Something of a person's character may be discovered by observing when and how he smiles. Some people never smile. They only grin.
Sometimes from her eyes / I did receive fair
speechless messages.
Sometimes ideas are made flesh; they breathe upon us with warm breath; they touch us with soft responsive hands; they look upon us with sad, sincere eyes, and speak to us in appealing tones.
Sometimes the half is better than the whole, / And sometimes worse than none; the dubious soul / Suspects the secret there in what is hid, / And holds the rest but trash.
Sometimes / 'Tis well to be bereft of promised good, / That we may lift the soul, and contemplate / With lively joy the joys we cannot share.
Somnus agrestium / Lenis virorum non humiles domos / Fastidit, umbrosamque ripam
Somnus est imago mortis
Son genre n'est pas le plus grand, mais elle est la plus grande dans son genre
Sonder Falsch wie die Tauben! und ihr beleidiget keinen; / Aber klug wie die Schlangen und euch beleidiget keiner
Song is the heroic of speech.
Song is the tone of feeling.
Songs may exist unsung, but voices exist
only when they sound.
Soon enough, if well enough.
Soon hot, soon cold.
Soon or late the strong need the help of the weak.
Soon ripe, soon rotten.
Sooner earth / Might go round heaven, and
the strait girth of Time / Inswathe the fulness of Eternity, / Than language grasp the infinite of Love.
Sooner or later the truth comes to light.
Soothed with the sound, the king grew vain, / Fought all his battles o'er again; / And thrice he routed all his foes, / And thrice he slew the slain.
Sordid and infamous sensuality, the most dreadful of the evils that issued from the box of Pandora, corrupts every heart and eradicates every virtue.
Sorex suo perit indicio
Sorrow breaks seasons and reposing hours, / Makes the night morning and the noontide night.
Sorrow concealed, like an oven stopped, / Doth burn the heart to cinders where it is.
Sorrow has ever produced more melody than mirth.
Sorrow has not been given us for sorrow's sake, but always as a lesson from which we are to learn somewhat, which once learned, it ceases to be sorrow.
Sorrow is always toward ourselves, not
heaven; / Showing, we would not spare heaven, as we love it, / But as we stand in fear.
Sorrow is an enemy, but it carries a friend's message within it too. All life is as death; and the tree Igdrasil, which reaches up to heaven, goes down to the kingdom of hell; and God, the Everlasting Good and Just, is in it all.
Sorrow is better than laughter; for by the sadness of the countenance the heart is made better.
Sorrow is good for nothing but sin.
Sorrow is knowledge; they who know the most must mourn the deepest over the fatal truth, the tree of knowledge is not that of life.
Sorrow is shadow to life, moving where life doth move.
Sorrow is the mere rust of the soul. Activity
will cleanse and brighten it.
Sorrow, like a heavy-hanging bell, once set on ringing, with his own strength goes; then little strength rings out the doleful knell.
Sorrow like this / Draws parted lives in one, and knits anew / The rents which time has made.
Sorrow of spirit (like Night among the Greeks) is the mother of gods.
Sorrow seems sent for our instruction, as we darken the cages of birds when we would teach them to sing.
Sorrow that is couched in seeming gladness /
Is like that mirth fate turns to sudden sadness.
Sorrow will pay no debt.
Sorrows are like thunder-clouds--in the distance they look black, over our heads hardly gray.
Sorrows are often evolved from good fortune.
Sorrow's crown of sorrow is remembering happier things.
Sorrows remembered sweeten present joy.
Sors tua mortalis; non est mortale quod optas
Sort thy heart to patience; / These few days' wonder will be quickly worn.
Sotto voce
Souffrir est la première chose qu'il doit apprendre, et celle qu'il aura le plus grand besoin de savoir
Souls made of fire, and children of the sun,
with whom revenge is virtue.
Souls must become expanded by the contemplation of Nature's grandeur before they can first comprehend the greatness of man.
Sound and sufficient reason falls, after all, to the share of but few men, and those few men exert their influence in silence.
Sound maxims are the germs of good; strongly imprinted on the memory, they nourish the will.
Sound, sound the clarion, fill the fife! / To all the sensual world proclaim, / One crowded hour of glorious life / Is worth an age without a name.
Sound the loud timbrel o'er Egypt's dark sea! /
Jehovah has triumph'd, His people are free.
Sound trumpets!--let our bloody colours wave; / And either victory or else a grave.
Soupçon est d'amitié poison
Sour woe delights in fellowship, / And needly will be rank'd with other griefs.
Souvent la perfidie retourne sur son auteur
Sow good works and you will reap gladness.

Space is the statue of God.
Spare but to spend, and only spend to spare.
Spare the rod and spoil the child.
Sparen ist grössere Kunst als erwerben
Sparing or spending, be thy wisdom seen / In keeping ever to the golden mean.
Speak every man truth with his neighbour.
Speak gently!--'tis a little thing, / Dropped
in the heart's deep well.
Speak in such a manner between two enemies, that, should they afterwards become friends, you may not be put to the blush.
Speak little and to the purpose.
Speak little, but speak the truth.
Speak no evil of a man if you know it not of him for certain, and if you do know it, then ask yourself, "Why do I tell it?"
Speak not at all till you have somewhat to
speak; and care simply and with undivided mind for the truth of your speaking.
Speak not peace to thyself when beset on every side with numerous and restless enemies.
Speak o' the deil and he'll appear.
Speak of me as I am; nothing extenuate, / Nor set down aught in malice. Then must you speak / Of one who loved not wisely but too well.
Speak that I may see thee.
Speak the truth, and all nature and all spirits
help you with unexpected furtherance; all things alive or brute are vouchers, and the very roots of the grass underground there do seem to stir and move to bear you witness.
Speak the truth and shame the devil.
Speak unto the children of Israel, that they go forward.
Speak well of the absent whenever you have a suitable opportunity.
Speak well of your friend; of your enemy say nothing.
Speak when you are spoken to, and come
when you are called for.
Speak your sincerest, think your wisest; there is still a great gulf between you and the fact.
Speaking comes by nature, silence by understanding.
Speaking much is a sign of vanity; for he that is lavish in words is a niggard in deed.
Speaking without thinking is shooting without aim.
Spectatum veniunt, veniunt spectentur ut ipsæ
Spectemur agendo
Spectres exist for those only who wish to see them.
Speculation should have free course and look fearlessly towards all the thirty-two points of the compass, whithersoever and howsoever it listeth.
Speech, even the commonest, has something of song in it.
Speech has been given to man to disguise his
thought.
Speech is a laggard and a sloth, but the eyes shoot forth an electric fluid that condenses all the elements of sentiment and passion in one single emanation.
Speech is external thought, and thought internal speech.
Speech is like tapestry unfolded, where the imagery appears distinct; but thoughts, like tapestry in the bale, where the figures are rolled up together.
Speech is morning to the mind; it spreads the beauteous images abroad, which else lie furled or clouded in the soul.
Speech is power: speech is to persuade, to
convert, to compel. It is to bring another out of his bad sense into your good sense.
Speech is the gift of all, but thought of few.
Speech is too often, not the art of concealing thought, but of quite stifling or suspending thought, so that there is none to conceal.
Speech of a man's self ought to be seldom and well chosen.
Speech that leads not to action, still more that hinders it, is a nuisance on the earth.
Speedy execution is the mother of good fortune.

Spem pretio non emo
Spend not on hopes.

Spill not the morning (the quintessence of the day) in recreation, for sleep itself is a recreation. Add not, therefore, sauce to sauce.
Spinner, spin softly, you disturb me. I am praying.
Spinoza was a God-intoxicated man
Spirit is the creator. Spirit hath life in itself. And man in all ages and countries embodies it in his language as the Father.
Spirit of Nature! / The pure diffusion of thy essence throbs / Alike in every human heart. / Thou aye erectest there / Thy throne of power unappealable; / Thou art the judge beneath whose nod / Man's brief and frail authority / Is powerless as the wind / That passeth idly by. / Thine the tribunal which surpasseth / The show of human justice, / As God surpasseth man.
Spirit-power begins in directing animal power to other than egoistic ends.
Spirits are not finely touch'd / But to fine issues, nor Nature never lends / The smallest scruple of her excellence / But, like a thrifty goddess, she determines / Herself the glory of a creditor, / Both thanks and use.
Spirits, when they please, / Can either sex
assume, or both.
Spiritual music can only spring from discords set in unison; but for evil there were no good, as victory is only possible by battle.
Spite of all the criticising elves, / Those who would make us feel must feel themselves.
Spite of cormorant devouring Time, / The endeavour of this present breath may buy / That honour which will bate his scythe's keen edge, / And make us heirs of all eternity.
Splendida vitia
Splendide mendax
Spolia opima
Sport is the bloom and glow of perfect health.
Sprechen ist silbern, Schweigen ist golden
Sprich nicht von Zeit, sprich nicht von Raum, / Denn Raum und Zeit sind nur ein Traum, / Ein schwerer Traum, den nur vergisst, / Wer durch die Liebe glücklich ist
Sprich vom Geheimniss nicht geheimnissvoll
St. Theresa right well defines the devil as an
unfortunate who knows not what it is to love.
Stab at thee who will, / No stab the soul can kill.
Stabat mater dolorosa / Juxta crucem lacrymosa / Qua pendebat Filius
Stabit quocunque jeceris
Stagnation is something more than death, it is corruption also.
Stain
resentment, nor take off from the brightness of thy crown by anger and impatience and eagerness to right thyself.
Stand fast! to stand or fall, / Free in thine own arbitrament it stands.
Stand not upon the order of your going, / But go at once.
"Stand out of the sun."
Stand still and see the salvation of the Lord.
Stand up bravely to afflictions, and quit thyself
like a man.
Stand ye in the ways, and see, and ask for the old paths, where is the good way, and walk therein.
Standing on what too long we bore / With shoulders bent and downcast eyes, / We may discern--unseen before--/ A path to higher destinies.

Stare super vias antiquas

Stars look down upon me with pity from their serene and silent places, like eyes glistening with tears over the little lot of man. Arcturus and Orion, Sirius and Pleiades, are still shining in their courses, clear and young, as when the shepherd first noted them in the plain of Shinar!
Stat sua cuique dies; breve et irreparabile tempus / Omnibus est vitæ; sed famam extendere factis, / Hoc virtutis opus

Statesmen that are wise / Shape a necessity, as sculptor clay, / To their own model.

Stay awhile to make an end the sooner.
Steady, durable good cannot be derived from an external cause, by reason all derived from externals must fluctuate as they fluctuate. What then remains but the cause internal; in rectitude of conduct?

years ago, but it is put to better use.

Steep regions cannot be surmounted except by winding paths.

Step by step one goes far.
Steps vary as much as the human face.

Stern Ruin's ploughshare drives elate / Full on thy bloom.

himself is obliged to stir in the administration of justice.
Stiff (a) and laboured manner is as bad in a letter as it is in conversation.... Sprightliness and wit are graceful in letters, just as they are in conversation.
Stiff in opinions, always in the wrong, / Was everything by starts, and nothing long; / But in the course of one revolving moon / Was chemist, fiddler, statesman, and buffoon.
Still humanity grows dearer; / Being learned the more.
Still in thy right hand carry gentle peace, / To silence envious tongues.
Still people are dangerous.
Still raise for good the supplicating voice, / But leave to Heaven the measure and the choice.
Still seems it strange that thou shouldst live for ever? Is it less strange that thou shouldst live at all? This is a miracle; and that no more.
Still swine eat all the draff.
Still the sight of too great beauty blinds us,
and we lose / The sense of earthly splendours, gaining heaven.
Still the skies are opened as of old / To the entrancèd gaze, ay, nearer far / And brighter than of yore.
Still they gazed, and still the wonder grew / That one small head could carry all he knew.
Still to the lowly soul / He doth Himself impart, / And for His cradle and His throne / Chooseth the pure in heart.
Still und bewegt
Still waters run deep.
Stillest streams oft water finest meadows, / And the bird that flutters least is longest on the wing.
Stillness of person and steadiness of features are signal marks of good breeding. Vulgar persons can't sit still, or at least they must work their limbs or features.

others, "Here lies such a one."

Stolen waters are sweet, and bread eaten in secret is pleasant.
Stone masons collected the dome of St. Paul's, but Wren hung it in the air.
Stony limits cannot hold love out; / And what love can do, that dares love attempt.
Store of grain, O king! is the best of stores.
A gem cast into the mouth will not support life.

Storms make oaks take deeper root.
Strait is the gate, and narrow is the way, that leadeth unto life; and few there be that find it.
Strange cozenage! none would live past years again; / Yet all hope pleasure in what yet remain; / And from the dregs of life think to receive / What the first sprightly running could not give.
Strange is the life of man, and fatal or fated
are moments, / Whereupon turn, as on hinges, the gates of the wall adamantine!
Strange trade that of advocacy. Your intellect, your highest heavenly gift, hung up in the shop window like a loaded pistol for sale; will either blow out a pestilent scoundrel's brains, or the scoundrel's salutary sheriff's officer's (in a sense), as you please to choose, for your guinea.
Stranger or countryman to me / Welcome alike shall ever be. / To ask of any guest his name, / Or whose he is, or whence he came, / I hold can never be his part / Who owns a hospitable heart.
Straws show which way the wind blows.
Strength alone knows conflict; weakness is below even defeat, and is born vanquished.
Strength, instead of being the lusty child of
passions, grows by grappling with and throwing them.
Strength needs support far more than weakness. A feather sustains itself long in the air.
Strength of mind is exercise, not rest.
Strength of mind rests in sobriety, for this keeps the reason unclouded by passion.
Strength was the virtue of Paganism; obedience is the virtue of Christianity.
Strenua nos exercet inertia; navibus atque /
Quadrigis petimus bene vivere; quod petis hic est
Strict laws are like steel bodices, good for growing limbs; but when the joints are knit, they are not helps, but burdens.
Strict punctuality is perhaps the cheapest virtue which can give force to an otherwise utterly insignificant character.
Strictly speaking, the imagination is never governed; it is always the ruling and divine power, and the rest of the man is to it only as an instrument which it sounds, or a tablet on which it writes; clearly and sublimely if the wax be smooth and the strings true, grotesquely and wildly if they are stained and broken.
Strike, but hear me.
Strike flat the thick rotundity o' the world! /
Crack Nature's moulds, all germens spill at once, / That make ungrateful man!
Strike those that hurt, and hurt not those that help.
Strike while the iron is hot.
Striking manners are bad manners.
Strip the bishop of his apron, the counsellor of his gown, and the beadle of his cocked hat, what are they? Men, mere men. Dignity, and even holiness too sometimes, are more questions of coat and waistcoat than some people imagine.
Strive mightily, but eat and drink as friends.
Strive not against the stream.
Strive to do thy duty; then shalt thou know what is in thee.
Striving to better, oft we mar what's well.
Strong character curdles itself out of the scum into its own place and power or impotence.
Strong characters are brought out by change of situation, gentle ones by permanence.
Strong conceit, like a new principle, carries all easily with it, when yet above commonsense.
Strong feeling must create poetry.
Strong folks have strong maladies.
Strong passions are the life of manly virtues. But they need not necessarily be evil because they are passions and because they are strong. The passions may be likened to blood horses, that need training and the curb only to enable them whom they carry to achieve the most glorious triumphs.
Strong reasons make strong actions.
Strong Son of God, immortal Love, / Whom we that have not seen Thy face, / By faith, and faith alone, embrace, / Believing where we cannot prove.
Stronger than steel / Is the sword of the
spirit; / Swifter than arrows / The life of the truth is; / Greater than anger / Is love, and subdueth.
Strongest minds / Are often those of whom the noisy world / Hears least.
Studies perfect nature, and are perfected by experience.
Studies serve for delight, for ornament, and for ability.
Studiis et rebus honestis
Studiis florentem ignobilis oti
Studio minuente laborem
Study gives strength to the mind; conversation, grace.
Study is like the heaven's glorious sun, / That will not be deep-searched with saucy looks.
Study is the bane of boyhood, the element of youth, the indulgence of manhood, and the restorative of age.
Study of the Bible will keep any man from
being vulgar in style.
Study the best and highest things that are, / But of thyself an humble thought retain.
Study the past if you would divine the future.
Study thyself; what rank or what degree / The wise Creator hath ordained for thee.
Study to be quiet; contain yourself within your own business, and let the prying, censorious, the vain and the intriguing world follow their own devices.
Study to be what you wish to seem.

care for nice discriminations. They always have decided opinions.
Stupid people move like lay-figures, while every joint of an intelligent man is eloquent.

Succedaneum
Success (by laws of competition) signifies always so much victory over your neighbour as to obtain the direction of his work and take the profits of it. This is the real source of all great riches.
Success consecrates the foulest crimes.
Success? If the thing is unjust, thou hast not succeeded.
Success in the majority of circumstances depends
on knowing how long it takes to succeed.
Success in war, like charity in religion, covers a multitude of sins.
Success is full of promise till men get it, and then it seems like a nest from which the bird has flown.
Success is sweet; the sweeter if long delayed, and attained through manifold struggles and defeats.
Success is the child of audacity.
Success makes men look larger, if reflection
does not measure them.
Success makes success, as money makes money.
Success often costs more than it is worth.
Success tempts many to their ruin.
Success throws a veil over the evil deeds of men.
Success! to thee, as to a god, men bend the
knee.
Successful love takes a load off our hearts and puts it on our shoulders.
Such a friend as speaketh kindly to a man's face, and behind his back defeateth his designs, is like a pot of poison with a surface of milk.
Such a genius as philosophers must of necessity have is wont but seldom, in all its parts, to meet in one man; but its different parts generally spring up in different persons.
Such a plot must have a woman in it.
Such as are careless of themselves can hardly
be mindful of others.
Such as are in the married state wish to get out, and such as are out wish to get in.
Such as every one is inwardly, so he judgeth outwardly.
Such as we are made of, such we be.
Such hath been--shall be--beneath the sun, / That many still must labour for the one.
Such is hope, Heaven's own gift to struggling
mortals; pervading, like some subtle essence from the skies, all things both good and bad.
Such is the aspect of this shore; / 'Tis Greece, but living Greece no more! / So coldly sweet, so deadly fair, / We start, for soul is wanting there.
Such only enjoy the country as are capable of thinking when they are there; then they are prepared for solitude, and in that case solitude is prepared for them.
Such tricks hath strong imagination, / That, if it would but apprehend some joy, / It comprehends some bringer of that joy; / Or in the night, imagining some fear, / How easy is a bush supposed a bear.
Such war of white and red within her cheeks.

Sudden blaze of kindness may, by a single blast of coldness, be extinguished; but that fondness which length of time has connected with many circumstances and occasions, though it may for a while be suppressed by disgust or resentment, with or without cause, is hourly revived by accidental recollection.
Sudden love is the latest cured.
Sudden resolutions, like the sudden rise of the mercury in the barometer, indicate little else than the changeableness of the weather.
Sudden tumultuous popularity comes more from partial delirium on both sides than from clear insight, and is of evil omen to all concerned with it.

Suffer no hour to slide by without its due improvement.
Suffer thyself to be led in everything but feeling and thinking.
Sufferance is the badge of all our tribe.
Suffering in human life is very widely vicarious.
Suffering is part of the divine idea.
Suffering is the mother of fools, reason of wise men.
Suffering which falls to our lot in the course of nature, or by chance or fate, does not, "ceteris paribus," seem so painful as suffering which is inflicted on us by the arbitrary will of another.

Super subjectam materiam
Superbo è quel cavallo che non si vuol portar
la biada
Superfluity comes sooner by white hairs, but competency lives longer.
Superior powers of mind and profound study are of no use if they do not sometimes lead a person to different conclusions from those which are formed by ordinary powers of mind without study.
Superior strength is found in the long-run to lie with those who had the right on their side.
Supersedeas
Superstition changes a man to a beast,
fanaticism makes him a wild beast, and despotism a beast of burden.
Superstition is a misdirection of religious feeling.
Superstition is an unreasoning fear of God; religion consists in the pious worship of the gods.
Superstition is but the fear of belief; religion is the confidence.
Superstition is certainly not the characteristic of this age. Yet some men are bigoted in politics who are infidels in religion.
Superstition is in its death-lair; the last
agonies may endure for decades or for centuries; but it carries the iron in its heart, and will not vex the earth any more.
Superstition is inherent in man's nature; and when we think it is wholly eradicated, it takes refuge in the strangest holes and corners, whence it peeps out all at once, as soon as it can do so with safety.
Superstition is passing away without return. Religion cannot pass away. The burning of a little straw may hide the stars in the sky; but the stars are there, and will re-appear.
Superstition is related to this life, religion to the next; superstition allies itself to fatality, religion to virtue; it is by the vitality of earthly desires we become superstitious, and by the sacrifice of these desires that we become religious.
Superstition is the fear of a spirit whose passions and acts are those of a man, who is present in some places, and not in others; who makes some places holy, and not others; who is kind to one person, and unkind to another; who is pleased or angry according to the degree of attention you pay him, or praise you refuse him; who is hostile generally to human pleasure, but may be bribed by sacrificing a part of that pleasure into permitting the rest.
Superstition is the only religion of which base
souls are capable.
Superstition is the poesy of life, so that it does not injure the poet to be superstitious.
Superstition! that horrid incubus which dwelt in darkness, shunning the light, with all its racks, and poison chalices, and foul sleeping draughts, is passing away without return.
Superstition without a veil is a deformed thing.
Superstitions would soon die out if so many old women would not act as nurses to keep them alive.
Supple knees feed arrogance.
Suppose a neighbour should desire / To light a candle at your fire, / Would it deprive your flame of light / Because another profits by't.
Suppressing love is but opposing the natural dictates of the heart.

Supra vires
Supremum vale
Sur esperance
Surdo fabulam narras
Sure as night follows day, / Death treads in pleasure's footsteps round the world, / When pleasure treads the path which reason shuns.
Sure, he that made us with such large discourse, / Looking before and after, gave us not / That capability and godlike reason / To fust in us unused.
Sure, of qualities demanding praise, / More go
to ruin fortunes, than to raise.
Sure those who have neither strength nor weapons to fight at least should be civil.
Surely half the world must be blind; they can see nothing unless it glitters.
Surely it is better to enclose the gulf and hinder all access, than by encouraging us to advance a little, to entice us afterwards a little further, and let us perceive our folly only by our destruction.
Surely life, if it be not long, is tedious, since we are forced to call in the assistance of so many trifles to rid us of our time, of that time which can never return.
Surely men of low degree are vanity, and men
of high degree are a lie; to be laid in the balance they are altogether lighter than vanity.
Surely nobody would be a charlatan who could afford to be sincere.
Surely the best way is to meet the enemy in the field, and not wait till he plunders us in our very bed-chamber.
Surely use alone / Makes money not a contemptible stone.
Surement va qui n'a rien
Surfeit has killed more than hunger.
Surfeit of the sweetest things / The deepest loathing to the stomach brings.
Surfeits destroy more than the sword.
Surgit post nubila Phœbus

Sus Minervam
Susceptibility to one class of influences, the selection of what is fit for him, the rejection of what is unfit, determines for a man the character of the universe.
Suspectum semper invisumque dominantibus, qui proximus destinaretur
Suspendens omnia naso
Suspense is worse than disappointment.
Suspicion always haunts the guilty mind; / The thief doth fear each bush an officer.
Suspicion is a heavy armour, and with its own weight impedes more than protects.
Suspicion is no less an enemy to virtue than to
happiness.
Suspicion is the bane of friendship.
Suspicion is very often a useless pain.
Suspicion shall be all stuck full of eyes.
Suspicions amongst thoughts are like bats amongst birds; they ever fly by twilight; they are to be repressed, or at the least well guarded, for they cloud the mind.
Suspicions are nothing when a man is really
true, and every one should persevere in acting honestly, for all will be made right in time.

Swearing is invoking the witness of a spirit to an assertion you wish to make, but cursing is invoking the assistance of a spirit in a mischief you wish to inflict.
Sweep before your own door.
Sweet are the uses of adversity, / Which like
the toad, ugly and venomous, / Wears yet a precious jewel in his head; / And this our life, exempt from public haunt, / Finds tongues in trees, books in the running brooks, / Sermons in stones, and good in everything.
Sweet bird, that shunn'st the noise of folly, / Most musical, most melancholy.
Sweet flowers are slow, and weeds make haste.
Sweet is the breath of morn, her rising sweet, / With charm of earliest birds.
Sweet is the lore which Nature brings; / Our meddling intellect / Misshapes the beauteous form of things: / We murder to dissect.
Sweet is true love though given in vain, / And
sweet is death that puts an end to pain.
Sweet mercy is nobility's true badge.
Sweet pliability of man's spirit, that can at once surrender itself to illusions which cheat expectation and sorrow of their weary moments!
Sweet reader, do you know what a toady is? That agreeable animal which you meet every day in civilised society.
Sweet Swan of Avon.
Sweetest melodies are those that are by distance
made more sweet.
Swift kindnesses are best: a long delay / In kindness takes the kindness all away.
Swift to its close ebbs out life's little day.
Sworn to no master, of no sect am I; / As drives the storm, at any door I knock, / And house with Montaigne now, and now with Locke.
Syllables govern the world.
Sympathetic people are often uncommunicative
about themselves; they give back reflected images which hide their own depths.
Sympathising and selfish people are alike given to tears.
Sympathy can create the boldness which no other means can evoke.
Sympathy is the first condition of criticism; reason and justice presuppose, at their origin, emotion.
Sympathy is the first great lesson which man should learn.... Unless he learns to feel for things in which he has no personal interest, he can achieve nothing generous or noble.
Sympathy is the solace of the poor, but for the
rich there is consolation.
Sympathy is two hearts tugging at one load.
Sympathy wanting, all is wanting; its personal magnetism is the conductor of the sacred spark that lights our atoms, puts us in human communion, and gives us to company, conversation, and ourselves.
Sympathy with Nature is a part of the good man's religion.

Tages Arbeit, Abends Gäste, / Saure Wochen,
