Take a bird from a clean nest.
Take a farthing from a thousand pounds, it will be a thousand pounds no longer.
Take a hair of the same dog that bit you, and it will heal the wound.
Take a stick to a Highland laddie, and it's no him you hurt, but his ancestors.
Take all that is given, whether wealth, / Or
love, or language; nothing comes amiss; / A good digestion turneth all to health.
Take any subject of sorrowful regret, and see with how much pleasure it is associated.
Take away desire from the heart, and you take away the air from the earth.
Take care of the pence; the pounds will take care of themselves.
Take care to be an economist in prosperity; there is no fear of your not being one in adversity.
Take each man's censure, but reserve thy
judgment.
Take everything easy
 (
Take fast hold of instruction; let her not go: keep her, for she is thy life.
Take from the philosopher the pleasure of being heard, and his desire for knowledge ceases.
Take heed, and beware of covetousness; for a man's life consisteth not in the abundance of the things which he possesseth.
Take heed of the vinegar of sweet wine.
Take heed you find not that you do not seek.
Take-it-easy and Live-long are brothers.
Take my yoke upon you, and learn of me; for I am meek and lowly in heart; and ye shall find rest unto your souls.
Take no thought for the morrow; for the morrow shall take thought for the things of itself.
Take no thought for your life, what ye shall
eat, or what ye shall drink; nor yet for your body, what ye shall put on.
Take not His name who made thy mouth in vain: / It gets thee nothing, and has no excuse.
Take note, take note, O world, / To be direct and honest is not safe.
Take physic, pomp; / Expose thyself to feel what wretches feel; / That thou mayst shake the superflux to them, / And show the heavens more just.
Take the Muses' servants by the hand; / ... And where ye justly can commend, commend them; / And aiblins when they winna stand the test, / Wink hard, and say the folks hae done their best.
Take the showers as they fall, / ... Enough
if at the end of all / A little garden blossom.
Take this rule, ... The best-bred child hath the best portion.
Take thou the beam out of thine own eye; then shalt thou see clearly to take the mote out of thy brother's.
Take thought for thy body with steadfast fidelity. The soul must see through these eyes alone; and if they are dim, the whole world is beclouded.
Take time by the forelock.
Take time in time, ere time be tint
Take time in turning a corner.
Take up the torch and wave it wide, / The torch that lights Time's thickest gloom.
Take your thirst to the stream, as the dog does.
Taking, therefore, my opinion of the English from the virtues and vices practised among the vulgar, they at once present to a stranger all their faults, and keep their virtues up only for the inquiring of a philosopher.
Tale tuum carmen nobis, divine poeta, / Quale
sopor fessis
Talent alone cannot make a writer. There must be a man behind the book.
Talent for literature, thou hast such a talent? Believe it not, be slow to believe it! To speak or to write, Nature did not peremptorily order thee; but to work she did.
Talent forms itself in secret; character, in the great current of the world.
Talent has almost always this advantage
over genius--that the former endures, the latter often explodes, or runs to waste
Talent is a cistern; genius, a fountain.
Talent is a gift which God has imparted in secret, and which we reveal without knowing it.
Talent is some one faculty unusually developed; genius commands all the faculties.
Talent is something, but tact is everything. It is not a seventh sense, but is the life of all the five. It is the open eye, the quick ear, the judging taste, the keen smell, and the lively touch; it is the interpreter of all riddles, the surmounter of all difficulties, the remover of all obstacles.
Talent is that which is in a man's power; genius is that in whose power a man is.
Talent ist Form, Genie Stoff
Talent, lying in the understanding, is often inherited; genius, being the action of reason and imagination, rarely or never.
Talents angel-bright, if wanting worth, are shining instruments in false ambition's hand, to finish faults illustrious, and give infamy renown.
Talents give a man a superiority far more agreeable than that which proceeds from riches, birth, or employments, which are all external. Talents constitute our very essence.
Taliter qualiter
Talk, except as the preparation for work, is
worth almost nothing; sometimes it is worth infinitely less than nothing; and becomes, little conscious of playing such a fatal part, the general summary of pretentious nothingnesses, and the chief of all the curses the posterity of Adam are liable to in this sublunary world.
Talk of the devil and he'll appear.
Talk that does not end in action is better suppressed altogether.
Talk to him of Jacob's ladder, and he would ask the number of the steps.
Talkers are no good doers.
Talking is one of the fine arts.
Talking is the disease of age.
Talking of love is making it.
Talking with a host is next best to talking with one's self.... He is wiser than to contradict his guest in any case; he lets him go on, he lets him travel.
Tam deest avaro quod habet, quam quod non habet
Tam diu discendum est, quum diu nescias, et,
si proverbio credimus, quam diu vivas
Tam Marte quam Minerva
Tam Marti quam Mercurio
Tam felix utinam, quam pectore candidus, essem
Tam lo'ed him like a vera brither; / They had been fou for weeks thegither.

Tandem poculum mœroris exhausit

Tanquam ungues digitosque suos

Tant mieux
Tant pis
Tant va la cruche à l'eau qu'à la fin elle se brise

Tanti eris aliis, quanti tibi fueris

Tantum religio potuit suadere malorum

Tarda sit illa dies, et nostro serior ævo
Tarda solet magnis rebus inesse fides
Tarde, quæ credita lædunt, credimus
Tarde sed tute
Tarde venientibus ossa
Tardiora sunt remedia quam mala
Tasks in hours of insight willed, / In hours of gloom must be fulfilled.
Taste can only be educated by contemplation, not of the tolerably good, but of the truly excellent.
Taste depends upon those finer emotions which make the organisation of the soul.
Taste, if it mean anything but a paltry connoisseurship, must mean a general susceptibility to truth and nobleness; a sense to discern and a heart to love and reverence all beauty, order, goodness, wheresoever found and in whatsoever form and accompaniment.
Taste is the very maker of judgment.
Taste may change, but inclination never.
Taurum tollet qui vitulum sustulerit
Te Deum laudamus
Te digna sequere
Te, Fortuna, sequor: procul hinc jam fœdera sunto: / Credidimus fatis, utendum est judice bello
Te hominem esse memento
Te sine nil altum mens inchoat
Teach me to feel another's woe, / To hide the fault I see; / That mercy I to others show, / That mercy show to me.
Teach self-denial, and make its practice pleasurable, and you create for the world a destiny more sublime than ever issued from the brain of the wildest dreamer.
Teach your children poetry; it opens the mind, lends grace to wisdom, and makes the heroic virtues hereditary.
Teaching has not a tithe of the efficacy of
training.
Teaching is of more importance than exhortation.
Teaching others teacheth yourself.
Tearless grief bleeds inwardly.
Tears are due to human misery.
Tears are often to be found where there is
little sorrow, and the deepest sorrow without tears.
Tears are the deluge of sin and the world's sacrifice.
Tears are the symbol of the inability of the soul to restrain its emotion and retain its self-command.
Tears, idle tears, I know not what they mean, / Tears from the depth of some divine despair / Rise in the heart and gather in the eyes, / In looking on the happy autumn fields, / And thinking of the days that are no more.
Tears of joy are the dew in which the sun of righteousness is mirrored.
Tears of joy, like summer rain-drops, are
pierced by sunbeams.
Tears such as angels weep.
Tecum habita
Teeth, hair, nails, and the human species, prosper not when separated from their place. A wise man, being informed of this, should not totally forsake his native home.
Tel brille au second rang, qui s'éclipse au premier
Tel coup de langue est pire qu'un coup de
lance
Tel, en vous lisant, admire chaque trait, / Qui dans le fond de l'âme vous craint et vous hait
Tel excelle à rimer qui juge sottement
Tel maître, tel valet
Tel père, tel fils
Tel vous semble applaudir, qui vous raille et
vous joue; / Aimez qu'on vous conseille, et non pas qu'on vous loue
Tell it not in Gath, publish it not in the streets of Askelon.
"Tell me how you bear so blandly the assuming ways of wild young people?" Truly they would be unbearable if I had not also been unbearable myself as well.
Tell me not, in mournful numbers, / "Life is but an empty dream," / For the soul is dead that slumbers, / And things are not what they seem.
Tell me what you like, and I will tell you what you are.
Tell me where is fancy bred, / Or in the heart,
or in the head? / How begot, how nourishéd? / It is engender'd in the eyes, / With gazing fed.
Tell me with whom you associate, and I will tell you who you are; if I know what it is with which you occupy yourself, I know what you may become.
Tell the truth and shame the devil.
Telum imbelle sine ictu
Temeritas est florentis ætatis, prudentia senescentis
Temper--a weapon that we hold by the blade.
Temper is so good a thing that we should never lose it.
Temperament lies behind mood; back of the caprice of will lies the fate of character; back of both is the bias of family; back of that, the tyranny of race; still deeper, the power of climate, of soil, of geology, the whole physical and moral environment. Still we are free men only so far as we rise above these.
Temperance and labour are the two best physicians of man.
Temperance is a bridle of gold.
Temperance is a tree which has for its root very little contentment, and for its fruit calm and peace.
Temperance is the nurse of chastity.
Tempi passati!
Templa quam dilecta!
Tempora labuntur, tacitisque senescimus annis;
/ Et fugiunt fræno non remorante dies
Tempora mutantur, nos et mutamur in illis
Tempore ducetur longo fortasse cicatrix; / Horrent admotas vulnera cruda manus
Tempted Fate will leave the loftiest star.

Tempus edax rerum
Tempus erit quo vos speculum vidisse pigebit

Tempus fugit

Ten censure wrong for one who writes amiss.
Tenax et fidelis
Tenax propositi
Tendency to sentimental whining or fierce intolerance may be ranked among the surest symptoms of little souls and inferior intellects.
Tenderness is a virtue.
Tenderness is the repose of passion.

Teneros animos aliena opprobria sæpe / Absterrent vitiis
Tenet insanabile multos / Scribendi cacoëthes
Tenez la bride haute à votre fils

Tollere humo, victorque virûm volitare per ora
Tenterden steeple was the cause of Goodwin Sands.

Terrible penalty, with the ass-ears or without them, inevitable as death, written for ever in heaven, against all who, like Midas, misjudge the inner and the upper melodies, and prefer gold to goodness, desire to duty, falsehood to fact, wild nature to God, and a sensual piping Pan to a high-souled, wise-hearted, and spirit-breathing Apollo.
Tertium quid
Tertium sal
Tertius e cœlo cecidit Cato
Testimony is like an arrow shot from a long bow; the force of it depends upon the strength of the hand that draws it. Argument is like an arrow from a cross-bow, which has equal force though shot by a child.
Tête-à-tête
Tête d'armée!
Tête de fou ne blanchit jamais
Teuer ist mir der Freund, doch auch den Feind kann ich nützen; / Zeigt mir der Freund, was ich kann, lehrt mich der Feind, was ich soll
That action is not warrantable which either blushes to beg a blessing, or, having succeeded, dares not present a thanksgiving.
That but this blow / Might be the be-all and the end-all here, / But here, upon this bank and shoal of time, / We'd jump the life to come.
That carries anger as the flint bears fire; / Who, much enforcèd, shows a hasty spark, / And straight is cold again.
That cause is strong which has not a multitude, but one strong man behind it.
That circle of beings, which dependence gathers round us, is almost ever unfriendly.
That civility is best which excludes all superfluous formality.
That cutting up, and parcelling, and labelling,
of the indivisible human soul into what are called "faculties," I have from of old eschewed, and even hated.
That death's unnatural that kills for loving.
That elevation of mind which we see in moments of peril, if it is uncontrolled by justice, and strives only for its own advantage, becomes a crime.
That friendship only is, indeed, genuine when two friends, without speaking a word to each other, can, nevertheless, find happiness in being together.
That friendship, which is exerted in too wide a sphere, becomes totally useless.
That gentleman who sells an acre of land,
sells an ounce of credit.
That golden key that opes the palace of eternity.
That government is the best which makes government unnecessary.
That great mystery of time, were there no other; the illimitable, silent never-resting thing called "time," rolling, rushing on, swift, silent like an all-embracing oceantide, on which we and all the universe swim like exhalations, like apparitions which are and then are not--this is for ever very literally a miracle, a thing to strike us dumb; for we have no word to speak about it.
That grief is light which is capable of counsel.
That he is mad 'tis true; 'tis true, 'tis pity; /
And pity 'tis 'tis true.
That in the captain's but a choleric word, / Which in the soldier is flat blasphemy.
That intention which fixes upon God as its only end will keep men steady in their purposes, and deliver them from being the jest and scorn of fortune.
That is a most wretched fortune which is without an enemy.
That is a treacherous friend against whom you must always be on your guard. Such a friend is wine.
That is always best which gives me to myself.
That is but an empty purse that is full of other men's money.
That is friendship which is not feigned.
That is gold that is worth gold.
That is indeed a twofold knowledge which profits alike by the folly of the foolish and the wisdom of the wise. It is both a shield and a sword; it borrows its security from the darkness, and its confidence from the light.
That is not a council wherein there are no
sages.
That is not a duty in which there is not virtue.
That is not possible which is impossible.
That is not virtue from which fear approacheth us.
That is the best part of beauty which a picture cannot express.
That is the best part of each writer which has
nothing private in it.
That is the briefest and sagest of maxims which bids us "meddle not."
That is the true light which lighteth every man that cometh into the world.
That is the true season of love, when we believe that we alone can love, that no one could ever have loved so before us, and that no one will love in the same way after us.
That is true love which is always the same, whether you give everything or deny everything to it.
That is well spoken that is well taken.
That last infirmity of noble minds.
That learning which thou gettest by thy own observation and experience is far beyond that which thou gettest by precept; as the knowledge of a traveller exceeds that which is got by reading.
That life is long which answers life's great end.
That low vice curiosity.
That man has advanced far in the study of
morals who has mastered the difference between pride and vanity.
That man is always happy who is in the presence of something which he cannot know to the full, which he is always going on to know.
That man is an ill husband of his honour that entereth into any action, the failing wherein may disgrace him more than the carrying of it through can honour him.
That man is learned who reduceth his learning to practice.
That man is little to be envied whose patriotism would not gain force upon the plain of Marathon, or whose piety would not grow warmer among the ruins of Iona.
That man lives twice that lives the first life
well.
That man may last, but never lives, / Who much receives but nothing gives; / Whom none can love, whom none can thank--/ Creation's blot, creation's blank.
That man that hath a tongue, I say, is no man, / If with his tongue he cannot win a woman.
That man will never be a perfect gentleman who lives only with gentlemen. To be a man of the world we must view that world in every grade and in every perspective.
That Mirabeau understood how to act with others, and by others--this was his genius, this was his originality, this was his greatness.
That must be true which all men say.
That nation is in the enjoyment of liberty which stands by its own strength, and does not depend on the will of another.
That net that holds no great, takes little fish.
That one man should die ignorant who had capacity for knowledge, this I call tragedy.
That one will not, another will.
That philanthropy has surely a flaw in it which
cannot sympathise with the oppressor equally as with the oppressed.
That rich man is great who thinketh not himself great because he is rich; the proud man (who is the poor man) braggeth outwardly but beggeth inwardly; he is blown up, but not full.
That single effort by which we stop short in the down-hill path to perdition is of itself a greater exertion of virtue than a hundred acts of justice.
That souls which are created for one another so seldom find each other and are generally divided, that in the moments of happiest union least recognise each other--that is a sad riddle!
That State must sooner or later perish where the majority triumphs and unintelligence

That state of life is alone suitable to a man in
which and for which he was born, and he who is not led abroad by great objects is far happier at home.
That strain again! It had a dying fall: / Oh, it came o'er my ear like the sweet sound / That breathes upon a bank of violets, / Giving and stealing odour!
That suit is best that best fits me.
That that comes of a hen will scrape.
That that is, is.
That the voice of the common people is the voice
of God, is as full of falsehood as commonness. For who sees not that those black-mouthed hounds, upon the mere scent of opinion, as freely spend their mouths in hunting counter, or, like Actæon's dogs, in chasing an innocent man to death, as if they followed the chase of truth itself, in a fresh scent?
That thee is sent receive in buxomness: / The wrestling of this world asketh a fall. / Here is no home, here is but wilderness. / Forth, pilgrim, forth--on, best out of thy stall. / Look up on high, and thank the God of all.
That thought I regard as true which is fruitful to myself, which is connected with the rest of my thoughts, and at the same time helps me on. Now it is not only possible, but natural, that such a thought should not connect itself with the mind of another, nor help him on ... consequently he will regard it as false. Once we are thoroughly convinced of this, we shall never enter upon controversies.
That ugly treason of mistrust.
That unity which has not its origin in the multitude is tyranny.
That very law which moulds a tear, / And bids
it trickle from its source; / That law preserves the earth a sphere, / And guides the planets in their course.
That vice has often proved an emancipator of the mind is one of the most humiliating, but also one of the most unquestionable, facts in history.
That virtue which requires to be ever guarded is scarcely worth the sentinel.
That voluntary debility, which modern language is content to term indolence, will, if it is not counteracted by resolution, render in time the strongest faculties lifeless, and turn the flame to the smoke of virtue.
That warrior on his strong war-horse, fire flashes through his eyes; force dwells in his arm and heart; but warrior and war-horse are a vision; a revealed force, nothing more. Stately they tread the earth, as if it were firm substance. Fool! the earth is but a film; it cracks in twain, and warrior and war-horse sink beyond plummet's sounding.
That we devote ourselves to God is seen / In
living just as though no God there were.
That we shall die, we know; 'tis but the time / And drawing days out, that men stand upon.
That we should find our national existence depend on selling manufactured cotton at a farthing an ell cheaper than any other people, is a most narrow stand for a great nation to base itself on.
That we would do, / We should do when we would; for this "would" changes, / And hath abatements and delays as many / As there are tongues, are hands, are accidents; / And then this "should" is like a spendthrift's sigh, / That hurts by easing.
That were but a sorry art which could be comprehended all at once; the last point of which could be seen by one just entering its precincts.
That which builds is better than that which is
built.
That which can be done with perfect convenience and without loss, is not always the thing that most needs to be done, or which we are most imperatively required to do.
That which each man can do best, not but his Maker can teach him.
That which God writes on thy forehead thou wilt come to.
That which hath been is now; and that which is to be hath already been.
That which I crave may everywhere be had, /
With me I bring the one thing needful--love.
That which in mean men we entitle patience, / Is pale cold cowardice in noble breasts.
That which, intellectually considered, we call Reason, considered in relation to nature we call Spirit.
That which is crooked cannot be made straight: and that which is wanting cannot be numbered.
That which is good to take is good to keep.
That which is in the midst of fools is made
known.
That which is not allotted the hand cannot reach, and what is allotted will find you wherever you may be.
That which is past is gone and irrevocable, and wise men have enough to do with things present and to come; therefore they do but trifle with themselves that labour in past matters.
That which is possible is ever possible.
That which is truly and indeed characteristic of the man is known only to God.
That which makes men happy is activity
which, first producing what is good, soon changes evil itself into good by power working in a god-like manner.
That which one least anticipates soonest
comes to pass.
That which produces and maintains cheerfulness is nothing but activity.
That which proves too much proves nothing.
That which seems to be wealth may in verity be only the gilded index of far-reaching ruin; a wrecker's handful of coin gleaned from the beach to which he has beguiled an argosy.
That which the droning world, chained to appearances, will not allow the realist to say in his own words, it will suffer him to say in proverbs without contradiction.
That which the sun doth not now see will be
visible when the sun is out, and the stars are fallen from heaven.
That which two will takes effect.
That which upholdeth him, that thee upholds--His honour.
That which was bitter to endure may be sweet to remember.
That which we do not believe we cannot adequately say, though we may repeat the words never so often.
That which we have we prize not to the
worth; / But being lacked and lost, why then we rake its value.
That which we may live without we need not much covet.
That which will not be butter must be made into cheese.
That which will not be spun, let it not come between the spindle and the distaff.
That woman is despicable who, having children, ever feels ennui.
That wretchedness which fate has rendered
voiceless and tuneless is not the least wretched, but the most.
That's a lee wi' a lid on, / And a brass handle to tak ho'd on.
That's my good that does me good.
That's the best gown that goes up and down the house.
That's the humour of it.
That's what a man wants in a wife, mostly:
he wants to make sure o' one fool as'll tell him he's wise. But there's some men can do wi'out that--they think so much o' themselves a'ready--an' that's how it is there's old bachelors.
The abandoning of some lower end in obedience to a higher aim is often made the very condition of securing the lower one.
The abiding city and post at which we can live and die is still ahead of us, it would appear.
The absent one is an ideal person; those who are present seem to one another to be quite commonplace. It is a silly thing that the ideal is, as it were, ousted by the real; that may be the reason why to the moderns their ideal only manifests itself in longing.
The absent party is still faulty.
The accepted and betrothed lover has lost the
wildest charms of his maiden in her acceptance of him. She was heaven whilst he pursued her as a star--she cannot be heaven if she stoops to such a one as he.
The accusing spirit, which flew up to heaven's chancery with the oath, blushed as he gave it in; and the recording angel, as he wrote it down, dropped a tear upon the word and blotted it out for ever.
The acknowledgment of our weakness is the first step towards repairing our loss.
The actual well seen is the ideal.
The advice that is wanted is commonly unwelcome; that which is not wanted is evidently impertinent.
The affection of young ladies is of as rapid
growth as Jack's beanstalk, and reaches up to the sky in a night.
The afflictions of earth exalt the spirit and lift the soul to God.
The age made no sign when Shakespeare, its noblest son, passed away.
The age of chivalry is gone. That of sophisters, economists, and calculators has succeeded; and the glory of Europe is extinguished for ever.
The age of curiosity, like that of chivalry, is ended, properly speaking, gone. Yet perhaps only gone to sleep.
The age of great men is going; the epoch of
the anthill, of life in multiplicity, is beginning.
The age of miracles past! The age of miracles is for ever here.
The ages of greatest public spirit are not always eminent for private virtue.
The agnosticism of doubt is as far from the agnosticism of devotion as blindness for want of vision from blindness through excess of light.
The aim of all morality, truly conceived, is to furnish men with a standard of action and a motive to work by, which shall not intensify each man's selfishness, but raise him ever more and more above it.
The aim of education should be to teach us
rather how to think than what to think.
The aim of life is work, or there is no aim at all.
The aim of the legislator should be, not truth, but expediency.
The air seems nimble with the glad, / Quaint fancies of our childhood dear.
The alchemists in their search for gold discovered other things of greater value.
The all in all of faith is
knowledge
The almighty dollar.
The alpha and omega of Socialism is the transmutation of private competing capital into united collective capital.
The amateur, however weak may be his efforts at imitation, need not be discouraged, ... for one advances to an idea the more surely and steadily the more accurately and precisely he considers individual objects. Only it will not do to measure one's self with artists; every one must go on in his own style.
The ambitious are ever followed by adulation, for such alone receive most pleasure from flattery.
The amount of intellect necessary to please us
is a most accurate measure of the amount of intellect we have ourselves.
The ancient Spartan custom of killing weak-bodied children is not much crueller than that of propagating weak-minded ones.
The ancients tell us what is best; but we must learn of the moderns what is fittest.
The anger of a strong man can always bide its time.
The animal is capable of enjoyment, only man is capable of serenity of mind and gladness of heart.
The animals look for man's intentions right
into his eyes. Even a rat, when you hunt him and bring him to bay, looks you in the eye.
The apparel oft proclaims the man.
The apprehension and representation of what is individual is the very life of art.
The apprehension of the good / Gives but the greater feeling to the worse.
The arch-enemy is the arch-stupid.
The archer who overshoots the mark misses,
as well as he that falls short of it.
The argument all bare is of more worth / Than when it hath my added praise beside.
The army is a good book to open to study human life.
The army is a school in which the niggardly become generous and the generous prodigal.
The arrows of sarcasm are barbed with contempt.... It is the sneer in the satire or the ridicule that galls or wounds.
The art of exalting lowliness and giving greatness
to little things is one of the noblest functions of genius.
The art of living is like every other art; only the capacity is born with us; it must be learned and practised with incessant care.
The art of pleasing is the art of deceiving.
The art was his to break vexations with a ready jest.
The art which is produced hastily will also perish hastily.
The artist belongs to his work, not the work
to the artist.
The artist is the son of his age; but pity for him if he is its pupil, or even its favourite.
The artist must conceive with warmth
and execute with c
The artist stands higher than the art, higher than the object: he uses art for his own purposes, and deals with the object after his own fashion.
The artist's vocation is to send light into the depths of the human heart.
The arts of deceit and cunning do continually
grow weaker, and less effectual and serviceable to them that use them.
The astonishing intellect that occupies itself in splitting hairs, and not in twisting some kind of cordage and effectual draught tackle to take the road with, is not to me the most astonishing of intellects. I want twisted cordage, steady pulling, and a peaceable bass tone of voice; not split hairs, hysterical spasmodics, and treble.
The Atlantic Ocean beat Mrs. Partington. She was excellent at a slop or a puddle, but she should not have meddled with a tempest.
The atmosphere of moral sentiment is a region of grandeur which reduces all material magnificence to toys, yet opens to every wretch that has reason the doors of the universe.
The attainment of a truer and truer aristocracy, or government again by the Best,--all that democracy ever meant lies there.
The attempt, and not the deed, / Confounds us.
The attraction of love is in an inverse proportion to the attraction of the Newtonian philosophy.
The author is often obscure to readers because, as has been said, he proceeds from the thought to the expression, whereas they proceed from the expression to the thought.
The awful shadow of some unseen Power / Floats, though unseen, among us.
The axe of intemperance has lopped off his green boughs and left him a withered trunk.
The axis of the earth sticks out visibly through
the centre of each and every town or city.
The back of one door is the face of another.
The back-door robs the house.
The backslider in heart shall be filled with his own ways.
The bad fortune of the good turns their faces up to heaven; and the good fortune of the bad bows their heads down to the earth.
The bad
also the bad against him.
The barrenest of mortals is the sentimentalist.
The basest thought about man is that he has no spiritual nature; and the foolishest, that he has, or should have, no animal nature.
The basis of good manners is self-reliance.
The battle of belief against unbelief is the never-ending battle.
The beams of joy are made hotter by reflection.
The bearers of the thyrsus
are ma

The bearing and the training of a child is
woman's wisdom.
The beaten road is the safest.
The beautiful is a manifestation of secret laws of nature, which, but for its appearance, had been for ever concealed from us.
The beautiful is higher than the good; the beautiful includes in it the good.
The beautiful is like sunshine to the world; the beautiful lives for ever.
The beautiful rests on the foundation of the
necessary.
The beggar is never out of the fashion, or limpeth awkwardly behind it.
The beggar is not expected to become bail or surety for any one.
The beggar is not required to put on court mourning.
The beggar is the only free man in the universe.
The beggar is the only man in the universe
who is not obliged to study appearances.
The beggar weareth all colours, fearing none.
The beggar's costume hath undergone less change than the Quaker's.
The beginning, and very nearly the end, of bodily education for a girl, is to make sure that she can stand and sit upright; the ankle vertical, and firm as a marble shaft; the waist elastic as a reed, and as unfatiguable.
The beginning of all good law, and nearly the end of it, is that every man shall do good work for his bread, and that every man shall have good bread for his work.
The beginning of all temptations and wickedness
is the fickleness of our own minds and want of trust in God.
The beginning of creation
is light. Till the eye have vision, the whole members are in bonds.
The beginning of inquiry is disease.
The beginning of strife is as when one letteth out water: therefore leave off contention before it be meddled with.
 (_i.e._ sym
The being whose strength exceeds its necessities
is strong; the being whose necessities exceed its strength is feeble.
The bell strikes one. We take no note of time / But for its loss.
The belly is chains to the hands and fetters to the feet. He who is a slave to his belly seldom worships God.
The beloved of the Almighty are the rich who have the humility of the poor, and the poor who have the magnanimity of the rich.
The benefactors of mankind are those who grumble to the best purpose. Grumbling has raised man from the condition of the gorilla to that of the judge on the bench of justice.
The benevolent heart will not solicit, but command
our reverence and applause.
The benevolent person is always by preference busy on the essentially bad.
The best advice is, Follow good advice and hold old age in highest honour.
The best architecture is the expression of the mind of manhood by the hands of childhood.
The best courages are but beams of the Almighty.
The best effect of any book is that it excites
the reader to self-activity.
The best fish swim near the bottom.
The best friends in the world may differ sometimes.
The best gifts find the fewest admirers, and most men mistake the bad for the good.
The best government is that which teaches us to govern ourselves.
The best independence is to have something to
do, and something that can be done, and done most perfectly in solitude.
The best is best cheap.
The best is but in season best.
The best is not to be explained by words.
The best laid schemes o' mice an' men / Gang aft a-gley, / And lea'e us naught but grief and pain / For promised joy.
The best loneliness is when no human eye has
rested on our face for a whole day.
The best may slip, and the most cautious fall;/ He's more than mortal that ne'er err'd at all.
The best mirror is an old friend.
The best of angels do not live in community, but by themselves.
The best of lessons, for a good many people, would be to listen at a keyhole. It is a pity for such that the practice is dishonourable.
The best of men/ That e'er wore earth about
him was a sufferer; / A soft, meek, patient, humble, tranquil spirit; / The first true gentleman that ever breathed.
The best of the sport is to do the deed and say nothing.
The best part of our knowledge is that which teaches us where knowledge leaves off and ignorance begins.
The best path through life is the highway.
The best portraits are those in which there is a slight mixture of caricature.
The best preservative to keep the mind in
health is the faithful admonition of a friend.
The best remedy against an ill man is much ground between both.
The best rules to form a young man are, to talk little, to hear much, to reflect alone upon what has passed in company, to distrust one's own opinions, and value others' that deserve it.
The best self-forgetfulness is to look at the things of the world with attention and love.
The best son is not enough a son.
The best, the only correct actions are those which demand no explanation and no apology.
The best thing I know between France and England is the sea.
The best thing which we derive from history
is the enthusiasm which it raises in us.
The best things are worst to come by.
The best use of money is to pay debts.
The best way to come to truth is to examine things as they really are, and not to conclude they are, as we have been taught by others to imagine.
The best way to make the audience laugh is by first laughing yourself.
The best way to please one half of the world is
not to mind what the other half says.
The best work in the world is done on the quiet.
The best work never was, nor ever will be, done for money at all.
The best works, and of greatest merit for the public, have proceeded from unmarried or childless men, which, both in affection and means, have married and endowed the public.
The betrayer is the murderer.
The better a man is morally, the less conscious
he is of his virtues. The greater the artist, the more aware he must be of his shortcomings.
The better day the better deed.
The better I know men the more I admire dogs.
The better part of valour is discretion.
The better you understand yourself, the less cause you will find to love yourself.
The Bible contains many truths as yet undiscovered.
The Bible contains more true sublimity, more exquisite beauty, more pure morality, more important history, and finer strains of poetry and eloquence than can be collected from all other books, in whatever age or language they have been written.
(The Bible) contains plain teaching for men of every rank of soul and state of life, which so far as they honestly and implicitly obey, they will be happy and innocent to the utmost powers of their nature, and capable of victory over all adversities, whether of temptation or pain.
The Bible is the great family chronicle of the Jews.
The Bible of a nation, the practically credited God's message to a nation, is, beyond all else, the authentic biography of its heroic souls. This is the real record of the appearances of God in the history of a nation; this, which all men to the marrow of their bones can believe, and which teaches all men what the nature of this universe, when you go to work in it, really is.
The Bible tells us what Christian graces are;
but it is in the struggle of life that we are to find them.
The biography of a nation embraces all its works. No trifle is to be neglected. A mouldering medal is a letter of twenty centuries.
The bird of wisdom flies low, and seeks her food under hedges; the eagle himself would be starved if he always soared aloft and against the sun.
The birds without barn or storehouse are fed: / From them let us learn to trust for our bread.
The birth of a child is the imprisonment of a soul.
The birth of a golden deer is impossible.
The bishop has set his foot in it
The biter is often bit.
The blanks as well as the prizes must be drawn in the cheating lottery of life.
The blast that blows loudest is soon overblown.
The blaze of reputation cannot be blown out,
but it often dies in the socket.
The blessed work of helping the world forward does not wait to be done by perfect men.
The blessing of the Lord, it maketh rich, and he addeth no sorrow with it.
The blind man bears the lame, and onward hies, / Made right by lending feet and borrowing eyes.
The block of granite, which was an obstacle in the pathway of the weak, becomes a stepping-stone in the pathway of the strong.
The blood more stirs / To rouse a lion than to
start a hare.
The blood of man should never be shed but to redeem the blood of man. It is well shed for our family, for our friends, for our God, for our country, for our kind. The rest is vanity, the rest is crime.
The blood of the martyrs is the seed of the Church.
The blue-bird carries the sky on his back.
The blue of heaven is larger than the cloud.
The blush is Nature's alarm at the approach of
sin, and her testimony to the dignity of virtue.
The body of a sensualist is the coffin of a dead soul.
The body of Christ is wherever human bodies are, and he who has any bitterness against his brother is always committing sacrilege.
The book of Nature is the book of Fate.
The bookful blockhead, ignorantly read, / With loads of learned lumber in his head.
The books which help you most are those which make you think the most.
The borrower runs in his own debt.
The bough that is dead shall be cut away for the sake of the tree itself. Let the Conservatism that would preserve the tree, cut it away.
The bounds of a man's knowledge are easily concealed if he has but prudence.
The boy stands astonished; his impressions
guide him; he learns sportfully; seriousness steals on him by surprise.
The boy's story is the best that is ever told.
The boy's will is the wind's will, / And the thoughts of youth are long, long thoughts.
The brain may devise laws for the blood; but a hot temper leaps o'er a cold decree.
The brain-women never interest us like the heart-women; white roses please less than red.
The brave man thinks of himself last of all.
The bravest are the tenderest, / The loving are the daring.
The breach of custom / Is breach of all.
The breeding of a man makes him courageous by instinct, true by instinct, loving by instinct, as a dog is; and therefore, felicitously above, or below (whichever you like to call it), all questions of philosophy and divinity.
The British nation--and I include in it the Scottish nation--has produced a finer set of men than you will find it possible to get anywhere else in this world.
The bud may have a bitter taste, / But sweet
will be the flower.
The buke o' May-bees is very braid.
The burden one likes is cheerfully borne.
The burning of a little straw may hide the stars of the sky; but the stars are there, and will reappear.
The burst of new light, by its suddenness, always appears inimical to the unprepared heart.
The busiest of living agents are certain dead
men's thoughts.
The calling of a man's self to a strict account is a medicine sometimes too piercing and corrosive; reading good books of morality is a little flat and dead ... but the best receipt (best to work, and best to take) is the admonition of a friend.
The camomile, the more it is trodden on, the faster it grows; yet youth, the more it is wasted, the sooner it wears.
The canary-bird sings the sweeter the longer it has been trained in a darkened cage.
The cancer of jealousy on the breast can never wholly be cut out, if I am to believe great masters of the healing art.
The canker galls the infants of the spring /
Too oft before their buttons are disclosed, / And in the morn and liquid dew of youth / Contagious blastments are most imminent.
The capacity of apprehending what is high is very rare; and therefore, in common life a man does well to keep such things for himself, and only to give out so much as is needful to have some advantage against others.
The captive bands may chain the hands, / But love enslaves the man.
The Carlyles were men who lavished their heart and conscience upon their work; they builded themselves, their days, their thoughts and sorrows, into their houses; they leavened the soil with the sweat of their rugged brows.
The casting away things profitable for the maintenance of man's life is an unthankful abuse of the fruits of God's good providence towards mankind.
The castle which Conservatism is set to defend
is the actual state of things, good and bad.
The cat shuts its eyes when stealing the cream.
The cause which pleased the gods has in the end to please Cato also.
The centuries are all lineal children of one another; and often, in the portrait of early grandfathers, this and the other enigmatic feature of the newest grandson will disclose itself, to mutual elucidation.
The centuries are conspirators against the sanity and authority of the soul.
The certain way to be cheated is to fancy one's
self more cunning than others.
The chains of habit are generally too small to be felt till they are too strong to be broken.
The champion true / Loves victory more when, dim in view, / He sees her glories gild afar / The dusky edge of stubborn war, / Than if th' untrodden bloodless field / The harvest of her laurels yield.
The change of a man's self is a very laborious undertaking.
The character of a nation is not to be learned from its fine folks.
The character of the person that commends
you is to be considered before you set a value on his esteem. The wise man applauds him whom he thinks most virtuous; the rest of the world, him who is most wealthy.
The character of the true philosopher is to hope all things not unreasonable.
The characteristic mark of minds

 (_Unmittelbarkeit_)  own thinking.
The characteristic of a philosopher is that he looks to himself for all help or harm.
The characteristic of Chaucer is intensity; of Spencer, remoteness; of Milton, elevation: of Shakespeare, everything.
The chariest maid is prodigal enough / If she
unmask her beauty to the moon.
The charitable give out at the door, and God puts in at the window.
The charity that thinketh no evil trusts in God and trusts in man.
The chaste mind, like a polished plane, may admit foul thoughts, without receiving their tincture.
The cheap swearer through his open sluice / Lets his soul run for nought.
The cheapness of man is every day's tragedy.
The chief glory of every people arises from its
authors.
The chief of all the curses of this unhappy age is the universal gabble of its fools, and of the flocks that follow them, rendering the quiet voices of the wise of all past time inaudible.
The chief requisites for a courtier are a flexible conscience and an inflexible politeness.
The chief value and virtue of money consists in its having power over human beings; a power which is attainable by other means than by money.
The child is father of the man.
The child is not to be educated for the present,
but for the remote future, and often in opposition to the immediate future.
The child who desires education will be bettered by it; the child who dislikes it, only disgraced.
The child's murmuring is more and is less than words; there are no notes, and yet it is a song; there are no syllables, and yet it is language.... This poor stammering is a compound of what the child said when it was an angel, and of what it will say when it becomes a man.
The childhood shows the man / As morning shows the day.
The children of others we never love so much as our own; error, our own child, is so near our heart.
The choicest thing this world has for a man is
affection.
The Christian doctrine, that doctrine of Humility, in all senses godlike, and the parent of all godlike virtue, is not superior, or inferior, or equal to any doctrine of Socrates or Thales, being of a totally different nature; differing from these as a perfect ideal poem does from a correct computation in arithmetic.
The Christian religion having once appeared, cannot again vanish; having once assumed its divine shape, can be subject to no dissolution.
The Christian religion is an inspiration and life--God's life breathed into a man and breathed through a man.
The Christian religion is especially remarkable, as it so decidedly lays claim to mere goodwill in man, to his essential temper, and values this independently of all culture and manifestation. It stands in opposition to science and art, and properly to enjoyment.
The Christian religion, often enough dismembered
and scattered abroad, will ever in the end again gather itself together at the foot of the cross.
The Christian religion, once here, cannot again pass away; in one or the other form, it will endure through all time. As in Scripture, so also in the heart of man, it is written, "The gates of hell shall not prevail against it."
The Christianity that cannot get on without a minimum of four thousand five hundred, will give place to something better that can.
The Church is a mere organisation to help a man to fulfil his duties; it is not the source from whence those duties sprung.
The Church is the working recognised union of those who by wise teaching guide the souls of men.
The Church! Touching the earth with one
small point (the event, viz., at Bethlehem of the year one); springing out of one small seed-grain, rising out therefrom, ever higher, ever broader, high as the heaven itself, broad till it overshadow the whole visible heaven and earth, and no star can be seen but through it. From such a seed-grain so has it grown; planted in the reverences and sacred opulences of the soul of mankind; fed continually by all the noblenesses of forty generations of man. The world-tree of the nations for so long!
The Churchmen fain would kill their Church, / As the Churches have killed their Christ.
The circle of noble-minded people is the most precious of all that I have won.
The city does not take away, neither does the country give, solitude: solitude is within us.
The city is recruited from the country.
The civil guest / Will no more talk all, than
eat all the feast.
The civilised man lives not in wheeled houses. He builds stone castles, plants lands, makes life-long marriage contracts; has long-dated, hundred-fold possessions, not to be valued in the money-market; has pedigrees, libraries, law-codes; has memories and hopes, even for this earth, that reach over thousands of years.
The civilised nation consists broadly of mob, money-collecting machine, and capitalist; and when the mob wishes to spend money for any purpose, it sets its money-collecting machine to borrow the money it needs from the capitalist, who lends it on condition of taxing the mob generation after generation.
The civilised savage
The Classical is healthy, the Romantic sickly.
The clergy are at present divided into three
sections: an immense body who are ignorant; a small proportion who know and are silent; and a minute minority who know and speak according to their knowledge.
The cloud-capp'd towers, the gorgeous palaces, / The solemn temples, the great globe itself, / Yea, all that it inherit, shall dissolve; / And, like this insubstantial pageant faded, / Leave not a rack behind.
The cloud incense of the altar hides / The true form of the God who there abides.
The clouds never pass against the wind.
The clouds that gather round the setting sun / Do take a sober colouring from an eye / That hath kept watch o'er man's mortality.
The clouds that wrap the setting sun / ... Why, as we watch their floating wreath, / Seem they the breath of life to breathe? / To Fancy's eye their motions prove / They mantle round the sun for love.
The clouds treat the sea as if it were a mill-pond
or a spring-run, too insignificant to make any exceptions to.
The cock, that is the trumpet of the morn, / Doth with his lofty and shrill-sounding throat / Awake the god of day.
The coin that is most current among mankind is flattery; the only benefit of which is that by hearing what we are not we may be instructed what we ought to be.
The combined arts appear to me like a family of sisters, of whom the greater part were inclined to good company, but one was light-headed, and desirous to appropriate and squander the whole goods and chattels of the household--the theatre is this wasteful sister.
The comic and the tragic lie close together, inseparable, like light and shadow.
The command "thou shalt" is in all circumstances
a hard one, unless it is softened down by the adjunct "for that which 'thou shalt' is just the same as that which rationally thou also willest."
The commencement of atonement is / The sense of its necessity.
The common crowd but see the gloom / Of wayward deeds and fitting doom; / The close observer can espy / A noble soul and lineage high.
The common fluency of speech in many men and most women is owing to a scarcity of matter and a scarcity of words.
The common "keeping up appearances" of society is a mere selfish struggle of the vain with the vain.
The company of fools may at first make us
smile, but at last never fails of rendering us melancholy.
The complete poet must have a heart in his brain or a brain in his heart.
The complete spiritualisation of the animal element in nature is the task of our species.
The conceived is never food save to the mind that conceives.
The concessions of the weak are the concessions of fear.
The condition of the great body of the people in
a country is the condition of the country itself.
The condition of the most fascinated
enthusiast is to be preferred to him who, from sheer fear of error, dares in the end no longer to affirm or deny.
The conditions necessary for the arts of men are the best for their souls and bodies.
The confidant of my vices is my master, though he were my valet.
The conflict of the old, the existent, and the persistent, with development, improvement, and transfigurment is always the same. Out of every arrangement arises at last pedantry; to get rid of this latter the former is destroyed, and some time must elapse before we become aware that order must be re-established.
The conscience is the inviolable asylum of the
liberty of man.
The conscience is the most elastic material in the world. To-day you cannot stretch it over a mole-hill, to-morrow it hides a mountain.
The conscience of the man who is given over to his passions is like the voice of the shipwrecked mariner overwhelmed by the tempest.
The conscious utterance of thought by speech or action, to any end, is art.
The conscious water saw its god and blushed.
The consolation which is derived from truth,
if any there be, is solid and durable; that which may be derived from error must be, like its original, fallacious and fugitive.
The contagion of crime is like that of the plague.
The contingent facts of history can never become the proof of the truths of reason.
The conversation of a friend is a powerful alleviator of the fatigue of walking.
The core will come to the surface.
The cormorant Oblivion swallows up / The
carcases that Time has made his prey.
The corpse is not the whole animal; there is still something that appertains to it, still a corner-stone, and in this case, as in every other, a very chief corner-stone--life, the spirit that makes everything beautiful.
The counsel thou wouldst have another keep, first keep thyself.
The country where the entire people is, or even once has been, laid hold of, filled to the heart with an infinite religious idea, has "made a step from which it cannot retrograde."
The courage
The courage that dares only die is on the
whole no sublime affair.... The courage we desire and prize is not the courage to die decently, but to live manfully.
The course of nature is the art of God.
The course of Nature's phases, on this our little fraction of a planet, is partially known to us; but who knows what deeper courses these depend on; what infinitely larger cycle
our little epicycle 
The course of prayer who knows?
The course of scoundrelism, any more than that of true love, never did run smooth.
The course of true love never did run smooth.
The court does not render a man contented, but it prevents his being so elsewhere.
The court is like a palace of marble; it is composed of people very hard and very polished.
The court, nor cart, I like, nor loathe; / Extremes are counted worst of all: / The golden mean betwixt them both / Doth surest sit, and fears no fall.
The court of the past differs from all living
aristocracy in this; it is open to labour and to merit, but to nothing else.
The covetous man heaps up riches, not to enjoy them, but to have them.
The covetous man never has money, and the prodigal will have none shortly.
The coxcomb is a fool of parts, a flatterer, a knave of parts.
The craftiest wiles are too short and ragged a cloak to cover a bad heart.
The crafty man is always in danger; and
when he thinks he walks in the dark, all his pretences are so transparent, that he that runs may read them.
The creation of a thousand forests is in one acorn; and Egypt, Greece, Rome, Gaul, Britain, America, lie folded already in the first man.
The credit of advancing science has always been due to individuals, never to the age.
The creed of the true saint is to make the best of life, and make the most of it.
The crickets sing, and man's o'er-laboured sense / Repairs itself by rest.
The cross is the invincible sanctuary of the
humble.
The cross of Christ is the key of Paradise; the weak man's staff; the convert's convoy; the upright man's perfection; the soul and body's health; the prevention of all evil, and the procurer of all good.
The cross was the fitting close of a life of rejection, scorn, and defeat.
The crow doth sing as sweetly as the lark / When neither is attended, and I think / The nightingale, if she should sing by day, / when every goose is cackling, would be thought / No better a musician than the wren.
The crowd ... if they find / Some stain or blemish in a name of note, / Not grieving that their greatest are so small, / Inflate themselves with some insane delight, / And judge all Nature from her feet of clay, / Without the will to lift their eyes, and see / Her godlike head crown'd with spiritual fire / And touching other worlds.
The cruelty of the affectionate is more dreadful
than that of the hardy.
The cry of the God-forsaken is from the heart of God himself.
The cuffs and thumps with which fate, our lady-loves, our friends and foes, put us to the proof, in the mind of a good and resolute man, vanish into air.
The cunning workman never doth refuse / The meanest tool that he may chance to use.
The cup of life which God offers to our lips is not always sweet; ... but, sweet or bitter, it is ours to drink it without murmur or demur.
The cups that cheer, but not inebriate.
The cure for false theology is mother wit.
The curfew tolls the knell of parting day, / The lowing herd winds slowly o'er the lea, / The ploughman homeward plods his weary way, / And leaves the world to darkness and to me.
The curiosity of knowing things has been given to man for a scourge.
The curious unthrift makes his clothes too wide, / And spares himself, but would his tailor chide.
The current that with gentle murmur glides, /
Thou know'st, being stopp'd, impatiently doth rage.
The curtains of yesterday drop down, the curtains of to-morrow roll up; but yesterday and to-morrow both are. Pierce into the Time-element, glance into the Eternal.

talent, so does the colour betoken temper and heart.
The cynic is one who never sees a good quality in a man, and never fails to see a bad one.
The danger of dangers is illusion.
The danger past and God forgotten.
The dark in soul see in the universe their own shadow; the shattered spirit can only reflect external beauty, in form as untrue and broken as itself.
The darkest day, live till to-morrow, will have passed away.
The darkest hour is nearest the dawn.
The day is longer than the brae; we'll be at the top yet.
The day of days ... is the day on which the
inward eye opens to the unity of things, to the omnipresence of law--sees that what is must be, and ought to be, or is the best.
The day wasted on others is not wasted on one's self.
The days are too short even for love, how can there ever be time for quarrelling?
The dead do not need us; but for ever and for evermore we need them.
The dead letter of religion must own itself dead, and drop piecemeal into dust, if the living spirit of religion, freed from its charnel-house, is to arise on us, new born of Heaven, and with new healing under its wings.
The decline of literature indicates the decline
of the nation. The two keep pace in their downward tendency.
The deeper the sorrow, the less tongue hath it.
The deity works in the living, not in the dead; in the becoming and the changing, not in the become and the fixed.
The delight of the destroyer and denier is no pure delight, and must soon pass away.
The democrat is a young conservative; the conservative is an old democrat.
The demonic in music stands so high that no understanding can reach it, and an influence flows from it which masters all, and for which none can account.
The demonic is that which cannot be explained by reason or understanding, which is not in one's nature, yet to which it is subject.
The dependant is timid.
The depth of our despair measures what capability and height of claim we have to hope.
The desire accomplished is sweet to the soul.
The desire of a man is his kindness: and a poor man is better than a liar.
The desire of perfection is the worst disease that ever afflicted the human mind.
The desire of power in excess caused the
angels to fall; the desire of knowledge in excess caused man to fall; but in charity there is no excess, neither can man or angel come in danger by it.
The desire of the moth for the star, / Of the night for the morrow, / The devotion to something afar / From the sphere of our sorrow.
The desire of the slothful killeth him; for his hands refuse to labour.
The destiny of any nation at any given time depends on the opinions of its young men under five-and-twenty.
The destruction of the poor is their poverty.
The devil can cite Scripture for his purpose! /
An evil soul producing holy witness / Is like a villain with a smiling cheek, / A goodly apple rotten at the heart.
The devil has a great advantage against us, inasmuch as he has a strong bastion and bulwark against us in our own flesh and blood.
The devil has his elect.
The devil hath power / To assume a pleasing shape.
The devil helps his servants for a season; but when they come once to a pinch, he leaves 'em in the lurch.
The devil is a busy bishop in his own diocese.
The devil is an ass.
The devil is an unfortunate who knows not what it is to love.
The devil is God's ape.
The devil knew not what he did when he made man politic; he crossed himself by it.
The devil lurks behind the cross.
The devil may get in by the keyhole, but the door won't let him out.
The devil taketh not lightly unto his working such as he findeth occupied in good works.
The devil tempts all other men, but idle men tempt the devil.
The devil tempts us not--'tis we tempt him, / Beckoning his skill with opportunity.
The devil was sick, the devil a monk would
be; / The devil was well, the devil a monk was he.
The dewdrop and the star shine sisterly, / Globing together in the common work.
The dictum that truth always triumphs over persecution is one of those pleasant falsehoods ... which all experience refutes. History teems with instances of truth put down by persecution. If not suppressed for ever, it may be thrown back for centuries.
The difference between Socrates and Jesus? The great Conscious; the immeasurably great Unconscious.
The difference between the great celebrities and the unknown nobodies is this, the former failed and went at it again, the latter gave up in despair.
The difficulty is not so great to die for a friend as
to find a friend worth dying for.
The difficulty is to teach the multitude that something can be both true and untrue at the same time.
The dignity of truth is lost with much protesting.
The dilettante takes the obscure for the profound, violence for vigour, the indefinite for the infinite, and the senseless for the supersensuous.
The disciple is not above his master, nor the servant above his lord.
The discovery of what is true, and the practice
of that which is good, are the two most important objects of philosophy.
The discretion of a man deferreth his anger; and it is his glory to pass over a transgression.
The disease of the mind leading to fatalist ruin is the concentration of man upon himself, whether his heavenly interests or his worldly interests, matters not; it is their being his own interests which makes the regard of them mortal.
The disease which afflicts bureaucratic governments, and which they usually die of, is routine.
The disease with which the human mind now labours is want of faith.
The dispute about religion and the practice of
it seldom go together.
The disputes of two of equal strength and fortune are worthy of attention; but not of two, the one great, the other humble.
The dissection of a sentence is as bad a way to the understanding of it, as the dissection of a beast to the biography of it.
The distances of nations are measured, not by seas, but by ignorances; and their divisions determined, not by dialects, but by enmities.
The distant landscape draws not nigh / For all our gazing.
The distant sounds of music, that catch new
sweetness as they vibrate through the long-drawn valley, are not more pleasing to the ear than the tidings of a far-distant friend.
The distinction between man and nature is, that man is a being becoming, and nature a being become.
The distinctive character of a child is to live always in the tangible present.
The distinguishing sign of slavery is to have a price and be bought for it.
The distinguishing trait of people accustomed to good society is a calm, imperturbable quiet, which pervades all their actions and habits.
The Divine mind is as visible in its full energy
of operation on every lowly bank and mouldering stone, as in the lifting of the pillars of heaven, and setting the foundations of the earth.
The divine power of the love, of which we cease not to sing and speak, is this, that it reproduces every moment the grand qualities of the beloved object, perfect in the smallest parts, embraced in the whole; it rests not either by day or by night, is ravished with its own work, wonders at its own stirring activity, finds the well-known always new, because it is every moment begotten anew in the sweetest of all occupations. In fact the image of the beloved one cannot become old, for every moment is the hour of its birth.
The divine state, "par excellence," is silence and repose.
The doctor sees all the weakness of mankind, the lawyer all the wickedness, the theologian all the stupidity.
The dog that fetches will carry.
The dog that starts the hare is as good as the
one that catches it.
The dog, to gain his private ends, / Went mad, and bit the man.
The dome of St. Peter's is great, yet is it but a foolish chip of an egg-shell compared with that star-fretted dome where Arcturus and Orion glance for ever, which latter, notwithstanding, no one looks at--because the architect was not a man.
The dome of thought, the palace of the soul.
The donkey means one thing and the driver another.
The doom of the old has long been pronounced
and irrevocable; the old has passed away; but, alas! the new appears not in its stead; the time is still in pangs of travail with the new. Man has walked by the light of conflagrations, and amid the sound of falling cities; and now there is darkness, and long watching till it be morning.
The door must either be shut or it must be open. I must either be natural or unnatural.
The dove found no rest for the sole of her foot.
The dread of censure is the death of genius.
The dread of something after death, / The undiscover'd country, from whose bourn / No traveller returns, puzzles the will; / And makes us rather bear those ills we have / Than fly to others that we know not of.
The dreamer is a madman quiescent, the
madman is a dreamer in action.
The dregs may stir themselves as they please; they fall back to the bottom by their own coarseness.
The dress of words, / Like to the Roman girl's enticing garb, / Should let the play of limb be seen through it, / And the round rising form.
The drunkard forfeits man, and doth divest / All worldly right, save what he hath by beast.
The dry light is ever the best.
The drying up a single tear has more / Of
honest fame than shedding seas of gore.
The dullest John Bull cannot with perfect complacency adore himself, except under the figure of Britannia or the British Lion.
The dust of controversy is but the falsehood flying off.
The dwarf behind his steam-engine may remove mountains, but no dwarf will hew them down with the pickaxe; and he must be a Titan that hurls them abroad with his arms.
The eagle suffers little birds to sing.
The earth hath bubbles, as the water has, /
And these are of them.
The earth is our workshop. We may not curse it; we are bound to sanctify it.
The earth is sown with pleasures, as the heavens are studded with stars, wherever the conditions of existence are unsophisticated.
The earth must supply man with the necessaries of life before he has leisure or inclination to pursue more refined enjoyments.
The earth, that's Nature's mother, is her tomb.
The earthen pot must keep clear of the brass
kettle.
The ebb'd man, ne'er loved till ne'er worth love, / Comes dear'd by being lack'd.
The echo of the nest-life, the voice of our modest, fairer, holier soul, is audible only in a sorrow-darkened bosom, as the nightingales warble when one veils their cage.
The effect of good music is not caused by its novelty; on the contrary, it strikes us more the more familiar we are with it.
The effect of righteousness
The effect of violent animosities between
parties has always been an indifference to the general welfare and honour of the state.
The efforts of him who contendeth with one stronger than himself are as feeble as the exertions of an insect's wings.
The elect are whosoever will, and the non-elect whosoever won't.
The electric telegraph will never be a substitute for the face of a man, with his soul in it, encouraging another man to be brave and true.
The element of water moistens the earth, but blood flies upwards and bedews the heavens.
The elements of poetry lie in natural objects, in the vicissitudes of human life, in the emotions of the human heart, and the relations of man to man.
The emphasis of facts and persons has nothing to do with time.
The empire of woman is an empire of softness,
of address, of complacency. Her commands are caresses, her menaces are tears.
The empty vessel makes the greatest sound.
The end crowns all, / And that old common arbitrator, Time, / Will one day end it.
Troil. and Cress.
The end of all opposition is negation, and negation is nothing.
The end of all right education of a woman is to make her love her home better than any other place; that she should as seldom leave it as a queen her queendom; nor ever feel entirely at rest but within its threshold.
The end of doubt is the beginning of repose.
The end of labour is to gain leisure.
The end of man is an action, not a thought, though it were the noblest.
The end of man is at no moment a pleasure, but a performance; and life always and only the continual fulfilment of a worthy purpose with a will.
The end we aim at must be known before the way.
The enemy is more easily repulsed if we never
suffer him to get within us, but, upon the very first approach, draw up our forces and fight him without the gate.
"The English," says Bishop Sprat, "have too much bravery to be derided, and too much virtue and honour to mock others."
The ennobling difference between one man and another--between one animal and another--is precisely this, that one feels more than another.
The entire grace, happiness, and virtue of
life depend on his contentment in doing what he can dutifully, and in staying where he is peaceably.
The entire object of true education is to make people not merely do the right things, but enjoy the right things.
The entire system of things gets represented
in every particle.
The entire vitality of art depends upon its having for object either to state a true thing or adorn a serviceable one.
The envied have a brilliant fate; / Pity is given where griefs are great.
The envious man waxeth lean with the fatness of his neighbours.
The envious will die, but envy never.
The errors of a great mind are more edifying
than the truths of a little.
The errors of a wise man are literally more instructive than the truths of a fool. For the wise man travels in lofty, far-seeing regions; the fool in low-lying, high-fenced lanes; retracing the footsteps of the former, to discover where he deviated, whole provinces of the universe are laid open to us; in the path of the latter, granting even that he have not deviated at all, little is laid open to us but two wheel-ruts and two hedges.
The errors of a wise man make your rule / Rather than the perfections of a fool.
The errors of woman spring almost always from her faith in the good or her confidence in the true.
The errors of young men are the ruin of business; but the errors of aged men amount to but this, that more might have been done, or sooner.
The essence of a lie is in deception, not in
words.
The essence of affectation is that it be assumed; the character is, as it were, forcibly crushed into some foreign mould, in the hope of being thereby re-shaped and beautified; and the unhappy man persuades himself he has become a new creature of wonderful symmetry, though every movement betrays not symmetry, but dislocation.
The essence of all government among good men is this, that it is mainly occupied in the production and recognition of human worth, and in the detection and extinction of human unworthiness.
The essence of all immorality, of sin, is the making self the centre to which we subordinate all other beings and interests.
The essence of all religion that was, and that will be, is to make men free.
The essence of all vulgarity lies in want of
sensation.
The essence of an aristocracy is to transfer the source of honour from the living to the dead, to make the merits of living men depend not so much upon their own character and actions as upon the actions and position of their ancestors.
The essence of aphorism is the compression of a mass of thought and observation into a single saying.
The essence of faith lies in this, a deep sense and conviction that in what we do, though it were single-handed, with all men standing aloof, and even saying nay to it, we have God and all his universe at our back.
The essence of friendship is entireness, a total magnanimity and trust.
The essence of greatness is the perception
that virtue is enough. Poverty is its ornament. It does not need plenty, and can very well abide its loss.
The essence of humour is sensibility, warm, tender, fellow-feeling with all forms of existence; and unless seasoned and purified by humour, sensibility is apt to run wild, will readily corrupt into disease, falsehood, or, in one word, sentimentality.
The essence of justice is mercy.
The essence of knowledge is, having it, to apply it; not having it, to confess your ignorance.
The essence of poetry is will and passion.
The essence of true nobility is neglect of self. Let the thought of self pass in, and the beauty of a great action is gone, like the bloom from a soiled flower.
 
The essence of wealth consists in its authority nominal wealth fail in this power, it fails in essence; in fact, ceases to be wealth at all. And since the essence of wealth consists in power over men, will it not follow that the nobler and the more in number the persons are over whom it has power, the greater the wealth.
The essence or peculiarity of man is to comprehend a whole.
The essential thing for all creatures is to be
made to do right.
The Eternal is no simulacrum; God is not only there, but here or nowhere,--in that life-breath of thine, in that act and thought of thine,--and thou wert wise to look to it.
The eternal stars shine out again, as soon as it is dark enough.
The eternity, before the world and after, is without our reach; but that little spot of ground which lies betwixt those two great oceans, this we are to cultivate.
The even and cheerful temper makes us pleasing to ourselves, to those with whom we converse, and to Him whom we were made to please.
The even-flow of constant cheerfulness
strengthens; while great excitements, driving us with fierce speed, both wreck the ship and end often in explosions.
The evening brings a' hame.
The evil that goeth out of thy mouth flieth into thy bosom.
The evil that men do lives after them; / The good is oft interréd with their bones.
The evil wound is cured, but not the evil name.
The ewe that will not hear her lamb when it
baes, will never answer a calf when it bleats.
The exacting a grateful acknowledgment is demanding a debt by which the creditor is not advantaged and the debtor pays with reluctance.
The example of good men is visible philosophy.
The excellent is rarely found, more rarely valued.
The exception proves the rule.
The excesses of our youth are draughts upon
our age, payable with interest about thirty years after date.
The expectation of the poor shall not perish for ever.
The experience of each new age requires a new confession, and the world seems always waiting for its poet.
The experience of suffering has been declared on the highest authority to be necessary to every poet who would touch the hearts of his fellow-creatures.
The express schoolmaster is not equal to much at present, while the unexpress, for good or for evil, is so busy with a poor little fellow.
The eye by which I see God is the same eye
by which he sees me.
The eye is easily daunted.
The eye is not satisfied with seeing, nor the ear filled with hearing.
The eye is the best of artists.
The eye is the mirror of the soul.
The eye is the only note-book of the true poet.
The eye is the window of the soul; even an animal looks for a man's intentions right into his eyes.
The eye--it cannot choose but see; / We cannot bid the ear be still; / Our bodies feel, where'er they be, / Against or with our will.
The eye of a critic is often like a microscope, made so very fine and nice, that it discovers the atoms, grains, and minutest particles, without ever comprehending the whole, comparing the parts, or seeing all at once the harmony.
The eye of the master will do more work than both his hands.
The eye repeats every day the first eulogy on
things: "He saw that they were very good."
The eye sees in all things what it brings with it the faculty of seeing.
The eye sees not itself, / But by reflection, by some other things.
The eye that mocketh at his father, and despiseth to obey his mother, the ravens of the valley shall pick it out, and the young eagles shall eat it.
The eye that sees all things else sees not itself.
The eyes being in the highest part, hold the
post of sentinels.
The eyes of other people are the eyes that ruin us. If all but myself were blind, I would want neither fine clothes, fine houses, nor fine furniture.
The eyes of the Lord are in every place, beholding the evil and the good.
The face is the index of the mind.
The face of man gives us fuller and more interesting information than his tongue; for his face is the compendium of all he will ever say, as it is the one record of all he has thought and endeavoured.
The faculty for remembering is not diminished
in proportion to what one has learnt, just as little as the number of moulds in which you cast sand lessens its capacity for being cast in new moulds.
The faculty of art is to change events; the faculty of science is to foresee them. The phenomena with which we deal are controlled by art; they are predicted by science.
The faculty of listening is a tender thing, and soon becomes weary and satiated.
The failings of good men are commonly more published in the world than their good deeds; and one fault of a deserving man shall meet with more reproaches than all his virtues praise; such is the force of ill-will and ill-nature.
The faint, exquisite music of a dream.
The fair maid who, the first of May, / Goes to the fields at break of day, / And washes in dew from the hawthorn tree, / Will ever after handsome be.
The fair point of the line of beauty is the line of love. Strength and weakness stand on either side of it. Love is the point in which they unite.
The fairest action of our human life is scorning to avenge an injury.
The fairest tulip's not the sweetest flower.
