The faith in an Invisible, Unnameable, Godlike, present everywhere in all we see and work and suffer, is the essence of all faith whatsoever; and that once denied, or, still worse, asserted with lips only, and out of bound prayer-books only, what other thing remains credible?
The faith of a hearer must be extremely perplexed who considers the speaker, or believes that the speaker considers himself as under no obligation to adhere to truth, but according to the particular importance of what he relates.
The faith that stands on authority is not faith.
The faithful servant is a humble friend.
The fall from the (Christian) faith, and all the
corruptions of its abortive practice, may be summed up briefly as the habitual contemplation of Christ's death instead of his life, and the substitution of his past suffering for our present duty.
The falling out of faithful friends is the renewing of love.
The family is the proper province for private women to shine in.
The family virtues are indispensable to the proper continuance of a society.
The fashion doth wear out more apparel than the man.
The fashion of this world passeth away.
The fatal man, is he not always the unthinking, the man who cannot think and see?
The fatal tendency of mankind to leave off thinking about a thing when it is no longer doubtful, is the cause of half their errors. A contemporary author has well spoken of "the deep slumber of a decided opinion."
The fatal trait
The fate of a man of feeling is, like that of a tuft of flowers, twofold; he may either mount upon the head of all, or go to decay in the wilderness.
The fate of empires depends upon the education
of youth.
The fated will happen.
The fates but only spin the coarser clue; / The finest of the wool is left for you.
The fathers have eaten sour grapes, and the children's teeth are set on edge.
The faults of the superior man are like the eclipses of the sun and moon. He has his faults, and all men see them; he changes, and all men look up to him.
The fear o' hell's the hangman's whip, / To
haud the wretch in order; / But when ye feel yer honour grip, / Let that be aye yer border.
The fear of the Lord is the beginning of wisdom: and the knowledge of the holy is understanding.
The fear of the Lord is the fountain of life.
The fear of the Lord is to hate evil: pride, and arrogancy, and the evil way, and the froward mouth, do I hate.
The fear of the Lord tendeth to life: and he that hath it shall abide satisfied.
The fearful unbelief is unbelief in yourself.
The feast of reason and the flow of soul.
The feelings, like flowers and butterflies, last longer the later they are delayed.
The female heart is just like a new india-rubber shoe; you may pull and pull at it till it stretches out a yard long; and then let go, and it will fly right back to its old shape.
The fetters of the slave bind the hands only.
The fewer our wants, the nearer we resemble
the gods.
The fibres of all things have their tension, and are strained like the strings of a lyre.
The field cannot be well seen from within the field. The astronomer must have his diameter of the earth's orbit as a base to fix the parallax of any other star.
The finding of your able man, and getting him invested with the symbols of ability, is the business, well or ill accomplished, of all social procedure whatsoever in the world.
The finer the nature, the more flaws it will show through the clearness of it; and it is a law of this universe that the best things shall be seldomest seen in their best form.
The finest composition of human nature, as
well as the finest china, may have a flaw in it, and this in either case is equally incurable.
The finest language is chiefly made up of unimposing words.
The finest lives, in my opinion, are those who rank in the common model and with the human race, but without miracle, without extravagance.
The finest minds, like the finest metals, dissolve the easiest.
The finest nations in the world--the English and the American--are going all away into wind and tongue.
The finest qualities of our nature, like the
bloom on fruits, can be preserved only by the most delicate handling; yet we do not treat ourselves or one another thus tenderly.
The fire in the flint shows not till it's struck.
The fire that all things else consumeth clean / May hurt and heal.
The fire that does not warm me shall never scorch me.
The fire which enlightens is the same fire which consumes.
The first and worst of all frauds is to cheat one's self. All sin is easy after that.
The first approach to riches is security from poverty.
The first article that a young trader offers for
sale is his honesty.
The first, as indeed the last, nobility of education is in the rule over our thoughts.
The first breath / Is the beginning of death.
The first business of the philosopher is to part with self-conceit.
The first condition of education is being put to wholesome and useful work.
The first condition of goodness is something to
love; the second, something to reverence.
The first creation of God in the works of the days was the light of the sense; the last was the light of the reason; and his Sabbath-work ever since is the illumination of the spirit.
The first day a man is a guest, the second a burden, the third a pest.
The first days of spring have less grace than the growing virtue of a young man.
The first duty of a man is that of subduing fear; he must get rid of fear; he cannot act at all till then; his acts are slavish, not true.
The first duty of every man in the world is to
find his true master, and, for his own good, submit to him; and to find his true inferior, and, for that inferior's good, conquer him.
The first evil those suffer who are fain to talk is that they hear nothing.
The first faults are theirs that commit them, / The second are theirs that permit them.
The first forty years of life furnish the text, the remaining thirty the commentary.
The first glass for myself, the second for my friends, the third for good-humour, and the fourth for mine enemies.
The first glass of a wine is the one which gives
us its true taste.
The first great work / Is that yourself may to yourself be true.
The first hour of the morning is the rudder of the day.
The first ingredient in conversation is truth, the next good sense, the third good humour, and the fourth wit.
The first lesson of life is one of vicarious suffering.
The first lesson of literature, no less than of
life, is the learning how to burn one's own smoke.
"The first love, which is infinite," can be followed by no second like it.
The first of the nine orders of knaves is he that tells his errand before he goes it.
The first period of a nation, as of an individual, is the period of unconscious strength.
The first point of wisdom is to discern that which is false; the second, to know that which is true.
The first power of a nation consists in knowing
how to guide the plough; its second power consists in knowing how to wear the fetter.
The first principle of all human economy--individual or political--is to live with as few wants as possible, and to waste nothing of what is given us to supply them.
The first problem
The first proof of a man's incapacity for anything is his endeavouring to fix the stigma of failure upon others.
The first requisite, both in conversation and correspondence, is to attend to all the proper decorums which our own character and that of others demand.
The first sigh of love is the last of wisdom.
The first sin in our universe was Lucifer's, that of self-conceit.
The first spiritual want of a barbarous man is decoration, as indeed we still see among the barbarous classes in civilised countries.
The first step towards greatness is to be honest.
The first test of a truly great man is his humility. I do not mean by humility, doubt of his power or hesitation in speaking his opinions; but a right understanding of the relation between what he can say and do, and the rest of the world's sayings and doings.
The first thing for acceptance of truth is to
unlearn human doctrines and become as a little child.
The first thing in oratory, Demosthenes used to say, was action; the second, action; and the third, action.
The first use of education is to enable us to consult with the wisest and the greatest men on all points of earnest difficulty.
The first wealth is health. Sickness is poor-spirited, and cannot serve any one; it must husband its resources to live. But health or fulness answers its own ends, and has to spare, runs over, and inundates the neighbourhoods and creeks of other men's necessities.
The first year let your house to your enemy; the second to your friend; the third, live in it yourself.
The fittest place where man can die / Is where
he dies for man.
The flesh-bound volume is the only revelation
that is, that was, or that can be. In that is the image of God painted; in that is the law of God written; in that is the promise of God revealed.
The flighty purpose never is o'ertook, / Unless the deed go with it.
The floating vapour is just as true an illustration of the law of gravity as the falling avalanche.
The flower is the proper object of the seed, not the seed of the flower.
The flower of sweetest smell is shy and lowly.
The flower of youth never appears more beautiful than when it bends towards the Sun of Righteousness.
The flute is sweet / To gods and men, but sweeter the lyre / And voice of a true singer.
The follies of modern Liberalism are practically summed up in the denial or neglect of the quality and intrinsic value of things.
The folly of all follies / Is to be love-sick for
a shadow.
The folly of others is ever most ridiculous to those who are themselves most foolish.
The fool doth think he is wise, but the wise man knows himself to be a fool.
The fool is always discovered if he stayeth too long; like the ass dressed in a tiger's skin, from his voice.
The fool is in himself the object of pity till he is flattered.
The fool needs company, the wise man solitude.
The foolish and the dead alone never change their opinion.
The foot of the owner is the best manure for his land.
The force of the guinea in your pocket depends on the default of a guinea in your neighbour's.
The form of government can never be a matter of choice; it is almost always a matter of necessity.
The formation of his character ought to be
the chief aim of every man.
The fortitude of a Christian consists in patience.
The fortune which nobody sees makes a man happy and unenvied.
The foul slime stands for the sloth and vice of man, the decay of humanity; the fragrant flower that springs from it, for the purity and courage which are immortal.
The foundations of man are not in matter, but in spirit.
The fountain which from Helicon proceeds, /
That sacred stream, should never water weeds.
The fox puts off all with a jest.
The fox thrives best when he is most curst.
The fraction of life can be increased in value not so much by increasing your numerator as by lessening your denominator. Nay, unless my algebra deceives me, unity itself divided by zero will give infinity.
The free man is he who is loyal to the laws of this universe; who in his heart sees and knows that injustice cannot befall him here; that, except by sloth and cowardly falsity, evil is not possible here.
The
The fresh air of the open country is the proper place to which we belong. It is as if the breath of God were there wafted immediately to men, and a divine power exerted its influence.
The fresh gaze of a child is richer in significance than the forecasting of the most indubitable seer.
The friends thou hast, and their adoption tried, / Grapple them to thy soul with hoops of steel.
The frost is God's plough, which he drives through every inch of ground, opening each clod and pulverising the whole.
The fruit of friendship, in opening the understanding,
is not restrained only to such friends as are able to give counsel (they indeed are best), but even without that a man learneth of himself, and bringeth his own thoughts to light, and whetteth his wits as against a stone, which itself cuts not.
The fruit of life is experience, not happiness, and its fruition to accustom ourselves, and to be content, to exchange hope for insight.
The fruit of righteousness is sown in peace of them that make peace.
The fruit that's yellow / Is found not always mellow.
The full moon brings fair weather.
The full soul loatheth a honeycomb; but to
the hungry soul every bitter thing is sweet.
The furiously wicked have but a short career. Bad for them, but good for the universe.
The future comes on slowly, the present flies like an arrow, the past stands for ever still.
The future destiny of the child is always the work of the mother.
The future epic of the world rests not with those near dead, but with those that are alive, and those that are coming into life.
The future hides in it / Gladness and sorrow; /
We press still thoro'; / Nought that abides in it / Daunting us--onward; / But solemn before us, / Veiled the dark portal, / Goal of all mortal. / Stars silent rest o'er us--/ Graves under us, silent.
The gain of lying is nothing else but not to be trusted of any, nor to be believed when we say the truth.
The game is not worth the candle.
The gardener's business is to tend the flowers and root out the weeds.
The general and perpetual voice of men is as the sentence of God himself.
The general tendency of things throughout
the world is to render mediocrity the ascendant power among mankind.
The generality never suspect the devil even when he has them by the throat.
The generous, who is always just, and the just who is always generous, may, unannounced, approach the throne of Heaven.
The genius of light is friendly to the noble, and, in the dark, brings them friends from afar.
The genius, wit, and spirit of a nation are discovered by their proverbs.
The gentle mind by gentle deeds is known.
The genuine use of gunpowder I hold to be that it makes all men alike tall.
The germs of all things are in every heart.
The getting of treasures by a lying tongue is a vanity tossed to and fro of them that seek death.
The gift blindeth the wise and perverteth the words of the righteous.
The gift of prayer is not always in our power,
but in the eye of Heaven the very wish to pray is prayer.
The gift which is to be given should be given gratuitously.
The gifted man is he who sees the essential point and leaves aside all the rest as surplusage.
The glass of fashion and the mould of form, / The observed of all observers.
The glory dies not, and the grief is past.
The glory is not in never falling, but in rising
every time you fall.
The glory of a people and of an age is always the work of a small number of great men, and disappears with them.
The glory of children are their fathers.
The glory of philosophy lies not in solving the problem, but in putting it.
The glory of young men is their strength: and the beauty of old men is the grey head.
The God of merely traditional believers is
the great Absentee of the universe.
The god of this world is riches, pleasure, and pride.
The God who dwells in my bosom can stir my heart to its depths.
The goddess Athene is armed with the Gorgon's head.
The gods approve the depth, and not the tumult, of the soul.
The gods are just, and of our pleasant vices /
Make instruments to scourge us.
The gods are long-suffering; but the law from the beginning was, He that will not work shall perish from the earth; and the patience of the gods has limits.
The gods are on the side of the strongest.
The gods are wont to save by human means.
The gods do not avenge on the son the misdeeds of the father. Each or good or bad reaps the due reward of his own actions. Parents' blessing, not their curse, is inherited.
The gods hearken to him who hearkens to
them.
The gods in charity oft lend their strength to man.
The gods invariably make us pay dear for the great benefits they confer on us.
The gods of fable are the shining moments of great men.
The gods sell all things at a fair price.
The gods sell to us all the goods which they
give us.
The gods, when they appear to man, are commonly unrecognised by them.
The golden age hath passed away, / Only the good have power to bring it back.
The golden age, that lovely prime, / Existed in the past no more than now. / And did it e'er exist, believe me, / As then it was, it now may be restored. Still meet congenial spirits, and enhance / Each other's pleasures in this beauteous world.
The golden moments in the stream of life rush past us, and we see nothing but sand; the angels come to visit us, and we only know them when they are gone.
The good are always ready to be the upholders
of the good in their misfortunes. Elephants even are wont to bear the burthens of elephants who have sunk in the mire.
The good are better made by ill, / As odours crushed are sweeter still.
The good die first, / And they whose hearts are dry as summer dust / Burn to the socket.
The good-for-nothing is he who cannot command and cannot even obey.
The good is always beautiful, the beautiful is good.
The good mother saith not, "Will you?" but
gives.
The good nature of the dog is not discouraged, although it often brings upon him only rebuffs; the abusive treatment of man never offends him, because he loves man.
The good need little water, but the base / Free from their guilt not ocean's self can lave.
The good of other times let others state; / I think it lucky I was born so late.
The good old rule / Sufficeth them, the simple plan, / That they should take who have the power, / And they should keep who can.
The good that passes by without returning,
leaves behind it an impression that may be compared to a void, and is felt like a want.
The good, the new, comes exactly from that quarter whence it is not looked for, and is always something different from what is expected.
The good things which belong to prosperity are to be wished; but the good things that belong to adversity are to be admired.
The good word is an easy obligation; but not to speak ill requires only our silence, which costs us nothing.
The goods of this world cannot be divided without being lessened; but why be a niggard of that which bestows bliss on a fellow-creature, yet takes nothing from our own means of enjoyment?
The goose that lays the golden eggs likes to
lay where there are eggs already.
The gospel is at once the assigner of our tasks and the magazine of our strength.
The Gothic cathedral is a blossoming in stone subdued by the insatiable demand of harmony in man.
The governing class, who should be working at an ark of deliverance for themselves and us while the hours still are, do nothing but complain, "We cannot get our hands kept rightly warm," and sit obstinately burning the planks.
The government must always be a step in advance of the popular movement.
The government of England is a government of law.
The gown is hers that wears it, and the world is his who enjoys it.
The graceful minuet-dance of fancy must give
place to the toilsome, thorny pilgrimage of understanding.
The grand encourager of Delphic and other noises is the echo.
"The grapes are sour," said the fox when he could not reach them.
The gravest events dawn with no more noise than the morning star makes in rising. All great developments complete themselves in the world, and modestly wait in silence, praising themselves never, and announcing themselves not at all. We must be sensitive and sensible if we would see the beginnings and endings of great things. That is our part.
The great agent of the march of the world is pain, the unsatisfied being that craves for development and is ill at ease in the process.
The great and rich depend on those whom
their power or their wealth attaches to them.
The great art of ruling consists for most part in persuading the people to believe that whatever happens happens through us.
The great artist is the slave of his ideal.
The great cause of revolutions is this: that, while nations move onward, constitutions stand still.
The great distinction between mediæval art and modern is, that the former was brought into the service of religion and the latter is not.
The great doers in history have always been
men of faith.
The great duty of life is not to give pain; and the most acute reasoner cannot find an excuse for one who voluntarily wounds the heart of a fellow-creature.
The great error of our nature is, not to know where to stop, not to be satisfied with any reasonable acquirement, not to compound with our condition; but to lose all we have gained by an insatiable pursuit after more.
The great event for the world is, now as always, the arrival in it of a new wise man.
The great facts are the near ones.
The great felicity of life is to be without perturbation.
The great hope of society is individual character.
The great make us feel, first of all, the indifference of circumstances.
The great man does, in good truth, belong to his own age; nay, more so than any other man; being properly the synopsis and epitome of such age with its interests and influences; but belongs likewise to all ages, otherwise he is not great.
 (_k
The great man goes ahead of his time, the man makes his own out of it, and the blockhead sets himself against it.
The great man has more of human nature than
other men organised in him.
The great man is he who, in the midst of the crowd, keeps with perfect sweetness the independence of solitude.
The great mass of people have eyes and ears, but not much more, especially little power of judgment, and even memory.
The great modern recipe is to work, still to work, and always to work.
The great moments of life are but moments like the others. Your doom is spoken in a word or two. A single look from the eyes, a mere pressure of the hand, may decide it; or of the lips, though they cannot speak.
The great point is not to pull down, but to
build up, and in this humanity finds pure joy.
The great portion of labour is not skilled; the millions are and must be skilless, where strength alone is wanted.
The great principle of all effort is to endeavour to do, not what is absolutely best, but what is easily within our power, and adapted to our temper and condition.
The great river-courses which have shaped the lives of men have hardly changed.
The great role of moral conduct is, next to God, to respect time.
The great school for learning is the brain itself
of the learner.
The great soul of the world is just. There is justice here below; at bottom there is nothing else but justice.
The great soul that sits on the throne of the universe is not, never was, and never will be, in a hurry.
The great source of calamity lies in regret or anticipation; he therefore is most wise who thinks of the present alone, regardless of the past or the future.
The great spirits that have gone before us can survive only as disembodied voices.
The great successes of the world have been
affairs of a second, a third, nay, a fiftieth trial.
The great thieves punish the little ones.
The great thing, after all, is only Forwards.
The great world-revolutions send in their disturbing billows to the remotest creek, and the overthrow of thrones more slowly overturns also the households of the lowly.
The greater and more various any one's knowledge, the longer he takes to find out anything that may suddenly be asked him; because he is like a shopkeeper who has to get the article wanted from a large and multifarious store.
The greater height sends down the deeper fall: / And good declin'd turns bad, turns worst of all.
The greater man the greater courtesy.
The greater proportion of mankind are more sensitive to contemptuous language than unjust acts; for they can less easily bear insult than wrong.
The greatest achievements of the human mind are generally received at first with distrust.
The greatest benefit which one friend can
confer upon another, is to guard, and excite, and elevate his virtues.
The greatest braggards are generally the greatest cowards.
The greatest clerkes
The greatest difficulties lie where we are not looking for them.
The greatest events of an age are its best thoughts. It is the nature of thought to find its way into action.
The greatest expense we can be at is that of
our time.
The greatest felicity that felicity hath is to spread.
The greatest flood hath the soonest ebb; the sorest tempest the most sudden calm; the hottest love the coldest end; and from the deepest desire oftentimes ensues the deadliest hate.
The greatest genius is the most indebted man.
The greatest happiness of the greatest number.
The greatest hatred, like the greatest virtue
and the worst dogs, is quiet.
The greatest man in history was the poorest.
The greatest man is ever a son of man
The greatest man living may stand in need of the meanest as much as the meanest does of him.
The greatest men even want much more of the sympathy which every honest fellow can give than that which the great only can impart.
The greatest men of a nation are those whom
it puts to death.
The greatest men of any age, those who become its leaders when there is a great march to be begun, are separated from the average intellects of their day by a distance which is immeasurable in ordinary terms of wonder.
The greatest men, whether poets or historians, live entirely in their own age, and the greatest faults of their works are gathered out of their own age.
The greatest men will be necessarily those who possess the best capacities, cultivated with the best habits.
The greatest miracle of love is to eradicate flirtation.
The greatest misfortune of all is not to be able
to bear misfortune.
The greatest object in the universe, says a certain philosopher, is a good man struggling with adversity; yet there is a still greater, which is the good man that comes to relieve it.
The greatest of all economists are the fortifying virtues, which the wisest men of all time have arranged under the general heads of Prudence, or Discretion, the spirit which discerns and adopts rightly; Justice, the spirit which rules and divides rightly; Fortitude, the spirit which persists and endures rightly; and Temperance, the spirit which stops and refuses rightly.
The greatest of all injustice is that which goes under the name of law.
The greatest of all perversities is to deny one's own nature and act contrary to its innate moral principle.
The greatest of faults, I should say, is to be
conscious of none.
The greatest of follies is to sacrifice health for any other advantage.
The greatest of heroic deeds are those which are performed within four walls and in domestic privacy.
The greatest ornament of an illustrious life is modesty and humility, which go a great way in the character even of the most exalted princes.
The greatest part of mankind labour under one delirium or another.
The greatest prayer is patience.
The greatest skill is shown in disguising our skill.
The greatest scholars are not always the wisest men.
The greatest star is that at the little end of the telescope,--the star that is looking, not looked after, nor looked at.
The greatest success is confidence, or perfect understanding between sincere people.
The greatest truths are commonly the simplest.
The greatest truths are the simplest; and so are the greatest men.
The greatest vessel hath but its measure.
The greatest virtues of men are only splendid sins.
The Greeks and Romans are the only ancients who never become old.
The Greeks cared for man only, and for the
rest of the universe little or not at all; the moderns for the universe only, and man not at all.
The Greeks were the first to exalt spirit to lordship over nature; it was Christ who first taught us what that spirit is in itself.
The grey mare is the better horse.
The grief that does not speak / Whispers the o'er-fraught heart, and bids it break.
The grief which all hearts share grows less for one.
The groundsel speaks not save what it heard
at the hinges.
The guilty mind debases the great image that it wears, and levels us with brutes.
The habit and power of reading with reflection, comprehension, and memory all alert and awake, does not come at once to the natural man any more than many other sovereign virtues.
The habit of looking on the best side of every event is worth more than a thousand a year.
The habit of lying, when once formed, is easily extended to serve the designs of malice or interest; like all habits, it spreads indeed of itself.
The habit of party in England is not to ask the alliance of a man of genius, but to follow the guidance of a man of character.
The hand of little employment hath the daintier
sense.
The hand that gives, gathers.
The Hand that hath made you fair hath made you good; the goodness that is cheap in beauty makes beauty brief in goodness; but grace, being the soul of your complexion, should keep the body of it ever fair.
The happiest of men were he who, understanding his craft and working intelligently with his hands, and earning competence and freedom by the exercise of his wits, found time to live by the heart and by the brain, to understand his own work, and to love the work of God.
The happiness of life is made up of minute fractions,--the little, soon-forgotten charities of a kiss, a smile, a kind look, a heartfelt compliment in the disguise of a playful raillery, and the countless other infinitesimals of pleasant thought and feeling.
The happiness of man depends on no creed
and no book; it depends on the dominion of truth, which is the redeemer and saviour, the Messiah and the King of glory.
The happiness of the human race is one of the designs of God, but our own individual happiness must not be made our first or our direct aim.
The happiness we owe to ourselves is greater than that which we owe to our surroundings.
The happy day will come when mind, heart and hands shall be alive together, and shall work in concert; when there shall be a harmony between God's munificence and man's delight in it.
The happy have whole days, and those they choose; / The unhappy have but hours, and those they lose.
The happy man is he who distinguishes the
boundary between desires and delight, and stands firmly on the higher ground.
The happy think a lifetime a short stage: / One night to the unhappy seems an age.
The hardest step is over the threshold.
The hardships or misfortunes we lie under are more easy to us than those of any other person would be, should we change conditions with him.
The hare leaps out of the bush where we least look for her.
The harvest truly is plenteous, but the labourers
are few.
The hatred which is grafted on extinguished friendship must bring forth the most deadly fruits.
The head cannot understand any work of art unless it be in company with the heart.
The head is a half, a fraction, until it is enlarged and inspired by the moral sentiments.
The head learns new things, but the heart for evermore practises old experiences.
The head only reproduces what the heart
creates; and so we give the mocking-bird credit when he imitates the loving murmurs of the dove.
The health of a state consists simply in this, that in it those who are wisest shall also be strongest.
The healthy know not of their health, but only the sick.
The healthy man is the compliment of the seasons, and in winter summer is in his heart. There is the south!
The healthy understanding is not the logical argumentative, but the intuitive; for the end of understanding is not to prove and find reasons, but to know and believe.
The heart always sees before the head can
see.
The heart aye's the part aye / That mak's us right or wrang.
The heart benevolent and kind / The most resembles God.
The heart can ne'er a transport know / That never feels a pain.
The heart has eyes that the brain knows nothing of.
The heart has its arguments with which the
understanding is not acquainted.
The heart is a small thing, but desireth great matters. It is not sufficient for a kite's dinner, yet the whole world is not sufficient for it.
The heart is deceitful above all things, and desperately wicked; who can know it?
The heart is like a millstone, which gives meat if you supply it with corn, but frets itself if you don't.
The heart is like a musical instrument of many strings, all the chords of which require putting in harmony.
The heart is like the sea, is subject to storms,
ebb-tide and flood, and in its depths is many a precious pearl.
The heart is the best logician.
The heart knoweth his own bitterness; and a stranger doth not intermeddle with his joy.
The heart must be beaten or bruised, and then the sweet scent will come out.
The heart must be divorced from its idols.
The heart must glow before the tongue can
gild.
The heart needs not for its heaven much space, nor many stars therein, if only the star of love has arisen.
The heart of a fool is in his mouth, but the mouth of a wise man is in his heart.
The heart of a wise man should resemble a mirror, which reflects every object without being sullied by any.
The heart of childhood is all mirth.
The heart of every man lies open to the shafts of reproof if the archer can but take a proper aim.
The heart of man is the place the devils dwell
in.
The heart of the righteous studieth to answer; but the mouth of the wicked poureth out evil things.
The heart of the wise is in the house of mourning; but the heart of fools is in the house of mirth.
The heart sees farther than the head.
The heart that is soonest awake to the flowers is always the first to be touched by the thorns.
The heart that once truly loves never forgets.
The heart, unlike the fancy and the imagination, is not complex, and may be reached by the same weapons of thought in the most luxurious court of Christendom as in the tent of the Arab or the wigwam of the Cherokee.
The heart which truly loves puts not its love aside ... but grows stronger for that which seeks to thwart it.
The heart will break, yet brokenly live on.
The hearts of men are their books, events are their tutors, great actions are their eloquence.
The heavenly powers never go out of their
road.
The heavens and the earth, and all that is between them, think ye we have created them in jest?
The heavens and the earth are but the time-vesture of the Eternal.
The heavens declare the glory of God; and the firmament showeth his handiwork.
The heavenward path which a great man opens up for us and traverses generally, like the track of a ship through the water, closes behind him on his decease.
The heaviest head of corn hangs its head
lowest.
The heavy and the weary weight / Of all this unintelligible world.
The Hebrew Bible, is it not, before all things, true, as no other book ever was or will be?
The height charms us, the steps to it do not; with the summit in our eye, we love to walk along the plain.
The height of ability consists in a thorough knowledge of the real value of things, and of the genius of the age we live in.
The heights by great men reached and kept /
Were not attained by sudden flight, / But they, while their companions slept, / Were toiling upward in the night.
The hell of these days is the infinite terror of Not getting on, especially of Not making money.
The hen of our neighbour appears to us as a goose.
The herd of people dread sound understanding more than anything; they ought to dread stupidity, if they knew what was really dreadful. Understanding is unpleasant, they must have it pushed aside; stupidity is but pernicious, they can let it stay.
The heroes of literary history have been no less remarkable for what they have suffered than for what they have achieved.
The heroic heart, the seeing eye, of the first
times, still feels and sees in us of the latest.
The higher character a person supports, the more he should regard his minutest actions.
The higher enthusiasm of man's nature is for the while without exponent; yet does it continue indestructible, unweariedly active, and work blindly in the great chaotic deep. Thus sect after sect, and church after church, bodies itself forth, and melts again into new metamorphosis.
The higher the culture, the more honourable the work.
The higher the wisdom, the closer its neighbourhood and kinship with mere insanity.
The higher we rise, the more isolated we
become, and all elevations are cold.
The highest art is always the most religious, and the greatest artist is always a devout man.
The highest elevation attainable by man is a heroic life.
The highest exercise of invention has nothing to do with fiction; but is an invention of new truth, what we can call a revelation.
The highest genius never flowers in satire, but culminates in sympathy with that which is best in human nature, and appeals to it.
The highest gift which we receive from God
and Nature is Life, the revolving movement, which knows neither pause nor rest, of the self-conscious being round itself. The instinct to protect and cherish life is indestructibly innate in every one, but the peculiarity of it ever remains a mystery to us and others.
The highest happiness of us mortals is to execute what we consider right and good; to be really masters of the means conducive to our aims.
The highest heaven of wisdom is alike near from every point, and thou must find it, if at all, by methods native to thyself alone.
The highest in God's esteem are meanest in their own.
The highest joys spring from those possessions which are common to all, which we can neither alienate ourselves nor be deprived of by others, to which kind Nature has given all an equal right--a right which she herself guards with silent omnipotence.
The highest liberty is in harmony with the eternal laws.
The highest man of us is born brother to his contemporaries; struggle as he may, there is no escaping the family likeness.
The highest melody dwells only in silence--the sphere melody, the melody of health.
The Highest not merely has, but is, reason and understanding.
The highest political watchword is not Liberty,
Equality, Fraternity, nor yet Solidarity, but Service.
The highest price a man can pay for a thing is to ask for it.
The highest problem of every art is, by means of appearances, to produce the illusion of a loftier reality.
The highest problem of literature is the writing of a Bible.
The highest reach of a news-writer is an empty reasoning on policy, and vain conjectures on the public management.
The highest thing that art can do is to set
before you the true image of the presence of a noble human being. It has never done more than this, and it might not do less.
The highest virtue of the tropics is chastity; of colder regions, temperance.
The highest wisdom is not to be always wise.
The highway of the upright is to depart from evil.
The hind that would be mated by the lion / Must die for love.
The historian is a prophet with his face directed
to the past.
The history of a man is his character.
The history of a soldier's wound beguiles the pain of it. We lose the right of complaining sometimes by forbearing it, but we often treble the force.
The history of every man should be a Bible.
The history of persecution is a history of endeavours to cheat Nature, to make water run uphill, to twist a rope of sand. It makes no difference whether the actors be many or one, a tyrant or a mob.
The history of reforms is always identical; it
is the comparison of the idea with the fact.
The history of the Church is a history of the invisible as well as of the visible Church; which latter, if disjoined from the former, is but a vacant edifice; gilded, it may be, and overhung with old votive gifts, yet useless, nay, pestilentially unclean; to write whose history is less important than to forward its downfall.
The history of the world is nothing but the history of successful or unsuccessful grumbling; operating in great things as in small, ... inculcating through all of them the great moral, that it is not good for a man to be contented with evils that he can remove.
The hoary head is a crown of glory, if it be found in the way of righteousness.
The hollow sea-shell which for years hath stood / On dusty shelves, when held against the ear / Proclaims its stormy parent.
The Holy Supper is kept indeed / In whatso
we share with another's need; / Not what we give, but what we share, / For the gift without the giver is bare.
The honest heart that's free frae a' / Intended fraud or guile, / However Fortune kick the ba', / Has aye some cause to smile.
The honest man does that from duty which the man of honour does for the sake of character.
The honest man, though e'er so poor, / Is king o' men for a' that.
The honourablest part of talk is to give the occasion; and again to moderate and pass to somewhat else, for then a man leads the dance.
The horse is prepared against the day of battle:
but safety is of the Lord.
The horse thinks one thing, and he that rides him another.
The host should be indeed a host, and a lord of the land, a self-appointed brother of his race; called to this place, besides, by all the winds of heaven and his good genius, as truly as the preacher is called to preach.
The hottest love has the coldest end.
The hour of all windbags does arrive; every windbag is at length ripped and collapses.
The hours should be instructed by the ages,
and the ages explained by the hours.
The hours that we pass with happy prospects in view are more pleasing than those crowned with fruition.
The house of the childless is empty; and so is the heart of him that hath no wife.
The house that is a-building looks not as the house that is built.
The household is the home of the man as well as of the child.
The human creature needs first of all to be
educated, not that he may speak, but that he may have something weighty and valuable to say.
The human face is my landscape.
The human heart has a sigh lonelier than the cry of the bittern.
The human heart is like a millstone in a mill; when you put wheat under it, it turns, and grinds, and bruises the wheat into flour; if you put no wheat in, it still grinds on; but then it is itself it grinds and slowly wears away.
The human heart is like heaven; the more angels the more room.
The human mind cannot go beyond the gift
of God.
The human mind, in proportion as it is deprived of external resources, sedulously labours to find within itself the means of happiness, learns to rely with confidence on its own exertions, and gains with greater certainty the power of being happy.
The human mind is to be treated like a skein of ravelled silk, where you must cautiously secure one free end before you can make any progress in disentangling it.
The human mind will not be confined to any limits.
The human race is in the best condition when it has the greatest degree of liberty.
The human soul is like a bird that is born in a cage. Nothing can deprive it of its natural longings, or obliterate the mysterious remembrance of its heritage.
The human voice has an authority and an
insinuating property which writing lacks.
The husbandman that laboureth must be first partaker of the fruits.
The hypocrite shows well and says well, and himself is the worst thing he hath.
The idea you have once spoken, if even it were an idea, is no longer yours; it is gone from you, so much life and virtue is gone, and the vital circulations of yourself and your destiny and activity are henceforth deprived of it.
The Ideal always has to grow in the Real, and to seek out its bed and board there in a very sorry way.
The ideal beauty is a fugitive which is never
located.
The ideal of beauty is simplicity and repose; from which it follows that no youth can be a master.
The ideal of friendship is to feel as one while remaining two.
The idle always have a mind to do something.
The ignorant classes are the dangerous classes.
The ignorant peasant without fault is greater
than the philosopher with many.
The Iliad and the Shakespeare are tame to him who hears the rude but homely incidents of the road from every traveller.
The "Iliad" of Homer is no fiction, but a ballad history, the heart of it burning with enthusiastic, ill-informed belief.
The ill that's wisely feared is half withstood, / And fear of bad is the best foil to good.
The image of God cut in ebony
The imagination, give it the least license, dives
deeper and soars higher than Nature does.
The imagination is a fine faculty; yet I like not when she works on what has actually happened; the airy forms she creates are welcome as things of their own kind; but uniting with reality she produces often nothing but monsters, and seems to me, in such cases, to fly into direct variance with reason and common-sense.
The imagination of man's heart is evil from his youth.
The imaginative power always purifies, the want of it therefore essentially defiles.
The imbecility of men is always inviting the impudence of power.
The importunities and perplexities of business
are softness and luxury, compared with the incessant cravings of vacancy, and the unsatisfactory expedients of idleness.
The impressions of our childhood abide with us, even in their minutest traces.
The indignation which makes verses is, properly speaking, an inverted love; the love of some right, some worth, some goodness, belonging to ourselves or others, which has been injured, and which this tempestuous feeling issues forth to defend and revenge.
The individual and the race are always moving, and as we drift into new latitudes new lights open in the heaven more immediately over us.
The individual loves and hatreds, which sum up existence and life, are the brood of Eros; for hatred is only love in some form, crossed and thwarted, and always in nature so much hostility, so much affection of some kind is there.
The individual soul should seek for an intimate
union with the soul of the universe.
The infant / Mewling and puking in the nurse's arms. / And then the whining schoolboy, with his satchel, / And shining morning face, creeping like snail / Unwillingly to school.
The infinite is more sure than any other fact. The infinite of terror, of hope, of pity; did it not at any moment disclose itself to thee, indubitable, unnameable? Came it never, like the gleam of preternatural eternal oceans, like the voice of old eternities, far-sounding through thy heart of hearts?
The infinitely little have a pride infinitely great.
The influence which we exercise over other objects depends on the influence we have over ourselves.
The injuries of life, if rightly improved, will be
to us as the strokes of the statuary on his marble, forming us to a more beautiful shape, and making us fitter to adorn the heavenly temple.
The injustice done to an individual is sometimes of service to the public.
The ingratitude of the world can never deprive us of the conscious happiness of having acted with humanity ourselves.
The initial virtue of the race consists in the acknowledgment of their own lowly nature, and submission to the laws of higher being.
The ink of the scholar and the blood of the martyr are of equal value in the eye of heaven.
The innocent seldom find an uneasy pillow.
The inquiry of truth, which is the love-making or wooing of it; the knowledge of truth, which is the presence of it; and the belief of truth, which is the enjoying of it, is the sovereign good of human nature.
The insolence of condescension.
The insolence of office.
The inspiration of the Almighty giveth man understanding.
The instinctive feeling of a great people is often wiser than the wisest men.
The instruction merely clever men can give us is like baked bread, savoury and satisfying for a single day; but flour cannot be sown, and seed-corn ought not to be ground.
The integrity of the upright shall guide them.
The intellect has only one failing: it has no conscience.
The intellect of the wise is like glass; it
admits the light of heaven and reflects it.
The intellectual power, through words and things / Went sounding on a dim and perilous way.
The intelligent have a right over the ignorant; namely, the right of instructing them.
The intolerant man is the real pedant.
The invariable mark of wisdom is to see the miraculous in the common.
The inventor of a spinning-jenny is pretty sure
of his reward in his own day; but the writer of a true poem, like the apostle of a true religion, is nearly as sure of the contrary.
The invisible world is near us; or rather it is here, in us and about us; were the fleshly coil removed from our soul, the glories of the unseen were even now around us; as the ancients fabled of the spheral music.
The iron tongue of midnight hath told twelve.
The irreligious poet is a monster.
The

The Israelitish people never was good for
much, as its own leaders, judges, rulers, prophets have a thousand times reproachfully declared; it possesses few virtues, and most of the faults of other nations; but in cohesion, steadfastness, valour, and when all this would not serve, in obstinate toughness, it has no match.
The jealous is possessed by a "fine mad devil" and a dull spirit at once.
The jealous man's disease is of so malignant a nature, that it converts all it takes into its own nourishment.
The jest which is expected is already destroyed.
The joy of a peaceful conscience is sown in tears.
The joys of parents are secret, and so are
their griefs and fears.
The judgment is like a pair of scales, and evidences like the weights; but the will holds the balance in its hand; and even a slight jerk will be sufficient, in many cases, to make the lighter scale appear the heavier.
The judgment of the world stands upon matter of fortune.
The judgments of the understanding are properly of force but once, and that in the strictest cases, and become inaccurate in some degree when applied to any other.
The just man walketh in his integrity: his children are blessed after him.
The justice, / In fair round belly with good
capon lined, / With eyes severe and beard of formal cut, / Full of wise saws and modern instances; / And so he plays his part.
The keeping of bees is like the directing of sunbeams.
The key to every man is his thought. Sturdy and defying though he look, he has a helm which he obeys.
The kind fool, of all kinds of fools, is worst.
The kind of speech in a man betokens the kind of action you will get from him.
The king goes as far as he may, not as far as
he would.
The king, like other people, has now and then shabby errands, and must have shabby fellows to do them.
The king may gang the cadger's gate
The king protecteth the people, and they support the greatness of their sovereign. But protection is better than greatness; for the one cannot exist without the other.
The king's errand may come in at the cadger's gate.
The king's favour is toward a wise servant.
The king's honour is that of his people. Their real honour and real interest are the same.
The kings of modern thought are dumb.
The king's wrath is as the roaring of a lion; but his favour is as dew upon the grass.
The kingdom of God does not lie in elegance of speech or fineness of parts, but in innocence of life and good works.
The knowledge of man is an evening knowledge,
"vespertina cognitio," but that of God is a morning knowledge, "matutina cognitio."
The knowledge of thyself will preserve thee from vanity.
The labour we delight in physics pain.
The labourer is worthy of his hire.
The lake's silver dulls with driving clouds.
The lamp of genius burns quicker than the
lamp of life.
The lamp of the wicked shall be put out.
The land is mother of us all; nourishes, shelters, gladdens, lovingly enriches us all; in how many ways, from our first wakening to our last sleep on her blessed mother-bosom, does she, as with blessed mother's arms, enfold us all!
The land, properly speaking, belongs to these two: to the Almighty God; and to all his children of men that have ever worked well on it, or that shall ever work well on it.
The language of truth is simple.
The largest soul of any country is altogether its own.
The last act crowns the play.
The last, best fruit which comes to late perfection, even in the kindliest soul, is tenderness toward the hard, forbearance toward the unforbearing, warmth of heart toward the cold, philanthropy toward the misanthropic.
The last drop makes the cup run over.
The last ounce breaks the camel's back.
The last pale rim or sickle of the moon, which had once been full, now sinking in the dark seas.
The last perfection of our faculties is that their activity, without ceasing to be sure and earnest, become sport.
The last stage of human perversion is when sympathy corrupts itself into envy; and the indestructible interest we take in men's doings has become a joy over their faults and misfortunes.
The last thing that we discover in writing a book is to know what to put at the beginning.
The Latin word for a flatterer
no more than a person that barely consents; and indeed such a one, if a man were able to purchase or maintain him, cannot be bought too dear.
The latter part of a wise man's life is taken up in curing the follies, prejudices, and false opinions he had contracted in the former.
The law always limits every power which it bestows.
The law cannot equalise men in spite of nature.
The law has no eyes, the law has no hands, the law is nothing--nothing but a piece of paper, till public opinion breathes the breath of life into the dead letter.
The law is good if a man use it lawfully.
The law is light; and reproofs of instruction are the way of life.
The law is past depth to those that, without heed, do plunge into it.
The law is the friend of the weak.
The law is what we must do; the gospel what God will give.
The law of nature is the strictest expression
of necessity.
The law of perseverance is among the deepest in man; by nature he hates change; seldom will he quit his old house till it has actually fallen about his ears.
The law of the wise is a fountain of life.
The law often permits what honour prohibits.
The law will never make men free; it is men who have got to make the law free.
The law's made to take care o' raskils.
The laws of morality are also those of art.
The laws of nature are just, but terrible. There is no weak mercy in them.
The laws of nature never vary; in their application they never hesitate, nor are wanting.
The laws undertake to punish only overt acts.
The lawyer is a gentleman who rescues your
estate from your enemies, and keeps it to himself.
The leafy blossoming present time springs from the whole past, remembered and unrememberable.
The lean and slippered pantaloon, / With spectacles on nose and pouch on side; / His youthful hose, well saved, a world too wide / For his shrunk shank; and his big manly voice / Turning again towards childish treble, pipes / And whistles in his sound.
The learned understand the reason of the art, the unlearned feel the pleasure.
The legacy of heroes--the memory of a great name and the inheritance of a great example.
The legal and proper mercy of a king of
England may remit the punishment, but ought not to stop the trial.
The lenient hand of time is daily and hourly either lightening the burden or making us insensible to the weight.
The less a man thinks or knows about his virtues the better we like him.
The less men think the more they talk.
The less routine the more of life.
The less the wise man pleases himself, the
more the world esteems him.
The less we deserve good fortune, the more we hope for it.
The less we have to do with our sins the better.
The lessons of adversity are not always salutary; sometimes they soften and amend, but as often they indurate and pervert.
The letter killeth, but the spirit giveth life.
The liberal deviseth liberal things; and by
liberal things shall he stand.
The liberal soul shall be made fat: and he that watereth shall be watered also himself.
The liberty of writing letters with too careless a hand is apt to betray persons into imprudence in what they write.
The life is more than meat, and the body is more than raiment.
The life of a fool is worse than death.
The life of a man is tormented not by things,
but by opinions of things.
The life of a nation is usually, like the flow of a lava stream, first bright and fierce, then languid and covered, at last advancing by the tumbling over and over of its frozen blocks.
The life of all gods figures itself to us as a sublime sadness,--earnestness of infinite battle against infinite labour.
The life of an animal, until the hour of his death, passeth away in disciplines, in elevations and depressions, in unions and separations.
The life of an egoist is a tissue of inconsistencies, of actions that, from his own point of view, are absurd and foolish.
The life of every man is a diary in which he means to write one story, and writes another.
The life of every man is as the well-spring of a stream, whose small beginnings are indeed plain to all, but whose ulterior course and destination, as it winds through the expanses of infinite years, only the omniscient can discern.
The life of man is a journey; a journey that
must be travelled, however bad the roads or the accommodation.
The life of the Divine Man stands in no connection with the general history of the world in his time. It was a private life; his teaching was a teaching for individuals.
The life of the lowest mortal, if faithfully recorded, would be interesting to the highest.
The life which renews a man springs ever from within.
The light by which we see in this world comes out from the soul of the observer.
The light can be a curtain as well as the darkness.
The light of friendship is like the light of phosphorus--seen plainest when all around is dark.
The light of the body is the eye; if therefore thine eye be single, thy whole body shall be full of light.
The light shineth in darkness; and the darkness comprehended it not.
The light that a man receiveth by counsel from another is drier and purer than that which cometh from his own understanding and judgment, which is ever infused and drenched in his affections and customs.
The light (which you refuse to take in) returns
on you, condensed into lightning, which there is not any skin whatever too thick for taking in.
The lightning is the shorthand of the storm, / That tells of chaos.
The limbs of my buried ones touched cold on my soul and drove away its blots, as dead hands heal eruptions of the skin.
The line of life is a ragged diagonal between duty and desire.
The lion is not so fierce as painted.
The lips of the righteous feed many; but fools
die for want of wisdom.
 (truss
The litigant, unlike the goose, never gets and dished.
The little done vanishes from the sight of man who looks forward to what is still to do.
The little foolery that wise men have makes a great show.
The little man is still a man.
The little mind will not by daily intercourse
with great minds become one inch greater; but the noble man ... will, by a knowledge of, and familiar intercourse with, elevated natures, everyday make a visible approximation to similar greatness.
The little that a just man hath is better than the riches of many wicked.
The lives of the best of us are spent in choosing between evils.
The loftier the building the deeper must the foundation be laid.
The loftiest mortal loves and seeks the same sort of things with the meanest, only from higher grounds and by higher paths.
The loftiest of our race are those who have
had the profoundest grief, because they have had the profoundest sympathies.
The longer a man's fame is likely to last, the later it will be in coming.
The longer life the more offence, / The more offence the greater pain, / The greater pain the less defence, / The less defence the lesser gain.
The longer we live and the more we think, the higher value we learn to put on the friendship and tenderness of parents and of friends.
The longer you read the Bible the more you will like it.
The longest day soon comes to an end.
The longest life is scarcely longer than the shortest, if we think of the eternity that encircles both.
The longest wave is quickly lost in the sea.
The look of a king is itself a deed.
The loom of Fortune weaves the fine and coarsest web.
The loom of life never stops; and the pattern
which was weaving when the sun went down in the evening is weaving when it comes up to-morrow.
The Lord bestoweth his blessings where he findeth the vessels empty.
The Lord gave, and the Lord taketh away: blessed be the name of the Lord.
The Lord is a buckler to all that trust in him.
The Lord is a God of knowledge, and by him actions are weighed.
The Lord will not suffer the soul of the
righteous to famish: but he casteth away the substance of the wicked.
The loss of territory, or of a wise and virtuous servant, is a great loss, ... for servants are not easily to be found.
The lot is cast into the lap; but the whole disposing thereof is of the Lord.
The love of country produces good manners, and good manners also love of country. The less we satisfy our particular passions, the more we leave to our general.
The love of gain never made a painter; but it has marred many.
The love of God is broader than the measure
of man's mind.
The love of letters is the forlorn hope of the man of letters.
The love of money is the root of all evil.
The love season is the carnival of egoism, and it brings the touchstone to our natures.
The lover has more senses and finer senses than others.
The lover, / Sighing like a furnace, with a
woeful ballad / Made to his mistress' eyebrow.
The lower a man descends in his love, the higher he lifts his life.
The lower has oftentimes to be with sorrow sacrificed to the higher duties of the soul.
The lower nature must always be denied when you are trying to rise to a higher sphere.
The lunatic, the lover, and the poet, / Are of imagination all compact.
The lust of fame is the last that a wise man
shakes off.
The lyric poet may drink wine and live generously, but the epic poet, who shall sing of the gods and their descent unto men, must drink water out of a wooden bowl.
The magic of the pen lies in the concentration of your thoughts upon one object.
The magic power of love consists in its ennobling whatever its breath touches, like the sun whose golden ray transmutes even thunderclouds into gold.
The main enterprise of the world for splendour, for extent, is the upbuilding of a man.
The majority have no other reason for their
opinions than that they are the fashion.
The make-weight! The make-weight! which fate throws into the balance for us at every happiness! It requires much courage not to be down-hearted in this world.
The malicious sneer is improperly called laughter.
The man at the head of the house can mar the pleasure of the household; but he cannot make it. That must rest with the woman, and it is her greatest privilege.
The man comes before the citizen, and our future is greater than both.
The man is only half himself, the other half
is his expression.
The man makes the circumstances, and is spiritually as well as economically the artificer of his own fortune, but the man's circumstances are the element he is appointed to live and work in; so that in a no less genuine sense it can be said circumstances make the man.
The man of consequence and fashion shall richly repay a deed of kindness with a nod and a smile, or a hearty shake of the hand; while a poor fellow labours under a sense of gratitude, which, like copper coin, though it loads the bearer, is yet of small account in the currency and commerce of the world.
The man of genius can be more easily misinstructed
and driven far more violently into false courses than a man of ordinary capability.
The man of genius, like a dog with a bone, sits afar and retired off the road, hangs out no sign of refreshment for man and beast, but says, by all possible hints and signs, "I wish to be alone--good-bye--farewell!"
The man of good common-sense may, if he
pleases, in his particular station of life, most certainly be rich.
The man of intellect at the top of affairs; this is the aim of all institutions and revolutions, if they have any.
The man of intellect is lost unless he unites energy of character to intellect. When we have the lantern of Diogenes we must have his staff.
The man of wisdom is the man of years.
The man should make the hour, not this the man.
The man that blushes is not quite a brute.
The man that hath no music in himself, / Nor is not moved with concord of sweet sounds, / Is fit for treasons, stratagems, and spoils; / The motions of his spirit are dull as night, / And his affections dark as Erebus: / Let no such man be trusted.
The man that makes a character makes foes.
The man that stands by himself, the universe stands also.
The man that wandereth out of the way of understanding shall remain in the congregation of the dead.
The man to whom the universe does not reveal
directly what relation it has to him, whose heart does not tell him what he owes to himself and others--that man will scarcely learn it out of books; which generally do little more than give our errors names.
The man truly proud thinks honours below his merit, and scorns to boast.
The man
though unconscious of it; and preached, through the cannon's throat, that great doctrine, "La carrière ouverte aux talens," "The tools to him that can handle them," which is our ultimate political evangel, wherein alone can liberty lie.
The man who can be nothing but serious or nothing but merry is but half a man.
The man who can thank himself alone for the happiness he enjoys is truly blest.
The man who cannot be a Christian in the
place where he is, cannot be a Christian anywhere.
The man who cannot blush, and who has no feelings of fear, has reached the acme of impudence.
The man who cannot enjoy his natural gifts in silence, and find his reward in the exercise of them, but must wait and hope for their recognition by others, must expect to reap only disappointment and vexation.
The man who cannot laugh is not only fit for treasons, stratagems, and spoils; but his own whole life is already a treason and a stratagem.
The man who cannot sometimes endure his own company must have a bad heart or a deficient intellect.
The man who cannot wonder, who does not habitually wonder (and worship), were he president of innumerable royal societies, and carried the whole "Méchanique Céleste" and Hegel's Philosophy, and the epitome of all laboratories and observatories with their results, in his single head, is but a pair of spectacles behind which there is no eye.
The man who does not know when to die, does not know how to live.
The man who does not learn to live while he is
getting a living is a poorer man after his wealth is won than he was before.
The man who fears not death will start at no shadows.
The man who has imagination without learning has wings without feet.
The man who has no enemies has no following.
The man who has nothing to boast of but his illustrious ancestry is like a potato,--the only good belonging to him is underground.
The man who in this world can keep the whiteness
of his soul is not likely to lose it in any other.
The man who in wavering times is inclined to be wavering only increases the evil, and spreads it wider and wider; but the man of firm decision fashions the universe.
The man who insists upon seeing with perfect clearness before he decides, never decides.
The man who invented "Ifs" and "Buts" must have first made gold out of straw choppings.
The man who is always fortunate cannot easily have a great reverence for virtue.
The man who is born with a talent which he
is meant to use, finds his greatest happiness in using it.
The man who is in a hurry to see the full effects of his own tillage must cultivate annuals, and not forest trees.
The man who leaves home to mend himself and others is a philosopher; but he who goes from country to country, guided by the blind impulse of curiosity, is only a vagabond.
The man who lives by hope will die by despair.
The man who pauses in his honesty wants little of a villain.
The man who small things scorns will next, /
By things still smaller be perplexed.
The man who will live above his present circumstances is in great danger of living in a little time much beneath them, or, as the Italian proverb says, "The man who lives by hope will die by despair."
The man who works at home helps society at large with somewhat more of certainty than he who devotes himself to charities.
The man who writes for fools is always sure of a large audience.
The man whom grown-up people love, children love still more.
The manifestation of one's own superiority
may render the purchase too dear, by being bought at the terrible price of our neighbour's dislike.
The manners of the ill-mannered are never so odious, unbearable, exasperating, as they are to their own nearest kindred.
The many still must labour for the one! It is Nature's doom.
The march of intellect is proceeding at quick time; and if its progress be not accompanied by a corresponding improvement in morals and religion, the faster it proceeds, with the more violence will you be hurried down the road to ruin.
The march of intellect, which licks all the world into shape, has reached even the devil.
The march of the human mind is slow.
The mark of the man of the world is absence of pretension. He does not make a speech; he takes a low business-tone, avoids all brag, is nobody, dresses plainly, promises not at all, performs much, speaks in monosyllables, hugs his fact. He calls his employment by its lowest name, and so takes from evil tongues their sharpest weapon.
The marks of attachment, even to a fault, are an accumulation of virtues.
The mass of men consulted at hustings, upon any high matter whatsoever, is as ugly an exhibition of human study as the world sees.
The master of slaves has seldom the soul of a man.
The master-spirit who can rule the storm is
great; but he is much greater who can both raise and rule it.
The mastiff is quiet while curs are yelping.
The material wealth of a country is the portion of its possessions which feeds and educates good men and women in it.
The May of our life blooms once, and not again.
The mean of true valour lies between the extremes of cowardice and rashness.
The means that Heaven yields must be embraced,
/ And not neglected.
The measure of a master is his success in bringing all men round to his opinion twenty years later.
The mechanical occupations of man, the watching any object, as it were, coming into existence by manual labour, is a very pleasant way of passing one's time, but our own activity is at the moment nil. It is almost the same as with smoking tobacco.
The meditative heart / Attends the warning of each day and hour, / And practises in secret every virtue.
The meek shall inherit the earth.
The memory of absent friends becomes dimmed, although not effaced by time. The distractions of our life, acquaintance with fresh objects, in short, every change in our condition, works upon our hearts as dust and smoke upon a painting, making the finely drawn lines quite imperceptible, whilst one does not know how it happens.
The memory of the just is blessed.
The men I am afraid of are the men who believe everything, subscribe to everything, and vote for everything.
The merchant who was at first busy in acquiring money ceases to grow richer from the time when he makes it his business only to count it.
The merciful shall obtain mercy.
The mere existence and necessity of a philosophy is an evil.
The mere reality of life would be inconceivably poor without the charm of fancy, which brings in its bosom, no doubt, as many vain fears as idle hopes, but lends much oftener to the illusions it calls up a gay flattering hue than one which inspires terror.
The merit of originality is not novelty, it is sincerity. The believing man is the original man; whatsoever he believes, he believes it for himself, not for another.
The meteor flag of England, / Shall yet terrific burn, / Till danger's troubled night depart, / And the star of peace return.
The milder virtues subsist only in co-existence
with the severer, and the heart which pronounces a blessing on the poor and the merciful utters with the same breath sentence of excommunication against all who are proud-spirited and cruel-hearted.
The mill will never grind with the water that is past.
The mind becomes bankrupt under too large obligations. All additional benefits lessen every hope of future returns, and bar up every avenue that leads to tenderness.
The mind can make / Substance, and people planets of its own / With beings brighter than have been, and give / A breath to forms that can outlive all flesh.
The mind conceives with pain, but it brings forth with delight.
The mind content both crown and kingdom is.
The mind goes antagonising on, and never prospers but by fits.
The mind is enlarged and elevated by mere purposes, though they end as they begin by airy contemplation.
The mind is ever ingenious in making its own distress.
The mind is its own place, and in itself / Can make a heaven of hell, a hell of heaven.
The mind must not yield to the body.
The mind of a fool is empty; and everything is empty where there is poverty.
The mind of a good man doth not alter, even when he is in distress; the waters of the ocean are not to be heated by a torch of straw.
The mind of man is no inert receptacle of knowledge, but absorbs and incorporates into its own constitution the ideas which it receives.
The mind of the greatest man on earth is not so independent of circumstances as not to feel inconvenienced by the merest buzzing noise about him; it does not need the report of a cannon to disturb his thoughts. The creaking of a vane or a pulley is quite enough. Do not wonder that he reasons ill just now; a fly is buzzing by his ear; it is quite enough to unfit him for giving good counsel.
The mind profits by the wrecks of every
passion, and we may measure our road to wisdom by the sorrows we have undergone.
 _th
The minds of some of our statesmen, like the pupil of the human eye, contract themselves the more the stronger light there is shed upon them.
The mind's the standard of the man.
The miracles which Christ and His disciples wrought were the scaffolding, not the building. The scaffolding is removed as soon as the building is finished.
The miser is as much in want of that which he
has as of that which he has not.
The miser is niggardly in death; two glances he casts on his coffin and a thousand with dismay on his anxiously-guarded treasures.
The miserable have no other medicine, / But only hope.
The misery of man proceeds not from any single crush of overwhelming evil, but from small vexations continually repeated.
The misfortune in the state is that nobody can enjoy life in peace, but that everybody must govern; and in art, that nobody will enjoy what has been produced, but that every one wants to reproduce on his own account.
The mixtures of spiritual chemistry refuse to
be analysed.
The mob has many heads, but no brains.
The mob is a monster, with the hands of Briareus but the head of Polyphemus,--strong to execute, but blind to perceive.
The mob is a sort of bear; while your ring is through its nose, it will even dance under your cudgel; but should the ring slip and you lose your hold, the brute will turn and rend you.
(The mob is) the scum that rises uppermost when the nation boils.
The modest virgin, the prudent wife, or the
careful matron, are much more serviceable in life than petticoated philosophers, blustering heroines, or virago queens.
The moment an ill can be patiently borne, it is disarmed of its poison, though not of its pain.
The moment must be pregnant and sufficient to itself if it is to become a worthy segment of time and eternity.
The moment there is a bargain over the pottage the family relation is dissolved.
The moment which is the cradle of the future is also the grave of the past.
The moon doth not withhold the light even from the cottage of a Chandala
The moon that shone in Paradise.
The moral difference between a man and a beast is, that the one acts primarily for use, and the other for pleasure.
The morality of a king is not to be measured
by vulgar rules. There are faults which do him honour, and virtues that disgrace him.
The morality of girls is custom, not principle.
The morality of some people is in remnants--never enough to make a coat.
The more a man has in himself the less he will want from other people--the less, indeed, other people can be to him.
The more a man lives, the more he suffers.
The more angels the more room.
The more business a man has to do, the more he is able to accomplish; for he learns to economise his time.
The more bustling the streets become, the more quietly one moves.
The more fair and crystal is the sky, / The uglier seem the clouds that in it fly.
The more generally persons are pleasing, the less profoundly do they please.
The more haste, the worse speed.
The more honesty a man has, the less he affects the air of a saint.
The more laws you accept, the fewer penalties you will have to endure, and the fewer punishments to enforce.
The more men refine upon pleasure, the less will they indulge in excesses of any kind.
The more of the solid there is in a man, the less does he act the balloon.
The more powerful the obstacle, the more
glory we have in overcoming it; and the difficulties with which we are met are the maids of honour which set off virtue.
The more profound the thought, the more burdensome.
The more riches a fool has, the greater fool he is.
The more sand has escaped from the hour-glass of our life, the clearer we should see through it.
The more sinful a man feels himself, the more Christian he is.
The more the soul admires, the more it is
exalted.
The more thou feelest thyself to be a man, so much the more dost thou resemble the gods.
The more we do, the more we can do; the more busy we are, the more leisure we have.
The more we have read, the more we have learned, the more we have meditated, the better conditioned we are to affirm that we know nothing.
The more we know, the greater our thirst for knowledge. The water-lily, in the midst of waters, opens its leaves and expands its petals at the first pattering of showers, and rejoices in the raindrops with a quicker sympathy than the parched shrub in a sandy desert.
The more we work, the more we shall be
trodden down.
The more weakness, the more falsehood; strength goes straight; every cannon-ball that has in it hollows and holes goes crooked. Weaklings must lie.
The more you are talked about, the less powerful you are.
The morning stars sang together, and all the sons of God shouted for joy.
The most advanced nations are always those who navigate the most.
The most brilliant flashes of wit come from a
clouded mind, as lightning leaps only from an obscure firmament.
The most certain sign of wisdom is a continual cheerfulness.
The most civilised are as near to barbarism as the most polished steel to rust. Nations, like metals, have only a superficial brilliancy.
The most cursory observation shows that a degree of reserve adds vastly to the latent force of character.
The most delightful letter does not possess a hundredth part of the charm of a conversation.
The most difficult thing in life is to know yourself.
The most elevated sensation of music arises from a confused perception of ideal or visionary beauty and rapture, which is sufficiently perceivable to fire the imagination, but not clear enough to become an object of knowledge.
The most enthusiastic Evangelicals do not preach a gospel, but keep describing how it should and might be preached; to awaken the sacred fire of faith, as by a sacred contagion, is not their endeavour, but, at most, to describe how faith shows and acts, and scientifically distinguish true faith from false.
The most enthusiastic mystics were women.
The most essential fact about a man is the constitution of his consciousness.
The most finished man of the world is he who
