is never irresolute and never in a hurry.
The most gladsome thing in the world is that few of us fall very low; the saddest that, with such capabilities, we seldom rise high.
The most happy man is he who knows how to bring into relation the end and the beginning of his life.
The most learned are often the most narrow-minded men.
The most important moment in man's life is certainly not the last.
The most important part of education is right
training in the nursery.
The most important period in the life of an individual is that of his development. Later on, commences his conflict with the world, and this is of interest only so far as anything grows out of it.
The most important thing is to learn to rule one's self.
The most original modern authors are not so because they advance what is new, but simply because they know how to put what they have to say as if it had never been said before.
The most objectionable people are the quibbling investigators and the crotchety theorists; their endeavours are petty and complicated, their hypotheses abstruse and strange.
The most part of all the misery and mischief,
of all that is denominated evil, in the world, arises from the face that men are too remiss to get a proper knowledge of their aims, and when they do know them, to work intensely in attaining them.
The most significant feature in the history of an epoch is the manner it has of welcoming a great man.
The most sorrowful occurrence often, through the hand of Providence, takes the most favourable turn for our happiness; the succession of fortune and misfortune in life is intertwined like sleep and waking, neither without the other, and one for the sake of the other.
The most unhappy and frail of all creatures is man, and yet he is the proudest.
The most universal quality is diversity.
The most virtuous of all men is he that contents
himself with being virtuous without seeking to appear so.
The mother-grace of all the graces is Christian good-will.
The mother of the useful arts is necessity; that of the fine arts is luxury. For father, the former has intellect; the latter, genius, which itself is a kind of luxury.
The mother's heart is always with her children.
The mother's yearning feels the presence of the cherished child even in the degraded man.
The motto of chivalry is also the motto of
wisdom; to serve all and love but one.
The mouth of a righteous man is a well of life: but violence covereth the mouth of the wicked.
The movement of sound, such as will reach the soul for the education of it in virtue, we call Music.
The multiplicity of facts and writings is become so great, that everything must soon be reduced to extracts.
The multiplying villanies of natures / Do swarm upon him.
The multitude have no habit of self-reliance
or original action.
The multitude is always in the wrong.
The multitude of fools is a protection to the wise.
The multitude unawed is insolent; once seized with fear, contemptible and vain.
The multitude which does not reduce itself to unity is confusion; the unity which does not depend upon the multitude is tyranny.
The Muses (daughters of Memory) refresh us
in our toilsome course with sweet remembrances.
The music in my heart I bore / Long after it was heard no more.
The mustard-seed of thought is a pregnant treasury of vast results. Like the germ in the Egyptian tombs, its vitality never perishes; and its fruit will spring up after it has been buried for long ages.
The mystery of a person is ever divine to him that has a sense for the godlike.
The nation is governed by all that has tongue in the nation: democracy is virtually there.
The nation is worth nothing which does not
joyfully stake its all on its honour.
The native land of the poet's poetic powers and poetic action is the good, noble, and beautiful, which is confined to no particular province or country, and which he seizes upon and forms wherever he finds it. Therein is he like the eagle.
The natural effect of sorrow over the dead is to refine and elevate the mind.
The natural qualities pass over all others and mount upon the head.
The near explains the far.
The nearer the church the farther from God.
The nearer we approach the goal of life, the better we begin to understand the true value of our existence, and the real weight of our opinions.
The necessities of my heart always give the cold philosophisings the lie.
The necessities of things are sterner stuff than the hopes of men.
The neck on which diamonds might have worthily sparkled will look less tempting when the biting winter has hung icicles there for gems.
The negation of will and desire is the only
road to deliverance.
The nerve that never relaxes, the eye that never blenches, the thought that never wanders--these are the masters of victory.
The nerves, they are the man.
The never-absent mop in one hand, and yet no effects of it visible anywhere.
The new man is always in a new time, under new conditions; his course is the fac-simile of no prior one, but is by its nature original.
The next dreadful thing to a battle lost is a
battle won.
The night cometh, when no man can work.
The night is far spent, the day is at hand: let us therefore cast off the works of darkness, and let us put on the armour of light.
The night is for the day, but the day is not for the night.
The night is long that never finds the day.
The night shows stars and women in a better light.
The nobility of life is work. We live in a working world. The lazy and idle man does not count in the plan of campaign. "My Father worketh hitherto, and I work." Let that text be enough.
The noble character at certain moments may resign himself to his emotions; the well-bred, never.
The noble ones who have lived among us have not left us; they only truly came to us when they departed, and they were then first kissed by us into immortality.
The nobler and more perfect a thing is, the
slower it is in attaining maturity.
The nobler the virtue is, the more eager and generous resolution do thou express of attaining to it.
The noblest charms of music, though real and affecting, seem too confused and fluid to be collected into a distinct idea. Harmony is always understood by the crowd, and almost always mistaken by musicians.
The noblest mind the best contentment hath.
The noblest vengeance is to forgive.
The noblest works and foundations have proceeded
from childless men, which have sought to express the images of their minds where those of their bodies have failed.
The north wind driveth away rain: so doth an angry countenance a backbiting tongue.
The Now is an atom of sand, / And the Near is a perishing clod; / But Afar is as Fairy Land, / And beyond is the bosom of God.
The nurse's bread is sweeter than the mother's cake.
The oak first announces itself when, with far-sounding crash, it falls.
The object of all true policy and true economy
is, the utmost multitude of good men on every given space of ground.
The object of art is to crystallise emotion into thought and then to fix it in form.
The object of preaching is constantly to remind mankind of what mankind are constantly forgetting; not to supply the defects of human intelligence, but to fortify the feebleness of human resolutions.
The object of reading is not to dip into everything that even wise men have ever written.
The object of the poet is, and must be, to "instruct by pleasing," yet not by pleasing this man and that man; only by pleasing man, by speaking to the pure nature of man, can any real "instruction," in this sense, be conveyed.
The object of the politician is expediency,
and his duty is to adapt his measures to the often crude, undeveloped, and vacillating conception of the nation. The object, on the other hand, of the philosopher is truth, and his duty is to push every principle which he believes to be true to its legitimate consequences, regardless of the results that may follow.
The object of true religion should be to impress the principles of morality deeply in the soul.
The obligation of veracity may be made out from the direct ill consequences of lying to social happiness.
The obscure is what transcends us, and what imposes itself upon us by transcending us.
The ocean beats against the stern dumb shore, / The stormy passion of its mighty heart.
The ocean may have bounds.
The offender never pardons.
The old fox is caught at last.
The old gloomy cathedrals were good, but the great blue dome that hangs over all is better than any Cologne one.
The old never dies till this happen, till all the soul of good that was in it get itself transfused into the practical new.
The old order changeth, yielding place to
new, / And God fulfils himself in many ways, / Lest one good custom should corrupt the world.
The old prose writers wrote as if they were speaking to an audience; while among us prose is invariably written for the eye alone.
The older we get the more we must limit ourselves, if we wish to be active.
The oldest, and indeed only true, order of nobility known under the stars, is that of just men and sons of God, in opposition to unjust men and sons of Belial, which latter indeed are second oldest, and yet a very unvenerable order.
The oldest in years is not always the most experienced, and he who has suffered most has not always the best manners.
The one enemy we have in this universe is
stupidity, darkness of mind; of which darkness there are many sources, every sin a source, and probably self-conceit the chief source.
The one essential point
is to know that it is wrong; how to get out of it you can decide afterwards at your leisure.
The one exclusive sign of a thorough knowledge is the power of teaching.
The one intolerable sort of slavery, over which the very gods weep, is the slavery of the strong to the weak; of the great and noble-minded to the small and mean; the slavery of wisdom to folly.
The one prudence in life is concentration.
The one thing of value in the world is the
active soul.
The one unhappiness of a man is that he cannot work, that he cannot get his destiny as a man fulfilled.
The only competition worthy a wise man is with himself.
The only disadvantage of an honest heart is its credulity.
The only evolution of any really human interest, and worthy of any human regard, is the evolution that springs from resolution and the birth of freedom in the self-conscious soul.
The only failure a man ought to fear is failure in cleaving to the purpose he sees to be best.
The only faith that wears well, and holds its colour in all weathers, is that which is woven of conviction, and set with the sharp mordant of experience.
The only fence against the world is a thorough knowledge of it.
The only freedom which deserves the name is that of pursuing our own good in our own way, so long as we do not attempt to deprive others of this, or impede their efforts to obtain it.
The only genuine Romance for grown persons
is Reality.
The only gift is a portion of thyself.
The only happiness a brave man ever troubled himself with asking much about was, happiness enough to get his work done.
The only liberty that is valuable is a liberty connected with order.
The only means of overcoming adversities is a fresh activity.
The only medicine which does women more
good than harm is dress.
The only ornament of old age is virtue.
The only poetry is history, could we tell it aright.
The only point now is what a man weighs in the scale of humanity; all the rest is nought. A coat with a star, and a chariot with six horses, at all events, imposes on the rudest multitude only, and scarcely that.
The only progress which is really effective depends, not upon the bounty of Nature, but upon the energy of man.
The only satisfaction of the will is that it
encounters with no resistance.
The only school of genuine moral sentiment is society between equals.
The only serious and formidable thing in Nature is will.
The only sin which we never forgive in each other is difference of opinion.
The only solid instruction is that which the pupil brings from his own depths; the true instruction is not that which transmits notions wholly formed, but that which renders him capable of forming for himself good opinions.
The only substance properly so called is the
soul.
The only teller of news is the poet.
The only thing grief has taught me is to know how shallow it is.
The only true principle for humanity is justice.
The only true source of politeness is consideration.
The only victory over love is flight.
The only way to have a friend is to be one.
The only way to understand the difficult parts of the Bible is first to read and obey the easy ones.
The opinions of men are as many and as different as their persons; the greatest diligence and most prudent conduct can never please them all.
The opportunity to do mischief is found a hundred times a day, and that of doing good once a year.
The ordinary man places life's happiness in
things external to him; his centre of gravity is not in himself.
The ornament of a house is the friends who frequent it.
The outer passes away; the inmost is the same yesterday, to-day, and for ever.
The over-curious are not over-wise.
The owl of ignorance lays the egg of pride.
The owl sees the sunshine and winks in its
nest.
The ox lies still while the geese are hissing.
The pain of an unfilled wish is small in comparison with that of repentance; for the one stands in presence of the vast open future, whilst the other has the irrevocable past closed behind it.
The pain that any one actually feels is still of all others the worst.
The pain which conscience gives the man who has already done wrong is soon got over. Conscience is a coward; and those faults it has not strength enough to prevent, it seldom has justice enough to accuse.
The pains of power are real, its pleasures are
imaginary.
The painful warrior famousèd for fight, / After a thousand victories, once foil'd, / Is from the books of honour razèd quite, / And all the rest forgot for which he toil'd.
The painter should grind his own colours; the architect work in the mason's yard with his men; the master-manufacturer be himself a more skilful operator than any man in his mills; and the distinction between one man and another be only in experience and skill, and the authority and wealth which these must naturally and justly obtain.
The parasite courtier in the palace is the legitimate father of the tyrant.
The parcel of books, if they are well chosen, ... awakens within us the diviner mind, and rouses us to a consciousness of what is best in others and ourselves.
The pardon of an offence must, as a benefit
conferred, put the offender under an obligation; and thus direct advantage at once accrues by heaping coals of fire on the head.
The particular is the universal seen under special limitations.
The passions are only exaggerated vices or virtues.
The passions are the only orators who never fail to persuade.
The passions, by grace of the supernal and also of the infernal powers (for both have a hand in it), can never fail us.
The passions may be likened to blood horses,
that need training and the curb only to enable them when they carry to achieve most glorious triumphs.
The passions of mankind are partly protective, partly beneficent, like the chaff and grain of the corn; but none without their use, none without nobleness when seen in balanced unity with the rest of the spirit which they are charged to defend.
The passions rise higher at domestic than at imperial tragedies.
The past alone is eternal and unchangeable like death, and yet at the same time warm and joy-giving like life.
The past and future are veiled; but the past wears the widow's veil, the future the virgin's.
The past at least is secure.
The past is all holy to us; the dead are all
holy; even they that were base and wicked when alive.
The past is an unfathomable depth, / Beyond the span of thought; 'tis an elapse / Which hath no mensuration, but hath been / For ever and for ever.
The past is to us a book sealed with seven seals
The path of falsehood is a perplexing maze.
The path of nature is indeed a narrow one, and it is only the immortals that seek it, and, when they find it, they do not find themselves cramped therein.
The path of sorrow, and that path alone, /
Leads to the land where sorrow is unknown.
The path of the just is as the shining light, that shineth more and more unto the perfect day.
The path of things is silent.
The paths of glory lead but to the grave.
The pathetic almost always consists in the detail of little circumstances.
The peace of heaven is theirs who lift their
swords / In such a just and charitable war.
The peacemakers shall be called the children of God.
The peevish, the niggard, the dissatisfied, the passionate, the suspicious, and those who live upon others' means, are for ever unhappy.
The pen is mightier than the sword.
The pencil of the Holy Ghost hath laboured more in describing the afflictions of Job than the felicities of Solomon.
The people have the right to murmur, but they
have also the right to be violent, and their silence is the lesson of kings.
The people of England are the most enthusiastic in the world.
The people of this world having been once deceived, suspect deceit in truth itself.
The people once belonged to the kings; now the kings belong to the people.
The perfect flower of religion opens in the soul only when all self-seeking is abandoned.
The perfection of art is to conceal art.
The perfection of conversation is not to play a regular sonata, but, like the Æolian harp, to await the inspiration of the passing breeze.
The perfection of spiritual virtue lies in being always all there, a whole man present in every movement and moment.
The period of faith must alternate with the period of denial; the vernal growth, the summer luxuriance of all opinions, spiritual representations and creations must be followed by, and again follow, the autumnal decay, the winter dissolution.
The persistent aspirations of the human race are to society what the compass is to the ship. It sees not the shore, but it guides to it.
The person who in company should pretend
to be wiser than others, I am apt to regard as illiterate and ill-bred.
The person who is contented to be often obliged ought not to be obliged at all.
The person whose clothes are extremely fine I am too apt to consider as not being possessed of any superiority of fortune, but resembling those Indians who were found to wear all the gold they have in the world in a bob at the nose.
The pest of society is egotists. There are dull and bright, sacred and profane, coarse and fine egotists. It is a disease that, like influenza, falls on all constitutions.
The philosopher is he to whom the highest has descended, and the lowest has mounted up; who is the equal and kindly brother of all.
The philosopher must station himself in the
middle.
The philosophy of grumbling is great, but not intricate ... the proof that there is something wrong, and that a sentient human being is aware of it.
The philosophy of one century is the common-sense of the next.
The philosophy of six thousand years has not searched the chambers and magazines of the soul.
The phœnix, Hope, can wing her flight / Through the vast deserts of the skies, / And still defying fortune's spite, / Revive and from her ashes rise.
The pillow is a dumb sibyl.
The pilot of the Galilean lake; / Two massy keys he bore, of metals twain, / The golden opes, the iron shuts amain.
The pious and just honouring of ourselves may be thought the radical moisture and fountain-head from whence every laudable and worthy enterprise issues forth.
The pious have always a more intimate connection with each other than the wicked, though externally the relationship may not always prosper as well.
The pious-hearted are cared for by the gods; and by men honoured and worshipped as divinities, when once they have by death stripped off for ever their week-day garments.
The pitcher goes so often to the water that it
comes home broken at last.
The place once trodden by a good man is hallowed. After a hundred years his word and actions ring in the ears of his descendants.
The plainer the dress, with greater lustre does beauty appear.
The plainest man that can convince a woman that he is really in love with her, has done more to make her in love with him than the handsomest man, if he can produce no such conviction. For the love of woman is a shoot, not a seed, and flourishes most vigorously only when ingrafted on that love which is rooted in the breast of another.
The plea of ignorance will never take away our responsibilities.
The pleasure of despising, at all times and in itself a dangerous luxury, is much safer after the toil of examining than before it.
The pleasure of talking is the inextinguishable passion of woman, coeval with the act of breathing.
The pleasure-seeker is not the pleasure-finder;
those are the happiest men who think least about happiness.
The pleasure we feel in criticising robs us of that of being deeply moved by very beautiful things.
The pleasure we feel in music springs from the obedience which is in it, and it is full only as the obedience is entire.
The pleasure which strikes the soul must be derived from the beauty and congruity it sees or conceives in those things which the sight or imagination lay before it.
The pleasures of the world are deceitful; they promise more than they give. They trouble us in seeking them, they do not satisfy us when possessing them, and they make us despair in losing them.
The plenty of the poorest place is too great;
the harvest cannot be gathered.
The poet bestrides the clouds, the wise man looks up at them.
The poet can never have far to seek for a subject; for him the ideal world is not remote from the actual, but under it and within it; and he is a poet precisely because he can discern it there.
The poet must believe in his poetry. The fault of our popular poetry is that it is not sincere.
The poet must find all within himself while he is left in the lurch by all without.
The poet must live wholly for himself, wholly
in the objects that delight him.
The poet should seize the particular, and he should, if there is anything sound in it, thus represent the universal.
The poet's delicate ear hears the far-off whispers of eternity, which coarser souls must travel towards for scores of years before their dull sense is touched by them.
The poet's eye, in a fine frenzy rolling, / Doth glance from heaven to earth, from earth to heaven, / And, as imagination bodies forth / The forms of things unknown, the poet's pen / Turns them to shapes, and gives to airy nothing / A local habitation and a name.
The poet's heart is an unlighted torch, which gives no help to his footsteps till love has touched it with flame.
The poetry of the ancients was that of possession,
ours is that of aspiration; the former stands fast on the soil of the present, the latter hovers between memory and anticipation.
The point is not that men should have a great many books, but that they should have the right ones, and that they should use those that they have.
The pomp of death is far more terrible than death itself.
The poor are only they who feel poor.
The poor is hated even of his own neighbour.
The poor man's budget is full of schemes.
The poor wren, / The most diminutive of birds, will fight, / Her young ones in her nest, against the owl.
The poor ye have always with you, but me ye have not always.
The poorer life or the rich one are but the larger or smaller (very little smaller) letters in which we write the apophthegms and golden sayings of life.
The poorest day that passes over us is the conflux of two eternities; it is made-up of currents that issue from the remotest part, and flow onwards into the remotest future.
The poorest human soul is infinite in wishes,
and the infinite universe was not made for one, but for all.
The poorest man may in his cottage bid defiance to all the forces of the crown. It may be frail, the wind may blow through it, the storm may enter, the rain may enter, but the king of England cannot enter! all his force dares not cross the threshold of that ruined tenement.
The popular ear weighs what you are, not what you were.
The popular man stands on our own level, or a hairsbreadth higher; and shows us a truth we can see without shifting our present intellectual position. The original man stands above us, and wishes to wrench us from our old fixtures, and elevate us to a higher and clearer level.
The population of the world is a conditional population; not the best, but the best that could live now.
The post of honour is the post of difficulty,
the post of danger,--of death, if difficulty be not overcome.
The power of every great people, as of every living tree, depends on its not effacing, but confirming and concluding the labours of its ancestors.
The power of faith will often shine forth the most when the character is naturally weak.
The power of fortune is confessed only by the miserable, for the happy impute all their success to prudence and merit.
The power of observing life is rare, that of drawing lessons from it rarer, and that of condensing the lesson in a pointed sentence is rarest of all.
The power, whether of painter or poet, to describe
rightly what he calls an ideal thing depends upon its being to him not an ideal but a real thing. No man ever did or ever will work well, but either from actual sight or sight of faith.
The practice of faith and obedience to some of our fellow-creatures is the alphabet by which we learn the higher obedience to heaven; and it is not only needful to the prosperity of all noble united action, but essential to the happiness of all noble living spirits.
The practice of submission to the authority of one whom one recognises as greater than one's self outweighs the chance of occasional mistake.
The praise that comes of love does not make us vain, but humble rather.
The praying soul is a gainer by waiting for an answer.
The precepts of philosophy effect not the least
benefit to one confirmed in fear.
The preparations of the heart in man and the answer of the tongue is from the Lord.
The presence of the Eternal is a presence that articulates and imparts itself in time.
The presence of the wretched is a burden to the happy; and alas! the happy still more so to the wretched.
The present holds in it both the whole past and the whole future.
The present is the only reality and the only
certainty.
The present moment is a potent divinity.
The present moment is our ain, / The neist we never saw.
The present time is not priest-ridden, but press-ridden.
The present time, youngest born of eternity, child and heir of all the past times with their good and evil, and parent of all the future, is ever a new era to the thinking man.
The press beginneth to be an oppression of the
land.
The press is a mill which grinds all that is put into its hopper.
The press is the foe of rhetoric, but the friend of reason.
The price of wisdom is above rubies.
The priest loves his flock, but the lambs more than the wethers.
The primal condition of virtue is that it shall
not know of, or believe in, any blessed islands till it find them, it may be, in due time.
The primal duties shine aloft, like stars; / The charities that soothe, and heal, and bless, / Are scattered at the feet of man, like flowers.
The primary vocation of man is a life of activity.
The prince as actual ruler is always limited
by public opinion; but what is there to limit public opinion if it holds sovereign sway?
The principal part of faith is patience.
The principal point of greatness in any state
is to have a race of military men.
The prisoner is troubled that he cannot go whither he would, and he that is at large is troubled that he does not know whither to go.
The prisoner's allowance is bread and water, but I had only the latter.
The privilege of the country is to be alone, when we like.
The problem of life is to make the ideal real, and convert the divine at the summit of the mountain into the human at its base.
The problem of philosophy is, for all that exists
conditionally, to find a ground unconditioned and absolute.
The prodigal robs his heir, the miser robs himself.
The production of something, where nothing was before, is an act of greater energy than the expansion or decoration of the thing produced.
The profession of riches without their possession leads to the worst form of poverty.
The promise given was a necessity of the past; the word broken is a necessity of the present.
The Promised Land is the land where one is
not.
The promises of God are yea and amen.
The promises of this world are, for the most part, vain phantoms; and to confide in one's self, and become something of worth and value, is the best and safest course.
The promissory lies of great men are known by shouldering, hugging, squeezing, smiling, and bowing.
The proper confidant of a girl is her father. What she is not inclined to tell her father should be told to no one, and, in nine cases out of ten, not thought of by herself.
The proper Epic of this world is no longer
"Arms and the man," much less "Shirt frills and the man;" no, it is now "Tools and the man;" that, henceforth to all time is now our Epic.
The proper power of faith is to trust
evidence, not
The proper reward of the good workman is to be "chosen."
The proper study of mankind is man.
The proper task of literature lies in the domain of belief.
The property of a man consists in
things
 (_c
The prophet is the revealer of what we are to do; the poet, of what we are to love. The former too has an eye on what we are to love; how else shall he know what we are to do?
The prosperity of our neighbours in the end is our own, and the poverty of our neighbours becomes also in the end our own.
The protection of God cannot without sacrilege be invoked but in behalf of justice and right.
The proud man often is the mean.
The proudest boast of the most aspiring philosopher
is no more than that he provides his little playfellows the greatest pastime with the greatest innocence.
The proverb says of the Genoese, that they have a sea without fish, lands without trees, and men without faith.
The proverbs of a nation furnish the index to its spirit and the results of its civilisation.
The providence of God has established such an order in the world, that of all which belongs to us, the least valuable parts can alone fall under the will of others.
The prudence of the best of hearts is often defeated by the tenderness of the best of hearts.
The prudent man may direct a state, but it
is the enthusiast who regenerates or ruins it.
The prudent part is to propose remedies for the present evils, and provisions against future events.
The public have neither shame nor gratitude.
The public highways ought not to be occupied by people demonstrating that motion is impossible.
The public is a personality that knows everything and can do nothing.
The public is the majority of a society.
The public sense is in advance of private practice.
The public? The public is just a great baby.
The pulpit only "teaches" to be honest; the market-place "trains" to over-reaching and fraud; and teaching has not a tithe of the efficiency of training.
The punishment of criminals should be of use; when a man is hanged he is good for nothing.
The punishment which the wise suffer, who
refuse to take part in the government, is to live under the government of worse men.
The pure in heart shall see God.
The purer the golden vessel the more readily is it bent; the higher worth of women is sooner lost than that of men.
The purest treasure mortal times afford / Is spotless reputation; that away, / Men are but gilded loam or painted clay.
The purse is the master-organ, soul's seat, and true pineal gland of the body social.
The pyramids, doting with age, have forgotten
the names of their founders.
The quality of mercy is not strain'd; / It droppeth as the gentle rain from heaven / Upon the place beneath. It is twice blest; / It blesseth him that gives and him that takes. / 'Tis mightiest in the mightiest; it becomes / The throned monarch better than his crown.
The quantity of books in a library is often a cloud of witnesses of the ignorance of the owner.
The quantity of sorrow a man has, does it not mean withal the quantity of sympathy he has, the quantity of faculty and victory he shall have? Our sorrow is the inverted image of our nobleness.
The quarrel toucheth none but us alone, / Betwixt ourselves let us decide it then.
The question is not at what door of fortune's
palace shall we enter in, but what doors does she open to us?
The question is not who is the most learned, but who is the best.
The question is this: is man an ape or angel? I, my lord, I am on the side of the angels.
The question of education is for the modern world a question of life or death, a question on which depends the future.
The question of questions (for men and nations) is--not how far they are from heaven, but whether they are going to it. (So in art) it is not the wisdom or the barbarism that you have to estimate, not the skill or the rudeness, but the tendency.
The question of the purpose of things is completely
unscientific.
The race is not to the swift, nor the battle to the strong.
The race of mankind would perish did they cease to aid each other.
The rainbow in the morning / Is the shepherd's warning; / The rainbow at night / Is the shepherd's delight.
The rank is but the guinea's stamp, / The man's the gowd for a' that.
The ransom of a man's life are his riches.
The ray of light passes invisible through space, and only when it falls on an object is it seen.
The readiness is all.
The real man is one who always finds excuses for others, but never excuses himself.
The real men of genius were resolute workers, not idle dreamers.
The real Nimrod of this era, who alone does
any good to the era, is the rat-catcher.
The real object of education is to give children resources that will endure as long as life endures; habits that time will ameliorate, not destroy; occupation that will render sickness tolerable, solitude pleasant, age venerable, life more dignified and useful, and death less terrible.
The real object of the drama is the exhibition of human character.
The real science of political economy is that which teaches nations to desire and labour for the things that lead to life; and which teaches them to scorn and destroy the things that lead to destruction.
The really strong may bend, and be as strong as ever; it is the unsound that has only the seeming of strength, which breaks at last when it resists too long.
The reason that there is such a general outcry
against flatterers is, that there are so very few good ones.
The reason why borrowed books are so seldom returned to their owners is, that it is much easier to retain the books than what is in them.
The reason why so few marriages are happy is because young ladies spend their time in making nets, not in making cages.
The reason why the character of woman is so often misunderstood, is that it is the beautiful nature of woman to veil her soul as her charms.
The reason why we sometimes see that men of the greatest capacities are not rich, is either because they despise wealth in comparison of something else, or, at least, are not content to be getting an estate, unless they may do it in their own way, and at the same time enjoy all the pleasures and gratifications of life.
The recording angel, consider it well, is no fable, but the truest of truths; the paper tablets thou canst burn; of the "iron leaf" there is no burning.
The regeneration of society is the regeneration
of the individual by education.
The regions of eternal happiness are provided for those women who love their husbands the same in a wilderness as in a city; be he a saint, or be he sinner.
The relation of the taught to their teacher, of the loyal subject to his guiding king, is, under one shape or another, the vital element in human society.
The religion of Christ is peace and goodwill, that of Christendom war and ill-will.
The religion of Jesus, with all its self-denials, virtues, and devotions, is very practicable.
The religion of one age is the literary entertainment
of the next.
The religions of the world are the ejaculations of a few imaginative men.
The religions we call false were once true. They also were affirmations of the conscience correcting the evil customs of their times.
The religious passion is nearly always vividest where the art is weakest; and the technical skill only reaches its deliberate splendour when the ecstasy which gave it birth has passed away for ever.
The reputation of a man is like his shadow--gigantic when it precedes him, and pigmy in its proportions when it follows.
The reputation of a woman is as a crystal
mirror, shining and bright, but liable to be sullied by every breath that comes near it.
The reputation of virtuous actions past, if not kept up with an access and fresh supply of new ones, is lost and soon forgotten.
The resentment of a poor man is like the efforts of a harmless insect to sting; it may get him crushed, but cannot defend him.
The rest is silence.
The result
The revelation of thought takes man out of
servitude into freedom.
The reverence of a man's self is, next religion, the chiefest bridle of all vices.
The revolutionary outbreaks of the lower classes are the consequence of the injustice of the higher classes.
The reward of one duty is the power to fulfil another.
The rich and poor meet together: the Lord is the maker of them all.
The rich are always advising the poor; but
the poor seldom venture to return the compliment.
The rich are invited to marry by that fortune which they do not want, and the poor have no inducement but that beauty which they do not feel.
The rich becoming richer and the poor poorer, is the cry throughout the whole civilised world.
The rich devour the poor, the devil the rich, and so both are devoured.
The rich man does not feel his wealth with any vividness.
The rich man is seldom in his own halls, because
it bores him to be there, and still he returns thither, because he is no better off outside.
The rich man's wealth is his strong city, and as an high wall in his own conceit.
The rich ruleth over the poor, and the borrower is servant to the lender.
The richest minds need not large libraries.
The riddle of the age has for each a private solution.
The ridge once gained, the path so hard of
late / Runs easy on, and level with the gate
The right divine of kings to govern wrong.
The right ear, that is fill'd with dust, / Hears little of the false or just.
The right honourable gentleman is indebted to his memory for his jests, and to his imagination for his facts.
The right law of education is that you take the most pains with the best material. Never waste pains on bad ground, but spare no labour on the good, or on what has in it the capacity of good.
The right man in the right place.
The righteous hath hope in his death.
The righteous man falls oft, / Yet falls but soft; / There may be dirt to mire him, but no stones / To crush his bones.
The righteousness of the upright shall deliver them.
The "rights" of men in any form are not worth discussing; the grand point is the "mights" of men--what portion of their "rights" they have a chance of getting sorted out and realised in this confused world.
The riotous tumult of a laugh is the mob-law
of the features, and propriety the magistrate who reads the Riot Act.
The risings and sinkings of human affairs are like those of a ball which is thrown by the hand.
The river has its cataract, / And yet the waters down below / Soon gather from the foam, compact, / And, just like those above it, flow.
The river remains troubled that has not gone through a lake; the heart is impure that has not gone through a sorrow.
The road's afore you, the sky's aboon you.
The road to resolution lies by doubt.
The road to ruin is always kept in good repair, and the travellers pay the expense of it.
The road which runs without a bend / Is that
which hath a proper end.
The robb'd that smiles, steals something from the thief.
The romantic is the instinctive delight in, and admiration for, sublimity, beauty, and virtue, unusually manifested.
The root of almost every schism and heresy from which the Christian Church has suffered has been the effort of men to earn, rather than to receive, their salvation; and the reason that preaching is so commonly ineffectual is, that it calls on men oftener to work for God than to behold God working for them.
The root of sanctity is sanity. A man must be healthy before he can be holy. We bathe first, and then perfume.
The rough material of fine writing is certainly
the gift of genius; but I as firmly believe that the workmanship is the united effort of pains, attention, and repeated trial.
The rough seas that spare not any man.
The rude man requires only to see something going on. The man of more refinement must be made to feel. The man of complete refinement must be made to reflect.
The rule of the footway is clear as the light, / And none can its reason withstand; / On each side of the way you must keep to the right, / And leave those you meet the left hand.
The ruling passion, be it what it will, / The ruling passion, conquers reason still.
The running waves of eager life end on the
motionless fixed strand of death.
The Sabbath was made for man, and not man for the Sabbath.
The sacred wrestler, till a blessing given, / Quits not his hold, but, halting, conquers heaven.
The sacrifice of the wicked is abomination.
The saddest external condition of affairs among men, is but evidence of a still sadder internal one.
The safest and purest joys of human life rebuke
the violence of its passions; they are obtainable without anxiety and memorable without regret.
The safest words are always those which bring us most directly to facts.
The safety-valves of the heart when too much pressure is laid on.
The salve of reformation they mightily call for, but where and what the sores are which need it, as they wot full little, so they think not greatly material to search.
The same motions and muscles of the face are employed both in laughing and crying.
The Satanic school.
"The savans and the asses in the middle."
The scholar without good-breeding is a pedant; the philosopher, a cynic; the soldier, a brute; and every man disagreeable.
The schoolboy counts the time till the return of the holidays; the minor longs to be of age; the lover is impatient till he is married.
The schoolmaster is abroad.
The sea belongs to eternity, and not time,
and of that it sings its monotonous song for ever and ever.
The sea complains upon a thousand shores.
The sea does not contain all the pearls, the earth does not enclose all the treasures, and the flint-stone does not enclose all the diamonds, since the head of man encloses wisdom.
The sea moans over dead men's bones.
The sea that bares her bosom to the moon.
The sea tosses and foams to find its way up to
the cloud and wind.
The seal of truth is simplicity.
The seat of knowledge is in the head; of wisdom, in the heart. We are sure to judge wrong if we do not feel aright.
The seat of law is the bosom of God; her voice, the harmony of the world.
The second fruit of friendship is healthful and sovereign for the understanding, as the first is for the affections; for friendship maketh indeed a fair day in the affections from storm and tempests, but it maketh daylight in the understanding out of darkness and confusion of thoughts.
The secret of education lies in respecting the
pupil.
The secret of happiness is never to allow your energies to stagnate.
The secret of language is the secret of sympathy, and its full charm is possible only to the gentle.
The secret of making one's self tiresome is not to know when to stop.
The secret of man's being is still like the Sphinx's secret; a riddle that he cannot rede; and for ignorance of which he suffers death, the worst death--a spiritual.
The secret of man's nature lies in his religion,
in what he really believes about the world and his own place in it.
The secret of man's success resides in his insight into the moods of men, and his tact in dealing with them.
The secret of our existence is the connection between our sins and our sufferings.
The secret of success in society is a certain heartiness and sympathy.
The secret of success is constancy to purpose.
The secret of tiring is to say everything that can be said on the subject.
The secret things belong unto the Lord.
The secrets of great folk are just like the wild beasts that are shut up in cages. Keep them hard and fast snecked up, and it's a' very weel or better--but ance let them out, they will turn and rend you.
The secrets of life are not shown except to sympathy and likeness.
The seed of knowledge ripens but slowly in the
mind, but the flowers grow quickly.
The seeds of things are very small.

The seers are wholly a greater race than the practical purpose in his thinking, and is sincere, as Plato, or Carlyle, or Helps, becomes in some sort a seer, and must be always of infinite use in his generation.
The self-same sun that shines upon his court / Hides not his visage from our cottage, but / Looks on alike.
The sense of beauty never furthered the performance of a single duty.
The sense of death is most in apprehension, /
And the poor beetle that we tread upon / In corporal sufferance finds a pang as great / As when a giant dies.
The sense of human dignity was the chief moral agent of antiquity, and the sense of sin of mediævalism.
The sense of the infinite nature of Duty is the central part of all with us; a ray as of Eternity and Immortality, immured in dusky many-coloured Time, and its births and deaths.
The senses do not deceive us, but the judgment does.
The sentimental by and by will have to give place to the practical.
The serenity that is not felt, it can be no
virtue to feign.
The seven wise men of Greece, so famous for their wisdom all the world over, acquired all that fame each of them by a single sentence consisting of two or three words.
The "seventeenth" century is worthless to us except precisely in so far as it can be made the "nineteenth."
The severe and restrictive virtues are almost too costly for humanity.
The severity of laws impedes their execution.
The shadowed livery of the burnished sun.
The sheep slips and is up again; the sow lies down and wallows.
The shepherd in Virgil grew at last acquainted with Love, and found him a native of the rocks.
The ship that carries most sail is most buffeted by the winds and storms.
The short and simple annals of the poor.
The shorter life, less count I find, / The less
account the sooner made, / The account soon made, the merrier mind, / The merrier mind doth thought evade.
The shortest and the surest way to prove a work possible is strenuously to set about it; and no wonder if that proves it possible that for the most part makes it so.
The shortest answer is doing.
The shortest way to do many things is to do only one thing at once.
The showy lives its little hour; the true / To after times bears rapture ever new.
The shrine is that which thou dost venerate, /
And not the beast that bears it on his back.
The sight of you is good for sore eyes.
The sign of health is unconsciousness.
The sign of the poet is that he announces what no man foretold.
The significance of life is doing something.
The signs of the times.
The silence often of pure innocence / Persuades when speaking fails.
The silence that is in the starry sky.
The silent heavens have goings-on; / The stars have tasks.
The simple believeth every word.
The sin that practice burns into the blood, /
And not the one dark hour which brings remorse, / Will brand us, after, of whose fold we be.
The single snowflake--who cares for it? But a whole day of snowflakes ... who does not care for that? Private opinion is weak, but public opinion is almost omnipotent.
The slack sail shifts from side to side, / The boat, untrimm'd, admits the tide, / Borne down, adrift, at random tost, / The oar breaks short, the rudder's lost.
The sleep of a labouring man is sweet, whether he eat little or much: but the abundance of the rich will not suffer him to sleep.
The sleeping and the dead / Are but as pictures.
The slender vine twists around the sturdy
oak, for no other reason in the world but because it has not strength sufficient to support itself.
The slight that can be conveyed in a glance, in a gracious smile, in a wave of the hand, is often the "ne plus ultra" of art. What insult is so keen, or so keenly felt, as the polite insult which it is impossible to resent?

The slow wheel turns, / The cycles round themselves and grow complete, / The world's year whitens to the harvest-tide, / And one all things living, and the word is "Love."
The sluggard is wiser in his own conceit than seven men that can render a reason.
The sly shadow steals away upon the dial, and the quickest eye can discover no more but that it is gone.
The small courtesies sweeten life; the greater
ennoble it.
The smallest annoyances disturb us most.
The smallest bird cannot light upon the greatest tree without sending a shock to its most distant fibre.
The smallest worm will turn, being trodden on; / And doves will peck, in safeguard of their brood.
The smoke of a man's own house is better than the fire of another's.
The snail sees nothing but his own shell, and thinks it the grandest place in the world.
The social, friendly, honest man, / Whate'er he be, / 'Tis he fulfils great Nature's plan, / And none but he.
The society of women is the element of good
manners.
The soldier's trade, verily and essentially, is not slaying, but being slain ... and the reason the world honours the soldier is because he holds his life at the service of the state.
The soldier's ultimate and perennial office is to punish knaves and make idle persons work; the defence of his country against other countries, which is his office at present, will soon now be extinct.
The sole terms on which the past can become ours are its subordination to the present.
The Son of man came not to be ministered unto, but to minister, and to give his life a ransom for many.
The song that we hear with our ears is only
the song that is sung with our hearts.
The sorest tempest has the most sudden calm.
The sorrow of Yesterday is as nothing; that of To-day is bearable; but that of To-morrow is gigantic, because indistinct.
The sorrowfulest of fates is to have liberty without deserving it.
The soul is like the sun, which, to our eyes, seems to set in night; but it has in reality only gone to diffuse its light elsewhere.
The soul is not where it lives, but where it
loves.
The soul knows no persons.
The soul may be trusted to the end.
The soul moralises the past in order not to be demoralised by it, and finds in the crucible of experience only the gold that she herself has poured into it.
The soul of a man can by no agency, of men or of devils, be lost and ruined but by his own only.
The soul of man is a mirror of the mind of God.
The soul reveals itself in the voice only.... It is audible, not visible.
The soul shut up in her dark room, / Viewing so clear abroad, at home sees nothing; / But, like a mole in earth, busy and blind, / Works all her folly up, and casts it outward / To the world's open view.
The soul, / The particle of God sent down to man, / Which doth in turn reveal the world and God.
The soul, / Though made in time, survives for aye; / And, though it hath beginning, sees no end.
The soul's armour is never well set to the
heart unless a woman's hand has braced it.
The soul's dark cottage, battered and decayed, / Lets in new light through chinks that time has made.
The soul's emphasis is always right.
The sound of a kiss is not so loud as that of a cannon, but its echo lasts a deal longer.
The sphere-harmony of a Shakespeare, of a Goethe, the cathedral music of a Milton, the humble, genuine lark-notes of a Burns.
The spider taketh hold with her hands, and is
in kings' palaces.
The spirit breatheth where it willeth, and thou hearest the voice thereof, but canst not tell whence it cometh, and whither it goeth: so is it with every one that is born of the spirit.
The spirit in which we act is the highest matter.
The spirit indeed is willing, but the flesh is weak.
The spirit is higher than nature.
The spirit of a man will sustain his infirmity;
but a wounded spirit who can bear?
The spirit of moderation should be the spirit of a lawgiver.
The spirit of poesy is the morning light, which makes the statue of Memnon sound.
The spirit only can teach.

The spirit was long ago liberated from the blind law of nature, and the task it is called to now is to unfold itself with freedom and now at length conscious of itself.
The spiritual artist too is born blind, and does
not, like certain other creatures, receive sight in nine days, but far later--perhaps never.
The spiritual is ever the inner in a man becoming outer, the invisible becoming visible, the supernatural becoming natural, the infinite becoming finite, and the eternal veiling itself in the guise of time; never an emancipation from the flesh, but ever an incarnation in flesh.
The spiritual is higher than the external; the spiritual cannot be externally authenticated.
The spiritual is the parent and first cause of the practical.
The spiritual man is free to rule his world, not his world to rule him.
The spiritual problem which Christ resolved
was pretty much this--the derivation of that from within man which was conceived to be above man, by the reperception of the forgotten truth that it was in His own image God made man. He first opened up the well within.
The spiritual universe is no more to be made out of a man's own head than the material universe or the moral universe.... No belief of ours will change the facts or reverse the laws of the spiritual universe.
The spiritual will always body itself forth in the temporal history of men; the spiritual is the beginning of the temporal, always determines the material.
The spiritual world is not closed; it is thy sense that is: thy heart is dead.
The spring can be apprehended only while it is flowing.
The springing of a serpent is from the sun; the wisdom of the serpent, whence is that?
The stars do not come to tell us it is night,
but to lay beams of light through it, and give the eye a path to walk in.
The stars shall fade away, the sun himself / Grow dim with age, and Nature sink in years; / But thou shalt flourish in immortal youth, / Unhurt amidst the war of elements, / The wrecks of matter and the crash of worlds.
The stars themselves are only bright by distance; go close, and all is earthy; but vapours illuminate there; from the breath and from the countenance of God comes light on worlds higher than they.
The "State in danger" is a condition of things which we have witnessed a hundred times; and as for the Church, it has seldom been out of "danger" since we can remember it.
The State must follow, and not lead, the character and progress of the citizen.
The statesman wishes to steer, while the politician
is satisfied to drift.
The steps of faith fall on the seeming void, and find the rock beneath.
The still, sad music of humanity.
The Stoic thought by slandering Happiness to woo her; by shunning to win her; and proudly presumed that, by fleeing her, she would turn and follow him.
The Stoic was a proud man, and not a humble, and he was content if he could only have his own soul for a prey. He did not see that the salvation of one man is impossible except in the salvation of other men, and that no man can save another unless he descend into that other's case, and be, as it were, in that other's stead.
The stoical exemption which philosophy affects
to give us over the pains and vexations of human life is as imaginary as the state of mystical quietism and perfection aimed at by some crazy enthusiast.
The stoical scheme of supplying our wants by lopping off our desires is like cutting off our feet when we want shoes.
The stomach has no ears.
The stone that lieth not in your way need not offend you.
The stone which the builders refused has become the head of the corner.
The storm of sad mischance will turn into
something that is good, if we list to make it so.
The stranger who turneth away from a house with disappointed hopes leaveth there his own offences, and departeth, taking with him all the good actions of the owner.
The stranger's greeting thou shouldst aye return!
The strawberry grows under the nettle, / And wholesome berries thrive and ripen best / Neighbour'd by fruit of baser quality.
The stream can never rise above the spring-head.
The street is full of humiliations to the proud.
The strength and power of a country depends absolutely on the quantity of good men and women in it.
The strength of aquatic animals is the waters; of those who dwell in towns, a castle; of footsoldiers, their own ground; of princes, an obedient army.
The string o'erstretched breaks, and the music flies; / The string o'erslack is dumb, and music dies; / Tune us the sitar neither low nor high.
The string that jars / When rudely touch'd, ungrateful to the sense, / With pleasure feels the master's flying fingers, / Swells into harmony and charms the hearers.
The stroke that comes transmitted through
a whole galaxy of elastic balls, is it less a stroke than if the last ball only had been struck and sent flying?
The strokes of the pen need deliberation as much as those of the sword need swiftness.
The strong man is the wise man; the man with the gift of method, of faithfulness, of valour; who has insight into what is what, into what will follow out of what, the eye to see and the hand to do.
The strong mind is nowise the mind acquainted with its strength.
The strong must build stout cabins for the weak; / Must plan and stint; must sow and reap and store; / For grain takes root though all seems bare and bleak.
_The strong thing is the just thing: this thou_                       35 
_The strong thing is the just thing: this thou_                       35  was God and Truth the maker of it, or was Satan and Falsehood?
The strong torrents, which in their own gladness fill the hills with hollow thunder and the vales with winding light, have yet their bounden charge of field to feed and barge to bear.
The strongest arm is impotent to impart momentum to a feather.
The strongest castle, tower, and town, / The golden bullet beats it down.
The strongest oaths are straw / To the fire i' the blood.
The student is to read history actively and
not passively; to esteem his own life the text, and books the commentary. Thus compelled, the muse of history will utter oracles as never to those who do not respect themselves.
The study of books is a languishing and feeble motion that hearts not, whereas conversation teaches and exercises at once.
The stumbler stumbles least in rugged way.
The style of an author is a faithful copy of his mind. If you would write a lucid style, let there first be light in your own mind; and if you would write a grand style, you ought to have a grand character.
The style of letters should not be too highly polished. It ought to be neat and correct, but no more.
The style of writing required in the great world is distinguished by a free and daring grace, a careless security, a fine and sharp polish, a delicate and perfect taste; while that fitted for the people is characterised by a vigorous natural fulness, a profound depth of feeling, and an engaging naïveté.
The sublime is in a grain of dust.
The sublime is the temple-step of religion, as
the stars are of immeasurable space. When what is mighty appears in nature--a storm, thunder, the starry firmament, death--then utter the word "God" before the child. A great misfortune, a great blessing, a great crime, a noble action, are building-sites for a child's church.
The sublime produces a beautiful calmness in the soul which, entirely possessed by it, feels as great as it ever can feel. When we compare such a feeling with that we are sensible of when we laboriously harass ourselves with some trifle, and strain every nerve to gain as much as possible for it, as it were, to patch it out, striving to furnish joy and aliment to the mind from its own creation, we then feel sensibly what a poor expedient, after all, the latter is.
The sublime, when it is introduced at a seasonable moment, has often carried all before it with the rapidity of lightning, and shown at a glance the mighty power of genius.
The sublimest canticle to be heard on earth is the stammering of the human soul on the lips of infancy.
The sublimity of wisdom is to do those things living which are to be desired when dying.
The substance of a diligent man is precious.
The substance of a man is full good when sin is not in a man's conscience.
The substantial wealth of a man consists in the earth he cultivates with its plants and animals, and in the rightly produced works of his own hands.
The success of many works is found in the relation between the mediocrity of the author's ideas and that of the ideas of the public.
The suffering man ought really "to consume his own smoke;" there is no good in emitting smoke till you have made it into fire.
The sufficiency of my merit is to know that my
merit is not sufficient.
The sun can be seen by nothing but its own light.
The sun flings out impurities, gets balefully incrusted with spots; but it does not quench itself, and become no sun at all, but a mass of darkness.
The sun! God's crest upon his azure shield, the heavens.
The sun is God.
The sun may do its duty, though your grapes
are not ripe.
The sun passeth through pollutions, and itself remains as pure as before.
The sun-steeds of time, as if goaded by invisible spirits, bear onward the light car of our destiny, and nothing remains for us but, with calm self-possession, to grasp the reins, and now right, now left, to steer the wheels, here from the precipice, and there from the rock. Whither he is hasting, who knows? Does any one consider whence he came?
The sun's power cannot draw a wandering star from its path. How then could a human being fall out of God's love!
The sunshine of life is made up of very little beams, that are bright all the time.
The superstition in which we have grown up
does not lose its hold over us even when we recognise it for such. Those who scoff at their fetters are not all free men.
The sure way to miss success is to miss the opportunity.
The surest sign of age is loneliness.
The surest test of a man's critical power is his judgment of contemporaries.
The surest way not to fail is to determine to succeed.
The surest way to have redress is to be earnest
in pursuit of it.
The surgeon practises on the orphan's head.
The sweetest music is not in the oratorio, but in the human voice when it speaks from its instant life tones of tenderness, truth, or courage.
The sweetest wine makes the sharpest vinegar.
The sweetness of the lips increaseth learning.
The sweets of love are washed with tears.
The sword is but a hideous flash in the darkness; right is an eternal ray.
The sympathy of sorrow is stronger than the sympathy of prosperity.
The system of the world is entirely one; small things and great are alike part of one mighty whole.
The tabernacle of the upright shall flourish.
The tallest trees are most in the power of the
winds, and ambitious men of the blasts of fortune.
The tanager flies through the green foliage as if he would ignite the leaves.
The teaching of art is the teaching of all things.
The teachings of Heaven are given--by sad law--in so obscure, nay, often in so ironical a manner, that a blockhead necessarily reads them wrong.
The tear of joy is a pearl of the first water; the mourning tear, only of the second.
The tears of penitents are the wine of angels.
The tell-tale out of school is of all wits the greatest fool.
The temper of the pedagogue suits not with the age; and the world, however it may be taught, will not be tutored.
The temperate man's pleasures are durable, because they are regular; and all his life is calm and serene, because it is innocent.
The tempest never rooteth up the grass, which is feeble, humble, and shooteth not up on high; but exerteth its power even to distress the lofty trees; for the great use not their might but upon the great.
The temple of our purest thoughts is--silence!
The tendency of laws should be rather to diminish the amount of evil than to produce an amount of happiness.
The tendency of party-spirit has ever been to disguise and propagate and support error.
The tender flower that lifts its head, elate, / Helpless must fall before the blasts of fate, / Sunk on the earth, defaced its lovely form, / Unless your shelter ward th' impending storm.
The tender heart o' leesome luve / The gowd and siller canna buy.
The tender mercies of the wicked are cruel.
The term of man's life is half wasted before he has done with his mistakes and begins to profit by his lessons.
The test of civilisation is the estimate of woman.
The test or measure of poetic genius is to read the poetry of affairs, to fuse the circumstance of to-day.
The theatre has often been at variance with the pulpit; they ought not to quarrel. How much is it to be wished that in both the celebration of nature and of God were intrusted to none but men of noble minds!
The There is never Here.
The thin edge of the wedge is to be feared.
The thing a lie wants, and solicits from all men, is not a correct natural history of it, but the swiftest possible extinction of it, followed by entire silence about it.
The thing done avails, and not what is said about it.
The thing men get to believe is the thing they will infallibly do.
The thing that hath been, it is that which
shall be; and that which is done is that which shall be done.
The thing that is, what can be so wonderful? what, especially to us that are, can have such significance?
The thing that matters most, both for happiness and for duty, is that we should strive habitually to live with wise thoughts and right feelings.
The thing to be anxious about is not to be right with man, but with mankind.
The thing visible, nay, the thing imagined, the thing in any way conceived of as visible, what is it but a garment, a clothing of the higher, celestial invisible, "unimaginable, formless, dark with excess of bright"?
The thing which is deepest rooted in Nature,
what we call truest, that, and not the other, will be found growing at last.
The things that destroy us are injustice, insolence, and foolish thoughts; and the things which save us are justice, self-command, and true thought, which things dwell in the loving powers of the gods.
The things that threatened me, / Ne'er look'd but on my back; when they shall see / The face of Cæsar, they are vanished.
The thinker requires exactly the same light as the painter, clear, without direct sunshine, or blinding reflection, and, where possible, from above.
The thinking minds of all nations call for change. There is a deep-lying struggle in the whole fabric of society; a boundless, grinding collision of the new with the old.
The third pays for all.
The thirst for truth still remains with us, even when we have wilfully left the fountains of it.
The thorny point / Of bare distress hath ta'en from me the show / Of smooth civility.
The thought is always prior to the fact; all the facts of history pre-exist in the mind as laws.
The thought is parent of the deed.
The thought of foolishness is sin.
The thoughts of the diligent tend only to plenteousness; but of every one that is hasty only to want.
The thoughts of the wicked are an abomination to the Lord.
The thoughts of youth are long, long thoughts.
The thoughts we have had, the pictures we have seen, can be again called back before the mind's eye and before the imagination; but the heart is not so obliging; it does not reproduce its pleasing emotions.
The thrall in person may be free in soul.
The throne is established by righteousness.
The time for words has passed, and deeds alone suffice.
The time has been / That when the brains were out the man should die, / And there an end.
The time is out of joint; O cursèd spite, / That ever I was born to set it right.
The time of breeding is the time of doing
children good; and not as many who think they have done fairly if they leave them a good portion after their decease.
The time that bears no fruit deserves no name.
The Times are the masquerade of the Eternities; trivial to the dull, tokens of noble and majestic agents to the wise.
The timid are in fear before danger, the cowardly in danger, and the courageous after danger.
The timing of things is a main point in the dispatch of all affairs.
The tired ocean crawls along the beach sobbing a wordless sorrow to the moon.
The toil of life alone teaches us to value the blessings of life.
The tomb is the pedestal of greatness.
The tongue can no man tame; it is an unruly
evil, full of deadly poison.
The tongue ever turns to the aching tooth.
The tongue is not of steel, but it cuts.
The tongue is the worst part of a bad servant.
The tongue of the just is as choice silver.
The tongue tells the thought of one man only,
whereas the face expresses a thought of nature itself; so that every one is worth attentive observation, even though every one may not be worth talking to.
The tongue's aye quick at saying "Na," / Though a' the while the heart be dumb.
The tongues of dying men / Enforce attention like deep harmony.
The too good opinion man has of himself is the nursing-mother of all false opinions, both public and private.
The torments of martyrdoms are probably most keenly felt by the bystanders.
The total loss of reason is less deplorable than
the total depravation of it.
The training
dispositions and the morals, is the only education that deserves the name.
The trappings of a monarchy would set up an ordinary commonwealth.
The traveller who goes round the world prepares himself to pass through all latitudes and to meet all changes.
The traveller without observation is a bird without wings.
The treasures of heaven are not negations of
passion but realities of intellect, from which all passions emanate, uncurbed in their eternal glory.
The tree doth not withdraw its shade, even from the woodcutter.
The tree Igdrasil, which reaches up to heaven, goes down to the kingdom of hell; and God, the Everlasting Good and Just, is in it all.
The tree is no sooner down than every one runs for his hatchet.
The tree of knowledge is grafted upon the tree of life; and that fruit which brought the fear of death into the world, budding on an immortal stock, becomes the fruit of the promise of immortality.
The tree of knowledge is not that of life.
The tree of liberty only grows when watered by the blood of tyrants.
The tree of silence bears the fruit of peace.
The tree which yieldeth both fruit and shade is highly to be esteemed: but if Providence, perchance, may have denied it fruit, by whom is its shade refused?
The trenchant blade, Toledo trusty, / For want of fighting was grown rusty, / And ate into itself, for lack / Of somebody to hew and hack.
The trident of Neptune is the sceptre of the
planet.
The triumphs of delusion are but for a day.
The trivial round, the common task, / Will furnish all we ought to ask. / Room to deny ourselves, a road / To bring us daily nearer God.
The true and the good will be reconciled when the two are wedded to each other in the beautiful.
The true art of being agreeable is to appear well pleased with all the company, and rather to seem well entertained with them than to bring entertainment to them.
The true beginning is oftenest unnoticed and
unnoticeable.
The true "compulsory education" now needed is not catechism, but drill.
The true cross of the Redeemer is the sin and sorrow of the world.
The true end of tragedy is to purify the passions.
The true epic of our times is, not arms and the man, but tools and the man--an infinitely wider kind of epic.
The true eye for talent presupposes the true
reverence for it.
The true fire of heaven always comes from heaven direct.
The true function of intellect is not that of talking, but of understanding and discerning with a view to performing.
The true God's voice, voice of the Eternal, is in the heart of every man.
The true good
world, not to speak of any that is to come, must be bought still, as it always has been, with our toil and with our tears. That is the final doctrine, the inevitable one, not of Christianity only, but of all heroic faith and heroic being.
The true harvest of my daily life is somewhat
as intangible and indescribable as the tints of morning or evening. It is a little stardust caught, a segment of the rainbow which I have clutched.
The true historical genius, to our thinking, is that which can see the nobler meaning of the events that are near him.
The true labourer is worthy of his hire, but, in the beginning and first choice of industry, his heart must not be the heart of an hireling.
The true ladder of heaven has no steps.
The true liberty of a man consists in his finding out, or being forced to find out, the right path, and to walk therein.
The true life of man is in society.
The true life of man, like God's, lies in the ungrudging imparting of himself to alike the worthy and unworthy without fear of forfeiture or claim of reward.
The true literary man is the light of the world; the world's priest guiding it, like a sacred pillar of fire, in its dark pilgrimage through the waste of time.
The true mind of a nation, at any period, is always best ascertainable by examining that of its greatest men.
The true original ground of all disquiet is within.
The true philosophical act is annihilation of self; this is the real beginning of all philosophy; all requisites for being a disciple of philosophy point hither.
The true poet is even more than a finder or troubadour; he is a seer, a prophet, and an interpreter between the divine and the human.
The true poet, who is but the inspired thinker,
is still an Orpheus whose lyre tames the savage beasts, and evokes the dead rocks to fashion themselves into palaces and stately inhabited cities.
The true poetic soul needs but to be struck, and the sounds it yields will be music.
The true preacher can be known by this, that he deals out to the people his life--life passed through the fire of thought.
The true scholar learns from the known to unfold the unknown, and approaches more and more to being a master.
The true Shekinah is man.
The true strength of every human soul is to
be dependent on as many nobler as it can discern, and to be depended upon by as many inferior as it can reach.
The true, strong, and sound mind is the mind that can embrace equally great things and small.

The True that is identical with the Divine can never be directly known by us; we behold in symbol, in individual and related phenomena; we perceive it as incomprehensible life, which yet we cannot renounce the wish to comprehend. This is true of all the phenomena of the conceivable world.
The true university of these days is a collection of books.
The true value of a man's book is determined by what he does not write.
The true veins of wealth are purple--not in
rock, but in flesh
and consummation of all wealth is in producing as many as possible full-breathed, bright-eyed, and happy-hearted human creatures.
The true way of softening one's troubles is to solace those of others.
The truly strong mind, view it as intellect or morality, or under any other aspect, is nowise the mind acquainted with its strength.
The truly sublime is always easy, and always natural.
The truly wise man should have no keeper of his secrets but himself.
The truth shall make you free.
The truth we need is only lightly veiled, not deeply buried by the wise hand which has designed it for us.
The truth works sometimes from without as from within.
The truths of Nature are one eternal change, one infinite variety.
The two best rules for a system of rhetoric are: first, have something to say; and next, say it.
The two foes of human happiness are pain and
ennui.
The two great movers of the human mind are the desire of good and the fear of evil.
The two most beautiful things in the universe are the starry heavens above us and the feeling of duty within us.
The two most engaging powers of an author are to make new things familiar and familiar things new.
The two sources of all quack-talent are cunning and impudence.
The ultimate rule
as possible to be intelligible and transparent--no notice taken of your style, but solely of what you express by it.
The ultimate tendency of civilisation is towards barbarism.
The unconscious is the alone complete.
The Understanding is indeed thy window, too clear thou canst not make it; but Fantasy is thy eye, with its colour-giving retina, healthy or diseased.
The undiscovered country, from whose bourn / No traveller returns.
The unfortunate are loud and loquacious
in their complaints, but real happiness is content with its own silent enjoyment.
The unhappy
wrong in being so, wrong in saying so, wrong in needing help of others, wrong in not being able to help them.
The unimaginative person can neither be reverent nor kind.
The universe has three children, born at one time ... called cause, operation, and effect, or, theologically, the Father, the Spirit, and the Son. These three are equal ... and each has the power of the others latent in him.
The universe is a thought of God.
The universe is an infinite sphere, the centre
of which is everywhere, and the circumference nowhere.
The universe is but one vast symbol of God; nay, if thou wilt have it, what is man himself but a symbol of God; is not all that he does symbolical; a revelation to sense of the mystic god-given force that is in him; a "gospel of freedom," which he, the "Messias of Nature," preaches, as he can, by act and word?
The universe is full of love, but also of inexorable sternness and severity.
The universe is not dead and demoniacal, a charnel-house with spectres, but godlike, and my Father's.
The universe is one great city, full of beloved ones, human and divine, by nature endeared to each other.
The universe is that great egoist that decoys
us by the grossest bird-calls.
The universe is the realised thought of God.
The universe stands by him who stands by himself.
The universe would not be rich enough to buy the vote of an honest man.
The unlearned man knoweth not what it is to descend into himself and call himself to account; nor the pleasure of that most pleasant life which consists in our daily feeling ourselves become better.
The unlettered peasant, whose views are only directed to the narrow sphere around him, beholds Nature with a finer relish, and tastes her blessings with a keener appetite, than the philosopher whose mind attempts to grasp a universal system.
The unpastured sea hungering for calm.
The unworn spirit is strong; life is so healthful that it even finds nourishment in death.
The upper classes and people of wealth suffer most from ennui.
The Upper Crust
The Upper Ten
The upper current of society presents no certain
criterion by which we can judge of the direction in which the under-current flows.
The upright shall dwell in the land, and the perfect shall remain in it.
The ups and downs of the world concern the beggar no longer.
The use of knowledge in our sex, besides the amusement of solitude, is to moderate the passions, and learn to be contented with a small expense, which are the certain effects of a studious life; and it may be preferable to that fame which men have engrossed to themselves, and will not suffer us to share.
The use of travelling is to regulate imagination by reality, and instead of thinking how things may be, to see them as they are.
