The useful encourages itself, for the multitude
produce it, and no one can dispense with it; but the beautiful must be encouraged, for few can set it forth, and many need it.
The useless men are those who never change with the years.
The usurer is the greatest Sabbath-breaker, because his plough goeth every Sunday.
The utmost point and acme of honour is not merely in doing no evil, but in thinking none.
The uttered part of a man's life bears to the unuttered, unconscious part of it a small unknown proportion; he himself never knows it, much less do others.
The valiant in himself, what can he suffer? /
Or what need he regard his single woes?
The valour of a just man is to conquer the flesh, to contradict his own will, ... to contemn the flatteries of prosperity, and inwardly to overcome the fears of adversity.
The valour that struggles is better than the weakness that endures.
The value of a man, as of a horse, consists in your being able to bridle him, or, what is better, in his being able to bridle himself.
The value of a thing is its life-giving power.
The vanity of loving fine clothes and new
fashions, and valuing ourselves by them, is one of the most childish pieces of folly that can be.
The veneration we have for many things entirely proceeds from their being carefully concealed.
The very head and front of my offending / Hath this extent, no more.
The very joy of a true man's heart is to admire, when he can; nothing so lifts him from all his mean imprisonments, were it but for moments, as true admiration.
The very meanest things are made supreme / With innate ecstasy.
The very nature of the dilettanti is that they
have no idea of the difficulties which lie in a subject, and always wish to undertake something for which they have no capacity.
The very pain of loving is all other joys before.
The very society of joy redoubles it, so that, whilst it lights upon my friend, it rebounds upon myself, and the brighter his candle burns the more easily will it light mine.
The vessel that will not obey her helm will have to obey the rocks.
The vice of our housekeeping is that it does not hold man sacred.
The vices we scoff at in others laugh at us
within ourselves.
The victories of character are instant, and victories for all.
"The victory of Miltiades does not suffer me to sleep."
The violets and the mayflowers are as the inscriptions or vignettes of spring. It always makes a pleasant impression on us when we open again at these pages of the book of life, its most charming chapter.
The virtue of great souls is justice
The virtue of justice consists in moderation,
as regulated by wisdom.
The virtue of man is, in a word, the great proof of God.
The virtue of prosperity is temperance; the virtue of adversity is fortitude; which in morals is the more heroical virtue.
The virtue of sex is the occasion of mutual teaching; the woman preaching love in the ears of justice, and the man justice in the ears of love.
The virtue of the man who lives according to the precepts of reason shows itself equally great in avoiding as in overcoming dangers.
The virtuous delight in the virtuous; but he who is destitute of the practice of virtue delighteth not in the virtuous. The bee retireth from the forest to the lotus, whilst the frog is destitute of shelter.
The virtuous man, from his justice and the affection he hath for mankind, is the dispeller of sorrow and pain.
The virtuous soul is pure and unmixed light, springing from the body as a flash of lightning darts from the cloud; the soul that is carnal and immersed in sense, like a heavy and dank vapour, can with difficulty be kindled, and caused to raise its eyes heavenward.
The visible creation is the terminus or the circumference of the invisible world.
The vitality of man is great.
The voice of conscience is so delicate that it is easy to stifle it; but it is also so clear that it is impossible to mistake it.
The voice of prophecies is like that of whispering-places; they who are near hear nothing, those at the first extremity will know all.
The voice of the majority is no proof of justice.
The voice of the people ought always to meet with attention, though it does not always claim obedience.
The vulgar estimate themselves by what they
do; the noble by what they are.
The vulgar great are comprehended and adored, because they are in reality on the same moral plane with those who admire; but he who deserves the higher reverence must himself convert the worshipper.
The vulgar keep no account of your hits, but of your misses.
The wail of grief is more sympathetic than the shout of triumph.
The walking of man and all animals is a falling forward.
The want of belief is a defect which ought to
be concealed when it cannot be overcome.
The want of occupation is no less the plague of society than of solitude.
The want of perception is a defect which all the virtues of the heart cannot supply.
The warl'ly race may riches chase, / And riches still may flee them; / And though at last they catch them fast, / Their hearts can ne'er enjoy them.
The watchful mother tarries nigh, / Though sleep has clos'd her infant's eye.
The way in which we form our ideas gives
character to our minds.
The way of the superior man is threefold--virtuous, he is free from anxieties; wise, he is free from perplexities; bold, he is free from fear.
The way of the wicked is an abomination unto the Lord.
The way of the world is to make laws, but follow customs.
The way of this world is to praise dead saints and persecute living ones.
The way to avoid evil is not by maiming our
passions, but by compelling them to yield their vigour to our moral nature.
The way to avoid the imputation of impudence is not to be ashamed of what we do, but never to do what we ought to be ashamed of.
The way to be original is to be healthy.
The way to get rid of wretchedness is to despise it; to conquer the devil is to defy him; to gain heaven is to turn your back upon it, and be as unflinching as the gods themselves. Satan may be roasted in his own flames; Tophet may be exploded with its own sulphur.
The way to heaven is set with briars and thorns; and they who arrive at the kingdom travel over craggy rocks and comfortless deserts.
The way to make thy son rich is to fill / His
mind with rest, before his trunk with riches.
The way to mend the bad world is to create the right world.
The way to wealth is as plain as the way to market; it depends chiefly on two words--industry and frugality.
The way to write quickly is to write well.
The way, truth, and life have been found in Christianity, and will not now be found outside of it.
The way's not easy where the prize is great.
The ways in which most men get their living, that is, live, are mere makeshifts, and a shirking of the real business of life; chiefly because they do not know, but partly because they do not mean better.
The weakest goes to the wall.
The weakest spot in every man is where he thinks himself to be the wisest.
The wealth of a country is in its good men and women, and in nothing else.
The wealth of a man is the number of things
which he loves and blesses, which he is loved and blessed by.
The wealth of both Indies seems in great part but an accessory to the command of the seas.
The wealth of both the Indies cannot redeem one single opportunity which you have once let slip.
The wealth of the land / Comes from the forge and the smithy and mine, / From hammer and chisel, and wheel and band, / And the thinking brain and the skilful hand.
The wealth we cannot wisely administer is an encumbrance.
The weariest and most loathéd worldly life, /
That age, ache, penury, and imprisonment / Can lay on nature, is a paradise / To what we fear of death.
The wearisome is in permanence here.
The weary night o' care and grief / May hae a joyful morrow.
 (_
The web of this world is woven of necessity and contingency; the reason of man places itself between them, and knows how to rule them both. It treats the necessary as the ground of its existence; the contingent it knows how to direct, lead, and utilise; and it is only while reason stands firm and steadfast that man deserves to be called the god of the earth. Woe to him who has accustomed himself from his youth to incline to find something arbitrary in what is necessary, who would fain ascribe a kind of reason to the contingent, which it were even a religion to follow; what is that but to disown one's own understanding, and to give loose reins to one's inclinations? We imagine it piety and to allow ourselves to be determined by agreeable accidents, and finally give to the results of such a vacillating life the name of Divine guidance.
The web of our life is of a mingled yarn, good and ill together; our virtues would be proud if our faults whipped them not, and our crimes would despair if they were not cherished by our virtues.
The wedge will rend rocks; but its edge must be sharp and single; if it is double, the wedge is bruised in pieces, and will rend nothing.
The wheel is always in motion, and the spoke which is uppermost will soon be under; therefore mix trembling with all your joy.
The whole art of war consists in getting at
what is on the other side of the hill, or, in other words, in learning what we do not know from what we do.
The whole course of things goes to teach us faith.
The whole difference between a man of genius and other men ... is that the former remains in great part a child, seeing with the large eyes of children, in perpetual wonder, not conscious of much knowledge--conscious rather of infinite ignorance, and yet infinite power.
The whole economy of nature is bent on expression.
The whole interest of history lies in the fortunes of the poor.
The whole function of the artist in the world is
to be a seeing and a feeling creature; to be an instrument of such tenderness and sensitiveness that no shadow, no hue, no line, no instantaneous and evanescent expression of the visible things around him, nor any of the emotions which they are capable of conveying to the spirit which has been given him, shall either be left unrecorded, or fade from the book of record.
The whole man to one thing at a time.
The whole of chivalry and of heraldry is in courtesy.
The whole past is the possession of the present.
The whole spiritual universe exists only in process--what Hegel calls "Der Process des Geistes"--the process of the spirit, that is to say, not as become, but as becoming; and if it once ceases to become, it ceases as such to be.
The whole universe is at all moments saying
"Nay" to the Spirit of God, and God's Spirit is at all moments saying "Yea" to the stolid "Nay" of the universe, which would fain be let alone; but stubborn as the material looks and is, it has to obey, and does obey, the voice of God.
The whole world is, properly speaking, a tragic
The whole world of truth and conscience is nothing without I.
The wide pasture is but separate spears of grass; the sheeted bloom of the prairies but isolated flowers.
The wife can carry more out of the house in her apron than the man can bring in on a harvest-waggon.
The wife is the key of the house.
The wife that expects to have a good name / Is always at home as if she were lame; / And the mind that is honest, her chiefest delight, / Is still to be doing from morning till night.
The will appears without its mask only in the affections and the passions.
The willow which bends to the tempest often escapes better than the oak which resists it.
The wind that has its nest in trees.
The winds and the waves are always on the
side of the ablest navigators.
The winter of our discontent.
The wisdom of life is in preventing all the evil we can, and using what is inevitable to the best purpose.
The wisdom of nations lies in their proverbs, which are brief and pithy. Collect and learn them; they are notable measures and directions for human life; you have much in little; they save time in speaking; and upon occasion may be the fullest and safest answers.
The wisdom of the wise and the experience of ages may be preserved by quotation.
The wise are instructed by reason, ordinary
minds by experience, the stupid by necessity, and brutes by instinct.
The wise are polite all the world over, but fools are only polite at home.
The wise are those who travel through error to truth; the foolish are those who persist in their error.
The wise grumbler ... is a public benefactor.
The wise have all ever said the same thing, and the fools, who are always in the majority, have always done just the opposite.
The wise in heart shall be called the prudent.
The wise man always looks to the degree of his indulgences.
The wise man can dispense with the favour of the mighty, but the mighty cannot dispense with the teaching of the wise.
The wise man does not grasp at what is far off in order to find what is near, and his hand does not grasp at the stars in order to kindle light.
The wise man, even destitute of riches, enjoyeth elevated and very honourable stations; whilst the wretch, endowed with wealth, acquireth the post of disgrace.
The wise man expects everything from himself; the fool looks to others.
The wise man had rather be envied for providence than pitied for prodigality.
The wise man has long ears and a short tongue.
The wise man knows his master; always some
creature larger than himself, some law holier than himself.
The wise man knows that he does not know; the ignoramus thinks he knows.
The wise man may strive to conquer, but he should never fight; because victory, it is observed, cannot be constant to both combatants.
The wise man moveth with one foot, and standeth fast with the other. A man should not quit one place until he hath fixed upon another.
The wise man must go to the foolish, else would his wisdom go for nought, since the foolish never come to the wise.
The wise man often shuns society for fear of
being bored.
The wise man ought to despise glory, but not honour. Honour is but seldom where glory is, and glory almost more rarely still where honour is.
The wise man should study the acquisition of science and riches as if he were not subject to sickness and death; but to the duties of religion he should attend as if death had seized him by the hair.
The wise man will commit no business of importance to a proxy when he may do it himself.
The wise men of old have sent most of their morality down the stream of time in the light skiff of apothegm or epigram.
The wise through excess of wisdom is made a
fool.
The wise weigh their words in a balance for gold.
The wise will determine from the gravity of the case; the irritable, from sensibility to oppression; the high-minded, from disdain and indignation at abusive power in unworthy hands.
The wiser mind / Mourns less for what age takes away / Than what it leaves behind.
The wisest at most observe only how fate leads them, and are content.
The wisest doctor is gravelled by the inquisitiveness
of a child.
The wisest, happiest of our kind are they / That ever walk content with Nature's way.
The wisest is omnipresent, and reveals His secrets universally to the seeing eye and the hearing ear. The revelation in all its fullness is nowhere wanting, only the sense to discern it, and the courage to be true to it.
The wisest man the warl' e'er saw, / He dearly lo'ed the lasses O.
The wisest men are wise to the full in death.
The wisest, most melodious voice cannot in
these days pass for a divine one; the word "inspiration" still lingers, but only in the shape of a poetic figure, from which the once earnest, awful, and soul-subduing sense has vanished without return.
The wisest of us must, for by far the most part, judge like the simplest; estimate importance by mere magnitude, and expect that which strongly affects our own generation, will strongly affect those that are to follow.
The wisest truly is, in these times, the greatest.
The wisest woman you talk with is ignorant of something that you know, but an elegant woman never forgets her elegance.
The wish was father to the thought.
The wished-for comes too late.
The wishing-gate opens into nothing.
The wit of language is so miserably inferior to the wit of ideas that it is deservedly driven out of good company.
The wit of one man, and the wisdom of many.
The wit one wants spoils what one has.
The woman and the soldier who do not defend
the first pass will never defend the last.
The woman that deliberates is lost.
The woman's cause is man's: they rise or sink / Together.
The womankind will not drill.
The women are quick enough--they're quick enough. They know the rights of a story before they hear it, and can tell a man what his thoughts are before he knows 'em himself.
The word is always bolder than the deed.
The Word is very nigh unto thee, in thy mouth, and in thy heart, that thou mayest do it.
The word of a gentleman is as good as his bond--sometimes better.
The words of a man's mouth are as deep waters, and the well-spring of wisdom as a flowing brook.
The words of a tale-bearer are as wounds, and they go down into the innermost parts of the belly.
The words of men are like the leaves of trees;
when they are too many they hinder the growth of the fruit.
The words of the wise are as goads.
The words that a father speaks to his children in the privacy of home are not heard by the world, but, as in whispering-galleries, they are clearly heard at the end and by posterity.
The work an unknown good man has done is like a vein of water flowing hidden under ground, secretly making the ground green; it flows and flows, it joins itself with other veins and veinlets; one day it will start forth as a visible perennial well.
The work of righteousness shall be peace.
The work of science is to substitute facts for appearances, and demonstrations for impressions.
The works of the great poets have only been read for most part as the multitude read the stars, at most, astrologically, not astronomically.
The world can never give / The bliss for which we sigh; / 'Tis not the whole of life to live, / Nor all of death to die.
The world cannot be governed without juggling.
The world cannot do without great men, but great men are very troublesome to the world.
The world considers eccentricity in great things genius: in small things, folly.
The world does not progress so quickly as a man grows old.
The world exists by change, and but for that / All matter would to chaos back / To form a pillar for a sleeping god.
The world exists for the education of each
man.
The world exists only by the strength of its silent virtue.
The world goes up, and the world goes down, / And the sunshine follows the rain; / And yesterday's sneer, and yesterday's frown, / Can never come over again.
The world grows more majestic, but man grows less.
The world has no business with my life; the world will never know my life, if it should write and read a hundred biographies of me.
The world has to obey him who thinks and
sees in the world.
The world is a carcase, and they who gather round it are dogs.
The world is a comedy to those who think, a tragedy to those who feel.
The world is a grand book from which to become wiser.
The world is a looking-glass, and gives back to every man the reflection of his own face. Frown at it, and it will in turn look sourly upon you; laugh at it and with it, and it is a jolly kind companion.
The world is a prison.
The world is a thing that man must learn to despise, and even to neglect, before he can learn to reverence it, and work in it and for it.
The world is a wheel, and it will all come round right.
The world is all barren to him who will not cultivate the fruit it offers.
The world is always ready to receive talent with open arms. Very often it does not know what to do with genius. Talent is a docile creature. It bows its head meekly while the world slips the collar over it. It backs into the shafts like a lamb.
The world is an excellent judge in general,
but a very bad one in particular.
The world is an old woman, that mistakes any gilt farthing for a gold coin; whereby, being often cheated, she will henceforth trust nothing but the common copper.
The world is as you take it.
The world is but an allegory; the idea is more real than the fact.
The world is content with words; few think of searching into the nature of things.
The world is everywhere perfect except where
man comes with his pain.
The world is fain to sully what is resplendent, and to drag down to the dust what is exalted.
The world is for him who has patience.
The world is glorious to look at, but dreadful in reality; it is one thing as a drama to a spectator, quite another thing to the actors in the plot, for in it the will is thwarted at every turn.
The world is governed much more by opinion than by laws.
The world is governed too much.
The world is not our peers, so we challenge the jury.
The world is not thy friend, nor the world's law.
The world is not to be despised but as it is compared with something better. Company is in itself better than solitude, and pleasure better than indolence.
The world is nothing but a wheel; in its whole periphery it is everywhere similar, but, nevertheless, it appears to us so strange, because we ourselves are carried round with it.
The world is nothing; the man is all.
The world is only governed by self-interest.
The world is so busied with selfish pursuits, ambition, vanity, interest, or pleasure, that very few think it worth their while to make any observation on what passes around them, except where that observation is a sucker, or branch of the darling plant they are rearing in their fancy.
The world is still deceived with ornament. / In law, what plea so tainted and corrupt, / But, being seasoned with a gracious voice, / Obscures the show of evil? In religion, / What damnéd error but some sober brow / Will bless it and approve it with a text, / Hiding the grossness with fair ornament?
The world is too much with us; late and soon, / Getting and spending, we lay waste our powers; / Little we see in Nature that is ours.
The world is undone by looking at things at a
distance.
The world is upheld by the veracity of good men; they make the earth wholesome.
The world is wide enough for all to live and let live, and every one has an enemy in his own talent, who gives him quite enough to do. But no! one gifted man and one talented persecutes another ... and each seeks to make the other hateful.
The world is wider than any of us think.
The world knows nothing of its greatest men.
The world looks at ministers out of the pulpit to know what they mean when in it.
The world ... may overlook most of us; but "reverence thyself."
The world never let a man bless it but it first
fought him.
The world of Nature for every man is the fantasy of himself; this world is the multiplex "image of his own dream."
The world of reality has its limits; the world of imagination is boundless. Not being able to enlarge the one, let us contract the other; for it is from their difference alone that all the evils arise which render us really unhappy.
The world of thought must remain apart from the world of action, for if they once coincided the problem of life would be solved, and the hope which we call heaven would be realised on earth. And therefore men "Are cradled into poetry by wrong; / They learn in suffering what they teach in song."
The world owes all its onward impulses to men ill at ease.
The world owes infinitely more to those who
have no history than to those who have; and the silent noble ones, who have enriched and exalted it by their mere presence, form a much grander and greater host than those do whose names stand emblazoned in written story, and are the loud boast of all.
The world remains ever the same.
The world seldom offers us any choice between solitude on the one hand and vulgarity on the other.
The world-spirit is a good swimmer, and storms and waves cannot drown him.
The world still wants its poet-priest, who shall not trifle with Shakespeare, the player, nor shall grope in graves with Swedenborg, the mourner; but who shall see, speak, and act with equal inspiration.
The world that surrounds you is the magic
glass of the world within you. To know yourself you have only to set down a true statement of those that ever loved or hated you.
The world throws its life into a hero or a shepherd, and puts him where he is wanted. Dante and Columbus were Italians in their time; they would be Russians or Americans to-day.
The world truly exists only in the presence of man, acts only in the passion of man. The essence of light is in his eyes--the centre of force in his soul--the pertinence of action in his deeds.
The world, which took but six days to make, is like to take six thousand to make out.
The world's a bubble, and the life of man less than a span.
The world's a room of sickness, where each
heart / Knows its own anguish and unrest! / The truest wisdom there, and noblest art, / Is his who skills of comfort best.
The world's a sea.
The world's a wood, in which all lose their way, / Though by a different path each goes astray.
The world's battle-fields have been in the heart chiefly. More heroism has there been displayed in the household and in the closet, I think, than on the most memorable military battle-fields of history.
The world's great men have not commonly been great scholars, nor its great scholars great men.
The world's wealth is its original men; by
these and their works it is a world and not a waste; the memory and record of what Men it loves--this is the sum of its strength, its sacred "property for ever," whereby it upholds itself and steers forward, better or worse, through the yet undiscovered deep of Time.
The worse the man, the better the soldier; if soldiers be not corrupt, they ought to be made so.
The worse things are, the better they are.
The worship of beauty apart from the soul becomes an idolatry enkindling desire instead of a reverence awakening devotion.
The worst deluded are the self-deluded.
The worst education which teaches self-denial
is better than the best which teaches everything else, and not that.
The worst of madmen is a saint run mad.
The worst of many is that their goodness is distributed rather than concentrated. They are like a sheet of water instead of being like a running stream, which can be used to turn a wheel.
The worst superstition is to consider our own the most tolerable.
The worst wheel in the waggon creaks the loudest.
The worst wild beast is called "Tyrant," and
the "Flatterer" the worst tame one.
The worth of a state, in the long-run, is the worth of the individuals composing it.
The wrath of brothers is fierce and devilish.
The wrath of man worketh not the righteousness of God.
The wretched have no friends.
The wretchedness which fate has rendered
voiceless and tuneless is not the least wretched, but the most.
The wrinkles of the heart are more indelible than those of the brow.
The writer of a book, is not he a preacher preaching not to this parish or that, on this day or that, but to all men in all times and places?
The wronged side is always the safest.
The young disease, that must subdue at length, / Grows with his growth, and strengthens with his strength.
The young mind is naturally pliable and imitative,
but in a more advanced state it grows rigid, and must be warmed and softened before it will receive a deep impression.
The young talk generously of relieving the old of their burdens, but the anxious heart is to the old when they see a load on the back of the young.
The youth gets together his materials to build a bridge to the moon, or perchance a palace on the earth; at length middle-aged, he concludes to build a woodshed with them.
The youth of the soul is everlasting, and eternity is youth.
Their angels do always behold the face of my Father which is in heaven.
Their chief pleasure is being displeased.
Their only labour was to kill the time, / And labour dire it is, and weary woe.
Their own will to all men, all their will to women.
Their strength is to sit still.
Theirs not to make reply, / Theirs not to reason why, / Theirs but to do or die.
Them as ha' never had a cushion don't miss it.
Then draw we nearer day by day, / Each to his brethren, all to God; / Let the world take us as she may, / We must not change our road.
Then fare-ye-weel, auld Nickle Ben, / Oh wad ye tak' a thought and men', / Ye aiblins
Then fare-ye-weel, auld Nickle Ben, / Oh wad ye tak' a thought and men', / Ye aiblins 
Then fare-ye-weel, auld Nickle Ben, / Oh wad ye tak' a thought and men', / Ye aiblins  I'm wae to think upon yon den / E'en for your sake.
Then gently scan your brother man, / Still gentler sister woman; / Though they may gang a kennin' wrang, / To step aside is human.
Then in the strife the youth puts forth his powers, / Knows what he is, and feels himself a man.
Then let us pray that come it may, / As come
it will for a' that, / That sense an' worth, o'er a' the earth, / May bear the gree and a' that.
Then was I as a tree / Whose boughs did bend with fruit; but, in one night, / A storm, or robbery, call it what you will, / Shook down my mellow hangings, nay, my leaves, / And left me bare to weather.
Theology is anthropology.
Theoretical principles must sometimes be suffered to give way for the sake of practical advantages.
Theories of genius are the peculiar constructions of our philosophical times; ages of genius have passed away, and they left no other record than their works.
Theories are very thin and unsubstantial; experience
only is tangible.
Theories which do not connect measures with men are not theories for this world.
Theory and practice always act upon one another. It is possible to construe from what we do what we think, and from what we think what we will do.
Theory in and by itself is of no use except in so far as it proves to us the connection
Theory in and by itself is of no use except in so far as it proves to us the connection (_Zusammenhang_) 
Theory in and by itself is of no use except in so far as it proves to us the connection (_Zusammenhang_)  phenomena.
There are a thousand occasions for sorrow,
and a hundred for fear that day by day assail the fool; not so the wise man.
There are always more tricks in a town than are talked of.
There are at bottom but two possible religions--that which rises in the moral nature of man, and which takes shape in moral commandments, and that which grows out of the observance of the material energies which operate in the external universe.
There are attractions in modest diffidence above the force of words. A silent address is the genuine eloquence of sincerity.
There are but three classes of men--the retrograde, the stationary, and the progressive.
There are but two ways of paying debt--increase
of industry in raising income; increase of thrift in laying it out.
There are cases where little can be said and much must be done.
There are certain things in which mediocrity is not to be endured, such as poetry, music, painting, public speaking.
There are certain times in our life when we find ourselves in circumstances, that not only press upon us, but seem to weigh us down altogether. They give us, however, not only the opportunity, but they impose on us the duty of elevating ourselves, and thereby fulfilling the purpose of the Divine Being in our creation.
There are charms made only for distant admiration. No spectacle is nobler than a blaze.
There are cloudy days for the mind as well as
for the world, and the man who has the most genius is twenty times a day in the clouds.
There are depths in the soul which are deeper than hell.
There are enough unhappy on this earth.
There are faces so fluid with expression that we can hardly find what the mere features are.
There are falsehoods which are not lies ... which is the case in parables, fables, &c.... In such instances no confidence is destroyed, because none was reposed; no promise to speak the truth is violated, because none was given.
There are few circumstances in which it is not
best either to hide all or to tell all.
There are few faces that can afford to smile. A smile is sometimes bewitching; in general vapid; often a contortion.
There are few men so obstinate in their atheism whom a pressing danger will not reduce to an acknowledgment of the Divine power.
There are few persons to whom truth is not a sort of insult.
There are few things that are worthy of anger, and still fewer that can justify malignity.
There are few thoughts likely to come across ordinary men which have not already been expressed by greater men in the best possible way; and it is a wiser, more generous, more noble thing to remember and point out the perfect words than to invent poorer ones, wherewith to encumber temporarily the world.
There are few who, either by extraordinary endowment or favour of fortune, have enjoyed the opportunity of deciding what mode of life in especial they would wish to embrace.
There are few wild beasts more to be dreaded than a communicative man having nothing to communicate.
There are fewer students of man than of geometry.
There are forty men of wit for one of sense;
and he that will carry nothing about him but gold, will be every day at a loss for want of ready change.
There are heads sometimes so little that there is no room for wit, sometimes so long that there is no wit for so much room.
There are in man, in the beginning / And at the end, two blank book-binder's leaves--childhood and age.
There are in the history of a man only three epochs, his birth, his life, and his death; he is not conscious of being born; he submits to die; and he forgets to live.
There are in this day, as in all days, around and in every man, voices from the gods, imperative to all, if obeyed by even none, which say audibly: Arise, thou son of Adam, son of Time, make this thing more divine, and that thing, and thyself of all things, and work, and sleep not; for the Night cometh wherein no man can work.
There are in this loud stunning tide / Of
human care and crime, / With whom the melodies abide / Of th' everlasting chime; / Who carry music in their heart, / Through dusty lane and wrangling mart, / Plying their daily task with busier feet, / Because their secret souls a holy strain repeat.
There are interests by the sacrifice of which peace is too dearly purchased. One should never be at peace to the shame of his own soul, to the violation of his integrity or of his allegiance to God.
There are many men who do not believe in evaporation. They get all they can, and keep all they get, and so are not fertilisers, but only stagnant, miasmatic pools.
There are many religions, but there is only one morality.
There are many troubles which you cannot cure by the Bible and the hymn-book, but which you can cure by a good perspiration and a breath of fresh air.
There are many truths of which the full
meaning cannot be realised until personal experience has brought it home.
There are men who, by long consulting their own inclination, have forgotten that others have a claim to the same deference.
There are men who dwell on the defects of their enemies. I always have regard to the merits of mine, and derive profit therefrom.
There are men whose tongues are more eloquent than those of women, but no man possesses the eloquence of a woman's eye.
There are moments in life when the heart is so full of emotion, / That if by chance it be shaken, or into its depths like a pebble / Drops some careless word, it overflows; and its secret, / Spilt on the ground like water, can never be gathered together.
There are more fools than wise men, and even
in the wise men more folly than wisdom.
There are more men ennobled by study than by nature.
There are more offences at my beck than I have thoughts to put them in, imagination to give them shape, or time to act them in.
There are more things in heaven and earth, Horatio, / Than are dreamt of in your philosophy.
There are more ways to the wood than one.
There are nae fules like auld fules.
There are natures that are great by what they attain, and others by what they disdain.
There are no better masters than poverty and want.
There are no chagrins so venomous as the chagrins of the idle; no pangs so sickening as the satieties of pleasure.
There are no English lives worth reading except those of players, who by the nature of the case have bidden Respectability good-day.
There are no fixtures in Nature. The universe
is fluid and volatile.
There are no grotesques in Nature.
There are no laws by which we can write Iliads.
There are no obstructions more fatal to fortune than pride and resentment.
There are no persons more solicitous about the preservation of rank than those who have no rank at all.
There are no proverbial sayings which are not
true.
There are no real pleasures without real needs.
There are no tricks in plain and simple faith.
There are no troubles which have such a wasting and disastrous effect upon the mind as those which must not be told, but which cause the mind to be continually rolling and turning over upon itself in ceaseless convolutions and unrest.
There are no twin souls in God's universe.
There are none but men of strong passions
capable of going to greatness; none but such capable of meriting the public gratitude.
There are none of the charges brought against Socialism which might not have been brought against Christianity itself.
There are omens in the air, / And voices whispering Beware!--/ But never victor in the fight / Heeded the portents of fear and care.
There are only three classes of people--those who have found God and serve him; those who have not found God and seek him; and those who live without either seeking or finding him--the first, rational and happy; the second, unhappy and rational; the third, foolish and unhappy.
There are only two ways of rising in the world, either by one's own industry or by the weakness of others.
There are people who will help you to get your
basket on your head, because they want to see what's in it.
There are people who would never have been in love if they had never heard love spoken of.
There are proselytes from atheism, but none from superstition.
There are several who would, or at least pretend they would, bear much in their own business who will bear nothing at all.
There are shades in all good pictures, but there are lights too, if we choose to contemplate them.
There are single thoughts that contain the
essence of a whole volume, single sentences that have the beauties of a large work.
There are soldiers of the ploughshare as well as soldiers of the sword.
There are some cases in which human nature and its deep wrongs will be ever stronger than the world and its philosophy.
There are some faults so nearly allied to excellence that we can scarce weed out the vice without eradicating the virtue.
There are some men who are witty when they are in a bad humour, and others only when they are sad.
There are some people who give with the air
of refusal.
There are some sorrows cannot be subjected / To man's construction, howsoe'er suspected.
There are some trifles well habited, as there are some fools well clothed.
There are sorrows / Where of necessity the soul must be / Its own support.
There are souls which fall from heaven like flowers; but ere the pure and fresh buds can open, they are trodden in the dust of the earth, and lie soiled and crushed under the foul tread of some brutal hoof.
There are things in this world to be laughed
at, as well as things to be admired; and his is no complete mind that cannot give to each sort his due.
There are things that should be done, not spoken; that, till the doing of them is begun, cannot be spoken.
There are those who never reason on what they should do, but what they have done; as if Reason had her eyes behind, and could only see backwards.
There are thousands hacking at the branches of evil to one who is striking at the root.
There are three classes of authors--those who write without thinking, those who think while writing, and those who think before writing.
There are three difficulties in authorship--to
write anything worth the publishing, to find honest men to publish it, and to get sensible men to read it.
There are three material things, not only useful, but essential, to life--pure air, water, and earth; and three immaterial that are equally essential--admiration, hope, and love.
There are three means of believing--by inspiration, by reason, and by custom. Christianity, which is the only rational institution, does yet admit none for its sons who do not believe by inspiration.
There are three religions--the religion which depends on reverence for what is above us, denominated the ethnic; the religion which founds itself on reverence for what is around us, denominated the philosophical; the religion grounded on reverence for what is beneath us, which we name the Christian.
There are three things in this world which deserve no quarter--hypocrisy, pharisaism, and tyranny.
There are three things which cause perfection
in a man--nature, reason, use. Reason I call discipline; use, exercise. If any one of these branches want, certainly the tree of virtue must needs wither.
There are times when silence, if the preacher did but know, / Shall preach to better purpose than a sermon stale and flat.
There are times when we are diverted out of errors, but could not be preached out of them.
There are truths that shield themselves behind veils, and are best spoken by implication. Even the sun veils himself in his own rays to blind the gaze of the too curious starer.
There are two, and only two, forms of possible gospel or "good message"--one, that men are saved by themselves doing what is right; and the other, that they are saved by believing that somebody also did right instead of them. The first of these gospels is eternally true and holy; the other eternally false, damnable, and damning.
There are two kinds of genius. The first and
highest may be said to speak out of the eternal into the present, and must compel its age to understand it; the second understands its age, and tells it what it wishes to be told.
There are two levers for moving men--interest and fear.
There are two modes of establishing our reputation--to be praised by honest men, and to be abused by rogues. It is best, however, to secure the former, because it will be invariably accompanied by the latter.
There are two sides to every question.
There are two things that can reach the top of a pyramid, the eagle and the reptile.
There are two ways of attaining an important end--force and perseverance; the silent power of the latter grows irresistible with time.
There are unhappy times in the world's history, when he that is the least educated will chiefly have to say that he is the least perverted; and with the multitude of false eye-glasses, convex, concave, green, even yellow, has not lost the natural use of his eyes.
There are very few moments in a man's existence
when he experiences so much ludicrous distress, or meets with so little charitable commiseration, as when he is in pursuit of his own hat.
There are very few people in this world who get any good by either writing or reading.
There are, whom heaven has blessed with store of wit, / Yet want as much again to manage it; / For wit and judgment ever are at strife, / Tho' meant each other's aid, like man and wife.
There are words which are worth as much as the best actions, for they contain the germ of them all.
There be some that think their wits have been asleep, except they dart out somewhat that is piquant, and to the quick; that is a vein which would be bridled.
There can be no excess to love, none to knowledge,
none to beauty, when these attributes are considered in the purest sense.
There can be no kernel in this light nut; the soul of this man is in his clothes.
There can be no profanity where there is no fane behind.
There can be no shame in accepting orders from those who have themselves learned to obey.
There can be no true aristocracy but must possess the land.
There can come no harm of supposing every
other man better than yourself; but the supposing any man worse than yourself may be attended with very ill consequences.
There coils a fear beneath the loveliest dream.
There hath no temptation taken you but such as is common to man.
There have been in all ages children of God and of man; the one born of the Spirit, and obeying it; the other born of the flesh, and obeying it.
There in others' looks discover / What thy own life's course has been, / And thy deeds of years past over, / In thy fellow-men be seen.
There is a better thing than the great man
who is always speaking, and that is the great man who only speaks when he has a great word to say.
There is a black speck, say the Arabs, were it no bigger than a bean's eye, in every soul; which, once set a-working, will overcloud the whole man into darkness and quasi-madness, and hurry him balefully into night.
There is a book, who runs may read, / Which heavenly truth imparts, / And all the love its scholars need, / Pure eyes and Christian hearts. / The works of God above, below, / Within us, and around, / Are pages in that book, to show / How God Himself is found.
There is a budding morrow in midnight.
There is a care for trifles which proceeds from love and conscience, and is most holy; and a care for trifles which comes of idleness and frivolity, and is most base. And so, also, there is a gravity proceeding from thought, which is most noble; and a gravity proceeding from dulness and mere incapability of enjoyment, which is most base.
There is a Cato in every man; a severe censor
of his manners. And he that reverences this judge will seldom do anything he need repent of.
There is a certain artificial polish, a commonplace vivacity, acquired by perpetually mingling in the beau monde, which, in the commerce of the world, supplies the place of natural suavity and good-humour; but it is purchased at the expense of all original and sterling traits of character.
There is a certain mien and motion of the body and all its parts, both in acting and speaking, which argues a man well within.
There is a certain noble pride through which merits shine brighter than through modesty.
There is a country accent, not in speech only, but in thought, conduct, character, and manner of existing, which never forsakes a man.
There is a crack in everything God has made.
There is a devil dwells in man as well as a divinity.
There is a different kind of knowledge good for every different creature, and the glory of the higher creatures is in ignorance of what is known to the lower.
There is a flush of the body which is full of warmth and life, and another which will pass into putrefaction.
There is a foolish corner even in the brain of the sage.
There is a frightful interval between the seed
and the timber.
There is a glare about worldly success, which is very apt to dazzle men's eyes.
There is a God within us who breathes that divine fire by which we are animated.
There is a great deal of folly in talking unnecessarily of one's private affairs.
There is a great difference between bearing malice, which is always ungenerous, and a resolute self-defence, which is always prudent and justifiable.
There is a great discovery still to be made in
literature, that of paying literary men by the quantity they do not write.
There is a heroic innocence, as well as a heroic courage.
There is a higher law than the constitution.
There is a history in all men's lives, / Figuring the nature of the times deceased; / The which observed, a man may prophesy, / With a near aim of the main chance of things / As yet not come to life: which, in their seeds / And weak beginnings, lie intreasurèd.
There is a kind of pride in which are included all the commandments of God, and a kind of vanity which contains the seven mortal sins.
There is a life which taketh not its hues / From earth or earthly things; and so grows pure / And higher than the petty cares of men, / And is a blessed life and glorified.
There is a living, literal communion of saints, wide as the world itself, and as the history of the world.
There is a long and wearisome step between
admiration and imitation.
There is a lust in man no charm can tame, / Of loudly publishing his neighbour's shame; / On eagle's wings immortal scandals fly, / While virtuous actions are but born and die.
There is a magic in a great name.
There is a magic in the memory of schoolboy friendships; it softens the heart, and even affects the nervous system of those who have no hearts.
There is a mean in all things. Even virtue itself hath its stated limits; which not being strictly observed, it ceases to be virtue.
There is a measure of self-regard which is
right, wherein the individual self is identified with the universal self.
There is a mercy that is weakness, and even treason against the common good.
There is a method in man's wickedness, / It grows by degrees.
There is a nobler ambition than the getting of all California, or the getting of all the suffrages that are on the planet just now.
There is a perennial nobleness, and even sacredness, in work. Were he ever so benighted, forgetful of his high calling, there is always hope in a man that actually and earnestly works.
There is a period of life when our backward
movements are steps in advance.
There is a pleasure in poetic pains which only poets know.
There is a pleasure in the pathless woods; / There is a rapture on the lonely shore; / There is society, where none intrudes, / By the deep sea, and music in its roar; / I love not the man the less, / But Nature more.
There is a pleasure, sure, in being mad, which none but mad men know.
There is a power over and behind us, and we are the channels of its communication.
There is a probity of manners as well as of
conscience, and a true Christian will regard in a degree the conventionalities of society.
There is a property in the horizon which no man has but he whose eye can integrate all the parts--that is, the poet.
There is a rabble amongst the gentry as well as the commonalty; a sort of plebeian heads, whose fancy moves in the same wheel with the others,--men in the same level with mechanics, though their fortunes do somewhat gild their infirmities, and their purses compound for their follies.
There is a remedy for everything but death.
There is a remedy for every wrong, and a satisfaction for every soul.
There is a sacredness in tears. They are not
the mark of weakness, but of power. They speak more eloquently than ten thousand tongues. They are the messengers of overwhelming grief, of deep contrition, and of unspeakable love.
There is a skeleton in every house.
Then is a snake in the grass.
There is a Spanish proverb that a lapidary who would grow rich must buy of those who go to be executed, as not caring how cheap they sell; and sell to those who go to be married, as not caring how dear they buy.
There is a special providence in the fall of a sparrow.
There is a spirit of resistance implanted by
the Deity in the breast of man, proportioned to the size of the wrongs he is destined to endure.
There is a Sunday conscience as well as a Sunday coat; and those who make religion a secondary concern put the coat and conscience carefully by to put on only once a week.
There is a sweet little cherub that sits up aloft, to keep watch for the life of poor Jack.
There is a tendency in things to right themselves.
There is a third silent party to all our bargains. The nature and soul of things takes on itself the guarantee of the fulfilment of every contract, so that honest service cannot come to loss.
There is a tide in the affairs of men, / Which,
taken at the flood, leads on to fortune; / Omitted, all the voyage of their life / Is bound in shallows and in miseries; / On such a full sea are we now afloat; / And we must take the current when it serves, / Or lose our ventures.
There is a time for all things.
There is a time in every man's education when he arrives at the conviction that envy is ignorance.
There is a time of life beyond which we cannot form a tie worth the name of friendship.
There is a time there for every purpose and for every work.
There is a time wherein one man ruleth over
another to his own hurt.
There is a true Church whenever one meets another helpfully, and that is the only holy or Mother Church which ever was or ever shall be.
There is a way which seemeth right unto a man, but the end thereof are the ways of death.
There is a worth in honest ignorance; 'twere almost a pity to exchange for knowledge.
There is always life for a living one.
There is always room for a man of force, and he makes room for many.
There is always some levity in excellent minds; they have wings to rise and also to stray.
There is always the possibility of beauty
where there is an unsealed human eye; of music where there is an unstopped human ear; and of inspiration where there is a receptive human spirit, a spirit standing before.
There is an abasement because of glory, and there is that lifteth up his head from a low estate.
There is an anger that is majestic as the frown of Jehovah's brow; it is the anger of truth and love.
There is an emanation from the heart in genuine hospitality which cannot be described but is immediately felt, and puts the stranger at once at his ease.
There is a heroic innocence, as well a heroic courage.
There is an insolence which none but those
who deserve some contempt themselves can bestow, and those only who deserve no contempt can bear.
There is as much difference between the counsel that a friend giveth and that a man giveth himself, as there is between the counsel of a friend and of a flatterer.
There is as much ingenuity in making an felicitous application of an passage as in being the author of it.
There is, at any given moment, a best path for every man; the thing which, here and now, it were wisest for him to do; whatsoever forwards him in that, were it even in the shape of blows and spurnings, is liberty; whatsoever hinders him, were it tremendous cheers and rivers of heavy wet, is slavery.
There is but one case wherein a man may commend himself with good grace, and that is in commending virtue in another, especially if it be such a virtue whereunto himself pretendeth.
There is but one class of men to be trembled
at, and that is the stupid class, the class that cannot see; who, alas! are mainly they that will not see.
There is but one misfortune for a man, when some idea lays hold of him which exerts no influence upon his active life, or still more, which withdraws him from it.
There is but one philosophy, and its name is Fortitude; to bear is to conquer our fate.
There is but one solid basis of happiness, and that is the reasonable hope of a happy futurity. This may be had everywhere.
There is but one temple in the world, and that is the body of man. Nothing is holier than this high form. Bending before men is a reverence done to this revelation in the flesh. We touch heaven when we lay our hand on a human body.
There is but one thing without honour, smitten
with eternal barrenness, inability to do or to be--insincerity, unbelief. He who believes nothing, who believes only the shows of things, is not in relation with nature and fact at all.
There is certainly something of exquisite kindness and thoughtful benevolence in that rarest of gifts--fine breeding.
There is differency between a grub and a butterfly; yet your butterfly was a grub.
There is enjoyment even in sadness, and the same souvenirs which have produced long regrets may also soften them.
There is ever a certain languor attending the fulness of prosperity. When the heart has no more to wish, it yawns over its possessions, and the energy of the soul goes out, like a flame that has no more to devour.
There is evil in every human heart, which may
remain latent, perhaps through the whole of life; but circumstances may rouse it to activity.
There is far less pleasure in doing a thing beautifully than in seeing it beautifully done.
There is for the soul a spontaneous culture, on which depends all its real progress in perfection.
There is forgiveness with God and Christ for the passing sin of the hot heart, but none for the eternal and inherent sin of the cold.
There is genius of a nation, which is not to be found in the citizen, but which characterises the society.
There is great force hidden in a sweet command.
There is in human nature an essential, though somewhat mysterious, connection of love with fear.
There is in human nature generally more of the fool than of the wise, and therefore those faculties by which the foolish part of men's minds is taken are most potent.
There is in man a Higher than love of happiness; he can do without happiness, and instead thereof find blessedness!
There is in nature an accessible and an inaccessible. Be careful to discriminate between the two. Be circumspect, and proceed with reverence.... It is always difficult to see where the one begins and the other leaves off. He who knows it, and is wise, will confine himself to the accessible.
There is in the heart of woman such a deep
well of love that no age can freeze it.
There is in this world infinitely more joy than pain to be shared, if you will only take your share when it is set before you.
There is little hope of equity where rebellion reigns.
There is little wisdom in knowing that every man must be up and doing, and that all mankind are made dependent on one another.
There is more concern nowadays to interpret interpretations than to interpret things, and more books about books than about any other subject. We do nothing but expound one another.
There is more danger in a reserved and silent friend than in a noisy babbling enemy.
There is more pleasure in loving than in being beloved.
There is more serfdom in England now than at any time since the Conquest.
There is music in all things, if men had ears.
There is need, bitter need, to bring back, if we may, into men's minds, that to live is nothing unless to live be to know Him by whom we live, and that He is not to be known amidst the hurry of crowds and crash of innovation, but in solitary places, and out of the glowing intelligence which He gave to men of old.
There is never a beginning, there is never an end, to the inexplicable continuity of the web of God, but always circular power returning into itself.
There is never but one opportunity of a kind.
There is no better counsellor than time.
There is no better sign of a brave mind than a
hard hand.
There is no better type of a perfectly free creature than the common house-fly.
There is no bridge from one being to another, each is a self, each rests on itself, and wills only itself, knows only itself, understands only itself.
There is no brotherhood possible, at any rate stable, between man and man but a brotherhood of labour.
There is no cause why one man's nose is longer than another's, but because that God pleases to have it so.
There is no class of men so difficult to be
managed in a state, as those whose intentions are honest, but whose consciences are bewitched.
There is no communion possible among men who believe only in hearsays.
There is no contingency, and what to us seems only blind chance is an efflux from the depths of being.
There is no courage but in innocence; no constancy but in an honest cause.
There is no creature so lonely as the dweller in the intellect.
There is no darkness but ignorance.
There is no darkness unto the conscience, which can see without light.
There is no dearth of charity in the world in giving, but there is comparatively little exercised in thinking and speaking.
There is no defence against reproach but obscurity.
There is no den in the wide world to hide a rogue. Commit a crime, and the earth is made of glass.
There is no despair so absolute as that which
comes with the first moments of our first great sorrow, when we have not yet known what it is to have suffered and be healed, to have despaired and have recovered hope.
There is no detraction worse than to overpraise a man.
There is no direr disaster in love than the death of imagination.
There is no dispute managed without passion, and yet there is scarce a dispute worth a passion.
There is no disputing against hobby-horses.
There is no education like adversity.
There is no end in nature, but every end is a beginning.
There is no end of settlements; there will never be an end; the best settlement is but a temporary partial one.
There is no event but sprung somewhere from the soul of man.
There is no evil but is mingled with good.
There is no extremity of distress which of
itself ought to reduce a great nation to despair. It is not the disorder, but the physician ... which alone can make a whole people desperate.
There is no fatigue so wearisome as that which comes from want of work.
There is no fear in love; but perfect love casteth out fear.
There is no fiercer hell than failure in a great object.
There is no flock, however watched and tended, / But one dead lamb is there; / There is no fireside, howsoe'er defended, / But has one vacant chair.
There is no foolishest man but knows one and
the other thing more clearly than any the wisest man does.
There is no gambling like politics.... Nothing in which the power of circumstance is more evident.
There is no genuine love for art without an ardent love for humanity.
There is no Gethsemane without its angel.
There is no ghost so difficult to lay as the ghost of an injury.
There is no God but God, the living, the self-subsisting.
There is no going to heaven in a sedan.
There is no good in arguing with the inevitable.
There is no good in emitting smoke till you have made it into fire, which all smoke is capable of becoming.
There is no great and no small / To the soul that maketh all; / And where it cometh, all things are; / And it cometh everywhere.
There is no great genius free from some tincture
of madness.
There is no greater evil among men than a testament framed with injustice; where caprice hath guided the boon, or dishonesty refused what was due.
There is no greater fraud than a promise unfulfilled.
There is no greater proof of human weakness than that which betrays itself in the boast of fortune and ancestry; these cannot ennoble us, but our conduct in life may ennoble or degrade them.
There is no greater punishment than that of being abandoned to one's self.
There is no greater wisdom than well to time the beginnings and onset of things.
There is no grief like hate! no pains like passions!
no deceit like sense! Enter the path! far hath he gone whose foot treads down one fond offence.
There is no grief that time will not soften.
There is no harm in anybody thinking that Christ is in bread. The harm is in the expectation of His presence in gunpowder.
There is no heroic poem in the world but is at bottom a biography, the life of a man; and there is no life of a man, faithfully recorded, but is a heroic poem of its sort, rhymed or unrhymed.
There is no jesting with edge tools.
There is no joy without alloy.
There is no hiding of evil but not to do it.
There is no index of character so sure as the voice.
There is no legislation for liars and traitors; they cannot be prevented from the pit; the earth finally swallows them.... There is no law for these but gravitation.
There is no less invention in aptly applying a thought found in a book than in being the first author of the thought.
There is no lie that many men will not believe;
there is no man who does not believe many lies; and there is no man who believes only lies.
There is no loss / In being small; great bulks but swell with dross. / Man is heaven's masterpiece; if it appear / More great, the value's less; if less, more dear.
There is no lustre
is the first rule to which every author should pay regard.
There is no man alone, because every man is a microcosm, and carries the whole world about him.
There is no man on the streets whose biography I would not like to be acquainted with.
There is no man so friendless but that he can
find a friend sincere enough to tell him disagreeable truths.
There is no man so rudely punished as he that is subject to the whip of his own remorse.
There is no man that has not his hour, nor is there anything that has not its place.
There is no man that hath power over the spirit to retain the spirit; neither hath he power in the day of death: and there is no discharge in that war.
There is no man that imparteth his joys to his friend, but he joyeth the more; and no man that imparteth his griefs to his friend, but he grieveth the less.
There is no man whom fortune does not visit
once in his life; but when she does not find him ready to receive her, she walks in at the door, and flies out at the window.
There is no merit where there is no trial; and, till experience stamps the mark of strength, cowards may pass for heroes, faith for falsehood.
There is no mistake; there has been no mistake; and there shall be no mistake.
There is no more fatal blunderer than he who consumes the greater part of his life getting his living.
There is no more potent antidote to low sensuality than the adoration of beauty.
There is no more welcome gift to men than a
new symbol.
There is no mortal extant, out of the depths of Bedlam, but lives all skinned, thatched, covered over with formulas; and is, as it were, held in from delirium and the inane by his formulas. These are the most beneficent and indispensable of human equipments; blessed he who has a skin and tissues, so it be a living one, and the heart-pulse everywhere discernible through it.
There is no mortal truly wise and restless at once; wisdom is the repose of minds.
There is no new thing under the sun.
There is no object of desire the supreme vanity of which we do not recognise and confess when once we have embraced it.
There is no object so foul that intense light
will not make beautiful. And the stimulus it affords to the sense, and a sort of infinitude which it hath like space and time, make all matter gay.
There is no one the friend of another: there is no one the enemy of another: friends, as well as enemies, are created through our transactions.
There is no one who does not exaggerate.
There is no ordinance obliging us to fight those who are stronger than ourselves. Such fighting, as it were, with an elephant, is the same as men's fighting against rocks.
There is no other ghost save the ghost of our own childhood, the ghost of our own innocence, the ghost of our own airy belief.
There is no other revelation than the thoughts
of the wise.
There is no outward sign of courtesy that does not rest on a deep moral foundation.
There is no part of the furniture of a man's mind which he has a greater right to exult in than that which he has hewn and fashioned for himself.
There is no part of the world from whence we may not admire these planets, which roll, like ours, in different orbits round the same central sun; ... and whilst my soul is thus raised up to heaven, it imports me little what ground I tread upon.
There is no patriotic art and no patriotic science.
There is no peace in ambition; it is always gloomy, and often unreasonably so. The kindness of the king, the regards of the courtiers, the attachment of my domestics, and the fidelity of a large number of friends, make me happy no longer.
There is no permanence in doubt; it incites the mind to closer inquiry and experiment, from which, if rightly managed, certainty proceeds, and in this alone can man find thorough satisfaction.
There is no permanent love but that which has duty for its eldest brother; so that if one sleeps the other watches, and honour is safe.
There is no place like home.
There is no place where earth's sorrows / Are
more felt than up in heaven; / There is no place where earth's failings / Have such kindly judgment given.
There is no policy like politeness; and a good manner is the best thing in the world, either to get a good name or to supply the want of it.
There is no pure malignity in nature.
There is no qualification for government but virtue and wisdom.
There is no real life but cheerful life.
There is no repose for the mind except in the
absolute.
There is no respect for others without humility in one's self.
There is no respect of persons with God.
There is no returning from a
There is no riches above a sound body, and no joy above the joy of the heart.
There is no right faith in believing what is
true, unless we believe it because it is true.
There is no road too long to the man who advances deliberately and without undue haste; there are no honours too distant to the man who prepares himself for them with patience.
There is no royal road to geometry.
There is no sanctuary of virtue like home.
There is no solemnity so deep, to a right thinking creature, as that of dawn.
There is no solitude in nature.
There is no solitude more dreadful for a stranger, an isolated man, than a great city. So many thousands, and not one friend.
There is no spirit without a body unless it be a ghost, and no body without a spirit unless it be a corpse.
There is no sporting with a fellow-creature's happiness or misery.
There is no sterner moralist than pleasure.
There is no stronger test of a man's real
character than power and authority, exciting, as they do, every passion, and discovering every latent vice.
There is no such flatterer as is a man's self, and there is no such remedy against flattery of a man's self as the liberty of a friend.
There is no such thing as a dumb poet or a handless painter. The essence of an artist is that he should be articulate.
There is no such thing as being agreeable without a thorough good-humour, a natural sweetness of temper, enlivened by cheerfulness.
There is no such thing as chance; and what seems to us merest accident springs from the deepest source of destiny.
There is no such thing as Liberty in the universe:
there can never be. The stars have it not; the earth has it not; the sea has it not; and we men have the mockery and semblance of it only for our heaviest punishment.
There is no sure foundation set on blood; / No certain life achieved by others' death.
There is no surer argument of a weak mind than irresolution.
There is no terror, Cassius, in your threats; / For I am armed so strong in honesty / That they pass by me as the idle wind / Which I respect not.
There is no thought in any mind, but it quickly tends to convert itself into a power, and organises a huge instrumentality of means.
There is no time so miserable, but a man may
be true.
There is no traitor like him whose domestic treason plants the poniard within the breast which trusted to his truth.
There is no true action without will.
There is no true love without jealousy.
There is no vague general capability in men.
There is no vice or folly that requires so much
nicety and skill to manage as vanity.
There is no vice or crime that does not originate in self-love; and there is no virtue that does not grow from the love of others out of and beyond self.
There is no vice so simple but assumes / Some mark of virtue in his outward parts.
There is no venom like that of the tongue.
There is no wealth but life--life, including all its powers of love, of joy, and of admiration.
There is no well-doing, no godlike doing, that
is not patient doing.
There is no wisdom nor understanding nor counsel against the Lord.
There is no work of genius which has not been the delight of mankind, no word of genius to which the human heart and soul have not, sooner or later, responded.
There is no worse fruit than that which never ripens.
There is no worse joke than a true one.
There is none so blind as they that won't see.
There is none so poor that he need sit on a pumpkin. That is shiftlessness.
There is not a Red Indian hunting by Lake Winnipeg can quarrel with his squaw but the whole world must smart for it; will not the price of beaver rise?
There is not any benefit so glorious in itself but it may be exceedingly sweetened and improved by the manner of conferring it. The virtue, I know, rests in the intent, but the beauty and ornament of an obligation lies in the manner of it.
There is not in earth a spectacle more worthy than a great man superior to his sufferings.
There is not in national life any real epoch, because there is nothing in reality abrupt. Events, however great or sudden, are consequences of preparations long ago made.
There is not one grain in the universe, either too much or too little, nothing to be added, nothing to be spared; nor so much as any one particle of it, that mankind may not be either the better or the worse for, according as it is applied.
There is not so agonizing a feeling in the whole
catalogue of human suffering as the first conviction that the heart of the being whom we most tenderly love is estranged from us.
There is not so much comfort in having children as there is sorrow in parting with them.
There is not the thickness of a sixpence between good and evil.
There is not yet any inventory of man's faculties.
There is nothing beyond the pleasure which the study of Nature produces. Her secrets are of unfathomable depth, but it is granted to us men to look into them more and more.
There is nothing born but has to die.
There is nothing by which I have, through life, more profited than by the just observations, the good opinion, and the sincere and gentle encouragement of amiable and sensible women.
There is nothing capricious in nature.
There is nothing covered that shall not be revealed; and hid, that shall not be known.
There is nothing divine but what is rational.
There is nothing either good or bad, but thinking
makes it so.
There is nothing evil but what is within us; the rest is either natural or accidental.
There is nothing exasperates people more than the display of superior ability or brilliancy in conversation. They seem pleased at the time, but their envy makes them curse him at their hearts.
There is nothing from without a man that entering into him can defile him; but the things which come out of him, those are they that defile the man.
There is nothing good or evil save in the will.
There is nothing good or godlike in this world
but has in it something of "infinite sadness."
There is nothing holier in this life of ours than the first consciousness of love, the first fluttering of its silken wings.
There is nothing in the world more shameful than establishing one's self on lies and fables.
There is nothing in this world that will keep the devil out of one but hard labour.
There is nothing in which the power of circumstance is more evident than in politics.
There is nothing innocent or good that dies
and is forgotten.
There is nothing insignificant, nothing!
There is nothing lighter than vain praise.
There is nothing like leather.
There is nothing like the cold dead hand of the past to take down our tumid egotism, and lead us into the solemn flow of the life of our race.
There is nothing little to the truly great in
spirit.
There is nothing more allied to the barbarous and savage character than sullenness, concealment, and reserve.
There is nothing more characteristic than the shakes of the hand.
There is nothing more charming than to see a mother with a child in her arms, and nothing more venerable than a mother among a number of her children.
There is nothing more frightful than for a teacher to know only what his scholars are intended to know.
There is nothing more frightful than imagination
without taste.
There is nothing more perennial in us than habit and imitation. They are the source of all working and all apprenticeship, of all practice and all learning.
There is nothing more pitiable in the world than an irresolute man, oscillating between two feelings, who would willingly unite the two, and who does not perceive that nothing can unite them.
There is nothing more precious to a man than his will; there is nothing which he relinquishes with so much reluctance.
There is nothing more terrible to a guilty heart than the eye of a respected friend.
There is nothing new under the sun.
There is nothing of which men are so fond and so careless as life.
There is nothing on earth divine beside humanity.
There is nothing on earth which is not in the heavens in a heavenly form, and nothing in the heavens which is not on the earth in an earthly form.
There is nothing on earth without difficulty. Only the inner impulse, the pleasure it gives us, and love we feel, help us to overcome obstruction, to pave our way, and to raise ourselves out of the narrow circle in which others sorrowfully torture themselves.
There is nothing really more monstrous in any
recorded savagery or absurdity of mankind than that governments should be able to get money for any folly they choose to commit, by selling to capitalists the right of taxing future generations to the end of time.
There is nothing so agonising to the fine skin of vanity as the application of a rough truth.
There is nothing so great or so goodly in creation, but it is a mean symbol of the gospel of Christ, and of the things that he has prepared for them that love him.
There is nothing so powerful as truth, and nothing so strange.
There is nothing so small but that we may honour God by asking his guidance of it, or insult him by taking it into our own hands.
There is nothing so secret but it comes to
light.
There is nothing so sure of succeeding as not to be over brilliant, as to be entirely wrapped up in one's self, and endowed with a perseverance which, in spite of all the rebuffs it may meet with, never relaxes in the pursuit of its object.
There is nothing so terrible as activity without insight.
There is nothing to be found only once in the world.
There is nothing to which man is not related.
There is nothing which vanity does not desecrate.
There is nothing without us that is not also within us.
There is often a complaint of want of parts, when the fault lies in a want of a due improvement of them.
There is often more true spiritual force in a proverb than in a philosophical system.
There is / One great society alone on earth; / The noble living and the noble dead.
There is one preacher who does preach with
effect, and gradually persuade all persons; his name is Destiny, Divine Providence, and his sermon the inflexible course of things.
There is only one cure for public distress, and that is public education, directed to make men thoughtful, merciful, and just.
There is only one mendacious being in the world, and that is man.
There is only one thing better than tradition, and that is the original and eternal life out of which all tradition takes its rise.
There is only one true religion, but there may be many forms of belief.
There is poetry and beauty in the common
lives about us, if we look at them with imaginative and sympathetic eye.
There is power over and behind us, and we are the channels of its communication.
There is precious instruction to be got by finding that we are wrong.
There is properly but one slavery in the world--the slavery of wisdom to folly.
There is properly no history, only biography.
There is, properly speaking, no misfortune in
the world. Happiness and misfortune stand in continual balance. Every misfortune is, as it were, the obstruction of a stream, which, after overcoming this obstruction, but bursts forth with the greater force.
There is really something absurd about the Present; all that people think of is the sight, the touch of each other, and there they rest; but it never occurs to them to reflect upon what is to be gained from such moments.
There is safety in solitude.
There is scarce truth enough alive to make societies secure, but security enough to make fellowships accursed.
There is scarcely a good critic of books born in our age, and yet every fool thinks himself justified in criticising persons.
