There is sentiment in all women, and sentiment
gives delicacy to thought, and tact to manner. But sentiment with men is generally acquired, an offspring of the intellectual quality, not, as with the other sex, of the moral.
There is so much of good among the worst, so much of evil in the best, such seeming partialities in providence, so many things to lessen and expand, yea, and with all man's boast, so little real freedom of his will, that to look a little lower than the surface, garb, or dialect, or fashion, thou shalt feebly pronounce for a saint, and faintly condemn for a sinner.
There is so much trouble in coming into the world, and so much more, as well as meanness, in going out of it, that 'tis hardly worth while to be here at all.
There is some soul of goodness in things evil, / Would men observingly distil it out.
There is some use in having two attorneys in one firm. Their movements resemble those of the man and woman in a Dutch babyhouse. When it is fair weather with the client, out comes the gentleman partner to fawn like a spaniel; when it is foul, forth bolts the operative brother to pin like a bull-dog.
There is something behind the throne greater
than the king himself.
There is something in sorrow more akin to the course of human affairs than joy.
There is something irresistibly pleasing in the conversation of a fine woman; even though her tongue be silent, the eloquence of her eyes teach wisdom.
There is something more awful in happiness than in sorrow.
There is something not solid in the good that is done for us.
There is something of all men in every man.
There is something so moving in the very image of weeping beauty.
There is something too dear in the hope of seeing again.... "Dear heart, be quiet;" we say; "you will not be long separated from those people that you love; be quiet, dear heart!" And then we give it in the meanwhile a shadow, so that it has something, and then it is good and quiet, like a little child whose mother gives it a doll instead of the apple which it ought not to eat.
There is still a real magic in the action and reaction of minds on one another. The casual deliration of a few becomes, by this mysterious reverberation, the frenzy of many; men lose the use, not only of their understandings, but of their bodily senses; while the most obdurate unbelieving hearts melt like the rest in the furnace where all are cast as victims and as fuel.
There is still enough to satisfy one in spite of all misfortunes.
There is such a choice of difficulties that I am myself at a loss how to determine.
There is that maketh himself rich, yet hath nothing: there is that maketh himself poor, yet hath great riches.
There is that scattereth, and yet increaseth:
and there is that withholdeth more than is meet, but it tendeth to poverty.
There is very great necessity indeed of getting a little more silent than we are.
There is work on God's wide earth for all men that he has made with hands and hearts.
There lives more faith in honest doubt, believe me, than in half the creeds.
There may come a day when there shall be no more curse; in the meantime you must be humble and honest enough to take your share of it.
There may often be less vanity in following the
new modes than in adhering to the old ones. It is true that the foolish invent them, but the wise may conform to, instead of contradicting, them.
There must always remain something that is antagonistic to good.
There must be a man behind a book.
There must be hearts which know the depths of our being, and swear by us, even when the whole world forsakes us.
There must be work done by the arms, or none of us would live; and work done by the brains, or the life would not be worth having. And the same men cannot do both.
There must first be seducing men before
seduced women.
There needs no ghost, my lord, come from the grave / To tell us this.
There needs not a great soul to make a hero; there needs a god-created soul which will be true to its origin; that will be a great soul.
There never did and never will exist anything permanently noble and excellent in a character which was a stranger to the exercise of resolute self-denial.
There never was a bad man but had ability for good service.
There never was a great man unless through
Divine inspiration.
There never was a literary age whose dominant taste was not sickly.
There never was a talent, even for real literature, but was primarily a talent for something infinitely better of the silent kind.
There never was any heart truly great and generous that was not also tender and compassionate.
There never was any party, faction, or sect in which the most ignorant was not the most violent.
There never was so great a thought labouring
in the breasts of men as now.
There occur cases in human life when it is wisdom not to be too wise.
There remaineth a rest to the people of God.
There seems to be no part of knowledge in fewer hands than that of discerning when to have done.
There shall no evil happen to the just.
There the wicked cease from troubling, and
there the weary be at rest.
There was a little city, and few men within it; and there came a great king against it, and besieged it, and built bulwarks against it. Now there was found in it a poor wise man, and he by his wisdom delivered the city, yet no man remembered that same poor man.
There was a time when meadow, grove, and stream, / The earth and every common sight, / To me did seem / Apparelled in celestial light, / The glory and the freshness of a dream. / It is not now as it has been of yore; / Turn wheresoe'er I may, / By night or day, / The things which I have seen, I now can see no more.
There was a time when the world acted upon books. Now books act upon the world.
There was but one Moses to the thousands of Israel that entered Jordan.
There was never a nation great until it came
to the knowledge that it had nowhere in the world to go for help.
There was never good or ill but women had to do with it.
There was never yet philosopher / Who could endure the toothache patiently.
There was sense in the sentences, but the sum-total was nonsense.
There was speech in their dumbness, language in their very gesture.
There were no ill language if it were not ill
taken.
There where thou art, there where thou remainest, accomplish what thou canst.
There will always be a government of force where men are selfish.
There's a brave fellow! There's a man of pluck! / A man who is not afraid to say his say, / Though a whole town's against him.
There's a courage which grows out of fear.
There's a divinity that shapes our ends, /
Rough-hew them as we will.
There's a medium in thoughtfulness and gaiety: find it out and keep to it.
There's a special providence in the fall of a sparrow.
There's a sweeter flower than e'er / Blush'd on the rosy spray, / A brighter star, a richer bloom, / Than e'er did western heaven illume / At close of summer day--/ 'Tis Love, the last best gift of Heaven.
There's always life for the living.
There's beggary in the love that can be reckoned.
There's folks as make bad butter, and trusten to the salt t' hide it.
There's folks 'ud stand on their heads and then say the fault was in their boots.
There's husbandry in heaven; / Their candles are all out.
There's language in her eye, her cheeks, her
lip, / Nay, her foot speaks.
There's many a good bit o' work done with a sad heart.
There's many a slip / 'Twixt the cup and the lip.
There's mercy in every place, / And mercy, encouraging thought, / Gives even affliction a grace, / And reconciles man to his lot.
There's music in the sighing of a reed; / There's music in the gushing of a rill; / There's music in all things, if men had ears.
There's nae sorrow there, John, / There's
neither cauld nor care, John, / The day is aye fair, / In the land o' the leal.
There's no armour against fate.
There's no art / To find the mind's construction in the face.
There's no folk sic idiots as them that looks like geniuses.
There's no glory like his who saves his country.
There's no grace in a benefit that sticks to the
fingers.
There's no great banquet but some fares ill.
There's no pleasure i' living, if you're to be corked up for ever, and only dribble your mind out by the sly, like a leaky barrel.
There's no seeing one's way through tears.
There's no slipping up-hill again, and no standing still when once you've begun to slip down.
There's no work so tirin' as danglin' about an'
starin', an' not rightly knowin' what you're goin' to do next; an' keepin' your face i' smilin' order, like a grocer o' market-day.
There's not a joy the world can give like that it takes away.
There's not a place where Rest can say, / I'll not have Labour here; / For Rest itself would pine away / If Labour were not near.
There's not a string attuned to mirth / But has its chord in melancholy.
There's not one wise man among twenty that will praise himself.
There's not the smallest orb which thou behold'st, /
But in his motion like an angel sings, / Still quiring to the young-eyed cherubims.
There's nothing but what's bearable as long as a man can work.
There's nothing certain but uncertainty.
There's nothing half so sweet in life / As love's young dream.
There's nothing situate under heaven's eye, / But hath its bound in earth, in sea, in sky.
There's none that can / Read God aright, unless
he first spell man.
There's small choice in rotten apples.
There's something good in all weathers. If it don't happen to be good for my work to-day, it's good for some other man's to-day, and will come round to me to-morrow.
There's such divinity doth hedge a king, / That treason can but peep to what it would.
There's things it's best to put off kenning as long as we can.
Thereby hangs a tale.
These / Are but the varied God. The rolling year / Is full of thee.
"These are my jewels."
These cases, wherein happiness would be sinful, are just as much, but no more, the ordainments of Providence as those more common ones wherein happiness is natural and right.
These fair tales, which we know so beautiful, / Show only finer than our lives to-day / Because their voice was clearer, and they found / A sacred bard to sing them.
These limbs, whence had we them; this
stormy force; this life-blood with its burning passion? They are dust and shadow: a shadow-system gathered round our Me; wherein through some moments or years, the divine essence is to be revealed in flesh.
These little things are great to little men.
These moving things, ca'ed wife and weans, / Wad move the very heart o' stanes.
These violent delights have violent ends.
They are as sick that surfeit with too much, as they that starve with nothing.
They are but beggars that can count their
worth.
They are dead even for this life who hope for no better.
They are never alone that are accompanied with noble thoughts.
They are not a pipe for fortune's finger, / To sound what stop she please.
They are not all free who scorn their chains.
They are not kings who sit on thrones, but
they who know how to govern.
They are not sages who do not declare men's duty.
They are slaves who dare not be / In the right with two or three.
They asked Lucman the fabulist, "From whom did you learn manners?" He answered, "From the unmannerly."
They can conquer who believe they can.
They do most by books who could do much without them; and he that chiefly owes himself unto himself is the substantial man.
They ever do pretend / To have received a wrong who wrong intend.
They fool me to the top of my bent.
They found no end, in wandering mazes lost.
They grew in beauty side by side, / They fill'd
one home with glee; / Their graves are sever'd far and wide, / By mount, and stream, and sea.
They govern the world, these sweet-lipped women, because beauty is the index of a larger fact than wisdom.
They had the divine right of kings to settle, these unfortunate ancestors of ours; ... and they did, on hest of necessity, manage to settle it.
They have been at a great feast of languages, and stolen the scraps.
They have destroyed the beaten track to heaven; we are now compelled to make for ourselves ladders.
They laugh that win.
They lose it
They love least that let men know their love.
They love most who are least valued.
They love not poison that do poison need.
They love us truly who correct us freely.
They most assume who know the least.
They must hunger in winter that will not work in summer.
They must often change who would be constant in happiness or wisdom.
They never taste who always drink; / They always talk who never think.
They only are wise who know that they know
nothing.
They only babble that practise not reflection.
They only should own who can administer.
They only who build on ideas build for eternity.
They pass best over the world who trip over it quickly; for it is but bog--if we stop, we sink.
They said that Love would die when Hope was
gone, / And Love mourn'd long, and sorrow'd after Hope; / At last she sought out Memory, and they trod / The same old paths where Love had walk'd with Hope, / And Memory fed the soul of Love with tears.
They say best men are moulded out of faults, / And, for the most, become much more the better / For being a little bad.
They say Doubt is weak, but yet, if life be in the doubt, / The living doubt is more than Faith that life did never know.
"They say so" is half a lie.
They, sweet soul, that most impute a crime / Are pronest to it, and impute themselves, / Wanting the mental range; or low desire / Not to feel lowest makes them level all; / Yea, they would pare the mountain to the plain, / To leave an equal baseness.
They that are above have ends in everything.
They that are against superstition oftentimes run into it of the wrong side. If I wear all colours but black, then I am superstitious in not wearing black.
They that are booted are not always ready.
They that be whole need not a physician; but they that are sick.
They that be wise shall shine as the brightness of the firmament; and they that turn many to righteousness, as the stars for ever and ever.
They that bear a noble mind, / Where they
want of riches find.
They that by pleading clothes / Do fortunes seek, when worth and service fail, / Would have their tale believed for their oaths, / And are like empty vessels under sail.
They that deny a God destroy man's nobility. For, certainly, man is of kin to the beasts, by his body; and if he be not of kin to God by his spirit, he is a base and ignoble creature.
They that do change old love for new, / Pray gods, they change for worse.
They that do nothing are in the readiest way to do that which is worse than nothing.
They that drive away time spur a free horse.
They that govern the most make the least noise.
They that hold by the Divine / Clasp too the Human in their faith.
They that know one another salute afar off.
They that marry ancient people merely in expectation to bury them, hang themselves in hope that one will come and cut the halter.
They that mean to make no use of friends will
be at little trouble to gain them: and to be without friendship is to be without one of the first comforts of our present state.
They that observe lying vanities forsake their own mercy.
They that plough iniquity and sow wickedness reap the same.
They that stand high have many blasts to shake them; and if they fall, they dash themselves to pieces.
They that sow in tears shall reap in joy.
They that sow the wind shall reap the whirlwind.
They that will crowd about bonfires may, sometimes very fairly, get their beards singed; it is the price they pay for such illumination; natural twilight is safe and free to all.
They told me I was everything; 'tis a lie: I am not ague-proof.
They well deserve to have / That know the strong'st and surest way to get.
They went out from us, but they were not of us; for if they had been of us, they would no doubt have continued with us.
They who accuse and blacken thee wrongfully are much the greatest sufferers by their own malice and injustice.
They who but slowly pacèd are / By plodding on may travel far.
They who contract absurd habits are such as have no fear.
They who crouch to those who are above them, always trample on those who are below them.
They who do not feel the darkness will never
look for the light.
They who embrace the entire universe with love, for the most part love nothing but their narrow selves.
They who gratefully the gods adore, / Still find their joys increasing more and more.
They who have lost an infant are never, as it were, without an infant child.
They who have no other trade but seeking their fortune, need never hope to find her; coquette-like, she flies from her close pursuers, and at last fixes on the plodding mechanic who stays at home and minds his business.
They who lie soft and warm in a rich estate
seldom come to heat themselves at the altar.
They who oppose a Ministry have always a better field for ridicule and reproof than they who defend it.
They who place their affections on trifles at first for amusement, will find those trifles at last become their serious concern.
They who play with the devil's rattles will be brought by degrees to wield his sword.
They who pretend most to universal benevolence are either deceivers or dupes--men who desire to cover their private ill-nature by a pretended regard for all.
They who resign life rather than part with
liberty do only a prudent action; but those who lay it down for friends and country do a heroic one.
They who resist indiscriminately all improvement as innovation, may find themselves compelled at last to submit to innovations although they are not improvements.
They who seek only for faults see nothing else.
They who sustain their cross shall likewise be sustained by it in return.
They who travel in pursuit of wisdom walk only in a circle, and, after all their labour, at last return to their pristine ignorance.
They who want a farthing, and have no friend
that will lend them it, think farthings very good things.
They who want money when they come to borrow, will always want money when they should come to pay.
They who will watch Providence will never want a Providence to watch.
They whom truth and wisdom lead / Can gather honey from a weed.
Thick as autumnal leaves that strew the brooks / In Vallombrosa.
Thine ears shall hear a word behind thee,
saying, This is the way, walk ye in it, when ye turn to the right hand, and when ye turn to the left.
Thine is the right, for thine the might.
Thine own friend, and thy father's friend, forsake not; neither go into thy brother's house in the day of thy calamity: for better is a neighbour that is near than a brother far off.
Thine own worm be not: yet such jealousy, As hurts not others, but may make thee better, / Is a good spur.
Things all are big with jest; nothing that's plain / But may be witty, if thou hast the vein ... / Many affecting wit beyond their power, / Have got to be a dear fool for an hour.
Things are graceful in a friend's mouth which
are blushing in a man's own.
Things are his property alone who knows how to use them.
Things are long-lived, and God above appoints their term; yet when the brains of a thing have been out for three centuries and odd, one does wish it would be kind enough and die.
Things are not so false always as they seem.
Things are sullen, and will be as they are, whatever we think them or wish them to be.
Things are what they are by nature, not by
will.
Things at the worst will cease, or else climb upward / To what they were before.
Things bad begun make strong themselves by ill.
Things base and vile, holding no quantity, / Love can transpose to form and dignity.
Things fasten upon thee only according as the degree of thy own love and inclination for them gives opportunity and advantage.
Things good, great Jove, asked or unasked,
supply: / Things evil, though we ask for them, deny.
Things have their laws as well as men; and things refuse to be trifled with.
Things ill got had ever bad success.... I'll leave my son my virtuous deeds behind.
Things may serve long, but not serve ever.
Things more excellent than every image are expressed through images.
Things must turn when they can go no farther.
Things refuse to be mismanaged long.
Things seen are mightier than things heard.
Things will always right themselves in time, if only those who know what they want to do, and can do, persevere unremittingly in work and action.
Things will never be bettered by an excess of haste.
Things without remedy should be without regard; what is done, is done.
Things won are done; joy's soul lies in the doing.
Think all you speak, but speak not all you think.
Think and thank God.
Think naught a trifle, though it small appear; / Small sands the mountain, moments make the year, / And trifles life.
Think not, dream not that thou livest, / If thy hand doth idly lie, / If thy soul for ever longing, / Yearn but for the by and bye.
Think not I came to send peace on the earth; I came not to send peace but a sword.
Think not thy fame at every twitch will break; / By great deeds show that thou canst little do; / And do them not; that shall thy wisdom be; / And change thy temperance into bravery.
Think not thy own shadow longer than that of
others.
Think not your estate your own, while any man can call upon you for money which you cannot pay.
Think of ease, but work on.
Think of "living!" Thy life, wert thou the "pitifullest of all the sons of earth," is no idle dream, but a solemn reality. It is thy own; it is all thou hast to front eternity with.
Think of the hosts of worlds, and of the plagues in this world-mote--death puts an end to the whole.
Think with awe on the slow, the quiet power
of time.
Think wrongly, if you please, but in all cases think for yourself.
Think ye that God made the universe, and then let it run round his finger?
Think you, 'mid all this mighty sum / Of things for ever speaking, / That nothing of itself will come, / But we must still be seeking.
Thinkers are scarce as gold; but he whose thoughts embrace all his subject, pursues it uninterruptedly and fearless of consequences, is a diamond of enormous size.
Think'st thou existence doth depend on time? /
It doth; but actions are our epochs.
Thinking about sin, beyond what is indispensable for the firm effort to get rid of it, is waste of energy and waste of time.
Thinking is but an idle waste of thought; / For nought is everything, and everything is nought.
Thinking is the function; living is the functionary.
Thinking leads man to knowledge. He may see and hear, and read and learn, whatever he pleases, and as much as he pleases; he will never know anything of it, except that which he has thought over, that which by thinking he has made the property of his mind.
Thinking nurseth thinking.
This above all; to thine own self be true, / And it must follow as the night the day, / Thou canst not then be false to any man.
This bodes some strange eruption to our state.
This century is not ripe for my ideal; I live a citizen of those that are to come.
"This comes of walking on the earth."
This communicating of a man's self to his
friend works two contrary effects, for it redoubleth joys and cutteth griefs in halves.
This day / Shall change all griefs and quarrels into love.
This day's propitious to be wise in.
This even-handed justice / Commends the ingredients of our poison'd chalice / To our own lips.
This ever-renewing generation of appearances rests on a reality, and a reality that is alive.
This fell sergeant, death, / Is strict in his
arrest.
This hand, to tyrants ever sworn the foe, / For freedom only deals the deadly blow: / Then sheathes in calm repose the vengeful blade / For gentle peace in freedom's hallowed shade.
This I think charity--to love God for himself, and our neighbour for God.
This is a great--properly the greatest--moment in a man's life, when, reconciling himself to necessity, he is able with clearness of purpose to say, "Let the will of the gods be done."
"This is a sharp medicine, but it cures all disorders."
This is faith; it is nothing more than obedience.
This is how I define talent; it is a gift God has given us in secret, which we reveal without knowing it.
This is not a time for purism of style; and style has little to do with the worth or unworth of a book.
This is not the liberty which we can hope, that no grievance should arise in the commonwealth, but when complaints are freely heard, deeply considered, and speedily reformed, then is the utmost bound of civil liberty attained that wise men look for.
This is the first condition of a living morality as well as of vital religion, that the soul shall find a true centre out from and above itself, round which it shall revolve.
This is the humour of it.
This is the monstrosity in love--that the will is infinite, and the execution confined; that the desire is boundless, and the act a slave to limit.
This is the state of man: to-day he puts forth / The tender leaves of hopes; to-morrow blossoms, / And bears his blushing honours thick upon him; / The third day comes a frost, a killing frost; / And when he thinks, good easy man, full surely / His greatness is a-ripening, nips his root, / And then he falls, as I do.
This is the very coinage of your brain; / This bodiless creation ecstasy / Is very cunning in.
This is the very curse of an evil deed, that it engenders and must bring forth more evil.
This is true philanthropy, that buries not its gold in ostentatious charity, but builds its hospital in the human heart.
This low man seeks a little thing to do, / Sees it and does it; / This high man, with a great thing to pursue, / Dies ere he knows it.
This man receiveth sinners, and eateth with
them.
This narrow isthmus 'twixt two boundless seas, / The past, the future--two eternities.
This nothing's more than matter.
This of old is sure, / That change of toil is toil's sufficient cure.
This one fact the world hates--that the soul becomes.
This present is a ruinous and ruining world.
This she knows in joys and woes, / That saints will aid if men will call; / For the blue sky bends over all.
This so solid-seeming world is, after all, but an air-image, our Me the only reality; and Nature, with its thousand-fold production and destruction, but the reflex of our own inward force, the "Phantasy of our Dream," or, what the earth-spirit in "Faust" names it, "the living visible garment of God."
This time, like all times, is a very good one, if we but knew what to do with it.
This was a man.
This was the most unkindest cut of all.
This will prove a brave kingdom to me, where I shall have my music for nothing.
This world belongs to the energetic.
This world is a busy scene, and man a creature destined for a progressive struggle.
This world is all a fleeting show, / For man's illusion given: / The smiles of joy, the tears of woe, / Deceitful shine, deceitful flow, / There's nothing true but heaven.
This world is full of fools, and he who would
not wish to see one must not only shut himself up alone, but must also break his looking-glass.
This world surely is wide enough to hold both thee and me!
This world, where much is to be done and little to be known.
Thistles and thorns prick sore, but evil tongues prick more.
Tho' men may bicker with the things they love, / They would not make them laughable in all eyes, / Not while they loved them.
Tho' world on world in myriad myriads roll /
Round us, each with different powers, / And other form of life than ours, / What know we greater than the soul?
Those are not empty-hearted whose low sound / Reverbs no hollowness.
Those are often raised into the greatest transports of mirth who are subject to the greatest depressions of melancholy.
Those deserve to be doubly laughed at that are peevish and angry for nothing to no purpose.
Those faces which have charmed us the most escape us the soonest.
Those faults conscience has not strength to
prevent, it seldom has justice enough to accuse.
Those friends thou hast, and their adoption tried, / Grapple them to thy soul with hoops of steel.
Those holy fields / Over whose acres walked those blessèd feet / Which, fourteen hundred years ago were nailed, / For our advantage, on the bitter cross.
Those of us who are worth anything spend our manhood in unlearning the follies or expiating the mistakes of our youth.
Those only are beautiful which, like the planets, have a steady, lambent light--are luminous, not sparkling.
Those only are despicable who fear to be
despised.
Those only deserve a monument who do not need one.
Those only obtain love, for the most part, who seek it not.
Those only who know little can be said to know anything. The greater the knowledge the greater the doubt.
Those people who are always improving never become great. Greatness is an eminence, the ascent to which is steep and lofty, and which a man must seize on at once by natural boldness and vigour, and not by patient, wary steps.
Those persons who do most good are least
conscious of it.
Those tender tears that humanise the soul.
Those that are the loudest in their threats are the weakest in the execution of them.
Those that come unsought for are commonly the most valuable, and should be secured, because they seldom return.
Those that dare lose a day are dangerously prodigal; those that dare misspend it, desperate.
Those that fly may fight again, / Which he can
never do that's slain.
Those that have loved longest love best.
Those that think must govern those that toil.
Those that with haste will make a mighty fire, / Begin with weak straws.
Those who are bent to do wickedly will never want tempters to urge them on.
Those who are elevated enough in life to reason
and to reflect, yet low enough to keep clear of the venal contagion of a court--these are a nation's strength!
Those who are quite satisfied sit still and do nothing; those who are not quite satisfied are the sole benefactors of the world.
Those who attempt to level never equalise; they load the edifice of society by setting up in the air what the solidity of the structure requires to be on the ground.
Those who attempt to reason us out of our follies, begin at the wrong end, since the attempt naturally presupposes us capable of reason.
Those who bring sunshine to the lives of others cannot keep it from themselves.
Those who can sit at home and gloat over their thousands in silent satisfaction are generally found to do it in plain clothes.
Those who carry much upon their clothes
are remarked for having but little in their pockets.
Those who do nothing generally take to shouting.
Those who dwell in fear dwell next door to hate; and I think it is the cowardice of women that makes them such intense haters.
Those who educate children well are more to be honoured than they who produce them; for these only gave them life, those the art of living well.
Those who first study fate, and say, Fate is the only cause of fortune and misfortune, terrify themselves.
Those who give the first shock to a state are
naturally the first to be overwhelmed in its ruin. The fruits of public commotion are seldom enjoyed by the man who was the first to set it a-going; he only troubles the waters for another's net.
Those who have even studied good books may still be fools.
Those who injure one party to benefit another are quite as unjust as if they converted the property of others to their own benefit.
Those who make the best use of their time have none to spare.
Those who make the worst use of their time most complain of its shortness.
Those who only run after little things will not
go far.
Those who profess most are ever the least sincere.
Those who regularly undertake to cultivate friendship find ingratitude generally repays their endeavours.
Those who seek for something more than happiness in this world must not complain if happiness be not their portion.
Those who seem to doubt or deny us what is justly ours, let us either pity their prejudice or despise their judgment.
Those who set their minds to deny things, and
are fond of pulling things to pieces, must be treated like deniers-of-motion; one need only keep incessantly walking up and down before them in as composed a manner as possible.
Those who trust us educate us.
Those who will not be ruled by the rudder must be ruled by the rock.
Those who would make us feel must feel themselves.
Thou art Heaven's tasker; and thy God requires / The purest of thy flour, as well as of thy fires.
Thou art ignorant of what thou art, and much
more ignorant of what is fit for thee.
Thou art in the end what thou art.
Thou art not alone if thou have faith. There is a communion of saints, unseen, yet not unreal, accompanying and brotherlike embracing thee, so thou be worthy.
Thou art the ruin of the noblest man / That ever lived in the tide of times.
Thou art thyself to all eternity.
Thou awakest us to delight in thy praise; for
thou madest us for thyself, and our heart is restless until it repose in thee.
Thou bear'st thy heavy riches but a journey, / And death unloads thee.
Thou canst not be entirely free till thou hast attained to such a mastery as entirely to subdue and deny thyself.
Thou dost not strive, O Sun, but, meek and still, / Thou dost the type of Jesus best fulfil, / A noiseless revelation in the sky.
Thou hast given me / A world of earthly blessings to my soul, / If sympathy of love unite our thoughts.
Thou hast not what others have, and others
have not the gift thou hast. From this imperfection springs sociability.
Thou little thinkest what a little foolery governs the world.
Thou mayest as well expect to grow stronger by always eating, as wiser by always reading.
Thou mayest be more prodigal of praise when thou writest a letter than when thou speakest in presence.
Thou must learn to break thine own will in many things if thou wilt have peace and concord with others.
Thou must live unto another if thou wilt live
unto thyself.
Thou must renounce; thou must abstain! is the eternal song which sounds in the ears of every one, which every hour is singing to us all our life long.
Thou, Nature, art my goddess; to thy law / My services are bound.
Thou of an independent mind, / With soul resolved, with soul resigned; / Prepared Power's proudest frown to brave, / Who wilt not be, nor have a slave; / Virtue alone who dost revere, / Thy own reproach alone dost fear, / Approach this shrine
and worship here.
Thou shall hear no more complaints from me; thou shalt hear only what happens to the wanderer.
"Thou shalt" is written upon life in characters
as legible as "Thou shalt not."
Thou shalt look outward, not inward.
Thou shalt not muzzle the ox that treadeth out the corn.
Thou, too curious ear, that fain / Wouldst thread the maze of Harmony, / Content thee with one simple strain, / ... Till thou art duly trained, and taught / The concord sweet of Love divine.
Thou who didst the stars and sunbeams know, / Self-schooled, self-scanned, self-honoured, self-secure, / Didst walk on earth unguessed at.
Thou! why, thou wilt quarrel with a man that hath a hair more or a hair less in his beard than thou hast. Thou wilt quarrel with a man for cracking nuts, having no other reason but because thou hast hazel eyes.... Thy head is full of quarrels as an egg is full of meat.
Thou wilt never sell thy life, or any part of thy life, in a satisfactory manner. Give it like a royal heart; let the price of it be nothing; then hast thou in a certain sense got all for it.
Thou would'st as soon go kindle fire with snow, / As seek to quench the fire of love with words.
Thou wouldst do little for God if the devil
were dead.
Though a man may become learned by another's learning, he never can be wise but by his own wisdom.
Though a sinner do evil an hundred times, and his days be prolonged, yet surely I know that it shall be well with them that fear God, which fear before him.
Though all his works abroad, / The heart benevolent and kind / The most resembles God.
Though ambition in itself is a vice, yet it is often the parent of virtues.
Though an honourable title may be conveyed
to posterity, yet the ennobling qualities which are the soul of greatness are a sort of incommunicable perfections, and cannot be transferred.
Though gentle, yet not dull, / Strong without rage, without o'erflowing, full.
Though great the force of little words, / Sped in an evil hour, / As great the might, and great the good, / Of one in Wisdom's power.
Though He comes in many shapes, / His love is throbbing in them all, / And from His love no soul escapes, / And from His mercy none can fall.
Though he says nothing, he pays it with thinking, like the Welshman's jackdaw.
Though He slay me, I shall yet trust in Him.
Though I am always in haste, I am never in a hurry.
Though justice be thy plea, consider this--/ That in the course of justice none of us / Should see salvation.
Though last, not least.
Though little fire grows great with little wind, / Yet extreme gusts will blow out fire and all.
Though losses and crosses / Be lessons right
severe, / There's wit there ye'll get there, / Ye'll find nae ither where.
Though lost to sight, to memory dear.
Though love cannot plant morals in the human breast, it cultivates them when there.
Though much is taken, much abides.
Though old the thought and oft repress'd, / 'Tis his at last who says it best.
Though peace be in every man's wishes, yet
the qualifications and predispositions necessary for procuring and preserving it are the care of very few.
Though scorn's malignant glances / Prove him poorest of his clan, / He's the noble--who advances / Freedom, and the cause of Man!
Though stars in skies may disappear, / And angry tempests gather, / The happy hour may soon be near / That brings us pleasant weather.
Though the cat winks a while, yet sure she is not blind.
Though the heavens fall, the orbs of truth and justice fall not.
Though the world exists for thought, thought
is daunted in presence of the world.
Though this be madness, yet there is method in't.
Though thousands hate physic, because of the cost, / Yet thousands it helpeth, that else should be lost.
Though we lose our fortune, yet we should not lose our patience.
Though wisdom wake, suspicion sleeps / At wisdom's gate; and to simplicity / Resigns her charge, while goodness thinks no ill where no ill seems.
Though you can fret me, you cannot play upon
me.
Though you had the wisdom of Newton or the wit of Swift, garrulousness would lower you in the eyes of your fellow-creatures.
Though you stroke the nettle ever so kindly, yet it will sting you.
Thought and science follow their own law of development; they are slowly elaborated in the growth and forward pressure of humanity, in what Shakespeare calls ... The prophetic soul / Of the wide world dreaming on things to come.
Thought discovered is the more possessed.
Thought disturbs the world, and thought of
God / Unsettles most of all; for it is life, / And only life can comprehend its force, / Or guide it.
Thought expands, but lames; action animates, but narrows.
Thought is deeper than all speech; / Feeling deeper than all thought; / Souls to souls can never teach / What unto themselves was taught.
Thought is free.
Thought is like opium: it can intoxicate us while it leaves us broad awake.
Thought is silence.
Thought is the property of him who can entertain it, and of him who can adequately place it.
Thought is the seed of action; but action is as much its second form as thought is its first. It rises in thought, to the end that it may be uttered and acted. The more profound the thought, the more burdensome. Always in proportion to the depth of its sense does it knock importunately at the gates of the soul, to be spoken, to be done.
Thought is the wind, knowledge the sail, and mankind the vessel.
Thought means life, since those who do not think do not live in any high or real sense. Thinking makes the man.
Thought once awakened does not again slumber.
Thought takes man out of servitude into freedom.
Thought, true labour of any kind, highest
virtue itself, is it not the daughter of pain? Born as out of the black whirlwind; true effort in fact, as of a captive struggling to free itself--that is thought.
Thought without reverence is barren, perhaps poisonous; at best dies, like cookery, with the day that called it forth.
Thought works in silence, so does virtue.
Thoughtlessness is precisely the chief public calamity of our day.
Thoughts are but dreams till their effects be tried.
Thoughts are not always at our beck; we
must wait till they come.
Thoughts
fool; / And time, that takes survey of all the world, / Must have a stop.
Thoughts are your own; your words are so no more.
Thoughts come into our minds by avenues which we never left open, and thoughts go out of our minds through avenues which we never voluntary opened.
Thoughts shut up want air, and spoil, like bales unopened to the sun.
Thoughts take up no room.
Thoughts that breathe and words that burn.
Thoughts that do often lie too deep for tears.
Thoughts that voluntary move / Harmonious numbers.
Thoughts we have had and pictures we have seen can be recalled by the mind; but the heart is not so obliging; it does not reproduce our pleasing emotions.
Threaten the threatener, and outface the
brow / Of bragging horror; so shall inferior eyes, / That borrow their behaviours from the great, / Grow great by your example, and put on / The dauntless spirit of resolution.
Threatened folks live long.
Three may keep a secret--if two of them are dead.
Three poets in three distant ages born, / Greece, Italy, and England did adorn. / The first in loftiness of thought surpass'd; / The next, in majesty; in both, the last. / The force of Nature could no further go; / To make a third, she join'd the former two.
Three removes are as bad as a fire.
Three things drive a man out of doors--smoke,
a leaking roof, and a scolding wife.
Three things that enrich genius are contentment of mind, the cherishing of good thoughts, and the exercise of memory.
Three thousand miles of ocean space are less impressive than three miles bounded by rugged mountain walls.
Three women and a goose make a market.
Thrice happy he who without rigour saves.
Thrice happy life that's from ambition free.
Thrice is he arm'd that hath his quarrel just; / And he but naked, though locked up in steel, / Whose conscience with injustice is corrupted.
Thrift must begin with little savings.
Thrifty be, but not covetous.
Through certain humours or passions, and from temper merely, a man may be completely miserable, let his outward circumstances be ever so fortunate.
Through every star, through every grass
blade, and most through every living soul, the glory of a present God still beams.
Through steep ascents, through strait and rugged ways, / Ourselves to glory's lofty seats we raise: / In vain he hopes to reach the bless'd abode / Who leaves the narrow path for the more easy road.
Through tatter'd clothes small vices do appear; / Robes and furr'd gowns hide all.
Through "the ruins of a falling era," not once missing his footing.
Through want of enterprise and faith men are where they are, buying and selling, and spending their lives like serfs.
Through wisdom is an house builded; and by
understanding it is established; and by knowledge shall the chambers be filled with all precious and pleasant riches.
Throw no gift again at the giver's head; / Better is half a loaf than no bread.
Throw physic to the dogs; I'll none of it.
Thu' nur das Rechte in deinen Sachen, / Das Andre wird sich von selber machen
Thursday come, and the week's gone.
Thus grief still treads upon the heels of pleasure;
/ Married in haste, we may repent at leisure.
Thus the native hue of resolution / Is sicklied o'er with the pale cast of thought.
Thus the whirligig of time brings in his revenges.
Thus we play the fools with the time; and the spirits of the wise sit in the clouds, and mock us.
Thus when I shun Scylla, your father, I fall into Charybdis, your mother.
Thus with the year / Seasons return; but not
to me returns / Day, or the sweet approach of even or morn, / Or sight of vernal bloom or summer's rose, / Or flocks, or herds, or human face divine; / But cloud instead, and ever-during dark / Surrounds me.
Thy actions, and thy actions alone, determine thy worth.
Thy friend put in thy bosom; wear his eyes / Still in thy heart, that he may see what's there. / If cause require, thou art his sacrifice.... / But love is lost; the way of friendship's gone.
Thy hand is never the worse for doing thy own work.
Thy love to me was wonderful, passing the love of women.
Thy nature / It is too full of the milk of human
kindness / To catch the nearest way.
Thy people shall be willing in the day of thy power.
Thy praise or dispraise is to me alike, / One doth not stroke me, nor the other strike.
Thy secret is thy prisoner.
Thy soul was like a star and dwelt apart.
Thy spirit, Independence, let me share; / Lord
of the lion-heart and eagle-eye! / Thy steps I follow with my bosom bare, / Nor heed the storm that howls along the sky!
Thy sum of duty let two words contain; / Be humble and be just.
Thy true beginning and Father is in heaven, whom with the bodily eye thou shalt never behold, but only with the spiritual.
Thy wish was father, Harry, to that thought.
Tibi nullum periculum esse perspicio, quod quidem sejunctum sit ab omnium interitu
Tickle me, Bobby, and I'll tickle you.
Tie up thy fears. / He that forbears / To suit and serve his need, / Deserves his load.
Tie your camel up as best you can, and then trust it to Providence.
Tief und ernstlich denkende Menschen haben gegen das Publikum einen bösen Stand
Tief zu denken und schön zu empfinden ist Vielen gegeben; Dichter ist nur, wer schön sagt was er dacht' und empfand
Tiens à la vérité
Tiens à ta foy
Tiers état
Till the hand ... from reed or string / Draws out faint echoes of the voice Divine / That bring God nearer to a faithless world.
Time and chance can do nothing for those who will do nothing for themselves. Providence itself can scarcely save a people who are not prepared to make a struggle for their safety.
Time and I against any two.
Time and space are not God, but creations of God; with God, as it is a universal Here, so is it an everlasting Now.
Time and thinking tame the strongest grief.
Time antiquates antiquities, and hath an art to make dust of all things.
Time, as it is, cannot stay; / Nor again, as it was, can it be; / Disappearing and passing away / Are the world, and the ages, and we.
Time brings roses.
Time conquers all, and we must time obey.
Time consecrates; and what is grey with age becomes religion.
Time destroys the speculations of man, but it confirms the judgment of nature.
Time devours all things.
Time dissipates to shining ether the solid
angularity of facts.
Time drinketh up the essence of every great and noble action which ought to be performed, and is delayed in the execution.
Time elaborately thrown away.
Time gives prudence; the lord of time, inspiration; the one is a reward, the other a gift.
Time has a strange contracting influence on many a wide-spread fame.
Time has only a relative existence.
Time incessantly hasteneth on; he seeks for perfection; if thou art true, thou canst cast fetters eternal on him.
Time is a continual over-dropping of moments, which fall down one upon the other and evaporate.
Time is a strange thing. It is a whimsical tyrant, which in every century has a different face for all that one says and does.
Time is a wonder-working god. In one hour many thousand grains of sand run out, so quickly do thoughts stir in the minds of men.
Time is but a stream I go a-fishing in. I
drink at it; but while I drink I see the sandy bottom, and detect how shallow it is. Its thin current slides away, but eternity remains. I would drink deeper, fish in the sky, whose bottom is pebbly with stars.
Time is but the measure of the difficulty of a conception. Pure thought has scarcely any need of time, since it perceives the two ends of an idea almost the same moment.
Time is eternity, / Pregnant with all eternity can give.
Time is generally the best doctor.
Time is incalculably long, and every day is a vessel into which very much may be poured, if one will really fill it up.
Time is like a fashionable host, / That slightly
shakes his parting guest by the hand; / And with his arms outstretched, as he would fly, / Grasps in the comer.
Time is like a river, in which metals and solid substances are sunk, while chaff and straws swim upon the surface.
Time is money.
Time is never more misspent than while we declaim against the want of it.
Time is of more value than type, and the wear and tear of temper than an extra page of index.
Time is the chrysalis of eternity.
Time is the life of the soul. If not this, then tell me what is time?
Time is the most undefinable yet paradoxical of things; the past is gone, the future is not come, and the present becomes the past, even while we attempt to define it, and, like the flash of the lightning, at once exists and expires.
Time is the nurse and breeder of all good.
Time is the old Justice that examines all offenders.
Time is the stuff life is made of.
Time is the wheel-track in which we roll on towards eternity.
Time is trouble and the author of destruction; he seizeth even from afar.
Time reposes on eternity; the truly great and
transcendental has its basis and substance in eternity; stands revealed to us as eternity in a vesture of time.
Time shall unfold what plaited cunning hides: / Who cover faults, at last shame them derides.
Time, that black and narrow isthmus between two eternities.
Time the shuttle drives, but you / Give to every thread its hue, / And elect your destiny.
Time trieth truth.
Time was when a Christian used to apologise
for being happy. But the day has always been when he ought to apologise for being miserable.
Time wasted is existence; used, is life.
Time, when well husbanded, is like a cultivated field, of which a few acres produce more of what is useful to life, than extensive provinces, even of the richest soil, when overrun with weeds and brambles.
Time, which deadens hatred, secretly strengthens love; and in the hour of threatened separation its growth is manifested at once in radiant brightness.
Time will discover everything to posterity; it is a babbler, and speaks even when no question is put.
Time works great changes.
Time writes no wrinkle on thine azure brow; / Such as creation's dawn beheld, thou rollest now.
Time's best gift to us is serenity.
Time's noblest offspring is the last.
Time's the king of men; / He's both their parent and he is their grave, / And gives them what he will, not what they crave.
Time's waters will not ebb nor stay; / Power
cannot change them, but Love may; / What cannot be, Love counts it done.
Timely advised, the coming evil shun; / Better not do the deed, than weep it done.
Timeo Danaos, et dona ferentes
Times of general calamity and confusion have ever been productive of the greatest minds.
Timet pudorem
Timidi mater non flet
Timidus se vocat cautum, parcum sordidus
Timor Domini fons vitæ
Tinsel reflects the sun, but warms nothing.
Tired Nature's sweet restorer, balmy Sleep! / He, like the world, his ready visit pays / Where Fortune smiles; the wretched he forsakes: / Swift on his downy pinions flies from woe, / And lights on lids unsullied with a tear.
Tirer le diable par la queue
Tirer les marrons du feu avec la patte du chat
Tirez le rideau; la farce est jouée
'Tis a consummation / Devoutly to be wished.
'Tis a cruelty / To load a falling man.
'Tis a folly to fret; grief's no comfort.
'Tis a good ill that comes alone.
'Tis a kind of good deed to say well: / And yet words are no deeds.
'Tis a lucky day, boy, and we'll do good deeds on't.
'Tis a physic that's bitter to sweet end.
'Tis a question whether adversity or prosperity
makes the most poets.
'Tis a vile thing to die ... / When men are unprepar'd and look not for it.
'Tis all one to be a witch as to be counted one.
'Tis always a delightful thing to see the human understanding following its imprescriptible rights in spite of all hindrances, and hurrying eagerly towards the utmost possible agreement between ideas and objects.
'Tis an economy of time to read old and famed books.
'Tis an old maxim in the schools / That flattery's
the food of fools; / Yet now and then your men of wit / Will condescend to take a bit.
'Tis beauty that doth oft make women proud; / 'Tis virtue that doth make them most admired; / 'Tis government that makes them seem divine.
'Tis better to be lowly born, / And range with humble livers in content, / Than to be perked up in a glistering grief, / And wear a golden sorrow.
'Tis better to cry over your goods than after them.
'Tis better to have loved and lost / Than never to have loved at all.
'Tis but a base, ignoble mind / That mounts no higher than a bird can soar.
'Tis but lame kindness that does its work by halves.
'Tis, by comparison, an easy task / Earth to despise; but to converse with heaven--/ This is not easy.
'Tis certainly much easier for a man to restrain himself from talking at all, than to enter into discourse without saying more than becomes him.
'Tis day still while the sun shines.
'Tis death to me to be at enmity; / I hate it, and desire all good men's love.
'Tis distance lends enchantment to the view, / And robes the mountain in its azure hue.
'Tis education forms the common mind, / Just as the twig is bent, the tree's inclined.
'Tis ever common that men are merriest when they are from home.
'Tis expectation makes a blessing dear; /
Heaven were not heaven if we knew what it were.
'Tis God / Diffused through all that doth make all one whole.
'Tis heaven alone that is given away; / 'Tis only God may be had for the asking.
'Tis impossible you should take true root, but by the fair weather that you make yourself; it is needful that you frame the season for your own harvest.
'Tis, in fact, utter folly to ask whether a person has anything from himself, or whether he has it from others, whether he operates by himself, or operates by means of others. The main point is to have a great will, and skill and perseverance to carry it out. All else is indifferent.
'Tis life itself to love.
'Tis life reveals to each his genuine worth.
'Tis little we can do for each other.
'Tis long since death had the majority.
'Tis mad idolatry / To make the service greater than the god.
'Tis my opinion 'tis necessary to be happy,
that we think no place more agreeable than that where we are.
'Tis my vocation, Hal; 'tis no sin for a man to labour in his vocation.
'Tis not a lip, or eye, we beauty call, / But the joint force and full result of all.
'Tis not always necessary that truth should be embodied; it is sufficient if it hovers about in the spirit, producing harmony; if, like the chime of bells, it vibrates through the air solemnly and kindly.
'Tis not enough to keep the feeble up, / But to support them after.
'Tis not enough when swarming faults are
writ, / That here and there are scatter'd sparks of wit.
'Tis not enough your counsel still be true; / Blunt truths more mischief than nice falsehoods do.
'Tis not in mortals to command success, / But we'll do more, Sempronius--we'll deserve it.
'Tis not prudent, 'tis not well, to meet / With purposed misconception any man, / Let him be who he may.
'Tis not so above: / There is no shuffling; there the action lies / In its true nature.
'Tis not the drinking that is to be blamed, but
the excess.
'Tis not the whole of life to live, / Nor all of death to die.
'Tis not want, but rather abundance, that creates avarice.
'Tis not what man does which exalts him, but what man would do.
'Tis not worth while quarrelling with the world, simply to afford it some amusement.
'Tis now the very witching time of night, /
When churchyards yawn, and hell itself breathes out / Contagion to this world.
'Tis only humanity as a whole that perceives Nature, only men collectively that live the life of man.
'Tis only in Rome one can duly prepare one's self for Rome.
'Tis only in the forehead Nature plants the watchful eye; the back, without defence, must find its shield in man's fidelity.
'Tis only noble to be good; / Kind hearts are more than coronets, / And simple faith than Norman blood.
'Tis only strict precision of thought that confers
facility of expression.
'Tis only woman's womanly beauty that makes a true queen; wherever she appears, and by her mere presence, she asserts her sovereignty.
'Tis pleasant, sure, to see one's name in print; / A book's a book, although there's nothing in't.
'Tis rashness to conclude affairs in a lost condition because some crosses have baulked your expectations.
'Tis said fantastic ocean doth unfold the likeness of whate'er on land is seen.
'Tis said that virtue dwells sublime / On
rugged cliffs, full hard to climb; / ... But mortal ne'er her form may see, / Unless his restless energy / Breaks forth in sweat that gains the goal, / The perfect manhood of the soul.
'Tis strange; / And oftentimes to win us to our harm, / The instruments of darkness tell us truths; / Win us with honest trifles, to betray 's, / In deepest consequence.
'Tis sweet to hear of heroes dead, / To know them still alive, / But sweeter if we earn their bread, / And in us they survive.
'Tis the curse of service; preferment goes by letter and affection, not by the old gradation where each second stood heir to the first.
'Tis the divinity that stirs within us; / 'Tis heaven itself that points out an hereafter, / And intimates eternity to man.
'Tis the fate of the noblest soul to sigh vainly
for a reflection of itself.
'Tis the fine souls who serve us, and not what is called fine society.
'Tis the fulness of man that runs over into objects, and makes his Bibles and Shakespeares and Homers so great.
'Tis the good reader that makes the good book; a good head cannot read amiss; in every book he finds passages which seem confidences, or asides, hidden from all else and unmistakably meant for his ear.
'Tis the mind that makes the body rich; / And as the sun breaks through the darkest clouds, / So honour peereth in the meanest habit.
'Tis the old secret of the gods that they come in low disguises. 'Tis the vulgar great who come dizened with gold and jewels.
'Tis the part of a poor spirit to undervalue
himself and blush.
'Tis the same to him who wears a shoe as if the whole earth were thatched with leather.
'Tis the sublime of man, / Our noontide majesty, to know ourselves / Parts and proportions of one wondrous whole! / This fraternises man, this constitutes / Our charities and bearings.
'Tis this
'Tis too much proved that, with devotion's visage / And pious action, we do sugar o'er / The devil himself.
'Tis well for once to do everything one can do,
in order to have the merit of knowing one's self more intimately.
'Tis well to be merry and wise, / 'Tis well to be honest and true; / 'Tis well to be off with the old love / Before you are on with the new.
'Tis when sovereigns build, carters are kept employed.
'Tis with our judgments as our watches; none / Go just alike, yet each believes his own.
Tit for tat is fair play.
Titles and mottoes to books are like escutcheons
and dignities in the hands of a king. The wise sometimes condescend to accept of them; but none but a fool would imagine them of any real importance. We ought to depend upon intrinsic merit, and not the slender helps of the title.
Titles of honour add not to his worth who is himself an honour to his title.
Titles of honour conferred upon such as have no personal merit are at best but the royal stamp set upon base metal.
Titus, amor et deliciæ humani generis
To a child in confinement its mother's knee is a binding-post.
To a dog the choicest thing in the world is a
dog: to an ox, an ox; to an ass, an ass; and to a sow, a sow.
To a father waxing old nothing is dearer than a daughter.
To a father, when his child dies, the future dies; to a child when his parents die, the past dies.
To a new truth nothing is more mischievous than an old error.
To a poet nothing can be useless.
To accuse a man of lying is as much as to say
he is brave towards God and a coward towards man.
To achieve great things a man must so live as if he had never to die.
To acquire certainty in the appreciation of things exactly as they are, and to know them in their due subordination, and in their proper relation to one another--this is really the highest enjoyment to which we ought to aspire, whether in the sphere of art, of nature, or of life.
To act is easy, to think is hard; to act according to our thought is troublesome.
To act with a purpose is what raises man above the brutes; to invent with a purpose, to imitate with a purpose, is that which distinguishes genius from the petty artists who only invent to invent, and imitate to imitate.
To adhere to what is set down in them, and
appropriate to one's self what one can for moral strengthening and culture, is the only edifying purpose to which we can turn the Gospels.
To affect a quality is just to confess that you have not got it.
To aim at excellence, our reputation, our friends, and our all must be ventured; by aiming only at mediocrity, we run no risk and we do little service.
To an ill-conditioned being all pleasure is like delicate wine in a mouth embittered with gall.
To answer a question so as to admit of no reply, is the test of a man.
To appear well-bred, a man must actually be
so.
To appreciate the noble is a gain which can never be torn from us.
To arrive at perfection, a man should have very sincere friends or inveterate enemies; because he would be made sensible of his good or ill conduct, either by the censures of the one or the admonitions of the other.
To attack vices in the abstract without touching persons, may be safe fighting indeed, but it is fighting with shadows.
To banish care, scare away sorrow, and soothe pain is the business of the poet, or singer
To be a good poet and painter genius is required,
and this cannot be communicated.
To be a man's own fool is bad enough; but the vain man is everybody's.
To be a philosopher is but a retreat from the world, as it is man's, into the world, as it is God's.
To be a philosopher is not merely to have subtle thoughts, nor even to found a school, but so to love wisdom as to live, according to its dictates, a life of simplicity, independence, magnanimity, and trust. It is to solve some of the problems of life, not only theoretically, but practically.
To be a poet is to have a soul in which knowledge passes instantaneously into feeling, and feeling flashes back as a new organ of knowledge.
To be able simply to say of a man he has character, is not only saying much of him, but extolling him; for this is a rarity which excites respect and wonder.
To be able to be silent shows power; to be willing to be silent shows forbearance
To be able to be silent shows power; to be willing to be silent shows forbearance 
To be able to be silent shows power; to be willing to be silent shows forbearance  spirit of the time.
To be acquainted with the merit of a Ministry, we need only observe the condition of the people.
To be always lamenting and always complaining without raising and nerving one's self to resignation, is to lose at once both earth and heaven, and have nothing over but a watery sentimentalism.
To be always thinking about your manners is
not the way to make them good; because the very perfection of manners is not to think about yourself.
To be an enthusiast is to be the worthiest of affection, the noblest and the best that a mortal can be.
To be angry is to avenge the faults of others upon ourselves.
To be as good as our fathers, we must be better. Imitation is not discipleship. When some one sent a cracked plate to China to have a set made, every piece in the new set had a crack in it.
To be bodily tranquil, to speak little, and to digest without effort are absolutely necessary to grandeur of mind or of presence, or to proper development of genius.
To be born in a duck's nest in a farmyard is of
no consequence to a bird if it is hatched from a swan's egg.
To be born with a silver spoon in the mouth.
To be borne seems to many ever more kingly than to bear; and a ship carried with the breeze is, in their eyes, a lordlier spectacle than when it stands against it, victoriously braving it.
To be disobedient through temptation is human sin; but to be disobedient for the sake of disobedience, fiendish sin. To be obedient for the sake of success in conduct is human virtue; to be obedient for the sake of obedience, angelic virtue.
To be ever beloved, one must be ever agreeable.
To be free is not to do nothing, but to be the
sole arbiter of what we do and what we leave undone.
To be good and disagreeable is high treason against the royalty of virtue.
To be great is to be misunderstood.
To be great one must be positive, and gain strength through foes.
To be guided in the right path by those who know better than they is the first "right of man," compared with which all other rights are as nothing.
To be happy is not the purpose of our being,
but to deserve happiness.
To be happy means to be sufficient for one's self.
To be honest, as this world goes, is to be one man picked out of ten thousand.
To be idle and to be poor have always been reproaches; and therefore every man endeavours with his utmost care to hide his poverty from others, and his idleness from himself.
To be ill thought of is sometimes for thy good, ... if thou seek not thy own glory, but His that sent thee, the affliction will not be very grievous to be borne.
To be in too great a hurry to discharge an
obligation is itself a kind of ingratitude.
To be introduced into a decent company, there is need of a dress cut according to the taste of the public to which one wishes to present one's self.
To be magnanimous--mighty of heart, mighty of mind--is to be great in life; to become this increasingly is to "advance in life."
To be mindful of an absent friend in the hours of mirth and feasting, when his company is least wanted, shows no slight degree of sincerity.
To be misunderstood is the cross and bitterness of life.
To be obliged to wear black, and buy it into
the bargain, is more than my tranquillity of temper can bear.
To be once in doubt is once to be resolved.
To be, or not to be, that is the question; / Whether 'tis nobler in the mind to suffer / The slings and arrows of outrageous fortune, / Or to take up arms against a sea of troubles, / And, by opposing, end them.
To be perfectly just, is an attribute of the divine nature; to be so to the utmost of our abilities is the glory of man.
To be poor, and to seem poor, is a certain method never to rise.
To be prepared for war is one of the most
effectual means of preserving peace.
To be provoked with every slanderous word argues a littleness of soul, a want of due regard to God.
To be rich is to have a ticket of admission to the master-works and chief men of each race.
To be seventy years young is sometimes far more cheerful and hopeful than to be forty years old.
To be spiritually minded is life and peace.
To be thus is nothing; / But to be safely thus.
To be true in heart and just in act are the first qualities necessary for the elevation of humanity.
To be vain is rather a mark of humility than pride.
To be vain of one's rank or place is to disclose that one is below it.
To be weak is miserable, / Doing or suffering.
To be wholly loved with the whole heart, one
must be suffering.
To be wise and love exceeds man's might.
To be without a servant in this world is not good; but to be without a master, it appears, is a still fataller predicament for some.
To be without passion is worse than a beast; to be without reason is to be less than a man.
To be wroth with one we love, / Doth work like madness in the brain.
To be young is to be as one of the immortals.
To bear is to conquer our fate.
To become properly acquainted with a truth, we must first have disbelieved it and disputed against it.
To beguile the time, / Look like the time; bear welcome in your eye, / Your hand, your tongue; look like the innocent flower, / But be the serpent under 't.
To believe your own thought, to believe that what is true for you in your private heart is true for all men--that is genius.
To blow is not to play the flute; you must move the fingers as well.
To breed a fresh soul, is it not like brooding a
fresh (celestial) egg, wherein as yet all is formless, powerless? Yet by degrees organic elements and fibres shoot through the watery albumen; out of vague sensation grows thought, grows fantasy and force, and we have philosophies, dynasties, nay, poetries and religions.
To bring nations to surrender themselves to new ideas is not the affair of a day.
To bring the generality of admirers on our side, it is sufficient to attempt pleasing a very few.
To business that we love we rise betime, / And go to 't with delight.
To call a man ungrateful is to sum up all the evil he can be guilty of.
To carry on the feelings of childhood into the
powers of manhood, to combine the child's sense of wonder and novelty with the appearances which every day, for perhaps forty years, has rendered familiar; this is the character and privilege of genius, and one of the marks which distinguish genius from talent.
To cast away a virtuous friend is as bad as to cast away one's own life, which one loves best.
To catch dame Fortune's golden smile, / Assiduous wait upon her; / And gather gear by ev'ry wile / That's justified by honour; / Not for to hide it in a hedge, / Nor for a train attendant, / But for the glorious privilege / Of being independent.
To circumstances and custom the law must yield.
To climb a tree to catch a fish is talking much and doing nothing.
To climb steep hills requires slow pace at first.
To confess Christ is, first, to believe righteously, truthfully, and continently; and, then, to separate ourselves from those who are manifestly or by profession rogues, liars, and fornicators.
To conquer inclination is difficult, but if habit, taking root, gradually associates itself with it, then it is unconquerable.
To conquer without danger would be to conquer without glory.
To consume your own choler, as some chimneys consume their own smoke; to keep a whole Satanic school spouting, if it must spout, inaudibly, is a negative yet no slight virtue, nor one of the commonest in these times.
To corporeal beings unthought-of troubles
arise; so, in like manner, do blessings make their appearance. In this, I think Providence hath extended them farther than usual.
To dance attendance on their lordships' pleasures.
To-day comes only once, and never again returns.
To-day is a king in disguise.
To-day is ours, we have it here, ... / To the gods belong to-morrow.
To-day must not borrow of to-morrow.
To deny is easy; nothing is sooner learned or more generally practised. As matters go, we need no man of polish to teach it; but rather, if possible, a hundred men of wisdom to show us its limits and teach us its reverse.
To depersonalise man is the dominant drift of our epoch.
To despise our own species is the price we must too often pay for a knowledge of it.
To die for truth is not to die for one's country but to die for the world.
To die is landing on some silent shore, / Where
billows never break nor tempests roar.
To die, to sleep; / No more; and by a sleep to say we end / The heartache and the thousand natural shocks / That flesh is heir to, 'tis a consummation / Devoutly to be wished.
To die, to sleep; / No more! perchance to dream; ay, there's the rub; / For in that sleep of death what dreams may come, / When we have shuffled off this mortal coil, / Must give us pause.
To do as much good and as little evil as we can is the brief and intelligible principle that comprehends all subordinate maxims.
To do easily what is difficult for others is the mark of talent.
To do good to the ungrateful is to throw rosewater
into the sea.
To do him any wrong was to beget / A kindness from him, for his heart was rich, / Of such fine mould, that if you sow'd therein / The seed of Hate, it blossom'd Charity.
To do justice and judgment is more acceptable to the Lord than sacrifice.
To do no evil is good; to intend none is better.
To do nothing by halves is the way of noble minds.
To do, one must be doing.
To do what is impossible for talent is the mark of genius.
To doubt is to dip love in the mire.
To draw a long bow
To dread no eye, and to suspect no tongue, is the greatest prerogative of innocence; an exemption granted only to invariable virtue.
To dwell alone is the fate of all great souls.
To each nation its believed history is its Bible.
To eat or drink too much, to play too much,
to work too much, or to grumble too much--all these are equally pernicious.
To educate the intelligence is to enlarge the horizon of its desires and wants.
To educate the wise man, the State exists; and with the appearance of the wise man, the State expires. The wise man is the State.
To elevate above the spirit of the age must be regarded as the end of education.
To endeavour all one's days to fortify our minds with learning and philosophy is to spend so much in armour that one has nothing left to defend.
To endeavour to work upon the vulgar with
fine sense is like attempting to hew blocks with a razor.
To endure is the first and most necessary lesson a child has to learn.
To equal a predecessor, one must have twice his worth.
To err is human, to forgive divine.
To escape from arrangements that tortured me, my heart sought refuge in the world of ideas, when as yet I was unacquainted with the world of realities, from which iron bars excluded me.
To every deep there is a deeper still.
To everything there is a season.
To excite a fierce dog to capture a lame rabbit is to attack a contemptible enemy.
To expect an author to talk as he writes is ridiculous: or even if he did, you would find fault with him as a pedant.
To express the most difficult matters clearly, and everything intelligibly, is to strike coins out of pure gold.
To fail at all is to fail utterly.
To fear is easy, but grievous; to reverence is difficult, but satisfactory.
To fear the foe, since fear oppresseth strength, / Gives, in your weakness, strength unto your foe.
To feel and respect a great personality, one must be something one's self.
To fight and die is death destroying death; / Where fearing dying, pays death servile breath.
To fight with its neighbours never was, and is
now less than ever, the real trade of England.
To fill the hour, that is happiness.
To find out your real opinion of any one, observe the impression made upon you by the first sight of a letter from him.
To find recreation in amusement is not happiness.
To fix a child's attention on what is present, to give him a description of a name, is the best thing we can do for him.
To forget a wrong is the best revenge.
To forgive and forget is to throw away dearly-bought experience.
To form a poet, the heart must be full to overflowing of noble feeling.
To free a man from error is to give, and not to take away.
To gain what is fit ye're able, / If ye in faith can but excel; / Such are the myths of fable, / If ye have observed them well.
To gather riches do not hazard health; / For,
truth to say, health is the wealth of wealth.
To genius irregularity is incident, and the greatest genius is often marked by eccentricity, as if it disdained to move in the vulgar orbit.
To genius life never grows commonplace.
To get general ideas first and make particular observations last is to invert the process of education.
To gild refined gold, to paint the lily, / To throw a perfume on the violet, / To smooth the ice, or add another hue / Unto the rainbow, or with taper-light / To seek the beauteous eye of heaven to garnish, / Is wasteful and ridiculous excess.
To give alms is nothing unless you give
thought also, and therefore it is written, not "Blessed is he that feedeth the poor," but "Blessed is he that considereth the poor."
To give should be our pleasure, but to receive our shame.
To give the world more than it gives us, to love it more than it loves us, and never to make suit for its applause, ensures a peaceful life and a happy departure.
To give to the human mind a direction which it shall retain for ages is the rare prerogative of a few imperial spirits.
To go back is easy, if we have missed our way on the road uphill; it is impossible only when the road is downhill.
To go beyond the bounds of moderation is to
outrage humanity.
To God belongeth the east and the west; therefore, whithersoever ye turn yourselves to pray, there is the word of God, for God is omnipresent and omniscient.
To govern men, you must either excel them in their accomplishments or despise them.
To grasp, to seize, is the essence of all mastery.
To great evils one must oppose great virtues; and also to small, which is the harder task of the two.
To guard from error is not the instructor's
business; but to lead the erring pupil.
To guide scoundrels by love is a method that will not hold together; hardly for the flower of men will love do; and for the sediment and scoundrelism of them it has not even a chance to do.
To have a respect for ourselves guides our morals; and to have a deference for others governs our manners.
To have all one's wants satisfied is something intolerable.
To have any chance of lasting, a book must satisfy, not merely some fleeting fancy of the day, but a constant longing and hunger of human nature.
To have ascertained what is ascertainable, and calmly to reverence what is not, is the fairest portion that can fall to a thinking man.
To have done anything by which you earned
money merely is to have been truly idle, or worse.
To have done, is to hang / Quite out of fashion, like a rusty mail, / In monumental mockery.
To have gold is to be in fear, and to want it to be in sorrow.
To have heard the voice / Of Godhead in the winds and in the seas, / To have known him in the circling of the suns, / And in the changeful fates and lives of men.
To have ideas is to gather flowers; to think is to weave them into garlands.
To have neither superior, nor inferior, nor
equal, united manlike to you; without father, without child, without brother,--man knows no sadder destiny.
To have no assistance from other minds in resolving doubts, in appeasing scruples, in balancing deliberations, is a very wretched destitution.
To have no pain, and not be bored, is the utmost happiness possible to man on earth.
To have read the greatest works of any great poet, to have beheld or heard the greatest works of any great painter or musician, is a possession added to the best things of life.
To have religion upon authority, and not upon conviction, is like a finger-watch, to be set forwards or backwards, as he pleases that has it in keeping.
To have the fear of God before our eyes, and,
in our mutual dealings with each other, to govern our actions by the eternal measures of right and wrong; the first of these will comprehend the duties of religion; the second, those of morality.
To have the gift of life and bread to sustain it with can never suffice as a substitute for the ministry and service which the life itself is given us that we may fulfil. To find and work out this is man's only satisfaction and true reward.
To hear complaints is wearisome alike to the wretched and the happy.
To Him no high, no low, no great, no small; / He fills, He bounds, connects and equals all.
To him that knoweth to do good, and doeth it not, to him it is sin.
To his
save his sign-post and himself.
To hold, as 'twere, the mirror up to nature.
To holy tears, / In lonely hours, Christ risen appears; / In social hours, who Christ would see / Must turn all tasks to charity.
