We are sure to be losers when we quarrel with ourselves; it is a civil war, and in all such contentions, triumphs are defeats.
We are sure to judge wrong if we do not feel
aright.
We are taxed twice as much by our idleness, three times as much by our pride, and four times as much by our folly; and from these taxes the Commissioners cannot ease or deliver us by allowing an abatement.
We are the children of our own deeds.
We are the miracle of miracles--the great inscrutable mystery of God. We cannot understand it, we know not how to speak of it; but we may feel and know, if we like, that it is verily so.
We are the slaves of objects round us, and appear little or important according as these contract or give us room to expand.
We are to earn the joys of a higher existence,
not by scorning, but by using, all the gifts of God in this.
We are too good for pure instinct.
We are very fond of some families because they can be traced beyond the Conquest, whereas indeed the farther back the worse, as being the nearer allied to a race of robbers and thieves.
We are wiser than we know.
We ask advice, but we mean approbation.
We barter life for pottage.
We boast our light; but if we look not wisely on the sun itself, it smites us into darkness.
We build statues of snow, and weep to see them melt.
We by Fancy may assuage / The festering sore by Fancy made.
We can conceive or desire nothing more exquisite or perfect than what is round us every hour.
We can do more good by being good than in
any other way.
We can do nothing against the truth, but for the truth.
We can finish nothing in this life, but we can make a beginning, and bequeath a noble example.
We can hardly be confident of the state of our own minds, but as it stands attested by some external action.
We can have no dependence upon morality without religion; so, on the other hand, there is nothing better to be expected from religion without morality.
We can live without our friends, but not without
our neighbours.
We can more easily avenge an injury than requite a kindness; on this account, because there is less difficulty in getting the better of the wicked than in making one's self equal with the good.
We can never soon enough convince ourselves how easily we can be dispensed with in the world.
We can offer up much in the large, but to make sacrifices in little things is what we are seldom equal to.
We can only know a little, and the question is merely whether or not we know this well.
We can only possess wealth according to our
capacity.
We can receive anything from love, for that is a way of receiving it from ourselves; but not from any one who assumes to bestow.
We can sometimes love what we do not understand, but it is impossible completely to understand what we do not love.
We can take up no scheme, however wild and impracticable, but it will strike off some flower or fruit from the tree of knowledge.
We cannot abolish fate, but we can in a measure utilise it. The projectile force of the bullet does not annul or suspend gravity; it uses it.
We cannot all be masters, nor all masters / Cannot be truly follow'd.
We cannot all serve our country in the same way, but each may do his best, according as God has endowed him.
We cannot approach beauty. Its nature is like opaline dove's-neck lustres, hovering and evanescent. Herein it resembles the most excellent things, which have all this rainbow character, defying all attempts at appropriation and use.
We cannot be just if we are not humane.
We cannot be kind to each other here for an hour; / We whisper, and hint, and chuckle, and grin at a brother's shame; / However we brave it out, we men are a little breed.
We cannot but speak the things we have seen and heard.
We cannot conquer fate and necessity, yet we can yield to them in such a manner as to be greater than if we could.
We cannot fashion our children after our fancy. We must have them and love them as God has given them to us.
We cannot fight for love, as men may do; /
We should be wooed, and were not made to woo.
We cannot make our exodus from Houndsditch
till we have got our own
(_i.e._, the now dead religion of the past) with us.
We cannot overstate our debt to the past, but the moment has the supreme claim.
We cannot part with our friends. We cannot let our angels go. We do not see that they only go out that archangels may come in. We are idolaters of the old. We do not believe in the richness of the soul, in its proper eternity and omnipresence.
We cannot pass our guardian angel's bound, / Resign'd or sullen, he will hear our sighs.
We cannot speak a loyal word and be meanly
silent; we cannot kill and not kill at the same moment; but a moment is room enough for the loyal and mean desire, for the outflash of a murderous thought, and the sharp backward stroke of repentance.
We cannot think too highly of our nature, nor too humbly of ourselves.
We conceive, I think, more nobly of the weak presence of Paul than of the fair and ruddy countenance of David.
We consecrate a great deal of nonsense, because it was allowed by great men.
We could not endure solitude, were it not for the powerful companionship of hope, or of some unseen one.
We crave a world unreal as the shell-heard
sea.
We cultivate literature on a little oatmeal.
We darken the cages of birds when we would teach them to sing.
We deceive and flatter no one by such delicate artifices as we do ourselves.
We deem those happy who, from their experience of life, have learned to bear its ills without descanting on the burden.
We derive from nature no fault that may not
become a virtue, no virtue that may not degenerate into a fault. Faults of the latter kind are most difficult to cure.
We do everything by custom, even believe by it; our very axioms, let us boast of our Freethinking as we may, are oftenest simply such beliefs as we have never heard questioned.
We do not believe immortality because we have proved it, but we for ever try to prove it because we believe it.
We do not commonly find men of superior sense amongst those of the highest fortune.
We do not correct the man we hang; we correct others by him.
We do not count a man's years until he has
nothing else to count.
We do not determine what we will think.... We have little control over our thoughts.
We do not die wholly at our deaths; we have mouldered away gradually long before.
We do not judge men by what they are in themselves, but by what they are relatively to us.
We do not know what is really good or bad fortune.
We do not teach one another the lessons of
honesty and sincerity that the brutes do, or of steadiness and solitude that the rocks do. The fault is commonly mutual, for we do not habitually demand any more of each other.
We don't always care most for those flat-pattern flowers that press best in the herbarium.
We draw the foam from the great river of humanity with our quills, and imagine to ourselves that we have caught floating islands at least.
We eagerly lay hold of a law that serves as a weapon to our passion.
We easily dispense with what was never our own.
We enjoy ourselves only in our work, our
doing; and our best doing is our best enjoyment.
We estimate
We exaggerate misfortune and happiness alike. We are never either so wretched or so happy as we say we are.
We expect a bright to-morrow; / All will be well. / Faith can sing through days of sorrow, / All, all is well.
We expect everything, and are prepared for nothing.
We expect in letters to discover somewhat
of a person's real character. It is childish indeed to expect that we are to find the whole heart of the author unveiled.... Still as letters from one friend to another make the nearest approaches to conversation, we may expect to see more of a character displayed in these than in other productions which are studied for public view.
We expect old men to be conservative, but when a nation's young men are so, its funeral-bell is already rung.
We fail? / But screw your courage to the sticking-place, / And we'll not fail.
We fancy we suffer from ingratitude, while in reality we suffer from self-love.
(We) feel that life is large, and the world small, / So wait till life have passed from out the world.
We find God twice--once within, once without
us; within us as an eye, without us as a light.
We forfeit three-fourths of ourselves in order to be like other people.
We furnish our minds as we furnish our houses--with the fancies of others, and according to the mode and age of our country; we pick up our ideas and notions in common conversation as in schools.
We gain nothing by being with such as ourselves. We encourage one another in mediocrity. I am always longing to be with men more excellent than myself.
We gain the strength of the temptation we resist.
We gape, we grasp, we gripe, add store to
store; / Enough requires too much; too much craves more.
We gild our medicines with sweets; why not clothe truth and morals in pleasant garments as well?
We give advice, but we cannot give the wisdom to profit by it.
We give advice by the bucket, but take it by the grain.
We go by the major vote, and if the majority are insane, the sane must go to the hospital. As Satan said, "Evil, be thou my good," so they say, "Darkness, be thou my light."
We hang little thieves, and take off our hats
to great ones.
We happiness pursue; we fly from pain; / Yet the pursuit, and yet the flight is vain.
We hate delay, yet it makes us wise.
We hate some persons because we do not know them, and we will not know them because we hate them.
We have a great deal more kindness than is ever spoken. Maugre all the selfishness that chills like east winds the world, the whole human family is bathed with an element of love like a fine ether.
We have all a cure of souls, and every man is
a priest.
We have all a speck of the motley.
We have all of us one human heart.
We have all of us our ferries (to cross over) in this world, and must know the river and its ways, or get drowned some day.
We have all strength enough to endure the troubles of others.
We have always considered taxes to be the
sinews of the state.
We have, and this is an interesting fact, a plant which may serve as a symbol of the most advanced age, since, having passed the period of flowers and fruit, it still thrives cheerfully without further foundation.
We have but to toil awhile, endure awhile, believe always, and never turn back.
We have done deeds of charity, / Made peace of enmity, fair love of hate.
We have just enough religion to make us hate, but not enough to make us love, one another.
We have less charity for those who believe the
half of our creed than for those who deny the whole of it.
We have little control over our thoughts. We are the prisoners of our ideas.
We have met the enemy, and they are ours.
We have more indolence in the mind than in the body.
We have more mathematics than ever, but less mathesis. Archimedes and Plato could not have read the "Méchanique Céleste;" but neither would the whole French Institute see aught in that saying, "God geometrises," but sentimental rhodomontade.
We have no more / The world to choose from,
who, where'er we turn, / Tread through old thoughts and fair. Yet must we sing--/ We have no choice.
We have not only multiplied diseases, but we have made them more fatal.
We have not read an author till we have seen his object, whatever it may be, as he saw it.
We have not the innocence of Eden; but by God's help and Christ's example, we may have the victory of Gethsemane.
We have not the love of greatness, but the love of the love of greatness.
We have not wings, we cannot soar; / But
we have feet to scale and climb / By slow degrees, by more and more, / The cloudy summits of our time.
We have nothing to do with what is happening in space (or possibly may happen in time); we have only to attend to what is happening here--and now.
We have raised Pain and Sorrow into heaven, and in our temples, on our altars. Grief stands symbol of our faith, and it shall last as long as man is mortal and unhappy.
We have scotch'd the snake, but not killed it.
We have such exorbitant eyes, that, on seeing the smallest arc, we complete the curve, and when the curtain is lifted from the diagram which it served to veil, we are vexed to find that no more was drawn than just that fragment of an arc which we first beheld.
We hear constantly of what Nature is doing,
but we rarely hear of what man is thinking. We want ideas, and we get more facts.
We hear the rain fall, but not the snow. Bitter grief is loud, calm grief is silent.
We, ignorant of ourselves, / Beg often our own harms, which the wise powers / Deny us for our good; so find we profit / By losing of our prayers.
We in turn / Shall one day be Time's ancients, and inspire / The wiser, higher race, which yet shall sing; / Because to sing is human, and high thought / Grows rhythmic ere its close.
We inherit, not life only, but all the garniture and form of life; and work, and speak, and even think and feel, as our fathers, and primeval grandfathers, from the beginning, have given it us.
We injure mysteries, which are matters of faith, by any attempt at explanation in order to make them matters of reason. Could they be explained, they would cease to be mysteries; and it has been well said that a thing is not necessarily against reason because it happens to be above it.
We keep but what we give, / And only daily
dying may we live.
We know accurately only when we know little; with knowledge doubt increases.
We know better than we do.
We know God easily, provided we do not constrain ourselves to define him.
We know not oftentimes what we are able to do, but temptations shows us what we are.
We know truth when we see it, let sceptic
and scoffer say what they choose.
We know what we are, but we know not what we may be.
We learn nothing from mere hearing, and he who does not take an active part in certain subjects knows them but half and superficially.
We learn to know a thing best in the place where it is native.
We learn to know nothing but what we love; and the deeper we mean to penetrate into any matter with insight, the stronger and more vital must our love and passion be.
We learn wisdom from failure much more than
from success; we often discover what will do by finding out what will not do; and probably he who never made a mistake never made a discovery. Horne Tooke used to say of his studies in intellectual philosophy, that he had become all the better acquainted with the country through having had the good luck sometimes to lose his way.
We lie down and rise up with the skeleton allotted to us for our mortal companion--the phantom of ourselves.
We like only such actions as have long already had the praise of men, and do not perceive that anything man can do may be divinely done.
We like slipping, but not falling; our real desire is to be tempted enough.
We like to see through others, but not that others should see through us.
We live by admiration, hope, and love; / And
even as these are well and wisely fix'd, / In dignity of being we ascend.
We live by our imaginations, by our admirations, by our sentiments.
We live in a real, and a solid, and a truthful world. In such a world only truth, in the long run, can hope to prosper.
We live in a world which is full of misery and ignorance, and the plain duty of each and all of us is to try to make the little corner he can influence somewhat less miserable and somewhat less ignorant than it was before he entered it. To do this effectually, it is necessary to be fully possessed of only two beliefs: the first, that the order of nature is ascertainable by our faculties to an extent which is practically unlimited; the second, that our volition counts for something as a condition of the course of events.
We live in deeds, not years; in thoughts, not breaths; / In feelings, not in figures on a dial.
We live in the age of systems.
We loathe what none are left to share; / Even bless 'twere woe alone to bear.
We long in vain to undo what has been done.
We long to use what lies beyond our scope, / Yet cannot use even what within it lies.
We look before and after, / And pine for what is not; / E'en our sincerest laughter / With some pain is fraught; / Our sweetest songs are those which tell of saddest thought.
We love a girl for very different things than
understanding. We love her for her beauty, her youth, her mirth, her confidingness, her character, with its faults, caprices, and God knows what other inexpressible charms; but we do not love her for her understanding. Her mind we esteem (if it is brilliant), and it may greatly elevate her in our opinion; nay, more, it may enchain us when we already love. But her understanding is not that which awakens and inflames our passions.
We love in others what we lack ourselves, / And would be everything but what we are.
We love justice greatly, and just men but little.
We love peace, as we abhor pusillanimity; but not peace at any price. There is a peace more destructive of the manhood of living man than war is destructive of his material body. Chains are worse than bayonets.
We love those who admire us, but not those whom we admire.
We love to see wisdom in unpretending forms,
to recognise her royal features under a week-day vesture.
We make trifles of terrors, ensconcing ourselves into seeming knowledge, when we should submit ourselves to an unknown fear.
We make way for the man who boldly pushes past us.
We manufacture everything there
except men; we blanch cotton, and strengthen steel, and refine sugar, and shape pottery; but to brighten, to strengthen, to refine, or to form a single living spirit, never enters into our estimate of advantages.
We may acquire liberty, but it is never recovered if it is once lost.
We may all agree in lamenting that there are so many houses where you will not find a good atlas, a good dictionary, or a good cyclopædia of reference. What is still more lamentable, in a good many more houses where these books are, is that they are never referred to or opened.
We may almost say that a new life begins when a man once sees with his own eyes all that before he has but partially read or heard of.
We may be as good as we please, if we please to be good.
We may be pretty certain that persons whom
all the world treats ill deserve entirely the treatment they get.
We may build more splendid habitations, / Fill our rooms with paintings and with sculptures,/ But we cannot / Buy with gold the old associations!
We may daily discover crowds acquire sufficient wealth to buy gentility, but very few that possess the virtues which ennoble human nature, and (in the best sense of the word) constitute a gentleman.
We may despise the world, but we cannot do without it.
We may fall in with a thousand learned men before we fall in with one wise.
We may give more offence by our silence than
even by impertinence.
We may grasp virtue so hard as to convert it into a vice.
We may have a law, or we may have no law, but we cannot have half a law.
We may have once been slugs, and may one day be angels, but we are men now; and we must, as men, do our work honourably and thoroughly.
We may lay in a stock of pleasures, as we would lay in a stock of wine; but if we defer the tasting of them too long, we shall find that both are soured by age.
We may, like the ships, by tempests be toss'd /
On perilous deeps, but cannot be lost.
We may not be able to parry evil thoughts, but we may surely guard against their taking root in us and bringing forth evil deeds.
We may outrun / By violent swiftness that which we run at, / And lose by overrunning.
We may say of angling as Dr. Boteler said of strawberries, "Doubtless God could have made a better berry, but doubtless God never did;" and so, if I might be judge, God never did make a more calm, quiet, innocent recreation than angling.
We may seek God by our intellect
but we can find him only with the heart.
We may take Fancy for a companion, but must
follow Reason as our guide.
We mount to heaven mostly on the ruins of our cherished schemes, finding our failures were successes.
We move too much in platoons; we march by sections; we do not live in our vital individuality enough; we are slaves to fashion, in mind and in heart, if not to our passions and appetites.
We must accept ourselves as we are.
We must accept the post to which Heaven appoints us, and do the duty to which Heaven calls us, and think it no shame, but an honour, to hold any office, however lowly, under heaven's King.
We must all receive and learn both from those
who were before us and from those who are with us. Even the greatest genius would not go far if he tried to owe everything to his own internal self.
We must all toil--or steal; no faithful workman finds his life a pastime.
We must avoid fastidiousness; neatness, when it is moderate, is a virtue; but when it is carried to an extreme, it narrows the mind.
We must be as courteous to a man as we are to a picture, which we are willing to give the advantage of a good light.
We must be free or die who speak the tongue / That Shakespeare spake, the faith and morals hold / Which Milton held.
We must be our own before we can be
another's.
We must bear what Heaven sends us; no noble heart will bear injustice.
We must carry the beautiful with us, or we find it not.
We must first cross a valley before we regain a favourable and cheerful height; meanwhile, let us see how we can stroll through it with our friends pleasantly and profitably.
We must first pray, and then labour; first implore the blessing of God, and use those means which he puts into our hands.
We must have the real thing before we can
have a science of the thing.
We must hold by what is definite, and not split up our strength in many directions.
We must, if we would husband life and not waste it, bravely resolve to dispense with the dispensable, to content ourselves with the minimum of want, to stake our reputation, if such be dear to us, upon intrinsic worth, and show once again, if we can, by our mere life and labour, what are the "roots of honour" and the "veins of wealth."
We must judge of a form of government by its general tendency, not by happy accidents.
We must labour unceasingly to render our piety reasonable, and our reason pious.
We must needs die, and are as water spilt on
the ground which cannot be gathered up again.
We must not arrogate to ourselves a spirit of forgiveness, until we have been touched to the quick where we are sensitive and borne it meekly.
We must not contradict, but instruct, him that contradicts us.
We must not judge of despots by the temporary successes which the possession of power enabled them to achieve, but by the state in which they leave their country at their death or at their fall.
We must not make a scarecrow of the law.
We must not only strike the iron while it is hot, but strike it till it is made hot.
We must not regard what the many say of us; but what he, the one man who has understanding of just and unjust, will say, and what the truth will say.
We must not stand upon trifles.
We must not stint / Our necessary actions, in
the fear / To cope malicious censurers; which ever, / As ravenous fishes, do a vessel follow / That is new trimmed, but benefit no further / Than vainly longing.
We must not suppose ourselves always to have conquered a temptation when we have fled from it.
We must not take the faults of our youth with us into our old age, for old age brings with it its own defects.
We must put up with our contemporaries, since we can neither live with our ancestors nor posterity.
We must sometimes cease to adhere to our own opinion for the sake of peace.
We must strive to make of humanity one
single family.
We must take the current when it serves, / Or lose our ventures.
We must take the world as we find it.
We need change of objects.
We
leaving Heaven to decide whether they are to rise in the world, decide for themselves that they will be happy in it, and have resolved to seek--not greater wealth, but simpler pleasure; not higher fortune, but deeper felicity; making the first of possessions self-possession, and honouring themselves in the harmless pride and calm pursuits of peace.
We need greater virtues to sustain good than
evil fortune.
We need not die while we are living.
We needs must love the highest when we see it, / Not Lancelot, nor another.
We never can know the truth of sin; for its nature is to deceive alike on the one side the sinner and on the other the judge.
We never can say why we love, but only that we love. The heart is ready enough at feigning excuses for all that it does or imagines of wrong; but ask it to give a reason for any of its beautiful and divine motions, and it can only look upward and be dumb.
We never desire ardently what we desire
rationally.
We never learn what people are by their coming to us; we must go to them if we wish to know what they are made of, and see how they conduct or misconduct their surroundings.
We never live, but we hope to live; and as we are always arranging for being happy, it cannot be but that we never are so.
We never love truly but once. It is the first time. Succeeding passions are less involuntary.
We never reflect on the man we love without exulting in our choice; while he who has bound us to him by benefits alone rises to our idea as a person to whom we have, in some measure, forfeited our freedom.
We never see anything isolated in Nature,
but everything in connection with something else which is before it, beside it, under it, and over it.
We never sufficiently consider that a language is properly only symbolical, only figurative, and expresses objects never immediately, but only in reflection; yet how difficult it is not to put the sign in place of the thing, always to keep the thing as it is
We never sufficiently consider that a language is properly only symbolical, only figurative, and expresses objects never immediately, but only in reflection; yet how difficult it is not to put the sign in place of the thing, always to keep the thing as it is 
We never sufficiently consider that a language is properly only symbolical, only figurative, and expresses objects never immediately, but only in reflection; yet how difficult it is not to put the sign in place of the thing, always to keep the thing as it is  the expression
We often quarrel with the unfortunate to get rid of pitying them.
We ought certainly to despise malice if we cannot oppose it.
We ought not, in general, to take the opinions of others upon trust, but to reason and judge for ourselves.
We ought not to isolate ourselves, for we
cannot remain in a state of isolation. Social intercourse makes us the more able to bear with ourselves and with others.
We ought not to judge men by their absolute excellence, but by the distance which they have travelled from the point at which they started.
We ought not to quit our post without the permission of Him who commands; the post of man is life.
We ought not to seek too high joys. We may be bright without transfiguration.
We ought not to teach children the sciences, but to give them a taste for them.
We ought to attempt no more than what is in
the compass of our genius and according to our vein.
We ought to be ashamed of our pride, but never proud of our shame.
We ought to obey God rather than man.
We ought to regard our servants as friends in a lower state.
We our betters see bearing our woes, / We scarcely think our miseries our foes.
We owe it to our ancestors to preserve entire
those rights which they have delivered to our care; we owe it to our posterity not to suffer their dearest inheritance to be destroyed.
We owe to man higher succours than food and fire. We owe to man, man.
We own whom we love. The universe is God's because He loves.
We pain ourselves to please nobody.
We pardon as long as we love.
We part with true joy almost more lightly
than with a beautiful dream.
We pass our life in deliberation, and we die upon it.
We pity in others only those evils which we have ourselves experienced.
We play the fools with the time, and the spirits of the wise sit in the clouds and mock us.
We poets in our youth begin in gladness, / But thereof come in the end despondency and madness.
We promise according to our hopes, and perform according to our fears.
We properly learn from those books only which are above our criticism, which we cannot judge.
We read far too many things, thus losing time
and gaining nothing. We should only read what we admire.
We readily believe what we wish to be true.
We reap what we sow, but Nature has love over and above that justice, and gives us shadow and blossom and fruit that spring from no planting of ours.
We receive but little advantage from repeated protestations of gratitude, but they cost them very much from whom we exact them in return.
We reform others unconsciously when we walk uprightly.
We retain from our studies only that which
we practically apply.
We sacrifice to dress till household joys and comforts cease. Dress drains our cellar dry and keeps our larder lean.
We see but the outside of the rich man's happiness; few consider him to be like the silkworm, that, when she seems to play, is at the very same time spinning her own bowels and consuming herself.
We see farthest into the future--and that is not far--when we most carefully consider the facts of the present.
We see so darkly into futurity, we never know when we have real cause to rejoice or lament. The worst appearances have often happy consequences, as the best lead many times into the greatest misfortunes.
We see the blossoms wither and the leaves
fall, but we likewise see fruits ripen and new buds shoot forth.
We seek but half the causes of our deeds, / Seeking them only in the outer life, / And heedless of the encircling spirit-world, / Which, though unseen, is felt, and sows in us / All germs of pure and world-wide purposes.
We seldom give our love to what is worthiest in its object.
We seldom speak of the virtue we have, but much more frequently of that which we have not.
"We shall fight in the shade."
We shall find no fiend in hell can match the
fury of a disappointed woman,--scorned, slighted, dismissed without a parting pang.
We should always keep a corner of our heads open and free, that we may make room for the opinions of our friends.
We should be slower to think that the man at his worst is the real man, and certain that the better we are ourselves the less likely is he to be at his worst in our company.
We should be sparing in our intimacies; because it so very often happens that the more perfectly men are understood, the less they are esteemed.
We should come home from adventures, and perils, and discoveries every day with new experience and character.
We should count time by heart-throbs. / He
most lives / Who thinks most, feels the noblest, / Acts the best.
We should despise the wretch who has never once thought what it is he is doing
We should distinguish between laughter inspired by joy, and that which arises from mockery.
We should eat to live, and not live to eat.
We should feel sorrow, but not sink under its oppression.
We should forgive freely, but forget rarely.
I will not be revenged, and this I owe to my enemy; but I will remember, and this I owe to myself.
We should guard against a talent which we cannot hope to practise in perfection. Improve it as we may, we shall always in the end, when the merit of the master has become apparent to us, painfully lament the loss of time and strength devoted to such botching.
We should have all our communications with men as in the presence of God; and with God, as in the presence of men.
We should hold the immutable mean that lies between insensibility and anguish; our attempts should be, not to extinguish nature, but to repress it; not to stand unmoved at distress, but endeavour to turn every disaster to our own advantage.
We should labour to treat with ease of things that are difficult; with familiarity, of things that are novel; and with perspicuity, of things that are profound.
We should live each day as if it were the full
term of our life.
We should manage our fortune like our constitution; enjoy it when good, have patience when bad, and never apply violent remedies but in cases of necessity.
We should never risk pleasantry except with well-bred people, and people with brains.
We should never so entirely avoid danger as to appear irresolute and cowardly; but, at the same time, we should avoid unnecessarily exposing ourselves to danger, than which nothing can be more foolish.
We should not be too hasty in bestowing either our praise or censure on mankind, since we shall often find such a mixture of good and evil in the same character, that it may require a very accurate judgment and a very elaborate inquiry to determine on which side the balance turns.
We should not spur a willing horse.
We should not trust the heart too much. The heart speaks to us very gladly, as our mouth expresses itself. If the mouth were as much inclined to speak the feelings of the heart, it would have been the fashion long ago to put a padlock on the mouth.
We should often feel ashamed of our most brilliant actions were the world to see the motives from which they sprung.
We should only utter higher maxims so far as they can benefit the world. The rest we should keep within ourselves, and they will diffuse over our actions a lustre like the mild radiance of a hidden sun.
We should round every day of stirring action with an evening of thought. We learn nothing of our experience except we muse upon it.
We should seem ignorant that we oblige, and leave the mind at full liberty to give or refuse its affections; for constraint may indeed leave the receiver still grateful but it will certainly produce disgust.
We should take a prudent care for the future,
but so as to enjoy the present. It is no part of wisdom to be miserable to-day, because we may happen to be so to-morrow.
We should, to the last moment of our lives, continue a settled intercourse with all the true examples of grandeur.
We shut our eyes, and, like people in the dark, we fall foul upon the very thing we search for, without finding it.
We sink to rise.
We smile at the satire expended upon the follies of others, but we forget to weep at our own.
We sometimes meet an original gentleman,
who, if manners had not existed, would have invented them.
We sometimes see a change of expression in our companion, and say, His father or his mother comes to the windows of his eyes, and sometimes a remote relative. In different hours, a man represents each of several of his ancestors, as if there were seven or eight of us rolled up in each man's skin--seven or eight ancestors at least--and they constitute the variety of notes for that new piece of music which his life is.
We speak that we do know, and testify that we have seen.
We still are fain, with wrath and strife, / To seek for gain, to shrink from loss, / Content to scratch our shallow cross / On the rough surface of old life.
We swallow at one gulp a lie which flatters us, but only drop by drop a truth which is bitter to us.
We take a great deal for granted in this world,
and expect that everything, as a matter of course, ought to fit into our humours, wishes, and wants; it is often only when danger threatens that we awake to the discovery that the guiding reins are held by one whom we had well-nigh forgotten in our careless ease.
We take a pleasure in being severe upon others, but cannot endure to hear of our own faults.
We take greater pains to persuade others that we are happy than in endeavouring to think so ourselves.
We take no note of time but from its loss.
We talk little if we do not talk about ourselves.
We talk on principle, but we act on interest.
We tell our triumphs to the crowd, but our own hearts are the sole confidants of our sorrows.
We tell the ladies that good wives make good husbands; I believe it is a more certain position that good brothers make good sisters.
We that acquaint ourselves with every zone, / And pass the tropics, and behold each pole; / When we come home, are to ourselves unknown, / And unacquainted still with our own soul.
We think our civilisation near its meridian; but we are yet only at the cock-crowing and the morning star.
We tolerate everybody, because we doubt
everything; or else we tolerate nobody, because we believe something.
We trample grass, and prize the flowers of May; / Yet grass is green when flowers do fade away.
We treat God with irreverence by banishing him from our thoughts, not by referring to his will on slight occasions.
We triumph without glory when we conquer without danger.
We unconsciously imitate what pleases us, and insensibly approximate to the characters we most admire. In this way, a generous habit of thought and of action carries with it an incalculable influence.
We underpin our houses with granite; what
of our habits and our lives?
We use up in the passions the stuff that was given us for happiness.
We usually lose the to-day, because there has been a yesterday, and to-morrow is coming.
We very often have to do things during our lives of which we do not understand the reasons, but the more clearly we understand the work we have to do, depend upon it, the better the work will be done.
We wander there, we wander here, / We eye the rose upon the brier, / Unmindful that the thorn is near, / Amang the leaves.
We want but two or three friends, but these
we cannot do without, and they serve us in every thought we think.
We want downright facts at present more than anything else.
We want foolishly to think the creed a man professes a more significant fact than the man he is.
We want one man to be always thinking, and another to be always working, and we call the one a gentleman, and the other an operative; whereas the workman ought often to be thinking, and the thinker often to be working, and both should be gentlemen in the best sense.
We waste our best years in distilling the sweetest flowers of life into potions which, after all, do not immortalise, but only intoxicate.
We wear a face of joy because / We have been
glad of yore.
We, who name ourselves its
we, / Half dust, half deity, alike unfit / To sink or soar.
We will have others severely corrected, and will not be corrected ourselves.
We will not estimate the sun by the quantity of gaslight it saves us.
We will not from the helm, to sit and weep; / But keep our course, though the rough wind say no.
We will obey the voice of the Lord our God, that it may be well with us.
We wish to be happier than other people; and
this is almost always difficult, for we believe others to be happier than they are.
We would commend a faith that even seems audacious, like that of the sturdy Covenanter Robert Bruce, who requested, as he was dying, that his finger might be placed on one of God's strong promises, as though to challenge the Judge of all with it as he should enter his presence.
We wound our modesty and make foul the clearness of our deservings when of ourselves we publish them.
We wrap ourselves up in the cloak of our own better fortune, and turn away our eyes, lest the wants and woes of our brother-mortals should disturb the selfish apathy of our souls.
We write from aspiration and antagonism, as well as from experience. We paint those qualities which we do not possess.
We'd jump the life to come. But, in these
cases, / We still have judgment here; that we but teach / Bloody instructions, which, being taught, return / To plague the inventor. This even-handed justice / Commends the ingredients of our poison'd chalice / To our own lips.
We'll stand up for our properties, was the beggar's song, that lived upon the alms-basket.
Weak eyes are precisely the fondest of glittering objects.
Weak minds sink under prosperity as well as under adversity; strong and deep ones have two highest tides--when the moon is at the full, and when there is no moon.
Weak persons cannot be sincere.
Weak Virtue that amid the shade / Lamenting
lies, with future schemes amused, / While Wickedness and Folly, kindred powers, / Confound the world!
Weakness of character is the only defect which cannot be amended.
Weaknesses, so called, are neither more nor less than vice in disguise.
Wealth and want equally harden the human heart, as frost and fire are both alien to the human flesh. Famine and gluttony alike drive nature away from the heart of man.
Wealth consists of the good, and therefore useful, things in the possession of the nation; money is only the written or coined sign of the relative quantities of wealth in each person's possession.
Wealth cannot purchase any great private
solace or convenience. Riches are only the means of sociality.
Wealth gotten by vanity shall be diminished; but he that gathereth by labour shall increase.
Wealth heaped on wealth, nor truth nor safety buys; / The dangers gather as the treasures rise.
Wealth imparts a birdlime quality to the possessor, at which the man in his native poverty would have revolted.
Wealth implies the possession of what is of intrinsic value and of a capacity to use it.
Wealth is a shift. The wise man angles with
himself only, and with no meaner bait.
Wealth is not his that has it, but his that enjoys it.
Wealth is the application of mind to nature; and the art of getting rich consists not in industry, much less in saving, but in a better order, in timeliness, in being at the right spot.
Wealth is the conjuror's devil; / Whom when he thinks he hath, the devil hath him.
Wealth is the possession of useful articles which we can use, (so that) instead of depending merely on a "have," it is thus seen to depend on a "can."
Wealth leaves us at death; kinsmen at the
grave; but virtues of the mind unto the heavens with us we have.
Wealth makes wit waver.
Wealth maketh many friends, but the poor is separated from his neighbour.
Wealth of every species necessarily flows to the hands of him who exerteth himself.
Wealth only by its use we know.
Wealth, power, and even the advantages of
youth, have little to do with that which gives repose to the mind and firmness to the frame.
Wealth richer than both the Indies lies for every man, if he will endure. Not his oaks only and his fruit-trees, his very heart roots itself wherever he may abide--roots itself, draws nourishment from the deep fountains of universal being.

Wealth which breeds idleness, of which the English peerage is an example, and of which we are beginning to abound in specimens in oyster-bed, where heirs and heiresses are planted, to spend a contemptible life of slothfulness in growing plump and succulent for the grave-worm's banquet.
Wealth without contentment climbs a hill, / To feel those tempests which fly over ditches.
Wear your learning, like your watch, in a private pocket; and do not pull it out and strike it, merely to show that you have one. If you are asked what o'clock it is, tell it, but do not proclaim it hourly and unasked, like the watchmen.
Wearers of rings and chains! / Pray do not
take the pains / To set me right. / In vain my faults ye quote; / I write as others wrote / On Sunium's height.
Weariness / Can snore upon the flint, when resty sloth / Finds the down pillow hard.
Weary the path that does not challenge reason. Doubt is an incentive to truth, and patient inquiry leadeth the way.
Weave in faith and God will find thread.
Weder sicher noch gerathen ist, etwas wider Gewissen zu thun. Hier stehe ich, ich kann nicht anders. Gott helfe mir
Wedlock, indeed, hath oft compared been / To publick feasts, where meet a publick rout: / When they that are without would fain go in, / And they that are within would fain go out.
Wedlock is like a besieged fortress: those who are outside wish to get in, and those who are inside wish to get out.
Wee modest crimson-tipped flower, / Thou's
met me in an evil hour; / For I maun crush amang the stour / Thy slender stem; / To spare thee now is past my power, / Thou bonny gem.
Wee Willie Winkie rins through the toun, / Upstairs and dounstairs, in his nicht-goun, / Tirlin' at the window, cryin' at the lock, / "Are the weans in their bed? for it's noo ten o'clock."
Weed your better judgments / Of all opinion that grows rank in them.
Weeds make dunghills gracious.
Weel is that weel does.
Weep no more, lady, weep no more. / For
sorrow is in vain; / For violets pluck'd, the sweetest showers / Will ne'er revive again.
Weeping may endure for a night, but joy cometh in the morning.
Weh dem Lande, wo man nicht mehr singt
Weigh not so much what men say, as what they prove: remembering that truth is simple and naked, and needs not invective to apparel her comeliness.
Weighty things are done in solitude, that is, without society. The means of improvement consist not in projects, or in any violent designs, for these cool, and cool very soon, but in patient practising for whole long days, by which I make the thing clear to my highest reason.
Weighty work must be done with few words.
Weise Hut, / Behält ihr Gut
Weise sein ist nicht allzeit gut
Weiser Mann, starker Mann
Weisheit, du wirst Unsinn / Im Mund des Schwärmers
Welch Glück geliebt zu werden: / Und lieben,
Götter, welch ein Glück!
Welcome evermore to gods and men is the self-helping man.
Welcome is the best cheer.
Welcome, Misfortune, if thou comest alone.
Well at ease are the sleepers for whom existence is a shallow dream.
Well for the drones of the social hive that there
are bees of an industrious turn, willing, for an infinitesimal share of the honey, to undertake the labour of its fabrication.
Well has Ennius said, "Kindnesses misplaced are nothing but a curse and disservice."
Well-married, a man is winged; ill-matched, he is shackled.
Well roared, lion.
Well thriveth that well suffereth.
Well to work and make a fire, / Doth both
care and skill require.
Well, well, is a word of malice.
Well, whiles I am a beggar, I will rail, / And say, there is no sin but to be rich; / And being rich, my virtue then shall be, / To say, there is no vice but beggary.
Well, you may fear too far.--/ Safer than trust too far.
Wem nicht zu rathen ist, dem ist auch nicht zu helfen
Wen die Natur zum Dichter schuf, den lehrt
sie auch zu paaren / Das Schöne mit dem Kräftigen, das Neue mit dem Wahren
Wen Gott niederschlägt, der richtet sich selbst nicht auf
Wen jemand lobt, dem stellt er sich gleich
Wenn alle untreu werden, / So bleib' ich dir doch treu
Wenn das Geld im Kasten klingt, / Die Seele aus dem Fegfeuer springt
Wenn das Glück anpocht, soll man ihm aufthun
Wenn das Leblose lebendig ist, so kann es auch wohl Lebendiges hervorbringen
Wenn der Purpur fällt, muss auch der Herzog nach
Wenn du eine weise Antwort verlangst, / Musst du vernünftig fragen
Wenn du nicht irrst, kommst du nicht zu Verstand
Wenn ein Edler gegen dich fehlt, / So thu' als
hättest du's nicht gezählt; / Er wird es in sein Schuldbuch schreiben / Und dir nicht lange im Debet bleiben
Wenn Gott sagt: Heute, sagt der Teufel: Morgen
Wenn ihr's nicht fühlt, ihr werdet's nicht erjagen
Wenn man von den Leuten Pflichten fordert und ihnen keine Rechte zugestehen will, muss man sie gut bezahlen
Wenn man was Böses thut, erschrickt man vor dem Bösen
Wenn mancher Mann wüsste, / Wer mancher Mann wär', / Thät' mancher Mann manchem Mann / Manchmal mehr Ehr'
Wenn Moses nicht bei Aaron ist, so macht Aaron--Kälber
Wenn sich der Verirrte findet / Freuen alle
Götter sich
Wer allen alles traut, dem kann man wenig trauen
Wer darf das Kind beim rechten Namen nennen?
Wer darf ihn nennen?
Wer den Tod fürchtet, hat das Leben verloren
Wer der Dichtkunst Stimme nicht vernimmt, /
Ist ein Barbar, er sei auch wer er sei
Wer der Vorderste ist, führt die Herde
Wer die Leiter hinauf will, muss bei der untersten Sprosse schon beginnen
Wer die Wahrheit kennet und saget sie nicht, / Der bleibt fürwahr ein erbärmlicher Wicht
Wer dir als Freund nichts nützen kann / Kann allemal als Feind dir schaden
Wer edel ist, den suchet die Gefahr / Und er
sucht sie, sie müssen sich treffen
Wer erst klug wird nach der That, / Braucht seine Weisheit viel zu spat
Wer fertig ist, dem ist nichts recht zu machen; / Ein Werdender wird immer dankbar sein
Wer fremde Sprachen nicht kennt, weiss nichts von seiner eignen
Wer fröhlich sein will sein Lebenlang / Lasse der Welt ihren tollen Gang
Wer ist der Weiseste? Der nichts anders
weiss und will, als das was begegnet
Wer ist ein unbrauchbarer Man? Der nicht befehlen und auch nicht gehorchen kann
Wer ist grösser, Schiller, Goethe? / Wie man nur so mäkeln mag! / Himmlisch ist die Morgenröte, / Himmlisch ist der helle Tag
Wer ist mächtiger als der Tod? / Wer da kann lachen, wenn er droht
Wer kann was Dummes, wer was Kluges denken, / Das nicht die Vorwelt schon gedacht?
Wer lange bedenkt, der wählt nicht immer
das Beste
Wer lügt, der stiehlt
Wer mit sich selber eins, ist eins mit Gott
Wer nicht Bitteres gekostet hat, weiss nicht was süss ist
Wer nicht hören will, der muss fühlen
Wer nicht liebt Wein, Weib und Gesang /
Der bleibt ein Narr sein Lebenlang
Wer nichts für andre thut, thut nichts für sich
Wer nichts fürchtet, ist nicht weniger mächtiger, als der, den alles fürchtet
Wer nie sein Brod mit Thränen ass, / Wer nicht die kummervollen Nächte / Auf seinem Bette weinend sass / Der kennt euch nicht, ihr himmlischen Mächte
Wer oft schiesst, trifft endlich
Wer sein eigener Lehrmeister sein will, hat
einen Narren zum Schüler
Wer sich behaglich fühlt zu Haus, / Der rennt nicht in die Welt hinaus; / Weltunzufriedenheit beweisen / Die vielen Weltentdeckungsreisen
Wer will, der vermag
Wer will was Lebendig's erkennen und beschreiben / Sucht erst den Geist herauszutreiben, / Dann hat er die Teile in seiner Hand, / Fehlt leider, nur das geistige Band
Wer wohl sitzt, der rücke nicht
Were a man of pleasure to arrive at the full extent of his several wishes, he must immediately feel himself miserable.
Were defeat unknown, neither would victory be celebrated with songs of triumph.
Were I a steam-engine, wouldst thou take the trouble to tell lies of me?
Were I so tall to reach the pole / Or grasp
the ocean with my span, / I must be measured by my soul: / The mind's the standard of the man.
Were it no for hope the heart wad break.
Were it not miraculous, could I stretch forth my hand and clutch the sun? Dost thou not see that the true inexplicable God-revealing miracle lies in this, that I can stretch forth my hand at all, that I have free force to clutch aught therewith?
Were man / But constant, he were perfect.
Were man not a poor hungry dastard, and even much of a blockhead withal, he would cease criticising his victuals to such extent, and criticise himself rather, what he does with his victuals.
Were one to preach a sermon on Health, as
really were worth doing, Scott ought to be the text.
Were the eye not sun-related
could never see the sun; were there not in us divine affinities, how could the divine so ravish us?
"Were there as many devils in Worms as there are roof-tiles, I would on."
Were there but one man in the world, he would be a terror to himself; and the highest man not less so than the lowest.
Were we as eloquent as angels, we would please some men, some women, and some children much more by listening than by talking.
Were we to take as much pains to be what we
ought to be as we do to disguise what we really are, we might appear like ourselves, without being at the trouble of any disguise at all.
Were wisdom given me with this reservation, that I should keep it shut up within myself and not impart it, I would spurn it.
Were wisdom to be sold, she would give no price; every man is satisfied with the share he has from nature.
Westward the course of empire takes its way.
What a blessed thing it is that Nature, when she invented, manufactured, and patented her authors, contrived to make critics out of the chips that were left!
What a delight to have a husband beside you,
were it only to salute you when you sneeze, and say "God bless you!"
What a dismal, debasing, and confusing element is that of a sick body on the human soul or thinking part!
What a fool is he who locks his door to keep out spirits, who has in his own bosom a spirit he dares not meet alone; whose voice, smothered far down, and piled over with mountains of earthliness, is yet like the forewarning trumpet of doom!
What a force of illusion begins life with us, and attends us to the end!
What a heavy burden is a name that has become too soon famous!
What a hell of witchcraft lies in the small orb
of one particular tear!
What a large volume of adventures may be grasped within this little span of life by him who interests his heart in everything.
What a man can do is his greatest ornament, and he always consults his dignity by doing it.
What a man does not believe can never at bottom be of any true interest to him.
What a man does, that he has.
What a man does, that he is.
What a man finds good of, and what he finds hurt of, is the best physic to preserve health.
What a man is contributes much more to his happiness than what he has or how others regard him.
What a man is irresistibly urged to say, helps him and us.
What a man wills, not what he knows, determines his worth or unworth, his power or impotence, his happiness or unhappiness.
What a miserable world!--trouble if we love,
and trouble if we do not love.
What a piece of work is a man! How noble in reason! How infinite in faculty! In form and moving how express and admirable! In action how like an angel! In apprehension how like a God!
What a poor creature is the woman who, inspiring desire, does not also inspire love and reverence!
What a road had human nature to traverse before it reached the point of being mild to the guilty, merciful to the injurious, and humane to the inhuman! Doubtless they were men of godlike souls who first taught this, who spent their lives in rendering the practice of this possible, and recommending it to others.
What a sense of security is in an old book which Time has criticised for us!
What a strange thing man is! and what a
stranger / Is woman!
What a thin film it is that divides the living from the dead!
What a vanity is painting, which attracts admiration by the resemblance of things that in the original we do not admire!
What a view a man must have of this universe who thinks he can swallow it all, who is not doubly and trebly happy that he can keep it from swallowing him!
What a wretched thing is all fame! A renown of the highest sort endures, say for two thousand years. And then? Why then a fathomless eternity swallows it.
What actually constitutes the human element
in man is a kindly spirit.
What an enormous camera obscura magnifier is Tradition! How a thing grows in the human memory, in the human imagination, when love, worship, and all that lies in the human heart is there to encourage it!
What an inaccessible stronghold that man possesses who is always in earnest with himself and the things around him!
What are all our histories but God manifesting himself, that he hath shaken, and tumbled down, and trampled upon everything that he hath not planted!
What are all prayers beneath / But cries of babes, that cannot know / Half the deep thought they breathe?
What are men better than sheep or goats, /
That nourish a blind life within the brain, / If, knowing God, they lift not hands of prayer / Both for themselves and those who call them friend?
What are the outward details of a life, if the inner secret of it, the remorse, temptations, true, often-baffled, never-ended struggle of it, be forgotten? Details by themselves will never teach us what it is.
What are we great ones on the wave of humanity? We think we rule it when it rules us, and drives us up and down, hither and thither, as it listeth.
What are words but empty sounds, that break and scatter in the air, and make no real impression?
What are your axioms, and categories, and systems, and aphorisms? Words, words. High air-castles are cunningly built of words, the words well bedded in good logic-mortar; wherein, however, no knowledge will come to lodge.
What Art had Homer? what Art had Shakespeare?
Patient, docile, valiant intelligence, conscious and unconscious, gathered from all winds, of these two things--their own faculty of utterance, and the audience they had to utter to; add only to which, as the soul of the whole, a blazing, radiant insight into the fact, blazing, burning interest about it, and we have the whole Art of Shakespeare and Homer.
What art was to the ancient world, science is to the modern.
What avail the largest gifts of Heaven, / When drooping health and spirits go amiss? / How tasteless then whatever can be given! / Health is the vital principle of bliss, / And exercise of health.
What avails a superfluity of freedom which we cannot use?
What avails the dram of brandy while it swims chemically united with its barrel of wort? Let the distiller pass it and repass it through his limbecs; for it is the drops of pure alcohol we want, not the gallons of water, which may be had in every ditch.
What belongs to everybody belongs to nobody.
What better time for driving, riding, walking, moving through the air by any means, than a fresh, frosty morning, when hope runs cheerily through the veins with the brisk blood and tingles in the frame from head to foot?
What bitter pills, / Compos'd of real ills, / Men swallow down to purchase one false good.
What boots it at one gate to make defence, / And at another to let in the foe?
What boots the hero-arm without a hero-eye?
What built St. Paul's Cathedral? Look at
the heart of the matter, it was that divine Hebrew Book, the word partly of the man Moses, an outlaw tending his Midianitish herds four thousand years ago in the wildernesses of Sinai!
What by straight path cannot be reached, / By crooked ways is never won.
What can be done, you must do for yourself.
What can ennoble sots, or slaves, or cowards? / Alas! not all the blood of all the Howards.
What can Fate devise to vanquish Love?
What can they see in the longest kingly line
in Europe, save that it runs back to a successful soldier?
What can we reason, but from what we know?
What cannot be abused is good for nothing.
What cannot be avoided, / 'Twere childish weakness to lament or fear.
What cannot be eschew'd must be embraced.
What can't be cured must be endured.
What care I for words? yet words do well / When he that speaks them pleases those that hear.
What cares any man for appearances except as signs of what otherwise he cannot see?
"What cheer? Brother, quickly tell." / "Above"--"Below." "Good-night"--"All's well."
What chiefly distinguishes great artists from feeble artists is first their sensibility and tenderness; secondly, their imagination; and thirdly, their industry.
What comes from God to us, returns from
us to God.
What comes from the heart goes to the heart.
What constitutes a state?... Men who their duties know, / But know their rights, and knowing, dare maintain.
What devilry soever kings do, the Greeks must pay the piper.
What dire offence from amorous causes springs! / What mighty contests rise from trivial things!
What distinguishes Christianity from all monotheistic religions lies in nothing else than in a making-dead to the law, the removal of the Kantian imperative; instead of which Christianity requires a free inclination.
What divine, what truly great thing has ever been effected by force of public opinion?
What do I gain from a man into whose eyes I cannot look when he is speaking, and the mirror of whose soul is veiled to me by a pair of glasses which dazzle me?
What do you mean by composing tragedies, when Tragedy in person stalks every street?
What does competency in the long-run mean? It means, to all reasonable beings, cleanliness of person, decency of dress, courtesy of manners, opportunities for education, the delights of leisure, and the bliss of giving.
 (somet
What doth cherish weeds, but gentle air? / And what makes robbers bold, but too much lenity?
What doth the Lord require of thee, but to do
justly, and to love mercy, and to walk humbly with thy God?
What exile from himself can flee?
What fates impose, that men must needs abide; / It boots not to resist both wind and tide.
What! fly from love? vain hope: there's no retreat, / When he has wings and I have only feet.
What glitters is for the moment; the genuine is for all time.
What God does all day is not to sit waiting
in churches for people to come and worship him.
What God hath joined together, let not man put asunder.
What God makes he never mars.
What good I see humbly I seek to do, / And live obedient to the law, in trust / That what will come, and must come, shall come well.
What governs men is the fear of truth, except such as is useful to them.
What great thing ever happened in this
world, a world understood always to be made and governed by wisdom, without meaning somewhat?
What gunpowder did for war, the printing-press has done for the mind; and the statesman is no longer clad in the steel of special education, but every reading man is his judge.
What hands build, hands can pull down.
What has been, may be; and what may be, may be supposed to be.
What has been written, as well as what has been actually done, shrivels up and ceases to be worth anything, until it has again been taken up into life, been again felt, thought, and acted upon.
What has never anywhere come to pass, that
alone never grows old.
What has posterity done for us / That we, lest they their rights should lose, / Should trust our necks to gripe of noose?
What hath he to do with a soul who doth not keep his passions in subjection?
What have I to do, ... either with your amusements or your pleasures, unless it was in my power to increase their measure?
What have kings that privates have not too, / Save ceremony, save general ceremony?
What have not you men to answer for who
talk of love to a woman when her face is all you know of her, and her passions, her aspirations, are for kissing to sleep, her very soul a plaything?
What he greatly thought, he nobly dared.
What house more stately hath there been, / Or can be, than is Man?
What hypocrites we seem to be whenever we talk of ourselves! Our words sound so humble, while our hearts are so proud.
What I cannot praise I speak not of.
What I for many a day wished, life has not
granted me, but it has instead taught me this, that my wish was a foolish one.
What I gave, that I have; / What I spent, that I had; / What I left, that I lost.
What I have written, I have written.
What I must do is all that concerns me, not what the people think.
What I object to is, not the poetry of sadness, but the sadness of poetry. Many of the poets make out the fountain of poetry to be only a fountain of tears.
What, indeed, is man's life generally but a
kind of beast-godhood; the god in us triumphing more and more over the beast; striving more and more to subdue it under his feet?
What is a foreign country to those who have science?
What is a handful of reasonable men against a crowd with stones in their hands?
What is a man, / If his chief good and market of his time, / Be but to sleep, and feed? A beast, no more.
What is a man profited if he shall gain the whole world and lose his own soul?
What is against Nature is against God.
What is all working, what is all knowing, but a faint interpreting, and a faint showing forth of the mystery, which ever remains infinite?
What, is any one, simply by birth, to be punished or applauded?
What is aught but as 'tis valued?
What is barely necessary cannot be dispensed with.
What is becoming is honourable, and what is
honourable is becoming.
What is beneath me floors me; what is on a level with me bores me; only what is above me supports and lifts me above myself.
What is bought is cheaper than a gift.
What is bred in the bone will never come out of the flesh.
What is called the spirit of the times is at bottom but the spirit of the gentlemen in which the times are mirrored.
What is cheapest to you now is likely to be
dearest in the end.
What is chiefly needed in the England of the present day is to show the quantity of pleasure that may be obtained by a consistent, well-administered competence, modest, confessed, and laborious.
What is difficulty? Only a word indicating the degree of strength requisite for accomplishing particular objects; a mere notice of the necessity for exertion; a bugbear to children and fools; only a mere stimulus to men.
What is distance to the indefatigable?
What is done by night appears by day.
What is done for those who have not their
passions in subjection, is like washing the elephant
What is done in a hurry is never done well.
What is done is done; has already blended itself with the boundless, ever-living, ever-working universe, and will also work there, for good or evil, openly or secretly, through all time.
What is everybody's business is nobody's business.
What is excellent should never be carped at nor discussed, but enjoyed and reverentially thought over in silence.
What is extraordinary try to look at with your
own eyes.
What is false taste but want of perception to discern propriety and distinguish beauty?
What is generally accepted as virtue in women is very different from what is thought so in men: a very good woman would make but a paltry man.
What is generally considered true amounts to much the same as if it were actually true.
What is genius or courage without a heart?
What is genuine but that which is truly excellent,
which stands in harmony with the purest nature or reason, and which even now ministers to our highest development! What is spurious but the absurd and the hollow, which brings no fruit--at least, no good fruit.
What is gray with age becomes religion.
What is happiness? To animals in this world, health.
What is important is to have a soul which loves truth, and receives it wherever it finds it.
What is in will out.
What is it
but an altercation with him before you begin honestly fighting with him?
What is it that keeps men in continual discontent and agitation? It is that they cannot make realities correspond with their conceptions, that enjoyment steals away from among their hands, that the wished-for comes too late, and nothing reached and acquired produces on the heart the effect which their longing for it at a distance led them to anticipate.
What is justice but another form of the reality we love--a truth acted out?
What is kindness? A principle in the good.
What is known to three is known to everybody.
What is learned in the cradle is carried to the
tomb.
What is life but the choice of that good which contains the least of evil!
What is life except the knitting up of incoherences into coherence?
What is man but a symbol of God, and all that he does, if not symbolical, a revelation to sense of the mystic God-given force that is in him?
What is man, / If his chief good, and market of his time, / Be but to sleep and feed? A beast, no man.
What is mine, even to my life, is hers I love;
but the secret of my friend is not mine!
What is modesty, if it deserts from truth?
What is more at ease, more abstracted from the world, than a true single-hearted honesty?
What is much desired is not believed when it comes.
What is my life if I am no longer to be of use to others?
What is nearest is often unattainably far off.
What is nearest us touches us most.
What is new finds better acceptance than what is good or great.
What is noble?--That which places / Truth in its enfranchised will, / Leaving steps, like angel-traces, / That mankind may follow still!
What is not allotted the hand cannot reach, and what is allotted will find you wherever you may be.
What is not sung is properly no poem, but a
piece of prose cramped into jingling lines,--to the great injury of the grammar, to the great grief of the reader, for the most part!
What is not to be, that is not to be; if it be to come to pass, it cannot be otherwise. This reasoning is an antidote. Why doth not the afflicted one drink of it?
What is not true has this advantage that it can be eternally talked about; whereas about truth there is an urgency that cries out for its application, for otherwise it has no right to be there.
What is not worth reading more than once is not worth reading at all.
What is now called the nature of women is an eminently artificial thing--the result of forced repression in some directions, unnatural stimulation in others.
What is obvious is not always known, and what
is known is not always present.
What is of the earth has no permanence; our hearts yearn after a better land.
What is often termed shyness is nothing more than refined sense, and an indifference to common observations.
What is our life but an endless flight of winged facts or events?
What is past is past. There is a future left to all men, who have the virtue to repent and the energy to atone.
What is philosophy? An entire separation from the world.
What is reason now was passion formerly.
What is religion? Compassion for all things
that have life.
What is sauce for the goose is sauce for the gander.
What is specially true of love is, that it is a state of extreme impressionability; the lover has more senses and finer senses than others; his eye and ear are telegraphs; he reads omens in the flower and cloud and face and form and gesture, and reads them aright.
What is strength without a double share / Of wisdom? vast, unwieldy, burdensome, / Proudly secure, yet liable to fall / By weakest subtleties; not made to rule, / But to subserve where wisdom bears command.
What is the adored Supreme Perfection, say?--/ What, but eternal never-resting soul, / Almighty power, and all-directing day; / By whom each atom stirs, the planets roll; / Who fills, surrounds, informs, and agitates the whole.
What is the best government? That which
teaches us to govern ourselves.
What is the best in the world? Healthy blood, sinews of steel, and strong nerves.
What is the body when the head is off?
What is the city but the people? True, the people are the city.
What is the elevation of the soul? A prompt, delicate, certain feeling for all that is beautiful, all that is grand; a quick resolution to do the greatest good by the smallest means; a great benevolence joined to a great strength and great humility.
What is the good of fear? The whole solar
system were it to fall together about our ears could kill us only once.
What is the highest secret of victory and peace? To will what God wills, and strike a league with destiny.
What is the majority? Majority is nonsense
Understanding has always been only with the minority.
What is the true test of character, unless it be its progressive development in the bustle and turmoil, in the action and reaction, of daily life?
What is the use of a lamp to a blind man, although it be burning in his hand?
What is the use of health or of life, if not to
do some work therewith?
What is the voice of song, when the world lacks the ear of taste?
What is there good in us if it is not the power and inclination to appropriate to ourselves the resources of the outward world, and to make them subservient to our higher ends?
What! is there no bribing death?
What is this day's strong suggestion? / "The passing moment's all we rest on!"
What is this life of ours? Gone in a moment,
burnt up like a scroll, into the blank eternity.
What is too great a load for those who have strength?
What is truth?
What is twice read is commonly better remembered than what is transcribed.
What is valuable is not new, and what is new is not valuable.
"What is wanting," said Napoleon one day to
Madame Campan, "in order that the youth of France be well educated?" "Good mothers," was the reply. The Emperor was most forcibly struck with this answer. "Here," said he, "is a system in one word."
What is writ is writ.
What joy a self-sufficing fortune yields, / Such modest livelihood is dear to me. The wise old maxim, "Not too much," / Too much has power my heart to touch.
What life only half imparts to man, posterity shall give entirely.
What love can do, that dares love attempt.
What love hides is raised as from the dead /
Some day, and kills the love which covered it, / And frankest truth is more than subtle wit.
What makes all doctrines plain and clear? / About two hundred pounds a year. / And that which was prov'd true before / Prove false again, two hundred more.
What makes life dreary is the want of motive.
What makes lovers never tire of each others' society is that they talk always about themselves.
What makes many so discontented with their own condition is the absurd estimate they form of the happiness of others.
What makes old age so sad is, not that our
joys, but that our hopes then cease.
What makes people discontented with their condition is the chimerical idea they conceive of the happiness of others.
What makes vanity so insufferable to us is that it wounds our own.
What man dare do, in circumstances of danger, an Englishman will. His virtues seem to sleep in the calm, and are called out only to combat the kindred storm.
What man dare, I dare.
What man didst thou ever know unthrift, that
was beloved after his means?
What man has done, man can do.
What man wants is always that the highest in his nature be set at the top and actively reign there.
What matter though I doubt at every pore ... / If finally I have a life to show, / The thing I did, brought out in evidence / Against the thing done to me underground / By hell and all its brood, for aught I know?
What matters it though the Gospels contradict each other if the Gospel does not contradict itself?
What matters it whether the alphabet
which you are to spell out the meaning of life) 
which you are to spell out the meaning of life)  ones, so you have an eye to read it?
What may be dune at ony time will be dune at
nae time.
What men prize most is a privilege, even if it be that of chief mourner at a funeral.
What men usually say of misfortunes, that they never come alone, may with equal truth be said of good fortune; nay, of other circumstances which gather round us in a harmonious way, whether it arise from a kind of fatality, or that man has the power of attracting to himself things that are mutually related.
What men want is not talent; it is purpose.
What millions died that Cæsar might be great!
What must be, shall be.
What Nature does not reveal to thy spirit, thou wilt not wrench from her with levers and screws.
What need the bridge much broader than the flood? The fairest grant is the necessity; look, what will serve is fit.
What need we have any friends, if we should never have need of them?
What needs my Shakespeare for his honour'd bones?
What of books? Hast thou not already a Bible
to write and publish in print that is eternal, namely, a Life to lead?
What once were vices are now the manners of the day.
What people call her
hers at all; but that of her kings (though the history of them is worth reading), or the tax-gatherers employed by them, which is as if people were to call Mr. Gladstone's history or Mr. Lowe's, yours or mine.
What perils on a woman's life may throng, / Sitting lonely with her thoughts, that chafe and murmur like the surf!
What persons are by starts, they are by nature. You see them at such times off their guard. Habit may restrain vice, and virtue may be obscured by passion, but intervals best discover the man.
What profit is it for men now to live in heaviness,
and after death to look for punishment?
What proves the hero truly great, / Is never, never to despair.
What quite infinite worth lies in Truth! how all-pervading, omnipotent, in man's mind is the thing we name Belief!
What rage for fame attends both great and small! / Better be damned than mentioned not at all.
What rein can hold licentious wickedness / When down the hill he holds his fierce career?
What religion do I profess! None of all you
name to me. Why none? Out of respect to religion.
What right have you, O passer-by-the-way, to call any flower a weed? Do you know its merits, its virtues, its healing qualities? Because a thing is common, shall you despise it? If so, you might despise the sunshine for the same reason.
What rights are his that dare not strike for them?
"What says Lord Warwick? Shall we after them?" "After them! Nay, before them if we can."
What shadows we are, and what shadows we pursue!
What shall be, shall be--that is all; / To one
great Will we stand and fall, / "The Scheme hath need"--we ask not why, / And in this faith we live or die.
What shapest thou here at the world; 'Tis shapen long ago; / The Maker shaped it, He thought it best even so. / Thy lot is appointed, go follow its hest; / Thy journey's begun, thou must move and not rest; / For sorrow and care cannot alter thy case, / And running, not raging, will win thee the race.
What signifies the life o' man / An' twerna for the lasses, O?
What signifies the loss of a Hercules even to the loss of an idea?
What signifies your gear? / A mind that's scrimpit never wants some care.
What should a wise man do if he is given a
blow? What Cato did when some one struck him on the mouth;--not fire up or revenge the insult, or even return the blow, but simply ignore it.
What skills it if a bag of stones or gold / About thy neck do drown thee? Raise thy head; / Take stars for money; stars not to be told / By any art, yet to be purchased.
What stronger breastplate than a heart untainted!
What the eye does not admire, / The heart does not desire.
What the eye don't see, the heart don't grieve.
What the fool does in the end, the wise man
does at the beginning.
What the heart has once owned and had, it shall never lose.
What the heart or the imagination dictates always flows readily; but where there is no subject to warm or interest these, constraint appears.
What the light of your mind pronounces incredible, that, in God's name, leave uncredited.
What the Maker sends us remains mysteriously with us after the bearer of it is dead and gone; and we, as we "mourn over, long for, and love distant and departed" goodness, are more embraced and possessed by it than we were when it was present with us only in the flesh, and we could look upon it and handle it.
What the poet has to cultivate above all things is love and truth;--what he has to avoid, like poison, is the fleeting and the false.
What the Puritans gave the world was not thought, but action.
What the universe was thought to be in Judea and other places, this may be very interesting to know; what it is in England here where we live and have our work to do, that is the interesting point.
What thou seest is not there on its own
account, strictly taken, is not there at all.
What though care killed a cat: thou hast mettle enough in thee to kill care.
What though on hamely fare we dine, / Wear hodden gray, and a' that? / Gie fools their silk, and knaves their wine, / A man's a man for a' that.
What though our songs to wit have no pretence, / The fiddlestick shall scrape them into sense.
What though success will not attend on all! / Who bravely dares must sometimes risk a fall.
What though the field be lost? / All is not
lost; th' unconquerable will, / And study of revenge, immortal hate, / And courage never to submit or yield.
What though the foot be shackled; the heart is free.
What, though thou wert rich and of high esteem, dost thou yield to sorrow because of thy loss of fortune?
What tragic wastes of gloom / Curtain the soul that strives and sins below!
What trifling silliness is the childish fondness of the every-day children of the world! 'Tis the unmeaning toying of the younglings of the fields and forests.
What 'twas weak to do, / 'Tis weaker to
lament, once being done.
What unknown seas of feeling lie in man, and will from time to time break through!
