Will a courser of the sun work softly in the harness of a dray-horse? His hoofs are of fire, and his path is through the heavens, bringing light to all lands; will he lumber on mud highways, dragging ale for earthly appetites from door to door?
Will all great Neptune's ocean wash this blood / Clean from my hand? No, this my hand will rather / The multitudinous seas incarnadine, / Making the green one red.
Will is deaf, and hears no heedful friends.
Will it, and set to work briskly.
Will localises us; thought universalises us.
Will minus intellect constitutes vulgarity.
"Will-to-do," which is the spirit of the true God, is eternally incompatible with "wish-to-have," which is the proper spirit of the false.
Willing to wound, and yet afraid to strike, / Just hint a fault, and hesitate dislike.
Willows are weak, yet they bind other wood.
Willst du den Dichter verstehen, so lerne wie
Dichter empfinden
Willst du dich am Ganzen erquicken, / So musst du das Ganze im Kleinsten erblicken
Willst du immer weiter schweifen? / Sieh, das Gute liegt so nah! / Lerne nur das Glück ergreifen, / Denn das Glück ist immer da
Willst du in's Unendliche schreiten, / Geh' nur im Endliche nach allen Seiten
Willst du leben, musst du dienen; willst du frei sein, musst du sterben
Willst du mit Kinderhänden / In des Schicksals
Speichen greifen? / Seines Donnerwagens Lauf / Hält kein sterblich Wesen auf
Willst lustig leben, geh' mit zwei Säcken, / Einen zu geben, einen um einzustecken
Wilt thou draw near the nature of the gods? Draw near them, then, in being merciful.
Wilt thou know a man, above all a mankind, by stringing together beadrolls of what thou namest facts? The man is the spirit he worked in; not what he did, but what he became.
Wilt thou know thyself, see how others do; wilt thou understand others, look into thine own heart.
"Win hearts," said Burleigh to Queen Elizabeth,
"and you have all men's hearts and purses."
Wine and youth are fire upon fire.
Wine is a mocker, strong drink is raging: and whosoever is deceived thereby is not wise.
Wine is a turncoat; first a friend and then an enemy.
Wine neither keeps secrets nor fulfils promises.
Wine washes off the daub.
Wings have we--and as far as we can go, / We may find pleasure: wilderness and wood, / Blank ocean and mere sky, support that mood / Which with the lofty, sanctifies the low.
Wink at small faults.
Wir Menschen sind ja alle Brüder
Wisdom alone is a science of other sciences and of itself.
Wisdom and Fortune combating together, / If that the former dare but what he can, / No chance may shake it.
Wisdom and knowledge shall be the stability of thy times.
Wisdom becomes nonsense
Wisdom begins at the end.
Wisdom excelleth folly, as far as light excelleth
darkness.
Wisdom is a defence, and money is a defence: but the excellency of knowledge is, that wisdom giveth life to them that have it.
Wisdom is a pearl; with most success / Sought in still water and beneath clear skies.
Wisdom is intrinsically of a silent nature; it cannot at once, or completely at all, be read off in words, and is only legible in whole when its work is done.
Wisdom is justified of her children.
Wisdom is not found with those who dwell at
their ease; rather Nature, when she adds brain, adds difficulty.
Wisdom is ofttimes nearer when we stoop than when we soar.
Wisdom is only in truth.
Wisdom is that attribute through which every action of a man receives its ideal value or import
Wisdom is the principal thing; therefore get wisdom: and with all thy getting get understanding.
Wisdom is too high for a fool.
Wisdom makes a slow defence against trouble, though at last a sure one.
Wisdom may be the ultimate arbiter, but is seldom the immediate agent in human affairs.
Wisdom may sometimes wear a look austere, / But smiles and jests are oft her helpmates here.
Wisdom not only gets, but, got, retains.
Wisdom picks friends; civility plays the rest. /
A toy shunn'd cleanly passeth with the best.
Wisdom resteth in the heart of him that hath understanding.
Wisdom sends us to childhood; "unless ye become as little children."
Wisdom sits with children round her knees.
Wisdom sometimes walks in clouted shoes.
Wisdom that is hid, and treasure that is
hoarded up, what profit is in them both?
Wisdom, which represents the marriage of truth and virtue, is by no means synonymous with gravity. She is L'Allegro as well as Il Penseroso, and jests as well as preaches.
Wisdom will out; it is the one thing in this world that cannot be suppressed or annulled.
Wisdom's a trimmer thing than shop e'er gave.
Wisdom's path is steep; but, gained the height, / The Muse's gifts will fill you with delight.
Wise above that which is written.
Wise, cultivated, genial conversation is the best flower of civilisation, and the best result which life has to offer us--a cup for gods, which has no repentance. Conversation is our account of ourselves. All we have, all we can, all we know is brought into play, and as the reproduction, in finer form, of all our havings.
Wise is the man prepared for either end, / Who in due measure can both spare and spend.
Wise kings have generally wise councillors, as he must be a wise man himself who is capable of distinguishing one.
Wise men are instructed by reason; men of less understanding, by experience; the most ignorant, by necessity; and beasts, by nature.
Wise men are not wise at all hours, and will
speak five times from their taste or their humour to one from their reason.
Wise men are wise but not prudent, in that they know nothing of what is for their own advantage, but know surpassing things, marvellous things, difficult things, and divine things.
Wise men argue causes, and fools decide them.
Wise men, for the most part, are silent at present, and good men powerless; the senseless vociferate, and the heartless govern; while all social law and providence are dissolved by the enraged agitation of a multitude, among whom every villain has a chance of power, every simpleton of praise, and every scoundrel of fortune.
Wise men mingle mirth with their cares, as a help either to forget or overcome them; but to resort to intoxication for the ease of one's mind is to cure melancholy by madness.
Wise men ne'er sit and wail their loss, / But
cheerly seek how to redress their harms.
Wise men say nothing in dangerous times.
Wise sayings are as saltpits; you may extract salt out of them, and sprinkle it where you will.
Wise sayings are not only for ornament, but for action and business, having a point or edge, whereby knots in business are pierced and discovered.
Wise sayings are the guiding oracles which man has found out for himself in that great business of ours, of learning how to be, to do, to do without, and to depart.
Wise to resolve, and patient to perform.
Wise, well-calculated breeding of a young soul lies fatally over the horizon in these epochs.
Wisely and slow; they stumble that run fast.
Wishing, of all employments, is the worst.
Wissen ist leichter als thun
Wit and judgment often are at strife, / Though
meant each other's aid, like man and wife.
Wit and understanding are trifles without integrity.
Wit and wisdom are born with a man.
Wit, bright, rapid, and blasting as the lightning, flashes, strikes, and vanishes in an instant; humour, warm and all-embracing as the sunshine, bathes its object in a genial and abiding light.
Wit is a dangerous weapon, even to the possessor, if he knows not how to use it discreetly.
Wit is a pernicious thing when it is not tempered
with virtue and humanity.
Wit is brushwood, judgment timber; the one gives the greatest flame, the other yields the durablest heat; and both meeting make the best fire.
Wit is of the true Pierian spring, that can make anything of anything.
Wit marries ideas lying wide apart, by a sudden jerk of the understanding.
Wit once bought is worth twice taught.
Wit strews a single ray
from the rest upon an object; never white light, that is the province of wisdom.
Wit, when neglected by the great, is generally despised by the vulgar.
Wit without employment is a disease.
Wit without wisdom is salt without meat.
Wit-work is always play, when it is good.
Wit's an unruly engine, wildly striking / Sometimes
a friend, sometimes the engineer: / Hast thou the knack? pamper it not with liking; / But if thou want it, buy it not too dear.
Witchcraft has been put a stop to by Act of Parliament, but the mysterious relations which it emblemed still continue.
With all appliances and means to boot.
With bag and baggage.
With centric and eccentric scribbled o'er, / Cycle and epicycle, orb in orb.
With consistency a great soul has simply
nothing to do. He may as well concern himself with his shadow on the wall.
With curious art the brain, too finely wrought, / Preys on herself, and is destroyed by thought.
With devotion's visage / And pious action we do sugar over / The devil himself.
With disadvantages enough to call him down to humility, a Scotchman is one of the proudest things alive.
With every anguish of our earthly part the spirit's sight grows clearer; this was meant when Jesus touched the blind man's lids with clay.
With every breath we draw, an ethereal
stream of Lethe runs through our whole being, so that we have but a partial recollection of our joys, and scarcely any of our sorrows.
With faith, martyrs, otherwise weak, can cheerfully endure the shame and the cross: and without it worldlings puke up their sick existence, by suicide, in the midst of luxury.
With fingers weary and worn, / With eyelids heavy and red, / A woman sat in unwomanly rags, / Plying her needle and thread--/ Stitch! stitch! stitch!
"With it, or upon it, my son."
With just enough of learning to misquote.
With love come life and hope.
With malice towards none, with charity for all, with firmness in the right, as God gives us to see the right.
With mirth and laughter let old wrinkles come.
With moral, political, religious considerations, high and dear as they may otherwise be, the philosopher, as such, has no concern.
With much we surfeit; plenty makes us poor.
With narrow-minded persons, and those in a
state of mental darkness, we find conceit: while with mental clearness and high endowments we never find it. In such cases there is generally a joyful feeling of strength, but since this strength is actual, the feeling is anything else you please, only not conceit.
With none who bless us, none whom we can bless--/ This is to be alone; this, this is solitude!
With necessity, the tyrant's plea, excused his devilish deeds.
With ordinary talent and extraordinary perseverance, all things are attainable.
With parsimony a little is sufficient, and without it nothing is sufficient, whereas frugality makes a poor man rich.
With patient mind thy path of duty run; /
God nothing does, nor suffers to be done, / But thou thyself wouldst do, if thou couldst see / The end of all events as well as he.
With poetry, as with going to sea, we should push from the shore and reach a certain elevation before we unfurl all our sails.
With poetry second-rate in quality, no one ought to be allowed to trouble mankind.
With remembrance of the greater grief to banish the less.
With respect to luxuries and comforts, the wisest have ever lived a more simple and meagre life than the poor.
With some life is exactly like a sleigh-drive,
showy and tinkling, but affording just as little for the heart as it offers much to eyes and ears.
With stupidity and sound digestion man may front much; but what in these dull, unimaginative days are the terrors of conscience to the diseases of the liver!
With temperance, health, cheerfulness, friends, a chosen task, one pays the cheapest fees for living, and may well dispense with other physicians.
With the dead there is no rivalry. In the dead there is no change. Plato is never sullen. Cervantes is never petulant. Demosthenes never comes unseasonably. Dante never stays too long.
With the Gospels one becomes a heretic.
With the majority of men unbelief in one thing is founded on blind belief in another thing.
With the possession or certain expectation of
good things our demand rises, and increases our capacity for further possession and larger expectations.
With thought, with the ideal, is immortal hilarity, the rose of joy. Round it all the Muses sing.
With too much quickness ever to be taught; / With too much thinking to have common thought.
With virtue, capacity, and good conduct, one still can be insupportable. The manners, which are neglected as small things, are often those which decide men for or against you. A slight attention to them would have prevented their ill judgments.
With well-doing ye may put to silence foolish men.
With what a heavy and retarding weight does
expectation load the wing of time.
With what is debateable I am unconcerned; and when I have only opinions about things ... I do not talk about them. I attack only what cannot on any possible ground be defended; and state only what I know to be incontrovertibly true.
With women worth the being won, / The softest lover ever best succeeds.
Withdraw thy foot from thy neighbour's house; lest he be weary of thee, and so hate thee.
Withhold not good from them to whom it is due, when it is in the power of thine hand to do it.
Within man is the soul of the whole; the
wise silence, the universal beauty, to which every part and particle is equally related--the Eternal One.
Within that awful volume lies / The mystery of mysteries.
Within the hollow crown / That rounds the mortal temples of a king, / Keeps Death his court.
Within the most starched cravat there passes a windpipe and weasand, and under the thickliest embroidered waistcoat beats a heart.
Within us all a universe doth dwell.
Within yourselves deliverance must be
Each man his pri
Without a belief in personal immortality religion surely is like an arch resting on one pillar, like a bridge ending in an abyss.
Without a God there is for man neither purpose, nor goal, nor hope, only a wavering future, an eternal dread of every darkness.
Without a rich heart wealth is an ugly beggar.
Without a sign his sword the brave man draws, / And asks no omen but his country's cause.
Without adversity a man hardly knows
whether he is honest or not.
Without affecting stoicism, it may be said that it is our business to exempt ourselves as much as we can from the power of external things.
Without cheerfulness no man can be a poet.
Without discretion learning is pedantry and wit impertinence; virtue itself looks like weakness. The best parts only qualify a man to be more sprightly in errors, and active to his own prejudice.
Without earnestness there is nothing to be done in life; yet among the people we name cultivated, little earnestness is to be found.
Without economy none can be rich, and with
it few can be poor.
Without enjoyment, the wealth of the miser is the same to him as if it were another's. But when it is said of a man "he hath so much," it is with difficulty he can be induced to part with it.
Without eyes thou shalt want light: profess not the knowledge therefore that thou hast not.
Without friends no one would choose to live, even if he had all other good things.
Without God in the world.
Without great men, great crowds of people in
a nation are disgusting; like moving cheese, like hills of ants or of fleas--the more, the worse.
Without great men nothing can be done.
Without justice society is sick, and will continue sick till it dies.
Without me ye can do nothing.
Without passion man is a mere latent force and possibility.
Without passion there is no geniality.
Without philosophy we should be little above the lower animals.
Without poetry our science will appear incomplete, and most of what now passes with us for religion and philosophy will be replaced by poetry.
Without real masters you cannot have servants.
Without some strong motive to the contrary, men united by the pursuit of a clearly defined common aim of irresistible attractiveness naturally coalesce; and since they coalesce naturally, they are clearly right in coalescing and find their advantage in it.
Without tact you can learn nothing. Tact
teaches you when to be silent. Inquirers who are always inquiring never learn anything.
Without the spiritual world the material world is a disheartening enigma.
Without the way there is no going; without the truth, no knowing; without the life, no living.
Without were fightings, within were fears.
Without wonder there is no faith.
Witticisms please as long as we keep them
within bounds, but pushed to excess they cause offence.
Witty, above all, O be not witty; none of us is bound to be witty, under penalties; to be wise and true we all are, under the terriblest penalties.
Wives are young men's mistresses, companions for middle age, and old men's nurses.
Wo der Teufel nicht hin mag; da send er seinen Boten hin
Wo fasse ich dich, unendliche Natur?
Wo grosse Höh', ist grosse Tiefe
Wo innen Sklaverei ist, wird sie von aussen bald kommen
Wo man singet, lass dich ruhig nieder, / Ohne Furcht, was man am Lande glaubt; / Wo man singet wird kein Mensch beraubt; / Bösewichter haben keine Lieder
Wo viel Freiheit, ist viel Irrthum
Wo viel Licht ist, ist starker Schatten
Wo viel zu wagen ist, ist viel zu wägen
Woe does the heavier sit / Where it perceives it is but faintly borne.
Woe, that too late repents.
Woe to every sort of culture which destroys the most effectual means of all true culture, and directs us to the end, instead of rendering us happy on the way.
Woe to him that is alone when he falleth; for he hath not another to help him up.
Woe to that land that's govern'd by a child.
Woe unto him that is never alone, and cannot bear to be alone.
Woe unto you when all men speak well of you.
Woe, woe to youth, to life, which idly boasts, / I am the End, and mine the appointed Way.
Wohl unglückselig ist der Mann, / Der unterlässt das, was er kann, / Und unterfängt sich, was er nicht versteht; / Kein Wunder, dass er zu Grunde geht
Wohlgethan überlebt den Tod
Wohlthätigheit kennt keinen Unterschied der Nation
Wollt ihr auf Menschen wirken, / Müsst ihr erst Menschen werden
Wollt ihr immer leben?
Wolves in sheep's clothing.
Woman alone knows true loyalty of affection.
Woman, divorced from home, wanders unfriended like a waif upon the wave.
Woman endeavours to breed her daughter a fine lady, qualifying her for a station in which she will never appear, and at the same time incapacitating her for that retirement to which she is destined.
Woman, in accordance with her unbroken, clear-seeing nature, loses herself, and what she has of heart and happiness, in the object she loves.
Woman is at once the delight and the terror of man.
Woman is like the reed which bends to every
breeze, but breaks not in the tempest.
Woman is mistress of the art of completely embittering the life of the person on whom she depends.
Woman is not undevelopt man, / But diverse; could we make her as the man, / Sweet love were slain: his dearest bond is this / Not like to like, but like in difference.
Woman is seldom merciful to the man who is timid.
Woman is the blood-royal of life; let there be slight degrees of precedency among them, but let them be all sacred.
Woman is the lesser man.
Woman is the salvation or the destruction of the family.
Woman is too soft to hate permanently; even if a hundred men have been a grief to her, she will still love the hundred and first.
Woman, last at the cross and earliest at the grave.
Woman, once made equal to man, becometh his superior.
Woman sees deep; man sees far. To the man
the world is his heart; to the woman the heart is her world.
Woman's at best a contradiction still.
Woman's cause is man's; they rise or sink / Together, dwarfed or godlike, bond or free.
Woman's counsel is not worth much, yet he that despises it is no wiser than he should be.
Woman's dignity lies in her being unknown; her glory, in the esteem of her husband; and her pleasure, in the welfare of her family.
Woman's fear and love hold quantity; / In neither aught, or in extremity.
Woman's function is a guiding, not a determining one.
Woman's grief is like a summer storm, short as it is violent.
Woman's heart is just like a lithographer's stone--what is once written upon it cannot be rubbed out.
Woman's love, like lichens upon a rock, will
still grow where even charity can find no soil to nurture itself.
Woman's power is for rule, not for battle; and her intellect is not for invention or creation, but for sweet ordering, arrangement, and decision.
Woman's power is over the affections. A beautiful dominion is hers, but she risks its forfeiture when she seeks to extend it.
Woman's tongue is her sword, which she never lets rust.
Woman's virtue is the music of stringed instruments, which sound best in a room; but man's that of wind instruments, which sound best in the open air.
Woman's work, grave sirs, is never done.
Women always show more taste in adorning others than themselves; and the reason is, that their persons are like their hearts--they read another's better than they can their own.
Women and clergymen have so long been in the habit of using pretty words without troubling themselves to understand them, that they now revolt from the effort, as if it were impiety.
Women and men of retiring timidity are cowardly only in dangers which affect themselves, but the first to rescue when others are endangered.
Women are as roses, whose fair flower / Being once display'd, doth fall that very hour.
Women are born worshippers.
Women are confined within the narrow limits of domestic assiduity, and when they stray beyond them they move beyond their sphere, and consequently without grace.
Women are ever in extremes; they are either better or worse than men.
Women are like limpets, they need something to hold on by.
Women are the poetry of the world, in the same sense as the stars are the poetry of heaven. Clear, light-giving, harmonious, they are the terrestrial planets that rule the destinies of mankind.
Women bestow on friendship only what they
borrow from love.
Women cannot see so far as men can, but what they do see they see quicker.
Women exceed the generality of men in love.
Women famed for their valour, their skill in politics or their learning, leave the duties of their own sex in order to invade the privileges of men's.
Women forgive injuries, but never forget slights.
Women have a kind of sturdy sufferance
which qualifies them to endure beyond, much beyond, the common run of men, but ... they are by no means famous for seeing remote consequences in all their real importance.
Women, it has been observed, are not naturally formed for great cares themselves, but to soften ours.
Women judge women hardly; ... they have no shading, / No softening tints, no generous allowance / For circumstance to make the picture human, / And true because so human.
Women know by nature how to disguise their emotions far better than the most consummate male courtiers can do.
Women, like princes, find few real friends.
Women, like the plants in woods, derive their
softness and tenderness from the shade.
Women may fall when there's no strength in men.
Women, priests, and poultry have never enough.
Women should learn betimes to serve according to station, for by serving alone she at last attains to the mastery, to the due influence which she ought to possess in the household.
Women that are the least bashful are not unfrequently the most modest; and we are never more deceived than when we would infer any laxity of principle from that freedom of demeanour which often arises from a total ignorance of vice.
Women, though they have the warmest hearts,
are no citizens of the world, scarcely citizens of a town or a village, but only of their own home.
Women who have lost their faith / Are angels who have lost their wings.
Women wish to be loved, not because they are pretty, or good, or well-bred, or graceful, or intelligent, but because they are themselves.
Women's hearts are made of stout leather; there's a plaguy sight of wear in them.
Women's jars breed men's wars.
Women's rage, like shallow water, / Does
but show their hurtless nature; / When the stream seems rough and frowning, / There is still least fear of drowning.
Women's sins are not alone the ills they do, / But those that they provoke you to.
Wonder is from surprise, and surprise ceases upon experience.
Wonder on till truth make all things plain.
"Wonder," says Aristotle, "is the first cause of philosophy." This is quite as true in the progress of the individual as in that of the concrete mind; and the constant aim of philosophy is to destroy its parent.
Wondrous indeed is the virtue of a true book. Not like a dead city of stones, yearly crumbling, yearly needing repair; more like a tilled field, but then a spiritual field; like a spiritual tree, let me rather say, it stands from year to year, and from age to age (we have books that already number some one hundred and fifty human ages); and yearly comes its new produce of leaves (commentaries, deductions, philosophical, political systems, or were it only sermons, pamphlets, journalistic essays), every one of which is talismanic and thaumaturgic, for it can persuade men.
Wondrous is the strength of cheerfulness, altogether past calculation its powers of endurance.
Woodman, spare that tree! / Touch not a single bough! / In youth it sheltered me, / And I'll protect it now.
Words are also actions, and actions are a kind of words.
Words are but poor interpreters in the realms
of emotion. When all words end, music begins; when they suggest, it realises; and hence the secret of its strange, ineffable power.
Words are but wind, but seein's believin'.
Words are fools' pence.
Words are good, but they are not the best. The best is not to be explained by words.
Words are like leaves, and when they most abound / Much fruit of sense beneath is rarely found.
Words are like sea-shells on the shore; they
show / Where the mind ends, and not how far it has been.
Words are men's daughters, but God's sons are things.
Words are rather the drowsy part of poetry; imagination the life of it.
Words are the motes of thought, and nothing more.
Words are things, and a small drop of ink, / Falling like dew upon a thought, produces / That which makes thousands, perhaps millions, think.
Words are wise men's counters, but they are
the money of fools.
Words are women, deeds are men.
Words become luminous when the finger of the poet touches them with his phosphorus.
Words do sometimes fly from the tongue that the heart did neither hatch nor harbour.
Words, like Nature, half reveal / And half conceal the soul within.
Words may be counterfeit, false coined, and
current only from the tongue, without the mind; but passion is in the soul, and always speaks the heart.
Words of love are works of love.
Words pay no debts.
Words that are now dead were once alive.
Words, "those fickle daughters of the earth," are the creation of a being that is finite, and when applied to explain that which is infinite, they fail; for that which is made surpasses not the maker; nor can that which is immeasurable by our thoughts be measured by our tongues.
Words to the heat of deeds too cold breath
give.
Words which flow fresh and warm from a full heart, and which are instinct with the life and breath of human feeling, pass into household memories, and partake of the immortality of the affections from which they spring.
Words without thoughts never to heaven go.
Work, according to my feeling, is as much of a necessity to man as eating and sleeping. Even those who do nothing which to a sensible man can be called work, still imagine that they are doing something. The world possesses not a man who is an idler in his own eyes.
Work alone is noble.
"Work and wait," "Work and wait," is what
God says to us in creation and in providence.
Work earnestly at anything, you will by degrees learn to work at almost all things.
Work first, you are God's servants; fee first, you are the fiend's.
Work for eternity: not the meagre rhetorical eternity of the periodical critics, but for the real eternity, wherein dwelleth the Divine.
Work for immortality if you will: then wait for it.
Work for some good, be it ever so slowly; /
Cherish some flower, be it ever so lowly; / Labour! all labour is noble and holy: / Let thy great deeds be thy prayer to thy God.
Work, go, fall, rise, speak, be silent! In this manner do the rich sport with those needy men, who are held by the grip of dependence.
Work is for the living.
Work is not man's punishment; it is his reward and his strength, his glory and his pleasure.
Work is of a religious nature,--work is of a brave nature, which it is the aim of all religion to be. "All work of man is as the swimmer's." A waste ocean threatens to devour him; if he front it not bravely, it will keep its word. By incessant wise defiance of it, lusty rebuke and buffet of it, behold how it loyally supports him,--bears him as its conqueror along! "It is so," says Goethe, "with all things that man undertakes in this world."
Work is only done well when it is done with
a will.
Work is our business; its success is God's.
Work is the cure for all the maladies and miseries of man--honest work, which you intend getting done.
Work is the inevitable condition of human life, the true source of human welfare.
Work is the mission of man on this planet.
Work is the only universal currency which God accepts. A nation's welfare will depend on its ability to master the world; that, on power of work; that, on its power of thought.
Work, properly so called, is an appeal from the Seen to the Unseen--a devout calling upon Higher Powers; and unless they stand by us, it will not be a work, but a quackery.
Work till the last beam fadeth, / Fadeth to shine no more; / Work while the night is darkening, / When man's work is o'er.
Work touches the keys of endless activity,
opens the infinite, and stands awe-struck before the immensity of what there is to do.
Work was made for man, and not man for work.
Work without hope draws nectar in a sieve, / And hope without an object cannot live.
Work, work, work, / Till the brain begins to swim; / Work, work, work, / Till the eyes are heavy and dim; / Seam, and gusset, and band, / Band, and gusset, and seam, / Till over the buttons I fall asleep, / And sew them on in a dream.
Works of true merit are seldom very popular in their own day; for knowledge is on the march, and men of genius are the "præstolatores" or "videttes," that are far in advance of their comrades. They are not with them, but before them; not in the camp, but beyond it.
Worldly affairs, which my friends thought so
heavy upon me, they are most of them of our own making, and fall away as soon as we know ourselves.
Worldly riches are like nuts; many clothes are torn in getting them, many a tooth broke in cracking them, but never a belly filled with eating them.
Worse than being fool'd / Of others, is to fool one's self.
Worse than despair, / Worse than the bitterness of death, is hope; / It is the only ill which can find place / Upon the giddy, sharp, and narrow hour / Tottering beneath us.
Worship is transcendent wonder; wonder for which there is no limit or measure.
Worship that is false will kill the soul as
quickly as no worship.
Worship your heroes from afar; contact withers them.
Worte sind der Seele Bild
Worte sind gut, wenn Werke folgen
Worth makes the man, and want of it the fellow; / The rest is all but leather or prunello.
Worth many thousand is the first salute; /
Him that salutes thee, therefore, friendly greet.
Worthless people live only to eat and drink; people of worth eat and drink only to live.
Would they could sell us experience, though at diamond prices, but then no one would use the article second-hand!
Would we but pledge ourselves to truth as heartily as we do to a real or imaginary mistress, and think life too short only because it abridges our time of service, what a new world we should have!
Would we but quit ourselves like men, and resolutely stand our ground, we should not fail of succours from above.
Would Wisdom for herself be wooed, / And
wake the foolish from his dream, / She must be glad as well as good, / And must not only be, but seem.
Would you have men think well of you, then do not speak well of yourself.
Wouldst thou a maiden make thy prize, / Thyself alone the bribe must be.
Wouldst thou both eat thy cake and have it?
Wouldst thou know thyself, then see how others act; wouldst thou understand others, look thou into thine own heart.
Wouldst thou plant for eternity? then plant
into the deep infinite faculties of man, his fantasy and heart. Wouldst thou plant for year and day? then plant into his shallow superficial faculties, his self-love and arithmetical understanding, what will grow there.
"Wouldst thou," so the helmsman answered, / "Learn the secret of the sea? / Only those who brave its dangers / Comprehend its mystery!"
Wouldst thou subject all things to thyself? Subject thyself to reason.
Wouldst thou the life of souls discern? / Nor human wisdom nor divine / Helps thee by aught beside to learn; / Love is life's only sign.
Wouldst thou travel the path of truth and goodness? Never deceive either thyself or others.
Wounds and hardships provoke our courage,
and when our fortunes are at the lowest, our wits and minds are commonly at the best.
Wounds cannot be cured without searching.
Wrap thyself up like a woodlouse, and dream revenge.
Write down the advice of him who loves you, though you like it not at present.
Write how you will, the critic shall show the world you could have written better.
Write, so much given to God; thou shalt be
heard.
Write thy wrongs in ashes.
Writers of novels and romances in general bring a double loss on their readers--they rob them both of their time and money; representing men, manners, and things, that never have been, nor are likely to be; either confounding or perverting history and truth, inflating the mind, or committing violence upon the understanding.
Writing is not literature unless it gives to the reader a pleasure which arises not only from the things said, but from the way in which they are said; and that pleasure is only given when the words are carefully or curiously or beautifully put together into sentences.
Written all of it
sympathetic ink. Bible awakens it, and you can read.
Wrong is not only different from right, but it is in strict scientific terms infinitely different.
Wrongs are often forgiven, but contempt never is. Our pride remembers it for ever. It implies a discovery of weaknesses, which we are much more careful to conceal than crimes. Many a man will confess his crimes to a common friend, but I never knew a man who would tell his silly weaknesses to his most intimate one.
Würf er einen Groschen auf's Dach, fiel ihm
ein Thaler herunter
Ye are my friends, if ye do whatsoever I command you.
Ye are the light of the world.
Ye are the people, and wisdom shall die with you.
Ye are the salt of the earth.
Ye blind guides, which strain at a gnat and
swallow a camel.
Ye cannot serve God and mammon.
Ye fearful saints, fresh courage take; / The clouds ye so much dread / Are big with mercy, and shall break / In blessings on your head.
Ye gentlemen of England / That live at home at ease, / Ah! little do you think upon / The dangers of the seas.
Ye gods, it doth amaze me / A man of such a feeble temper should / So get the start of the majestic world / And bear the palm alone.
Ye good yeomen, whose limbs were made in
England.
Ye hae a stalk o' carl-hemp in you.
Ye have not chosen me, but I have chosen you.
Ye mariners of England, / That guard our native seas, / Whose flag has braved a thousand years / The battle and the breeze.
Ye may darken over the blue heavens, ye vapoury masses in the sky. It matters not! Beyond the howling of that wrath, beyond the blackness of those clouds, there shines, unaltered and serene, the moon that shone in Paradise.... The moon that promises a paradise restored.
Ye men of gloom and austerity, who paint the
face of Infinite Benevolence with an eternal frown, read in the everlasting book, wide open to your view, the lesson it would teach. Its pictures are not in black and sombre hues, but bright and glowing tints; its music--save when ye drown it--is not in sighs and groans, but songs and cheerful sounds. Listen to the million voices in the summer air, and find one dismal as your own.
Ye shall know them by their fruits.
Ye stars! which are the poetry of heaven!... In our aspirations to be great, / Our destinies o'erleap their mortal state, / And claim a kindred with you; for ye are / A beauty and a mystery, and create / In us such love and reverence from afar, / That fortune, fame, power, life, have named themselves a star.
Ye think the rustic cackle of your bourg / The murmur of the world.
Ye'll find mankind an unco squad, / And muckle they may grieve ye.
Yea, let all good things await / Him who cares
not to be great, / But as he saves or serves the state.
Yea, surely the sea like a harper laid hand on the shore as a lyre.
Year chases year, decay pursues decay, / Still drops some joy from withering life away.
Years do not make sages; they only make old men.
Years following years steal something every day; / At last they steal us from ourselves away.
Years steal / Fire from the mind as vigour
from the limb, / And life's enchanted cup but sparkles near the brim.
Yes, there are things we must dream and dare, / And execute ere thought be half aware.
Yes, you find people ready enough to do the good Samaritan without the oil and twopence.
Yet a little while, and we shall all meet there, and our Mother's bosom will screen us all; and Oppression's harness, and Sorrow's fire-whip, and all the Gehenna bailiffs that patrol and inhabit ever-vexed Time, cannot harm us any more.
Yet all that poets sing, and grief hath known, / Of hopes laid waste, knells in that word--Alone.
Yet better thus, and known to be contemn'd, /
Than still contemn'd and flatter'd.
Yet do I fear thy nature; / It is too full o' the milk o' human kindness.
Yet I doubt not through the ages one increasing purpose runs, / And the thoughts of men are widen'd by the process of the suns.
Yet I've heard say, by wise men in my day, / That none are outwitted so easy as they / Who reckon with all men as if they suspect them, / And traffic in caution, and watch to detect them.
Yet one thing secures us, whatever betide, / The Scripture assures us the Lord will provide.
Yet taught by Time, my heart has learned to glow / For other's good and melt at other's woe.
Yet there are surely times when there is nought / So needed as unsettling, just to get / Out of old ruts, and seek a nobler life.
Yet this grief / Is added to the griefs the great must bear, / That howsoever much they may desire / Silence, they cannot weep behind a cloud.
Yield not thy neck / To fortune's yoke, but let thy dauntless mind / Still ride in triumph over all mischance.
Yield not to temptation, for yielding is sin; /
Each victory will help you some other to win.
Yield to God's word and will, and you will escape many a calamity.
Yielding is sometimes the best way of succeeding.
Yielding, timid weakness is always abused and insulted by the unjust and unfeeling; but meekness, when sustained by the "fortiter in re," is always respected, commonly successful.
You accuse woman of wavering affection. Blame her not; she is but seeking a constant man.
You always aspire to very little at first, but
as you mount the ladder, you are sure to look down upon what you formerly looked up to as the height of happiness.
You always end ere you begin.
You are always willing enough to read lives, but never willing to lead them.
You are my true and honourable wife, / As dear to me as are the ruddy drops / That visit my sad heart.
You are not very good if you are not better than your best friends imagine you to be.
You are obliged to your imagination for three-fourths
of your importance.
You are prosperous, you are great, you are "beyond the world," as I have heard people say, meaning the power or the caprice thereof; but you are not beyond the power of events.
You are to come to your study as to the table, with a sharp appetite, whereby that which you read may the better digest. He that has no stomach to his book will very hardly thrive upon it.
You are transported by calamity / Thither where more attends you.
You arrive at truth through poetry, and I arrive at poetry through truth.
You beat your pate, and fancy wit will come; /
Knock as you please, there's nobody at home.
You begin in error when you suggest that we should regard the opinion of the many about just and unjust, good and evil, honourable and dishonourable.
You can easily ascertain
comes from the heart, for what comes from it in another's must go to your own.
You can imagine thistle-down so light that when you run after it your running motion would drive it away from you, and that the more you tried to catch it the faster it would fly from your grasp. And it should be with every man, that, when he is chased by troubles, they, chasing, shall raise him higher and higher.
You can never be wise unless you love reading.
You can never by persistency make wrong
right.
You can speak well, if your tongue deliver the message of your heart.
You canna expect to be baith grand and comfortable.
You cannot abolish slavery by Act of Parliament, but can only abolish the name of it, which is very little.
You cannot climb a ladder by pushing others down.
You cannot fathom your mind. There is a well
of thought there which has no bottom; the more you draw from it, the more clear and fruitful it will be.
You cannot get anything out of Nature or from God by gambling;--only out of your neighbour.
You cannot have the ware and the money both at once; and he who always hankers for the ware without having heart to give the money for it, is no better off than he who repents him of the purchase when the ware is in his hands.
You cannot have your work well done if the work be not of a right kind.
You cannot hide any secret.
You cannot lead a fighting world without
having it regimented, chivalried; nor can you any more continue to lead a working world unregimented, anarchic.
You cannot love the real sun, that is to say, physical light and colour, rightly, unless you love the spiritual sun, that is to say, justice and truth, rightly.
You cannot make a silk purse out of a sow's ear.
You cannot push a man far up a tree.
You cannot put a quartern loaf into a child's head; you must break it up, and give him the crumb in warm milk.
You cannot rear a temple like a hut of sticks
and turf.
You cannot save men from death but by facing it for them, nor from sin but by resisting it for them.
You cannot secure even enjoyment in stagnation.
You can't be lost on a straight road.
You can't "have" your pudding unless you can "eat" it.
You can't order remembrance out of a man's
mind.
You can't see the wood for the trees.
You can't tell a nut till you crack it.
You complain of the difficulty of finding work for your men; the real difficulty rather is to find men for your work.
You do not believe, you only believe that you believe.
You do not educate a man by telling him what he knew not, but by making him what he was not, and what he will remain for ever.
You don't value your peas for their roots or your carrots for their flowers. Now that's the way you should choose women.
You draw me, you hard-hearted adamant; / But yet you draw not iron, for my heart / Is true as steel; leave you your power to draw, / And I shall have no power to follow you.
You feel yourself an exile in the East; but in the West too it is exile; I know not where under the sun it is not exile.
You find faut wi' your meat, and the faut's
all i' your own stomach.
You find yourself refreshed by the presence of cheerful people. Why not make earnest effort to confer that pleasure on others? You will find half the battle is gained if you never allow yourself to say anything gloomy.
You frighten me out of my seven senses.
You gazed at the moon and fell in the gutter.
You give me nothing during your life, but you promise to provide for me at your death. If you are not a fool, you know what I wish for.
You have deserved / High commendation, true
applause and love.
You have many enemies that know not / Why they are so, but, like to village curs, / Bark when their fellows do.
You have no business with consequences; you are to tell the truth.
You have no hold on a human being whose affections are without a tap-root!
You have not outgrown, you cannot outgrow, the need of a great and authoritative teacher.
You have scotched the snake, not killed him.
You have too much respect upon the world; / They lose it that do buy it with much care.
You knock a man into the ditch, and then you tell him to remain content in the "position in which Providence has placed him."
You know how slight a line will tow a boat when afloat on the billows, though a cable would hardly move her when pulled up on the beach.
You know it is not my interest to pay the principal, nor is it my principle to pay the interest.
You know no rules of charity, / Which renders
good for bad, blessings for curses.
You know not where a blessing may light.
You know that in everything women write there are always a thousand faults of grammar, but, with your permission, a harmony which is rare in the writings of men.
You lie nearest to the river of life when you bend to it. You cannot drink but as you stoop.
You live one half year with deception and art; / With art and deception you live t'other part.
You make but a poor trap to catch luck if you
go and bait it with wickedness.
You may as soon separate weight from lead, heat from fire, moistness from water, and brightness from the sun, as misery, discontent, calamity, and danger from man.
You may as well ask a loom which weaves huckaback why it does not make cashmere, as expect poetry from this engineer, or a chemical discovery from that jobber.
You may depend upon it, religion is, in its essence, the most gentlemanly thing in the world. It will alone gentilise, if unmixed with cant; and I know nothing else that will, alone; certainly not the army, which is thought to be the grand embellisher of manners.
You may depend upon it that he is a good man whose intimate friends are all good.
(You may) dig the deep foundations of a long-abiding
fame, / And wist not that they undermine (your) home of love and peace.
You may do anything with bayonets except sit on them.
You may fail to shine, in the opinion of others, both in your conversation and actions, from being superior as well as inferior to them.
You may grow good corn in a little field.
You may have to wait a bit--some of you a shorter, some a longer time; but do wait, and everything will fit in and be perfect at last.
You may imitate, but never counterfeit.
You may know a wise man by his election of an aim, and a sagacious by his election of the means.
You may overthrow a government in the twinkling of an eye, as you can blow up a ship or upset and sink one; but you can no more create a government with a word than an iron-clad.
You may paint with a very big brush, and yet not be a great painter.
You may rest upon this as an unfailing truth, that there neither is, nor ever was, any person remarkably ungrateful who was not also insufferably proud; nor any one proud who was not equally ungrateful.
You may ride 's / With one soft kiss a thousand
furlongs ere / With spur we heat an acre.
You may say, "I wish to send this ball so as to kill the lion crouching yonder ready to spring upon me. My wishes are all right, and I hope Providence will direct the ball." Providence won't. You must do it; and if you do not, you are a dead man.
You might as well ask an oyster to make progress, as the people of any country in which grumbling could by any possibility be prohibited.
You must be content sometimes with rough roads.
"You must be in the fashion," is the utterance of weak-headed mortals.
You must begin at a low round of the ladder if you mean to get on.
You must confine yourself within the modest limits of order.
You must educate for education's sake only.
You must empty out the bathing-tub, but not
the baby along with it.
You must either be directed by some that take upon them to know, or take upon yourself that which I am sure you do not know, or jump the after-inquiry on your own peril.
You must get your living by loving, else your life is at least half a failure.
You must live for another if you wish to live for yourself.
You must live the life.
You must lose a fly to catch a trout.
You must not equivocate, nor speak anything positively for which you have no authority but report, or conjecture, or opinion.
You must not fear death, my lads; defy him, and you drive him into the enemy's ranks.
You must not fight too often with one enemy, or you will teach him all your art of war.
You must not measure every man's corn by your own bushel.
You must not suppose that everything goes
right at first even with the best of us.
You must not think / That we are made of stuff so flat and dull, / That we can let our beard be shook with danger, / And think it pastime.
You must rouse in men a consciousness of their own prudence and strength, if you would raise their character.
You must seek and find God in the heart.
You need not tell all the truth, unless to those who have a right to know it all. But let all you tell be truth.
You never can elude the gods when you even
devise wrong.
You never long the greatest man to be; / No! all you say is; "I'm as good as he." / He's the most envious man beneath the sun / Who thinks that he's as good as every one.
You never will love art well till you love what she mirrors better.
You often understand the true connection of important events in your life not while they are going on, nor soon after they are past, but only a considerable time afterwards.
You ought to read books, as you take medicine, by advice, and not advertisement.
You rub the sore, when you should bring the
plaster.
You said your say; / Mine answer was my deed.
You see when they row in a barge, they that do drudgery work, slash, and puff, and sweat; but he that governs sits quietly at the stern, and scarce is seen to stir.
You shall never take a woman without her answer, unless you take her without her tongue.
 (as Carl
You shall not shirk the hobbling Times to catch a ride on the sure-footed Eternities. well, you are there to make them better."
You take my house, when you do take the
prop / That doth sustain my house; you take my life / When you do take the means whereby I live.
You that choose not by the view, / Choose as fair, and choose as true.
You traverse the world in search of happiness, which is within the reach of every man; a contented mind confers it on all.
You watch figures in the fields, digging and delving with spade or pick. You see one of them from time to time straightening his loins, and wiping his face with the back of his hand.... It is there that for me you must seek true humanity and great poetry.
You were used / To say, extremity was the trier of spirits; / That common chances common men could bear; / That when the sea was calm, all boats alike / Showed mastership in floating.
You who are ashamed of your poverty, and
blush for your calling, are a snob; as are you who boast of your pedigree, or are proud of your wealth.
You who follow wealth and power with unremitting ardour, / The more in this you look for bliss, you leave your view the farther.
You who forget your friends, meanly to follow after those of a higher degree, are a snob.
You will as often find a great man above, as below, his reputation, when once you come to know him.
You will catch more flies with a spoonful of honey than with a cask of vinegar.
You will find angling to be like the virtue of
humility, which has a calmness of spirit and a world of other blessings attending upon it.
You will find rest unto your souls when first you take on you the yoke of Christ, but joy only when you have borne it as long as He wills.
You will find that most books worth reading once are worth reading twice.
You will find that silence, or very gentle words, are the most exquisite revenge for reproaches.
You will get more profit from trying to find where beauty is, than in anxiously inquiring what it is. Once for all, it remains undemonstrable; it appears to us, as in a dream, when we behold the works of the great poets and painters; and in short, of all feeling artists; it is a hovering, shining, shadowy form, the outline of which no definition holds.
You will never live to my age, without you keep yourselves in breath with exercise, and in heart with joyfulness.
You will never miss the right way if you only act according to your feelings and conscience.
You will never see anything worse than yourselves.
You wise, / To call him shamed, who is but overthrown?
You wish, O woman, to be ardently loved, and
for ever, even until death, be thou the mother of your children.
You write with ease to show your breeding, / But easy writing's cursed hard reading.
You'll repent if you marry, and you'll repent if you don't.
Young authors give their brains much exercise and little food.
Young Christians think themselves little; growing Christians think themselves nothing; full-grown Christians think themselves less than nothing.
Young folk, silly folk; old folk, cold folk.
Young hot colts, being raged, do rage the more.
Young men are apt to think themselves wise enough, as drunken men are to think themselves sober enough.
Young men are fitter to invent than to judge; fitter for execution than for counsel; and fitter for new projects than for settled business.
Young men soon give, and soon forget affronts; old age is slow in both.
Young men think that old men are fools; but
old men know young men are fools.
Young people are quick enough to observe and imitate.
Your acts are detectives, keener and more unerring than ever the hand of sensational novelist depicted; they will dog you from the day you sinned till the hour your trial comes off.
Your born angler is like a hound that scents no game but that which he is in pursuit of.
Your cause belongs / To him who can avenge your wrongs.
Your goodness must have some edge to it,
else it is none.
Your hands in your own pockets in the morning, is the beginning of the last day; your hands in other people's pockets at noon, is the height of the last day.
Your "if" is the only peacemaker; much virtue in "if."
Your labour only may be sold; your soul must not.
Your learning, like the lunar beam, affords light but not heat.
Your levellers wish to level down as far as
themselves; but they cannot bear levelling up to themselves.
Your noblest natures are most credulous.
Your own soul is the thing you ought to look after.
Your own words and actions are the only things you will be called to account for.
Your prime one need is to do right, under whatever compulsion, till you can do it without compulsion. And then you are a Man.
Your tongue runs before your wit.
Your rusty kettle will continue to boil your water for you if you don't try to mend it. Begin tinkering and there is an end of your kettle.
Your voiceless lips, O flowers, are living preachers,--each cup a pulpit, and each leaf a book.
Your words are like notes of dying swans--/ Too sweet to last.
You're always sure to detect / A sham in the things folks most affect.
Yours is a pauper's soul, a rich man's pelf: /
Rich to your heirs, a pauper to yourself.
Youth, abundant wealth, high birth, and inexperience, are, each of them, the source of ruin. What then must be the fate of him in whom all four are combined?
Youth beholds happiness gleaming in the prospect. Age looks back on the happiness of youth, and, instead of hopes, seeks its enjoyment in the recollection of hope.
Youth, enthusiasm, and tenderness are like the days of spring. Instead of complaining, O my heart, of their brief duration, try to enjoy them.
Youth ever thinks that good whose goodness or evil he sees not.
Youth fades; love droops; the leaves of friendship
fall; a mother's secret hope outlives them all!
Youth holds no society with grief.
Youth is a blunder; manhood, a struggle; old age, a regret.
Youth is ever apt to judge in haste, and lose the medium in the wild extreme.
Youth is ever confiding; and we can almost forgive its disinclination to follow the counsels of age, for the sake of the generous disdain with which it rejects suspicion.
Youth is full of sport, age's breath is short; /
Youth is nimble, age is lame: / Youth is hot and bold, age is weak and cold; / Youth is wild, and age is tame.
Youth is not rich in time; it may be, poor; part with it, as with money, sparing; pay no moment but in purchase of its worth; and what its worth ask death-beds, they can tell.
Youth is not the age of pleasure; we then expect too much, and we are therefore exposed to daily disappointments and mortifications. When we are a little older, and have brought down our wishes to our experience, then we become calm and begin to enjoy ourselves.
Youth is the season of credulity.
Youth is too tumultuous for felicity; old age too insecure for happiness. The period most favourable to enjoyment, in a vigorous, fortunate, and generous life, is that between forty and sixty. Life culminates at sixty.
Youth may make / Even with the year; but age, if it will hit, / Shoots a bow short, and lessens still his stake, / As the day lessens, and his life with it.
Youth never yet lost its modesty where age had not lost its honour; nor did childhood ever refuse its reverence, except where age had forgotten correction.
Youth no less becomes / The light and careless livery that it wears, / Than settled age his sables and his weeds, / Importing health and graveness.
Youth should be a savings-bank.
Youth to itself rebels, though none else near.
Youth would rather be stimulated than instructed.
Youth, when thought is speech and speech is truth.
Youth will never live to age, without they keep themselves in breath with exercise, and in heart with joyfulness. Too much thinking doth consume the spirits; and oft it falls out, that while one thinks too much of doing, he leaves to do the effect of his thinking.
Youthful failing is not to be admired except in so far as one may hope that it will not be the failing of old age.
Zahltag kommt alle Tag
Zankt, wenn ihr sitzt beim Weine, / Nicht um Kaisers Bart
Zeal ever follows an appearance of truth, and the assured are too apt to be warm; but it is their weak side in argument, zeal being better shown against sin than persons, or their mistakes.
Zeal for uniformity attests the latent distrusts, not the firm convictions, of the zealot. In proportion to the strength of our self-reliance is our indifference to the multiplication of suffrages in favour of our own judgment.
Zeal is fit for wise men, but flourishes chiefly among fools.
Zeal is like fire; it needs both feeding and
watching.
Zeal is no further commendable than as it is attended with knowledge.
Zeal is very blind or badly regulated when it encroaches upon the rights of others.
Zeal without knowledge is a runaway horse.
Zeal without knowledge is like expedition to a man in the dark.
Zeit ist's, die Unfälle zu beweinen, / Wenn sie
nahen und wirklich erscheinen
Zeit verdeckt und entdeckt
Zeitungsschreiber: ein Mensch, der seinen Beruf verfehlt hat
Zerstreuung ist wie eine goldene Wolke, die den Menschen, / Wär es auch nur auf kurze Zeit, seinem Elend entrückt
Zerstörend ist des Lebens Lauf, / Stets frisst ein Thier das andre auf
Zerstreutes Wesen führt uns nicht zum Ziel
Zeus hates busybodies and those who do too much.
Zielen ist nicht genug; es gilt Treffen
Zonam perdidit
Zu leben weiss ich, mich zu kennen weiss ich nicht
Zu Rom bestehen die 10 Gebote aus den 10
Buchstaben
Zu schwer bezahlt man oft ein leicht Versehn
Zu viel Demuth ist Hochmuth
Zu viel Glück ist Unglück
Zu viel Weisheit ist Narrheit
Zu viel Wissbegierde ist ein Fehler, und aus
einem Fehler können alle Laster entspringen, wenn man ihm zu sehr nachhängt
Zufrieden sein, das ist mein Spruch
Zum Kriegführen sind dreierlei Dinge nötig--Geld! Geld! Geld!
Zum Leiden bin ich auserkoren
Zur Tugend der Ahnen / Ermannt sich der Held
Zwar eine schöne Tugend ist die Treue, / Doch
schöner ist Gerechtigkeit
Zwar nicht wissen--aber glauben / Heisst ganz richtig--Aberglauben
Zwar sind sie an das Beste nicht gewöhnt, / Allein sie haben schrecklich viel gelesen
Zwar weiss ich viel, doch möcht' ich alles wissen
Zwei Fliegen mit einer Klappe schlagen
Zwei gute Tage hat der Mensch auf Erden; / Den Hochzeitstag und das Begrabenwerden
Zwei Seelen und ein Gedanke, / Zwei Herzen und ein Schlag
Zwei Seelen wohnen, ach! in meiner Brust, /
Die eine will sich von der andern trennen
Zwei sind der Wege, auf welchen der Mensch zur Tugend emporstrebt, / Schliesst sich der eine dir zu, thut sich der andre dir auf, / Handelnd erreicht der Glückliche sie, der Leidende duldend; / Wohl ihm, den sein Geschick liebend auf beiden geführt
Zweierlei Arten giebt es, die treffende Wahrheit zu sagen; / Oeffentlich immer dem Volk, immer dem Fürsten geheim
Zwischen Amboss und Hammer
Zwischen heut' und morgen sind Grüfte, zwischen Versprechen und Erfüllen Klüfte
Zwischen Lipp' und Kelchesrand / Schwebt
der dunkeln Mächte Hand
Zwischen uns sei Wahrheit
